title: Temple of Literature - Imperial Academy
description: The Temple of Literature was built in 1070 under King Ly Thanh Tong to honor Confucian saints and scholars.|||It also served as a royal school, with the first student being Prince Ly Can Duc, the king's son. In 1076, King Ly Nhan Tong established the Imperial Academy next to the Temple of Literature as a school for the king's children and high-ranking nobles.|||In 1253, King Tran Thai Tong renamed it the National Academy, expanding it to accept talented students from common families.|||The famous teacher Chu Van An was appointed as the head of the Imperial Academy and tutor to the royal princes during the reign of King Tran Minh Tong.|||After his death in 1370, King Tran Nghe Tong had him honored at the Temple of Literature alongside Confucius.|||In 1785, King Le Hien Tong renamed the Imperial Academy the Royal School.|||At the beginning of the Nguyen dynasty, the Imperial Academy was relocated to Hue, and the Royal School was renamed the Khai Thanh School.|||From the outside, the entire Van Mieu - Quoc Tu Giam complex is surrounded on all four sides by a wall built with large stone bricks - a common architectural material during the Late Le dynasty, creating a vintage, solemn, and nostalgic space.|||Inside the wall, the ancient architectural roofs are hidden under the lush canopies of old trees, making this place have a completely different scenery compared to the outside, creating a special attraction for visitors.|||In front of Van Mieu, on the other side of Quoc Tu Giam street, there is a quite large lake called Ho Van. Previously, in the middle of the lake, there was Kim Chau hill, on which a pavilion - Phan Thuy dinh was built, where scholars would gather to critique poetry. Nowadays, the pavilion no longer exists, but on the hill, there is still a stele from year 18 of Tu Duc reign (1865) documenting the restoration of Van Mieu.|||Located in a large area, the inner sanctum of Van Mieu - Quoc Tu Giam is divided into 5 sections, separated by ancient brick walls.|||The first area starts from Van Mieu Mon to Dai Trung Mon. Before entering Van Mieu Mon, visitors will have to go through the outer Nghi Mon gate consisting of 4 large pillars built of bricks, in which the two middle pillars are built higher, on top of the pillars are placed two nghê statues; the two outer pillars are lower, on top of the pillars are decorated with phoenix shapes, tails gathered together, 4 heads facing 4 directions. The body of the pillar is decorated with pairs of Chinese couplets. On either side of the Nghi Mon gate are 2 "Ha Ma" (dismount) steles.|||Through the outer gate, visitors go straight to the inner gate of Van Mieu, comprising three arched doors, with the central door built in two stories. The lower story is designed large and wide, with a staircase leading up. The exterior of the lower story has only one arched door, made of two wooden wings, with a semicircular door frame carved with a pair of dragons. The upper story is smaller, designed like a two-story gate with 8 roofs, including 4 eaves and 4 roof tops. This story has three arched doors, with a bronze bell hung at the central door, and a wide corridor with balustrades on all four sides.|||From Van Mieu Mon, along the straight brick path, visitors will reach the second gate, Dai Trung Mon, consisting of 3 rooms on a high brick foundation, tiled roof, three rows of pillars, with two small doors on either side, Thanh Duc Mon and Dai Tai Mon. The horizontal wall connecting the three gates of Dai Trung Mon extends to both sides, reaching the outer enclosing wall. Along with the horizontal wall at Van Mieu Mon, it forms a square frame, inside which are many trees and shaded areas, creating a serene and peaceful atmosphere for visitors to stroll through the solemn and quiet surroundings.|||The brick-paved path from Van Mieu gate will continue to take visitors to the second area, from Dai Trung gate to Khuê Văn Các. Built in 1805, Khuê Văn Các is a square tower with 2 floors, 8 roofs. The lower floor is supported by 4 brick pillars, with 4 empty sides. The upper floor has a wooden structure, tiled roof, 4 wooden boarded sides, each side has a round window, with ornamental details representing the rays of the Khuê star shining in the sky. On either side of Khuê Văn Các are Bi văn and Súc văn gates – names that praise the beauty and value of literature. Khuê Văn Các is considered a unique architectural work, a symbol of Vietnamese culture and literature.|||As visitors pass through Khue Van Cac, they arrive at the third area within the Van Mieu - Quoc Tu Giam complex, which features the Thien Quang well and the system of Doctoral Steles. Thien Quang Well (Thien Quang Tinh), also known as Van Tri (Literature Pond), is square-shaped and filled with water all year round. The calm water surface acts as a mirror reflecting the images of Khue Van pavilion and ancient trees, creating a mystical and enchanting scenery.|||The ancients believed that the square well symbolized the earth, while the round door of Khue Van pavilion represented the sky. The essence of both heaven and earth is concentrated in this sacred cultural and educational center located in the heart of the capital city.|||The brick-paved path around Thien Quang Well leads visitors to the Stele of Doctors on both sides of the well. This is considered an important historical site within the Temple of Literature - Quoc Tu Giam complex, featuring 82 stone steles with inscriptions honoring Vietnamese scholars from the Le and Mac dynasties (1442-1779). All steles share a similar design: flat, curved top, and arched shape. They are placed on the backs of turtles to symbolize the enduring essence of the nation. These steles reflect the cultural and historical values of Vietnam over 300 years. They provide a valuable source of historical documents for future generations to study the lives and careers of Vietnam's renowned scholars.|||With its outstanding and rare values, in 2010, the 82 stone steles of doctoral degrees from the Le and Mac dynasties at Van Mieu - Quoc Tu Giam were recognized as a World Documentary Heritage under UNESCO's Memory of the World Program.|||After visiting the stone tablets of doctoral scholars, through Dai Thanh gate, visitors will come to a large brick-paved yard, marking the beginning of the fourth and main area of Van Mieu - Quoc Tu Giam. On either side of the yard are two rows of houses, Ta Vu and Huu Vu, each with 9 rooms, built on an elevated foundation, with tiled roofs and decorative trim, using the 'chong ruong' frame structure.|||The Great Bai Hall, connecting with the gables of the two rows of houses, Tả vu and Hữu vu, forms a traditional U-shaped structure. This is where the king, royal family, and officials would come to worship Confucius during the spring and autumn seasons.|||The Great Bai Hall consists of 9 rooms with 6 rows of pillars, built on a foundation 30cm higher than the courtyard, surrounded by brick edging. The roof is tiled with curved eaves.|||The architectural structure is of the type 'chồng rường, cốn kẻ chồng, bẩy hiên', with a pair of dragons adorning the roof and decorative floral patterns on the pillars.|||Currently, only the central room has an incense altar, while the other rooms are empty.|||The walls around the worship room are adorned with many couplets and plaques praising Confucianism and wise philosophers.|||Alongside the Dai Bai hall at the back is the Dai Thanh temple with 9 compartments, built with walls on 3 sides. The front has a closed wooden door covering 5 compartments. The 4 end compartments have fixed ventilated windows. The central compartment of the temple houses a large altar and throne for worshiping Confucius.|||The fifth area in the complex of Van Mieu - Quoc Tu Giam is the Thai Hoc house, formerly the Quoc Tu Giam, where talented people were trained for dynasties. After going through time and historical events, the old building was destroyed. In 1999, the Thai Hoc house was rebuilt on a large architectural scale and harmoniously integrated with the landscape of the Van Mieu area. The Thai Hoc house has a continuous structure, tiled roof, and support beams in the style of "stacked frames, stacked columns, and seven- beam brackets". The floor is paved with Bat Trang bricks.|||The back worship hall is built with a stacked roof, tiled roof, and beam structure in the "stacked frame and chieng beam" style.|||The final architectural area is the Tien Duong and Hau Duong, rebuilt in 1999. Tien Duong has 9 compartments with 40 teak pillars supporting the roof, and gable ends built with brick walls. This is currently a place to display documents showcasing the tradition of love for learning and respect for teachers of Vietnamese generations. Tien Duong connects to Hau Duong through a covered walkway, with two doors leading to the bell house and empty house. Hau Duong is a two-story wooden structure, with the first floor having 9 compartments, 2 chaises with 72 teak pillars, honoring famous educator Chu Van An – a world cultural celebrity and Vietnam's great teacher, and displaying documents about Van Mieu – Quoc Tu Giam and Vietnam's Confucian education. The second floor is dedicated to the kings who built Van Mieu - Quoc Tu Giam and contributed to the Confucian education cause, namely King Ly Thanh Tong, Ly Nhan Tong, and Le Thanh Tong.|||Today, Van Mieu - Quoc Tu Giam is still a venue for notable cultural events such as scientific workshops, thematic exhibitions; honoring outstanding graduates from universities and institutes in Hanoi; awarding certificates of Professorship and Associate Professorship; and annually organizing the Book Fair, Vietnamese Poetry Day…

title: Tra Su Melaleuca Forest
description: Location: Van Giao commune, Tinh Bien district, An Giang province, about 20km from Chau Doc city and 10km from the Vietnam - Cambodia border.|||Characteristics: This is a typical flooded forest in the western area of Hau River, home to many waterbirds, wild animals and aquatic life, belonging to the special-use forest system in Vietnam.|||From Chau Doc city, turn left and travel about 17km to Nha Bang town in Tinh Bien district. From here, follow provincial road 948 to Km 6, then turn left onto a small road about 4km long to Tra Su Cajuput forest.|||At the reception station, visitors can rent bicycles to explore the Melaleuca forest. The path is about 5-6km long. Above is the green canopy of Melaleuca trees, and below is the waterway where the sound of fish splashing can be heard. When reaching the long canal with cool water and the distant Melaleuca forest, visitors will have to switch to small boats to navigate through the streams and explore the forest. Sitting on the boat, gently paddling through the water, and watching dozens of birds singing on the Melaleuca trees, visitors will feel like they are in a fairyland.|||Visitors to Tra Su Melaleuca forest are increasingly amazed and delighted as they discover the wonders of nature preserved in the forest's leaves and the fragrance of Melaleuca. Spanning nearly 850ha, Tra Su forest is home to 70 bird species from 13 orders and 31 families, including two rare species listed in Vietnam's Red Book: Mycteria leucocephala and Anhinga melanogaster. For mammals, 11 species from 4 orders and 6 families have been recorded, with bats (15 species) and rodents (4 species) being the most diverse, including the rare short-eared bat listed in Vietnam's Red Book. Additionally, there are 25 species of reptiles, frogs, and toads from 2 orders and 10 families, including cobras and kraits. The forest is also home to 10 fish species present year-round and 13 species that appear during the flood season, including two species of scientific value and at risk of extinction: cá còm and cá trê trắng. Tra Su is not only rich in fauna but also hosts 140 plant species from 52 families and 102 genera, including 22 tree species, 25 shrub species, 10 climber species, 70 grass species, 13 aquatic plants, 11 epiphytes, 78 medicinal plants, and 22 ornamental plants.|||The diverse flora and fauna make Tra Su Melaleuca forest an ideal destination for researchers and nature enthusiasts. The flood season is the best time to visit the forest. Visitors traveling by boat can admire the vast green forest, with white melaleuca flowers blooming in the morning sun, and the gentle scent of melaleuca. The scenery includes water lily, hydrilla, and numerous aquatic species swaying in the clear water. While taking in the beauty, visitors can pick water spinach, water cabbage, and other plants before exploring deeper into the forest to discover the world of various bird species.|||Tra Su forest is lively at a certain time every day. When the sunlight fades, leaving only golden threads peeking through the trees, the birds start flying back to their nests. Flocks of birds appear, filling the forest with natural activities, seemingly unaware of human presence. White storks hide behind curved branches; herons and cormorants peck at each other behind melaleuca trees; warblers and ducks fly around the forest and land gently on melaleuca trunks; large flying foxes weighing 3kg with 1m wingspans hang from branches. Each species has different shapes and colors: white, black, green, spotted, and striped.|||In nests on high branches, visitors can see young birds chirping, waiting for their mothers to feed them, or pairs of birds tenderly grooming each other. The constant chirping creates a harmonious melody, making distant visitors feel connected to the natural scenery. Additionally, visitors can climb a 14m watchtower in the forest, using binoculars to observe, and if lucky, see tens of thousands of white storks flying back to their nests like a giant white cloth covering the green forest.|||As the afternoon wears on, the atmosphere becomes increasingly vast and serene. At the huts on the edge of the forest, visitors can enjoy specialty dishes from the Mekong Delta region, such as grilled fish, steamed fish with gourd, grilled chicken with chili salt, and crab with sour tamarind sauce. They can also let their spirits soar to the sweet sounds of traditional Vietnamese opera sung by local women. The atmosphere here, from the sounds, sunlight to the rustic garden cuisine, all have a unique flavor that is hard to find elsewhere.|||In addition to its rich natural resources, Tra Su Melaleuca forest contains unique cultural elements of the community living near the forest. Around Tra Su, there are many Khmer and Kinh people living with traditional handicrafts such as weaving, making palm sugar, distilling Melaleuca oil, beekeeping...|||was removed as there was no|||in the original text, the sentence was broken into shorter clear English sentences.|||Come to Tra Su Melaleuca forest to explore the wilderness, live in harmony with nature and temporarily forget the worries of life.|||Tra Su is a strange yet familiar land, because the people here are always friendly and hospitable, giving visitors a feeling like they're strolling in their own space.

title: Ba Chua Xu Temple Festival
description: Time: from April 23rd to 27th in lunar calendar.|||Location: Ba Chua Xu Temple, Sam Mountain, 5km from Chau Doc city.|||Object of worship: Ba Chua Xu.|||Characteristics: ritual bathing of the goddess.|||Ba Chua Xu Temple is located at the foot of Sam Mountain, previously in Vinh Te commune, now in Nui Sam ward, Chau Doc city, An Giang province. Ba Chua Xu Festival (also known as Via Ba) is held annually from the 23rd to the 27th of the 4th lunar month.|||Pilgrims can travel by road from Long Xuyen to Chau Doc via provincial road 10, then turn in and travel 7km to reach Sam Mountain; or travel by waterway from Can Tho, Soc Trang or from Sai Gon.|||The ceremonial part of Via Ba includes five rituals: Bathing ceremony, inviting Thoai Ngoc Hau's spirit to Ba Temple, Tu Yết ceremony, presenting offerings, and the main ceremony.|||The Ceremony of Bathing the Goddess. This ceremony takes place at midnight on the 23rd, transitioning into the 24th. Although called bathing the goddess, it's actually about cleaning the dust off the statue and changing her clothes. The water used is scented. The old clothes are cut into small pieces and distributed to pilgrims as talismans believed to bring health and ward off evil spirits. The ceremony lasts about an hour, followed by free time for worship.|||Ceremony to invite the spiritual tablet of Thoai Ngoc Hau to Mieu Ba: This ceremony takes place at 3 pm on the 24th. The village elders and the management board of the temple, dressed in formal attire, go to the tomb of Thoai Ngoc Hau, located opposite Mieu Ba, to make the invitation. They bring the spiritual tablets of Ngoc Hau Nguyen Van Thoai, his wife Truong Thi Miet, and the council members. Upon arrival at Mieu Ba, the tablets are placed in the main altar. The management board then offers incense and the ceremony concludes. The tradition of inviting the spiritual tablet of Thoai Ngoc Hau has been around for a long time to show appreciation for his contributions to the opening up of this previously desolate land.|||Tuc Yiet Ceremony: The ceremony is held at 0:00 on the 25th, just before the 26th. All the elderly men in the village and the management board of the temple are dressed in ceremonial attire, standing in two lines on either side of the statue. The offerings include: a white pig (uncleaned and uncooked), a dish of blood with some pig hair, a tray of steamed rice, a tray of fruit, a tray of betel and areca nuts, and a dish of salt and rice. The chief officiant performs the ritual, offering incense, wine, tea, and then burns some gold and silver paper.|||Ceremony to start the performance: After the initial offering is the ceremony to start the performance. The chief ritualist steps to the altar in the middle of the stage, holding drumsticks raised to his forehead to pray. On the left side of the altar, there is a bowl of water and a sprig of olive branch. The chief ritualist dips the branch into the water and sprinkles it around while reading out prayers. After finishing, he puts the bowl and branch back on the altar, beats the drum three times, and says "ca cong tiep gia". Immediately, the singing group starts with gongs and drums, and the performance begins. The following traditional plays are often performed at Mieu Ba: Tran Binh Trong, Sat That, Luu Kim Dinh, Trung Nu Vuong, etc.|||Chinh Tế Ceremony: At 4 am on the 26th, the Chinh Tế ceremony takes place (similar to the "túc yết" ritual).|||On the afternoon of the 27th, the Thoai Ngoc Hau's royal edict is brought to Son Lang.|||The festival part took place very lively, interspersed with the ceremony, folk cultural and artistic activities were performed such as lion dance, múa mâm thao, múa đĩa chén... attracting many tourists.|||Ba Chua Xu festival on Sam Mountain is a festival with a strong national identity, containing many local colors of the Southern region.|||The festival is a folk cultural event that meets the cultural and social needs, and spiritual life of local residents, while attracting a large number of visitors and pilgrims.

title: Cam Mountain
description: Location: Cam Mountain is located in the That Son cluster in the Mekong Delta, in An Hao commune, Tinh Bien district, An Giang province.|||Features: The largest Di Lac Buddha statue in Vietnam; Van Linh pagoda with a grand and sacred stupa.|||Nui Cam is also known as Thien Cam Son, considered a picturesque destination, located about 90 km from Long Xuyen city center via National Highway 91 and then Provincial Road 948, and approximately 37 km from Chau Doc town. The mountain stands at 705m with a perimeter of 28,600m and an average temperature of 25°C, ideal for sightseeing and exploration. From the mountain peaks, visitors can see vast rice fields stretching to Ha Tien sea and the southwest border.|||There are many anecdotes to explain the name of Cam Mountain. Cam Mountain or Cam Son is the official name first appearing in Dai Nam nhat thong chi compiled in the late 19th century. The book describes that: "...the mountain is very high, trees are lush, it is one of seven mountains. Because it's high, few people reach the top".|||According to Gia Dinh thanh thong chi by Trinh Hoai Duc, the mountain was called Doai Ton mountain, and the author said it was 50 zhang high, 20 miles in circumference, shaped like a high terrace, naturally located in the Chen Si direction, hence the name Dai Ton mountain... It's also called Thien Cam Son because besides famous landscapes, Cam Mountain has attractive natural scenery, with flowers and trees all year round, creating a "Carm tu son ki" picture, famous for many peaks of different heights called "vo", each with a legend and many interesting meanings such as Thien Tue vo, Bo Hong vo, Ong But vo, Dau vo, Ba vo...|||These are five "vo" or five mountains that pilgrims often visit to worship.|||Not having the majestic and majestic appearance like the mountain ranges in Truong Son - Tay Nguyen, Cam Mountain in An Giang has a wild, mysterious beauty, is a treasure that nature has bestowed upon the southwestern region of Vietnam. Right at the foot of the mountain, there is a Son Than temple where everyone stops to light incense.|||Climbing up the mountain road with dense forests, visitors will see a beautiful scenery: a waterfall cascading down the rocks, the sound of the waterfall echoing in the mountain wind, sometimes far, sometimes near; beautiful stalactites in Thuy Liem cave…|||The journey continues to Phat Lon Temple. The temple is located in a serene atmosphere, surrounded by ancient banyan trees over a century old.|||Nearby is a 33.6m high Maitreya Buddha statue. This is the largest religious architectural work to date in the Bay Nui region. What's fascinating is that visitors standing anywhere on the hills can see the bright white Buddha statue, sitting majestically in a lush green space with a smile of tolerance and kindness.|||About 100 meters away is Van Linh pagoda with three stupa in front of the hall, 40m high, consisting of 9 floors, each floor displaying a Buddha riding a fierce animal over 2m high made of Thanh Hoa stone, extremely sophisticatedly carved, creating a solemn and serene landscape.|||In addition, along the trails from the foot to the top of the mountain, visitors can explore many other attractions such as: Thanh Long stream, Tiên stream, Cay Que shrine, Mười Ba shrine, Tam Thanh shrine, Huỳnh Long shrine, Ong The cave, Ong Ho cave, Bac Vat Lang cave, Thuy Liem grotto... each place has a fascinating legend and a mystical atmosphere full of religious colors.|||At the foot of Cam mountain, to the east lies Lam Vien tourist area, covering around 100 ha, with beautiful scenery. A wide concrete road leads to the top, and a Cam mountain cable car has been in operation since February 14, 2015.|||Visiting Cam Mountain, An Giang, besides enjoying the majestic scenery, experiencing activities like hiking, exploring caves, and bathing in streams... visitors should not miss the opportunity to taste local specialties like mountain snails, various types of mountain mangoes, jackfruits, bananas, durians, avocados, and mountain custard apples...|||Nui Cam is now a popular pilgrimage site for visitors within and outside the province, and is a major tourist attraction in An Giang province. It is estimated that Nui Cam welcomes over 1.2 million visitors each year, with the peak season being during the spring festival from January to June in the lunar calendar.

title: Tho Ha Communal House
description: Location: Tho Ha village, Van Ha commune, Viet Yen district, Bac Giang province. Features: The communal house worships Thai Thuong Lao Quan as the tutelary deity.|||Legend has it that Thai Thuong Lao Quan, originally named Ly Dam, was from the North and lived during the reign of King An Duong Vuong. For his contributions to eliminating the Xich Quy enemy and establishing a school in Tho Ha village, he was promoted to the rank of Upper Level God and tutelary deity by successive feudal dynasties, who allowed the villagers to build a communal house in his honor.|||The main communal house is 27m long and 16m wide, consisting of 5 bays and 2 wings, supported by 48 columns. The roof is tiled with curved ngói mũi hài, adorned with dragon, phoenix, and nghê figurines.|||The communal house was initially built in 1686, covering an area of 3,000m², in the shape of the character 'Cong'. In front of the communal house lies the poetic Cau River; surrounding it are ancient trees with lush foliage. After several renovations, the current architecture includes the Tiền tế, Đại đình, and Hậu cung.|||The Hậu cung has 3 bays, built in the 'tường hồi bít đốc' style, with a 'long đình' ridge. This architectural style is characteristic of the late 19th century.|||On January 13, 1964, Tho Ha communal house was recognized as a national-level cultural and artistic relic by the Ministry of Culture, Sports, and Tourism. The relic preserves several valuable artifacts, including couplets, stele inscriptions, and 'sao chép lại các đạo sắc phong' (copies of royal edicts) honoring the tutelary deity.

title: Vinh Nghiem Pagoda
description: Location: Situated in Quoc Khanh village, Tri Yen commune, Yen Dung district, Bac Giang province.|||Characteristics: Vinh Nghiem Pagoda is one of the most important sacred sites of Buddhism in Vietnam, especially for the Truc Lam Yen Tu Buddhist sect. It is considered the first Buddhist university in Vietnam.|||Thac Ba Lake is a cultural and historical site.|||Vinh Nghiem Pagoda (also known as Chuc Thanh Pagoda) is surrounded by beautiful natural scenery.|||It is recorded in ancient texts as one of the most famous pagodas. A stone stele erected on September 4, 1606 describes the scenery: "Vinh Nghiem Pagoda is a famous site. To the right is Xương Giang, Đức Giang, and Lục đầu giang."|||Behind it lies Phuong Son, Lang Son, Hinh Son, and Qua Son mountains in layers.|||The scenery here is as breathtaking as Buddha's paradise. Inside the pagoda, a golden Buddha sits on a lotus throne, with a heavenly maiden offering tea above. The landscape is truly miraculous. The pagoda looks out onto Phuong Nhac junction, where the Thuong and Luc Nam rivers meet, in Cam Ly - the gateway to Yen Tu mountain. Across the river lies the former palace of Tran Hung Dao and Kiep Bac Temple.|||Holding an important spiritual geographic position, over the decades, this place has become an ideal stop for tourists before crossing the river and climbing to the capital of the sacred land of Yen Tu. The folk still recite the verse:|||Anyone passing through Yen Tu, Quinh Lam|||Vinh Nghiem hasn't reached a meditative state yet.|||Built in the 11th century under King Ly Thai To (1010-1028), the pagoda was originally named Chuc Thanh Pagoda.|||According to the stele inscription, in 1010, King Ly Thai To commissioned two officials, Nguyen Dao Thanh and Pham Hat, to design and oversee the construction of 8 pagodas, including Vinh Nghiem Pagoda.|||Completed in 1016, the first abbot was Zen Master Van Hanh, followed by Dao An, Minh Tam, Bao Tanh, and Hue Quang.|||In the 13th century, King Tran Nhan Tong renovated the pagoda and changed its name to Vinh Nghiem Pagoda, wishing for it to be eternal and sacred.|||Vinh Nghiem Pagoda has long been recognized by the people as one of the centers for propagating Buddhism of the Truc Lam Yen Tu Zen Sect during the Tran Dynasty, bearing distinct national identity.|||It is where the model of unified Buddhism was established on the basis of unifying existing Zen sects, and also served as a model for Buddhist organizations later on.|||According to historical records, Vinh Nghiem Pagoda had a large number of monks and nuns participating in the summer retreat and a significant number of Buddhists attending the Mahayana dharma talks. Therefore, the pagoda was built on a large land area, with an architectural design that ensured sufficient living space for the monastic community.|||During the Ly Dynasty, the temple was relatively unknown.|||By the Tran Dynasty, after Tran Nhan Tong founded the Truc Lam Yen Tu Buddhist sect and promoted Buddhism in society, Vinh Nghiem Temple, as a major center for the sect, had a significant impact not only on the Buddhist community but also across various aspects of society.|||All three patriarchs (Tran Nhan Tong, Phap Loa, and Huyen Quang) used Vinh Nghiem Temple as the center to propagate the Buddhism of the Truc Lam Yen Tu sect, which continued to develop after the Tran dynasty.|||For nearly 800 years, the Truc Lam Yen Tu Buddhist sect has gone through many ups and downs, closely linked to the ups and downs of Vietnamese history, but it is still maintained and developed. From the Vinh Nghiem Buddhist center, the ideology of this sect spread throughout the country and to the region and the world.|||Vinh Nghiem Pagoda is considered the most important historical site of Buddhism in Vietnam, especially for the Truc Lam Yen Tu Buddhist sect. It is regarded as the first Buddhist university in Vietnam and is considered the ancestral site of Vinh Nghiem. Researchers consider it a "Museum of Mahayana Buddhist Culture".|||In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Vinh Nghiem Pagoda was a major publishing center for Vietnamese Buddhism. The woodblock repository preserved here contains 34 book titles with nearly 3,000 engraved blocks, each with two sides, and each side has 2 pages (negative images) with around 2,000 Nom and Han characters.|||This is the only original set of woodblocks of the Truc Lam Buddhist sect still preserved at Vinh Nghiem Pagoda, used to spread the core teachings of Buddhism to hundreds of pagodas with millions of monks and Buddhists over time.|||With its scientific and historical significance, the Moc Ban of Vinh Nghiem Pagoda was recognized by UNESCO as a Memory of the World in the Asia-Pacific region in 2012.|||Unique Artistic Architectural Work|||After nearly a thousand years with many renovations, the current architectural complex of Vinh Nghiem Pagoda is a product of the Le Trung Hung and Nguyen dynasties. To meet the needs of worship and training Buddhist monks nationwide, Vinh Nghiem Pagoda was built on a large scale. The architectural clusters are arranged in a rectangular space, spread along a longitudinal axis and in order from south to north, forming five main architectural complexes: Tam Quan gate, Tam Bao hall, First Ancestor Hall, Bell Tower, Second Ancestor Hall.|||Tam quan: The Tam quan gate of Vinh Nghiem Pagoda is a wooden architectural structure built in the overlapping style, consisting of 1 compartment and 2 wings with 2 floors and 8 curved roofs. The ridge is built with bricks and covered with mortar, with a figure of two dragons facing the moon. The architectural design symbolizes three elements of Buddhist philosophy: Falsehood, Emptiness, and Reality. Passing through this Tam quan gate means entering a meditative state, where one is blessed by Buddha to achieve a calm and serene mind. This architectural structure was rebuilt in 1993-1994.|||Tam Bao: A complex of three Buddhist structures following the Mahayana tradition, characterized by multiple Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, and practitioners. The wooden architectural components include the front hall, Thiêu huong, and Upper Hall, forming a single unit. The layout is in the cong shape, with a spacious design, seven-boat-shaped roof beams, leaf-shaped decorations, four curved roofs, and eight rafters.|||is removed and the sentence is broken into clear English sentences: The complex consists of three main parts: the front hall, Thiêu huong, and Upper Hall. These structures are arranged in a cong shape.|||The outermost house is the front hall, consisting of 5 bays and 2 wings; the structure of the beams follows the traditional style, with intricate carvings. Connecting the front hall to the upper hall is the Thiêu hương house, which has 3 bays and a similar beam structure. The upper hall, located innermost, also has 3 bays and is constructed in the same style, with smooth and sturdy wooden panels.|||The Tam Bao Tower preserves three treasures of the Buddhist realm: the Buddha treasure, the Dharma treasure, and the Sangha treasure.|||The Buddha treasure refers to revered statues worshipped and honored throughout the year. The Dharma treasure includes scriptures and texts related to Buddhism. The Sangha treasure represents monks devoted to Buddhist practices, serving as a connection between Buddha and sentient beings. These three treasures are carefully preserved by the people, with the mindset of only adding to their beauty and value, never taking away.|||It is believed that losing a Buddhist treasure will result in a tenfold loss, so even if someone takes it unintentionally, they will feel remorse and return it, repenting for the rest of their life.|||A very special feature at the Tam Bao tower is the rammed earth floor, which has been preserved for a long time, a rare feature among ancient Vietnamese temples. The rammed earth floor is significant in Buddhism as it represents the harmony of yin and yang.|||Upon entering the Tam Bao temple, everyone will feel the refreshing and serene atmosphere that brings peace to the soul. The arrangement of Buddha statues, plaques, couplets, and worship items creates a truly sacred and solemn ambiance, fitting for a Buddhist setting. Visitors from all directions bow reverently and light incense sticks as an offering to the Buddhas, expressing their devotion. They also pledge to contribute their limited resources to help build and beautify this sacred site.|||First Ancestor House: This is where the three patriarchs of the Trúc Lâm Yên Tử Buddhist sect are worshiped: King Tran Nhan Tong, Master Pháp Loa, and Master Huyen Quang. The layout is arranged in the cong shape, characteristic of the Le Trung Hung architecture (18th century). It consists of a 3-bay front hall, a 2-bay connecting hall, and a 1-bay rear shrine, with a 4-roof structure; the foundation is not large but is quite imposing and solemn.|||The first Ancestor House is made with wooden roof structures in the style of ke chuyen gia chieng and ke chuyen doc tru. It has minimal intricate carvings, mostly plain and joined with mortise and tenon. With this house, Vinh Nghiem Temple becomes a temple with the most distinctively Vietnamese Buddhist architecture among ancient temples in the North.|||In Bac Giang, large pagodas typically have a house for the patriarch behind the Tam Bao hall. However, this patriarch's house in most pagodas only has an idol of the first patriarch or just an image of Bodhidharma, not the Three Patriarchs of Trúc Lâm. This is the difference that is unique to Vinh Nghiem Pagoda, unlike other pagodas in Bac Giang province in particular and the northeastern region of North Vietnam in general.|||Bell tower: A two-story structure behind the first house, with "upper thu, lower trai" architecture in the Nguyen style (19th century). The upper floor has a wooden floor, with a large bell cast in 1830 hung in the middle, used by monks to toll the bell for Buddhist teachings.|||This is a beautiful architectural work with intricate carvings and a harmonious combination of wood and tile materials.|||Second Ancestor House: Located behind the Bell Tower, the layout is in the shape of the character "nhị", consisting of 11 bays of the worship hall running parallel to 3 bays of the sanctum. They are connected by a gutter, which is the flow of the roof behind the worship hall and the front roof of the sanctum. Built during the Le - Nguyen period, it is where the statues, altars, or photos of the patriarchs who succeeded the three founding patriarchs of the Truc Lam Yen Tu Zen sect are placed.|||This description was broken into two sentences to improve clarity, but the original "|||" separator is maintained for the sake of the original instruction, even though there's only one sentence now.|||Corridor: along the sides of the above buildings are two corridors, also where visitors sit and rest. Here, there are no statues of Arhat like other temples, which is also a difference from other ancient temples in Bac Giang.|||It is notable that Vinh Nghiem Pagoda bears the strong identity of Vietnamese Buddhist culture in that it has two separate ancestral worship halls following the Truc Lam Yen Tu Zen sect, without worshiping Bodhidharma. The architectural layout also reveals that the ancient monks followed Buddhism but still valued Indian Buddhism and the Mahayana sect that was introduced to our country. This is reflected in the first building, the Tam Bao hall, which faces a large open space in front.|||Thus, Vinh Nghiem Pagoda has both 18th and 19th century architectural styles, making it a diverse and exemplary site for studying Vietnam's traditional architecture. The Buddha statue system at Vinh Nghiem Pagoda is relatively complete in terms of form, position, hierarchy, and function, and is considered beautiful works of art in Vietnam's Buddhist sculpture heritage. The round sculptures at Vinh Nghiem Pagoda hold a special position in terms of artistic value, representing the Nguyen period.|||The system of Buddha statues is very large in number, rich in posture, proportion, and diverse in expression. The sculpture art is standard in terms of proportion, described in a conventional Buddhist style. The greatest value of Vinh Nghiem Pagoda's architecture lies in its spatial landscape with a beautiful feng shui location and the connection between various architectural components, creating a grand hundred-room pagoda complex, affirming its role as a Trúc Lâm Yên Tử Buddhist center.

title: Ba Be National Park
description: Location: Ba Be National Park is located in Ba Be District, Bac Kan Province, about 70km from Bac Kan town and 250km north of Hanoi. Characteristics: Recognized as an ASEAN Heritage Park in 2004, it is an ideal eco-tourism destination with stunning landscapes and rich biodiversity.|||Ba Be National Park covers an area of 7,610ha, with 3,226ha being a strictly protected zone. It is rich in biodiversity, featuring typical ecosystems such as evergreen limestone forests and mountain lakes.|||The park is home to a diverse range of fauna, including 81 mammal species, 27 reptile species, 17 amphibian species, 322 bird species, 106 fish species, and 553 insect species, many of which are rare and endemic.|||In addition to Ba Be Lake, the park features other unique attractions like Puong Cave, Dau Dang Waterfall, and Roong Waterfall. The lake, with over 500ha of water surface, is home to many endemic freshwater fish species and is a vital source of freshwater for local residents. In 1995, Ba Be Lake was recognized as one of the world's 20 most important freshwater lakes.|||Ba Be National Park is home to 1,281 plant species, including 25 species listed in the IUCN Red List and many other rare and precious species listed in Vietnam's Red List. It is considered a center of high biodiversity and endemism, particularly for orchids, with 182 species.

title: Bac Lieu Gentleman's House
description: Located near Bac Lieu River, 13 Dien Bien Phu, Ward 3, Bac Lieu City, Bac Lieu Province. The house is associated with Tran Trinh Huy, the most famous young nobleman in the South of Vietnam in the early 20th century.|||"Bac Lieu young nobleman" refers to the children of wealthy families in Bac Lieu during the French colonial period. The most famous was Tran Trinh Huy (1900-1974), known as Ba Huy, Hoi Dong Ba, or Black young nobleman, a famous playboy in Saigon and the South in the 1930s and 1940s.|||The house, also known as the Big House, was built in 1919. Most of the building materials, from cast steel to marble flooring, bricks, and decorative iron frames, bear the letter "P" marking their origin in Paris. After completion, it was considered the grandest house in the South.|||The two-story house is characterized by its luxurious white color and French architecture. The ground floor has 2 bedrooms, 2 large halls, and a staircase leading to the upper floor. The upper floor has 3 bedrooms and 2 large halls, with Tran Trinh Huy's room fully equipped with modern amenities.|||Today, the house remains intact, serving as a tourist attraction. Visitors are drawn to its intricate design, exuding luxury and elegance. The house also features a display of rare artifacts, including intricately crafted furniture and tea sets.|||Part of the house has been renovated into a high-end hotel and restaurant. Visitors can stay in luxurious French-style rooms, enjoy the "Gentleman's" hotpot, and relax with the "Singing Together" program held every evening at 7 pm.

title: Hoang De Ancient Citadel
description: Location: In Nhon Hau commune, An Nhon town, Binh Dinh province, about 27km north of Qui Nhon city.|||Characteristics: Hoang De Citadel was the headquarters of the Tay Son army in the early stages and later became the capital of Hoang De Thai Duc - Nguyen Nhac's government.|||Thanh Do Ban was built under King Yangpuku Vijaya in the late 10th century.|||It was the capital of the Cham kingdom from the 11th to the 15th century. In 1775, the Tay Son dynasty rebuilt and expanded it to 15 miles to the east. It was officially named Thanh Hoang De in 1778.|||Hoang De Citadel is not large but has its own unique beauty, particularly with its Cham architecture, featuring three layers: the inner, outer, and Forbidden City. The outer citadel is the outermost layer, rectangular but with wavy edges, not straight, with a circumference of 7400m. The base is over 10m wide, the wall is over 6m high, and the top is over 4m wide. The citadel has 5 gates. The southern wall has two gates, Ve gate and Tan Khai gate. The other three walls have one gate each: East, West, and North. The wall is made of earth with laterite stone on both sides. The inner citadel, also known as Hoang Thanh, is built southwest of the outer citadel, with a circumference of 1600m and a base width of 7-9m. The wall is also made of earth with laterite stone on both sides. The inner citadel has three gates, with the main gate, called Tien gate, facing Ve gate of the outer citadel.|||The Forbidden City is in the center, rectangular, with a circumference of nearly 600m. The wall is 1.8m high, with the southeast corner being over 3m high, and the top is about 1.5m wide. It has 4 gates, with the southern gate being the main gate, called Nam Lau or Quyen Bong gate.|||Hoang De citadel witnessed battles between the Tay Son and Nguyen dynasties, including the siege by Tay Son generals Tran Quang Dieu and Vo Van Dung against Nguyen general Vo Tan in May 1801. Unable to withstand the Tay Son army, Vo Tan set himself on fire, and civil official Ngo Tung Chau took poison. After the Tay Son dynasty collapsed in 1802, Hoang De citadel was flattened by the Nguyen dynasty. On the site of the Bat Giac palace, where King Thai Duc held court, Nguyen Anh built a tomb and an octagonal pavilion to worship defeated generals Vo Tan and Ngo Tung Chau.|||With a history of hundreds of years, the ancient Hoang De citadel is like an old, forgotten book. When touched and opened, visitors are conquered by the beauty of its past pages and valuable historical content. No one can explain why the old me tree remains lush and tall; the old red stone wall remains charming; the over 100-year-old sung tree is always fruitful; and the square well made of red stone is always full of cool water... These mysteries await travelers to explore.|||In addition to the strong walls, the citadel is also defended by a system of rivers, mountains, and hills. The Dam Da river surrounds Hoang De citadel like a natural moat and is also a convenient waterway.|||The entrance to the citadel has two stone elephants standing over 20m apart. Inside, there are stone lion statues. In the Forbidden City area, visitors can see some remaining relics, including the octagonal pavilion and fake mountain.|||Two semi-circular pools have been dredged, restoring their original shape as ancient bathing pools. The pool walls are made of brown red stone, cleverly and beautifully held together with clay.|||A coral and some stone pedestals are attached to the pool walls. The pool bottom is flat and compacted with bricks and clay.|||A 50m away is an ancient leaf-shaped well. The well is built with red stone and clay.|||At the citadel corner, there is a square ancient well made of red stone, with clear water to this day.|||Tu Cam Thanh is always shaded by green trees, very poetic. Behind the ancient trees is the Canh Tien tower from the Champa era, leaning gently, beautiful like a painting. After withstanding the ravages of time, the ancient trees of various types: mango, fig, bodhi, starfruit... still stand proudly like brave imperial guards protecting the palace.|||was removed as there was no|||in the original description, so the sentence was translated as a whole.|||Hoang De ancient citadel was ranked as a national historical site by the Ministry of Culture and Information in 1982.

title: Yok Don National Park
description: Location: Yok Don National Park is in Buon Don and Ea Sup districts, Dak Lak province, 40km northwest of Buon Ma Thuot city.|||Characteristics: Yok Don National Park is one of the largest nature reserves in Vietnam, with a total area of 115,545ha.|||Yok Don National Park is a treasure trove of wonders, attracting tourists and scientists alike with its rich and unique pristine nature. The vast forests are characteristic of the Southeast Asian tropical forest ecosystem, interspersed with lush green humid forests and shrublands featuring many precious tree species such as giang huong, ca te, cam lai, trac, go do, and sao la tim.|||The terrain here is relatively flat, with the Yok Don and Reheng mountains standing out. The primary forest occupies over 90% of the entire park's area, providing an ideal living environment for various animal and plant species. According to scientific surveys, Yok Don is home to 67 mammal species, 196 bird species, 46 reptile species, 15 amphibian species, and around 100 insect species. The wildlife is not only rich and diverse but also characteristic of the Southeast Asian fauna.|||Yok Don is home to 36 of the 56 rare animal species in the Indochina region, including 17 species listed in the world's red book, such as elephants, wild buffalo, kouprey, spotted deer, serow, pheasants, peacocks, starlings, and Asian fairy bluebirds. It is also the only area in Vietnam with a large concentration of rare animals like wild cattle, leopards, Eld's deer, and water monitors. The flora here is rich and diverse with 464 species, many of which are found only in the Central Highlands. The area is also home to many rare and beautiful flowers, with over 23 species of orchids alone. Yok Don is the only place in Vietnam that preserves the Dipterocarp forest type.|||In recent years, scientists have conducted many research projects on the biodiversity of the national park, studying the ecological characteristics of wild animals, and researching specific species such as elephants, hoofed animals, Indochinese tigers and leopards, and various bird species. Alongside conservation efforts, maintaining and developing the ecosystem of Yok Don National Park, one of the park's tasks is to develop tourism. The national park management board has actively collaborated with Dak Lak Tourism to develop eco-tourism, research, and exploration of the primeval forest.|||In addition, Yok Don National Park preserves many cultural values of the Central Highlands ethnic groups such as Ede, M'Nong, Lao, etc. Buon Don still preserves many traditional stilt houses with beautiful carvings, showcasing the skillful hands and creativity of the local people. Buon Don is also famous for its elephant hunting and taming. Visitors can see the tools used to catch elephants and ride them through the forests or cross the Serepok River.|||The Serepok River originates from Nam Da mountains and flows through Buon Don, creating a natural boundary protecting the forest. The banyan trees along the riverbank have numerous branches and roots, forming a unique "stilt house" for visitors to climb and enjoy the scenery. At night, visitors can join a campfire night with lively melodies from traditional instruments.|||Besides riding elephants, visitors can also join outdoor tours, hiking, camping in the forest, or stay in a small hut by the river to enjoy the scenery at sunset.

title: Dua Beach
description: Location: Dua Beach is located between the front and back beaches at the foot of Nho Hill, near Nghinh Phong Cape, Vung Tau city. Characteristics: According to legend, the beach was named Dua because there were many wild pineapple trees on the hill overlooking the sea, emitting a fragrant aroma.|||It is also said that the fragrance lured travelers and wanderers, making it hard for them to leave, hence the name Lang Du Beach (Wanderer's Beach).|||Dua Beach is one of the most beautiful beaches in Vung Tau, attracting many tourists. Its beauty is not loud and crowded, but rather dreamy and subtle. The sea is nestled among the rocky coves, creating small bays with crystal-clear water and a hint of countryside fragrance.|||On the hill above Dua Beach, along Ha Long Avenue, there are villas, hotels, and resorts with full amenities, as well as pagodas and temples surrounded by tranquil gardens, creating a mystical atmosphere. Relaxing and sightseeing here will soothe the soul and refresh the mind after a long period of intense work.

title: Da Nhim Lake - Ngoan Muc Pass
description: Location: Da Nhim Lake - Ngoan Muc Pass is on the road from Phan Rang to Da Lat, in Don Duong district, 40km east of Da Lat.|||Features: Da Nhim Lake - Ngoan Muc Pass is a beautiful natural scenery with a winding and twisting road...|||From Ngoan Muc Pass, you can see a steep slope, with a winding road below. Two high mountains hug the Phan Rang valley, running out to the sea. On a clear day, you can see the white sandy beach and the rolling waves. That's why this road is called Ngoan Muc Pass.|||The area is also home to the Da Nhim hydropower plant, with two water pipes that look like white stripes against the green mountains.|||In the afternoon, the area around Phan Rang is ablaze with purple color. Da Nhim Lake is calm and peaceful, with no ripples on the water. The dam is 1,460m long, 38m high, and 180m wide at the base. The lake has an area of 9.7km², at an altitude of around 1,042m.|||The weather in Da Nhim is a mix of temperate and tropical, with sunshine and rain alternating. At the foot of Ngoan Muc Pass, the rain and fog can be thick, but when it clears, the scenery is revealed again.

title: Ky Co Beach
description: Located at the foot of Phuong Mai mountain, Nhon Ly commune, Quy Nhon city, Binh Dinh province, 25km northeast of Quy Nhon city center.|||Called the Maldives of Vietnam with blue sea, white sand, and golden sun.|||From Quy Nhon city center, take a motorbike or taxi to Eo Gio, then a canoe or boat to Ky Co beach.|||The beach is a crescent-shaped bay with three sides surrounded by mountains and one side facing the sea.|||The water is divided into shades of blue, from dark to light, and turquoise.|||The beach has rocks on both sides, creating unique "canyons" and "small lakes" at low tide.|||Visitors can snorkel to see coral reefs and fish, or take a boat to fish or explore the sea.|||Try local seafood dishes like grilled snails, grilled abalone, steamed crab, and grilled sea urchin.|||Ky Co is a wild and unspoiled destination with friendly locals.|||Visit Ky Co and nearby places like Eo Gio, Yen Island, and Trung Luong camping site for a great summer vacation.|||The best time to visit is from April to September.

title: Con Phung (Coconut Island)
description: Ben Tre is a province in the Mekong Delta region. Visitors will be captivated by the serene beauty of the riverine landscape and the unique culinary culture of this coconut-rich land.|||Gifted with a mild climate year-round and a dense network of rivers, Ben Tre boasts lush fruit gardens and vast coconut groves. Visitors can enjoy the fresh air and experience the hospitality of the locals.|||A must-visit attraction in Ben Tre is Con Phung, a small island in the Tien River, located in Tan Thach commune, Chau Thanh district. It covers over 50 ha and is part of the famous four-island ensemble known as Long, Lan, Quy, Phung.|||In Con Phung, visitors can admire the natural beauty of the riverine landscape, explore traditional crafts such as making rice cakes and coconut candy, and see handicrafts made from coconut trees.|||Visitors can take a boat ride on the Tien River, visit a local house with a coconut-leaf roof, ride a horse-drawn carriage through coconut-lined roads, and experience the traditional music of the region.|||They can also witness the process of making delicious coconut candy.|||The island has a system of restaurants with good service quality, offering a range of local dishes made from fresh ingredients, such as fried fish, puffed rice, hot pot, and coconut-based desserts.

title: Ngu Hanh Son
description: Location: Ngu Hanh Son is in Hoa Hai ward, Ngu Hanh Son district, about 7km southeast of Da Nang city center. Characteristics: Ngu Hanh Son is on a 2km long, 800m wide strip of yellow sand.|||Ngu Hanh Son is not high, with steep slopes and sparse vegetation. The stone is marble with various colors: milky, white, pink, red veining, black, dark green, etc. It's not very hard and is a great material for carving statues and decorative art. There are many legends about the formation of Ngu Hanh Son. One story tells that: “Long ago, this was a desolate sea area, with only one old man living alone in a thatched hut. One day, the sky suddenly darkened, a storm arose, and a giant dragon appeared, writhing on the sand, and a huge egg rolled out from under its belly. The dragon then disappeared into the sea. Soon after, a golden turtle appeared, claiming to be the Kim Quy god, buried the egg, and tasked the old man with protecting the offspring of the Dragon King. The egg grew larger, rising high, occupying a large area of land. The eggshell shone with colors: blue, red, white, yellow, purple, sparkling like a giant brick. One day, the old man dozed off and heard a fire breaking out. He called for help, using the turtle's claw, a gift from the Kim Quy god. Inside the egg, a spacious, cool cave appeared. He fell asleep, unaware of a miracle: a beautiful girl emerged from the egg, and where he lay was one of the five marble rocks formed from the eggshell fragments...”.

title: Con Dao
description: Con Dao is an archipelago located in the Southeast, belonging to Ba Ria - Vung Tau province. This beautiful island is known as an attractive destination on the Vietnamese and world tourism map due to its scenery, ecosystem, and special historical values.|||Con Dao today has transformed into one of the most charming islands on the planet, praised by many prestigious magazines around the world, such as Lonely Planet, which voted it into the top 10 most charming islands, and Travel & Leisure, which ranked it among the top 25 most beautiful beaches in the world.|||Visitors can learn about history and culture, explore the ocean world with colorful coral reefs, conquer the primeval forest with a rich flora and fauna, and find peaceful moments in the midst of daily bustle.|||For nature-loving tourists and those who want to explore new lands, Con Dao promises to be an ideal stop. The island has a green sea with long sandy beaches, large mountains covered in green, allowing tourists to immerse themselves in a fresh and cool natural environment. Some notable beaches include Dam Trau, Nhat, Suoi Nong, Hon Bay Cach, Hon Tai, Hon Ba...|||Not only does Con Dao possess beautiful natural scenery, but it also has many historical and spiritual sites, such as Hang Duong cemetery, where the tomb of heroine Vo Thi Sau is located, Van Son Tu, Cau temple, Ba Phi Yen temple, and Chua Nui Mot...|||Con Dao has a mild climate, with a rainy season from May to October and a dry season from November to April. Tourists can visit Con Dao during the dry season when the sea is calm and blue, or during the rainy season, when the rain does not last long, making it suitable for sea activities, especially during the turtle nesting season.

title: Ho Tay Park
description: Location: Main gate at 614 Lac Long Quan Street, Tay Ho District and waterway welcoming customers from Thanh Nien Road passing by Ho Tay, docking at the Water Park. Features: One of the largest entertainment venues in the North. Located on the northwest side, by the romantic Ho Tay lake, with the attraction of bright colors and dynamic modern entertainment facilities, Ho Tay Park is a popular destination for tourists.|||Tay Ho Park was established in 2000, on the 110th anniversary of the birth of President Ho Chi Minh and the 990th anniversary of Thang Long - Hanoi. Spanning over 8ha, it is a complex that includes areas such as Water Park, New Sun Park, club areas, and a multi-functional service zone. Tay Ho Park has 34 entertainment and recreational facilities with diverse and modern activities.||||||The Water Park covers an area of 35,560m², divided into 5 entertainment zones.|||It features seven water slides with an average height of 12m. Notable attractions include two high-speed slides, 14.5m high, installed for the first time in Vietnam. The wave pool generates six types of waves, with a maximum height of 1.2m and a depth of 3m.|||Other attractions include the "dead man's drop" and Tibetan bridge for thrill-seekers, a massage pool (bubble pool) with a depth of 0.6m for relaxation, and a diving pool with a depth of 3.5m for adventure-seekers. The diving pool also offers scuba diving training and jumping activities.|||For children, there are kid-friendly pools, mini water slides, underwater games, and a 450m long, 4.5m wide lazy river flowing under five bridges. Tay Ho Water Park is the first large-scale, modern water park in the North, equipped with state-of-the-art facilities imported from Spain, providing visitors with a refreshing and rejuvenating experience.||||||||||||As the first water park to achieve international standards in the North, Ho Tay Water Park has invested in large-scale, modern, and professional equipment and facilities to serve customers better.|||It is also a venue for cultural exchange programs and events. Here, you will be served by the largest outdoor stage with a grand space; a dignified and elegant conference system; and a modern sound, lighting, and technical equipment system.||||||The New Sun Park (previously known as Moon Park) is located adjacent to the Water Park. Continuously investing in advanced equipment for various diverse and rich activities, New Sun Park is a complex of modern, impressive, thrilling, and adventurous games. Sitting on a 60m high Ferris wheel, you can relax and enjoy the panoramic view of the city. Here, you can also find a 3D cinema, new generation video games, a supermarket, a multi-sport zone with tennis courts, badminton, table tennis, a billiards room, a fishing pond, a mini golf course, and various other games like spinning teacups, bumper cars, and high-speed trains. Additionally, there's the dynamic and powerful Octopus Ferris wheel; Thang Long Steel Dragon (a roller coaster); and a children's play area featuring a luxurious Ferris wheel, spinning teacups, bumper cars, helicopter simulators, a ball pit, a wooden castle, and a maze…..||||||The club area includes music, sports, and cultural clubs, providing guests with relaxing moments after thrilling rides.|||The multifunctional service area is convenient and diverse, catering to essential needs when visiting Tay Ho Park.||||||Ho Tay Park is and will be an attractive destination for many visitors near and far. This is an interesting and useful entertainment address.|||Not only that, this place also creates conditions for many groups of customers who are excellent students, poor children who overcome difficulties, disabled children, orphans... to come and play for free.

title: Cai Mon Ornamental Plant Village
description: Location: Vinh Thanh commune, Cho Lach district, Ben Tre province. Features: Cai Mon is a well-known land, likened to a "kingdom" of ornamental plants.|||From My Tho city, you cross Rach Mieu bridge and follow provincial road 884 to Tien Thuy market in Chau Thanh district, Ben Tre province. Here, high-speed tourist boats will take you on a one-hour journey through rivers and waterways to Cai Mon canal, a green countryside with an abundance of fruit trees.|||Cai Mon is named after a large stream. 'Cai' means large stream and 'Mon' is a distorted form of 'Mum' (in Khmer, it means honey). According to Son Nam's research on the culture of the Mekong Delta, the banks of this stream were once abundant with honeybees due to the lush fruit trees and constant blooming flowers.|||The name Cai Mon originates from this.|||One of the natural wonders is that while all rivers and canals flow in one direction, the flow of Cai Mon canal converges from two ends. The meeting point of the two streams is called the 'Dragon's Navel' by locals, a name full of mystique. At this point, the canal widens, and the calm water forms a bustling ornamental plant floating market, one of the most beautiful in the Cuu Long delta. Early in the morning, people from the gardens along the Co Chien and Ham Luong rivers paddle their boats to the market. By the end of the day, when the Cai Mon stream divides and flows back to its two origins, the boats return, marking the end of a working day.|||Cai Mon has many relaxation and entertainment spots modeled after garden homestays. Visitors can tour areas where plants are grown, nurtured, and crafted into ornamental trees. Cai Mon Village is home to thousands of households growing traditional flowers like marigold, paper flower, large chrysanthemum, chrysanthemum, dahlia, carnation... Notably, Cai Mon preserves dozens of rose varieties: red velvet rose, purple lay-on rose, Elizabeth rose, Korokit rose... Visitors can also find rare, centuries-old ornamental trees. Familiar trees include fig, banyan, starfruit, cau... Some trees have quite "flashy" names like purple ginseng, little blood, five-leaf ginseng... All are crafted by skilled artisans with an artistic touch into valuable, uniquely shaped ornamental trees.|||Besides ancient trees, local artisans also grow various foliage like red luck, kim phat tai, thanh da lan, bich hiep truc... and especially animal-shaped ornamental trees like deer, dragon, phoenix... that are very beautiful.|||Strolling along the winding paths through the green and artistic gardens, visitors will feel as if they are lost in a paradise. After visiting the "kingdom of ornamental trees", visitors can stop by the Cai Mon fruit orchards, pick and enjoy ripe fruits such as bon bon, mangosteen, and durian. In the afternoon, visitors can stand on the curved monkey bridges and admire the sunset over the Cai Mon canal, visit the coconut-leaf-roofed restaurants along the banks, or relax in the beautiful gardens and enjoy the local specialties of Ben Tre, and let their spirits soar while listening to the charming Cai Mon girls in traditional ao ba ba clothing playing the traditional music.|||was removed as there was no "|||". The sentence was broken into shorter ones for clarity.

title: Quan Su Temple
description: Location: 73 Quan Su Street, Tran Hung Dao ward, Hoan Kiem district, Hanoi. Characteristics: It is the headquarters of the Central Buddhist Association of Vietnam.|||Quan Su Pagoda was built in the 15th century on the territory of An Tap village, Co Vu ward, Tien Nghiem commune (later changed to Vinh Xuong commune), Tho Xuong district; now is Quan Su Street, Hoan Kiem district, Hanoi capital.|||In 1934, the General Buddhist Association of North Vietnam was established, and Quan Su Pagoda was chosen as its headquarters. In 1942, the pagoda was rebuilt according to the design of two architects Nguyen Ngoc Ngoan and Nguyen Xuan Tung, approved by To Vinh Nghiem. The art of architecture and decoration combines the essence of the major Buddhist monasteries in the North.|||The pagoda has a three-story gatehouse, with a bell tower in the middle.|||The main hall is square, with a surrounding corridor. The Buddha Hall is arranged solemnly, with large and golden statues.|||The pagoda is also the headquarters of the Buddhist Association of Vietnam and the Asian Buddhist Conference for Peace (in Vietnam).

title: Sam Son Beach
description: Location: Sam Son Beach is in Sam Son town, Thanh Hoa province, 16km from Thanh Hoa city. Characteristics: Long, flat coastline, majestic scenery, exploited by the French since 1906.|||Sam Son Beach was known for its excellent bathing conditions and was exploited by the French from 1906, quickly becoming a famous resort of Indochina. Many villas were built here decades ago. King Bao Dai, the last emperor of the Nguyen dynasty, also built a private villa in Sam Son. Sam Son has many beautiful landscapes: Hon Trong Mai islet, Doc Cuoc temple, Co Tien mountain...|||Sam Son has a 10km long, flat coastline with many valuable seafood such as lobster, mackerel, squid... Sam Son has majestic natural scenery, a vast sea with historical sites and legends rich in humanistic values and hospitality. Sam Son Beach is one of the widest and most beautiful beaches in the north.

title: Dien Bien Phu Victory Museum
description: Located at Street 1, Muong Thanh Ward, Dien Bien Phu City, Dien Bien Province. Built in 1984 to commemorate the 30th anniversary of the Dien Bien Phu historical victory.|||In late 2003, the museum was upgraded and rearranged. It now has 5 exhibition areas with 274 artifacts and 122 paintings on the following topics:|||- Strategic location of Dien Bien Phu.|||- Enemy stronghold in Dien Bien Phu.|||- Party's preparation for the Dien Bien Phu campaign.|||- Impact of the Dien Bien Phu victory.|||- Dien Bien Phu today.

title: Quang Dong Assembly Hall
description: Located at 17 Tran Phu Street, Hoi An town. Features: Built by Quang Dong Chinese in 1885, initially to worship Thien Hau Thanh Mau and Confucius, then changed to worship Quan Cong and Tien Hien after 1911.|||The artful use of wood and stone materials in the load-bearing structure and decorative motifs has given the assembly hall a majestic and unique beauty. The hall still preserves many ancient artifacts, including 4 large horizontal boards, 1 large bronze incense burner (1.6m high, 0.6m wide), 1 pair of Chinese ceramic votive urns... Every year, on the Nguyen Tieu day (15th January in lunar calendar) and Quan Cong's birthday (24th June in lunar calendar), the assembly hall hosts a grand festival, attracting many participants.

title: Giac Lam Pagoda
description: Location: 565 Lac Long Quan, Tan Binh District, Ho Chi Minh City. Characteristics: This is one of the oldest pagodas in Ho Chi Minh City and is the main pagoda of the Lam Te Zen sect in the South.|||In 1744, the layman Ly Thuy Long (a Chinese descendant) raised funds to build a pagoda on Cam Son hill, named Son Can, later changed to Cam Son. In 1774, the Zen master Vien Quang of the Lam Te Zen sect became the abbot, renaming it Giac Lam Pagoda. During this period, the pagoda became the first center for training monks in Gia Dinh and the Mekong Delta. In 1873, it was also a place for printing, copying, and carving Buddhist scriptures.|||After several restorations, the current architecture of Giac Lam Pagoda is typical of ancient pagodas in the South, with a tam-style layout, consisting of three main sections: the main hall, the lecture hall, and the monks' quarters. The main hall has one room with two wings, featuring traditional Vietnamese architecture with large columns and ornate decorations. The hall houses 113 Buddha statues made of bronze and precious wood. Notably, the set of 18 La Han statues made of wood, painted in gold, is a testament to the development of Buddhism in the South. The pagoda also has a statue of Quan The Am Bodhisattva under a Bodhi tree, gifted by Deekshita Narada from Sri Lanka in 1953.|||In front of the main hall stands the Bao Thap Xa Loi, a 32-meter-high hexagonal stupa housing Buddha's relics, consisting of 7 tiers. The pagoda grounds also contain 38 stupas of Zen masters and monks from the 19th century. The ceramics on the pagoda walls and stupas were crafted at the Binh Duong ceramics kiln between 1939 and 1945, featuring a blend of cultural influences from China, India, and France.|||Giac Lam Pagoda was recognized as a national historical and cultural relic in 1988.

title: Ngoc Son Temple
description: Location: Situated on Ngoc Son Island in Hoan Kiem Lake, Hanoi city.|||Characteristics: Although it is a relatively new architectural temple, Ngoc Son is a typical example of spatial and architectural design.|||Ngoc Son Island used to be called Tượng Nhĩ (elephant's ears). King Ly Thai To moved the capital to Thang Long and renamed the island Ngoc Tuong. Later, during the Tran dynasty, it was renamed Ngoc Son. A temple was built here to honor heroes who sacrificed during the resistance against the Mongol invaders. It later collapsed. During the Le dynasty (1735-1739), Lord Trinh Giang built Thuy Khanh palace.|||Later, the palace was destroyed. A philanthropist named Tin Trai built a pagoda on the old palace grounds. In 1843, a charity organization rebuilt the main halls and brought in the statue of Van Chang de quan to worship, renaming it Ngoc Son shrine.|||According to "Ha Thanh linh tich co luc", from the Le dynasty, there was a temple on Ngoc Son island dedicated to Quan Cong, a famous figure known for his loyalty during the Chinese Tam Quoc period. When the Le king and Trinh lord used the lake for naval drills, the temple was considered a martial temple. People from Ha Noi placed a statue of Tran Hung Dao alongside Quan Cong. However, "Khâm dinh Viet su thong giam cuong muc" states it was a statue of Le Lai, a founding hero of the Le dynasty who sacrificed himself to save his king.|||In 1865, the 18th year of Tu Duc's reign, the Confucian scholar Nguyen Van Sieu renovated the temple. The renovated temple was built with additional earth and a stone embankment around it, and a Tran Ba pavilion was constructed. A bridge was built from the east bank to the temple, called The Huc Bridge. On the old Ngoc Boi hill, a stone tower was built, with its top shaped like a brush tip, and its body inscribed with the words "Ta Thanh Thien" (Writing to the Blue Sky). It is now commonly called But Tower. Next to it is a coiled gate called Nguen, topped with a stone ink slab in the shape of half a peach cut lengthwise, with three frogs on it. The ink slab is inscribed with a poem about its usefulness from a philosophical perspective. People later praised it as: "Nhat dai Phuong Dinh but". From the outer gate, there are two walls on either side, one with a dragon tablet and the other with a tiger tablet, symbolizing the two prestigious lists of names of those who passed the exams, encouraging scholars to work harder.|||The name of The Huc Bridge means keeping the beautiful light of the sun. The Huc Bridge leads to the gate of Ngoc Son Temple. The main temple consists of two connected temples, the first one to the north worships Tran Hung Dao and Van Chang. The statue of Van Chang stands, holding a pen, placed on a stone pedestal about 1m high, with two stone staircases on either side. To the south is Tran Ba pavilion (a pavilion blocking waves - implying a pillar standing firm against unhealthy waves in contemporary culture). The pavilion is square with eight roofs, two-tiered roofs, supported by eight columns, four outer columns made of stone, and four inner columns made of wood. The deities worshiped in the temple, apart from Van Chang De Quan, Lu Dong Tan, Quan Van Truong, Tran Hung Dao, also include Amitabha Buddha. This reflects the Vietnamese concept of Tam giao dong nguyen.|||The combination of Ngoc Son Temple and Hoan Kiem Lake forms an architectural unity of Heaven and Human, creating an ancient, harmonious beauty for the temple and the lake.|||It evokes a sense of harmony between humans and nature. The temple and lake have become historical witnesses recalling the past about the nation's history, awakening national pride, legitimate patriotism as well as the spirituality and awareness of every Vietnamese about the nation's longevity.

title: Ba Ra - Thac Mo Ecological Tourist Area
description: Location: Ba Ra - Thac Mo ecological tourist area is located in Ba Ra mountain area - Thac Mo lake, in Son Giang and Thac Mo wards, Phuoc Long town, Binh Phuoc province, about 160km northwest of Ho Chi Minh City.|||Features: This area not only has romantic natural scenery with mountains, forests, rivers, lakes, and waterfalls, but also preserves many historical sites and valuable cultural works.|||Ba Ra mountain has a total area of 307,325m², 732m high, considered the highest mountain in Binh Phuoc province and the third highest in the Southern region.|||In the Stieng language, Ba Ra means "Bơnom Brah" or "the divine mountain". According to legend, the area was once a flat plain, then suddenly a spring burst forth, flooding a vast area. A god placed a lid over the spring, which became Ba Ra mountain.|||Located in a low hill region with rugged terrain and dense vegetation, in the early 20th century, the Ba Ra mountain area was considered a place of "wild forest and poisonous water", inaccessible to people. In 1925, the French colonizers built a penal colony here to detain political prisoners and those suspected of being communists but without a conviction. Later, when the US got involved in Vietnam, they took over this area and built a modern military base, including a helicopter airfield, on the mountaintop to control the entire Southeast region. However, with the strong and unyielding fighting will of the people and soldiers of Binh Phuoc, the French and American forces eventually withdrew from Ba Ra mountain. Today, many historical relics related to the two wars remain, such as: Ba Ra prison (built by the French), helicopter airfield (built by the US), Dove cave, Sung tree cave, Ba Bay Tuyết cave (where the people and soldiers of Binh Phuoc once resided to resist the French and Americans)…|||At the foot of Ba Ra mountain lies Thac Mo lake, covering around 12,000ha with a capacity of 1.3 billion m3 of water. The lake has 10 large and small islands, surrounded by lush greenery. The lake not only supplies water to Thac Mo hydropower plant, regulates floods for the lower reaches, and provides an environment for aquaculture to serve the local community, but is also an ideal tourist destination, combining with Ba Ra mountain to form a scenic complex on the mountain and lake, creating a poetic landscape.|||With its rich natural beauty and historic significance, the Ministry of Culture and Information (now Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism) issued Decision 568-VH/QD-BVHTT on October 4, 1995, recognizing Ba Ra mountain as a national-level cultural and historical site.|||On December 30, 2002, the People's Committee of Binh Phuoc Province issued Decision No. 2535/QD-UB approving the planning of Ba Ra - Thac Mo eco-tourism area.|||The project includes restoration of historical sites such as Ba Ra prison, Doi cave, Cay Sung cave, Ba Bay Tuyết cave, and Ba Ra temple; construction of new facilities like the Monkey Island village, tourist village, accommodations, and dining on Ba Ra mountain; development of information stations, shrines, and Buddha statues; and provision of tourist services.|||Notably, a 2,063m-long cable car system with 32 cabins has been completed. Other projects will be finished in subsequent years.|||Visiting Ba Ra - Thac Mo ecological tourist area, besides admiring the natural scenery of the highland lake at dawn, joining local fishermen to cast nets and fishing at dusk, or enjoying the specialties of Be river's Pangasiidae and eel in the evening, tourists can also learn about the brave and persistent fight against France and America of the people and army of Binh Phuoc through historical relics.|||Especially, if visiting on January 6th every year, tourists have the opportunity to participate in the international Ba Ra mountain conquest running event, attracting many athletes from countries such as Laos, Cambodia, Thailand…|||To reach the top of Ba Ra mountain, visitors can take a cable car or follow this route: From the foot of the mountain, ride a motorbike or car along the asphalt road to By Lang hill - where there's a memorial stele honoring heroes and martyrs. From here, climb 1,767 stone steps lined with lush green bamboo forests and ancient trees hundreds of years old to reach the summit - where the remains of a US-built helicopter airport, a 48m-high antenna of Binh Phuoc Radio and Television Station, and a thousand-hand Buddha statue are located.|||From the top of Ba Ra mountain, visitors can see the entire Phuoc Long town, with the Thac Mo hydroelectric lake at the foot of the mountain, reflecting the mountains, trees, and sky.|||Investing in Ba Ra - Thac Mo tourist area not only helps preserve and promote the natural beauty, culture, and history of the local area, but also connects nearby attractions such as Thac Mo ward, Thac Mo Hydropower Plant, Bu Gia Map nature reserve, and the system of rivers, streams, waterfalls, and dams, creating a complex of appealing tourist destinations in Binh Phuoc.

title: Dong Ba Market
description: Location: Dong Ba Market is located along the north bank of the Huong River, on Tran Hung Dao street, Hue city, about 100m north of Truong Tien Bridge.|||Dong Ba Market is the largest commercial center in Thua Thien Hue province and the region.|||Before Dong Ba market existed, outside the Chanh Dong gate (also known as Dong Ba gate), there was a large market called "Qui gia thi" under Gia Long's rule. The market's name marked the return of Nguyen army to Phu Xuan. After a period of turmoil during Quang Toan's time, people fled and later returned. Qui Gia market was for those who came back. Nearly a century later, in 1885, the capital was invaded, and Qui Gia market was burned down by the French. In 1887, King Dong Khanh rebuilt the market and renamed it Dong Ba. The market supplied food to the palace, hospitals, military barracks, and dormitories of Quoc Hoc, Dong Khanh, Binh Linh, and Thien Huu schools. In 1899, during the urban renovation following Western style, King Thanh Thai moved the market to its current location, and the old market building became the Dong Ba French-Vietnamese school.|||Dong Ba market during the Thanh Thai period consisted of 4 blocks: front, back, right, and left. The front block had 8 rooms, the back block had 12 rooms, and the right block had 13 rooms... all were tiled. In the center of the market was a three-story square tower. The ground floor had 4 walls, each with 2 doors. The upper floor had doors on all 4 sides, and each side had a clock to mark the time. Inside the market, a stone well was built with a system to facilitate drawing water. When drawing water, users turned the handle, and water from the well would flow out and spout.|||In the early 20th century, Dong Ba market was renovated several times but still kept its old structure.|||In 1967, the Saigon government demolished the old market and built a new one, but the construction was interrupted by US bombing during the 1968 Hue Spring campaign.
