After that, the Saigon government made temporary repairs for commercial activities.|||In 1987, Dong Ba market was fully renovated. Apart from the central bell tower, the new Dong Ba market has 9 surrounding buildings and 4 new commercial areas, including a fish market, local products, and services, with a total construction area of 15,597m². The market management also oversees the Chuong Duong Flower Garden, parking lots for cars, motorbikes, and bicycles, bringing the total area to over 47,614m² with 2,543 fixed business households, 141 stalls, and 500-700 street vendors. On average, 5,000 to 7,000 customers visit the market daily, increasing to over 12,000 during holidays.|||The cultural essence of Thua Thien - Hue can be found at Dong Ba market, featuring products like Phu Cam conical hats, Hien Luong knives, Ke Mon jewelry, Song Hy sesame candy, Truoi strawberries, Tuan tea, Huong Can oranges, Lai Bang tangerines, dried lotus from Tịnh Lake, and paper products from Sinh village.|||It also offers traditional Hue dishes like rice with clams, beef noodle soup, and various desserts. Dong Ba market has become a center supplying delicacies to international hotels and restaurants, serving Hue specialties to tourists visiting the World Heritage site.|||Today, Dong Ba market plays an important role in the market economy. In addition to supplying food and consumer goods to the city, Dong Ba market is also a place that creates jobs for thousands of unemployed people and contributes tens of billions of dong in taxes to the state budget each year.|||Dong Ba market and Truong Tien bridge, along with the Huong river, are symbols of the poetic Hue city.

title: Binh Ta Di Tich Cluster
description: Location: Binh Ta Di Tich Cluster is located in Binh Ta hamlet, Duc Hoa Ha commune, Duc Hoa district, Long An province. Characteristics: Part of a complex of di tích from prehistoric to ancient times along ancient roads and along the Vam Co Dong river, this site belongs to the Oc Eo - Phù Nam culture, dating from the 1st to 7th century AD.|||Three di tích have been excavated: Go Nam Tuoc, Go Xoai and Go Don, relatively close to each other. The Go Xoai temple, found 1.70-1.90m underground, is considered a ritual site of the Phù Nam people. Notably, a collection of 26 gold artifacts discovered at Go Xoai includes a gold leaf with ancient Sanskrit inscriptions, recording a Buddhist prayer. Many valuable artifacts have been unearthed, such as statues of Siva, temple guardians, Vinu, and sacred objects like Linga and Yoni.|||Many Oc Eo fine pottery shards, metal fragments, precious stones, sandstone, and other archaeological evidence of prehistoric human presence within a 10km radius have been discovered.|||The architectural structures found at Binh Ta Di Tich Cluster are Siva temples, belonging to Brahmanism, which emerged in India in the 1st century BC and was introduced to Southeast Asia from the beginning of the AD era. As part of a larger archaeological site in Dong Thap Muoi and the ancient alluvial region of Duc Hoa (Long An), the Oc Eo - Binh Ta di tích was built for religious purposes and also served as a political and cultural center of the ancient Phù Nam - Chân Lạp kingdom.

title: Linh Son Pagoda
description: Location: Linh Son Pagoda is located on Nguyen Van Troi Street, about 700m northwest of Da Lat city center. Features: The pagoda has a simple Asian-style architecture with two sloping roofs. On the roof ridge is a pair of dragons curling in the "lythong" style. On both sides of the steps leading to the main hall are a pair of dragons with open mouths, symbolizing the long spirit protecting Buddhism.|||Linh Son Pagoda is situated on a 4ha hill, planted with tea, coffee, eucalyptus, pine, cypress, and cherry blossoms. The pagoda was built from 1936 to 1940. The scenery around the pagoda is solemn and ancient. The path to the pagoda is shaded by tall pine trees and sao trees. Right in front of the courtyard is a statue of Quan The Am standing on a Lotus Platform. To the left of the pagoda is a three-story octagonal pagoda, and to the right are beautiful artificial rocks and bonsai trees.|||The pagoda also has a pond with water lilies and goldfish, creating a pleasant sight. Inside the pagoda, the Buddha hall is arranged solemnly. The main hall worships the Buddha Thich Ca Mâu Ni in meditation on a lotus throne. The statue was cast in 1952, made of bronze, and weighs 1,250kg. The pagoda also has a room for distributing Buddhist scriptures and souvenirs. The abbot of the pagoda from 1964 to present is Venerable Thich Tu Man. The Lam Dong Buddhist Administration Committee is currently headquartered here.

title: Hanoi Old Quarter
description: Location: Adjacent to Hoan Kiem Lake, Hanoi Old Quarter includes 76 streets, bounded by: Hang Dau street to the north; Phung Hung street to the west; Hang Bong, Hang Gai, Cau Go, and Hang Thung streets to the south; and Tran Quang Khai and Tran Nhat Duat streets to the east.|||Hanoi Old Quarter is a precious architectural heritage rich in traditional cultural characteristics, symbolizing the soul of the capital city with a thousand years of history.|||With a total area of around 100ha, the old quarter of Hanoi was formed in the 11th century and has nearly a thousand years of history as a bustling urban area. It is characterized by residents engaging in small-scale handicrafts and trade, forming traditional craft streets with unique features. Artisans from surrounding villages gathered here, concentrating in specific areas by their trade, making the craft streets increasingly vibrant. Every street was bustling with buying, selling, and working, like a miniature craft village. The products sold became the names of the streets, prefixed with "Hang" as in Hang Gao, Hang Duong, Hang Muoi... This led to Hanoi being referred to as Hanoi of 36 streets and guilds, where people doing the same handicraft or selling the same goods gathered, following the adage "buying with friends, selling with guilds".|||Another characteristic of Hanoi's Old Quarter is the architecture of old houses with tube-like structures, tiled roofs, and shopfronts. These houses were mainly built in the 18th-19th centuries. The Hanoians have skillfully arranged the rooms, mezzanines, and inner courtyards to meet the diverse needs of daily life. As a result, although not large, each old house in Hanoi still has space for selling, making goods, worshiping, receiving guests, sleeping, and relaxing.|||Visiting Hanoi's Old Town, even the most discerning visitors are captivated by the cultural values contained in around 100 ancient architectural works, including communal houses, temples, pagodas, and guild halls. A notable example is Bach Ma Temple on Hang Buom Street, considered one of the four sacred sites of Thang Long citadel.|||Many foreigners visiting Hanoi Old Town for the first time may feel a bit disoriented among the similarly named streets, lined with shops selling similar products, and bustling eateries on both sides of the road. But this feeling gradually fades, replaced by a deep affection when they discover the vibrant, dynamic, and poetic life of Hanoi's people. They get drawn into a land of endless culinary delights, from traditional dishes like bun cha, pho, and bun ca... in small sidewalk stalls to street vendors selling grilled eggs, fried cakes, bun oc, bun dau mam tom...|||Every weekend, when night falls, the pedestrian street Hang Dao - Dong Xuan connected to the Dong Xuan night market creates a nearly 3km long pedestrian area in the Old Quarter at night. This has become an attractive tourist destination, promoting the cultural characteristics of the Old Quarter while allowing visitors to explore Hanoi at night. Joining the flow of pedestrians in the Old Quarter and shopping for souvenirs and consumer goods at the stalls set up along the new street, you can feel the appeal of the night market and the Old Quarter at night.|||Right next to the bustling rows of shops, one can still feel the serene ancient night of the old town through the small, cramped houses nestled together, evoking a sense of antiquity and nostalgia.|||Especially on Saturday nights, traditional folk arts activities such as cheo singing, xam singing, ca tru, quan ho... reenacted by the Vietnam Musicians Association add to the unique and ancient charm of Hanoi Old Town.|||Hanoi's Old Quarter with its charming small tube houses, bustling streets, curved-roof temples and pagodas, and unique flavors of local cuisine... all combine to create a beauty that is uniquely Hanoi.

title: Buon Ma Thuot Prison
description: Location: Buon Ma Thuot Prison is located in Buon Ma Thuot City, Dak Lak Province. Characteristics: Buon Ma Thuot Prison is not only a witness to the crimes of the imperialists and colonialists, but it is also a large school that trained and forged strong revolutionaries of Vietnam.|||Many young people may be surprised to hear that the vibrant Buon Ma Thuot City today was a vast wilderness with dense forests and sparse population just over 50 years ago, considered a haunted place.|||However, at the same time, there was a prison here (one of the political detention camps) with the most brutal regime of the French colonialists in our country. Visiting Buon Ma Thuot, one cannot miss this historically ranked site.|||Here, visitors will see, hear, and learn more about the glorious struggle tradition of former communist fighters such as Ho Tung Mau, Phan Dang Luu, Nguyen Chi Thanh, To Huu, Hong Chuong, Bui San, Tran Van Quang, Ngo Duc De, Nguyen Duy Trinh, Nguyen Phung Tan, Huynh Thanh... and many other outstanding children of the nation.|||Buon Ma Thuot Prison played a particularly important role in the August Revolution movement in Dak Lak. Communist fighters imprisoned here became the ones who sowed the seeds of revolution in this red earth highland.|||Expanded and built on the basis of a prison from 1900 to 1930, Buon Ma Thuot Prison became a place to exile Vietnamese patriots. Now, visiting Buon Ma Thuot Prison, visitors will see the evidence of the crimes of the French colonialists.|||Through this, one can imagine the entire Buon Ma Thuot Prison with its harsh and brutal regime, not much different from the hell of the French colonialists.|||Time has passed, but these marks are still clearly imprinted in everyone's mind. When visiting here, looking at the shackles, one will feel heartbroken and pay tribute to the strong communist fighters who were not afraid to sacrifice and fought to victory, contributing to the nation's liberation from the dark night of slavery.|||Those who survived Buon Ma Thuot Prison became the nucleus of the August 1945 General Uprising and contributed significantly to the two resistance wars against the French and American imperialists. Buon Ma Thuot Prison was recognized as a historical monument in 1980.

title: Lang Sen Wetland Conservation Area
description: Located in the Dong Thap Muoi region, within Vinh Loi and Vinh Dai communes, Tan Hung district, Long An province. It is a diverse ecological area, typical of the flooded marshes with wild flora and fauna, including many species listed in Vietnam's Red Book.|||Lang Sen Wetland Conservation Area was established in January 2004, covering 5,030ha, with Cai He as the center of the core area. The conservation area has a special natural boundary, a 1,500ha island surrounded by the Vam Co Tay river, providing suitable habitats for aquatic plants and animals.|||The area is home to 156 wild plant species and 149 vertebrate species, including 13 listed in Vietnam's Red Book.|||Visitors can enjoy the pristine atmosphere, take a motorized boat trip through the wetlands, and experience local cuisine such as steamed snails and grilled fish.|||Lang Sen is a valuable area for biodiversity conservation, scientific research, and eco-tourism in the Mekong Delta region.

title: Duong Long Tower
description: Location: Duong Long Tower is located in Binh Hoa commune, Tay Son district, Binh Dinh province. Features: Duong Long Tower, also known as Nga Tower, consists of 3 towers, with the middle tower standing 24m tall and the two side towers standing 22m tall. This is one of the most beautiful remaining tower clusters in central Vietnam.|||From Highway 1A, turn towards Go Gang, 40km from Qui Nhon city and 270km from Da Nang city, then head west towards Phu Cat airport, turn left before the airport gate, and continue for about 9km to reach the site.|||The tower's body is made of bricks, with large stones at the corners and stone carvings for decoration. The tower's door faces east and is raised about 1.5m high, with large stone frames. The upper part of the tower is made of large stones stacked on top of each other. At the corners are large carvings of mythical creatures such as Garuda, Elephants, and Eagles. The wall surfaces are covered with large reliefs depicting scenes of dance, music, and ascetics.|||All decorative details on the tower are very large, carved on sandstone, with clear lines and well-preserved. Only the large stones on the roof have been displaced. The figures depicted have relatively large heads, wearing hats with high crowns. Notably, the tower's pinnacles are giant lotus flowers with multiple layers of petals pointing upwards.

title: Dalat Flower Garden
description: Location: Dalat Flower Garden is located at 2 Phu Dong Thien Vuong, on the road from Xuan Huong Lake to Dalat University. Characteristics: Dalat Flower Garden is a fairly complete collection of rare flowers from Vietnam and the world.|||The garden was established in 1966 and restored in 1985 to grow new flowers. There are over 300 species of flowers, including hundreds of types such as roses, chrysanthemums, gladiolus, orchids, hydrangeas, and mimosas... which bloom all year round.

title: Hung Temple Relic
description: Location: Situated on Nghia Linh mountain, Hy Cuong commune, Viet Tri city, Phu Tho province. Characteristics: The temple was built in the 15th century, and legend has it that this is where the eldest son of Lac Long Quan and Au Co ascended to the throne, taking the title of Hung Vuong and naming the country Van Lang.|||The Hung Temple relic is a complex of solemn architectural works on Nghia Linh mountain. From Hanoi, follow National Highway 2 to Viet Tri city (84km), then continue for about 10km to the Hang crossroads, turn left for 3km to reach the relic. The historical relic site of Hung Temple includes Ha Temple and a pagoda, Gien Temple, Trung Temple, Thuong Temple, and Hung Vuong's tomb.|||Hung Vuong's tomb: Legend has it that this is the tomb of the 6th Hung Vuong. After Thanh Dong defeated the An invaders and flew up to heaven, the king turned into a deity here.|||Ha Temple: From the foot of Hung mountain, turn through Dai Mon (temple gate) and climb 225 stone steps to reach Ha Temple and Thien Quang pagoda. The temple was built in the 15th century and is said to be where Au Co gave birth to a hundred eggs, which hatched into a hundred children. Au Co led 50 children up the mountain, while Lac Long Quan led 49 children down to the sea, leaving the eldest child to become the king, named Hung Vuong, and establish the capital in Phong Chau, naming the country Van Lang. In front of Ha Temple is a thousand-year-old tree, where President Ho Chi Minh, on his way to take over the capital, talked to soldiers of the vanguard division: "The Hung kings have built the country, and we must work together to protect it."|||Trung Temple: From Ha Temple, climb 168 more stone steps to reach Trung Temple. Legend has it that this is where the Hung kings established a resting place and discussed matters with their nobles. It was also here that Prince Lang Lieu offered Chung cake and Giay cake to his father, the king, during the Tet festival.|||Thuong Temple: From Trung Temple, walk 102 more stone steps to reach Thuong Temple, where the Hung kings performed rituals to Heaven, Earth, Mountain Spirit, and Rice Spirit. This is also where Thuc Phan, after receiving the throne from the 18th Hung Vuong, erected a stone pillar, vowing to take care of the temple and preserve the Hung dynasty's legacy.|||Gien Temple: Located at the foot of the mountain to the southeast. Inside the temple is the Ngoc Well, which is full of water all year round and crystal clear. The temple enshrines Ngoc Hoa and Tien Dung, the beloved daughters of the 18th Hung Vuong, who often combed their hair and admired themselves in this well.|||Today, near Cong Quan (a place to welcome pilgrims), there is a relatively large Hung Vuong Museum built to display many artifacts from the time of the Hung Vuong, showcasing the stone, bronze, and iron ages.

title: Hai Phong City
description: Area: 1,527.4 km² Population: 1,963,300 people (2015). Districts and rural districts: - Urban districts: Hong Bang, Ngo Quyen, Le Chan, Kien An, Hai An, Duong Kinh, Do Son. - Rural districts: Thuy Nguyen, An Duong, An Lao, Kien Thuy, Tien Lang, Vinh Bao, Cat Hai, Bach Long Vi. Ethnic groups: Vietnamese (Kinh), Hoa, Tay, Nung...|||Natural conditions|||Hai Phong City, one of Vietnam's major tourist centers, is located on the East - Pacific coast; to the north it borders Quang Ninh Province, to the east it borders the East Sea, to the west it borders Hai Duong Province, and to the south it borders Thai Binh Province.|||Hai Phong is in a tropical monsoon climate zone, with an average temperature of 23ºC - 24ºC, and an annual rainfall of 1,600 – 1,800mm; the weather is warm all year round, with lush greenery throughout the four seasons.|||Tourism development potential|||The Cai Beo archaeological site (Cat Ba) shows that this land has been inhabited for over 6,000 years. Today, Hai Phong still preserves many historical relics, scenic spots, temples, pagodas, and the unique and famous Do Son Buffalo Fighting Festival.|||Hai Phong is on the Hanoi - Hai Phong - Ha Long Bay tourist route. Hai Phong has Do Son resort stretching 5km out to sea. From Do Son, tourists can take a high-speed boat to visit Cat Ba Island and National Park, Bai Tu Long Bay and Ha Long Bay (Quang Ninh).|||Transportation|||Hai Phong has a large seaport on the East - West, North - South international shipping route. It is an important transportation hub with a system of waterways, roads, railways, and domestic and international airports.|||- Road: Hai Phong is 102km from Hanoi on National Highway 5. Hai Phong is on National Highway 10: Thai Binh - Hai Phong - Quang Ninh.|||- Railway: There are daily trains from Hanoi - Hai Phong – Hanoi.|||- Waterway: There are Hai Phong - Ha Long - Cat Ba - Mong Cai waterway routes.|||- Air: There are daily flights from Ho Chi Minh City - Hai Phong.

title: Quan De Temple
description: Location: Quan De Temple is located on the Bac Lieu river, in Vinh Trach commune, Bac Lieu city, Bac Lieu province. Characteristics: The temple is an architectural complex that carries a distinctive ethnic Chinese identity.|||The Chinese people in Bac Lieu consider Quan De Temple a cultural symbol of their nation. The temple was built in 1835, initiated by the salt owner Chau Quai who mobilized contributions. The temple retains many large boards, some of which were carved by Chinese artisans from 1865 to 1897. There is also a valuable altar.|||The temple worships Guan Yunchang from the Three Kingdoms period. In the main hall, there is a statue of Guan Gong in armor, flanked by Guan Ping and Zhou Cang. According to the Chinese in Bac Lieu, they choose to worship Guan Gong because they value integrity in business. The temple is where they come to pray, and even make business deals. The temple also worships the Heavenly Empress and the God of Wealth. This is one of the popular tourist attractions in Bac Lieu city.

title: Hanoi City
description: Area: 3,324.5 km² Population: 7,216,000 people (2015) Districts: - 12 Districts: Hoan Kiem, Ba Dinh, Dong Da, Hai Ba Trung, Tay Ho, Thanh Xuan, Cau Giay, Long Bien, Hoang Mai, Ha Dong, Nam Tu Liem, Bac Tu Liem. - 1 Town: Son Tay. - 17 Rural Districts: Dong Anh, Soc Son, Thanh Tri, Gia Lam (old Hanoi); Ba Vi, Chuong My, Dan Phuong, Hoai Duc, My Duc, Phu Xuyen, Phuc Tho, Quoc Oai, Thach That, Thanh Oai, Thuong Tin, Ung Hoa (old Ha Tay) and Me Linh (from Vinh Phuc). Ethnic groups: Vietnamese (Kinh), Chinese, Muong, Tay, Dao... Hanoi is the Capital of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam.|||Natural conditions|||Geographical location: Hanoi is located in the Red River Delta, bordering the provinces of Thai Nguyen and Vinh Phuc to the north; Ha Nam and Hoa Binh to the south; Bac Giang, Bac Ninh and Hung Yen to the east; Hoa Binh and Phu Tho to the west.|||Hanoi is located on the right bank of the Da River and on both sides of the Red River, with a favorable position and geographical location for a political, economic, cultural, scientific center and an important traffic hub of Vietnam.|||Climate: Hanoi's climate is typical of North Vietnam, characterized by a warm tropical monsoon climate with hot, rainy summers and cold, dry winters. Located in the tropics, Hanoi receives abundant solar radiation throughout the year with high temperatures. The average annual solar radiation is 122.8 kcal/cm2, and the average annual air temperature is 23.6°C. Influenced by the sea, Hanoi has high humidity and significant rainfall. The average annual relative humidity is 79%, with an average annual rainfall of 1,800mm and around 114 rainy days per year.|||The climate in Hanoi is marked by distinct hot and cold seasons. From May to September, it's hot and rainy with an average temperature of 29.2°C. From November to March, it's cold and dry with an average temperature of 15.2°C. There are two transitional periods (April and October), giving Hanoi a clear four-season cycle of Spring, Summer, Autumn, and Winter. Each season brings its own unique beauty. Autumn is the best time for tourism in Hanoi.|||The geography of former Ha Tay, now merged with Hanoi, has its own characteristics, forming sub-regions with different climates: mountainous, hilly, and plain areas. However, the differences in weather and temperature across Hanoi's regions are not significant.|||Terrain: Hanoi has two main types of terrain: plains and hills and mountains. The plain terrain mainly lies in the old Hanoi area and some districts in the east of Ha Tay (former), accounting for about 3/4 of the natural area, located on the right bank of the Da River, on both sides of the Red River and its tributaries. Most of the hills and mountains are in Soc Son, Ba Vi, Quoc Oai, and My Duc districts. Some high peaks include: Ba Vi 1,281m; Gia De 707m; Chan Chim 462m; Thanh Lanh 427m; Thien Tru 378m; Ba Tuong 334m; Soc Son 308m; Nui Boc 245m; Duc Linh 294m…|||Waterways: Hanoi is located next to two major rivers in the North: the Da River and the Red River. The Red River is 1,183km long, originating from Yunnan, China. The section of the Red River passing through Hanoi is 163km long, accounting for about one-third of its length in Vietnam, which is approximately 550km. Besides these two major rivers, Hanoi is also home to other rivers such as Duong, Cau, Ca Lo, Day, Nhu, Tich, To Lich, Kim Nguu, and Buu.|||There are many lakes and ponds in Hanoi. Famous lakes in the inner city of Hanoi include West Lake, Truc Bach, Hoan Kiem, Thien Quang, and Bay Mau. Dozens of lakes and ponds are located in the old Hanoi area: Kim Lien Lake, Lien Dam Lake, Van Tri pond... and many large lakes in the old Ha Tay area: Ngai Son - Dong Mo, Suoi Hai, Meo Gu, Xuan Khanh, Tuy Lai, Quan Son...|||Residents|||As of April 1, 1999, the residents of Hanoi and Ha Tay (former) were primarily Vietnamese (Kinh) people, making up 99.1% of the population; other ethnic groups such as Dao, Muong, and Tay made up 0.9%.|||In 2006, also in Hanoi and Ha Tay (former), urban residents accounted for 41.1% and rural residents for 58.1%; the female population made up 50.7% and males 49.3%.|||The current average population density across the city is 1875 people/km2; approximately 2.5 million people are engaged in agricultural production.|||Transportation|||From the capital Hanoi, you can travel to every region of the country with ease using various convenient transportation options.|||No road: Noi Bai International Airport (located in Soc Son district, about 35km from Hanoi center). Gia Lam Airport, formerly the main airport of Hanoi before the 1970s. Now it is a helicopter airport serving service flights, including tourist services.|||Road: Interprovincial passenger cars depart from Southern, Gia Lam, Luong Yen, Nuoc Ngam, and My Dinh bus stations to all regions across the country on National Highway 1A north-south; National Highway 2 to Vinh Phuc, Phu Tho, Tuyen Quang, Ha Giang; National Highway 3 to Thai Nguyen, Cao Bang; National Highway 5 to Hai Phong, Quang Ninh; National Highway 6 to Hoa Binh, Son La, Lai Chau…|||Railway: Hanoi is the junction of 5 domestic railway lines. There is a railway line connecting to Beijing (China) and to many European countries.|||Waterway: Hanoi is an important traffic hub with Den Ferry to Hung Yen, Nam Dinh, Thai Binh, Viet Tri; Ham Tu Quan Ferry to Pha Lai.|||Culture – Tourism|||Hanoi currently has over 4,000 historical sites and scenic spots, of which more than 1,000 have been nationally ranked (including hundreds of sites recently incorporated from Ha Tay and Me Linh). These include hundreds of temples, pagodas, architectural works, and famous scenic spots.|||Hanoi is a major tourist hub in Vietnam. Visitors have the opportunity to explore numerous cultural and artistic architectural works built over generations, throughout the country's history of national construction and defense. There are beautiful and charming natural landscapes; traditional craft villages that have existed for centuries; traditional festivals - cultural products that distill many spiritual values... These will be attractive tourist products.|||It's not that Hanoi only had these favorable conditions at the end of the 20th century. Long ago, when King Ly Thai To moved the capital from Hoa Lu (Ninh Binh) to Dai La to establish Thang Long in the seventh month of the Canh Tuat year (1010), in the "Declaration of the Capital Move", the founder of the Ly Dynasty (1010-1225) also illuminated the path for Thang Long - Hanoi.

title: Sa Lon Pagoda (Chen Kieu Pagoda)
description: Location: Sa Lon Pagoda is located on National Highway 1A, 12km from Soc Trang City, heading from Soc Trang to Bac Lieu. Characteristics: The pagoda's unique feature is the use of ceramic pieces (cups, plates) attached to the walls for decoration, hence it's also called Chen Kieu Pagoda.|||Initially, the pagoda was built with wood and forest leaves. During the war, the main hall was destroyed by bombing. The pagoda was rebuilt in 1969 and completed in 1980.|||The unique ceramic tiling technique creates a very impressive appearance. The pagoda also preserves a rare collection of precious woodwork, carved and inlaid with great finesse, purchased from the assets of the Bac Lieu noble in 1947.

title: Bach Thuan Garden Village
description: Location: Bach Thuan garden village is located in Vu Thu district, Thai Binh province. Characteristics: It is a prosperous garden village with fruit and ornamental gardens.|||The village is 20km from Thai Binh city, heading towards Tan De bridge to Nam Dinh. This is a prosperous garden village, with a riverside area for growing mulberries for sericulture and bananas, sugarcane. Inside the village are fruit and ornamental gardens.|||Visiting Bach Thuan, tourists seem to enter a mini park with various shades of color... Along the village road are the dark green of ngau and the fresh green of hoa. Nature has favored Bach Thuan to develop traditional gardening. Here, there are all kinds of flowers and fruits throughout the year: apples, pears, jujubes, plums, lemons, longans, rambutans, pomelos, grapefruits, bananas, jackfruits...|||Alongside the fruit gardens are ornamental and bonsai gardens. Each type of ornamental plant has its own unique shape with different names depending on the owner's pruning.|||During the flooding season, the village road of Bach Thuan is inundated, turning into small rivers, and people travel by boat from house to house. It's wonderful when tourists sit on small boats visiting the garden, picking and tasting the sweet fruits.|||Bach Thuan is also an ancient rural village, typical of those in the Red River Delta. It has Tu Van and Bach Tinh pagodas, which have been ranked as historical sites by the State, and is a tourist destination for visitors to pay respects and enjoy the scenery. Domestic and international tourists are very interested in the landscape and ecological environment of Bach Thuan garden village.|||

title: Long Khanh Pagoda
description: Location: No. 141 Tran Cao Van Street, Quy Nhon City, Binh Dinh Province. Characteristics: Built during the reign of King Le Du Tong (18th century), Long Khanh Pagoda was a place for spreading Buddhist faith in the region at that time.|||The main hall is solemnly decorated with a 2m-high copper statue of Buddha Shakyamuni in the center, cast at the pagoda in 1960. The 17m-high Amitabha Buddha statue in the front yard was erected in 1972. The pagoda currently preserves two precious artifacts:|||- Thai Binh Hong Chung (Hong Thai bell) cast in 1805, during the reign of King Gia Long.|||- The "Long Khanh Tu" emblem stamp was printed in 1813 during the reign of King Gia Long.

title: Oc Eo Ancient Ruins
description: Location: Oc Eo ancient ruins are located in the Sap - Ba The mountain region, Thoai Son district, An Giang province. Characteristics: Oc Eo ancient city is a medieval commercial port that sank underground, discovered when locals dug the Ba The canal.|||This is a well-known site, both domestically and internationally: a large ancient relic complex, closely associated with the material remains of the Funan Kingdom, a powerful state in Southeast Asia about two thousand years ago.|||In addition to the area considered as "Oc Eo city" with an area of 4,500ha, there are several other areas in the Southwest region such as Dong Thap Muoi, Chau Doc, Kien Giang..., which still hold many secrets for researchers and archaeologists.|||Today, Oc Eo ancient ruins not only welcome many collectors and archaeologists to study and explore but also attract numerous domestic and international tourists to visit the discovered artifacts and traces of a glorious development period of An Giang land in particular and the Mekong Delta in general.

title: Linh Phong Pagoda (Nunnery)
description: Location: Linh Phong Pagoda (Nunnery) is located on Hoang Hoa Tham Street, Da Lat city. Features: The pagoda covers an area of 400m² and is divided into 5 architectural sections in the style of rural temples in Central Vietnam. The double roof is curved and decorated with the four sacred animals (dragon, unicorn, turtle, phoenix) winding between the mountain wind and clouds.|||The pagoda was built in 1944 on a small peak hidden among the pine trees. Initially, it was a simple Buddhist prayer house with a corrugated iron roof and wooden walls, led by Reverend Thich Bich Nguyen.|||From 1948 to 1962, Abbess Thich Nu Tu Huong renovated and built Linh Phong Ni Tu, a majestic and splendid pagoda as it stands today. The three-gate entrance is made of green stone, embodying the philosophy of 'Empty, False, and Middle.' The main hall enshrines a 1.8m-high statue of Amitabha Buddha. On either side, the front section enshrines statues of Quan The Am Bodhisattva and Dai The Chi Bodhisattva in shiny bronze, while the rear section honors the Ancestors and Spirits. Behind the pagoda, on a hill, a small 3-story hexagonal stupa will serve as the resting place for the Abbess when she passes away.

title: Buu Nghiem Pagoda
description: Location: Ly Thai To Street, Pleiku City, Gia Lai Province. Characteristics: A place of Buddhist worship and the office of the Buddhist committee of Gia Lai Province.|||The pagoda is located on Ly Thai To Street, about 200m west of Cho Moi market. It was built in 1964 on an area of 3565m2. The pagoda has undergone several restorations, including in 1978 when the main hall was renovated. A large-scale restoration was carried out in 2004 by Abbot Tu Huong.|||The pagoda gate consists of a main gate and a side gate. The side gate is on the left of the main gate. The main gate has a three-door gate, made of concrete, and a relatively sturdy iron door. On the gate, there are two pairs of couplets on a yellow background with red letters.|||The Tam Bao building has a three-tiered roof. The outer courtyard has two towers on either side; the right tower houses a one-ton bell, 1.60m high, cast in 1974. In front of the pagoda is a 2m-high statue of Quan Am. The first floor of the pagoda is the ancestor worship area; where Patriarch Dat Ma and Linh Nam and Linh Nu are worshiped. The 18-arm statue of Chuan De Vuong Bo Tat is in the center. The second floor, with a large area, is the main hall where Buddha Shakyamuni is worshiped, and on either side are Manjusri and Samantabhadra. This is also where sutras are chanted and dharma is taught to Buddhists on special days.|||Buu Nghiem Pagoda has made significant contributions to the Buddhist work in the province. It is currently managed by Abbot Thich Quang Phuc.

title: Suoi Tien Tourist Area
description: Location: Hanoi Highway, Tan Phu Ward, District 9, Ho Chi Minh City Features: Suoi Tien Cultural Tourist Area is located at the northeastern gateway of Saigon, built and renovated with the purpose of combining tourism with cultural and historical education. It is a 200,000m2 S-shaped hill area, with a stream in the middle and many underground water sources winding through the 2,000m length.|||Suoi Tien consists of 12 main areas, with an investment of 50 billion dong. Every year, Suoi Tien welcomes 1.5 to 2 million visitors.|||The uniqueness of Suoi Tien lies in its historical and legendary nature, with model clusters inspired by folk tales and Eastern philosophical ideas.|||With the dream of peace and prosperity, Suoi Tien was built as 4 lands based on the legend of the four sacred animals: Dragon, Unicorn, Turtle, and Phoenix, each land corresponding to an element in the five elements: metal, wood, water, fire, and earth as the center.|||The poetic beauty combining harmoniously between nature and human-made structures, ancient and modern architecture, and the fresh air have made Suoi Tien a truly attractive recreational and entertainment area for city dwellers and distant tourists.|||Kim Long Tho|||This is a world of legends and fairy tales. Upon crossing the Tu Linh Bridge, visitors are immediately greeted by a giant 400m-long Dragon. The underwater aquarium features over 500 species of marine life with vibrant colors. As visitors journey through the Dragon's belly, they arrive at Long Quy an hidden spring, reminiscent of the legend of the golden sword presented to King Le by the dragon turtle. The Dragon's tail leads to Au Lac Hill, where Lac Long Quan and Au Co first met, got married, and had 100 eggs hatch into 100 children, symbolizing the pride of the Vietnamese people as descendants of the Dragon and Phoenix. Next, visitors will visit Thien Island, a place to commemorate ancestors and national heroes who contributed to building and defending the country. On Long Hoa Island, visitors can see the gathering of Immortals, and learn about the legend of the Diem Hong Conference during the Tran dynasty. After crossing the "O Thuc" bridge, visitors will arrive at Tien Island, where the cowherd Nguu Lang and the weaver girl Chuc Nu meet.|||Moc Lan Tho|||Moc Lan Tho is a land area near the main gate, heading north. Passing through the Fairy Gate, visitors feel like stepping into a majestic primeval forest. Alongside the stream are Cau Kieu, Tien Well, Prehistoric Cave, Nine-Stream Waterfall, and the Temple of Goddess Quan The Am Bo Tat.|||A miniature pristine world, where you can have refreshing and tranquil moments. Next to it is the Frog God stage, symbolizing good luck, where visitors can enjoy special performances before skating at the Patin Park with winding paths under a shady garden.|||Thuy Quy Tho|||Thuy Quy Tho is a vast plain with lush longan forests, making it an ideal spot for picnics, camping, and outdoor activities.|||Hoang Phong Tho|||The land known as Hoa Phung Tho is vast with rows of poplar trees and green grass. This place also displays hundreds of rare and precious animals, making the natural scenery even more vibrant. In the distance, the 20m-high Bodhi tree stands tall with the statue of Buddha Shakyamuni sitting serenely beneath it. A short walk away is Son Cung, featuring famous scenic spots of the country such as: Hai Van Pass, Ha Long Bay, Hon Phu Tu, and folk legend-inspired sculptures in the caves... all recreated here.|||The games|||Suoi Tien not only features traditional models but also offers a variety of modern and rich games. There are children's games like ball house, spring rides, wooden horses, electric cars, trains... and new, adventurous, thrilling yet absolutely safe games such as: Flying bicycles that take visitors to observe the 'Crocodile Farm' from above with over 1,500 crocodiles; With the Standing Ferris wheel, visitors can see the whole of Suoi Tien from a 30m height; And it's even more exciting to fly into space with a self-controlled Boeing at a height of 9m.|||

title: Phu Lang Pottery Village
description: Location: Phu Lang commune, Que Vo district, Bac Ninh province, about 60km north of Hanoi. Characteristics: One of the traditional pottery craft villages in ancient Kinh Bac|||Unlike other pottery products made from green clay in Tho Ha (Bac Giang) or white clay in Bat Trang (Hanoi), Phu Lang pottery is made from red pink clay taken from Thong Vat and Cung Khem (Bac Giang). The clay is then dried, mixed, and pounded into small pieces.|||The products are shaped on a hand-turning wheel, and two people are needed to operate it. The pottery is then dried, shaped, and glazed. The glaze is made from a mixture of forest tree ash, quicklime, crushed pebbles, and white alluvial mud.|||Phu Lang pottery is known for its unique glaze and technique of firing with wood, creating distinctive patterns on the surface. The products are fired at 1000°C for 3 days and 3 nights. The clay turns into a brown color with two main glaze colors: yellow-brown and dark brown.|||The pottery products include three main types: ceremonial pottery (incense burners, altars...), household pottery (jars, vases...), and art pottery (animal-shaped vases...).|||Visiting Phu Lang pottery village, tourists can learn about the history of the craft and create their own pottery products.

title: Phu Quoc Prison
description: Location: An Thoi town, Phu Quoc island district, Kien Giang province, about 30km southeast of Duong Dong town. Characteristics: Phu Quoc Prison was also known as the "Hell on Earth" because the US - Ngo Dinh Diem regime used many brutal torture methods here, such as nailing, cages with iron spikes, iron grid pressing, and burying alive, to break the will of revolutionary soldiers.|||In 1950, the French colonialists built Cây Dừa prison camp in Phu Quoc, covering about 40ha, with four areas A, B, C, D, to detain anti-French prisoners. In July 1954, after the Geneva Agreement, France returned most of the prisoners in this camp and Cây Dừa camp was closed.|||In 1955, Ngo Dinh Diem, the first president of the Republic of Vietnam, renovated the old Cây Dừa camp into Cây Dừa reeducation camp, also known as Cây Dừa prison, to detain communist prisoners. In 1966, the Republic of Vietnam expanded the prison to 400ha with 4 areas: A, B, C, D, including 400 cells, and named it Phu Quoc Prison. By 1972, the prison had 14 areas, each divided into 4 sub-areas, with 11 cells each. All cells had iron trusses, zinc roofs, and zinc walls. Phu Quoc Prison became the largest prison in South Vietnam, strictly guarded with 10-15 layers of barbed wire, 14 guard towers with machine guns, and many mobile guard posts.|||From 1967 to 1973, over 40,000 prisoners were detained here, more than 4,000 died, and tens of thousands were injured or disabled. However, with their bravery and strong will, prisoners at Phu Quoc Prison organized 42 successful escapes in various forms: climbing over fences, attacking guards during forced labor, digging tunnels...|||Today, Phu Quoc Prison relic includes a monument in the shape of a clenched fist - a symbol of the prisoners' spirit, a martyrs' cemetery, a museum, and an outdoor display area. Visitors can watch documentaries, observe models, exhibits, and simulated scenes of brutal torture.|||Phu Quoc Prison was recognized as a national historical site in 1996 and a special national site in March 2015.

title: Hoan Kiem Lake
description: Hoan Kiem Lake, also known as Gucm Lake, is a shining jewel of Hanoi Capital. This place has become a famous destination attracting tourists and closely linked to the cultural life of Hanoian people for generations.|||Hoan Kiem Lake has several other names such as Ta Vong Lake, Luc Thuy Lake (green water lake) or Thuy Quan Lake (because it was once a place to train naval forces). In the 15th century, the lake was renamed Hoan Kiem Lake (returning the sword), associated with the legend of returning the precious sword to the golden turtle of King Le Thai To. Since then, Hoan Kiem Lake has been preserved and become a historically and culturally significant site of the capital and the whole country.|||The lake is an ideal meeting place for all four seasons: vibrant with peach blossoms and traditional festivals in spring, refreshing with cool breeze in summer, romantic with weeping willows in autumn, or dreamy in the cold air of winter.|||Located on the central mound of the lake, the Turtle Tower is the most attractive highlight of Hoan Kiem Lake. Built from 1884, with French architecture combined with ancient Vietnamese feudal architecture, the Turtle Tower stands out in the ancient, mossy and tranquil lake. Around the lake, there are many other famous historical sites such as Hoa Phong Tower, But Tower, The Huc Bridge, Ngoc Son Temple, Ba Kieu Temple…|||Visitors can choose various means of transportation such as motorbikes, cyclos, electric cars or on foot to explore and feel the beautiful scenery around the lake.|||In recent years, on weekend days, the area around the lake has become a walking street with many attractive activities such as street music, folk games… attracting a large number of tourists. Walking around the walking street and spending time enjoying the famous cuisine in the center of the old town will be an unforgettable experience for visitors to Hanoi.

title: One Pillar Pagoda
description: Location: One Pillar Pagoda Street, Ba Dinh District, Hanoi. Feature: The pagoda has a unique architecture, designed to look like a lotus flower rising from the water.|||The pagoda's original name is Dien Huu (long-lasting blessings), built in 1049 during the reign of King Ly Thai Tong. According to legend, the king was childless at an old age and often visited temples to pray for a son. One night, he dreamt that the Goddess of Mercy, Quan Am, appeared on a lotus flower in a square pond west of Thang Long Citadel, holding a boy and offering him to the king. Soon after, the queen gave birth to a son. The king then built the One Pillar Pagoda in the likeness of his dream to worship Quan Am.|||The One Pillar Pagoda is a National Temple related to the king who founded the Ly Dynasty. It was built near the Citadel of Thang Long. Every full moon and the first day of the month, the king would come to make offerings and pray for blessings.|||According to historical records, the pagoda was first built in 1049: "In the winter of the 10th month, the Dien Huu Pagoda was built. Previously, the king had a dream in which he saw the Buddha Quan Am sitting on a lotus throne, leading him up to the throne. Upon waking, the king told his officials, and some thought it was an unlucky omen. A monk named Thien Tue advised the king to build a pagoda and set up a stone pillar in the middle of the land, with a lotus throne like the one seen in the dream. Monks walked around it reciting sutras, praying for the king's longevity. Hence, it was called Dien Huu Pagoda (long-lasting blessings). In the spring of 1070, during the second year of Than Vo, the king wrote a 1.6-tranche Buddha character on a stone slab."|||The second construction took place in 1105 when the king renovated the Dien Huu Pagoda: "In the autumn of the 9th month, two white chom towers were built at the Dien Huu Pagoda... At that time, the king restored the pagoda to make it more beautiful than before, dug the Lien Hoa Dai (Lotus) pond, also called Linh Chieu pond. Outside the pond was a gallery with paintings, and outside the gallery was another pond called Bich Tri. A bridge was built for crossing. A stupa was built in front of the pagoda. Before entering the pagoda, there was a green stone pavilion, 8 fathoms high, in front of the gate. The pagoda was a complex of impressive architecture with an original and beautiful aesthetic that was destroyed by war and became overgrown during the Ming invasion.|||Many ancient documents reveal that the magical pillar was 20m high, described and recorded in detail by the Binh Bo Thuong Thu Nguyen Cong Bat in the bia Sung Dien Linh at Long Doi Nam Ha Pagoda: "Open the Dien Huu Pagoda gate in the western garden. The traces follow the old plan, considering today's Royal intention. The Linh Chieu pond fragrance, in the middle of the pond rises a stone pillar. On the stone pillar, a thousand-petaled lotus flower blooms. On the flower, a red temple is built. Inside the temple, a golden statue is placed, and outside the pond, a gallery encloses it. Outside the gallery is another Bich Tri pond, a curved bridge for crossing, in the front yard two bridges on the right and left sides build stupa...".

title: Military History Museum (Army Museum)
description: Located at 28A Dien Bien Phu Street, near Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, Ba Dinh District, Hanoi.|||The museum showcases artifacts and documents introducing the process of birth and growth of Vietnam's people's armed forces through historical periods.|||The Military History Museum (Army Museum) was established on December 22, 1959, on an area of about 10,000m², with an exhibition area of 2,000m².|||The exhibition content is divided into 6 parts:|||The history of the nation and the birth of the Vietnam People's Army.|||The resistance war against French colonialists.|||The resistance war against American imperialists.|||The Vietnam People's Army advancing to a regular and modern force.|||The people and army united - a hundred battles, a hundred victories.|||The outdoor exhibition area features planes, tanks, heavy artillery, armored vehicles, missiles, mortars, bombs... all large-sized artifacts.|||Notably, there are maps and sand tables of the historic Dien Bien Phu and Ho Chi Minh campaigns. Precious artifacts about battles and heroic soldiers in the armed forces.

title: Perfume Pagoda Festival
description: Time: From 6th day of the first lunar month to the end of the third lunar month. Location: Huong Son commune, My Duc district, Hanoi. Worship object: Goddess of Mercy Quan Am. Characteristics: Dragon dance, boat racing.|||The Perfume Pagoda Festival lasts from the 6th day of the first lunar month to the end of the third lunar month. Visitors can travel by road on the route: Ha Dong - Van Dinh - Huong Son or from Phu Ly town, following the Day River to Ben Duc - Yen Vi - Huong Son.|||In the Vietnamese mind, Huong Son is considered the realm of Buddha. The Perfume Pagoda is a place of worship for Goddess Quan Am. On the 6th day of the first lunar month is the opening day of the festival, featuring a dragon dance in the Trinh temple yard, and dragon boat racing on the Yen stream.|||The festival spans three routes: Huong Tich, Tuyet Son and Long Van. The Perfume Pagoda festival is most crowded from the 15th to the 20th day of the second lunar month (main festival). The mountain road from Ngoai pagoda to Trong pagoda is always bustling with groups of people going up and down.|||Visiting the Perfume Pagoda festival is not only an opportunity to pray to Buddha but also a chance to admire the beauty of the rivers and mountains, and to discover the numerous large and small works of the Huong Son relic site, which has become a cultural heritage of the nation.

title: Bo Da Pagoda
description: Location: Bo Da Pagoda is located at the northern foot of Phuong Hoang Mountain, in Thuong Lat village, Tien Son commune, Viet Yen district, Bac Giang province. Characteristics: Bo Da Pagoda is one of the centers of Buddhism of the Truc Lam Tam To sect.|||Built in the Ly dynasty - 11th century and rebuilt in the early 18th century, Bo Da Pagoda is a collection of relics including the main pagoda (Tu An Tu) and two temples dedicated to Duc Thanh Hoa and Thach Tuong Dai Vuong.|||The Buddhist scriptures are placed on 8 racks, each rack holding 4 volumes of 240 wooden blocks, totaling nearly 2,000 blocks. Each block, used for carving the scriptures, measures on average 50cm in length, 25cm in width, and 2.5cm in thickness. To display the entire collection of ancient scriptures, a space of 250m² would be needed to lay out the wooden blocks. The scriptures were carved on market wood, a type of wood commonly found in the local forest. Market wood is not only durable but also very light, making it ideal for carving and transporting the scriptures. The scriptures were compiled based on the idea of the sect founders, who also built the pagoda, aiming to create a Buddhist scripture to teach and leave a special Buddhist legacy for posterity. The scriptures reflect the thoughts of two major Buddhist streams in Asia: India and China.|||Bo Da Pagoda is very beautiful and serene, surrounded by earthen walls, and distant mountains and rivers. Many people call it the 'earth pagoda' due to its earthy brown color, from the water basin to the walls and old moss-covered bricks. Visitors can admire the statues of Truc Lam Tam To (Tran Nhan Tong, Phap Loa, and Huyen Quang). Notably, the pagoda preserves the oldest Buddhist scripture in Vietnam, carved on market wood.|||The wooden scripture discusses the characteristics of Chinese Buddhism as it was introduced to Vietnam, with its three main sects (Zen, Pure Land, and Esoteric Buddhism). The focus is on human suffering and liberation, particularly the Four Noble Truths - four wonderful truths of Buddhism: the truth of suffering, the truth of the origin of suffering, the truth of the cessation of suffering, and the truth of the path to the cessation of suffering. After nearly 300 years, the scriptures remain largely intact, with the wooden blocks still durable, beautiful, and unaffected by pests, despite not being treated with any preservatives. The scriptures are carved in Chinese characters with delicate strokes that remain clear and vibrant.|||The uniqueness of this special scripture attracts thousands of visitors each year to explore and pay respects. The scripture also mentions the realm of Nirvana, the cycle of rebirth and death, and explains the concepts of accumulating virtue and the realm of non-action. The scripture reflects the thoughts of Vietnamese Buddhism, particularly the influence of the Truc Lam Tam To Zen sect.

title: Buon Don
description: Located in Krong Na commune, Buon Don district, Dak Lak province, 42km northwest of Buon Ma Thuot city. Features: Buon Don has long been famous not only for its mountainous scenery and unique customs of the Central Highlands but also for its tradition of hunting and domesticating wild elephants.|||Buon Don boasts vast natural forests; the Srepok river, known for its fierce currents and thunderous waterfalls. Visiting Buon Don offers the chance to ride elephants up mountains, wade through streams, and swim in rivers; you can also enjoy local entertainment like archery, grilled fish, and rice wine; stay in simple, cozy houses built high up in ancient fig trees. If you're here in spring, don't miss the elephant racing festival in March... The natural beauty and peaceful life here are sure to delight visitors with refreshing and exciting experiences.|||Although the war has ended, it has left behind many historical sites such as: "Giao Lien Ferry", "Dead Letter Box", "Ho Chi Minh Trail".

title: Truc Bach Lake
description: Location: situated near West Lake, separated by Thanh Nien road, in Quan Thanh ward, Ba Dinh district, Hanoi. Features: Truc Bach Lake, along with West Lake, creates a beautiful landscape for Hanoi capital.|||According to the book 'Tay Ho Chi', Truc Bach Lake was formed in the 17th century when people from Yen Hoa (now Yen Phu) and Yen Quang (now Quan Thanh) villages built a dike to block the southeast corner of West Lake for fish farming. During the reign of Lord Trinh Giang (1729 - 1740), he took a piece of land south of the lake in Truc Yen village to build a palace for relaxation, called Truc Lam Vien. However, a few years later, the palace became a prison for female servants who committed crimes. These women had to weave silk to make a living, and their silk became famous throughout the region, known as 'Truc village silk', or 'Truc Bach'. From then on, the separated part of the lake near Truc Yen village was also called Truc Bach Lake. In the second year of Le Chieu Thong (1788), King Le Chieu Thong ordered the burning of Lord Trinh's palace, and Truc Lam Vien was also destroyed.|||Most tourists visiting Hanoi stop by Truc Bach Lake because there are many historical sites and unique architectural works around it. In the southwest corner of the lake is Quan Thanh Temple (on Thanh Nien road) - one of the Thang Long four towns; to the east are Than Quang Temple (on Ngu Xa street) and Chau Long Temple (on Chau Long street), built during the Tran dynasty, where Princess Khiet Co, daughter of King Tran Nhan Tong (1279-1293), practiced. To the northeast is An Tri Temple (on Pho Duc Chinh street), dedicated to Uy Do - a hero who led the people against the Yuan army; on a small island in the north of the lake is a stone stele recording the legend of Cau Nhi Temple.|||The area around Truc Bach Lake is planted with many trees, along with small gardens and green lawns. Visitors can enjoy a cup of coffee at a lakeside cafe; take a boat ride or paddleboat to admire the lake scenery; or stroll along Thanh Nien road, lined with phoenix and purple bauhinia trees, to let their spirits wander with the lake water and breeze.

title: Khai Dinh Tomb (Ung Tomb)
description: Location: Khai Dinh Tomb is located in Thuy Bang commune, Huong Thuy town, Thua Thien - Hue province, 10km from Hue city. Characteristics: The tomb has a smaller area compared to the tombs of previous kings but is more elaborate and majestic; it combines Eastern and Western architectural styles.|||King Khai Dinh ascended to the throne in 1916 and chose Chau Chu mountain (also known as Chau E), 10km from Hue, to build his tomb. The construction of the tomb began on September 4, 1920, and took 11 years to complete.|||Compared to the tombs of previous kings, Khai Dinh's tomb is much smaller in area (117m x 48.5m) but is very elaborate and took a long time to build. It is the result of the integration of Asian and European architectural styles, classical and modern Vietnamese architecture.|||The tomb is a rectangular structure with 127 steps, divided into several sections:|||To enter the tomb, one must climb 37 steps with large dragon-shaped stone walls, the largest in the country, and cross the courtyard with two rows of Tả and Hữu tòng tự. The two sides are built in a double-roofed style with eight slopes, but the roof frames are made of cement and steel.|||Climbing 29 more steps to the sacred courtyard, there is a octagonal stele house made of concrete and steel, with a stone stele inside. On either side of the courtyard, there are two rows of statues facing the center. In addition to the usual statues found in other tombs, there are six pairs of guardian statues, each pair made of rare stone and having a distinct expression. Two tall pillars stand at the entrance.|||After three levels of foundation, one reaches the worshiping hall. From the courtyard to the entrance of the hall, one must climb 15 more steps. The Khai Thanh Hall is the main room of the Thien Dinh palace, with many connected rooms. The walls are decorated with dense ceramic mosaics. Along with the wall paintings, the floor is paved with flower-patterned tiles, and the ceiling is painted with nine dragons hidden in clouds. The entire space creates a world of art.|||The back room of the Khai Thanh Hall is the main chamber, where King Khai Dinh's statue and his tomb are located. In the inner sanctum is the altar with the tablet of the deceased king.|||The Khai Dinh Tomb is a true masterpiece of art and architecture, enriching and diversifying the complex of tombs in Hue.|||Biography of King Khai Dinh|||King Khai Dinh (1916 - 1925) was the 12th king of the Nguyen dynasty, ascending to the throne at the age of 31.|||Khai Dinh's name was Nguyen Phuc Buu Dao, the only son of King Dong Khanh. After King Duy Tan was exiled to Africa, Buu Dao ascended to the throne and took the reign name Khai Dinh. From his ascension, he was obsessed with building palaces, mansions, and tombs for himself and the royal family, such as the Kien Trung palace, An Dinh palace, Truong An gate, Hien Nhon gate, and Chuong Duc gate, especially the Ung tomb (Khai Dinh's tomb). Khai Dinh reigned for 9 years before his death in 1925, at the age of 40.

title: Hoang Lien National Park
description: Location: Hoang Lien National Park is located in Sa Pa town, San Sa Ho, Lao Chai, Ta Van, Ban Ho communes, Sa Pa district; part of Van Ban district, Lao Cai province and two communes Muong Khoa, Than Thuoc, Than Uyen district, Lai Chau province.|||This is an ideal eco-tourism spot and suitable for scientific research.|||From Sa Pa town, visitors go through a winding slope about 20km to reach O Quy Ho Pass - Hoang Lien Pass, located in the National Park. Continuing on the winding path along the mountain slope at an altitude of over 1,000m above sea level, visitors can overlook the mountainous landscape - a forest with lush green trees covered with golden sunlight interweaving... dotted with rhododendron, wild orchids, and plum flowers... as if they are all blooming together; in the distance, ethnic villages appear through thin fog...|||Hoang Lien National Park is primarily a primeval forest with a dense, subtropical, high-mountain forest ecosystem and a rich, diverse wildlife system.|||Hoang Lien National Park - one of Vietnam's important special-use forests - has a core area of 29,845 hectares, including a high mountain system in the Hoang Lien Son range, with the 3,143m peak of Fansipan, and a buffer zone of 38,724 hectares, covering Sa Pa town, some communes of Sa Pa district, part of Van Ban district, Lao Cai province, and two communes of Than Uyen district, Lai Chau province.|||Regarding the forest vegetation, it has over 2,000 species with typical timber trees such as Tong Quan Su, Bo De, Do Quyen, Po Mu, wild plum..., of which about 66 species are listed in Vietnam's Red Book, including Bach Xanh, Thiet Sam, Thong Tre, red pine, Dinh Tung, De Tung..., and 32 rare species like Bach Xanh distributed in the limestone mountains of Ban Ho commune (Sa Pa), red pine found in Sa Pa commune (Sa Pa), Hoang Lien Sam (cold sam) distributed in the core zone of the national park (these three tree species are main materials to extract many precious medicines) and hundreds of medicinal herbs like Quy, Thuc, Do Trong, Hoang Lien Chan Chim, Do Quyen, Kim Giao... Besides, the precious fungus Linh Chi and Sa Pa nứa have been found here - mainly distributed in high mountain forests of China and Vietnam.|||Alongside a rich forest flora, the forest fauna system is also very diverse with 66 mammal species, including: black gibbon, yellow-cheeked gibbon, dwarf muntjac, silver-haired langur..., of which 16 species are listed in Vietnam's Red Book; 347 bird species such as spotted eagle, red-crested argus, golden-naped racket-tailed treepie...; 41 amphibian species and 61 reptile species, including the rare spiny frog which was just discovered in Vietnam.|||With such a rich forest ecosystem, Hoang Lien National Park is considered one of the most important biodiversity centers in Vietnam.|||In particular, it preserves many traditional cultural features of the ethnic communities living in the core and buffer zones of the National Park;|||These include the singing and dancing activities of the Mong, Dao, and Giay people with musical instruments such as: khaen, flute, horn, dan mo;|||The architectural styles of the houses of the ethnic people such as: the Mong people live in high places, the houses are usually low and wind-proof, the main building materials are wood,|||The Tay people's houses are in low-lying areas so they usually have stilt houses, with roofs covered with straw or hay, which have been replaced with tiles today.|||Coming to Hoang Lien National Park, you are in an attractive eco-tourism environment. Here, you will experience the moments of spring - summer - autumn - winter in just one hour; see the sun rays through the dense foliage, through the misty fog shining down on the lush grasslands; admire the swaying bamboo clusters whenever the wind blows... all leave a deep impression on visitors, but perhaps the most impressive is the feeling of sleeping overnight on the mountain slope to immerse yourself in the majestic nature of the Hoang Lien Son range, listening to the flowing streams, the waterfalls... and in this vast, spacious space, you feel so small. Besides, visitors can also participate in village tours: come and stay at the ethnic people's houses, you will do household chores with the homeowners, in the evening gather at the communal cultural house for cultural exchange. Visitors can also play traditional sports with local people such as: stick pushing, archery, tug of war, stilts... or visit villages, rice mills, terraced fields, cham cultivation... of ethnic people. Especially, the "Conquer the Peak of Fansipan" climbing competition is held here with a national scale for domestic and international athletes. The organization of the competition aims to introduce to domestic and international friends about the Hoang Lien Son range with Fansipan peak - the roof of Indochina, about Sa Pa tourist site and Hoang Lien National Park - ASEAN Heritage Park.

title: Moc Chau Highlands
description: Located in Moc Chau district, Son La province, about 200km northwest of Hanoi on National Highway 6. Moc Chau highlands stretches out with rolling tea hills, vast grasslands, and herds of dairy cows roaming freely in the evening forest...|||At an altitude of 1050m above sea level, Moc Chau is a large highland spanning approximately 80km long and 25km wide, with 1600ha of grasslands. It is considered a place with the most concentrated tourism resources in Son La and the Northwest - North region. The climate is a special tourism resource of Moc Chau. In the center of Moc Chau highlands, there is a microclimate zone with a cool summer with an average temperature of 20ºC and a dry winter.|||Visitors to Moc Chau will have a beautiful impression of this highland through historical sites such as Son Moc Huong cave, pine forest, Chien Vien pagoda, Dai Yem waterfall, Phieng Luong peak, and cultural villages of Mong and Dao people in Van Ho with songs, dances, traditional instruments, ethnic specialties, and handicrafts.|||Come to Moc Chau highlands with vast grasslands and flowers to find the serenity of your soul and the love for life.

title: Bang Hot Mineral Water Spring
description: Location: Bang hot mineral water spring is located in Kim Thuy commune, Le Thuy district, 60km west of Dong Hoi city. Characteristics: Bang mineral water has many medicinal effects, considered rare and very good for treating some human diseases.|||From Dong Hoi city, go southwest for 60km, or from Truong Son road, turn west about 20km to reach the eco-tourism area and Bang hot mineral water spring. A large green hillside over 70ha with a fresh and cool environment, strange and attractive scenery, wild and charming nature. Especially, there is a winding stream with mineral water flowing endlessly, both exposed and mysterious. The mineral water temperature increases to 1050C at the source, releasing misty vapor like a magical land. Bang mineral water has many medicinal effects, evaluated by scientists as rare and very good for treating some human diseases.|||COSEVCO Tourism Company (under the Central Vietnam Construction Corporation) manages, invests and gradually exploits this eco-tourism area and Bang mineral water source. The roads are convenient, and the main roads are paved. Electricity is supplied fully day and night. The company offers services such as outdoor and indoor mineral water bathing, mud bathing, physical therapy, foot soaking, rest, egg boiling, restaurants, guesthouses, forest tours and many other interesting services. Bottled Bang mineral water is available in most provinces and cities nationwide and is increasingly consumed due to its positive effects. Visitors from near and far come to visit, travel, learn and treat diseases at this Bang hot mineral water spring throughout 4 seasons.|||Quang Binh province and COSEVCO Tourism and Mineral Water Company are gradually investing and exploiting this area, creating attractive and useful services for visitors. The goal is to build without disrupting the natural landscape and ecological environment. The works created by humans to improve and diversify services must be closely tied to nature, convenient and rustic, honoring the true values of this mineral water spring. Nature has gifted Quang Binh a valuable hot mineral water spring. What humans are doing is just the beginning. In the future, the Bang Eco-Tourism Area and Hot Mineral Water Spring will continue to be effectively and qualitatively invested, worthy of its potential and value. Visitors traveling north or south, if having a chance to visit Quang Binh, should drop by and admire the scenery of the Bang Eco-Tourism Area and hot mineral water spring. Even just once, visitors will have an unforgettable impression of the journey to this poetic and charming mountain and stream land.

title: Thich Ca Phat Dai
description: Location: Thich Ca Phat Dai is located on the northwest slope of Lon Mountain in Vung Tau City, Ba Ria - Vung Tau Province. Characteristics: The beauty of the temple is the combination of religious architecture and natural scenery.|||This is a large temple in Vung Tau City, built in 1941, covering about 6 hectares on the slope of Lon Mountain, about 3 km from the city center.|||Notable features include an 19m-high octagonal tower and a 10.2m-high sitting Buddha statue on a lotus throne. The statue and tower are white and located halfway up the mountain, visible from afar.

title: Vinh Nghiem Pagoda
description: Location: 339 Nam Ky Khoi Nghia, District 3, Ho Chi Minh City. Characteristics: This is one of the typical architectural works of Vietnamese Buddhism in the 20th century, and a place of study for Buddhists of Ho Chi Minh City Basic Buddhist School.|||Vinh Nghiem Pagoda was built in 1964 by two monks, Thich Thanh Kiem and Thich Tam Giac, who came from the North to propagate Buddhism in the South. The construction was done on a low land area of about 6,000m² next to Thi Nghe canal. The work was completed in 1971, bearing a distinct architectural style of Vinh Nghiem Pagoda in Duc La village, Tri Yen commune, Lang Giang district, Bac Giang province (now Duc La village, Tri Yen commune, Yen Dung district, Bac Giang province).|||The pagoda's architecture is in the shape of a Chinese character 'work', consisting of a three-gate entrance with red curved tile roof and a central building. The central building has two floors. The ground floor includes an ancestor's altar, lecture hall, office, library, and monk's room. From here, there are three wide staircases leading to the upper floor and the Buddha hall. On the right corner of the upper floor is a bell tower with a large bronze bell, 1.8m in diameter, given by Japanese Buddhists in 1969 to pray for early peace in Vietnam.|||The Buddha hall has an architectural style similar to ancient pagodas in Northern Vietnam with curved roof corners and double-layered eaves. In the center of the roof is a Dharma wheel; the corners are decorated with dragon-shaped finials. The Buddha hall consists of a main hall worshiping Sakyamuni Buddha (in the center), Manjusri (on the left), and Samantabhadra (on the right), an Amitabha hall, and a Ksitigarbha shrine. On the altars in the main hall are carved reliefs of famous pagodas in Vietnam and some Asian countries. At the corridors on both sides of the main hall's entrance, two large Kim Cang statues are placed.|||To the left of the central building is a 35m-high square Quan The Am tower with 7 floors and a 9-wheel structure on the top. This is one of the largest Buddhist towers in Vietnam. In the pagoda's grounds is also a 14m-high stone tower, Vinh Nghiem tower, dedicated to Thich Thanh Kiem, made of 80m³ of Thanh Hoa stone and carved following the model of But tower (Hanoi). This is the largest and tallest stone tower in Vietnam (as of 2013).|||The pagoda also has a complex of buildings, including an L-shaped house for resting and a monks' dormitory.

title: Van Long Wetland Nature Reserve
description: Location: Van Long Wetland Nature Reserve is located in Gia Vien district, Ninh Binh province, 90km south of Hanoi. Features: Van Long is not only a wetland nature reserve but also home to cultural relics.|||Here, visitors can take a boat trip to explore the scenic landscape of Van Long. A vast area with majestic mountains forming a natural wall surrounding vast and calm water, creating a peaceful rural scenery.|||Covering nearly 3000ha, Van Long Wetland Nature Reserve has 32 caves, including Ca Cave, Bong Cave, Rua Cave, and Chanh Cave, each with its unique beauty. The most beautiful is Ca Cave, located at the foot of Hoang Quyen mountain. The cave is 250m long, 8m high, and 10m wide, with a semi-submerged structure and a ceiling adorned with shimmering stalactites.|||Among the caves in Van Long, Thung Doi Cave has the highest elevation above ground level (210m), while Bong Cave has the largest width (16m). There are also mountains with interesting names like Nghien, Hom Sach, Da Ban, and Meo Cao.|||The Van Long forest is home to 457 species of high-level plants, including 8 species listed in Vietnam's Red Book: kieng, lat hoa, tue la rong, cot toai boi, sang, bach bo, and ma tien hoa tan. There are 39 animal species, including 12 rare ones like white-throated langur, Asiatic black bear, and red-shanked douc.|||The wetland area of Van Long is home to the rare ca cuong species.|||During the dry season, Van Long is a wintering ground for many migratory bird species from the north, including dozens of kaluga storks, gray herons, and hundreds of egrets.|||Visitors to Van Long should not miss the 600-year-old market tree, Chi Le temple, Mai Trung temple, Le Kha Lang temple, Nguyen Duc Thanh temple, and other historical sites like Dinh Tien Hoang temple and Thanh Mau temple.|||Along with Hoa Lu capital, Tam Coc - Bich Dong, Cuc Phuong forest, Van Long is dubbed the 'inland Ha Long Bay'.

title: Cu Chi Tunnels
description: Location: Cu Chi District, Ho Chi Minh City. Characteristics: The tunnels are a complex and creative network created by the people and soldiers of Cu Chi, stretching hundreds of kilometers with numerous branches like a spider web underground.|||In 1948, to avoid French colonialist sweeps and to hide revolutionary cadres, documents, and weapons, residents of Tan Phu Trung and Phuoc Vinh An communes (Cu Chi district) dug short tunnels and hideouts in the area of clay and sandstone soil which was durable and less prone to collapse. The digging was later expanded to other communes.|||From 1961 to 1967, to intensify guerrilla warfare and counter the fierce sweeps and attacks by the US and its puppet forces, the people of Cu Chi district connected the tunnels and underground roads into a main axis called the 'spine road'. They then dug additional branch tunnels linking to the 'spine road', forming a comprehensive network of interconnected tunnels.|||Using only very primitive tools, the military and people of Cu Chi have built a 250km network of underground tunnels, connecting communes and hamlets, including tunnels leading to the Saigon River, and to Ben Cat base in Binh Duong province in times of emergency. The tunnels are equipped with blocking nodes to prevent chemical toxins, ventilation holes with camouflaged covers. The entrance and exit points are designed as sniper nests, surrounded by trenches, fighting pits, spike traps, mine pits against tanks and bomb launchers against helicopters.|||The tunnel system has a depth of 3-10m, consisting of 3 layers. The first layer is 3m underground, able to withstand the destructive power of bullets, cannons, and armored tanks. The second layer is 5m underground, able to withstand small bomb attacks. The third layer, 8-10m underground, is a safe shelter. The connecting points between layers have secret trapdoors.|||The inside of the tunnel is arranged like a miniature village with a hospital area; Hoang Cam kitchen (a kitchen with hidden smoke outlets); underground wells providing water for the entire tunnel system; weapon storage, food, and water supply areas; meeting rooms; wounded soldier care areas; shelters; movie screening areas…|||From 1968, the enemy continuously launched fierce sweeps to attack Cu Chi. However, the tunnel system was still reinforced and became a gathering point for army corps and main units to move in and liberate Saigon, successfully ending the resistance war against America on April 30, 1975.|||The Cu Chi tunnels are preserved at two sites: Ben Duc tunnels (formerly the base of the Zone Committee, Command Headquarters of Saigon - Cho Lon - Gia Dinh Military Zone) in Phu Hiep hamlet, Phu My Hung commune and Ben Dinh tunnels (formerly the base of Cu Chi district committee) in Ben Dinh hamlet, Nhuan Duc commune.|||When visiting this land known as 'land of steel turned into bronze', visitors will see tour guides dressed in wartime attire (men wearing liberation clothes, wearing a bèo hat; women wearing black áo bà ba, scarves, and rubber sandals) and have the opportunity to experience life in the tunnels like real residents before.|||Ben Duc and Ben Dinh tunnels were recognized as national historical and cultural relics in 1979 and 2004.

title: Quang Trung Museum
description: Location: Kien My Village, Phu Phong Town, Tay Son District, Binh Dinh Province, about 45km northwest of Qui Nhon City. Features: Quang Trung Museum preserves artifacts about the victories of King Quang Trung and performs Nhac vo Tay Son - a traditional martial art of Binh Dinh.|||From Quy Nhon city, take National Route 19 for about 45km to reach the Quang Trung Museum in Phu Phong town, the hometown of the three Tay Son brothers: Nguyen Nhac, Nguyen Hue and Nguyen Lu.|||Construction started in 1978 on a 95,000m² area with a blend of traditional and modern architectural styles. The Quang Trung Museum is a cultural space featuring: a museum, Tay Son Tam Kiet temple, Quang Trung Emperor statue, Tay Son martial music performance house, and a cultural house of West Highland ethnic groups...|||A must-experience for visitors to the Quang Trung Museum is to enjoy the Tay Son martial music, featuring a set of 12 drums representing the 12 zodiac animals. The drum performance consists of three parts: marching into battle, capturing the fortress, and the triumphant melody. Listening to this drum piece, visitors can feel the intensity and excitement, as if they are in the midst of a storm. According to legend, this martial music was used to boost the morale of the Tay Son rebels. Visitors can also watch unique performances of traditional martial arts, experience the culture of Central Highlands with gongs and drums, and enjoy various dance performances, recalling the early days of the Tay Son brothers' uprising in An Khe (Gia Lai). The museum consists of 9 display rooms with different themes, preserving thousands of documents and artifacts throughout the development of the Tay Son uprising and Emperor Quang Trung (1771 - 1789). Nguyen Hue, a national hero, led the rebellion and defeated foreign invaders. In 1788, he led his army from Phu Xuan (Hue) to the North, defeating 290,000 invading Qing soldiers and liberating Thang Long (now Hanoi). Nguyen Hue became Emperor Quang Trung. At the Quang Trung Museum, visitors can learn about the legendary feats, admire important artifacts, and see the drums, gongs, and 18 types of primitive weapons that helped the Tay Son rebels achieve victories. The museum also displays the names, ages, and hometowns of officials from the Tay Son dynasty. Additionally, visitors can see the preserved traditional costumes of these officials, which have been kept for centuries.|||Additional informationAs visitors cross Canh bridge, they will reach the Tay Son Tam Kiet temple and the house of the Tay Son heroes. This is where the three Tay Son brothers were born, grew up, and became outstanding leaders of the Tay Son movement. The temple also honors their parents, Ho Phi Phuc and Nguyen Thi Dong. Although small, the temple is solemn. The front yard has a three gate entrance, followed by a stele house with Quang Trung - Nguyen Hue's merits written in national language. The main hall has three rooms; the middle room honors Quang Trung - Nguyen Hue with a framed picture of him riding a horse; the left room honors Nguyen Nhac; and the right room honors Nguyen Lu. The two ends of the hall are altars for the Tay Son heroes' military and literary mandarins, including Tran Quang Dieu, Bui Thi Xuan, Vo Van Dung, Ngo Thi Nham, Ngo Van So, and Tran Van Ky… The old garden still has two precious relics: an ancient tamarind tree and an ancient well said to date back to Ho Phi Phuc's era. The ancient tamarind tree stands to the left of the Tay Son temple with lush branches and leaves, its trunk circumference measuring 3.5m. To the right of the temple is the well with a diameter of 0.9m; previously built with Ong stone and not as deep as it is now. Locals later dug it deeper and built the well 0.8m above ground level for communal use. Visitors can sit under the tamarind tree and drink water from the well to boost their spirit like the heroes of old.|||Visiting Quang Trung Museum, visitors will feel like traveling back in time to experience the spirit of martial virtue, heroism, righteousness, and unyielding determination to defend the homeland through the glorious history of the Tay Son uprising and the remarkable victories of Quang Trung - Nguyen Hue.|||Every year on the 5th day of the 1st lunar month, local people gather at the museum to commemorate the national hero Quang Trung, also known as the Dong Da festival.

title: Kon Tum Wooden Church
description: Location: Kon Tum Wooden Church is located on Nguyen Hue Street, Kon Tum City.
