Inside, you'll see a shimmering gold color inlaid on the engravings and Buddha statues. Notably, the main hall features pairs of long pillars, large round columns made of precious wood, constructed in the "upper shrink lower section" style.|||The interior of the main hall and the ancestor's house follow Chinese architecture but still retain Vietnamese characteristics. Connecting these two structures is a small area with a miniature landscape. Standing on the miniature landscape and looking towards the back of the main hall, the bridge on either side, and the front of the ancestor's house, you will see Roman architecture with colorful decorative stones in a French style on the roof ridge and cement columns.|||The temple preserves 60 precious statues made of bronze, wood, and terracotta, all gilded.|||The most artistically valuable are the eighteen Arhat statues on both sides of the main hall, carved from jackfruit wood in the early 20th century. Each statue is about 0.8m high and 0.58m wide.|||These statues, crafted by Nguyen and his apprentices, showcase a unique style of the Mekong Delta region and represent the pinnacle of round carving art.|||Each Arhat rides a mythical creature, holding a jewel, symbolizing the six senses in Buddhist teachings: the six roots (eye, ear, mouth, nose, body, and mind) across three periods: past, present, and future.|||The temple has 3 bronze statues (Amitabha Buddha 98cm high, Quan Am and The Chi 93cm high) created in the mid-19th century.|||It also features 7 exquisite gilded lam panels with carvings of the Eight Immortals, the Sun God, and the Moon God, skillfully crafted by local artisans around 1907-1908.|||Additionally, there is a large bronze bell named Phap Bao Chuong, 1.2m high and weighing around 150kg, cast in May 1854 with the inscription "Vinh Truong Tu".|||Unfortunately, the bell is no longer usable due to prolonged submersion in water during its period of loss.|||The temple currently houses over 20 valuable landscape paintings. Although influenced by Chinese art, these paintings have a distinctly Vietnamese folk style, featuring "plum, orchid, chrysanthemum, and bamboo", and poetic Vietnamese landscapes. They were sketched by layman Long Giang in 1904. The horizontal scrolls and couplets in the temple have been intricately carved with gold leaf characters, such as the phrase "Hoang kim bao dien", which was engraved from 1851 and still looks quite beautiful.|||Unlike any other three gateways of a pagoda, Vinh Trang pagoda's two gates are built in an ancient style with two floors and decorated with many ceramic and porcelain pieces in shimmering colors following the themes of 'dragon, unicorn, turtle, phoenix', 'fish, woodcutter, farmer, scholar', birds, flowers and buddhist allusions, showcasing the skillful craftsmanship of the artisans. The pagoda has a five-roof structure representing the five elements (metal, wood, water, fire, earth) according to Eastern philosophy.|||The surrounding area is filled with beautiful gardens planted with many fragrant flowers and exotic grasses, serene water ponds filled with the sweet scent of lotus, and ancient trees providing a canopy of shade. This creates a perfect harmony between the natural landscape and the architectural space, adding to the temple's ancient and solemn charm.|||Standing out in the garden is a 24m high statue of Amitabha Buddha (6m pedestal, 18m statue). The white statue depicts the Buddha standing watching over the sentient beings of all realms. The statue is believed by locals to be the iconic symbol of the temple today.|||Cultural experts say the beauty of the temple lies in its sculptural art and can be seen as a reflection of the history of fine arts in Tien Giang. Every day, besides devotees coming to worship, many tourists visit Vinh Trang Pagoda; it is most crowded on full moon days, the 1st of the lunar month, and holidays.

title: Nguyen Du Memorial Zone
description: Location: The Nguyen Du Memorial Zone is located in Tien Dien village, Tien Dien commune, Nghi Xuan district, Ha Tinh province, about 50km from Ha Tinh city and 8km from Vinh city (Nghe An province). Characteristics: Here, visitors can learn more about the life and career of Nguyen Du; and also learn more about the Nguyen Tien Dien family.|||From Vinh city, following National Highway 1A, passing Ben Thuy bridge - a bridge spanning Lam river, connecting Nghe An and Ha Tinh provinces, visitors arrive in Xuan An town, Nghi Xuan district. Continuing on National Highway 8B for about 4km, visitors will reach the Nguyen Du Memorial Zone.|||Nguyen Du (1765 - 1820) was originally from Tien Dien village, Nghi Xuan district, Duc Quang prefecture, Nghe An province (now Ha Tinh province) but was born and raised in Thang Long (Hanoi today). His father was Nguyen Nghiem, a royal advisor, and his mother was Tran Thi Tan from Hoa Thien village, Dong Ngan district, Kinh Bac region (now Bac Ninh province).|||From a young age, Nguyen Du was exposed to the rich cultural heritage of three regions: Nghe An, Thang Long, and Kinh Bac. As a result, Nguyen Du grew up to be a learned and talented person, well-versed in Buddhism and proficient in various subjects, including poetry and painting. His masterpiece, The Tale of Kieu, is a significant contribution to Vietnamese literature.|||The Nguyen Du Memorial Zone was built for scholars, writers, and domestic and international tourists who love The Tale of Kieu and admire Nguyen Du - a great national poet and a world cultural celebrity; to come and pay their respects. This cultural relic is part of the Nguyen Tien Dien family heritage. This complex includes many relics: the temple dedicated to Nguyen Hue; the temple dedicated to Nguyen Nghiem and Nguyen Trong; the Nguyen Quynh altar; two Tu van houses; the tomb of Nguyen Du; the Nguyen Du museum; and the Nguyen Du ancestral house.|||The Nguyen Du ancestral house was built in 1825 on the family's garden in Tien Giap hamlet. Inside, there is an altar made of limestone, and above it hangs a horizontal board with the four characters 'Hong son the pha' (Red Mountain Family Chronicle) presented by Hoang Phu Phai, a noble of the Thanh dynasty, in 1790, along with a stone stele with the inscription 'Thanh Hien Nguyen Tien Sinh'.|||Next to the Nguyen Du ancestral house is the Nguyen Du museum, which displays many original documents and artifacts related to the life and career of the great poet.|||Visiting the Nguyen Du Memorial Zone, tourists can admire the scenery and learn about the cultural and historical values, as well as the humanistic significance of the Nguyen Tien Dien heritage. Especially, if visitors come here during the early spring, they can enjoy poetry nights at the Tu van house in the memorial zone.

title: Mơ Waterfall
description: Location: Mơ Waterfall is located in Na Hang town, Na Hang district, Tuyen Quang province, within the Na Hang natural reserve, about 100km from Tuyen Quang town. Characteristics: The waterfall, with its majestic scenery and dense forest, awaits adventure-seekers.|||The road to Mơ Waterfall is relatively convenient. From a distance, you can hear the roar of the waterfall. The closer you get, the colder it becomes. Upon arrival, you feel like you've entered a mystical realm. The waterfall is hidden at the foot of a mountain, with a crystal-clear lake underneath. You take a small boat to reach the waterfall. As you sit on the boat, you can relax and admire the natural scenery of 'mountains embracing clouds, clouds caressing mountains'.|||A massive silver waterfall appears before your eyes. The waterfall has three tiers. To reach the second tier, you need to climb over 10m using a rope ladder. At the foot of the second tier is a small, crystal-clear lake. Here, you can immerse yourself in the majestic scenery with stunning stalactites and stalagmites. The water flows gently, passing through rock crevices and large stones covered in green moss, resembling velvet carpets. Continuing on the rope ladder, you reach the top of the third tier.|||Water cascades down like a massive curtain. The cool mist dispels fatigue and inspires you as you stand atop the majestic waterfall, taking in the panoramic view of Na Hang town surrounded by 99 mountains. If you wish, you can take a stroll into the primeval forest to discover its secrets. The roar of the waterfall, bird songs, and sunlight filtering through the dense foliage transport you back to prehistoric times.|||Mơ Waterfall, an ideal eco-tourism destination in Tuyen Quang, awaits adventure-seekers.

title: Minh Mang Tomb
description: Location: The Minh Mang Tomb is located in Cam Ke mountain, Huong Tho commune, Huong Tra town, Thua Thien - Hue province, near Bang Lang crossroad, where Ta Trach and Huu Trach rivers converge to form the Huong River that flows through Hue city. The tomb is 12km from Hue city. Characteristics: The Minh Mang Tomb is a large architectural complex with around 40 structures of various sizes. The tomb exudes a majestic and solemn atmosphere, yet it is in perfect harmony with the surrounding architecture and nature.|||In April 1840, King Minh Mang renamed Cam Ke Mountain to Hieu Son and called the tomb Hieu Lang.|||The tomb was started construction in September 1840.|||In January 1841, the construction was underway but King Minh Mang fell ill and passed away. King Thieu Tri succeeded him and continued the construction of the tomb according to the original design.|||In August 1841, King Minh Mang's remains were buried in Buu Thanh.|||The new tomb was completed in 1843.|||The Minh Mang Tomb is a complex of about 40 architectural works of varying sizes including palaces, castles, temples... arranged symmetrically along a longitudinal axis from Dai Hong Mon gate (at the outermost part) to the foot of the wall of La Thanh behind the royal tomb.|||The structures are arranged along three main axes parallel to each other, with Than Dao Street as the center. The overall layout of the mausoleum is divided into:|||Dai Hong Mon is the main gate to the tomb. The gate has 3 passageways with 24 unevenly high and low roofs and very beautiful decorations. The main gate was only opened once to bring the king's coffin into the tomb; for entering and exiting, one had to go through two auxiliary gates, namely Ta Hong Mon and Huu Hong Mon.|||Bi Dinh, located behind Dai Hong Mon gate, is a spacious courtyard with two rows of statues of officials, elephants and horses.|||Bi Dinh is situated on Phung Than Son hill, inside which is the stele "Thanh Duc Than Cong" written by King Thieu Tri about the biography and merits of his father.|||The royal tomb area (where the king is worshiped): continuing to the ceremonial courtyard is divided into 4 levels. The beginning of the tomb area is Hieu Duc Gate; Sung An Temple is located in the center, worshiping the king and Queen Ta Thien Nhan Hoang Hau. Hoang Trach Gate is the final structure of the tomb area, filled with the fragrance of orchids.|||Minh Lau Pavilion: continuing through the three bridges Trung Dao (middle), Ta Phu (left), and Huu Bat (right) spanning Truong Minh lake, you will reach Minh Lau pavilion (the bright pavilion) built on Tam Dai Son hill. The house is square-shaped, two stories high, with eight roofs. On either side of Minh Lau, towards the back, are two pillars standing on Binh Son and Thanh Son hills. Behind Minh Lau are two symmetrical flower gardens in the shape of the character Tho, separated by the Than Dao path.|||Bau Thanh (the wall around the tomb): the crescent-shaped Tan Nguyet lake embraces the round Bau Thanh. Through the Thong Minh Chinh Truc bridge over Tan Nguyet lake, there are 33 stone steps leading to the resting place of the king, located in the center of Khai Trac Son hill, bounded by a round Bau Thanh.|||The tomb of Minh Mang, with Bi Dinh, Hieu Duc Mon, Sung An temple and Minh Lau pavilion, along with nearly 60 carved poetic stanzas, is a curated poetry museum of Vietnamese literature from the early 19th century...|||Besides its majestic and imposing character, Minh Mang Tomb also has the charm of nature that has been shaped to create a backdrop for its architectural works.|||Biography of King Minh Mang (Nguyen Phuc Dam):|||Minh Mang's given name was Nguyen Phuc Dam, born on 23rd January 1789, was the second son of Gia Long. In January 1820, Crown Prince Dam ascended to the throne, with the reign name Minh Mang.|||Minh Mang was intelligent, studious, proactive and decisive. Minh Mang established a rule: all mandarins who were promoted or appointed had to come to the capital to meet the King, so the King could inquire about their work, check their abilities and offer advice.|||As a scholar deeply devoted to Confucianism and the teachings of Khong and Manh, Minh Mang prioritized education and the selection of talented individuals. In 1821, he established the Quoc Tu Giam, appointing a Celestial Master and a Deputy, and revived the national examinations, reducing the interval between them from six years to three.|||Minh Mang was also very interested in military affairs, especially the navy. He sent people to learn about European shipbuilding techniques with the goal of enabling Vietnamese people to build Western-style ships and navigate the high seas.|||Minh Mang completed the system of dikes in North Vietnam, appointed officials to promote agriculture, and reclaimed land along the coast of North Vietnam, establishing two additional districts, Kim Son and Tien Hai.|||In terms of foreign policy, Minh Mang paid special attention to serving the Qing dynasty, but was aloof and suspicious of Western countries, which hindered the country's development.|||Minh Mang had many wives, with whom he had 78 princes and 64 princesses, a total of 142 children.|||In December 1840, Minh Mang fell seriously ill and then passed away, having reigned for 20 years and lived to be 50 years old.

title: Da Lat Market
description: Location: Da Lat Market is located in the city center of Da Lat. Characteristics: The market has a majestic yet elegant and artistic appearance.|||Built from 1958 to 1960, Da Lat Market had the most modern architecture at that time. It is situated at the foot of a hill, connected to Hoa Binh Hill by a bridge on the second floor and to Xuan Huong Lake by a path leading to the ground floor. In front of the market is a roundabout with flowers. On the side, next to the roundabout, there are steps leading up to Le Dai Hanh Street and a slope connecting Hoa Binh Hill to Xuan Huong Lake. All of this creates a spectacular layout for Da Lat Market, unique to a highland city with many hills.|||In addition to the usual goods found in other markets, Da Lat Market sells various specialties, mainly on the ground floor. The outermost area has flower stalls, followed by fruit stalls, and then a section for Da Lat specialties such as artichokes, dried plums, wine, syrup, etc.

title: Thien Ha Cave
description: Location: Dong Tam village, Son Ha commune, Nho Quan district, Ninh Binh province. Features: A beautiful scenic spot in the core of Trang An Complex - a UNESCO World Heritage Site|||Thien Ha Cave is nestled in the heart of Tuong mountain range at an altitude of nearly 200m, within the Hoa Lu special forest. In the 10th century, this mountain range served as a natural fortress protecting the southwestern border of Hoa Lu capital, associated with historical and cultural sites such as Le dynasty wharf, Phat Dau Son mountain, and Dau Linh field...|||To explore the cave's beauty, visitors start from Muong Tho Ha village (Son Ha commune), follow a 1km-long small canal from the Ben Dang river system, then walk 500m on a stone path along the foot of Tuong mountain to reach the cave. The cave entrance is about 4m high with numerous stalactites and stalagmites illuminated by a stunning light beam. The entire cave is approximately 700m long, comprising both dry and wet sections.|||The dry section is the highest and widest part of Thien Ha Cave, with a 40m-wide and 200m-long area. Inside, a variety of stalactites and stalagmites resemble shapes that spark imagination, such as Buddha, castles, animals, fans, and human ears. The section also features a sky well, called Giong Troi, which is 3m high and wide, allowing natural light to pour in. On sunny days, the reflected light on the stalactites creates shimmering colors.|||The 500m-long wet section requires a boat ride on an underground river called Ngan Ha. Visitors can admire stunning stalactites and stalagmites with names like Hoa Tien island, Mother's Breast, and Ca Hoa Long, creating a magical experience.|||Thien Ha Cave remains largely pristine and is home to thousands of bats. Scientists have discovered ancient Vietnamese artifacts, including shells, tools, and animal bones. The preserved cultural layer provides insight into the lives of ancient Vietnamese people and their adaptation to environmental changes during the New Stone Age.|||With its mystical and majestic beauty, Thien Ha Cave is a highlight of Ninh Binh's cave tourism, inviting visitors to explore and admire.

title: Den Ba Trieu
description: Location: The temple is built on Nui Gai (also known as Nui Ai) mountain, right next to National Route 1A, in Phu Dien village, Hau Loc district, Thanh Hoa province, 137km from Hanoi. Characteristics: The temple remains simple yet solemn. Travelers on the way to the North or South often stop to visit, pay respects to the female general, and enjoy the scenery.|||Her real name was Trieu Thi Trinh, but people commonly call her Ba Trieu out of respect and gratitude for leading a rebellion against the invading Ngo army in the 3rd century.|||Entering the temple, visitors are greeted by a lotus pond surrounded by stone walls. The main hall, or Tien duong, consists of 5 rooms with square stone pillars. Behind it lies a small courtyard with reception rooms on both sides. At the end of the courtyard stands the 3-room rear hall, built on higher ground and attached to the mountain slope. Across from the temple, on the other side of National Route 1A, lies Nui Tung mountain, where Ba Trieu's tomb is located.

title: Banh It Tower
description: Located in Phuoc Hiep commune, Tuy Phuoc district, Binh Dinh province, on a hilltop between two branches of the Con River, Tan An and Cau Ganh, next to National Highway 1A, about 20km from Quy Nhon city. This is a complex of four towers, resembling Banh It cakes from a distance, hence the name Banh It Tower.|||The main tower, standing at 22m, resembles a Banh It cake with a prickly leaf. Surrounding the main tower are three smaller towers, two of which resemble sweet Banh It cakes and one a savory Banh It cake. Each tower has a distinct architecture with a different character. The top of each tower features a stone Shiva statue.|||Nearby Banh It Tower is Nguyen Thieu monastery with a majestic open-air Buddha altar on a hill, overlooking the serene waters of the Tan An stream.|||In terms of art, Banh It Tower is a unique architectural complex among the remaining Cham towers, showcasing diverse and beautiful designs, with high artistic value.

title: Bac Lieu Bird Garden Nature Reserve
description: Location: The reserve is located in Hiep Thanh commune, Bac Lieu city, Bac Lieu province, about 6km south of Bac Lieu city. Characteristics: With high biodiversity, Bac Lieu Bird Garden was recognized as a natural reserve in 1986.|||Previously, this reserve was a coastal mangrove forest with a rich and diverse natural ecosystem. Due to natural accretion, the forest moved further away from the sea and only a part of it remained to form the current bird garden.|||The reserve has a natural mangrove ecosystem covering about 385ha, including 19ha of primeval forest, with 104 plant species from 50 genera and 46 families. The upper layer of the forest consists of Tra La (50%), Gia (30%), and other trees like Coc and Lam Vo. The understory is dominated by grasses and vines. This is also the habitat of about 46 bird species, including rare ones like Giang Sen, Dien Dien, Co Ruoi, etc.; 109 plant species from 90 genera of 46 families; and 150 animal species, including 58 fish species, 7 amphibian species, 10 mammal species, 8 reptile species, and other animals.|||Bac Lieu Bird Garden is an important nesting site for many water bird species, typically le le, co, diec, vac, cong coc, quam den, and many others. The birds gather here during the rainy season from May to October. They build nests on trees until January, then fly away and return in May or June.|||The bird garden always surprises visitors who come to explore. Upon entering, visitors see the bustling scene of a natural bird sanctuary. Bird eggs are scattered on the ground like white pebbles. The most interesting experience is standing on the watchtower, high like the treetops, and gazing out at the scenery. This is when the birds return to their nests after foraging. From the East, the sea appears purple in the evening, and from the Bac Lieu fields, the ripe rice appears golden. The flocks of birds fly back to their nests in an orderly manner, separated by their plumage and species. Some formations resemble arrows, while others form hearts or scattered groups. The white color belongs to the Ngao Co flock, and the black color like black oil belongs to the Cong Coc flock. They swarm on the treetops, covering the sky. The forest suddenly becomes lively with various sounds: the wind whistling, wings flapping, leaves rustling, and mother birds calling their young.|||If visitors wish to spend the night at the bird garden, they can enjoy the serenade of nature with the rustling of leaves, the sounds of nocturnal birds foraging, the whispering of the wind at the beginning of the season, and the light rain on the leaves. All these sounds blend together to create the music of the forest, the breath of nature, which sounds gentle and soothing. In the morning, waking up to the birds singing in the early sunshine, visitors will feel their souls become pure and calm.

title: Dia Dish Ghenh
description: Ghenh Da Dia is a famous scenic spot in Phu Yen, known for its majestic and unique beauty. Formed over 200 million years ago, the prism-shaped rocks here have a shiny black color, stacked on top of each other in a spectacular way, as if arranged by nature's hand. This place has been blessed by nature with a poetic and lyrical beauty, harmonious landscape, and beautiful like a watercolor painting|||Anyone who has been to and fallen in love with the beautiful land of Phu Yen will never forget the moments strolling along the long white sandy beach, sipping on simple local delicacies with a touch of warmth, or the quiet moments watching the sunset over Ghenh Da Dia. The beauty of light, sky, and ancient rocks stretching along creates a poetic and majestic scene, like a surreal painting.|||There aren't many places in the world that have a unique rock formation like Ghenh Da Dia in Phu Yen. Here, millions of years ago, a volcano erupted strongly, and the lava flow cooled down and solidified into rocks. When the lava's heat met the sea's cold, it became frozen, cracked, and formed into the honeycomb-shaped rocks we see today.|||From a distance, Ghenh Da Dia looks like the keys on an old piano, left behind in the sky. The rocks are stacked close to each other, stretching along the pristine beach. Their heights vary, and the closer to the sea, the lower they become. Over time, the waves have made the rocks more serene and silent. But it hasn't diminished their beauty, and they remain a lovely flower in full bloom. Anyone, near or far, wants to come and admire, and fall more in love with what mother nature has given to Phu Yen.|||With its majestic scenery, Ghenh Da Dia in Phu Yen is one of Vietnam's most beautiful natural wonders. A place where anyone wants to visit, take beautiful pictures, and experience the land of 'yellow flowers and green grass'.

title: Phoenix Historical Site
description: Location: In Van An ward, Chi Linh town, Hai Duong province, about 80km east of Hanoi. Characteristics: This is a special sacred land, with unique natural scenery and many remarkable architectural works such as: Chu Van An temple, Luu Quang altar, Miet Tri,...|||Legend has it that one day, in the sky over Chi Linh, a flock of 72 Phoenix birds appeared, spreading their wings and flying. Seeing the beautiful landscape, the birds did not continue flying but landed and transformed into a range of 72 mountains.|||Phuong Hoang Mountain has long been famous for its picturesque scenery with vast pine forests, babbling brooks, and singing birds. Notably, 72 mountains resemble 72 Phoenix birds spreading their wings.|||The book 'Chi Linh huyen su tich' by the Institute of Han Nom Studies wrote: 'The mountains line up in an array / Left and right wings spread, Phoenix flying across the sky.' The mountains here are structured in a decreasing order from northeast to southwest, connecting to the alluvial plain and reflecting on the vast waves of Luc Dau Giang River.|||Phuong Hoang Mountain is home to many historical relics such as Huyen Thien ancient temple, Ky Linh ancient temple, Tinh Phi ancient pagoda... Especially, the Phuong Hoang relic complex is closely associated with the life of teacher Chu Van An, including: Chu Van An temple, Luu Quang building, Miet Tri, Son Well, and the tomb area.|||After Chu Van An passed away (1370), a temple was built at the site where he taught. However, due to the harshness of time and the intense war bombings, by the 80s, the temple was almost completely destroyed. In the 90s, with the approval of the authorities, the Hai Duong Museum, Van An Ward People's Committee, Education sector, and local residents carried out a major restoration and reconstruction.|||The temple now is a complex of impressive structures including inner and outer tam quan gates, lower, middle and upper courtyards, a tree garden, two ritual houses, two stele houses, the main temple and 112 stone steps leading up to it. The main temple follows the Nhu character layout, built in the Nguyen dynasty style with 2 layers of 8-roof tiles, 8 curved corners, comprising 5 front halls and 1 rear sanctum.|||The front hall features an altar for the public, behind which is the ancestor altar of the Chu family, on the right is the altar for the mountain god of Phuong Hoang mountain, and on the left is the altar for the teacher's students. In the rear sanctum is a 100kg bronze statue of the teacher.|||The temple's art decor features the four symbols (dragon, ly, turtle, phoenix) and the four precious plants (pine, chrysanthemum, bamboo, and plum). The doors are decorated with the image of 'a dragon attending a blooming chrysanthemum'.|||Lu Quang Temple is about 100m west of Chu Van An Temple. This is a architectural structure in the shape of the character 'Ding', following the style of 'stacked tile roof' with 8 curved eaves, creating a sense of lightness and dignity. The temple consists of 5 rooms and 2 raised rooms with ornate details. Inside, a statue of teacher Chu Van An is placed and a large sign 'Van Su the bieu' is hung.|||The roof, eaves, and decorative elements are adorned with patterns in the style of the Tran - Le dynasty, such as two dragons playing with the moon, dragons and phoenixes dancing...|||Miet Tri is a turtle pond located in front of Dien Luu Quang. This place helps visitors recall the legend of Thuy Than (a mythical creature) who transformed into a commoner to study with teacher Chu Van An, impressed by his wisdom and talent. However, later the creature had to sacrifice its life to make rain and help the people escape drought.||||||During excavations in Miet Tri, archaeologists found many artifacts with 14th-15th century art styles.|||The Son Well (now filled in) is believed by researchers to be located to the east of the Chu Van An Temple. Because, according to archaeological findings, there are many pieces of vermilion at this site.|||According to the books 'Du dia chi' by Phan Huy Chu and 'Cong du tiep ky' by Vu Phuong De, Phuong Hoang mountain has a precious type of vermilion, with a vibrant red color, considered by ancient alchemists as a good material for elixir. Teacher Chu Van An and his students often took bamboo tubes and inserted them into the well, then pulled them out to get soft, mud-like vermilion, which they would dry to harden. The teacher used these vermilion sticks to write poems, essays, and grade students' papers. Many people who admired his virtue often came to ask him for a calligraphic character written with vermilion.|||The Chu Van An tomb complex is located in a beautiful spot on the eastern peak of Phoenix Mountain, about 600m from the main temple. According to local legend, this location is the head of the Phoenix bird – the highest point of justice and virtue.|||The tomb complex has a rectangular monolithic architecture. The tomb is surrounded by rectangular stone walls, measuring 4x7m. The decorative carvings here focus on the image of a book and two sharp brushes, symbolizing the noble and pure dedication to education of teacher Chu Van An.|||While digging soil to plant flowers next to the grave, people discovered many Tran dynasty ceramic dishes, many of which were still intact.|||Ngoc Well is about 50m west of the tomb, filled with water all year round and very clear. According to local legend, this is the eye of the Phoenix bird. Visitors to the tomb often take a sip of well water with the thought that the sacred energy of the land will soak into their body.

title: Cua Tung Beach
description: Location: Cua Tung Beach is located in Vinh Linh district, Quang Tri province. Features: Cua Tung attracts tourists with its beautiful beach, white sand, and flat, smooth texture, along with nearby historical sites such as the 17th Parallel, Hien Luong Bridge, Ben Hai River, and Truong Son Martyrs' Cemetery.|||Cua Tung is not just a historical site but also a famous tourist destination. The beach is beautiful with white sand, gently welcoming the sweet kisses of the vast sea. The area features eight red Badan headlands running along the coast, creating a magnificent, ancient comb-like structure, smoothing out millions of waves.|||In the distance, Con Co Island appears like a golden turtle rising out of the blue water, evoking ideas about primitive legends. Located here, Cua Tung can be likened to a "Queen" leaning against Vinh Quang village, which is always green with tea trees and rustling phi lao forests.|||During the summer when the Laos wind blows hot and dry through the Central highlands, Cua Tung is truly the "Rich Queen" with colorful attire and a fresh, youthful body, attracting visitors not inferior to famous destinations like Sam Son, Non Nuoc, Nha Trang, or Vung Tau.|||Cua Tung also attracts tourists because it is close to historical sites such as the 17th Parallel, Hien Luong Bridge, Ben Hai River, Truong Son Martyrs' Cemetery, Vinh Moc tunnels, and heroic Con Co Island. These historical names mark a long period of struggle and heroism of the nation, removing the boundaries that separated the country, allowing North and South to reunite. These sites have become a unique tourist complex.|||Now, after years of reconstruction, Cua Tung has truly become the "Queen" it was meant to be.|||Visitors are invited to Cua Tung to enjoy famous local seafood and admire the beauty of this beach, known as the "Queen of beaches".

title: Kim Boi Hot Spring
description: Location: The hot mineral water spring is located in Kim Boi District, Hoa Binh Province. Characteristics: It is a natural hot mineral spring. The mineral water is very good for human health.|||From Hoa Binh Town, continue 30km to a guesthouse named after a Muong village, called Mo Da Guesthouse, Kim Boi.|||The guesthouse is built next to a large mineral water source. Therefore, sitting in the room, you can still hear the sound of water spraying up endlessly. The water sprays up at a temperature of 36°C. After testing, Kim Boi mineral water meets the standards for drinking, bathing, and soaking to treat joint inflammation, digestive problems, stomach issues, and high blood pressure. Kim Boi spring water has been bottled as a beverage, similar to Thach Bich in Quang Ngai, Kum-dua in Russia, and Paven Banis in Bulgaria.

title: Hoang A Tuong Palace (Hoang Yen Chao Castle)
description: Location: Hoang A Tuong Palace is located in the center of Bac Ha district, Lao Cai province. Characteristics: The architecture of Hoang A Tuong Palace is a combination of Asian and European styles, creating harmony with a rectangular, closed layout.|||Hoang A Tuong's Residence was built in 1914 and completed in 1921. The owner was Hoang Yen Chao, a Tay ethnic person and the biological father of Hoang A Tuong. After over 80 years, despite being covered in moss and weathering, the house still stands majestically among the crowded residential area.|||Before 1945, Bac Ha was a semi-feudal colonial society with ruling and oppressed classes, exploiters and those exploited, with the exploiting class being the local tyrants, typically the father-son duo of Hoang Yen Chao and Hoang A Tuong.|||During their reign, backed by the French colonizers, the father-son duo of Hoang Yen Chao and Hoang A Tuong ruthlessly exploited the people, seized fertile land, forced the locals to serve them, and demanded valuable items. They also monopolized the sale of salt, consumer goods, and the extraction of forest products, opium, and food supplies for the French garrisons and their collaborators. With their economic power, Hoang Yen Chao built an impressive mansion and hired a geomancer to select the site and orientation, working with two architects, one French and one Chinese, to design and directly construct the building.|||The site was chosen based on feng shui principles on a spacious southeast-facing hill. Behind and on either side are mountains, and in front is a stream with "Mother and Child" mountain. The overall terrain has a beautiful "suitable landscape" with tropical Asian climate.|||The main house is located deep in the center. On either side are auxiliary houses, with a screen in front and an open courtyard in the middle. To enter the dinh, one must climb several steps from either side, then proceed to the waiting room, and finally enter the spacious courtyard for ceremonies and xoe dancing. The two-story main house covers an area of 420m². The doors are arched. Although the doors vary in height, they are balanced, and the corridors have railings. There are raised cannons in front of each door. Both floors of the main house have three rooms each. The four rooms on either side of both floors are used for family activities. The middle room on both floors serves as a meeting space. The front is decorated with intricate designs. On either side, there are two raised couplets with content wishing the family prosperity and honor...||||||On both the left and right sides are two rows of transverse houses with identical layout and architecture. Each row has two floors, but is lower than the main house; each floor has three rooms with a total area of 300m², and each room has its own specific function.|||Adjacent to the two rows of houses are two auxiliary houses, also with two floors, but with simpler architecture, used as warehouses, and for soldiers and servants to live in, with a total area of 160m² for each house.||||||Building materials such as bricks and tiles were produced locally with the help of Chinese experts. Iron, steel, and cement were purchased from elsewhere and transported by plane. The perimeter is surrounded by a wall with three gates (one main, two auxiliary) featuring many loopholes and guarded by two platoons of soldiers. The total area of the compound is 4,000m². This villa complex is being preserved, restored, and upgraded so that visitors can learn about the social history of the mountainous ethnic region.

title: Long Hai Beach
description: Location: Long Hai Beach is located in Long Hai town, Long Dien district, 30km northeast of Vung Tau city. Features: Stretching along the southern foot of Thuy Van or Ky Van mountain (now known as Minh Dam), Long Hai Beach is a clean and beautiful beach with clear blue water.|||The natural scenery here is romantic. The long, golden sand beach is peaceful and quiet, perfect for sea lovers who prefer a serene atmosphere. The beach is connected to Nuoc Ngot Pass. Here, the rocky mountain stretches out to the sea, challenging the waves and creating a poetic and majestic landscape.|||On the other side of Nuoc Ngot Pass lies the cherry blossom forest. Every spring, looking down from the pass, visitors can't help but be amazed by the white and purple cherry blossoms, the green of the forest, and the Long Hai sea.

title: Bac Ha Market
description: Location: Bac Ha district, Lao Cai province, about 60km from Lao Cai city. Characteristics: Bac Ha market is one of the largest border highland markets.|||On the way, tourists will encounter high mountains, deep valleys and terraced fields. Visitors often have to stop their vehicles to capture the breathtaking natural scenery and meet groups of ethnic people chatting and laughing while leading packhorses carrying goods to the market. To make it to the market on time, they have to leave very early, some even travel a day in advance and arrive the next day at noon.|||Previously, Bac Ha market was held on a gentle hill, but later it was rebuilt on a concrete foundation and divided into separate sales areas, losing some of its original charm. Bac Ha market offers a wide range of highland products and essential goods for ethnic people: plows, hoes, shovels, knives, vegetables, fruits, honey.|||However, what attracts ethnic women and tourists most is the area selling jewelry, dresses, shirts, brocades and elegant rattan baskets. Here, you can freely choose from a variety of handicrafts, dazzled by the vibrant colors of the dresses of Mong and Dao girls. Foreign tourists are often impressed by hand-woven pictures with lively motifs, harmonious colors and beautiful scenery.|||For highland men, the market is also a place to meet and drink wine with chao thang co. The wine never runs out, just like the alcohol in the bottle. The special wine of Mong people in Pho village is well-known for its strong and distinctive flavor. The horse sale area is where men are most attracted, coming from remote villages, even from Bac Giang and Ha Tay provinces, to buy horses.|||In the noisy trading, you can hear the sound of khen and singing, with young men inviting girls. Tourists, especially foreigners, are very interested in discovering the new life and customs of the local people.|||In the trend of commercialization of highland markets today, Bac Ha is one of the few places that still preserves its ethnic identity and unique charm of ancient markets. When visiting Bac Ha, you won't encounter pushy vendors; instead, you'll see pure faces in colorful ethnic clothes, coming to the market not just to buy and sell but also to enjoy the market and the company of travelers. As the day ends, the market slowly disperses; men drunk on wine sit on horseback, while women lead horses back to their villages, leaving a lasting impression on tourists.

title: Chua Tram Gian
description: Location: Chua Tram Gian is located in Tien Lu village, Tien Phuong commune, Chuong My district, Hanoi. Characteristics: The temple has 104 rooms, is a famous ancient temple in Vietnam.|||The temple's literary name is Quang Nghiem temple, established in 1185 during the reign of King Ly Cao Tong. During the Tran dynasty, the temple was a place of study for monk Binh An, whose real name was Nguyen Lu, from Boi Khe. According to legend, the monk was knowledgeable in scriptures and had many magical powers, so after his death, the villagers built a tower to preserve his remains and honored him as Duc Thanh Boi. The temple worships both Buddha and Duc Thanh Boi.|||Chua Tram Gian is a unique architectural complex of 104 rooms. The temple gate is built with two large pillars creating a pathway in the middle, with two walls connected to two smaller pillars. Stepping through the temple gate is a large courtyard with a clean brick-paved yard, two rows of corridors on either side, the left corridor leading to the Tam Quan gate and the bell tower, and the right corridor leading to the stele house. In the center is the ancient and majestic main hall.|||The Tam Quan gate is located on the central axis of the Tam Bao area. Through the Tam Quan gate, visitors can admire one of the oldest bell towers still standing today. It is a 2-story, 8-roofed tower with a railing running around all four sides. The wooden boards are carved with dao-shaped flowers curving upwards like a giant lotus flower. A bell, 1.1m high and 0.6m in diameter, cast in 1794, hangs here. The bell features an inscription by Phan Huy Ich.|||In the center of the upper hall is a red, rectangular clay pedestal, similar to the stone pedestals from the Tran dynasty. On the pedestal is a lotus stand, decorated with many animal and plant motifs, and four corners featuring divine birds. On the stand are the Three World Buddha statues.|||In addition, in the courtyard behind the upper hall, before the rear hall, stands the Phuong dinh pavilion, where a drum and a khanh are hung, and visitors can rest and admire the surrounding scenery. All the structures in the main and auxiliary areas are connected according to two spaces, spiritual and secular, which are different yet harmoniously unified across the hilltop.|||The temple currently preserves a collection of 153 statues, mostly made of wood, with a few made of clay. Notably, there are statues of Tuyet Son, Quan Am Bo Tat, and Do Doc Dang Tien Dong, a general from the Tay Son dynasty. Additionally, there is a statue of Duc Thanh Boi kept in a wooden shrine. This statue is made by removing the core with woven bamboo and wrapped in fabric, allegedly containing the monk's remains.|||The Chua Tram Gian festival takes place from the 4th to the 6th day of the first lunar month annually to commemorate Duc Thanh Boi. The festival features a procession of the saint's palanquin, vegetarian food offerings, and water puppet performances; as well as entertainment activities like human chess, wrestling, and firework displays… The temple has been recognized as a National Historical Site.

title: Hon Rom
description: Location: Hon Rom is located in Mui Ne ward, Phan Thiet city, Binh Thuan province, 26km northeast of Phan Thiet city center. Characteristics: During the dry season, under the scorching sun, the wild grass turns yellow and withers, resembling giant straw piles from a distance.|||The beach is clean and beautiful, the sea water is clear and blue, with gentle waves and a soothing breeze rustling through the cool, fruit-laden coconut groves. The golden and white sand dunes stretch and roll in waves, constantly changing shape... All of this creates a pristine and alluring beauty that attracts visitors to come and experience and explore the wonderful beauty of the sand.|||New tre-made resorts have been built on the sand dunes in Hon Rom, offering new tourism activities such as sand sliding, sea bathing, campfires at night, or fishing with fishermen and squid fishing at sea.

title: Binh Thuy Ancient House
description: Location: Binh Thuy Ancient House is located on Bui Huu Nghia street, Binh Thuy ward, Binh Thuy district, Can Tho city. Characteristics: The five-room house with two roofs, built in French style, was constructed by the Duong family in 1870.|||The house features French-style architecture with a foundation 1m higher than the yard.|||It has four elegant curved steps connecting the house to the spacious yard.|||The interior boasts a high ceiling with decorative patterns and multiple large and small windows with simple iron frames, allowing for good ventilation.|||The facade is adorned with raised relief sculptures.|||The entire house is built with red and black flower-patterned tiles imported from France, along with a cast iron fence protecting the premises.|||This rare and well-preserved ancient house provides valuable insights into the daily life, culture, and development progress of the Mekong Delta residents during the transition period between two centuries.|||To blend in with nature, the house is always connected to a garden (the garden covers over 6,000/8,000m² of the entire campus), wide but not deep. Most of the front hall is used to receive guests without dividing into small rooms, with two back doors leading out to the back, a spacious yard paved with Chinese tiles, complete with an ornamental rockery, potted plants, a three-gate entrance, and an animal enclosure...|||In the past, people processed anti-termite and kept the house cool in a unique way by spreading over 10cm of salt under the floor. The construction didn't use cement but instead used keo o duoc. The entire system of roof trusses and 16 large pillars with a diameter of 180cm and height of 4-6m were connected not with nails but with mortise and tenon joints. The law of symmetry with yin and yang, left and right, front and back was particularly emphasized by the homeowner. In the middle of the front hall, the most solemn place used for the altar, ancestor worship, and a pair of carved and gilded couplets, there is a worship bed, a dresser, a long bench, and a pair of high vases over 3m... All were created by skilled artisans from the North, Central, and South with large sizes made of precious wood, covered with lacquer and gold, or made of xac cu wood, intricately carved with themes of water life in the Mekong Delta or: Tam Da - Tu Quy, Mai - Lan - Cuc - Truc, Phuc - Loc - Tho, Long - Lan - Quy - Phuong...|||Notably, this ancient house holds a valuable "treasury of antiques" that has been preserved for generations, including two sets of furniture from Yunnan, China, with a 1.5m diameter, 6cm thick green marble tabletop, a Louis 15-style French salon with a green marble tabletop, an 18th-century chandelier, a 19th-century hanging lamp, and more. The family's passion for collecting antiques was renowned in the six provinces of the Mekong Delta. In the 1970s, a 1.2m high blue and white ceramic vase was offered 25 taels of gold, after deducting dozens of taels that had been gilded around the mouth. The story of buying elephant ivory in Saigon in the 1940s and then selling it to Tran Trinh Trach, the salt king of Bac Lieu, for "any price" is also remarkable, but the Duong family refused to sell and brought it back to Binh Thuy to enjoy.|||Spanning over a century with many natural storms and 30 years of war, it's miraculous that this house still stands in the "land of talented people" of Can Tho: Long Tuyen - Binh Thuy. To this day, the house continues to captivate many visitors: the young feel connected to their ancestors, the elderly reminisce about the past, travelers away from home hear the echoes of their roots, and friends from afar gain a deeper understanding of their nation's history and culture.|||The scenery and artistic character along with the open and hospitable Southern Vietnamese mentality, as well as the owner's deep understanding of this land, have made this house a familiar cultural tourism destination, welcoming hundreds of domestic and international visitors each year. The current owner of the ancient Binh Thuy house is Mr. Duong Minh Hien, a former soldier over 60 years old. The ancient Binh Thuy house also has a connection with the 'seventh art' as it has been featured in dozens of Vietnamese films and the famous French film 'The Lover' directed by JJ.Annaud, which was shot here for over a week. The ancient beauty of the house amazed the demanding director and he affirmed that the house's interior and exterior will add value to the film. Later, director JJ.Annaud shared that his stay at the ancient Binh Thuy house was a very beautiful experience in his filmmaking career.

title: Nguyen Sinh Sacc Relic Site
description: Location: Nguyen Sinh Sacc Relic Site is located at 123/1 Pham Huu Lau, Ward 4, Cao Lanh City, Dong Thap Province. Characteristics: This is a monument dedicated to Nguyen Sinh Sacc, a patriot and the father of President Ho Chi Minh.|||The Nguyen Sinh Sacc relic site is a unique cultural architectural complex, recognized as a national historical site by the Ministry of Culture on April 9, 1992.|||Nguyen Sinh Sacc was an intelligent and studious boy who became an orphan at a young age. He was adopted by a scholar named Hoang Xuan Duong and later passed the imperial exam with a high ranking. He then worked as a mandarin for the Nguyen dynasty. Later in life, he lived in Hoa An village, Dong Thap Province, where he taught and practiced medicine.|||The construction of the Nguyen Sinh Sacc relic site began in August 1975 and was completed in December 1977. Covering an area of 3.6 hectares, the site consists of three main areas: Nguyen Sinh Sacc's tomb, the Ho Chi Minh Stilt House, and the Lotus Pond.|||The tomb of Nguyen Sinh Sacc faces east and features a roof shaped like a lotus leaf, symbolizing protection and care. The roof is decorated with nine dragon statues representing the Mekong Delta provinces. The tomb is made of granite, and the surrounding area has various trees and flowers planted by people from all over the country.|||In front of the tomb is a star-shaped lotus pond with a 7-meter-high lotus statue, symbolizing Nguyen Sinh Sacc's pure and bright spirit.|||The site also features a memorial house displaying artifacts and documents related to Nguyen Sinh Sacc's life and career, as well as a replica of Ho Chi Minh's stilt house.|||Every year on the 27th day of the 10th lunar month, people gather to pay respects to Nguyen Sinh Sacc in a solemn and traditional ceremony, showing their gratitude to their ancestors.

title: Thu Bon River
description: Location: Thu Bon River originates from numerous small streams flowing down from Ngoc Linh mountain at the border of Quang Nam and Kon Tum provinces (Duy Xuyen district). Characteristics: Thu Bon River is like a vibrant vein of Quang Nam - Da Nang land, winding through rugged mountains in western Quang Nam and then flowing down to fertile plains.|||Over a long journey of hundreds of kilometers, the river thunders through rapids and waterfalls, then stretches leisurely through fertile fields and affluent villages, and passes through thriving industrial areas, each section showcasing its unique character. But no matter where it flows, the Thu Bon River is a harmonious blend of natural beauty and the richness of resources, shaped by the hands and minds of the people of Quang Nam. From Tra Mi, the river flows towards Tien Phuoc.|||Downstream of Tien Phuoc is Thac Ca waterfall, where water cascades down like a white silk ribbon against the green backdrop of the forest. The area is serene and peaceful, only occasionally disrupted by a herd of elephants crossing the river, causing a commotion in the rushing water.|||Beyond Tra Linh, the river winds its way between two towering mountains known as Hon Kem, resembling a wall. At the foot of Hon Kem are many white rocks, which still bear ancient Chieng Thanh inscriptions.|||Upon reaching Giao Thuy, the Thu Bon River merges with the Vu Gia River branch from Ha Tan, and together they flow southward, then splits into two branches encircling the Go Noi area.|||The two streams then flow through Cho Cui and Cau Lau before converging again to exit at Cua Dai.|||The riparian areas in Duy Xuyen and Dien Ban, where the Thu Bon River flows, still hold poetic and touching stories.|||The folk tale of Chiêm Sơn's maiden has been passed down. When still young, Lord Nguyên Phuc Lan lived with his father, Thuy Quan Cong, who was the governor of Quang Nam, at Thanh Chiêm citadel. One moonlit night, Lord Nguyen Phuc Lan and his father released a boat to play on the Thu Bon river. In the quiet night, they suddenly heard a mesmerizing singing voice coming from a mulberry bush. The royal boat hastily docked at the shore. Under the mulberry trees, bathed in the golden moonlight, Nguyen Phuc Lan - later to become the Lord - was captivated by the beauty of a young woman named Doan from Tien Phuoc district, Dien Ban prefecture. He had her brought to the palace, and she, who used to pick mulberries by the Thu Bon river, became Hieu Chieu Hoang Hau, the mother of Thai Ton Nguyen Phuc Tan, also known as Chua Hien.|||Nowadays, in Chiêm Sơn (Duy Xuyen), towards the West of Go Coc Hung, there is still the Vinh Vien tomb, dedicated to Hieu Chieu Hoang Hau. The Thu Bon river also runs deep in the memories and feelings of many Quang Nam writers. In the poem 'Tu vung dat que huong', writer Nguyen Van Bong writes about the Thu Bon river: 'From my village to Hoi An, in the evening I departed from the Thu Bon river pier, then took a boat. At night, the boat departed, leaving the pier, now rowing, now raising the sail to run swiftly on the water. At midnight, waking up, I drifted in the sound of singing.|||The singing echoed behind the boat, and on other boats going downstream, the voices of men and women responded to each other, resonating across the moonlit water... The next morning, I opened my eyes to find the boat had anchored at Hoi An pier. On both sides of the river, this side was the town, that side was Cam Pho, roosters crowed. On the water and on the streets, vendors called out to sell chao hen, khoai Tien Doa, Quang noodles, and banh mi mat nam (braised pork sauce)'. The Thu Bon river has clear green water, vast mulberry fields, and many poetic scenes.|||During the resistance war against France (1946-1954), the Thu Bon River was a borderline: the right bank and west were free zones; the left bank and east were temporarily occupied. Many fierce battles against French colonizers and American invaders took place on both banks and on the river. Countless revolutionary soldiers, militia, guerrilla fighters, and patriotic civilians forever remained on the land attached to this river. Those people became immortal. The Thu Bon River remains beautiful and fresh, like a vibrant vein of Quang Nam - Da Nang land.

title: Son Doong Cave
description: Location: Son Trach commune, Bo Trach district, Quang Binh province, in the core zone of Phong Nha - Ke Bang National Park. Characteristics: It is the world's largest natural cave.|||Son Doong is 3 million years old, nearly 9km long, 200m high, and 160m wide - large enough to fit a 40-storey building. With an estimated volume of 38.5 million cubic meters, Son Doong surpasses Deer Cave in Malaysia to become the world's largest natural cave. The 80m-high stalagmite columns inside the cave are also considered the tallest.|||It's known that the world's largest cave was discovered by a local man. Later, the British Royal Cave Exploration Team continued to explore and announce it. Son Doong was formed on a fault line of the Truong Son mountain range and eroded by the Rao Thuong river over millions of years, creating a giant tunnel beneath the limestone mountain. The cracks on the ceiling of the cave were eroded and collapsed, forming large sinkholes that opened up to the outside.|||The drops of water falling from the ceiling over millions of years created cave pearls with sizes as large as baseballs.|||Inside that majestic space is a separate world, a rare natural wonder that amazed Son Doong conquerors.|||Currently, the only way to reach Son Doong is to hike through the forest to Ban Doong – a small village of the Bru-Van Kieu ethnic minority community. From Ban Doong, continue deep into the Phong Nha – Ke Bang National Park forest to Hang En – the third largest cave in the world and also the entrance to Son Doong.|||The highlight inside the cave is a massive natural stalactite and stalagmite formation in Son Doong, from a distance, towards the first Sinkhole area, you can see the silhouette of the Dog's Footprint Rock towering, a majestic scene of the world's largest cave.|||From this position to get to the first Sinkhole, you have to go through a huge cave section over 1km long. From this position, you can almost admire the entire Son Doong cave.|||The second collapse doline of Son Doong, also known as the "Garden of Eden", offers a panoramic view of the forest below. The formation of this doline allows sunlight to filter into the cave, creating a small forest with trees and vegetation. A unique ecosystem within Son Doong cave has developed thanks to the sunlight.|||Inside the cave there are two campsites: the first campsite of Son Doong Cave is located near the First Sinkhole. The campsite is on a fairly flat sandy area with a stunning view of the First Sinkhole. The second campsite is also known as the beachside campsite because it is on a cave floor covered in white sand like a beach. This is also considered the most majestic campsite in the world.|||The end of the cave is a 90m-high stalactite wall named “The Vietnam Wall”. This is also the highest ceiling of the cave, about 200m. This section of the cave is quite muddy.|||When reaching the top of The Vietnam Wall is the exit of the cave.|||Currently, only Oxalis Adventure Company is licensed to operate adventure tours to explore Son Doong. These expeditions require tourists to be in good health, without heart disease, high blood pressure, or other health issues, and to provide detailed health information when registering. The tour typically lasts 4 days, with a high price tag, limited to 10 guests per tour, and usually operates from January to August.

title: Sin Ho
description: Location: About 40km from Lai Chau town on road 4D. Characteristics: This village is home to many different ethnic groups and has a vibrant weekly market on Sundays.|||Sin Ho is a highland district in Lai Chau province, with its district capital being Sin Ho town. Sin Ho district has 56,000 residents consisting of 15 ethnic groups living together on an area of 1,746km². Geographically, the north of Sin Ho borders Yunnan (China), the east borders Phong Tho district, the south borders Tua Chua district (Dien Bien) and the west borders Muong Te district.|||In the local language, "Sin Ho" is where many streams converge. At an altitude of 1,500m above sea level, Sin Ho plateau is likened to the roof of Lai Chau province. The climate here is quite similar to that of Sa Pa town, cool all year round, creating conditions for many temperate flowers and fruits such as plums, peaches, pears... to develop.|||Sin Ho, an attractive destination|||From Lai Chau town, the road to Sin Ho passes through many dense forests with valleys, streams and a quite rich system of caves. From Dien Bien, you can get to Sin Ho by National Road 12 to Muong Lay, then at Cha Nua junction, turn into Provincial Road 128 to have the chance to travel along the majestic Da River, conquer two passes Ma Thi Ho (Muong Lay) and Cha Nua (Sin Ho) covered in clouds all year round.|||Regardless of the route taken, visitors can enjoy the pristine beauty and the adventurous feeling when winding along the ups and downs, sharp turns that make you dizzy…|||Sin Ho boasts many attractive scenic spots such as Cong Troi, Tien Ong mountain, O Da mountain... associated with numerous legendary tales. Visitors will be amazed and delighted by the sight of misty mountains and valleys turning golden during harvest season.|||Exploring the villages of Pu Dao, Ta Ghenh, Hoang Ho, Ta Phin, and Phang Xo Lin of the Mong and Dao people, who live close to the mountainside, one might feel as if stepping into a fairy tale. The small wooden houses nestled among the green forests, women from ethnic minorities carrying water up steep slopes, and small pigs foraging at the forest edge create a picturesque scene.|||Sin Ho is even more beautiful on weekends when the market takes place. Although it starts on Saturday morning, it mainly attracts locals living around the town at this time. It becomes truly lively and bustling on Sunday when people from distant villages and communes come, including the Red Mong from Chan Lua, Lang Mo, or the Lu, Yao from Phang Xo Lin, and the Hoa Mong, Phu La from Pu Sam Cap, who travel a whole day to get here. They come with goods they make themselves. The gentle and simple faces, the colorful ethnic costumes, the chatter of buying and selling, and the joyful laughter along with the food brought with the flavor of the mountains and forests create a vibrant picture full of the sounds of life…|||New tourism product|||In recent years, in zone 2 of Sin Ho town, a health care service for tourists has been offered, including herbal baths, massages, and acupressure, provided by Mr. Sung A Pao, a renowned Mong ethnic medicine man. Many leaders of the district and agencies have brought guests to this service, introducing it as a local "specialty", but it has yet to develop due to lack of capital and a rational investment strategy.|||The bathing soak solution is a type of black viscous water made from 10 types of medicinal herbs picked from the mountain, including ginger and lemongrass that can be grown in your own garden. Guests will be invited into a small room, to shed their clothes and sit soaking up to their necks in the hot medicinal water solution at around 40º, contained in a wooden barrel, with a strong, pungent aroma.|||It's a medicinal bath, so after just a few minutes of soaking, visitors feel like their body is melting into a pleasant, floating sensation. No wonder before getting into the medicinal tub, the technician keeps reminding: "if you feel too dizzy, please sit up and pull back the curtain to breathe some fresh air" (!). After 30 to 40 minutes of soaking, guests are invited upstairs to move on to the "technical" stage of massage and acupressure.|||Many people, after lying on their stomach to experience the renowned doctor's fingers tracing across various acupressure points on their body, can't help but acknowledge that Mr. Pao possesses a pair of "golden hands". Starting from the temples, under the jawline, down the spine, and all the way to the tips of the toes and fingers, wherever Mr. Pao's hands touch, the initial sensation is a sharp pain, followed by numbness that spreads evenly, leaving the person feeling as though their body is dissolving and then being rearranged, as if preparing for rebirth. The most fascinating part is the "high-level" thrust into the back, which seems to transfer an extraordinary force, causing the client to suddenly jump up with a surprising and artistic movement, marking the end of this unique physical therapy session. Notably, the service comes with an equally unique price tag: only 50,000 dong. Before parting ways, clients are also offered a cup of hot medicinal water, brewed from the same herbs used in the therapeutic bath.|||Potential and prospects|||Sin Ho is a potential tourist destination in Lai Chau province, a relatively new spot for many travelers.|||This place boasts stunning natural scenery with famous landmarks like O Rock and Tiên Cave, as well as two historical sites in Le Loi commune: the Le Loi stele carved on the stone wall on the north bank of the Da River and the mansion of the puppet king Deo Van Long during the resistance war against France.|||The area also features unique terraced fields, highland markets with distinct local traditions, and villages of the Mong and Dao ethnic groups nestled on mountain slopes, including Pu Dao village.|||Although Sin Ho attracts around 30,000 domestic and international visitors each year, tourism activities are still spontaneous and lack clear products and target services. In Lai Chau province's socio-economic development plan, the 2011-2015 tourism development project focuses on sustainable tourism development in Sin Ho plateau in stages, including community-based tourism and eco-tourism with homestays. This approach connects cultural villages and existing tourism routes in the Northwest region, while highlighting the folk cultural values of local communities.|||Besides its eco-tourism and resort potential, visitors to Sin Ho can also participate in a health treatment using physical therapy with precious medicinal plants found only in this region. They can enjoy local specialties like beef wrapped in lard leaves, steamed deer, hill pork, brook trout, sticky rice, and thang co ... along with the cold-water salmon, a specialty of the region, successfully farmed locally.|||Hopefully in the near future, Sin Ho tourism will not only stop at its hidden beauty but will be developed reasonably, bringing many interesting inspirations for visitors whenever they have the opportunity to explore. Sin Ho plateau will forever be an impressive destination, both simple and peaceful...

title: Ho Coc Beach
description: Nature has favored Vung Tau with many charming beaches, and among them, Ho Coc Beach stands out as a renowned destination, often referred to as a paradise within Vung Tau.|||Ho Coc Beach is located in Hung Bien Commune, Xuyen Moc District, Ba Ria - Vung Tau Province. At just 175km from Ho Chi Minh City, it has become an ideal getaway for tourists from Ho Chi Minh City and the southern provinces.|||The beauty of Ho Coc Beach lies in its pristine shores with crystal-clear waters and soft, white sand. The beach is surrounded by rows of pine and green trees providing shade. A notable feature of Ho Coc Beach is the presence of variously shaped rocks scattered from the sandy dunes to the clear waters. Sitting on the beach, listening to the clear sound of waves hitting the rocks, and enjoying the cool sea breeze is surely an unforgettable experience.|||Not far from Ho Coc Beach is a primeval forest, popular among young travelers for its picturesque spots perfect for photography. The forest has some waterlogged areas forming natural saltwater lakes, both unique and romantic.|||Ho Coc Beach is a preferred choice for many tourists for short vacations, weekends, or team-building activities. When visiting Ho Coc Beach, tourists can also combine their trip with visits to other attractions such as Binh Chau Hot Spring, Suoi Nghe Sheep Farm, Phuoc Hai Seafood Market…

title: Den Cuong Temple
description: Location: Den Cuong Temple is located on Mo Da Mountain, in Dien An Commune, Dien Chau District, Nghe An Province, about 30km north of Vinh City. Characteristics: This is a sacred temple dedicated to Thuc An Duong Vuong - King of Au Lac (250-208 BC).|||From Vinh City, follow National Highway 1A for about 30km north to reach Den Cuong Temple.|||Legend has it that after being helped by Than Kim Quy to build a citadel and create a magical crossbow, Thuc An Duong Vuong became complacent and fell into a trap set by Trieu Da. In 208, after capturing the magical crossbow, Trieu Da launched a surprise attack on Au Lac, and Thuc An Duong Vuong retreated south. When he reached Cua Hien Beach (at the northern foot of Mo Da Mountain), he was welcomed by Than Kim Quy and Thuy Than.|||To commemorate Thuc An Duong Vuong, after his death, locals built a temple in his honor at Cua Hien. However, whenever night fell, a flickering flame would appear on the slope of Mo Da Mountain, and locals believed it was the king's spirit. They then built a temple at this location, calling it Den Cuong.|||The temple is called Den Cuong, but it implies 'Den Cong,' as 'Cong' in Nghe An dialect means 'Cuong.' Legend says that the Mo Da Mountain area was once inhabited by many peacocks, and the mountain's shape resembles a giant peacock dancing, with the temple located at the bird's head. To this day, there is no historical record of the exact time when Den Cuong Temple was first built. However, during the Nguyen Dynasty, the temple was renovated several times, especially in 1864 when King Tu Duc ordered its reconstruction on a larger scale.|||Den Cuong Temple is a beautiful and sturdy architectural work, harmonizing with the natural surroundings in Central Vietnam, with many green trees planted around it. The temple follows the 'Tam' architecture, comprising three main buildings: Tam Quan, and the Upper, Middle, and Lower Halls.|||The Tam Quan gate is impressive, with three entrances: the central gate has three tiers, and the two side gates have two tiers, all designed in a vaulted style.|||The Upper Hall, where Thuc An Duong Vuong's altar is located, and the Lower Hall, both have a 4-roof architecture with curved eaves. The Middle Hall, dedicated to Cao Lo - the general who helped the king create the magical crossbow, is built with an 8-roof architecture. All structures are grand, with large pillars and thick walls, yet elegant and refined due to intricate carvings and patterns.|||Den Cuong Temple also preserves many valuable artifacts: drums, gongs, statues, and ritual objects. The temple still keeps many documents in Chinese characters on horizontal boards, pillars, and steles, reminding descendants and people of Thuc An Duong Vuong's merits.|||The Den Cuong Temple festival takes place from the 14th to 16th day of the 2nd lunar month every year, attracting locals and tourists to come and pay respects to Thuc An Duong Vuong. The festival features various activities such as: worshiping gods, parades, folk songs, traditional performances, firecrackers, and lantern releases... which are sure to bring interesting experiences to visitors.

title: Phuoc Lam Pagoda
description: Location: Cam Ha Ward, Hoi An City, Quang Nam Province. Characteristics: The pagoda was built by monk Minh Luong (one of the two first monks to come to Hoi An) at the end of the 17th century to worship Buddha|||The pagoda is built in the ancient Eastern style, in the form of the Chinese character "Mon", including the main gate, yard, main hall, great hall, and ancestor worship house. The main hall is a 3-room, 2-tiled structure with two tower-shaped bell towers on either side. The great hall preserves many precious artifacts such as the alms bowl of monk Minh Luong and wooden Buddhist scriptures. Phuoc Lam Pagoda is a religious relic that contributes to the richness of Buddhist architectural forms and the process of spreading Buddhism in Hoi An.

title: Love Valley
description: Location: Love Valley is about 5km north of Da Lat city center. Characteristics: Love Valley is nestled on a hillside with pine forests that are green year-round.|||Initially, the French called this place Valley d'Amour; later, during Bao Dai's reign, it was renamed Hoa Binh Valley. In 1953, when Nguyen Vy, Chairman of the town council at the time, suggested changing French names to Vietnamese to reflect national independence, the name 'Love Valley' was born.|||In 1972, a large dam was built across the valley, creating a large lake called Da Thien Lake. The lake adds to the valley's charm and appeal to tourists, especially couples from all over the country. Visitors can follow the winding paths or climb hundreds of steps, passing through colorful flower gates to reach Vong Canh Hill. From here, Love Valley unfolds like a picturesque painting, with sailboats gliding across the lake.

title: Co Le Pagoda
description: Location: Co Le Pagoda is located in Co Le town, Truc Ninh district, Nam Dinh province. Characteristics: The pagoda has existed for a long time. It features a 12-storey Cao Pham Lien Hoa tower built in 1926-1927.|||From Nam Dinh city, cross the suspension bridge over Dao river, follow road 21 for about 15km to Co Le town, then take a small bridge and turn right about 200m to reach the pagoda.|||Co Le Pagoda has a long history. Legend has it that the pagoda was founded by Zen master Nguyen Minh Khong during the Ly dynasty. The current pagoda was built by abbot Pham Quang Tuyen in November 1920. In front of the pagoda stands a 12-storey Cao Pham Lien Hoa tower built in 1926-1927. The tower's base has 8 sides, placed on the back of a large turtle facing the pagoda. Inside the tower is a large pillar with 60 spiral stairs from the base to the top. From here, visitors can admire the scenery of the area.|||Crossing a curved bridge leads to the "Buddhist meeting hall" built in 1936. From this hall, cross two bridges between mountains to reach the main pagoda. In the pagoda's yard is a large bell weighing 9 tons, 3.2m high, cast in 1936. The upper hall features a 4m high, 3.5m wide wooden statue of Buddha Shakyamuni. The Ancestor's house has a statue of Pham Quang Tuyen.|||Co Le Pagoda not only worships Buddha but also honors Zen master Nguyen Minh Khong. The pagoda has many precious artifacts such as a large bronze bell, a bronze drum from the Ly dynasty, and a bronze pouch. Co Le Pagoda has been recognized by the state as a cultural and architectural relic.

title: Lac Canh Dai Nam Van Hien Tourist Site
description: Location: Hiep An Ward, Thu Dau Mot City, Binh Duong Province, about 30km north of Ho Chi Minh City. Features: With a total area of 476ha, Lac Canh Dai Nam Van Hien is a complex of spiritual tourism with various structures including temples, citadels, mountains, rivers, hotels, and entertainment areas… offering a spiritual tourism experience rich in cultural and historical significance of the nation.|||The highlight of Lac Canh Dai Nam Van Hien tourist area is the spiritual zone with a total area of 61ha.|||The worship area is encircled by 2 green dragons, each 270m long, which is a cultural and historical landmark.|||It represents the essence of Vietnamese civilization over 4,000 years.|||Behind the Dai Nam temple is the majestic Bao Son mountain range with 5 peaks: Metal - Wood - Water - Fire - Earth, with the central peak standing at 65.8m. To the west of Bao Son is the temple dedicated to the White Tiger god, while to the east are the temples of Mountain God and Nong God.|||Venturing deeper into the mountain, looking westward is the place of worship for various celestial deities including: Pham Mau Chuan De, Quan Am Nam Hai, Quan Am Bach Y, Di Lac Buddha and Dia Mau; to the east lies the shrine for Vietnam's national heroes across different eras such as: King Ngo Quyen, Trang Trinh Nguyen Binh Khiem.|||This site also serves as a historical recreation of Vietnam's struggles in nation-building and defense, notable for being home to thousands of swallows, symbolizing a 'fertile land where birds settle'. The heart of the religious complex is the 5,000m² Dai Nam temple.|||The highlight of Dai Nam temple is the Kim Dien building, whose main hall is dedicated to Sakyamuni Buddha, King Hung and Dieu Ngu Giac Hoang Tran Nhan Tong. To the right of the hall are shrines for Tran Hung Dao, Mother Au Co and a communal board listing 1039 family names of Vietnamese people.|||To the left are shrines for Uncle Ho, ancestral founders and a triad altar for Town God - God of Wealth - Earth God. All statues in Kim Dien and the steles of national heroes Quang Trung and Ly Thuong Kiet standing guard outside are gilded.|||Kim Dien was built in a square and circular shape. The circular roof symbolizes the sky, featuring 108 painted storks: 54 represent Vietnam's 54 ethnic groups in the mortal realm, and 54 represent the same ethnic groups in the underworld. The center of the vaulted ceiling is the acoustic point called diem vong am. Standing at this point, sounds are amplified and transmitted throughout Kim Dien. The square shape is represented by the four temple walls, which include 28 sets of doors, each weighing 500kg. These 28 doors are adorned with 28 historical paintings highlighting significant milestones in Vietnam's history, from the Hai Ba Trung uprising to the glorious victory of the 1975 spring. The temple contains two giant candles called Dai Hoang Dang, each 2.7m high and 90cm in diameter, which are expected to burn for many years.|||The gentle, winding Bao Giang stream with a total length of 720m flows around Kim Dien. Following the Bao Giang stream, a part of Vietnamese people's life is recreated through terraced fields, chayote trellises, the gentle gurgling sound of water flowing from the mountain crevices, and schools of fish swimming in the crystal-clear small streams. All of this evokes a sense of serenity, peace, and simplicity of Vietnamese rural life.|||The 9-storey Bao Thap tower rises from the central mountain of the Bao Son range. This is a place of worship, expressing the gratitude and tribute of later generations to their ancestors and predecessors.|||Each floor of the tower has different meanings.|||Floor 1: Dedicated to the spirits of heroic martyrs and fallen compatriots.|||Floor 2: honors the unknown soldiers who sacrificed themselves for their country.|||The third floor: to worship President Ho Chi Minh.|||Floor four: dedicated to Tran Hung Dao.|||Floor 5: Dedicated to female heroes throughout Vietnamese history: Trung Trac - Trung Nhi, Trieu Thi Trinh, Bui Thi Xuan and Nguyen Thi Dinh.|||The sixth floor: honors those who have contributed to the country and have been deified.|||The seventh floor: worship of 18 generations of Hung Kings.|||Floor eight: worship of the Three Realms Council including: Council of Buddhas, Four Palaces Council and Council of the Country from the founding of the country to present.|||Floor 9: dedicated to the homeland.|||Another attraction at Lac Canh Dai Nam Van Hien tourist site is the 12.5ha zoological garden. This is the first open zoo in Vietnam with over 100 species of mammals, birds, reptiles and ornamental fish living in harmony in a diverse ecological environment. Here, visitors can see firsthand the animals raised and released into a semi-natural environment, including rare species that have appeared in Vietnam for the first time such as white lions, white tigers, spiral-horned antelopes, South American squirrels... Additionally, with the first night zoo in Vietnam, visitors can observe the life and activity of wild animals at night thanks to the moonlight system at the zoo.|||In addition, the modern entertainment zone offers over 40 games ranging from gentle, relaxing experiences to thrilling challenges that test your spirit, from adventurous games to exploring nature's mysteries, catering to every visitor's needs. Most of these games are making their first appearance in Vietnam. Notably, the 21.6ha Dai Nam artificial sea, comprising freshwater and saltwater areas, is an ideal spot for relaxation. The saltwater at Dai Nam is blended from sea salt in the Vinh Hao - Tuy Phong - Binh Thuan region and dissolved minerals, with an appropriate salinity level, beneficial for health. The waves are created by wind with 9 unique wave patterns. Interesting water games for kids, sports playgrounds for adults, and seafood dishes with a distinct coastal flavor are sure to provide a truly enjoyable and relaxing experience.|||Part of the Lac Canh Dai Nam Van Hien tourist complex, it features a hotel system with unique architectural styles inspired by Co Loa Citadel and Hue Imperial City, allowing visitors to glimpse the past of our ancestors during the early nation-building and defense period.|||The Dai Nam shopping area, covering over 8,000m², offers a wide range of diverse products that will satisfy the shopping needs of tourists.|||With such a large-scale tourist site, Lac Canh Dai Nam Van Hien is holding many national records: the largest temple, the longest hotel, the longest artificial mountain and river, the largest artificial sea, the largest square, the zoo with the most rare and expensive species. This is a project with a profound educational, cultural, and historical significance.

title: Tu Duc Tomb (Khiem Tomb)
description: Location: Tu Duc Tomb is located in Thuy Bieu commune, Hue city, Thua Thien - Hue province. Characteristics: The tomb was built in 1864 and completed in 1867 on an area of 475ha.
