Unlike other tombs which are built symmetrically, Tu Duc Tomb is built in a free and natural style, harmonizing with the available nature, reflecting the romantic spirit of this poet king.|||Tu Duc Tomb is a masterpiece poem, a picturesque landscape painting, evoking for visitors a 'soul of serene poetry' (a sweet dream). The tomb of King Tu Duc was built in an extremely difficult historical context of the country and of the king himself.|||The king was born in 1829 and ascended to the throne at the age of 20 (1848). Ten years later, due to the Hue court applying a narrow-minded foreign policy, French colonizers attacked Da Nang (1858) and then invaded and occupied Gia Dinh (1859) and several other provinces in Southern Vietnam (1862)... King Tu Duc had quite thoroughly absorbed Eastern philosophy and culture, but with an internal contradiction between the positive aspects of his youth and the negative aspects of his old age, between life and death. As he grew older and faced more failures in national affairs, he became increasingly pessimistic. The king thought about the inevitable death that would come to his life, and to alleviate the pain and suffering in his remaining years, he ordered the construction of a tomb like a second imperial palace where he could occasionally come to relax and rest, and also to make it his "eternal palace" (vi ngo vinh vu, cited in Khiem Cung Ky).|||Standing in the present day, looking back at the difficult circumstances of the country at that time, the grand and costly architecture of the royal tomb, and the names Khiem Cung and Khiem Lang used to name it, we see that it is also an internal contradiction that is hard to justify by the king himself.|||However, after the construction of the tomb was completed, King Tu Duc lived for another 16 years, until 1883, at the age of 55.|||After officials specializing in geography surveyed the land and chose a site in Duong Xuan Thuong village, King Tu Duc 'finalized' the architectural plan for the tomb according to his own preferences in October 1864. However, they had to choose a good day to start, so construction began in December of that year.||||||The entire construction work of this tomb complex was expected to take 6 years with 3,000 soldiers and workers, and they would be rotated to rest every 3 months. However, the Minister of Public Works, Nguyen Van Chat, petitioned to complete it in just 3 years. The court sent him and Major General Le Van Xa from the Ministry of Defense to oversee the construction.|||Unable to take turns to rest, and forced to work at maximum capacity in poor conditions, these 3,000 disgruntled soldiers and workers heeded the call to rise up by Doan Trung. On the night of 16 to 17 September 1866, they used the banner of "Nguy Dai Hoan Ton" to march towards the Imperial City, aiming to overthrow King Tu Duc and install Ung Dao, a 5th generation grandson of King Gia Long, to the throne. However, when they reached the Thai Hoa Hall, they were strongly opposed by the imperial forces and failed. The rebellion was completely crushed. This close call for King Tu Duc was over, but his prestige was considerably damaged, as this was not a foreign invasion but an internal rebellion right at the heart of the central imperial court.|||Among the 13 Nguyen kings, King Tu Duc was the most knowledgeable about Eastern studies, particularly Confucianism. He excelled in history, philosophy, literature, art, and especially poetry. He left behind 600 articles and 4,000 poems and essays in Chinese and around 100 poems in Nom script. His poetry and writings reflect a kind-hearted person, a sensitive soul, and a passion for art.|||This artistic inclination is also evident in the architecture of his tomb. According to historical records, the king himself decided on the construction plan. Within the La Thanh wall, covering approximately 12 hectares, nearly 50 architectural works are scattered across complex terrain with varying heights of around 10 meters.|||However, the stone-paved steps and winding paths made of Bat Trang tiles connect all the architectural works into a unified, harmonious, and intimate whole.|||Beyond Khiem Cung Mon, a two-story triple gate built on high ground, visitors enter a complex of palaces and dozens of large and small buildings, along with ancillary architectural works.||||||The transverse and longitudinal buildings here were reserved for the king and his entourage of ladies-in-waiting to occasionally stay and play. Minh Kiem Hall - an ancient theater with architectural and decorative artistic value. Hoa Kiem Temple - where the king and queen are worshiped, currently contains many royal artifacts and contemporary artworks.|||While the houses in Khiem Cung are made of wood, all the architectural works in the tomb area are built with bricks and stones. The most notable is the largest stele in Vietnam, standing at about 5m high, protected by a large sturdy building with thick columns and walls and a vaulted door. The architects built the Stele Pavilion with such materials and style to withstand the test of time.|||On the hill overlooking the semicircular lake, Tieu Khiem Tri, is Bao Thanh, built of bricks, and in the center is a small stone house, where the king rests. Bao Thanh is covered by a lush green pine forest, which rustles throughout the four seasons.|||In addition, the drainage system throughout the tomb complex has been designed and built to a high standard, with very good circulation. Overall, each architectural work in Tu Duc Tomb has its own unique artistic style, with no repetition and great vitality. The layout of the areas and the arrangement of the architectural works in each area in Tu Duc Tomb have broken the traditional convention of maintaining classical symmetry found in some other tombs. There are winding paths that follow the natural terrain or have been shaped by human hands. The architectural lines are truly free and harmonious with nature, either taking advantage of the existing natural beauty or reworking it to fit the landscape architecture.|||Breaking symmetry is also a beauty in art, and Tu Duc Tomb has that extra beauty. The architecture and nature here evoke new and unique aesthetic emotions for visitors, reflecting the romantic and poetic soul of a poet king.|||Tu Duc Tomb is a masterpiece, a picturesque landscape painting that evokes a serene and dreamy atmosphere for visitors.

title: Ngã Ba Đồng Lộc Youth Relic
description: Located in Dong Loc commune, Can Loc district, Ha Tinh province, 20km from Ha Tinh city center. Characterized as a monument to the unyielding will and noble sacrifice of young volunteers during the anti-American resistance war.|||Ba Dong Loc junction is nestled in a triangular valley, flanked by bare hills on both sides, with a sole road running through it. It is the intersection of National Route 15A and Provincial Road 2, located in Dong Loc commune.|||From late April 1965, National Route 1A was completely severed. All goods transported by road to support the Southern battlefield had to pass through Nga Ba Dong Loc. From then on, Nga Ba Dong Loc became the most heavily attacked point by the US Empire on the entire Military Zone 4.|||During the 7 months of "limited bombing" in 1968, the enemy focused a large amount of bombing on Nga Ba Dong Loc. However, the main force units, local military units, and self-defense militia fighting here still bravely held their positions and effectively counterattacked.|||At its peak, there were 16,000 people here, mostly artillery soldiers and youth volunteers clearing bombs and opening roads.|||The strong firepower of the 210 high-angle artillery regiment combined with 12.7mm clusters of self-defense militia in the area created a dense fire net in the sky of Nga Ba Dong Loc, ensuring the safe transportation of supplies from North to South.|||During the intense battles against enemy bombs and bullets, many brave and resilient fighters emerged at Nga Ba Dong Loc. A notable example is the 10 young female volunteers of Team 4, Company 552, Battalion 55, led by team leader Vo Thi Tan. With the spirit of ensuring the smooth operation of the strategic transport route from the North to the South, the military and people of Dong Loc united to shoot down 19 American planes; dismantle 1,780 slow-explosion and magnetic bombs; contribute 974,240 workdays to clear and create new roads; mobilize 42,620 people to serve the fight; dig and fill 95,209m3 of wood; provide 22,448 bamboo stakes, 24,000 loads of sand and gravel to prevent mud... completely foiling the US imperialists' plot to cut off the North-South strategic transport route through Dong Loc. This place has become a legend during the years of fighting against the US to save the country of the Party Committee and people of Ha Tinh.|||The Ngã ba Đồng Lộc youth shock troops historical site is built on an area of 0.6km2, including the following items:|||The Victory Monument was inaugurated on July 15, 1998, symbolizing the strength, will to fight and win, and the spirit of rising of young volunteers, soldiers, traffic workers, police, militia, etc.|||The monument is surrounded by reliefs depicting the vibrant and urgent atmosphere of filling bomb craters, shooting down enemy planes, defusing bombs, and clearing roads for vehicles to pass by the forces at Nga Ba Dong Loc.|||The memorial symbol of the Transportation industry is located right in the middle of the intersection, and was inaugurated on March 26, 1992.|||Located near the symbol, at the foot of Tro Voi mountain, is a stele house commemorating the heroes and martyrs of the Transportation industry, listing and commemorating 842 heroic martyrs of the industry who sacrificed their lives during the resistance war against America in Ha Tinh.|||The memorial monument for national youth volunteers was built by the Ho Chi Minh Communist Youth Union in 1998. It engraved the names of 1,950 heroic martyrs who were national youth volunteers and those who sacrificed their lives at Nga Ba Dong Loc.|||The tomb of 10 female youth volunteers who died heroically at the Dong Loc Intersection. On July 15, 1990, the 10 graves were moved to the foot of Tro Voi mountain, about 30 meters from the memorial stele. The bomb crater next to where the 10 women sacrificed still remains in its original position.||||||The National Traditional Youth Shock Troop Museum displays 228 original artifacts, over 248 photos, and documents that provide visitors with insight into the life, labor, and fight of youth shock troops on all roads with the spirit of 'All for the frontline', 'The enemy destroys one, we build ten'.|||The Ngã Ba Dong Loc traditional display room features an electronic sand table depicting the intense scene of the Dong Loc battlefield nearly 50 years ago, as well as the strong will and bravery of our soldiers and people at this "Deadly Coordinate". The display room has precious artifacts such as a letter from sister Vo Thi Tan to her mother, a set of clothes of sister Xuan, electric wire and bomb-detonating magnet of Vuong Dinh Nho, a bowl used by the sisters, a personal history book, a notebook of songs by sister Huong, restored photos of 10 young female soldiers, an original aerial photo of Dong Loc, bomb fragments, dozens of unexploded bombs, a 12ly7 gun... and some outdoor exhibits such as AD6 plane, 57, 37, 63, 57 guns, bulldozer...|||The Dong Loc Bell Tower was inaugurated on January 2, 2011.|||This is a gratitude monument for the previous generations and an educational work on revolutionary patriotism.|||It instills the tradition of "drinking water, remembering its source" for the current and future generations.|||The tower has 7 floors, 8 roofs, and a height of 37m.|||A 5.7-ton bell is hung at the top.|||Visitors can climb a spiral staircase to the top to see the scenery of Nga Ba Dong Loc and the landscape of Can Loc.|||The monument of 10 young female volunteers is located near the center on Mui Mac mountain slope. On the left are 3 ready-made bomb craters. The monument is 7.5m high, 15.5m long and 5m wide, depicting the scene of 10 sisters rushing out to the road with rugged bomb craters. The sisters are portrayed in different poses: one holding a shovel, one pulling a cart, and sister Tran - the team leader, still holding a gun to observe for her teammates, and one hand holding a flag raised high to guide the transport convoys passing through.|||On December 9, 2013, the Ngã ba Đồng Lộc Youth Shock Troop historic site was recognized by the State as a Special National Historic Site on the legendary Ho Chi Minh trail.|||It has become a cradle that fosters patriotism and educates revolutionary traditions for our people, especially for today's and future young generations.

title: Cam Luong Fish Cave
description: Location: Cam Luong Fish Cave is located in Cam Luong commune, Cam Thuy district, Thanh Hoa province, about 80km from Thanh Hoa city. Feature: There are thousands of fish swimming in the stream. Locals consider this a sacred school of fish, they never catch them and voluntarily protect them, hoping the gods will bring good weather.|||Traveling nearly 80km from Thanh Hoa city to Cam Thuy district, a boat will take you to the left bank of the Ma River to visit Cam Luong Fish Cave (also known as the "divine" Fish Stream), one of the unique natural wonders of Xuc Thanh land.|||Hang Ca is a vast body of water located within the Truong Sinh mountain range.|||The school of "divine" fish, with thousands of individuals, swim and play in the stream flowing towards the shore, as if welcoming visitors to the site.|||The "divine" fish are stunning to behold, with shiny skin in shades of gold and black, resembling a luxurious brocade; their fins and lips are a vibrant pink, and each fish weighs around 20kg.|||The larger "divine" fish only emerge from the cave on high tide days.|||The fish reproduce inside the cave, and the young ones, once they reach about 2kg, swim out of the cave and into the Ngoc stream.|||The school of fish usually stays within the Ngoc stream and rarely swims beyond the confluence of the streams, where the Tu Phu Long Vuong temple is located.|||From the upstream, following the path to Truong Sinh mountain range shrouded in dense Đăng trees, visitors will reach the entrance of Đăng cave at a height of 70m above the ground. Entering the cave, multi-colored stalactites and stalagmites sparkle like diamonds on the cave walls and ceiling, creating a breathtakingly beautiful scene. Đăng cave is high, airy and cool, giving the feeling of standing under a starry summer sky. The cave's interior seems endless, stretching deep into the earth. The gentle gurgling of a small stream nestled beside the cave wall catches the visitor's attention. This is the source of the Cam Luong fish stream.|||Visiting the fish cave, tourists often wonder why it's called the "divine fish"? The legend of the Muong people tells the story of an old couple who were childless and would often go to their field by the stream to farm and catch fish for food. One day, the old woman found a strange egg while fishing. She threw it back into the water but kept finding it again. She took it home and they decided to let a chicken incubate it. A few days later, the egg hatched into a snake. The old man released the snake into the Ngoc stream, but it kept coming back home. Over time, the snake became like a domesticated animal. Since the snake appeared, the crops flourished, and the region enjoyed peace, prosperity, and happiness. The snake was revered by the villagers and called Chang Ran.|||One stormy night, the snake died under the Truong Sinh mountain, near the Ngoc stream. The villagers were informed by the spirits that Chang Ran had died fighting the water monster that was destroying their village, and he was then crowned by Ngoc Hoang as a god and the Tu Phu Long Vuong. The villagers built the Ngoc temple by the stream to commemorate his merits.|||From then on, the Ngoc stream in front of the temple had a group of thousands of "divine" fish that came to pay homage to the gods and guard the Ngoc temple every day and night.|||Every year, on the day of the Tet le Tu phu Long vuong ceremony, the elderly man performed a ritual to ask the gods and waited until the evening, when the fish entered the cave, and any fish that remained in the stream would self-offer as a sacrificial offering.|||The village elder would then take the fish to the temple to offer to the gods and invite the villagers to share in the offering.|||The village custom has been maintained to this day, and as a result, the group of fish in the Ngoc stream has never dwindled, and has instead grown larger and more abundant each day.|||Protecting the "divine" fish is a voluntary effort in the minds of the people of Muong village, who wish for the gods to grant them favorable weather and bountiful harvests.

title: Dam Sen Water Park
description: Location: 03 Hoa Binh, Ward 3, District 11, Ho Chi Minh City. Phone: (84-8) 38588418; Fax: 38588419. Features: Dam Sen Water Park is equipped with modern water play equipment, harmoniously set in a 3-hectare Eastern-style garden in the heart of the city, making it an ideal spot for entertainment for you and your family.|||Located in the Dam Sen entertainment complex, the water park features 26 unique water attractions and a 3000m2 wave pool surrounded by lush greenery, providing an ideal place for relaxation and fun for you and your family after stressful days of work or study. Here, you can experience a green oasis in the midst of the city. Take a deep breath to enjoy the fresh air of a romantic natural setting, then immerse yourself in the gentle waves.|||For young thrill-seekers, there are adrenaline-pumping games like the 19m high Kamikaze slide, or become Tarzan with the Rope Sliding game. For those who prefer milder experiences, you can float along the 400m Lazy River or relax at the Massage Pool amidst nature. Many other exciting games await your exploration.|||Over the years, the park has invested in and upgraded new attractions like the 20m high Tornado slide, 119m long; Black Thunder three-person raft slide with special sound and light effects; Multi Slide with four paths for you and your family to compete; Love Storm 12m high with three unique spiral turns. Notably, in the summer of 2006, the park introduced the Twister-Space Bowl slide, a completely new game that promises to bring special thrilling experiences.|||When visiting the park, you can feel secure with a professional lifeguard team always ready to support and care for you. Additionally, the park offers fast food counters and a 400-seat restaurant with diverse menus, always ready to serve you.

title: Chua Doi
description: Location: 73B Le Hong Phong Street, Ward 3, Soc Trang City, Soc Trang Province, approximately 2km southeast of the city center. Characteristics: This is the only Buddhist temple dedicated to Sakyamuni Buddha for the Khmer community in Soc Trang Province.|||The temple grounds are home to tens of thousands of bats, hence the name Chua Doi. These bats are of the bat species, weighing 1-1.5kg with a wingspan of up to 1.5m. During the day, they hang and sleep on tree branches within the temple grounds. Although they are fruit-eating animals, this bat colony never eats the ripe fruit in the temple garden. Around 6pm, they fly out to forage and return to the temple at 5am the next morning.|||The temple was built in the 16th century in Khmer architectural style and has been renovated several times. Initially, the main hall was built with bamboo and thatched roof, later rebuilt with bricks, tiled roof, and four curved roof ends decorated with Naga snake. On top of the roof is a pointed spire. Surrounding the main hall are supporting columns, each with a Kemnar maiden statue with hands clasped in front of her chest. Inside the main hall is a monolithic stone statue of Sakyamuni Buddha on a 2m high lotus throne and a statue depicting the Buddha riding on the Muchalinda snake. The temple walls are adorned with paintings telling the life story of Buddha. Besides the main hall, the temple grounds also feature several stupas containing the remains of the temple's abbots and a Sa La assembly hall in the style of a communal house, serving as a resting and study place for monks.|||Chua Doi also preserves intact sets of Buddhist scriptures written on palm leaves, rare artifacts holding significant cultural and spiritual values of the Southern region.|||Behind the temple, there are peculiar tombs with a pig image on each. The first tomb was erected for a five-clawed pig that died in 1996. These five-clawed pigs were raised by monks in the temple like domestic animals and upon their death, they were buried here. The temple currently raises 4-5 five-clawed pigs.|||In 1999, Chua Doi was recognized as a national historical and cultural site by the Ministry of Culture and Information (now the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism).

title: Ham Rong Mountain
description: Location: Sa Pa town, Sa Pa district, Lao Cai province Features: This place has many beautiful flowers and is the best spot to admire the whole town of Sa Pa.|||Located right next to the center of Sa Pa town, Ham Rong Mountain is a famous tourist spot that anyone visiting Sa Pa wants to visit.|||Part of the majestic Hoang Lien Son range, at an altitude of nearly 1,800m, Ham Rong Mountain consists of rocky peaks with many interesting shapes.|||Seen from afar, Ham Rong Mountain resembles a giant dragon curled up, facing west towards the Hoang Lien Son range.|||The peak of the mountain is cleverly arranged by Mother Nature, giving the seemingly lifeless rock formations meaningful shapes.|||Locals call this peak Dragon Head Mountain because it looks like the head of a dragon facing the sky.|||There are many variations of the legend about Ham Rong Mountain, but they all tell of the love, devotion, and loyalty of the dragon.|||To preserve and promote the beauty of Ham Rong mountain, the Ham Rong tourist area was officially started construction in 1996 on an area of nearly 150ha. Here, visitors can feel the converging beauty of nature, culture and people of Sa Pa highland on every step from the foot of the mountain to the top of Ham Rong. Especially, for those who love to admire the scenery and take photos, this is a place to keep many beautiful and unique pictures.|||Ham Rong Mountain attracts tourists with a variety of flowers blooming all year round, such as azalea, rhododendron, rose... The azalea alone creates a colorful picture with a range of colors from red, purple, pink to yellow, and white.|||Here, visitors will be quickly captivated by the orchid garden located on the mountain slope with hundreds of different orchid species, including shoe orchid, sword orchid, and golden orchid, among which are rare species like Tran Mong sword orchid, Thu sword orchid, and wooden stem orchid.|||At Ham Rong, regardless of the time of year, visitors will be treated to a colorful "feast" of blooming orchid pots.|||It is most commonly found on Ham Rong mountain. Besides orchids, there are also hydrangea flowers. The flowers not only grow naturally in the rock crevices and beside the mini landscapes but are also planted into gardens with large flowers, up to 30cm in diameter. Although the colors are not too vibrant, just lightly pink, green or white, but because they grow in clusters and bloom for a long time on the rocky soil background, any place with hydrangeas seems to burst with a strong vitality, as if to dispel the cold and dryness of the highland gravel.|||Visiting Ham Rong in the spring, visitors can admire the beauty of the ancient peach garden. Here, the old peach trees with moss bloom brightly, filling a corner of the mountain with vibrant pink. Interspersed are the pure white flowers of plum and cherry blossoms.|||Not only is it stunning with many beautiful flowers in vibrant colors, Ham Rong Mountain is also considered the best spot to overlook the whole town of Sa Pa. There are 3 viewpoints: Garden of Flowers 1, Sa Pa Telecommunication Station, and Cloud Yard at the mountain peak. From different heights, visitors will have a new perspective on the "city in the fog". Among them, Cloud Yard is considered the most impressive viewpoint of Sa Pa, offering a clear and sharp view of the earth and sky.|||When visiting Ham Rong Mountain, visitors can experience the unique cultural values of local ethnic minorities. They can watch performances by young Mong men and women or dress up in traditional clothes to blend in with the locals. Various sports, cultural exchanges, and art performances are organized, allowing tourists to learn more about the daily lives of the highland people of Sa Pa.

title: Kon Ka Kinh National Park
description: Location: Kon Ka Kinh National Park (41,780ha) is located in the northeast of Gia Lai province, about 50km from Pleiku city, bordering Kon Tum province to the north and Dak Roong commune, KBang district (Gia Lai) to the north; Ha Ra, AYun and Dak Jo Ta communes, Mang Yang district to the south; Dak Roong, K Rong and Lo Ku communes, KBang district to the east and Ha Dong commune, Dak Doa district (Gia Lai) to the west. Characteristics: This is an ideal eco-tourism spot, suitable for tourists to come and relax, recuperate and conduct scientific research.|||In 1986, Kon Ka Kinh National Park (covering approximately 28,000ha) was listed as a special forest to preserve subtropical mountain forests with coniferous species. In 1999, the Forest Investigation and Planning Institute (FIPI) collaborated with BirdLife International to develop a project to establish the Kon Ka Kinh Nature Reserve, which was approved by the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development and the People's Committee of Gia Lai Province. On November 25, 2002, the Kon Ka Kinh Nature Reserve was officially upgraded to Kon Ka Kinh National Park with an area of 41,780ha under Decision No. 167/2002/QD-TTg of the Prime Minister.|||Through a meeting of Ministers on natural resources and environment held at Iagon (Myanmar) on 18 December 2003, Kon Ka Kinh National Park was recognized as an ASEAN Heritage Park.|||Kon Ka Kinh National Park is primarily made up of primeval forests with main types of forest vegetation including: dense tropical rainforest and humid subtropical mountain forest, and mixed coniferous and broadleaf forest, containing a large amount of Fokienia hodginsiana. This type of forest is uniquely found in Kon Ka Kinh National Park.|||Due to its diverse topography, climate, and other factors that form forests, Kon Ka Kinh National Park has a very rich forest vegetation; this is a convergence of various plant species such as: The North Vietnam flora including tree species of the legume, mulberry, custard apple, beech, castor oil, and magnolia families... The Yunnan - Guizhou and Himalayan foothills flora including coniferous tree species of the gymnosperm division such as: pinus, false cypress, spruce, and podocarpus... The Malayan - Indonesian flora including tree species of the dipterocarpaceae family such as: keruing, kapur, meranti, and cinnamomum. The Indian - Myanmar flora including some tree species of the combretaceae family such as: terminalia; the meliaceae family such as: cedrela. In addition, there are some endemic species such as: trung bo nettle, du mooc, khes flower, red striped orchid, goncalo alves, lang hiệp, mahogany, dalat pine, song bot, and some other rare species listed in the Red Book of Vietnam and the world.|||Alongside such a rich flora, the Garden also has a forest fauna system that is endemic to both Vietnam and Indochina, including: 5 large mammal species such as: red-shanked douc, grey-shanked douc, tiger, Truong Son muntjac and large muntjac. 7 bird species such as: black-headed thrush, long-billed thrush, Kon Ka Kinh thrush - a species newly discovered to science in the last 30 years in the Asia region, grey-headed thrush, golden-eye barbet, silver pheasant and red-tailed laughingthrush. 4 species of the reptile and amphibian class: reticulated gecko, red-tailed gecko, Sapa gecko, spiny frog.|||In addition to the endemic species; the forest flora and fauna at Kon Ka Kinh National Park also include around 38 other rare and precious animal species; which have the value of gene conservation; scientific research and are listed in both the Red Book of Vietnam and the world.|||In addition to its diverse and rich forest ecosystem; Kon Ka Kinh National Park plays an important role in protecting the watershed of major rivers such as: Ba River and Dak Pne River, providing irrigation water for thousands of hectares of coffee, pepper, agricultural land and providing clean water for the districts of Gia Lai and Kon Tum provinces. Furthermore, the western part of the National Park is part of the Ya Ly hydroelectric watershed.|||Standing on Kon Ka Kinh peak (1,748m high), visitors can feel the majesty of the Truong Son mountains, enjoy the fresh and cool atmosphere, and it seems the beauty of this place is unfolding endlessly before their eyes: Mountains shrouded in mist, waterfalls cascading from above, creating a white foam, and the singing of countless birds calling out to each other...|||Coming to Kon Ka Kinh, visitors experience the villages of West Central Highlands ethnic minorities. Here, tourists can immerse themselves in the atmosphere of festivals such as: funeral ceremony, gong festival, wedding ceremony, buffalo stabbing ceremony...|||Kon Ka Kinh National Park is not only recognized as a priority area for biodiversity conservation in Vietnam, the region, and internationally, but it is also expected to become an eco-tourism destination, attracting visitors to relax, rejuvenate, and conduct scientific research.

title: The Grand Opera House Hanoi
description: Location: at 1 Trang Tien street, Hoan Kiem district, Hanoi. Characteristics: this is one of the cultural centers of the capital Hanoi, where cultural activities, art performances, music and dance shows, concerts, exchanges are regularly held.|||The Grand Opera House in Hanoi is a large construction built by the French in Vietnam in the early 20th century. The construction started on 7 June 1901 and was completed in 1911 following the model of the Paris Opera House. It was designed by architects Harlay and Broyer but on a smaller scale. The materials used were adjusted to the local economic conditions and climate. The building features many colors and architectural details typical of theaters in Southern France.|||The layout organization the main hall the entrance hall the main staircase and the service spaces for the stage of the Hanoi Grand Opera House are similar to those of European theaters of the early 20th century.|||The architectural structure and decorative motifs of the Opera House are in the style popular in France in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The tiled roof with two sloping sides and a pointed top, symmetrical elements, decorative motifs on the vaulted ceiling, and wreaths and medals on the walls bring a unique touch of modern Western architectural style amidst traditional Vietnamese buildings.|||The Hanoi Opera House has an area of 2600m2, 87m long, 30m wide, and 34m high at its tallest point.|||The interior features a spacious stage and a main auditorium.|||The central staircase to the second floor opens into a large hall.|||There are also auxiliary stairs and corridors on either side.|||Behind the stage are the administration office, 18 dressing rooms, 2 rehearsal rooms, a library, and a meeting room.|||The main hall: This is the first area to welcome guests to the Theater, featuring high-quality Italian stone flooring that gives the impression of a large carpet. The small chandeliers hanging on the walls are made of copper in an antique style. The overhead chandeliers are coated with a layer of gold using new technology.|||The auditorium: Inside the Hanoi Grand Opera House is a spacious stage and a 576m2 auditorium, with a total of 900 seats on three levels. The auditorium floor is made of high-quality tiles and covered with fire-resistant carpet. The seats are designed in the classic French style of the 19th century. The ceiling above the auditorium is painted by French artists. The chandeliers are coated with a new layer of gold. The wall lights are made of copper in an antique style.|||The Mirror Room: This is an important ceremonial room that regularly hosts high-ranking officials of the Party and State, heads of state, and is where important government documents are signed. The room is also used for chamber music performances, press conferences, and small-scale conferences. The floor of the Mirror Room is completely restored using mosaic techniques. The floor tiles were brought from Italy and assembled by hand by skilled Italian craftsmen to ensure the precision of the work. The ceiling of the Mirror Room was restored from the original by artisans from Venice. The crystal chandeliers and hanging lamps in the corners are in the classic French style.||||||The Grand Opera House in Hanoi is not only a cultural space but also a venue for many significant political events of the country. It witnessed the first moments of peace in the country and is a revolutionary witness of the thousand-year-old capital. Since then, the Grand Opera House has always been the center of important conferences, rallies, and artistic performances by domestic and international art troupes.|||After going through the ups and downs of history, like many other architectural works and intangible cultural forms, the Hanoi Opera House has become a testament to a period of cultural exchange, helping Vietnam integrate with the world. Therefore, preserving and safeguarding this heritage, making its significance deeper and richer, is what the whole country and the people of the capital are always striving for.

title: Kenh Ga Hot Spring
description: Location: Kenh Ga Hot Spring is located in Kenh Ga village, Gia Thinh commune, Gia Vien district, Ninh Binh province, 15km north of Ninh Binh city. Characteristics: The spring flows from a mountain in Kenh Ga village, offering an eco-tourism, resort and healing site that attracts many visitors.|||From Hanoi, follow National Route 1A south for about 84 km to Giao Khao junction, Gia Tran commune, then turn right on road 477 through Me town, and stop at Dong Chua wharf (Gia Thinh commune). From here, visitors take a boat through Hoang Long river branches, into Kenh Ga village, winding through a spacious mountainous area with sweet paddy field fragrance to reach Kenh Ga Hot Spring. Kenh Ga Hot Spring has existed for a long time but was only discovered by the French in 1940. The spring provides mineral water containing sodium chloride, potassium chloride, calcium, magnesium chloride, and bicarbonate salts. The water is clear, colorless, odorless, with a stable temperature of 53°C, and flows out thousands of liters per hour.|||Visiting Kenh Ga, tourists not only admire the charming scenery but also soak in hot mineral water for relaxation, healing, and forget about daily worries. Kenh Ga mineral water is now processed and bottled to provide a natural mineral water source for tourists.|||The site offers a rich system of accommodations, dining, entertainment services, providing visitors with relaxing moments. The accommodation system includes: a stilt house with separate and collective rooms; a 2-star hotel; a restaurant serving over 200 seats with specialty and traditional dishes; diverse entertainment services such as a collective swimming pool, massage room, karaoke, and a campfire area.|||Kenh Ga Hot Spring is a unique countryside tourist spot, an interesting resort, that always attracts visitors.

title: Kiep Bac Temple
description: Location: Kiep Bac Temple is located in Van Kiep and Duoc Son villages, Hung Dao commune, Chi Linh town, Hai Duong province, about 80km from Hanoi, and 5km from Con Son historical site. Features: The temple was built in the early 14th century, dedicated to Tran Hung Dao.|||The Kiep Bac temple complex is situated in a lush, green valley. Three sides are surrounded by the Dragon mountain range with its Nam Tao and Bac Dau branches, while the remaining side borders the Luc Dau Giang river, where six rivers converge: the Cau, Thuong, Luc Nam, Duong, Kinh Thay and the main branch of the Thai Binh river. The mountains form a majestic scene of dragons gathering and tigers crouching, while the river creates a wide, clear path. This strategic location serves as a vital transportation hub, both by land and water, guarding the eastern gateway to the ancient Kinh Thanh Thang Long (present-day Hanoi). The area boasts a harmonious balance of heaven and earth, with a prime position in terms of feng shui and military significance.|||After the first resistance war against the Mongols (1258), General Tran Hung Dao chose this area as the command center for the northeastern military line, stretching from the Lang Son border through Chi Lang pass, Noi Bang along the Luc Nam river, via Luc Dau Giang, Bach Dang to the East Sea, aiming to create a battle plan of "combined land and water, advancing in attack and retreating in defense" to resist the second (1285) and third (1288) Mongol invasions.|||Following Tran Hung Dao's passing, to commemorate his great contributions to the country, the local people built a temple at the former command center, naming it Kiep Bac and honoring him as Duc Thanh Tran.|||The temple has a grand and imposing gate with three entrances. The gate features nine large characters: the top four characters are 'Hung thien vo cuc', and the bottom five characters are 'Tran Hung Dao Vuong tu' and two columns of couplets 'Kiep Bac huu son giai kiem khi/ Luc Dau vo thuy bat thu thanh', which means 'At Kiep Bac, all mountains possess the heroic spirit of sacred swords/ At Luc Dau, no water fails to echo the sound of autumn'.|||Beyond the main gate, on the left, is the Dragon-Eyed Jade Well.|||Following the stone path leads to the area where the palanquin is kept during festival seasons, and in front of it is an altar.|||The temple has 3 large halls. In the most impressive position - the middle hall, a majestic statue of Tran Hung Dao is placed. The outermost hall features a statue of General Pham Ngu Lao (Tran Hung Dao's son-in-law). The innermost hall is dedicated to National Mother Thien Thanh Princess (Tran Hung Dao's wife) and her two daughters, including First Kham Tu Royal Concubine Quyen Thanh Princess (wife of King Tran Nhan Tong) and Second Princess Anh Nguyen (wife of General Pham Ngu Lao). The temple also has four altars dedicated to Tran Hung Dao's four sons.|||The Kiep Bac Temple Festival is associated with the Con Son Festival (Commune Cong Hoa, Chi Linh town), and takes place twice a year. The spring festival of Con Son - Kiep Bac commemorates the death anniversary of the Third Patriarch, Tran Nguyen Hue Quang, and occurs from 14th to 17th of the first lunar month, featuring cultural and sports activities such as: Mong son thi thuc ceremony, worship of heaven and earth on Ngu Nhac linh tu; water procession; competitions of making and cooking chung cake, pounding banh day, firecrackers, boat racing on Luc Dau Giang river, cockfighting, human chess, wrestling... The autumn festival of Con Son - Kiep Bac commemorates the death anniversary of Tran Hung Dao and national hero Nguyen Trai, taking place from 15th to 20th of the eighth lunar month with rituals and folk performances such as: procession of offerings to Saint Tran, military parade on Luc Dau river, prayer for peace and lantern festival on Luc Dau river, visiting Saint Tran, and the ceremony of giving orders by Saint Tran along with many folk games like: wrestling, boat racing, catching ducks, cooking rice competition, jumping...|||In addition to the two festivals above, Kiep Bac Temple is associated with Tran Thuong Temple Festival (Tran Thuong village, Nhan Dao commune, Ly Nhan district, Ha Nam province) which takes place from 18th to 20th August lunar calendar, also honoring Tran Hung Dao. Joining this festival, tourists will have the opportunity to make a pilgrimage to visit the route: Kiep Bac Temple - Tran Thuong Temple - Bao Loc Temple (Nam Dinh) to pray for Tran Hung Dao to bestow many blessings and good luck.

title: Ba Be Lake
description: Location: Ba Be Lake is near Cho Ra town, Ba Be district, Bac Kan province, about 70km from Bac Kan city. Features: Ba Be is the largest natural lake in northern Vietnam, situated in a phyllite and limestone region.|||Ba Be Lake is located in Ba Be National Park, Nam Mau commune, Ba Be district, about 75km northwest of Bac Kan city and over 220km north of Hanoi.|||Locals call it Slam Pe, meaning three lakes, as it's formed by the confluence of three rivers: Pe Lam, Pe Lu, and Pe Leng.|||Ba Be Lake covers an area of approximately 500ha, stretching over 8km in length, with the widest part being around 2km. It has an average depth of 20m and a maximum depth of 35m, holding about 90 million m3 of water.|||In 1995, at an international conference on freshwater lakes held in the US, Ba Be Lake was ranked among the 20 largest and most beautiful natural freshwater lakes in the world that need protection.|||With its special historical, cultural, scientific, and aesthetic values, in 2012, the Prime Minister decided to classify the Ba Be Lake scenic spot as a Special National Relic.|||With the cool mountain air, you can visit Ba Be at any time of the year. Our group arrived at Ba Be lake on a sunny afternoon. The golden sunlight shining down on the calm lake surface created a huge sparkling mirror. All the worries, hustle and bustle of everyday life seemed to melt away as we took a boat ride and blended into the peaceful water.|||Enjoying the scenery on the lake, listening to the legend of Ba Be lake, seeing Tay girls paddling wooden boats, admiring Ba Go Island, and sightseeing at An Ma temple… it was truly an interesting experience.|||Departing from Buoc Lom wharf, our boat cruises down the Nang River, passing through Puong Cave - where the Nang River flows through the limestone mountain of Lung Nham. This is considered one of the most beautiful and worth-visiting caves in Ba Be National Park. The cave has a high ceiling and stalactites that form many fascinating shapes, attracting tourists.|||As we continued to glide along the calm river, our boat stopped at the impressive Dau Dang waterfall. Here, the Nang River is blocked by hundreds of large rocks, splitting into smaller streams that flow rapidly, creating the magnificent Dau Dang waterfall.|||The waterfall stretches over 1,000 meters, flowing through variously shaped rocks stacked on top of each other like a stone maze.|||The waterfall roars loudly, then curves and bends, with some sections flowing gently and romantically.|||Near Ba Be Lake, visitors can also visit Hua Ma cave, also known as "Hanging cave" located about 10km south of Ba Be National Park center. This is a large cave with attractive beauty, holding mystical legends. From Ba Be Lake, walk about 100m to reach Tien Ao Lake. Tien Ao Lake covers over 3,000m2, surrounded by limestone mountains and primeval forests, the lake water is clear and cool. Tien Ao Lake has many precious fish species such as crystal carp, lăng fish, ban fish... At Tien Ao Lake, visitors can see footprints on rocks and hear the legendary story of a hunter and seven fairies. Besides, visitors can experience daily life, culture and customs of ethnic villages living on the hillside near the lake.|||After a while drifting on a boat, our group visited An Ma Temple. The temple is located on An Ma Island in Ba Be Lake and was renovated and rebuilt in 2006. The temple worships Buddha, Mau Thuong Ngan, Chu Son Trang, Duc Thanh Tran... The quiet space here gave us a feeling of peace and serenity. This is also an interesting sightseeing spot and very convenient for observing birds and animals, and the lake scenery.|||Returning to the boat is also the time when the sun starts to set. When the boat moved to Ba Go Island, we encountered Tay girls in traditional costumes paddling a simple wooden boat that has long become a symbol of Bac Kan tourism. That simple image deeply imprinted in every tourist's heart a indescribable feeling of peace.|||After a long journey, warming up under the gentle sunlight of winter, letting our souls drift along the peaceful and quiet stream, our group seemed to be invigorated, every sense refreshed, and our souls became pure and full of vitality.|||Ba Be Lake is likened to a "green gem" amidst the mountains and forests, making it an ideal eco-tourism destination. If you're looking to escape the fatigue of city life, the hustle and bustle of daily routines, and wanting to immerse yourself in nature, then exploring Ba Be Lake is an excellent choice for you.

title: Quang Tri Ancient Citadel
description: Location: In Ward 2, Quang Tri Town, Quang Tri Province, 2km east of National Route 1A. Characteristics: Quang Tri Ancient Citadel was both a military fortress and the administrative headquarters of the Nguyen Dynasty in Quang Tri from 1809 to 1945.|||The ancient citadel was built and constructed from soil from the beginning of King Gia Long's reign (1802) in Tien Kien Village, Trieu Thanh Commune, Trieu Phong District. In 1809, King Gia Long moved the citadel to Thach Han Commune (now Ward 2, Quang Tri Town). In 1837, King Minh Mang rebuilt the citadel with large burnt bricks, bound together with lime, molasses and other additives. The citadel is square-shaped with a perimeter of nearly 2000m, 9.4m high and 12m thick at the base. The citadel walls are surrounded by a wide moat. Four turrets stand at the four corners, and in the center of each side are gates: Tien, Hau, Ta, Huu, each 3.4m wide, built in an arched style, with a watchtower above, curved roof and tiled. Within the citadel are architectural works such as: the communal house, the dinh Tuan Vu, flag tower, dinh An Sat, dinh Lanh Binh, Ty Phien, Ty Niet…|||During the war, French colonialists and American imperialists turned the ancient citadel into a military zone and prison for Vietnamese communist fighters. This place witnessed many fierce battles of our army and people, notably the battle of the Vietnam Liberation Army against the counter-attacks to recapture the ancient citadel of Quang Tri by the Saigon regime during 81 days and nights in the summer of 1972 (from June 28 to September 16, 1972). After the war, the citadel was largely destroyed, leaving only remnants of some sections, jails, Tien Gate and Hau Gate.|||From 1993-1995, the moat system, bridge, culverts, some sections of the citadel and Tien Gate were restored. A large memorial was built in the center of the ancient citadel to commemorate the meritorious services of the liberation fighters who sacrificed their lives for the peace of this land. In the southwest corner of the citadel is a museum preserving many war relics.|||On December 12, 1986, Quang Tri Ancient Citadel was ranked as a National Historical Site by the Ministry of Culture and Information (now the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism). Today, Quang Tri Ancient Citadel has become an attractive destination for many domestic and international tourists to visit.

title: Den Dong Xam
description: Location: Den Dong Xam is located in Hong Thai commune, Kien Xuong district, Thai Binh province. Characteristics: Den Dong Xam can be considered a masterpiece of Vietnamese wood, stone, metal, and plaster art from the Nguyen dynasty.|||Den Dong Xam is a complex of historical sites with a grand and vast scale, featuring the worship of Trieu Vu De, a temple dedicated to Trinh Thi Hoang Hau (the wife of Trieu Vu De), and a temple honoring Nguyen Kim Lau (the ancestor of the traditional silver engraving profession) along with a system of temples and pagodas situated near the Vong River.|||The center of the Den Dong Xam complex is a large architectural ensemble with nearly 10,000m2 of construction, featuring many magnificent and beautiful structures such as Vong Lau, Thuy Toa, Hoang Ma, San Te, Tien Te, Phuong Dinh, Dien Tho, Hau Cung, and Tho Su Nha...|||Thuy Toa is a hexagonal house with six arched doors facing different directions, from where visitors can observe the entire San Te and the bustling boat racing on the river during festivals.|||The front hall of the temple is a large five-room building with a height of 13 meters and an impressive architectural style rarely seen in other historical sites. Connecting the front hall to the rear palace is the Trung Te hall, constructed in the Phuong Dinh style. The area's floor plan was skillfully designed by artisans, transforming the three rooms of the front hall into a central room as the foundation for the Phuong Dinh hall.|||The rear palace of the temple is structured into two connected parts: a five-room electric hall and a raised platform for the altar. The exterior of the rear palace is harmoniously decorated with large characters, scrolls, couplets, and a wooden door with engraved patterns. The system of doors in the three central rooms of the rear palace features intricate engravings of eight precious items, floral patterns, and calligraphy on 12 door panels, creating a sense of serenity and detachment for visitors before entering.|||The altar room in the rear palace is a unique work characteristic of the traditional silver, copper, and iron engraving village. The room is enclosed by perforated copper sheets with various motifs such as the four noble ones, four seasons... The altar contains statues of Trieu Vu De and Queen Trinh Thi, both made of bronze with gold, silver, and silver inlays, and are life-sized.

title: Chua Dau Pagoda
description: Location: Chua Dau Pagoda is located in Khuong Tu village (also known as Dau village), Thanh Khuong commune, Thuan Thanh district, Bac Ninh province. Characteristics: It is the first Buddhist temple in Vietnam, built in the early 3rd century.|||Since the early centuries AD, Chua Dau Pagoda has been a famous Buddhist center in Vietnam and abroad. In the late 4th century, Zen Master Pini-dalu-chi opened a Dharma hall here to preach and founded the first Zen sect in Vietnam.|||The temple was rebuilt on a large scale by Mac Dinh Chi in the 14th century and restored many times in the following centuries. Currently, in the temple yard, there is a 3-storey Hoa Phong tower, about 17m high. In the tower, there is a large bell cast under the Canh Thinh reign (1793), a large bronze khanh cast in the 18th year of Minh Mang reign. Besides, there are statues of Ba Phap Van, Kim Dong and Ngoc Nu.

title: Chien Dan Tower
description: Located beside National Highway 1, in Tam An commune, 5km north of Tam Ky city, Quang Nam province. The site features a cluster of three Cham towers standing parallel to each other on a north-south axis, facing east.|||Only the central tower remains relatively intact, while the northern and southern towers have lost their upper levels. The three towers are identical in shape, with square bases and tiered roofs that taper upwards. The Chien Dan towers lack decorative motifs, with moderately protruding wall columns. Each tower has three false doors and one entrance, with pointed arches above the false doors. The sandstone eaves feature a carved sequence of Kala faces.|||The site also hosts a display room for Cham artifacts, including reliefs; statues of people: female deities, dancing girls, warriors with weapons; and mythological creatures: Naga snakes, Garuda birds, elephants, lions, stone steles... of high artistic value that interest researchers and tourists. These sculptures exhibit the Chien Dan architectural and sculptural style, dating back to the late 10th century, a transitional phase between the My Son and Binh Dinh styles.

title: Vang Family Mansion
description: Location: Sa Phin commune, Dong Van district, Ha Giang province. Characteristics: A rare and unique architectural work of the Dong Van stone plateau.|||The Vang Family Mansion is an ancient villa complex of Vuong Chinh Duc, the only person from Ha Giang province who was crowned as the 'King of Meo' by the local people in the early 20th century, ruling over four districts: Quan Ba, Yen Minh, Meo Vac, and Dong Van.|||Built in 1919 and completed in 1928, the entire mansion covers an area of nearly 3,000m2, situated on a raised plot of land like a turtle shell in the valley, surrounded by a semicircular mountain range, creating a solid defensive position. The mansion is enclosed by two stone walls, about 60cm to nearly 1m thick, 2.5 to 3m high, with many loopholes.|||The path leading to the mansion is gently sloped, paved with square granite slabs. On both sides of the entrance are two rows of centuries-old sa mộc trees, tall and straight. Upon entering, visitors will see a horizontal board with golden letters 'Bien chinh kha phong' ('This border area is strong'), granted by King Nguyen to Vuong Chinh Duc. The interior of the mansion features a unique architecture, influenced by three cultures: China, France, and Vietnam's Mong ethnic group.|||The mansion is constructed from green stone, pine wood, pơmu wood, and burnt earth tiles, stretching 56m long, 20m wide, and 10-12m high, comprising four transverse houses and six longitudinal houses, all with two-story structures and 64 rooms for 100 occupants. The mansion is divided into three areas: tien dinh, trung dinh, and hau dinh. Tien dinh is for soldiers and servants, while trung dinh and hau dinh are for the Vuong family. The walls are made of stone, with wooden interior decorations, columns, and wooden floors, tiled roofs, and ornamental flower patterns. The layout of the house decreases in height from outside to inside. The main house faces the gate, with auxiliary houses like kitchens, water tanks, warehouses, and stables. A spacious courtyard with plenty of light separates the houses. The mansion is surrounded by a garden with various trees like sa mộc, cinnamon, peach, and pear. There are also two blockhouses for defense and a storage room for assets.|||One of the highlights of the mansion is the exquisite carving art, with intricate details and skillful carvings symbolizing prosperity and thriving.|||In 1993, the Vang Family Mansion was recognized by the state as a national architectural and artistic relic, attracting many tourists to visit and explore.

title: Xa Loi Pagoda
description: Location: 89 Ba Huyen Thanh Quan, District 3, Ho Chi Minh City. Phone: (84-4) 8.829 2438. Characteristics: The pagoda was built on August 5, 1956, on a 2,500 square meter site designed by architects Tran Van Duong and Do Ba Vinh, at a cost of 5.5 million dong, contributed by the people of 21 southern provinces. The grand inauguration ceremony took place on May 2, 3, and 4, 1958.|||The Nam Viet Buddhist Association built the pagoda to enshrine the Buddha's Relics. Monks, nuns, and Buddhists commonly called it Xa Loi Pagoda. At the inauguration, Venerable Khanh Anh named the pagoda Xa Loi, as it was commonly known.|||The first floor shrine is simply and solemnly decorated with a 6.5m high statue of Sakyamuni Buddha, a special artwork made of stone by sculptor Le Van Mau in 1954-1955. The pagoda enshrines the Buddha's Relics from Tich Lan, presented to Vietnamese Buddhism by Narada.|||The seven-story bell tower was built from 1960 to 1961. The large bell was installed on October 17, 1961. Xa Loi Pagoda was chosen as the headquarters of the Buddhist Protection Committee and the founding site of the Unified Buddhist Church of Vietnam in 1963. From 1981 to May 1993, the pagoda housed the Office II of the Buddhist Church of Vietnam in the South.

title: Xeo Quit - Historical and Ecological Forest Relic
description: Located in My Hiep and My Long communes, Cao Lanh district, Dong Thap province. Xeo Quit is a preserved historical site featuring underground houses, military bases, and secret tunnels, showcasing the harsh realities of life during the American war.|||About 30km from Cao Lanh town, Dong Thap province, along National Highway 30, lies a 20ha tràm forest that has been protected and turned into a revolutionary historical site, surrounded by natural scenery.|||This was the base of the Kiến Phong Provincial Committee during the anti-American resistance war (from late 1959). The forest provided shelter for officials and soldiers to carry out revolutionary activities until the complete victory on April 30, 1975.|||Visiting the tràm forest during the flooding season, tourists can take a canoe ride to explore the site and experience its beauty. The journey offers a chance to immerse in the natural atmosphere and hear the sounds of wildlife.|||The forest landscape is serene, with a unique feature being the bòng bong vines covering the tràm trees, creating a dense canopy. The area is filled with the sounds of birds, fish, and the excitement of tourists.|||Although not large, Xeo Quit provides a glimpse into the larger, famous tràm forests in Dong Thap Muoi.|||Xeo Quit, a base surrounded by enemy strongholds and intense bombardment, remained resilient with simple structures like underground houses and secret tunnels, demonstrating the determination of the people during the war.

title: Son My Historical Relic
description: Location: Son My historical relic is located in Tinh Khe commune, Son Tinh district, Quang Ngai province. Characteristics: Son My is a site that recorded the brutal crimes of the American imperialists against the Vietnamese people. On March 16, 1968, American soldiers killed hundreds of innocent civilians here during a destructive operation.|||The Son My massacre site consists of two locations. The first one is in Thuan Yen hamlet (now Khê Thuận hamlet), where 47 people from Tu Cung village were killed by American soldiers.|||The second one is in My Hoi hamlet (now Khê Hội hamlet), where 97 people from Co Luy village were massacred by American soldiers.|||The Son My massacre site is 13km northeast of Quang Ngai city. On March 16, 1968, a brutal and unprecedented destruction was carried out by US invaders, targeting innocent people in Son My who were unarmed. With the policy of burning everything, destroying everything, and killing everything, they turned this place into a dead land. The Son My massacre was the peak of the numerous crimes committed by the US imperialists against the Vietnamese people during the unjust invasion war, and was condemned by all humanity. The Son My massacre site is a complex of locations that bear witness to the atrocities committed by the US against our people:|||The Son My Relic Site, covering 2.4ha, is located in Kho Thuan hamlet (Tu Cung village, Tinh Khe commune), adjacent to provincial road 24B from Quang Ngai city to Son My - My Khe - Sa Ky. It is about 400m away from the Many Nguoi relic cluster, watchtower, and village road. The site includes preserved and restored original relics and later constructed works such as a supplementary exhibition house, reception area, monument and garden statues.|||The relic site includes: Ong Nhieu field, watchtower, and cotton tree located in Khe Thuan hamlet and the relic sites of Ong Pham Minh garden (Khe Dong), Pham Hoi (Khe Tay).|||Historical site: anti-cannon tunnel of Mr. Ly Le's and Mr. Ngo Man's family at My Hoi hamlet (Co Luy village).|||Mass grave sites of massacre victims.|||Besides its historical significance, Son My is a site documenting the typical atrocities committed by American invaders during the Vietnam War, and a place to commemorate the 504 Vietnamese people who fell. Son My also holds tourism value as part of the Thien An (Huynh Thuc Khang tomb) - Chau Sa - Son My - My Khe - Dung Quat tourist route. Every year, over 50,000 people visit Son My. Currently, nearly 3,300 visitors come here each month.|||At Son My today, visitors can stop in front of the statue to feel the extreme pain of the Son My victims. Inside the Memorial House, visitors can see many preserved artifacts: an old scratched and bullet-holed brass tray, a child's shirt and sandals that were shot; various bowls, plates, pots and pans that were shot through and broken, and a monk's prayer beads that belonged to Thich Tam Tri. Among these artifacts is a hair clip that belonged to Nguyen Thi Huynh. After she was killed, her lover found and kept the clip for 8 years before handing it over to the Memorial House...|||Outside the memorial site, scattered around the hamlets and villages, are commemorative steles erected at locations where mass shootings took place. This is a watchtower on the edge of the village, by a small dirt road in Thuan Yen where 102 people were shot and killed. Over there is a cotton tree where 15 women and children were slaughtered.|||In My Hoi hamlet, coconut trees now stretch high into the sky, and the blue sea still rolls in with waves crashing onto the clean, golden sand. This is truly one of Vietnam's most beautiful scenes.|||Amongst this serene and familiar landscape stands a monument marking the 97 local residents of the hamlet who were brutally slaughtered.|||The Son My relic site regularly welcomes visitors. They are businesspeople, scientists, and tourists of various nationalities, especially with an increasing number of Americans coming to this place to express sympathy with the deep pain of the Vietnamese people during the war.

title: T'Nung Lake
description: T'Nung Lake, also known as Pleiku Sea or Ea Nueng Lake, is a freshwater lake located north of Pleiku City, Gia Lai Province.|||The lake's beauty is likened to a jade gem due to its deep green and sparkling water, resembling a giant natural jade. Formed from a volcanic crater, the lake boasts natural and romantic scenery.|||The path to the lake is extremely beautiful and poetic, lined with ancient trees that provide shade during the hot summer. T'Nung Lake is stunning at any time of the year or day. Early in the morning, with mist still present, visitors feel like they've entered a dreamy and mystical realm. At noon, with the sun shining, the lake sparkles with shimmering rays. As dusk falls, the sunset casts a red glow, and the gentle breeze creates soft ripples on the lake's surface, exuding a peaceful and serene atmosphere.|||Around the lake, there are small observation decks for visitors to admire the scenery and gaze out at the vast lake. Cycling around the lake is also an interesting way to explore its natural beauty.|||For a more immersive experience, take a traditional wooden boat and glide across the lake. The boat will take you deeper into the surrounding forest, revealing the unique and majestic landscape.|||In addition to its beauty, the lake is also a significant source of freshwater fish for the region and an important water supply for Pleiku City. T'Nung Lake is a masterpiece of nature and a source of pride for the people of Gia Lai and the Central Highlands.

title: Phuong Hoang Cave, Mo Ga Stream
description: Location: Phuong Hoang Cave is located on Phuong Hoang Mountain in Vo Nhai district, 45km from Thai Nguyen city via National Highway 1B (Thai Nguyen - Lang Son). At the foot of Phuong Hoang Mountain is Mo Ga Stream Cave. Characteristics: Phuong Hoang Mountain, Phuong Hoang Cave, and Mo Ga Stream Cave form a stunning scenic complex in Thai Nguyen province with majestic natural landscapes and beautiful caves.|||To reach the entrance of Phuong Hoang Cave, visitors must climb a long, rocky path, which takes over half an hour. From a distance, the mountain resembles two phoenix birds lying next to each other. The mountain is named Phuong Hoang due to a legend about a happy phoenix couple that lived on the mountain and laid two eggs. One day, the male phoenix forgot its duty and didn't return, and the female phoenix turned to stone. Overcome with regret, the male phoenix lay down on the opposite mountain, looking towards his wife, but she never returned, and he eventually turned to stone as well.|||From the cave entrance, visitors can take in the breathtaking view of the surrounding area. The cave has three layers: the upper layer is Doi Cave, the middle layer is Sang Cave, and the lower layer is Toi Cave. Sang Cave is spacious and well-lit, with stunning stalactites that shimmer and shine under the light from the three entrance gates. Visitors can let their imagination run wild, seeing shapes like a mother carrying her child on her back, groups of primitive humans hunting, and giant lanterns.|||At the foot of the mountain lies Mo Ga Stream Cave. The entrance is about 10m wide, with a small stream flowing out. In front of the cave, there are many small waterfalls, bathing areas, and rock formations that resemble seats and islands. The water is crystal clear, creating a picturesque scene. After exploring Phuong Hoang Mountain, visitors can stop to rest, wash their feet and hands, and cool off in the stream, especially during hot summer days.

title: Ao Ba Om
description: Located in Luong Hoa commune, Chau Thanh district, Tra Vinh province, along National Highway 53, about 7km southwest of Tra Vinh town center. Characteristics: Ao Ba Om, also known as Vuong Lake, has a nearly perfect square shape with each side approximately 200m long and calm, clear water.|||Ao Ba Om is a famous scenic spot in Tra Vinh and the Mekong Delta. The lake is surrounded by a high sandbank shaded by ancient sa and oil trees, with many trees having roots rising above the ground, creating unique shapes. The air around the lake is fresh and cool. Visitors can hear intriguing legends about Ao Ba Om.|||In 1994, the Ministry of Culture and Information recognized Ao Ba Om as a national historical and cultural site.

title: Lang Bian Plateau
description: Location: Lang Bian Plateau is located in Lac Duong district, 12km north of Da Lat city center. Features: This is a suitable site for ethnologists and tourists who love traditional culture to study the culture of the ethnic groups in South Central Highlands.||||||Langbiang is often referred to as the roof of Dalat, not only because of its height of over 2,000m above sea level but also because of its stunning beauty. From the top of Langbiang, you can admire the entire city of Dalat, which appears like a beautiful ink wash painting, along with Dan Kia Lake and Suoi Vang Stream, which looks like a huge silk fabric standing out among the vast green hills and mountains.||||||In 2015, Lang Biang Biosphere Reserve was recognized by UNESCO as a World Biosphere Reserve. The Lang Biang Biosphere Reserve includes a large primeval forest with the core being Bidoup - Nui Ba National Park, which is considered one of the four biodiversity centers of Vietnam.|||The Lang Biang World Biosphere Reserve recognized by UNESCO is a premise for Lam Dong to develop sustainably by exploiting the overall values of ecosystem services, focusing on developing tourism and services, contributing to building and developing Da Lat city into a tourism, training and scientific research center on tropical forests.|||Located at a high altitude, Langbiang Mountain is considered a unique tourist destination for outdoor activities, nature exploration, and cultural discovery. At the foot of the mountain lies a large valley, where the 100-year anniversary celebration of Dalat's establishment was successfully held. This valley is therefore called the Century Valley, designed as an eco-tourism and entertainment area.|||At Lang Biang, visitors can enjoy cultural exchange programs, campfires, and traditional rice wine with ethnic people, listening to their stories and cultural experiences.|||This place is also a popular spot for adventure-seekers with hiking and mountain climbing programs. If visitors don't want to take a Jeep ride to the top of the Ra-Da hill, they can conquer the peak on foot along the asphalt road through pine forests and ethnic minority houses.|||At the top of the Ra Da hill, there are services such as restaurants, cafes and other services like: binoculars to look at Da Lat city from above, horse riding for photos. Especially, on the top of the hill, there is a flower garden, statues of K'lang and Hobiang, souvenir shops,... From here, visitors can see Golden Stream and Silver Stream and the whole view of Da Lat from above with floating mist, making you feel like you're on the clouds.|||Legend has it that the name Lang Biang comes from a love story of K'lang, the chief of Lat tribe, and H'biang, the daughter of Chil tribe's chief, which has moved many travelers who come here. Because they are of different tribes, H'biang and K'lang couldn't get married, so they chose to die to keep their love and protest against the strict tribal laws.|||When K'lang and H'biang passed away, H'biang's father regretted and united the Lát, Chil, Sré tribes into one K'Ho ethnic group. The tall mountain in La Ngư Thuong village, where K'lang and H'biang died, was named Lang Biang - a combination of the couple's names, to remember them and their love.

title: Dieu Thanh Waterfall
description: Location: Dieu Thanh Waterfall is located on the Dak Tit stream, which serves as a natural boundary between Nhan Co and Quang Tan communes, Dak Rlap district, Dak Nong province. Characteristics: Dieu Thanh Waterfall is beautiful, pristine and romantic|||In addition to the largest waterfall about 30m high pouring down into the deep abyss, Dieu Thanh also has many small waterfalls, along with the mother waterfall, water flows down to the stream all year round, creating a white foam. Under the waterfall is a vast expanse of water with many small rocky outcrops, creating hundreds of streams flowing in many directions. On both sides of the stream are flat land areas with many trees providing shade.

title: Gia Long Waterfall
description: Location: Gia Long Waterfall is an upper source waterfall within the system of three waterfalls: Gia Long - Dray Nur - Dray Sap of the Srepok River, Dak Nong province. Features: At night, visitors can hear the haunting calls of birds and the howling of wild deer.|||In the past, King Gia Long visited this waterfall to explore and rest. He had a beautiful road built through the mountains and forests to the waterfall, and also planned to build a suspension bridge across it, but for some reason, the project was abandoned after the construction of two pillars, and the remains still exist today.

title: Van Phong Bay
description: Located in Van Ninh district, Khanh Hoa province, approximately 80km north of Nha Trang city. It is a natural wonder with a mild climate, beautiful beaches, fine sand, and majestic mountains surrounding it.|||There is an 18km long sand dune between the mainland and two islands, creating a stunning Van Phong Bay. Along with the nearly intact tropical forests, colorful coral reefs, and remnants of a mangrove forest, numerous ecosystems, exotic wildlife, and tens of thousands of aquatic and marine species make Van Phong a strong candidate for eco-tourism development.|||The Vietnam National Administration of Tourism has designated Van Phong as a key development area in its long-term plan until 2010. Van Phong Bay has also been recognized by the World Ocean Association as one of four bays with ideal marine tourism positions.|||It offers various water and mountain sports tourism activities such as diving, surfing, sailing, hunting, mountain climbing, and mineral water bathing.

title: Bat Trang Pottery Village
description: Located in Bat Trang commune, Gia Lam district, Hanoi, over 10km southeast of the city center. This traditional craft village is famous for its ceramic products.|||According to the Complete Historical Records of Dai Viet and Du Dia Chi by Nguyen Trai, Bat Trang pottery village was formed during the Ly Dynasty. When King Ly Thai To moved the capital from Hoa Lu to Thang Long, five families with renowned pottery skills from Bo Bat village, Yen Mo district, Truong Yen prefecture (now Yen Mo district, Ninh Binh province) namely Tran, Vuong, Nguyen, Le, and Pham, decided to relocate their skilled craftsmen and families to Thang Long. They eventually settled in Bach Tho quarter, Gia Lam district, Thuan An prefecture (now Bat Trang commune, Gia Lam district, Hanoi), where they found a good source of material for pottery - white clay. Here, they teamed up with the local Nguyen family to open kilns and establish the Bat Trang pottery village.|||Bat Trang ceramics are mostly handmade, showcasing the skill and creativity of the artisans. The creamy white glaze, along with the style of drawing patterns that emphasize description, has been highly regarded by customers for its artistic value. Therefore, ancient Bat Trang ceramic products have very high economic value and are preserved in several domestic and international museums.|||To create ceramic products, artisans first soak clay in a system of 4 tanks at different heights for about 3-4 months to remove impurities. Then, they use the clay to shape the product, let it sit, and refine its shape. Next, the product is dried and baked in a drying kiln to prevent warping, cracking, or breaking, and then decorated with patterns. The craftsman uses a brush to directly draw harmonious patterns on the product. Once complete, the product is cleaned with a feather duster and fired at low temperature, then glazed. The glazing technique involves various methods such as spraying, pouring, dipping, and others. The final step, firing the ceramic in a kiln, requires gradually increasing the temperature until the ceramic is done, then gradually decreasing it. After firing, the kiln doors are sealed for slow cooling over 2 days and nights. The doors are then opened and the ceramics left for another day and night before being removed.|||Bat Trang ceramic products come in various designs, patterns, and types, categorized into groups based on their functional use: household ceramics, worship items, art ceramics, construction ceramics, and decorative ceramics. With their passion for their craft and diligent labor, research, and creativity, Bat Trang artisans have created a vibrant, diverse, and dynamic world of ceramics. Bat Trang ceramics are famous not only domestically but also exported to many countries worldwide, such as the European Union, South Korea, Taiwan, Japan, the United States, etc.|||In October 2004, Bat Trang Ceramic Market was opened on a campus of over 5,000m², featuring stalls of nearly 1,000 households specializing in ceramic and porcelain products.|||This market is not only a place for trading and display but also a popular tourist spot in Hanoi, attracting many domestic and international visitors.|||Bat Trang also preserves many historical and cultural relics such as communal houses, temples, and pagodas.|||These architectural works, along with ceramic products and the friendly, hospitable locals, have left unforgettable impressions on visitors.

title: Tam Thanh Cave
description: Location: It is located in Tam Thanh ward, Lang Son city, to the west of Ky Lua street. Features: The cave wall features a poem by Ngo Thi Si, praising the majestic natural beauty of this place.|||Tam Thanh Cave is situated within a mountain range that resembles a herd of elephants lying on the green grass. The cave is located halfway up the mountain. The entrance faces east, about 8m high, with 30 stone steps carved into the mountain slope, surrounded by dense foliage that blocks sunlight.|||The right wall of the cave has a poem carved by Ngo Thi Si (1726-1780), who was the governor of Lang Son, praising the majestic natural beauty. The poem conveys: "Clear streams flow over hundreds of rock peaks as if chatting. Turning my back to look at the mountain in front, I see the Vong Phu rock". Inside the cave, there is a statue of Buddha A-di-da and many impressive stalactites.

title: Phat Tich Pagoda
description: Location: Phat Tich Pagoda is located on the slope of Lan Kha Mountain (Riu Moc), Phat Tich Commune, Tien Du District, Bac Ninh Province. Features: Phat Tich Pagoda was once a place where many monks practiced. According to historical records, Phat Tich Pagoda is where the Buddha resided.|||Phat Tich Pagoda is also known as Van Phuc Pagoda, built from the 7th to the 10th century. The pagoda was completed during the reign of King Ly Thanh Tong (1057) and restored in 1686. In 1057, King Ly Thanh Tong erected a precious stupa and cast a golden Buddha statue.|||The pagoda was built on a large scale in the 17th century. In 1947, due to war, the pagoda was completely destroyed. In 1958, the pagoda was rebuilt roughly. In 1991, the pagoda was gradually rebuilt according to ancient architectural style.|||Currently, the remaining relic of the pagoda is a 1.85m high stone statue of Amitabha Buddha, sitting in meditation on a lotus throne (with a 3m high stone pedestal). The pagoda's pillars are carved with lotus flowers and musical scenes, with artisans playing various instruments.

title: Phat Tich Pagoda Festival
description: Time: 4/1 lunar calendar. Location: Phat Tich Commune, Tien Du District, Bac Ninh Province. Worship: Buddha Lady Quan Am and King Ly Thanh Tong. Characteristics: Worship Buddha, listen to sutras, pray for peace and prosperity, visit historical sites.|||The pagoda was built during the reign of King Ly Thanh Tong (11th century), featuring unique ancient architecture. The pagoda was damaged in 1947. Today, some ancient structures remain, including a row of 10 large stone animals: horse, rhinoceros, buffalo, elephant, and lion, all in a crouching position, 1.2m high on a lotus-flower stone pedestal in front of the stone stairs leading to the main hall. There is also a stone statue of Amitabha Buddha sitting on a lotus throne and a stupa garden.|||The pagoda was rebuilt in 1991 according to the original architecture, a complete Buddhist complex with halls and palaces, various statues. The annual festival is an opportunity for people to come pilgrimage, worship Buddha, pay respects to King Ly Thanh Tong, visit historical sites and scenic spots in Kinh Bac.

title: Mui Ne Beach
description: Location: Mui Ne Beach is located in Mui Ne ward, Phan Thiet City, Binh Thuan Province, 22km northeast of Phan Thiet City center. Characteristics: Mui Ne - the sleeping princess in the forest. Mui Ne is synonymous with its unique sand dunes.|||Mui Ne Beach stretches for dozens of kilometers with beautiful spots like Rang Beach, Hon Rom Beach, Suoi Nuoc Beach, and Ong Dia Rock with towering cliffs where waves crash against the shore.|||The long sand dunes have become an endless source of inspiration for many photographers.|||Mui Ne is located on the eastern coast of Phan Thiet city, famous for its coconut-lined roads. Mui Ne is also known as the resort capital and is a top destination for those who love relaxation.|||Especially, you will have the chance to enjoy fresh and delicious seafood, famous dishes of locals in this beautiful coastal area. Besides, Mui Ne Phan Thiet travel also offers many interesting things, especially stunning and pristine beaches that captivate tourists.|||1. Rang Beach|||Rang Beach is the most beautiful beach in Phan Thiet City. Rang Beach is about 15 km north of the city center, surrounded by dense coconut groves that resemble a beautiful coconut forest. Every summer, Rang Beach is crowded with visitors coming to swim and enjoy grilled green flying fish, sweet and delicious.|||2. Hon Rom Beach|||Hon Rom is a small, untouched mountain located in Long Son hamlet, Mui Ne ward, Phan Thiet city. Here, the water is crystal clear, the waves are calm, and there are no submerged rocks. In the morning or afternoon, you can sit and watch the sunrise or sunset; at night, you can gaze at the moon or organize a campfire.
