The poetic Thu Bon River flows through many clusters of mountains and rocks, including Hon Kem Da Dung, like two rocky peaks protruding, bathing in the river water, and over time, Hon Kem Da Dung seems to have been shaped by nature's hand into mysterious patterns, hidden on the rocks, blending with nature; forest trees, mist, and warm sunshine. Along with the surrounding mountains such as: Chua Mountain, Ca Tang Mountain... it creates a 'sơn thủy hữu tình' painting on the poetic Thu River. That's why the folk song has been passed down for generations:|||Looking up at Hon Kem Da Dung,|||Missing parents so much, my friends.||||||Coming to Hon Kem Da Dung, going upstream of the Thu River from Cua Dai - Hoi An or from Han River - Da Nang, it will be an interesting boat trip on the river, about 30-40km long, or from Tam Ky city center, by car, following National Route 1A to the north, to Huong An intersection, turn left to the southwest about 40km, visitors will arrive at Hon Kem Da Dung.

title: Mau Son Mountain
description: Located 30km east of Lang Son City. Mau Son Mountain stands at 1,541m above sea level, with a mild climate suitable for relaxation.|||Mau Son Mountain is surrounded by hundreds of smaller hills. The climate here is temperate, with mist covering the mountain in winter, bright sunshine in summer, and vibrant peach blossoms in spring.|||Mau Son's peaches are large and sweet. The mountain is also famous for its delicious tea and fragrant rice wine made by locals using special herbs found only in Mau Son. The unique water source from the mountain contributes to the distinct flavor of the wine.|||Visiting Mau Son offers not only breathtaking scenery and fresh air but also an opportunity to immerse oneself in the local culture and lifestyle of ethnic minorities.|||Previously, Mau Son was a popular resort with many elegant villas comparable to Sa Pa and Tam Dao. Although damaged during the war, Mau Son is set to be rebuilt into a resort and trekking destination in the future.

title: The Double Tower
description: Location: The tower is located next to Doi Bridge on Tran Hung Dao Street, Dong Da Ward, Quy Nhon City, Binh Dinh Province. Characteristics: The Double Tower, also known as the Hung Thanh Tower, is considered one of the most beautiful and unique towers of Cham architecture.|||Built in the late 12th century, Thap Doi is a unique architectural work consisting of two towers standing side by side along the North-South axis, with the North tower being 20m high and the South tower 18m high. They are called Thap Doi because the two towers stand almost parallel to each other.|||Both towers are not traditional square multi-story Cham towers but are composed of two main parts: a square body and a curved roof.|||At first glance, this tower looks like a 12th-century Khmer temple.|||This assessment is based on the Garuda deity images arranged at the four corners of the eaves with two raised hands and lowered feet as if supporting the roof.|||The roof is not a system of gradually shrinking floors like traditional Cham towers but a single block with four faces, each divided into six floors with horizontal eaves, and each floor divided into five compartments, with the central one being the largest featuring a person sitting in meditation with crossed legs.|||The four corners of the roof are decorated with five-headed Naga snakes.|||Meanwhile, the entire body of the tower retains its original shape, structure, and characteristic decoration of traditional Champa ancient towers: a square body, each exterior wall with a fake door with a vaulted arch rising like spears, smooth pilasters running along the body, between the pilasters are solid, raised masses, no longer with decorative motifs on the exterior surface of the tower wall... The base of the tower is surrounded by a belt of large stone blocks supporting the entire tower, interspersed with images of elephants, lions, and dancing figures.|||Of the two towers, the North Tower is taller and less deteriorated than the South Tower. The North Tower has a well-balanced design, with its body and roof both featuring delicate lines and subtle indentations that create a cohesive architectural composition. The main entrance of the tower faces east, protruding forward with four layers of pillars that gradually narrow towards the entrance. Corresponding to the layers of pillars are four layers of pointed-arch roofs, adorned with symmetrical patterns on either side. The remaining three walls each have three false doors that replicate the decoration of the main entrance but on a smaller scale. The roof is multi-tiered, tapering towards the top. Surrounding the eaves are 21 carved dancing girls in various poses, exuding a lively atmosphere. At the junction of the roof and the tower body, a meditating monk is depicted, flanked by symmetrical elephant pairs.|||The South Tower has a similar structure to the North Tower, but at the eaves, instead of female figures, the decorative carvings depict a herd of 13 deer with different postures, looking playful and lively.|||In 2008, the Twin Towers historical site was restored by the government to its original appearance and has become one of the most attractive destinations when tourists visit Quy Nhon city.|||Come here to admire the artistic architectural works built by talented artisans from many centuries ago.|||Visitors seem to immerse themselves in a mysterious world to reminisce about a civilization of the Champa kingdom.

title: Hien Lam Cac
description: Location: Hien Lam Cac is located in front of The Mieu, southwest of Hoang Thanh, Hue City, Thua Thien - Hue Province. Characteristics: Hien Lam Cac is the tallest architectural structure in Hoang Thanh. It serves as a memorial to honor the meritorious officials who founded the Nguyen Dynasty.|||Hien Lam Cac was built from 1821 to 1822 during the reign of King Minh Mang.|||Hien Lam Cac is built on a high rectangular base, paved with Bat Trang bricks, constructed with bricks and mortar, and decorated with ceramic pieces. Two stone staircases, each with 9 steps, lead up to the base. The staircases are flanked by dragon-shaped decorations, with the middle section reserved for the king.|||Hien Lam Cac is a multi-story wooden structure. The first floor is divided into three rooms with two gables. The exterior walls of the gables are built with bricks to reinforce the columns and conceal the interior. A series of wooden panels are installed on the third column from the front, with a vaulted door in the middle of each room. The roof supports, brackets, and wooden panels feature intricate carvings of stylized dragons and foliage. A large horizontal plaque with the three characters "Hien Lam Cac" hangs above the central door, set against a green background with golden accents and surrounded by nine carved dragons.|||The right room features a beautifully decorated staircase leading to the upper floors. The handrails are adorned with patterns of the characters "tho" and "van", as well as geometric shapes. The handrails are shaped like dragon heads and tails, soft and curved...

title: Suoi Tien
description: Location: Suoi Tien is located in Tan Thanh district, Ba Ria - Vung Tau province, 7km northwest of Ba Ria city. Characteristics: Originating from Dinh mountain peak with an altitude of nearly 500m, Suoi Tien is dubbed the second Da Lat of Vietnam by tourists due to its stunning natural scenery.|||To reach the upper source of Suoi Tien, visitors must trek 600m through a winding forest path with picturesque and serene landscapes. According to legend, this place was once a dense forest with sparse mountains and on full moon nights, fairies from heaven would descend to the mortal realm for leisure. Through this crystal-clear stream, the fairies would bathe and then return to heaven. Currently, on the rocky peak of Dinh mountain, there are adorable footprints imprinted on the stone, known as fairy footprints.|||Suoi Tien flows from a height of hundreds of meters, gradually descending to the east, pouring down the stone mountain slope, winding and irrigating lush fields before merging into the Thi Vai river. Suoi Tien retains its natural, pristine beauty, impressing anyone who visits. Along the riverbanks, there are flat stone slabs lying gently, where visitors can sit or rest while admiring the scenery. The rocky peaks have unique shapes: some resemble a mother and child chatting, others a young elephant, an old man in contemplation, or a pair of fighting cocks, crocodiles, birds... playing in the morning. Next to them are granite clusters covered in lichen and moss, seemingly sleeping here for a thousand years.|||Notably, from any position, visitors can hear the constant roar of the stream flowing from the mountain peak, creating deep pools with clear water that allows one to see white pebbles at the bottom. Water cascades down, creating white foam, and the misty air carries tiny droplets, creating a refreshing atmosphere. During the rainy season, the stream swirls and turns white, but in the dry season, it becomes gentle, inviting young travelers to swim.|||When visiting Suoi Tien, if time permits, visitors should follow a small path to nearby pagodas to hear the peaceful tolling of bells and enjoy the scent of incense and flowers, evoking the serenity of a Buddhist sanctuary amidst the mountains. This is also one of the unique impressions of Suoi Tien.|||Suoi Tien is an ideal destination for excursions, outdoor activities, and reconnecting with nature, allowing tourists to forget their stressful work moments.

title: Tomb of General Vo Nguyen Giap
description: Location: Vung Chua - Yen Island area, Tho Son village, Quang Dong commune, Quang Trach district, Quang Binh province, about 2km east of National Route 1. Features: The path to the tomb has 103 wooden stairs, 103 mai flowers and 103 Dien Bien ban flowers symbolizing the General's 103 years.|||General Vo Nguyen Giap (1911 - 2013) was the first general of the Vietnam People's Army and the commander of the legendary Dien Bien Phu battle. In 1984, The New Encyclopedia Britannica listed General Vo Nguyen Giap among the world's 10 outstanding generals.|||Vung Chua - Yen Island, where General Giap chose to rest, boasts a majestic and pristine landscape, with Tho Son mountain in the background and the East Sea in the foreground, featuring small islands like Hon La, Hon Gio and Hon Nom (Yen Island). The General's tomb is located at Mui Rong, overlooking Yen Island.|||The tomb is guarded 24/7 by a team from Border Guard Station 184. The guards are stationed at three checkpoints: one for receiving and recording visitors, one for guiding them to the tomb and one for supervising the incense-lighting ceremony.|||To beautify the area, 13,000 Thanh Hoa pine and coconut trees were planted on Tho Son mountain and along the coastal road leading to the tomb. A bell tower with a large bronze bell inscribed 'Vung Chua Hong Chung' stands near the tomb.|||Thousands of visitors come to pay their respects every day, with even more on weekends and holidays.

title: Hot Spring Hoi Van
description: Location: Hoi Van village, Cat Hiep commune, Phu Cat district, Binh Dinh province, about 50km northwest of Quy Nhon city. Characteristics: This is one of the hot mineral water sources in Vietnam used for therapeutic purposes.|||From Ngo May town, Phu Cat district, heading northwest less than 10km, visitors will arrive at Hoi Van hot spring.|||The stream is called Hoi Van because the water vapor rising from it condenses into clouds above the trees. People walking below, beside the stream, seem to be walking on clouds, hence the name Hoi Van, meaning "cloud gathering".|||Hoai Van Hot Spring is also known as Tien Spring, originating from a legend. A beautiful Champa princess suffered from a strange disease that no doctor could cure. Her skin broke out in ugly bumps, causing her to feel ashamed and hide in the palace. The king took her on a hunting trip and discovered a forest stream with clear water bubbling up from underground. He had a screen set up for the princess to bathe, and miraculously, she felt relief from her itching and discomfort. She asked to stay by the spring and bathe daily, and over time, her condition improved, and her skin regained its beauty. People believed that the spring was blessed by the gods, and that's why it's also called Tien Spring.|||The stream originates from the low mountains in the north of Phu Cat district, flowing into a large pond in Hoi Van village. The pond covers about 400m² and is over 1m deep. The bottom of the pond is lined with jagged rocks.|||Hot water springs up from the pond, releasing steam that rises like smoke. The pond is situated in a vast sand valley surrounded by mountains. To the northeast lies the majestic Ba mountain range. On cold days, especially early in the morning, the rising water vapor creates a misty atmosphere, making the scene mystical. When the sun shines, the fog clears, revealing a clear body of water where you can see the hot springs bubbling up from the bottom, resembling dragons playing in the water.|||The sandy shores around the pond are white and fine, making it an ideal spot to bask in the sun.|||The natural mineral water source in Hoi Van is very abundant and rich in therapeutic potential for various types of diseases. Today, through research, it has been discovered that the hot water contains sulfur and various minerals that are suitable for treating skin diseases, arthritis, and cardiovascular conditions.|||The water here has a temperature of over 80°C and is dissolved with over 20 minerals, including chloride, hydrocarbonate, and sulfate sodium, making it a type of hot Silica mineral water used in some renowned spas worldwide.|||In early 1976, the Hoi Van hot mineral water spa was established, welcoming many patients for treatment. Various therapies were applied, including mineral water, mud baths, and physical therapy such as individual pool baths, pressure shower baths, and combined therapies like psychology, physiotherapy, massage, and acupuncture.|||By June 2004, the Hoi Van spa was upgraded to the Binh Dinh Rehabilitation and Nursing Hospital. Spanning 7 hectares, the hospital boasts a cool and scenic environment with a tree-filled park, a miniature landscape, and stone-paved pathways for foot massage. This unique pathway is a characteristic feature of a nursing hospital, allowing patients to relax while supporting their treatment.|||Besides those who come to heal, Hoi Van also attracts tourists from all over the country to visit. Visitors can enjoy boiled eggs cooked in hot water springs with a boiling point of 70-80ºC, then soak in the warm water to feel the relaxing sensation spreading throughout their body. Or, they can sit and wait for the sunset, watching the steam rising from the natural hot springs (scattered along a 1km long stream) and feel like they're in a dream.|||With its unique natural scenery and endless natural hot springs, Hoi Van will increasingly attract more tourists to visit and treat themselves.

title: Sung Phuc Pagoda
description: Sung Phuc Pagoda is a place of worship for Nguyen Thi Due, the only female doctoral degree holder in the history of Vietnam's feudal era examinations, who graduated at Ban Thanh Cao Bang National School (Mạc dynasty).|||Sung Phuc Pagoda originally named Sung Khanh was built during the reign of King Tran Nhan Tong (1279 - 1293) on Po Kien mountain behind Na En village, surrounded by ancient trees that stay green all year round. During the Tran dynasty, Buddhism flourished; the pagoda primarily worships Buddha and those who contributed to defending the border.|||During the reign of King Le Hien Tong (1740 - 1786) in the Canh Hung period, the temple was renamed Sung Phuc and moved to the field of Xuan Du village (now in Thanh Nhat town, Ha Lang district, Cao Bang province).|||Sung Phuc Pagoda is built in the shape of the character 'Nhị'.|||It is surrounded by a double wall made of fire-resistant bricks, built in the 'bít đốc' style.|||The pagoda features a three-gate entrance and a rear hall constructed in the architectural style of the Lê Dynasty, with relatively simple decorative patterns.|||The temple currently enshrines the statue of Buddha Quan Am Bo Tat, and in the rear hall, there is a statue of the Buddha. On the left side, there is a shrine dedicated to Nguyen Thanh Vuong, also known as Nguyen Dinh Ba, who was born in Binh Dan village, Khoai Chau district, Hung Yen province. During his time as Tri Chau Tu Lang, historical records show that he successfully attracted settlers to clear land and establish new villages, earning him the title of Tien Cong Thanh Hoang, a village guardian deity. He continued to gain the trust of his superiors and the admiration of the people, eventually rising to the position of Doc Dong in Cao Bang.|||The temple also honors Nguyen Thi Due (from Kiet Dac village, now part of Van An commune, Chi Linh district, Hai Duong province) - the only female doctoral degree holder in the history of Vietnam's feudal era, who graduated from the Quoc Hoc Ban Thanh Cao Bang school (Mạc dynasty).|||According to historical records, during the Mac dynasty, King Mac Kinh Cung established the Ban Thanh National School (now Ban Thanh) which held triennial examinations. Over 85 years (1592 - 1677), the school held 12 examinations, producing many talented individuals, including female scholar Nguyen Thi Due. As a child, Nguyen Thi Due followed her father to Cao Bang. Being a keen learner, she disguised herself as a man and changed her name to Du, then studied under Master Cao from Hai Duong. In 1616, she and her teacher took the examination together, with her teacher ranking second and she topping the list.|||After passing the exam, she was invited to the palace to attend a banquet for new scholars. During the banquet, the king discovered that she was a girl disguised as a boy. However, impressed by her talent and virtue, the king invited her to the Ly Cung Dong Lan palace to teach the princes and princesses. He also proposed to her, and they got married, with her being titled Tinh Phi (Star Sa).|||In 1625, King Mac Kinh Cung was captured by Trinh Kien of the Le dynasty and brought back to Thang Long to face trial. Afterwards, Madame Duet escaped to Ha Lang and then took refuge in Sung Phuc Pagoda, where she was ordained with the dharma name Dieu Huyen, the nickname Du, and the name Ban Huyen Du was also given according to her name. While at the pagoda, she often taught morality and lectured on Buddhist scriptures to the local people.|||In 1631, knowing she was in Ha Lang, Trinh Trang, the Lord of Trinh, welcomed her back to Thang Long and appointed her as Le Thi. At the end of her life, despite King Le and Lord Trinh Tac wanting to keep her in the capital, she firmly refused, wishing to return to her homeland. After her death, her tomb was buried in her hometown of Hai Duong. Later, to commemorate Madame Duet, the people of Ha Lang (Cao Bang) cast her statue for worship in the pagoda.|||During the reign of King Le Hien Tong, the royal court issued an imperial decree for this complex of temples and pagodas. Later, three Nguyen kings: Duy Tan, Dong Khanh and Khai Dinh also issued decrees. This is a rare feature among temples and pagodas across Vietnam.|||Currently, the temple has a stone stele carved during the reign of King Le Canh Hung in 43. The stele has content in Chinese characters, recording the history and restoration of the temple, the tradition of protecting the country and the divine protection that brought a prosperous and peaceful life to the people.|||The stele was recognized as a National Cultural Historical Relic at Decision No. 68 QD/BT on January 29, 1993.|||To date, the temple has been renovated several times and hosts the Tam Tong festival annually on the 14th, 15th, and 16th days of the first lunar month. On the main day of the festival (the 15th day of the first lunar month), locals and tourists from afar come to join in the festivities in great numbers. The Sung Phuc Temple festival is rich in content, including rituals to offer incense, a procession of the Quan Am Bodhisattva palanquin, and a procession of the Thành Hoàng palanquin.|||The festival also features dragon dances, lion dances, qilin dances, and traditional folk games characteristic of the region.|||Sung Phuc Pagoda is not only a place of worship for Buddha and national heroes in this border area, but also where people commemorate and honor Nguyen Thi Due, a talented and virtuous woman during the feudal era, known as the 'Sao Sa' lady in the hearts of Vietnamese people.

title: Dao Thuc Water Puppet Village
description: Location: Thuy Lam commune, Dong Anh district, Hanoi. Characteristics: Famous for its water puppet troupe|||From Hanoi city center, follow National Route 3 to Dong Anh town center, then turn right for about 10km to reach Dao Thuc water puppet village.|||The ancestor of Dao Thuc water puppetry is Nguyen Dang Vinh, also known as Phuc Thiêm, the last official of the Le Y Tong dynasty (1735-1740). While working as an internal supervisor in the court, he learned the art of water puppetry from troupes performing for the king and royal court. After returning to his village, he established a small water puppet troupe and taught this art form to the villagers. Every year, on the 24th day of the 2nd lunar month (the day of his death), the villagers hold a ceremony to offer incense and perform water puppet shows to commemorate his merits.|||In Dao Thuc water puppet village, puppets are created by the villagers based on characters from Vietnamese folk tales. Each puppet is about 30-40cm tall, made of wood, and coated with paint to prevent water damage. Unlike other puppet troupes, Dao Thuc puppets can move left, right, and even turn around to enter the performance area. The puppeteers use a special device to control the puppets, allowing them to move their arms and hands. The puppets' movements are synchronized with music, singing, and drums. Over 20 plays are performed, including ancient stories, agricultural activities, folk games, and national legends. In recent years, new performances have been created to praise the homeland and country, such as 'Tặng hoa ngày hội', 'Rước ảnh Bác Hồ', and 'Hà Nội 12 ngày đêm'.|||The Dao Thuc puppet troupe has over 30 artists, mostly farmers who perform during their free time. Many families have kept the tradition of water puppetry for five generations. They pass down the secrets of the craft and overcome challenges to adapt to the changing times.|||Visiting Dao Thuc water puppet village, tourists not only enjoy the unique water puppet shows but also experience the gentle folk melodies, love songs, and rustic atmosphere. After centuries, the people of Dao Thuc still preserve their water puppet tradition like a precious treasure.

title: Phuoc Tich Ancient Village
description: Location: situated on the banks of the O Lau River in Phong Hoa commune, Phong Dien district, Thua Thien - Hue province. Characteristics: a living cultural museum of a Vietnamese rural village, preserved intact for centuries.|||The land of Phuoc Tich was originally known as Con Duong, where ethnic minorities lived. After the great victory over the Cham Kingdom in 1470, during the reign of King Le Thanh Tong (1460 - 1497), noble Hoang Minh Hung (from Cam Quyet, Quynh Luu, Nghe An) recruited some of his fellow villagers to Con Duong to clear land and establish a new settlement. Later, Con Duong was renamed Phuc Giang village, then Hoang Giang village. During the reign of King Gia Long (1802 - 1820), the village was renamed Phuoc Tich, meaning accumulating merit for descendants. Noble Hoang Minh Hung is considered the founder of the village.|||The village's architectural works, including houses, communal houses, temples, and family shrines, are built solidly in the traditional style of the Thuan Hoa region (an old administrative area including Quang Binh, Quang Tri, and Thua Thien - Hue provinces). Out of 117 houses in Phuoc Tich, 37 are over 100 years old, and 12 are particularly rare and precious, aged between 150 and 200 years. The houses have a 3-room, 2-roof architecture, with black wooden pillars; the framework, beams, and rafters are intricately carved. Inside the houses, many ancient artifacts have been preserved through generations, such as limestone vases, wooden wine cups, wooden dining tables, jars, and ceramic containers.|||Phuoc Tich village was famous for its high-quality ceramics that were presented to the king. Today, remnants of ancient kilns are still preserved. The villagers have dedicated a soil mound called Con Treng to store old ceramic pieces like a traditional museum.|||Phuoc Tich is also known as a village of scholars, where many people achieved high academic success. During the Nguyen dynasty (1802 - 1945), 19 villagers became bachelors or mandarins. The villagers built a temple to honor Confucius at the entrance of the village to promote learning and encourage descendants to pursue academic excellence.|||In Phuoc Tich village, from the elderly to children, everyone knows the village's history as a fundamental lesson in life. This has made a strong impression on tourists who witness the villagers' respect for their heritage.|||Phuoc Tich ancient village was recognized as a national historical site in 2009.

title: Truc Lam Phuong Nam Zen Monastery
description: Location: in the historical relic site of Lo Vong Cung, My Nhon hamlet, My Khanh commune, Phong Dien district, Can Tho city. Characteristics: one of the largest Zen monasteries in the Mekong Delta|||With the desire to inherit and promote the Truc Lam Yen Tu Zen sect of Emperor Tran Nhan Tong, General Pham Van Tra - former Minister of National Defense - proposed to build Truc Lam Phuong Nam Zen Monastery. The construction started on July 16, 2013, and was inaugurated on May 17, 2014, on an area of 38,016m2. The monastery follows traditional Vietnamese architecture, with main structures including the main hall, ancestor's hall, bell tower, and drum tower, modeled after the Buddhist temples during the Ly-Tran dynasty.|||The main gate is notable for its curved roof resembling a stylized dragon head. Two stone statues of Vi Da Ho Phap (Mr. Thien) and Tieu Dien Dai Si (Mr. Ac) are placed on either side. The path to the main hall is lined with two rows of stone La Han statues. Each statue has the name of a national hero who contributed to the country's defense and construction engraved at its base.|||The main hall is constructed with 44 lim wood columns on gray stone slabs with carved lotus patterns. Each column has inscribed couplets reflecting the solemnity. In the center is a 3.5-ton bronze statue of Buddha Shakyamuni. The monastery also features other structures, including Quan Am and Di Lac halls, a one-pillar pagoda, lecture hall, guest house, vegetarian hall, library, and Eastern medicine room.

title: Bao Dai Villa
description: Location: Van Huong Ward, Do Son District, Hai Phong City. Characteristics: A unique architectural work with special historical value|||Bao Dai Villa was built by French Governor-General Pafquiere in 1928 in an octagonal shape, following French architecture. In 1932, after returning from studying in France, King Bao Dai was invited to visit this place. Impressed by its unique architecture and beautiful landscape, he was given the villa by Pafquiere. From then on, it was named Bao Dai Villa. King Bao Dai used this villa from 1933 to 1954 for work and family vacations when traveling to the North. In May 1955, Bao Dai Villa came under the management of the Vietnamese Ministry of Defense. In 1984, the Ministry of Defense handed over the villa to Hai Phong Tourism Company (now Do Son Tourism Joint Stock Company) to manage, restore according to the 1928 architectural model, and open it to tourists in 1997.|||Bao Dai Villa has a 3,700m2 campus, with about 1,000m2 of usage area, surrounded by gardens and many trees. At nearly 40m above sea level, the villa has a view of the sea and the entire Do Son peninsula. The villa has one basement and two floors. The basement has kitchen, storage, technical rooms, and staff quarters. The first floor has a living room, office, dining room, and bedrooms of King Bao Dai and Queen Nam Phuong. The second floor has bedrooms of princesses, princes, and a room of Nguyen De - a close associate of King Bao Dai. The bedrooms and artifacts remain intact.|||Visiting Bao Dai Villa, tourists can hear guides tell interesting stories about King Bao Dai's life, famous for his quote: 'Being a citizen of an independent country is better than being a king of a slave country.' Tourists can also enjoy Hue royal court cuisine with many attractive and unique dishes in this windy coastal area. Additionally, tourists can rent royal court costumes to take souvenir photos at the villa.|||Bao Dai Villa has long been a special attraction, welcoming many tourists each year. The majestic yet romantic beauty of the villa amidst the 'nine dragons' scenery has contributed to making Do Son tourism more appealing.

title: Hien Luong - Ben Hai Historic Site
description: Location: in 3 communes Vinh Thanh, Vinh Giang, Vinh Son, Cuu Tung town, Vinh Linh district and Trung Hai commune, Gio Linh district, Quang Tri province. Characteristic: it symbolizes the glorious revolutionary heroism in the struggle for the aspiration of national reunification.|||The area on both sides of Hien Luong Bridge|||Hien Luong Bridge was first built with wood in 1928. In 1952, the French built a new bridge with 7 spans, 178m long, 4m wide, concrete and steel pillars, pine wood deck, 1.2m high railings on both sides, and a maximum load capacity of 18 tons.|||Under the Geneva Accords, a demilitarized zone along the 17th parallel, from the mouth of the Ben Hai River in Quang Tri, Vietnam, running along the river's length to the Vietnam-Laos border, would become a temporary military demarcation line dividing Vietnam into North and South. At that time, the Hien Luong Bridge spanning the Ben Hai River was also divided into two parts belonging to two different regions and was painted in two colors: the southern part on the south bank was painted yellow, while the northern part on the north bank was painted blue, with a 1cm wide white line marking the boundary between the two parts of the bridge.|||After being destroyed by American bombs in 1967, Hien Luong Bridge became a symbol of the division of the country into North and South Vietnam. From 2001 to 2008, Quang Tri Province restored the bridge based on the original design by French architects in 1952, with a length of 183.65m, width of 5.50m, and a traffic lane of 3.20m.|||The bridge's railings were painted in two colors, green and yellow, to reflect the Hien Luong Bridge during the period of national division.|||Currently, Hien Luong Bridge connects National Route 1A, spanning Ben Hai River, with the north bank located in Hien Luong village (Vinh Thanh commune) and the south bank in Xuan Hoa village (Trung Hai commune).|||The police station and flagpole are located on the northern bank of the Ben Hai river.|||Under the Geneva Agreement, there were 4 police stations along the Ben Hai river (demilitarized zone). On the north bank of the river were Hien Luong and Cua Tung police stations, while on the south bank were Xuan Hoa and Cat Son police stations. Each station had around 20 personnel, armed with handguns and infantry carbines, responsible for maintaining the demilitarized zone regulations, controlling people crossing the zone, and monitoring each other's implementation of the Agreement's terms, all under the supervision of International Organization 76 (consisting of representatives from Canada, India, and Poland).|||In 1967, two outposts on the southern bank of the river were destroyed by American bombs. To this day, the two outposts on the northern bank remain, but due to deterioration, the Quang Tri province has restored them to their original model.|||Hien Luong police station is located right at the bridge abutment on the north bank of Ben Hai river (Vinh Thanh commune). The complex consists of 3 houses A, B and C, forming a V shape. House A (union house) was built in a stilt house style, measuring 12m x 6m, with a tiled roof and glass windows. This used to be a meeting place and for receiving guests.|||House B, measuring 10m x 5m, was made of wood with a thatched roof, serving as a residence for border police officers.|||House C, measuring 12m x 4m, was used as a logistics warehouse and kitchen.|||Hien Luong Flag Tower|||From 1954 to 1967, a 'flagpole competition' took place on both sides of Hien Luong Bridge, where each side tried to build a taller flagpole. The flagpole in the police station area of Hien Luong on the north bank ultimately won. The flagpole is made of steel pipes, built in 1962, and stands 38.6m high. On top of the flagpole is a flag measuring 9.6m x 4m.|||The flagpole is now a replica of the flagpoles erected by the Democratic Republic of Vietnam government and military. The flagpole is 28m high, made of 6 linked steel pipe sections. A five-pointed yellow star flag is attached to the top. Rectangular steel bars are attached to the pole to serve as a ladder. The flagpole also features a cable and pulley system for easy flag raising and lowering. The base is circular and decorated with images describing revolutionary history.|||Cua Tung Police Station now belongs to Border Guard Station 204 (Cua Tung town). Besides its function as a workplace and accommodation, this area also serves national security purposes.|||This place has a traditional house displaying 92 photos and 60 artifacts directly related to the history of revolutionary struggle of officers and soldiers of Cua Tung Police Station and other stations along the northern bank of Ben Hai River from 1954 to 1967.|||Architectural complex on the south bank of Ben Hai River|||To simulate the former demilitarized zone on the 17th parallel and create a historical destination for tourists, as well as to educate younger generations about revolutionary traditions, Quang Tri province has constructed the "17th Parallel and Reunification Aspiration" exhibition house and the "Reunification Aspiration" monument cluster on the south bank of the Ben Hai river.|||The exhibition "The 17th Parallel and The Aspiration for Reunification" (in Vinh Thanh commune) consists of two rooms. The main room is where Ho Chi Minh's statue is placed. The exhibition room features 53 documents and artifacts directly related to the fighting of our army and people on both sides of Hien Luong - Ben Hai during the resistance war against America. The documents and artifacts are categorized into four themes: The Geneva Accords and the temporary military demarcation line; The indomitable spirit of Vinh Linh people and the fight to protect the border; People in the south of the 17th parallel and the struggle for the aspiration of national reunification; The 17th parallel after the liberation of Quang Tri in 1972.||||||Notably, this place preserves a restored version of a 500W loudspeaker used by the Democratic Republic of Vietnam's government and military on the northern bank.|||Viewing this speaker helps visitors imagine the 'loudspeaker battle' along the Ben Hai River from 1954 to 1965.|||On one side of the river, a powerful loudspeaker system broadcast political messages to the opposing side, which responded with an even more powerful system.|||The northern bank's loudspeaker system, with each speaker ring measuring 1.7m in diameter and 500W in power, was mounted on a mobile vehicle to send intimidating messages.|||When the wind was favorable, the sound could travel as far as 10km.|||The "Aspiration for Reunification" monument complex (Trung Hai commune) was built on an area of 2,700m², consisting of two parts. The base is made up of many differently sized stone blocks, decorated with bas-reliefs. The monument part is made of Thanh Hoa green stone with the following layout: in the front are 2 statues of a mother (7.70m high) and a child (5.50m high) standing close together, depicting the image of a wife and child in the South longing and looking towards the North, unable to cross the river to meet their husband, father, and relatives during the country's division. Behind is a group of statues forming the background, describing the image of water coconut leaves.|||This area also features a spacious campus, festival grounds, a lake, a reception house, and a security house to serve visitors and promote the value of the historical site.|||Ben Hai River and ferry crossings on Ben Hai River|||The Ben Hai River originates from Dong Chan Mountain in the Truong Son range, flowing nearly 100km, along the 17th parallel from west to east and emptying into the Cua Tung sea mouth.|||The ferry piers on the Ben Hai River include: Cua Tung (pier A), Tung Luat (pier B), Luy (pier C), Thuong Dong and Duc Duc. Of these, Cua Tung and Tung Luat piers played a crucial role in the victory of the Vietnamese people in their struggle for independence and national reunification.|||Cua Tung Wharf (Wharf A) is located in the area of Cua Tung beach (Cua Tung town). This is where boats and ships carrying officials operating from 1954 to 1975 used to anchor. Currently, this wharf is planned within a 187.6m2 area, surrounded by a fence. The memorial stele of Wharf A consists of two parts: the pedestal and the artistic architectural complex, which prominently features the image of boats overcoming waves to transport officials and soldiers across the river and the aspiration for the day of national reunification.|||Tung Luat ferry dock (dock B) was about 150m long, located in Tung Luat village, Vinh Giang commune (now Cua Tung town), 7km east of Hien Luong bridge and 2km west of Cua Tung sea. It was a secret anchorage point for boats and ships that transported officials, soldiers, wounded soldiers, civilians and weapons to the South bank. It was a key departure point for the transportation line to Con Co island.|||The ferry terminal is currently planned to include a park and a memorial. The memorial is an artistic complex symbolizing the image of boats carrying soldiers and goods moving forward despite enemy bombs and bullets.|||In 1996, these ferry piers were ranked as national historical relics by the Ministry of Culture and Information (Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism).|||Every year on April 30, a national reunification festival takes place at the historic site of Doi bo Hien Luong - Ben Hai. This is a unique revolutionary festival that only occurs at this site. The festival features many attractive and historically significant events, contributing to education and promotion of the tradition of fighting for the aspiration of national reunification of our ancestors.||||||The Hien Luong - Ben Hai historical complex was ranked as a national historical site in 1986 and a special national historical site in 2013.

title: Ngoc Van Pagoda
description: Location: on the peak of Ngoc Van of Bao Dai mountain, Tay Son village, Binh Khe commune, Dong Trieu district, Quang Ninh province. Characteristics: this is where Buddha King Tran Nhan Tong cultivated and entered Nirvana in the 13th century.|||Ngoc Van Peak is located on the southern slope of Bao Dai Mountain (also known as Vay Rong Mountain), part of the Yen Tu range, at an average height of 588-644m above sea level.|||The peak of Ngoc Van and the temple located here is named Ngoc Van (meaning lying cloud).|||Ngọa Vân Pagoda was built during the Tran Dynasty, is one of the typical works in the historical site of Tran Dynasty in Dong Trieu. After a period of ascetic practice and founding the Truc Lam Zen sect in Yen Tu, King Tran Nhan Tong came down from the mountain and traveled to educate people on practicing the Ten Good Deeds, and gave medicine to cure diseases for the people. In May of Dinh Mui (1307), he went to Bao Dai mountain and chose Ngọa Vân peak to build a hut for meditation. At the hour of Tý on the 3rd day of the 11th lunar month in Mậu Thân (1308), he attained Buddhahood at Ngọa Vân hut, completing his cultivation process. Therefore, Ngọa Vân became the sacred land of Truc Lam Buddhism.||||||After King Tran Nhan Tong became a Buddha, along with the strong development of the Truc Lam Zen sect, Zen master Phap Loa, a successor of the sect, built Ngoc Van from a small hut into a large complex of pagodas and towers on Bao Dai mountain.|||The complex includes many groups of structures such as: the hut and tower cluster, main pagoda, Thong Dan - Do Kieu cluster, Ngoc Van 1 and 2.|||Over the historical ups and downs, many Ngoc Van structures were ruined.|||Only a few remain, including Tan Long, Am Tra, Do Kieu slope, Thong Dan, Da Chong, Ba Bac..., notably the Ngoc Van pagoda and hut.|||Recognizing the importance of Ngọa Vân Pagoda to the history of Vietnamese Buddhism, Dong Trieu town has collaborated with the Executive Board of Quang Ninh Province Buddhist Church to restore, renovate and promote the value of Ngọa Vân historical site. Currently, the pagoda and temple complex of Ngọa Vân includes architectural works such as: Tổ House (main temple), Sơn Thần shrine, Ngọa Vân shrine...|||The Ancestor's House is a place of worship for Buddha and the Three Patriarchs of the Truc Lam Zen sect. It has a rectangular shape with an area of 50m2 and 3 tiled roof sections. The walls are made of stone.|||The house currently houses statues of Buddha Tran Nhan Tong, Dharma Protector Phap Loa, Dharma Protector Huyen Quang, Van Huu, Pho Hien, and Buddha Sakya. All the statues are made of bronze, each 1.3 to 2.2 meters tall.|||Next to the Ancestor's House are two stone towers built of rice stone and semi-laterite stone. One is the Buddha King Tower containing the relics of King Tran Nhan Tong. The other is the Doan Nghiem Tower containing the relics of Zen Master Duc Hung, a disciple of the Truc Lam Zen sect.|||In front of the Buddha King Tower is a rectangular stone stele erected in the 21st year of Minh Mệnh (1840).|||About 10m east of the Ancestral House, the Son Than shrine (worshiping the mountain god) is a rectangular structure with an area of 9.2m2, featuring a brick vaulted roof. In front of the Son Than shrine is a stone stele erected in the 3rd year of Vinh Thinh (1707) recording the restoration process of Ngoa Van Pagoda.|||Similar in architecture to the Son Than shrine, Ngoa Van shrine is where King Tran Nhan Tong passed away. According to legend, when entering Nirvana, the Buddha king lay on a large stone in the shrine in the posture of a lion. This stone is now called the Nirvana stone, measuring 4.4m in length, 3.65m in width, and 2.44m in height.|||To visit Ngoc Van temple, besides two hiking trails to the mountain, visitors can also use a 2km cable car system. This, along with the route connecting Yen Tu relic site (Uong Bi town) to the Tran dynasty historical site in Dong Trieu, facilitates pilgrims and tourists to explore and worship at this sacred Buddhist site of Truc Lam.|||Ngọa Van Pagoda was recognized as a national cultural historical site by the Ministry of Culture and Information (now the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism) in 2006.

title: Tien Phi Cave
description: Location: on top of Thuc hill (also known as Thung Phi hill) in Hoa Binh City, Hoa Binh Province. Characteristics: The cave features many uniquely shaped stalactites and stalagmites|||Tien Phi Cave was discovered in 1982 and officially opened for tourism in 1984. From the foot of Thuc hill, visitors climb hundreds of winding stone steps to reach the cave. The path is lined with phoenix trees, jackfruit trees, eucalyptus trees, and bamboo groves that provide shade. On the left side of the cave entrance is the Trinh Temple, built under a stone roof. Visitors typically stop to burn incense at the temple before entering the cave. The cave entrance is formed by massive stones stacked together, facing northeast. The path down into the cave is gentle.|||Upon entering the cave, visitors reach the first chamber, 15m long, 8m wide, and 20m high. The cave floor is rough and sloping, with dry, dark yellow soil. The cave walls feature lively stalactites, some hanging down, others spreading out like blooming flowers. A sinkhole in the ceiling allows natural light to filter in, creating an ethereal atmosphere.|||Further 10m into the cave lies the next chamber, 53m long, 20m wide, and 10m high. On the left wall is a stalactite formation resembling a fairy with long hair and a flowing scarf, surrounded by fairies in elegant attire, seemingly floating on clouds. The chamber also features other fantastical stalactites and stalagmites, including an old man with a white beard and hair, Jesus Christ, a giant, a crouching panther, and a lion. At the cave's end is a semicircular 'fairy well,' 3m wide and 30cm deep, filled with clear, cool water.|||Tien Phi Cave is a must-visit attraction in Hoa Binh, offering a fascinating experience for travelers.

title: Thu An Beach
description: Location: Thu An Beach is located in Thu An town, Phu Vang district, Thua Thien - Hue province. Characteristics: Thu An is an interesting beach for tourists after a day of sightseeing in the imperial city, tombs, temples, and landscapes in Hue.|||Thu An Beach is situated next to Thu An estuary, where the Huong River flows into Tam Giang lagoon and then opens up to the sea. The beach is 15km from Hue city and visitors can get there by car.|||The car ride is both quick and enjoyable, with one side being the scenic river and the other side being the landscape of houses, pagodas, temples, and rice fields.|||Thu An is a place that attracts a large number of Hue people to relax and swim during the summer. The busiest period here usually lasts from April to September, when the weather is hottest.|||In addition, visitors can visit nearby Thai Duong temple with the legend of the goddess Thai Duong, who is highly revered by the locals, or visit Am Linh temple, which worships the whale, a sacred animal of the coastal people.

title: A1 Hill
description: Location: A1 Hill is located in Muong Thanh Ward, Dien Bien Phu City, Dien Bien Province. Characteristics: A1 Hill was a key stronghold in the French defensive system in Dien Bien Phu.|||The hill runs northwest to southeast, with two peaks: the northwest peak is over 490m high, and the southeast peak is over 493m high. A1 was the code name given to the hill by the Vietnamese military. After intense battles took place here, the Vietnamese army captured A1 Hill at 4am on May 7, 1954.|||Today, visitors to Dien Bien Phu will see a monument built in the 'Tam son' style on the northwest peak of A1 Hill, with a higher center and lower sides, and curved roof edges. In front is an incense burner, in the middle is a stele, and a national flag emblem.|||Next to the monument is the wreckage of one of two 18-ton tanks that was brought up to counterattack the Vietnamese army. Another important relic is a large funnel-shaped crater, a remnant of a massive explosion.|||Visiting A1 Hill allows tourists to experience the spirit of Vietnam's struggle and contributes to the great victory that shook the world, now forever remembered.

title: Tham Om Cave
description: Location: The cave is located in Quy Chau district, Nghe An province. Characteristics: This is a beautiful cave with diverse natural formations.|||Archaeologists have discovered many artifacts proving that ancient Vietnamese people once lived here. Today, Tham Om Cave still retains much of its pristine beauty and is being restored to welcome tourists.

title: Nhan Tower
description: Location: Nhan Tower is located on the north bank of the Da Rang River, near National Route 1A, in Tuy Hoa City, Phu Yen Province. Characteristics: The tower is a place of worship for the ancient Cham people.|||Nhan Tower was built at the end of the 11th century or beginning of the 12th century on a relatively flat land near the top of Nhan Mountain.|||There is a legend about the construction of the tower on Nhan Mountain. During that time, Luong Phu Gia's army (also known as Luong Van Chanh) clashed with the Cham army (also known as Chiem Thanh). The battlefield took place on the land of Tuy Hoa city today. Luong Phu Gia's army was stationed at Nhuu Mountain, while the Cham army was stationed at Nhan Mountain to defend. The battle was extremely fierce with no clear winner.|||To avoid harm to people and property of the civilians, the two sides agreed to build a tower. The side that completed the tower first would win, and the losing side would have to withdraw their troops from Phu Yen. The two locations chosen by the two sides were: the Cham army on Nhan Mountain and Luong Phu Gia's army on Co Rua Mountain, an outcrop of Nhuu Mountain.|||The Cham army devoted all their strength day and night to building, but just as they were about to complete it, Phu Gia's tower was finished, standing tall in the sky. The Cham army had to accept defeat.|||Later, Phu Gia's army challenged the Chiem Thanh to burn the tower; the side whose tower burned first would lose and have to withdraw their troops. Phu Gia's tower burned down in just one night, while the tower on Nhan mountain still stood firm.|||Luong Van Chanh led a large army to the foot of Nhan mountain, forcing the Cham army to retreat to the other side of Ca pass.|||During the resistance war against France (1945 – 1954), when French colonizers invaded our country, they bombarded the tower, causing the top and 3 corners of the tower to collapse. Due to severe damage from the war, at the end of 1960, under the puppet government, Phu Yen province decided to restore the tower, repairing cracks inside and outside.|||The building materials of the tower are all made of burnt bricks with various sizes depending on the position of each wall section and each tower floor, and are arranged tightly together, with no visible mortar but very solidly bonded. The upper rows of bricks are slightly recessed compared to the lower rows until the vault is closed.|||Nhan Tower has a similar architectural style to the Cham Po Nagar tower in Nha Trang, built in a high-rise form. The tower is quadrilateral with 4 floors, getting smaller as it rises, but still following the style of the lower floors. The tower is nearly 23.5m high, with each side of the base being 10m long.|||The roof of the tower consists of multiple stacked layers, the apex is made of a single piece of stone carved into a lotus bud shape. This is a Linga symbol of the Cham people. On the top of the tower, there are four fake windows on each side, separating the upper and lower parts. The main entrance is oriented to the east, with a semicircular arch above it, built in a stepped style. The door frame and lintel are made of soft limestone, easily carved and sculpted.|||Inside the tower, the wall is built straight up from the base to the top. The higher it goes, the smaller the wall becomes, forming a cone shape. The tower wall has no decorative patterns, only a few dragon motifs carved in granite are placed outside the tower corner. Inside the tower, there is no altar, no statue, just a small shrine in front to worship Lady Thuong Dinh Chua Thiet A Na Dien Ngoc Phi built during the Later Le dynasty.|||Notably, at the foot of Nhan Mountain to the southwest, along the Chua River bank, there is a stone standing 1.3m tall and 0.9m wide on each side. The base of the stone features a carved lotus petal design, and on it are inscribed three ancient letters in Sanskrit, commonly found on the pillar plaques of Cham towers. The inscription appears at about one-third of the stone's height. This is likely the only remaining written record in the tower area to date.|||Nhan Tower is an architectural work of art with high historical value of the Cham people and is also a typical scenic spot of Phu Yen province. Nhan Tower was recognized by the Ministry of Culture and Information as a national architectural and artistic relic on November 16, 1988.

title: Long Bien Bridge
description: Location: Long Bien Bridge spans the Red River, connecting Hoan Kiem and Long Bien districts of Hanoi. Characteristics: Long Bien was the first steel bridge across the Red River and is considered a historical witness to the ups and downs of Hanoi through two wars against France and the US.|||The project was approved by French Governor-General Paul Doumer in 1897 to improve infrastructure for colonial exploitation. The French company Daydé & Pille won the bid to design and build the bridge in 1898. Construction started in 1899 and finished in 1902, initially named Doumer Bridge. It was the largest bridge in Indochina at that time and praised by the French as a bridge connecting two centuries. The bridge has a 2,290m long section across the river with 19 steel beam spans on 20 pillars over 40m high and 896m of access roads built of stone. The design includes a railway track in the middle and roads for pedestrians and carts on both sides. The pedestrian paths were the best places to enjoy the Red River scenery in Hanoi.|||After the liberation of Hanoi (October 10, 1954), the bridge was renamed Long Bien. During the Vietnam War (1954-1975), Vietnamese forces built anti-aircraft artillery positions on the river island and used the bridge's high points as gun emplacements. Damaged bridge spans were replaced with temporary beams to keep traffic flowing. In 2002, the bridge underwent repairs and reinforcement.|||Today, the bridge is only used for trains, motorbikes, bicycles, and pedestrians. A peculiarity of Long Bien Bridge is that traffic flows on the left side, contrary to Vietnam's traffic rules. At the bridge's entrance, a metal plate still shows the construction time and the contractor's name.

title: Soc Xiem Tourist Area
description: Location: An Phu commune, Binh Long district, Binh Phuoc province, 70km from Dong Xoai town and 120km northwest of Ho Chi Minh City. Features: This place is ideal for resort tourism with a serene lake, picturesque waterfalls in a highland forest.|||From Thu Dau Mot city, Binh Duong province, take National Highway 13 about 70km north to An Loc town, Binh Long district, turn left and continue for about 10km to reach Sóc Xiêm Lake tourist area.|||Located in the Tra Thanh red soil forest area with a surface area of 30ha, and a depth of up to 14m, Soc Xiêm Lake is like a wild flower with a pristine and romantic beauty. The lake was originally a valley with a small stream flowing through it that never ran dry.|||In 1981, Mr. Tu Nguyen established a rubber production team here and had it excavated to create a large water body, using the water to irrigate 116ha of rubber trees. Over time, the lake formed from the stream's water and groundwater springs.|||The lake is surrounded by hundreds of hectares of primeval forest and rubber forest in a vast space, exuding both serenity and harmony. The summer sun seems to soften in front of the clear lake, reflecting the sky and clouds amidst the endless green rubber forests.|||During the season of rubber tree leaf change, the fallen golden leaves spread out, creating a picturesque autumn scene.|||Next to the cool Soc Xiem lake is Thac So 4, with 4 streams of waterfalls flowing day and night. The sight leaves travelers in awe, praising the creator's skillful touch in painting a majestic scene, gifting humans a breathtaking beauty.|||The Soc Xiêm Lake tourist area is a place for sightseeing, relaxation, camping, workshops, and exchange. It's an ideal spot for young people and couples to enjoy the scenery and spend time together. You can sit for hours by the spacious lake or beautiful stream, chatting, laughing, and singing without any disturbance. From the floating house in the middle of the lake, you can fish and enjoy the bird songs, immersing yourself in the pristine atmosphere of the forest. The lake is home to many fish species, including tilapia, kìm fish, snakehead fish, and more. In the afternoon, with a gentle breeze, you can watch flocks of birds return to their nests. At night, in the silent forest, in the stilt houses of the Western Highlands, the wind rustling through the trees will lull you into a peaceful sleep. In the morning, with calm winds, the water surface is smooth, and mist still clings to the lake... Adventure-seekers can swim, kayak, or play volleyball, badminton at the sports ground of So 4 waterfall.|||When visiting Ho Soc Xiem tourist area, visitors can explore the remaining vestiges of the airport from different historical periods. Additionally, tourists can ride horses or take a vehicle along the trail into the thousands-of-hectares rubber plantations, meet workers extracting rubber for conversation, or visit Xoai, Xiêm, Sacô, and Lac Su communities to meet the hospitable Xtieng ethnic people. They are very open and sincere; if they have rice wine and buffalo meat, they will offer some to visitors for tasting...||||||The So Xiêm Lake tourist area is sure to delight those who have visited here, leaving with new discoveries and sweet memories of this historic and beautiful land.

title: Dong Khe Historical Site
description: The Dong Khe battle was the largest attack by the Viet Minh on a well-fortified enemy position since Vietnam's independence in 1945 up to 1950. The battle marked the development of the Viet Minh army and laid the foundation for future tactics.|||Located on a hill in Dong Khe town, Thạch An district, Cao Bang province, the Dong Khe fort was the site of the opening battle of the 1950 Thu-Dong border campaign, which set the stage for the nation's great resistance war. The Dong Khe relic site includes bunkers, underground tunnels, and other structures like fences, fortifications, and a fortified gate with a 12-firepower gun emplacement.|||Dong Khe was a key point on the French National Route 4 defense line. The enemy forces consisted of two legionnaire companies and a puppet army platoon, equipped with 105mm and 57mm artillery, mortars, and strong firepower. From September 16, 1950, General Hoàng Văn Thái directly commanded the Dong Khe battle to eliminate the enemy stronghold, isolate the enemy in Cao Bang, and create conditions to attack enemy reinforcements on National Route 4. The battle was fought in two phases.|||Phase 1, from 6am on September 16 to dawn on September 17, 1950, focused on destroying outlying positions; our forces captured five outpost forts but did not advance further. The enemy concentrated firepower and launched counterattacks, recapturing three forts and causing us significant difficulties. In phase 2, on September 17, 1950, at 5pm, the commander shifted the 174th Regiment's attack from the north to the northeast to pin down the enemy and create conditions to destroy the central stronghold.|||At 3am on September 18, our artillery fired on enemy targets in the center. Our troops stormed the enemy positions on all fronts, with notable bravery shown by Lý Văn Mưu, La Văn Cầu, and Trần Cừ. Under our intense attack, the enemy retreated to their headquarters. At 4:30am on September 18, our forces broke through to the headquarters, capturing the garrison commander and a staff officer. By 10am that day, we had secured the battlefield and the battle ended.|||After over two days of fighting with fortified tactics, we captured the Dong Khe stronghold, breaking a crucial link in the French National Route 4 defense line and eliminating 300 French and allied troops, seizing all their weapons. The Dong Khe victory decisively contributed to the development of the campaign, forcing the enemy to withdraw from Cao Bang and setting up the opportunity for us to destroy enemy reinforcements in the next phase.|||Historians later evaluated that the Dong Khe battle was the Viet Minh's largest attack on a well-fortified enemy position since independence up to 1950. The battle marked the development of the Viet Minh army and laid the foundation for future tactics.|||With its great historical significance, the Dong Khe historical site was recognized as a national-level historical and revolutionary site in Vietnam.

title: Non Nuoc Tourist Area
description: Location: Non Nuoc tourist area is invested and built in Tien An village, Tien Thanh commune, Phan Thiet city, Binh Thuan province. Features: Here, tourists will have the opportunity to enjoy the fresh and cool atmosphere.|||Located on an area of over 2ha, Non Nuoc tourist area is designed with a quite luxurious and romantic style, facing the East Sea, with a harmonious space mixed with many colors of trees, flowers, birds, sky and ocean...|||With a system of cool and comfortable rooms, along with attractive food and entertainment services such as: Restaurants designed based on traditional Vietnamese house architecture with a capacity of hundreds of guests; conference and meeting rooms; internet rooms; swimming pools; water motorcycles; water balloons, beach volleyball... always bring interesting and comfortable feelings to tourists when coming here. In addition, with the criterion of "Customer is the king", Non Nuoc tourist area also has a team of highly professional staff with a dedicated, attentive and friendly service style.|||In the future, the tourist area will be invested and constructed with additional works such as: accommodation area, infrastructure, high-end service area to meet all relaxation and resort needs of tourists, entertainment area such as: Gala Dinner, a system of staggered houses, playgrounds for children...|||Coming to Non Nuoc tourist area, tourists have the opportunity to enjoy the fresh, cool and airy atmosphere and have a chance to rest and relax after the hard work and fatigue in daily life.

title: Chu Van An Temple
description: Location: It is located in the Phuong Hoang relic site, in Van An ward, Chi Linh town, Hai Duong province, about 80 km east of Hanoi. Characteristics: The temple bears a distinct architectural style from the Nguyen dynasty, and is dedicated to teacher Chu Van An (1292 - 1370).|||The land of Chi Linh was considered by ancient people to be a particularly important strategic location, with the terrain 'Lục thuỷ tứ linh', where six rivers converge into one called Luc Dau Giang. Four majestic mountain ranges form a masterpiece called Tu Linh: Long - Ly - Quy - Phuong. This place is also home to the Phuong Hoang mountain range with 72 peaks, symbolizing 72 phoenix birds spreading their wings. The phoenix is a symbol of wisdom and talent, also known as 'Tieu an co bich' (ancient house wall), the secluded residence of teacher Chu Van An, as recorded in Nguyen Dinh Phu's book 'Phuong Son tu chi luoc' that 'Chu Van Trinh tiên sinh ẩn cư sứ'.|||Chu Van An originally came from Van Thon village, Thanh Liet commune, Thanh Tri district, Hanoi. He was a prominent figure in propagating and educating Confucian ethics in Vietnam. At 16, he passed the 'Dinh Thi' exam but chose not to become a mandarin; instead, he opened a school in Huynh Cung village, near his hometown. In his early 20s, King Tran Minh Tong appointed him as a teacher at the National Academy, tutoring the Crown Prince. During the reign of King Tran Du Tong, due to his intolerance for corrupt officials, he retired to Phuong Hoang mountain, taking the alias 'Tieu An', focusing on teaching, writing, and studying medicine until his death.||||||After Chu Van An passed away (1370), a temple was built at the site where he taught. However, due to the harshness of time and the intense war bombings, by the 80s, the temple was almost completely destroyed. In the 90s, with the consensus of the authorities, the Hai Duong Museum, Van An Ward People's Committee, Education sector, and local residents carried out a major restoration and reconstruction.|||The result of the two renovation phases was that by 2008, Chu Van An's temple had become a complex of impressive and solemn architecture including: inner and outer tam quan, lower, middle and upper courtyards, a tree garden, two ceremonial houses, two stele houses, the main temple and 112 stone steps leading up to it, decorated with dragon and phoenix reliefs.|||The main temple is situated on high, spacious land, which according to feng shui, is the eye of the Phoenix bird. In front of the temple is Ngoc Mountain as a precedent, behind which is Phuong Mountain as a support, and on either side are Ky Lan and Phuong Hoang Mountains that seem to be bowing. The temple is built in the shape of the Chinese character for 'two' (二), a two-storeyed, eight-roofed tiled structure with eight curved corners, comprising five front halls and one rear sanctum. In the centre of the front hall is the communal altar, right behind which is the ancestral altar of the Chu family, on the right is the altar of the mountain god of Phuong Hoang Mountain, and on the left is the altar for the teacher's disciples. In the rear sanctum is a 100kg bronze statue of the teacher. The art of decoration in the temple follows the themes of 'four spirits' (Dragon, Snake, Turtle, Phoenix) and 'four precious things' (Pine, Chrysanthemum, Bamboo, Plum). The doors are decorated with gold and lacquer in the pattern of 'a dragon bowing to a blooming chrysanthemum'. In front of the temple are a pair of stone dragons in the architectural style of the Tran dynasty…|||In the serene and majestic space of the Chu Van An temple, nestled among the endless green pine forest, stands out the phrase “Vạn thế sư biểu”, and notably, a large calligraphic inscription of the word “Học” on the path leading to the temple. This is a manifestation of the gratitude of many generations of Vietnamese people towards the exemplary teacher Chu Van An. Another distinctive feature of the temple is that during their visit, besides offering traditional dishes, visitors also offer pens, books, and notebooks to pray for success in their studies and academic pursuits.|||The Chu Van An Temple is a spiritual and educational tourist destination for many visitors, officials, teachers, students across the country. Every year, a spring opening ceremony (a cultural beauty preserved since teacher Chu Van An came here to open a school) takes place on the 6th day of the Lunar New Year with 4 Han Nom calligraphy words: Chinh-Hoc-Thuuan-Hanh, and 10 national language words: Tam-Duc-Chi-Nghia-Trung/Tai-Minh-Tri-Thanh-Vinh; a autumn festival from August 1st to 25th (main festival on 25th); a memorial ceremony for Vietnamese Teacher's Day on November 20th; a source festival from November 24th to 26th (main festival on 26th).|||The temple was ranked as a national historical monument by the State in 1998.

title: Thac Da Eco-Tourism Site
description: Location: Thac Da Eco-Tourism Site is located in Muong Chau village, Van Hoa commune, Ba Vi district, Hanoi. Features: Part of the famous Ao Vua, Suoi Mo, Suoi Hai tourism complex, Thac Da spans 100ha at the foot of Ba Vi mountain with pristine and majestic natural scenery, bearing historical marks and traditional cultural nuances.|||Thac Da is about 60km west of Hanoi city center, making it a convenient and ideal getaway for a weekend after a busy week. Coming to Thac Da, visitors will discover new experiences compared to other tourist sites.|||A charming, untouched landscape, skillfully developed to transport visitors back in time to the era of ancient Vietnamese tribes, recalling the victories of Trưng and Triệu sisters. Visitors can enjoy fresh air on the 1281m high peak of Ba Vi mountain, stay in cozy Thai stilt houses surrounded by lush greenery, crystal-clear streams, and serene scenery, forgetting their daily fatigue to indulge in nature's gifts. Unique bar-like structures in the form of stilt houses for visitors to rest. Here, visitors can sit on wooden or wicker chairs, admiring the dreamy surroundings. The site features a swimming pool, fishing lake, sports playground, fruit garden, distinctive ethnic cuisine, and more, leaving unforgettable impressions.|||From the stilt house, guides will take visitors to Thac Da, the largest waterfall in the area. The path to Thac Da winds and turns. Before reaching the majestic Thac Da, visitors will visit Khe Can, Doc Mong Waterfall, and May Waterfall. Khe Can is called so because the dry stream bed reveals shiny white pebbles glistening in sunlight.|||At Thac Da, visitors can immerse themselves in the warm festive atmosphere of ethnic minorities, savoring the rice wine in bonfires, enjoying traditional dances like the Tai people's xòe dance, Mường people's sênh tiền dance, Dao people's chuông dance, H'Mong people's kèn lá call to love, or Tày people's Hát mừng năm mới. Visitors can grasp the basic characteristics of cultural identity of many ethnic groups through their customs, costumes, and musical heritage.

title: Con Se Tre Tourist Area
description: Location: Con Se Tre Tourist Area is located on the southern part of Hon Tre Island in Nha Trang Bay, Nha Trang City, Khanh Hoa Province, 3km from Nha Trang coastline. Features: From a rocky island, Con Se Tre has been developed into a charming tourist site in Nha Trang.|||With just a 15-minute boat ride, you will arrive at Con Se Tre. Here, you can find the nostalgic rural scenery that once appeared in your dreams or childhood memories in a peaceful space, a pristine beach, poetic landscapes, traditional folk activities, and perfect service.

title: Vietnam National Village for Culture and Tourism
description: Location: Dong Mo village, Son Tay town, Hanoi. Features: This is a place that introduces typical cultural and historical values of Vietnamese ethnic communities.|||The Vietnam National Village for Culture and Tourism is built on a total area of 1,544ha, including 7 functional areas: ethnic villages, cultural and entertainment center, world cultural heritage site, boat dock park, Dong Mo lake green space and water surface, general tourism service area, and office management area.|||The ethnic village area, covering 198.61ha, features a mix of hills, mountains, valleys, and lakes, with traditional village models of ethnic groups to recreate the natural and cultural scenes of 4 clusters across the country. Cluster I features cultural and architectural characteristics of 28 ethnic groups in the Northeast, Northwest, and North Central Vietnam. Cluster II features those of 18 ethnic groups in the South Central and Central Highlands regions. Cluster III showcases the culture of ethnic groups in the semi-mountainous and highland areas. Cluster IV represents the culture of ethnic groups in the semi-mountainous, mountainous, and lowland areas.|||At the ethnic village, traditional cultural festivals such as Northwest border market, Cor people's rain-seeking festival (Quang Nam), B'râu people's rice transplanting festival (Kon Tum), Ba Yen Mountains bull racing festival (An Giang), Cai Rang floating market (Can Tho)... are recreated, allowing tourists to experience the vibrant atmosphere and unique cultural identity of each region.|||The ethnic village is now open to tourists, while the remaining 6 areas are under construction and completion.|||A special feature of the Vietnam National Village for Culture and Tourism is that visitors will be guided by ethnic people, the cultural subjects themselves, to discover traditional beauty and experience their cultural life.

title: Tam Dao Tourism and Golf Resort
description: Location: Tam Dao Tourism and Golf Resort is located in the Tam Dao mountain tourism area, Vinh Phuc province; 45km north of Noi Bai International Airport and 65km from Hanoi. Characteristics: Tam Dao Golf Course is an 18-hole golf course designed to ensure golfing conditions equivalent to golf courses around the world.

title: Long Doi Son Pagoda
description: Location: Long Doi Son Pagoda is located on top of Long Doi mountain, in Doi Son commune, Duy Tien district, Ha Nam province, 15km from Dong Van town (via Hoa Mac town), about 6km from National Route 1A. Characteristics: The pagoda, also known as Sung Thien Dien Linh, was built during the Ly Dynasty (around 1121), and still preserves many precious artifacts.|||The pagoda's grounds are very spacious, with its back against Diap mountain and three winding rivers encircling it. The pagoda has been renovated several times; it still retains many precious artifacts such as a bronze Laughing Buddha statue in the main hall; six stone Diamond statues, 1.60m high; a stone stele Diên Linh (built in 1121), 2.88m high, 1.40m wide and 0.29m thick, placed on a dragon-carved stone pedestal; the engravings and decorative patterns on the stele distinctly reflect the Ly Dynasty style; and four winged human statues, 40cm high and 30cm wide.

title: Nui Voi Eco-Tourism Area
description: Location: Nui Voi Eco-Tourism Area is located in Da Lat City, Lam Dong Province, about 15km from the city center. Features: Coming here, visitors will feel like living in a wild world.|||To get here, follow the road from Prenn Pass to Truc Lam Zen Monastery, then turn left a few kilometers to reach Nui Voi Eco-Tourism Area.|||The red basalt road leading to the eco-tourism area is very beautiful on sunny days, with green stones mixed in the red soil, creating a harmonious blend of primitive and modern elements. However, the road can be muddy and difficult to navigate on rainy days.|||Visitors can walk to the eco-tourism area, but it's more interesting to ride a horse or elephant. After walking about 3km into the forest, visitors will see a few stilt houses of the K'Ho ethnic group; further on, they will reach the gate of Nui Voi Eco-Tourism Area, where two elephant statues welcome them.|||Nui Voi Eco-Tourism Area covers nearly 400 hectares and is planted with many pine trees. Here, about twenty wooden houses are designed in the traditional style of the K'Ho ethnic group. A special feature of the house design is that some houses are built on the trunks of large trees, 6 to 10 meters high, with an area of about 2 people. In the vast pine forest, visitors can experience a strange feeling of living on a tree, like living in a world of birds. Despite living in a wild world, visitors can still enjoy modern amenities.|||The most romantic and interesting experience is to live here on a 'Da Lat moonlit night', in a birdhouse in the forest, visitors can admire the misty fog covering the mountains and forests, listen to the sound of streams and wind, and have a good night's sleep. When waking up, visitors will see the sunlight filtering through the green trees, and the sound of birds chirping, welcoming them to a new day… This space will be an unforgettable memory for visitors, especially those who love to explore the secrets of nature.|||For those who have been here, they will surely love nature more. Therefore, the Eco-Tourism Area is a message to visitors: 'Those who love nature and have lived in such a primitive landscape, please protect nature wholeheartedly.'

title: Thuận Tinh Eco Tourism
description: Located in Thuan Tinh (Hoi An City - Quang Nam Province), near Cua Dai Beach where Thu Bon River and Truong Giang River meet before flowing into the sea. Thuan Tinh is an islet with wooden resorts hidden among vast coconut forests, facing the river and embracing the cool breeze.|||In the spacious and airy landscape of the riverine area, there are long stretches of poplar trees and lush green grass like velvet under tourists' feet... This place is ideal for weekend outings, camping, and group activities. Following the eco-tour organized by Thuan Tinh Travel Company, visitors can take a boat trip on the river, learn about the life of fishermen or try their hand at fishing.|||Besides, tourists can also participate in community cultural events, engaging folk games such as egg balancing, om pounding... The tour departs from Da Nang at 6 am and returns at 6 pm on the same day. The package price is 100,000 VND per person.

title: Ngũ Xã Bronze Casting Village
description: Location: Near Truc Bach Lake, Ba Dinh district, Hanoi city. The village is famous for producing extremely sophisticated bronze products that meet the demand for bronze goods in the old Thang Long city.|||The Hanoi proverb says “Linh hoa Yen Thai, Bat Trang ceramics, Dinh Cong goldsmiths, Ngũ Xã bronze casters”. This phrase seems to have encapsulated all the information about some of the famous handicraft villages in the old capital city. Ngũ Xã is synonymous with the talent of Vietnamese bronze casters. Their products have been famous and representative of the national art for nearly 500 years.|||One of the most famous and highly artistic products of Ngũ Xã bronze casters is bronze bells and statues. Bells are a special musical instrument, and when struck, they must produce a clear and resonant sound. Therefore, the bell-making process, from creating the mold to mixing and pouring the bronze, must follow a strict and sophisticated process, often involving trade secrets. Bronze statues are also a famous product of Ngũ Xã, notably the Amitabha Buddha statue cast in 1952 at Than Quang Pagoda, in the village. The statue is 3.95m high, 11.6m in circumference, weighs 10 tons, and sits on a 96-petal bronze lotus. This is a magnificent, unique, and delicate bronze artwork. The statue's composition is harmonious and rational, with a serene and calm expression. The overall appearance, from the body and sitting posture to the folds of the robe, exudes a sense of tranquility and depth.|||In addition to the Amitabha Buddha statue, Ngũ Xã bronze casters have also created many other famous works, considered masterpieces of Vietnamese bronze art, such as Tran Vu statue at Quan Thanh Temple, and bronze worship objects like incense burners, bronze candle holders, and bronze cranes, which are considered precious antiques.

title: Bai Lu Sea Eco-Tourism Area
description: Location: Bai Lu Sea Eco-Tourism Area is located in Nghi Yen and Nghi Tien communes, Nghi Loc district, Nghe An province, about 20km north of Vinh city by road, and about 4km from National Highway 1A. Characteristics: This is an ideal place for tourists to rest and relax in the fresh and cool natural air.|||Bai Lu, also known as Lu Son, has a golden sand beach curving along the sea, surrounded by pine and phi lao trees swaying in the sea breeze. Some people have compared Bai Lu to a Da Lat by the sea. With an area of nearly 160ha, featuring mountains, forests, and sea, tourists coming here can not only admire the beautiful and romantic natural scenery but also rest and relax at Bai Lu Sea Eco-Tourism Area with a modern and impressive infrastructure system, leaving all fatigue in daily life behind with the sea waves and wind.|||Domestic and international tourists can reach Bai Lu by air, rail, or road. If traveling by air, tourists can take the Saigon - Vinh or Da Nang - Vinh flights of Vietnam Airlines. If traveling by train, tourists can take the unified train on the Hanoi - Saigon or Saigon - Hanoi route to get off at Vinh station. From Vinh city, following National Highway 1A about 20km north, tourists will arrive at Bai Lu. Bai Lu Sea Eco-Tourism Area was built by Bai Lu Investment Joint Stock Company and started operation in 2008 with luxurious services, attracting a large number of domestic and international tourists.
