The site features 4 and 5-star hotel areas on the hillside; high-end resorts by the sea; a beach system with 3 areas: a swimming area for teenagers, an area for adults, and a relaxation and recreation area; a restaurant with famous Asian and European dishes; a casino; a conference and meeting room; a golf course; a water music area; a swimming pool; sea games… In addition, the Company also organizes tours to explore Bai Lu and surrounding attractions for tourists.

title: Dong Da Bac Cave
description: Location: Dong Da Bac Cave is located in Lien Son commune, Luong Son district, Hoa Binh province. Characteristics: Dong Da Bac Cave is a strangely shaped artwork of nature, a fine combination of sculpture and painting, blending grandeur and vigor with elegance and romance.|||Not far from Xuan Mai town is a stunning landscape that has captivated visitors, which is Da Bac cave. With a length of nearly 70m and many small chambers, Da Bac cave holds latent values and many mysteries of nature.|||Local legend has it that, in the past, heavenly fairies, bored with their divine life, descended to earth to explore. The breathtaking scenery captivated them, and they got lost in the Da Bac Lien Son cave. The stunning beauty inside the cave left the fairies speechless and amazed, as they had never imagined such a heavenly place on earth. The shimmering stalactites and curved stone arches seemed to enthrall them.|||The Jade Emperor, upon learning of this, was furious and sealed the heavenly gates to prevent the fairies from returning. Over time, the fairies transformed into part of the mountain wall. From then on, the Da Bac cave was also known as the Fairy Cave.|||Da Bac Cave was discovered in 1990 by locals gathering firewood. Initially, the cave entrance was a small crevice that only one person could enter. The locals then expanded the entrance for easier access.|||Walking into the cave, visitors will arrive at Co Tien Cave, which has two sections. The outer section is spacious with a high ceiling, featuring many stalactites hanging down like soft, velvet curtains. Over time, water drips from the stalactites, forming two natural pools filled with water. Behind the pools is a system of tiered fields carved by nature, creating a lively and dynamic landscape.|||The inner section is small, quiet, and serene, like a bedroom. The thin, soft stone strips hanging down resemble a screen. Even this simplicity makes one feel close to nature and the stone. When tapping on the thin stone strips, sounds like drums, bronze drums, or harp music can be heard. Visitors can sit for hours, calm and focused, letting their hearts converse with the stone.|||Leaving Co Tien Cave, visitors move to Long Tien Cave, where they will see a niche with a stone rim shaped by nature like a scarf draped over a girl's shoulder.|||During the rainy season, the balcony overflows with water. Stalactites hang down from the ceiling, and stone pillars rise from the balcony floor like ancient castles under the water palace. The pillars are intricately carved. Each arch and alcove is a strange work of art that leaves visitors speechless... Long Tien Cave leads to a side exit with daylight shining in, creating a soft, neon-like glow or flickering like a virtual moonlight. After bidding farewell to Long Tien Cave, visitors turn left about ten steps to reach Mau Cave. Upon entering, one is overwhelmed by a forest of stalactites hanging down in clusters, shining with green, red, purple, and yellow rays like colorful lanterns at a festival. Under the high and wide cave ceiling, a maiden lies on a stone wall, while nearby, Thach Sanh sits under an ancient mulberry tree. In the distance, a couple sits on a boat dock, whispering to each other. On the opposite side, Saint Giong rides a metal horse, holding a sacred tree branch, soaring into the sky. Next to him, Ton Ngo Khong brandishes his magic staff, fighting monsters... The Silver Rock Cave is a strangely artistic creation of nature. It combines elegant sculpture and painting, blending grandeur and vigor with poetic charm.

title: Eco-Tourism Site Doi Su
description: Location: Doi Su eco-tourism site is located in Thuan Thanh village, Thuan Quy commune, Ham Thuuan Nam district, Binh Thuan province. Features: Fresh air, pristine and pure of mountain, forest, sea, suitable for all ages.|||This is the first eco-tourism site built under the overall planning of tourism development in Ham Thuuan Nam district. Located at a corner of the triangle of Ho Chi Minh City - Binh Duong industrial zone - Ham Thuuan Nam. Doi Su is very convenient for a weekend getaway.|||The tourism site has a total area of 14ha, of which about 10ha is phi lao forest, sand dunes, a brick road built on the sand dune called Tieu Van Ly Truong Thanh to create an ecological landscape, the remaining area is 8,000m² for infrastructure construction. Currently, Doi Su has 6 Deluxe rooms, 24 Bungalows and 10 Standard rooms fully equipped. Particularly, out of 24 Bungalows, 10 are made of wood in the style of Muong - Vietnamese stilt houses. In addition, the site has a 3,000m² conservation garden raising animals such as deer, many bird species, turkey, goose, rabbit... and many fruit trees like longan, mango, banana. Visitors can walk and take photos in the garden with animals.|||When the sun is setting, visitors can ride a sports bike or horseback to visit Khe Ga (also called Ke Ga) about 3km away - a place with a 100-year-old lighthouse. A private beach, gentle waves, no submerged rocks and whirlpools, visitors can fish, relax or enjoy the moonlight on the calm sea, beside the flickering fire.|||If desired, visitors can go along the beach for another 50km to Mui Ne (Phan Thiet) or back to Vung Tau to create a closed tourism loop. It can be said that Doi Su has awakened the potential of the pure and wild sand dune area, low and far behind the romantic phi lao forest.

title: Institute of Oceanography
description: Located at 1 Cau Da, Nha Trang City, Khanh Hoa Province, the Institute of Oceanography sits on a spacious and elevated plot of land.|||Established in 1923, it is one of Vietnam's earliest scientific research facilities and is considered Southeast Asia's largest center for marine research and artifact storage.|||Visitors can explore the Marine Life Museum, featuring over 20,000 specimens of more than 4,000 marine and freshwater species collected and preserved over the years, alongside live specimens in aquariums.|||The institute is also home to the Oceanography Museum, famous since the 1930s as the 'Nha Trang Aquarium'. Today, it is being upgraded and expanded into a complex including marine life aquariums for research, education, and community engagement.|||The museum showcases hundreds of tropical marine species and stores over 10,000 specimens from the East Vietnam Sea, including rare and endangered species like the Dugong.|||Notably, it preserves a 26m-long, 3m-high whale skeleton, buried in the Red River Delta for over 200 years.|||The museum also educates visitors about the East Vietnam Sea's natural features, valuable resources, and marine environments, promoting conservation awareness.|||Recently, the Institute was voted one of the top 10 cultural and historical tourist attractions, achieving the 'Satisfactory Tourist Destination 2005' title.|||In the near future, the Institute will inaugurate a high-tech marine life acclimation zone to support Vietnam's marine economic development policy.

title: Dakrong Scenic Spot
description: Location: Dakrong District, Quang Tri Province. Characteristics: It is a common name for an area with majestic and romantic natural scenery in the western mountains of Quang Tri.|||This scenic spot features the beautiful Dakrong River, which hides within it mythologies and epic legends, a graceful Dakrong Bridge amidst vast skies, clouds, rivers, water, and forests, and valuable natural mineral water sources.|||This place is also a crucial junction of the Ho Chi Minh Highway and National Highway 9, the trans-Asian road through the Lao Bao - Densavan international border gate.

title: Quyet Mountain Tourist Area
description: Location: The Quyet Mountain tourist area is located at the foot of Quyet Mountain, Vinh City, Nghe An Province. Features: On the way from the South to the North through Ben Thuy ferry, looking to the west, there is a small mountain range, which is Quyet mountain with lush pine trees. It has become the Quyet mountain forest park, a new type of tourist destination in Nghe An Province.|||The Quyet Mountain tourist area covers an area of nearly 160ha (mountain area 56ha) and consists of several sub-zones: hotels and guesthouses in the southwest, looking out to the Lam River are mini bungalow hotels and a cultural village; an entertainment zone with a swimming pool, water slide, aquarium, water puppet theater, cinema, camping site, sports ground, and especially a tourist cable car over the Lam River connecting Nghe An and Ha Tinh provinces; a service zone with supermarkets, boat houses, parking lots...; a historical site zone with ancient citadel, stele house...|||In 1998, on the 210th anniversary of Phuong Hoang Trung Do Vinh, the city completed a 5km road system around the mountain, a flag tower on the peak and a stele house. Quyet Mountain originally had a 'dragon ly quy phoenix' position but truly has a prominent location when Quang Trung - Nguyen Hue chose it as the capital: 'Recalling the previous journey, when passing Hoanh Son, I had viewed the map and seen that in Chan Loc district, Yen Truong commune (Quyet Mountain - Ben Thuy), the terrain is spacious, with bright atmosphere... it is really a beautiful place to build the capital...' (quoted from Nguyen Hue's letter to La Son Phu Tu Nguyen Thiep on September 3, 11th year of Thai Duc, ie. October 1, 1788).|||Nguyen Hue built a citadel and palace here. Phuong Hoang Trung Do was built between Quyet Mountain and Ky Lan Mountain (Meo mountain), now there are remains of a triangular citadel. That is the inner citadel, with a perimeter of 1680m and a three-story dragon tower. The outer citadel is shaped like a trapezoid, with a perimeter of 2820m. From the citadel, you can see the Lam River, Vinh Doanh River and Le canal winding through Hung Nguyen and Nam Dan fields. Heading east, you can see Ngư Island, Mat Island, adjacent to the eight beautiful scenes of Nghi Xuan (Nghi Xuan eight scenic spots). From the foot of Quyet Mountain, visitors can take a boat trip down the Lam River to Hung Hoa bird sanctuary, or navigate through the primeval forest or up the La River, a river of nostalgia to Huong Son, Duc Tho...

title: Van Sat Eco-Tourism Area
description: Van Sat tourist area is located within the Can Gio mangrove forest biosphere reserve in Ly Nhon town. Here, visitors can immerse themselves in a fascinating natural world and experience many exciting recreational activities.|||The road to Van Sat tourist area is very easy and convenient. Visitors can get here by road or waterway. With a large area and rich mangrove ecosystem, visitors can observe and learn about the life of many rare animals and plants.|||The bat sanctuary is an interesting place to visit for those who like to explore wildlife. The bat has a large body, yellow belly, and a wingspan of up to 1 meter, eating only fruit and being a rare bat in the world. Sitting in silence on a small wooden boat, gently paddling through the mangroves, watching the sleeping bats clinging to the branches gives a feeling of peace and excitement.|||Crossing the mangrove forest is to reach the bird sanctuary with millions of birds, including rare species such as Giang Sen, Gia Day, Cong Coc, and Diec. It's even more interesting if visitors come here from April to October when birds come here to breed. From a 25m high watchtower, visitors can admire the vast green forest and observe the lively life of birds. To explore deeper, visitors can move on a boat through the forest to get closer to the bird nests.|||Exploring the crocodile swamp is also an experience not to be missed. Crocodiles in Van Sat are raised in a semi-wild model. Visitors can experience a thrilling boat tour with iron cage protection, bringing unique and unforgettable impressions. Visiting the crocodile swamp, visitors can also encounter a group of long-tailed monkeys.|||In addition to exploring nature, recreational activities make the trip more interesting, such as fishing, crab catching, playing soccer on the swamp, catching fish, walking on the suspension bridge, riding a bike on rough terrain... Visitors can organize group outdoor activities, set up tents, organize overnight camping or stay overnight at the Van Sat accommodation. A night sleeping in the pure and pristine nature will be an unforgettable memory.|||Restaurants in Van Sat tourist area also have many delicious dishes, typical of the local cuisine, for visitors to enjoy, such as: 3 dishes of Van Sat duck (roasted duck, duck salad with forest vegetables, duck porridge), steamed shrimp crab, grilled mussels with butter, grilled fish with salt and chili, spicy snail soup, grilled fish in paper...|||Exploring the fascinating nature, immersing in memorable experiences, enjoying the fresh air, putting aside the worries of life, family, friends, colleagues are warmer... are the things that linger in the hearts of visitors after an interesting journey to Van Sat.

title: An Dinh Palace
description: Location: 97 Phan Dinh Phung street, Hue city, Thua Thien - Hue province. Features: A structure within the Hue Imperial City complex, recognized by UNESCO as a World Cultural Heritage site.|||An Dinh Palace was originally named Phu Phung Hoa, built by King Dong Khanh (1886 - 1889) in the early 20th century on the banks of the An Cuu river as a gift for Prince Nguyen Phuc Buu Dao. In 1917, Prince Buu Dao, now King Khai Dinh (1916 - 1925), rebuilt the palace and renamed it An Dinh Palace. In 1922, following King Khai Dinh's wishes, An Dinh Palace was given to Prince Vinh Thuy, later King Bao Dai (1926 - 1945). After the August Revolution in 1945, the former royal family of Bao Dai moved from the Imperial City to live in An Dinh Palace. In 1955, Ngo Dinh Diem, after becoming President of the Republic of Vietnam, confiscated An Dinh Palace and used it as a residence for local government officials. After 1975, An Dinh Palace was handed over to the revolutionary government.|||An Dinh Palace covers an area of nearly 24,000m² and is surrounded by a solid brick wall system. From the outside in, An Dinh Palace consists of: boat dock, main gate, Trung Lap pavilion, flower garden, Khai Tuong tower, Nhu Tu Dai theater, animal pens, two transverse houses, ornamental gardens and a lake, and finally the rear gate. Among them, the most prominent are the main gate, Trung Lap pavilion and Khai Tuong tower.|||The main gate of An Dinh Palace is built in the tam quan style with two floors. The roof peak of the upper floor is decorated with a large pearl symbol. The entire gate is decorated with ceramic, glass and traditional Vietnamese motifs. Notably, the Chinese characters naming the palace and the couplets at the gate are all made from colorful ceramic pieces in a unique way.|||Through the main gate is the Trung Lap communal house with an octagonal structure and a two-layered roof in the ancient tower style. The lower roof has 8 sides and the upper one has 4 sides. The 12 raised ridges of the roof are decorated with 12 dragons and on the top is a chipped heavenly pond. Previously, a bronze statue of King Khai Dinh was placed inside, cast in 1920. However, by 1960, the statue had been moved to the Khai Dinh tomb. At the communal house corners, there are statues of the Eight Immortals with very lively depictions.|||Behind Trung Lap communal house and flower garden lies Khai Tuong tower, a building with a distinct Western architectural style, covering an area of nearly 750m². The entire facade of the building is elaborately decorated with modern Roman architectural motifs (such as the etoile and angels) intertwined with traditional Eastern decorative themes (dragons, phoenixes, eight precious items, stylized flowers…).|||The Khai Tuong tower consists of three floors: the first floor has seven rooms, with the most prominent being the living room featuring six oil paintings directly drawn on the walls depicting the tombs of Gia Long, Minh Mang, Thieu Tri, Tu Duc, Dong Khanh and Khai Dinh.|||The second floor has eight rooms used for activities and rest.|||The third floor has three large and four small rooms used for worship.|||Right after the Khai Tuong building, visitors will see the foundation of the Cuu Tu Dai theater. This was where Tuong and Cai Luong performances were held for the Royal Family during the reign of King Bao Dai. After the 2003 archaeological excavation, the appearance of the theater was reconstructed. It was a building with an area of about 1,500m² and a capacity for over 500 spectators, consisting of 2 floors: the 1st floor was the stage and surrounding audience seats, the 2nd floor was a private viewing area for the King and special guests.|||An Dinh Palace marks the period when Vietnamese art began to be influenced by Western styles. The architectural works in An Dinh Palace combine traditional Vietnamese decorative motifs with European ones, creating a unique architectural picture.|||In mid-2008, Long An Hall, where the main artifacts of the Hue Imperial Court Museum are displayed, was restored and renovated, so the artifacts were moved to An Dinh Palace for display until now. This place has become an attractive address for tourists who want to learn about Vietnam's national cultural heritage through unique and impressive collections of ancient artifacts.

title: Binh Quoi Tourist Village
description: Location: Binh Quoi Tourist Village is located on Thanh Da peninsula by the Saigon River, 8km from Ho Chi Minh City center. Features: With its unique river and water landscape, this is the largest integrated tourist area in Ho Chi Minh City.|||Here, there are 55 modern rooms, hidden under shady trees along the river. The restaurant is a trusted address for parties, receptions and is famous for grilled dishes and Vietnamese specialties. Every night, the tourist area has unique folk art programs: "Ky Yen Festival", "Southern amateur music on Ghe Hau", "traditional Vietnamese wedding", folk music... These programs have attracted many domestic and international tourists. Here, tourists can also participate in surfing, fishing, tennis, swimming, and many other sports.|||From Binh Quoi, tourists can take a boat trip along the Saigon River to visit Ben Duc tunnel, Lai Thieu fruit garden or to Nha Rong port...

title: Mạc Cửu Tomb Historical Site
description: Location: On Mac Cuu street, at the foot of Binh San mountain, Binh San ward, Ha Tien town, Kien Giang province, about 92km northwest of Rach Gia city. Characteristics: This historical site honors the Mac family, starting with Mr. Mac Cuu, who pioneered the development of Ha Tien.|||Mac Cuu was from Guangdong, China, but left his homeland because he refused to cut his hair and follow some Qing dynasty customs. He went to trade in Southeast Asia. In 1680, when he arrived in Ha Tien, he stopped and decided to build up the area. On August 1708, seeing the strong position of the Nguyen Lords in expanding their territory to the South, Mac Cuu offered Ha Tien to the Nguyen and was accepted by Nguyen Phuc Chu. He was then appointed as Tong Tran Ha Tien.|||Although he gave Ha Tien to the Nguyen, Nguyen Phuc Chu still allowed Mac Cuu to govern the area autonomously, maintaining the tradition of hereditary rule like a small king. Seven generations of the Mac family worked to make Ha Tien an important trade hub for Dai Viet with neighboring countries.|||The relic includes a temple dedicated to the Mac family and a tomb. The temple is located at the foot of Binh San mountain, built by the Nguyen dynasty to commemorate the contributions of the Mac family in developing Ha Tien. In front of the temple are two large ponds full of lotus flowers, which were previously dug by Mac Cuu to provide fresh water for the local people during dry seasons. On either side of the temple gate are two couplets in Han Nom characters, gifted by the Nguyen dynasty.||||||The first gate of loyalty and righteousness is precious|||Seven Leaf Korean Drama Petite Vinh|||Temporary translation:|||A righteous house brings honor to the entire family|||Seven screens of foliage shield it, and the whole nation adores it|||Inside the gate is a spacious yard with many trees that create a serene and quiet atmosphere all year round.|||On the right of the temple is the Tien Hien house, which honors those who arrived in Ha Tien before Mr. Mac Cuu. On the left is the Hau Hien house, which honors those who arrived later.|||The main hall features an altar dedicated to Mr. Mac Cuu and his descendants, who are revered as minor royalty in Ha Tien.|||On the right is an altar for the mandarins and military officers from the Mac dynasty. On the left is an altar for the ladies of the Mac family.|||Follow a staircase path up Binh San Mountain and visitors will reach the tomb area with over 60 ancient tombs divided into 4 separate sections: section 1 is for the tombs of the Mạc family princes, section 2 for the tombs of the princesses, section 3 for the tombs of mandarins, and section 4 for the tombs of other Mạc family members.|||The tomb of Mạc Cửu is located at the highest position in section 1, shaped like a semicircle and carved deep into the mountain.|||The tomb is built according to feng shui principles, with its back against the mountain and its face towards the sea, and two stone generals standing guard on either side.|||When building the tomb for his father, Mạc Cửu's eldest son, Mạc Thiên Tích, brought stones from Malaysia to pave the tomb.|||On top of Binh San mountain is the Xa Tac altar, where the people of Ha Tien used to and still perform rituals to heaven and earth. The Xa Tac altar foundation has a large red octagonal diagram, black in the middle, and a yellow center, on which a large bronze incense burner is placed. On the 15th day of the 1st lunar month every year, different altars are set up for worship, but the worship time varies from year to year.|||Binh San Mountain was recognized as a national scenic spot by the Ministry of Culture and Information on January 21, 1989.|||To commemorate Mạc Cửu's contributions to the development of Hà Tiên and the 300th anniversary of the region's establishment, the People's Committee of Kien Giang Province organized the inauguration of a 10m high monument of Mạc Cửu on September 7, 2008, at the square next to To Chau bridge in Ha Tien town.

title: Suoi Hoa Lan Eco-Tourism Site
description: Location: Suoi Hoa Lan Eco-Tourism Site, also known as Suoi Tu Si, is located in Ninh Phu commune, Ninh Hoa district, Khanh Hoa province, about 18km north of Nha Trang city. Features: Here, visitors can admire the natural beauty of the sea and breathe the fresh air of the forest and waterfalls.|||Suoi Hoa Lan is not only a place of stunning natural scenery but also bears the mark of the Cham people who once lived here and was a revolutionary base during the two long wars of the nation.|||The pristine beauty that nature has bestowed upon Suoi Hoa Lan will provide visitors with an interesting day of outings, campfires, cultural performances, and enjoying rice wine.

title: Den Do Temple
description: Location: Den Do is located in Dinh Bang village, Dinh Bang commune, Tu Son town, Bac Ninh province. Characteristics: This is the worship place of 8 Ly dynasty kings. They are: Ly Cong Uan aka Ly Thai To (1009 - 1028); Ly Thai Tong (1028 - 1054); Ly Thanh Tong (1054 - 1072); Ly Nhan Tong (1072 - 1128); Ly Than Tong (1128 - 1138); Ly Anh Tong (1138 - 1175); Ly Cao Tong (1175 - 1210) and Ly Hue Tong (1210 - 1224).|||Do Temple, also known as Co Phap Temple or Ly Bat De Temple, was built in the 11th century (1030), on the southeastern land of Huong Co Phap, Chau Co Phap (Dinh Bang village). This land is considered by Zen master Ly Van Hanh to be where the heavenly breath gathers, with the terrain resembling 8 dragon heads facing inward. Legend has it that in the past, in front of the temple was a Banh forest, with the winding Tieu Tuong stream flowing through.|||When King Ly Cong Uan passed away (1028), Ly Thai Tong inherited the throne from his father. He renovated the old house and chose it as a place to worship his father. From then on, the temple became a place to worship the kings of the Ly dynasty after they passed away.|||The temple was built on a piece of land. When King Ly Cong Uan was crowned and returned to visit his hometown in the 2nd month of the Canh Tuat year (1010), he stopped his royal boat to visit the elderly, pay respects to the queen mother, and measured dozens of miles of land to create the 'Son Lang forbidden area'.|||The people of Dinh Bang village built a large house to welcome the king.|||Through the Ly, Tran, and Le dynasties, Do Temple was continuously restored and expanded.|||It was expanded the most in the 17th century (1602) with 21 construction items arranged in the 'inner Vietnamese, outer foreign' style, surrounded by a wall.|||The temple's architecture combines imperial and folk styles, with intricate carvings, showcasing a majestic yet harmonious structure in a natural setting.|||In 1952, Do Temple was occupied by the French and completely destroyed. Since 1989, thanks to the care of the Party and State, the efforts of the people of Dinh Bang and the contributions of people from all over, Do Temple has been gradually restored to its original appearance from the 1602 renovation and expansion, featuring: Rear Palace (80m²), Bamboo House (80m²), Sedan Chair House (130m²), Horse Stables (130m²), Floating Pavilion, Square Pavilion...|||Based on the vestiges, documents and reconstructed works, we can imagine the overall architecture of Den Do as follows:|||Den Do covers an area of 31,250m², featuring 21 major and minor structures. The center is the main hall, where the tablets and statues of the Eight Ly Dynasty kings are enshrined. Surrounding buildings include the Bồng communal house, Tiền tế house, Phương Đình house, sedan chair house, horse stable, Thủy Đình house... The architecture of Den Do is divided into inner and outer city areas.|||The interior includes the following structures: The Rear Palace - where the throne and ceremonial tablets of the eight Ly Dynasty kings are kept (Ly Thai To, Ly Thai Tong, Ly Thanh Tong, Ly Than Tong, Ly Anh Tong, Ly Cao Tong and Ly Hue Tong). The Chuyen Bong House has an eight-roofed architecture with gently curved eaves. There are also a stele house, a horse stable, a palanquin house... all built with meticulous care and intricate carvings.||||||The inner city covers an area of 4,320m², arranged in the style of 'inner Vietnamese, outer foreign', surrounded by a 3m high and 1m wide brick wall (brick on both sides, soil in the middle) with two entrances. The inner city is divided into Inner and Outer sections.|||The exterior includes a square building with an eight-gabled roof in the overlapping tile style, featuring 8 curved and softened eaves. This area comprises the main hall, storage rooms, guest house, and the temple dedicated to the queens (worshiping the empresses of the Ly Dynasty).|||Den Do boasts stunning architecture with unique designs, artistic value, and picturesque scenery.|||It holds significant historical and cultural value of the Ly Dynasty and Vietnamese history.|||Den Do lives up to its praise.|||Thang Long is the most beautiful, with a thousand years of beautiful people|||The historical and cultural relic site of Den Do has been recognized by the State and ranked as a national historical and cultural relic according to Decision No. 154 dated 25/01/1991 of the Ministry of Culture and Information.

title: My Son Cultural Heritage
description: Location: My Son is located in Duy Phu commune, Duy Xuyen district, Quang Nam province, about 70km southwest of Da Nang city, and about 10km west of Tra Kieu in a secluded valley. Features: My Son is a Hindu sanctuary of the Champa Kingdom. The main temples in My Son worship a set of Linga or the image of Siva - The protector of the Champa kings.|||The inscriptions on the earliest epigraphs at My Son, dated to around the 4th century, mention King Bhadresvara building a temple to worship god Siva. Bhadravarman built a temple dedicated to Siva. Over two centuries later, the first temple made of wood was destroyed in a great fire.|||At the beginning of the 7th century, King Sambhuvarman rebuilt the temple using more durable materials, which still exist today. Subsequent dynasties restored old temples and built new ones to dedicate to their gods. With over 70 architectural structures made of stone and brick, built from the 4th to the 13th century, My Son became the most important architectural center of the Champa Kingdom. The deity worshiped in My Son is Bhadravarman, the king who founded the first royal line of Amaravati at the end of the 4th century, combined with the god Siva, becoming the main worship of the god-king and royal ancestor.|||In 1898, the My Son sanctuary was discovered by a French scholar named M.C Paris. At the beginning of the 20th century, two researchers from the French Far East, L.Finot and L.de Lajonquière, and the architect and archaeologist H. Parmentier came to My Son to study the inscriptions and the art of Cham architecture and sculpture.|||By 1903-1904, L.Finot officially published the basic documents on the inscriptions and architectural art of My Son.|||The precursor to this ancient architectural complex in My Son, according to remaining inscriptions, was a wooden temple dedicated to the god Siva Bhadravarman. However, towards the end of the 6th century, a fire burned down the wooden temple. The historical veil has been gradually lifted by scientists through inscriptions and historical records from various dynasties, revealing that My Son was the most important sacred site of the Cham people from the end of the 4th century to the 15th century. Using baked clay bricks and sandstone, the Cham people constructed a unique and interconnected complex of temples and towers over several centuries. The main temple enshrines the Linga-Yoni, a symbol of creative power. Adjacent to the main tower (Kalan) are other towers dedicated to various gods or deified kings. Although time and war have reduced many towers to ruins, the surviving artifacts and architectural remains still showcase the artistic styles of different historical periods of the Cham people, representing masterpieces that highlight the glorious era of Champa's culture and architecture, as well as that of Southeast Asia.|||Each historical period, the architecture bears its own unique style, just like each temple and tower worships different gods and kings, creating a distinctive architectural style. However, in general, Cham towers are built on a quadrilateral base, divided into 3 parts: The base of the tower represents the earthly world, solid and firm. The body of the tower is a symbol of the divine world, mystical and enchanting. The top part is often in the shape of people offering flowers and fruits in rituals, or leaves, birds, elephants, lions... animals that are close to religion and human life.|||According to researchers of ancient Cham towers, the architecture of Cham towers in My Son converges many styles; continuously from the ancient style of the 7th century to the 8th century; Hoa Lai style from the 8th to the 9th century; Dong Duong style from the mid-9th century; My Son style and transition between My Son and Binh Dinh; Binh Dinh style... Among the remaining architectural works when discovered (1898), there was a tower as high as 24m, in the area of Chua Tower, which archaeology books and research on My Son refer to as the ancient Champa tower, with 2 entrances to the East and West. The tower body is high and slender with a system of attached columns. Around it are 6 subsidiary towers, the whole tower complex spreads out like a lotus flower. The upper floor, the sandstone spire is carved with images of elephants and lions; the lower floor, the wall surface features people riding elephants and images of heavenly female water monsters. However, this valuable tower was destroyed by the US air force during the war in 1969. After discovering the ancient My Son tower complex, many typical artifacts, especially the dancing girls statues, deities worshiped by the Cham people, worshiped animals as well as community life scenes, were brought to Da Nang city and placed at the Cham Sculpture Museum. Although not many, these artifacts are representative works of sculpture art, they carry the cultural value of an ethnic group, but more than that, they are living and authentic historical testimonies of one of the ethnic groups in the rich cultural tradition community of Vietnam.|||My Son Sanctuary was restored by EFEO (Ecole Francaise d'Extreme Orient) from 1937 to 1944, but the site suffered severe damage from American bombing during the war. By 1975, out of 32 remaining monuments, only about 20 temples and towers still retained their original appearance. From 1981 to 1991, My Son Sanctuary underwent preservation and partial restoration with technical assistance from P.K.Z (Poland). Most of the sculptures from My Son were collected by the French and moved to Da Nang in the early 20th century and are now on display at the Cham Museum. My Son Sanctuary was recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in December 1999.

title: Den Nghe Temple
description: Location: An Bien Ward, Le Chan District, Hai Phong City, about 600m from Hai Phong City Theater. Features: A cultural and spiritual tourism site with notable wood and stone carvings.|||Den Nghe Temple worships Lady Le Chan, a brilliant female general from the 1st century (40-43) during the Hai Ba Trung uprising. She arrived at the Tam Bac - Cam River confluence, established Ven Village, later renamed An Bien Trang, the predecessor of today's Hai Phong. Legend has it that when Lady Le Chan drowned herself in the river, her body turned into stone and floated on the water. The stone was then brought to and worshiped at the temple.|||The temple was initially a small shrine with a thatched roof. From 1919 to 1926, it was rebuilt and expanded with additional architectural features. After restoration and preservation efforts, Den Nghe Temple is now a complex of historical sites with 20th-century Nguyen Dynasty architecture, including a tam quan gate, a main hall, a bái đường, a thiêu hương house, and a stone stele house.|||The main hall features a 3-room structure with a two-story roof, housing a large statue of Lady Le Chan. The bái đường has 5 rooms supported by 16 lim wood columns, with a large Han Chinese character inscription.|||Visitors can admire the unique architectural complex and valuable stone carvings, including a stone khánh and a stone sập. The stone khánh produces a clear, resonant sound when struck.|||Near the temple is a 7.5m-high, 19-ton bronze statue of Lady Le Chan, built in 1999-2000.|||Den Nghe Temple was recognized as a national historical and cultural site in 1975.

title: Tam Thanh Beach
description: Location: Tam Thanh Beach is 7km east of Tam Ky City, Quang Nam Province. Characteristics: Tam Thanh Beach is always full of sunshine and waves, making it an attractive destination for tourists during summer vacations.

title: Bang Ta Natural Forest Tourist Area
description: Location: Bang Ta natural forest tourist area is located on a low hill, in Ba Vi district, Hanoi, 14km away from Au Vua tourist site and 3.8km from Suoi Hai lake. Characteristics: With a rich collection of flora and fauna, Bang Ta is not only a tourist attraction but also a place for conservation, restoration of diverse ecosystems and wildlife research.|||The total area of the tourist area is 26.5ha, of which the primeval forest area is over 17ha.|||Bang Ta is a primeval forest with 4 layers of trees closing the canopy. According to the survey results on ecology and biological resources by the Vietnam Institute of Geography, there are 387 plant species belonging to 252 genera, 94 families of 4 high plant divisions. Regarding animals in Bang Ta forest and surrounding areas, there are 13 mammal species belonging to 7 families, 4 typical orders such as rodents, bats, civets, tree squirrels... There are 69 bird species belonging to 37 families and 13 orders. Currently, Bang Ta has diving birds, cranes, falcons, storks, pigeons, cuckoos, weavers, woodpeckers, sparrows and butterflies... In the primeval forest, there are over 200 monkeys, living in groups...|||When visiting Bang Ta primeval forest, tourists can rent buffalo-drawn carts, ride horses or walk but are not allowed to travel by motorized vehicles. This is a unique feature of this tourist area. In the future, this forest will be planted with many rare orchid species such as golden orchid, terrestrial orchid, slipper orchid..., and semi-natural breeding of some animal species such as deer, roe deer, wild boar, sambar deer, tiger, leopard, bear, primate... so that tourists can observe and learn about the life of wild animals.|||To the north of the forest is Long dam, a large and vast lake that has been upgraded to sen (lotus) ponds, creating an attractive natural environment. Long dam is the habitat of animals and reptiles such as the Asian water monitor, Bim Bip, gecko, lizard, water snake, python... After visiting the primeval forest, tourists can take a boat trip around the dam, go fishing or row a boat to the floating houses in the dam... Around the Long dam are bamboo groves where birds come to roost and nest.|||Visiting Bang Ta, tourists will have the opportunity to breathe the fresh air, stroll with their favorite animals, enjoy specialties of Ba Vi mountain forest or visit a village of Muong ethnic group with stilt houses and dynamic cultural activities such as campfires, drinking rice wine, listening to folk music and dance... If anyone needs a picnic, they will be provided with tents and mats, and guided on setting up a campsite and having a campfire. In this tourist area, a rural market is built to serve as a cultural exchange venue for ethnic groups, selling handicrafts, serving cultural specialties and cuisine... From Bang Ta, tourists can easily connect with nearby tourist sites such as Au Vua, Ngoc Nhi stork garden, Suoi Hai lake...

title: Thiencam Mountain
description: Located in Cam Xuyen district, Ha Tinh province, about 20km from Ha Tinh city. The mountain is situated by the sea, creating a beautiful landscape, and is a popular tourist destination in Ha Tinh|||The mountain is about 20km from Ha Tinh city. It's not tall and lies beside the sea, forming a scenic spot. Near the foot of the mountain is Yen Lac pagoda, built in the 13th century, a ranked historical site with the famous 'Ten Courts of Yanwang' mural.|||Since the early 20th century, the French had built a resort in Thiencam, but it was destroyed during the war. Today, Thiencam has become a popular tourist spot.

title: Sapp Mountain Tourist Area
description: Location: The Sapp Mountain tourist area is located in Thoai Son district, An Giang province, about 26km from Long Xuyen city. Features: Previously, Sapp Mountain had the shape of a rabbit lying down beside vast green rice fields stretching to the horizon. Over time, the mountain was deformed into colorful shapes, painting a mystical mountainous landscape.|||The western slope of Sapp Mountain has one of the most famous scenic spots in Thoai Son mountain range: lake No. 1, lake No. 2, and Ong Thoai lake, connected by tunnels through the mountain and Sapp Mountain cave. These three lakes were only created a few years ago when locals excavated the foot of the mountain to create unique stone products.|||Visitors can take a boat to admire the majestic beauty of the high mountains, deep caves, and blue lakes with swimming fish. To highlight the beauty of the lakes, the management board of Sapp Mountain tourist area has erected stone statues around the lakes and small islands, including the Goddess Siva, Po Nagar tower, Linga, Yony..., carved by artisans from Ngu Hanh Son, Da Nang.|||A system of roads to the top of the mountain has been expanded, offering a thrilling experience with fresh air and a panoramic view of Thi Tran Nui Sapp town, vast rice fields, and a mesmerizing white smoke landscape during the burning season.

title: Ham Rong Historical and Cultural Relic Site
description: Location: Ham Rong ward, Thanh Hoa city, Thanh Hoa province. Features: This is a place name associated with the glorious Ham Rong victory in history.|||With a total area of 568ha, the Ham Rong historical and cultural relic site includes famous landscapes, revolutionary historical sites and spiritual cultural works such as: Ham Rong Bridge, Ham Rong Mountain, Tien Son Cave, Long Quang Cave, Ngoc Mountain, Canh Tien Mountain, Temple of the Mother of Vietnam and heroes of Thanh Hoa province, Truc Lam Ham Rong Zen monastery, Dong Son ancient village...|||The first image that comes to mind when recalling the historic Ham Rong victory is Ham Rong bridge spanning the Ma River, about 5km north of Thanh Hoa city center. The bridge was built in 1904 in the style of a modern steel arch bridge, the most advanced in Indochina at that time. On April 3 and 4, 1965, the military and people of Thanh Hoa bravely fought, shot down 47 enemy planes, captured many pilots, and protected the bridge and ensured smooth traffic, contributing to the complete victory of the national resistance war against America. After being attacked several times, Ham Rong bridge still stands proudly, leaning against Ham Rong mountain, reflecting on the Ma River, becoming a symbol of the strong will, indomitable spirit, and patriotism of the people of Thanh Hoa.|||Ham Rong Mountain (or Long Ham Mountain) stretches approximately 2km from Duong Xa village, Thieu Duong commune, Thieu Hoa district, following the right bank of the Ma River to the foot of Ham Rong Bridge. The mountain has a winding, gentle shape resembling a 9-knot dragon, with the final section featuring a high peak with stacked rocks that look like the mouth of a dragon bending down to drink from the Ma River.|||This unique geography has turned the area into a solid air defense stronghold, contributing to the legend of the glorious Ham Rong victory in history.|||The Ham Rong mountain range not only holds a strategic position in combat, but also boasts a majestic landscape surrounded by rolling hills of pine and picturesque valleys. Notably, the mountain is home to the Long Quang and Tien Son caves, featuring unique and captivating beauty that attracts many visitors.|||The Long Quang cave, also known as the Dragon Eye cave, has two entrances on either side, resembling the eyes of a dragon. The area outside the cave is very spacious. Standing at the cave entrance, visitors can gaze out at the breathtaking view of Thanh Hoa city, nestled between majestic mountains and the winding Ma River, which appears to be embracing the Dragon Mountain.|||With its poetic and lyrical scenery, the Long Quang cave has long been a magnet for poets and scholars, including Nguyen Trai, Le Thanh Tong, Cao Ba Quat, and Pham Su Manh.|||The stone walls inside the cave still preserve many ancient Chinese poems from the Hậu Lê dynasty, praising the beauty of the Rong mountain and Ma river.|||Follow the footpath around Ham Rong mountain, going up about 30m on stone steps, visitors will reach Tien Son cave. The cave consists of 3 main caves: cave 1, cave 2 and cave 3, connected by small passageways. Here, visitors can admire the primordial stone formations in various shapes, such as the Jade Emperor, fairies, thunder god, lightning god, flying dragon, dancing phoenix...|||The cave also features unique areas like the peach garden, aquarium, hell, sky gate, fairy well... making visitors feel like they are in a fairy-tale world with a legendary atmosphere.|||Facing Dragon Head Mountain, on the northern bank of the Ma River, is Ngoc Mountain, also known as Chau Phong Mountain. From a distance, the shapes of Ham Rong and Ngoc mountains resemble a dragon playing with a jewel. Next to it is Canh Tien Mountain, where a artillery battery was once stationed to protect Ham Rong Bridge. Today, on the mountain slope, two words 'Quyet Thang' are engraved, affirming the tradition of brave and resilient fighting of Thanh region's military and people.|||Located on Canh Tien Mountain, the temple dedicated to the Heroic Mother of Vietnam and the martyrs of Thanh Hoa province is a spiritual destination not to be missed when visiting the Ham Rong historical and cultural relic site. The temple stands out not only for its grandiose scale and harmonious blend of traditional and modern architecture but also for its profound significance as a tribute from the people of Thanh Hoa to the mothers and martyrs who sacrificed their lives for the peace of their homeland today. Covering a total planned area of 15ha, the temple complex includes notable architectural features such as the Tam Quan gate, four-pillar gate, semi-circular lake, main temple, bell tower, and memorial stele. The temple is surrounded by a stone wall system, lotus bud-shaped pillars, and a staircase leading up and down. Inside the temple, the memorial area is adorned with intricate patterns, lacquered and gilded. At the back of the temple, a striking 9-storey bell tower rises with an ethereal, mystical beauty.||||||With a total area of 40,000m2, Thien Vien Truc Lam Ham Rong is located on hill C4 and is one of the unique cultural and spiritual works in the Ham Rong historical and cultural relic site.|||This is a place for Buddhists to come and study, as well as a venue for conversations and sermons for people of all walks of life.|||The construction includes main architectural works such as: Tam Quan gate, Tam Bao, ancestor worship house, bell tower, drum tower, monk's quarters, vegetarian hall, monk's guest house, sutra lecture hall, meditation hall, boat dock and other auxiliary works.|||Continuing the journey to explore the historical and cultural relic site of Ham Rong, visitors will come to the ancient Dong Son village located on the south bank of the Ma River, with its back against the Ham Rong mountain range. Dong Son village has a typical rural structure, with a large and fertile field in front, a bustling riverbank with boats and ships; the village is surrounded by hills, mountains and rocks. With a history of formation dating back thousands of years, the ancient Dong Son village still retains its traditional gate, communal house and dozens of ancient houses with mossy walls along the winding roads paved with bricks and stones.|||The village is also home to a system of unique tangible and intangible cultural heritage, including many historical sites related to religious and spiritual life such as the Temple of Duc Thanh Ca, Phu Mau, Mieo Nhi, Am Van Pagoda, Bo De Pagoda, Văn chi, Vo chi, Trung communal house, temple of the Le dynasty, house of Ba, "Tuong Son bi ky" stone stele...|||Particularly, the cultural artifacts discovered from the ancient Dong Son village, such as farming tools, weapons, pottery, jewelry and Dong Son bronze drums with intricate patterns, have shown that since the time of Van Lang, Dong Son has been an important agricultural village in the region. In the early 20th century, Dong Son became the name of a famous archaeological culture, the Dong Son culture, and the Dong Son bronze drum became a symbol of the talent and creativity of ancient Vietnamese people in the early stages of building human civilization.|||With its glorious historical pages and majestic landscape of a mountainous region, Ham Rong historical and cultural relic site will be an enduring monument throughout the nation's history.

title: Thap Ba Hot Spring Tourism Center Nha Trang
description: Located at 15 Ngoc Son, Ngoc Hiep, about 4km north of Nha Trang city center.|||This is a unique healthcare service with diverse options for visitors to choose from.|||Situated behind the ancient Thap Ba Ponagar tower, the 3ha tourism center is surrounded by mountains, rivers, eucalyptus forests, fruit trees and natural flowers.|||Thap Ba Hot Spring Nha Trang proudly shares this invaluable natural gift, adding a new color to the tourism picture of Nha Trang - Khanh Hoa - Vietnam.|||Nowadays, mud bathing is recognized worldwide as an effective natural therapy for health and skin beauty. It not only serves relaxation but also treats joint diseases, gout, skin diseases, and neurological disorders.|||The services at Thap Ba Hot Spring are constantly upgraded and diversified so that visitors can choose suitable services and enjoy wonderful natural care.

title: National Convention Center
description: Location: At the intersection of Pham Hung and Tran Duy Hung streets, 10 km southwest of Hanoi city center. Features: It is considered one of the three largest convention centers in Southeast Asia today.|||The National Convention Center is located on an area of 64 hectares. This is a venue for major conferences and meetings of the Party, State, socio-political organizations, international conferences, political, social, economic, trade, fairs and exhibitions... of national and international significance.|||The National Convention Center was designed based on the landscape idea of Ha Long Bay cultural heritage with the design plan named "East Sea Waves" by German expert Dr. Meinhard Von Gerkar. This modern work has a main building of 5 floors and 1 basement floor, started construction in November 2004 and completed in September 2006 to serve the 14th APEC high-level meeting.|||In front of the building is a nearly 10,000m² square that harmoniously combines natural elements like gardens, green trees, grass, and climate-regulating lakes with convenient traffic. There is a floating parking lot and an underground garage system with a capacity for nearly 1,100 cars of all types. The underground garage system alone can accommodate over 500 vehicles. Additionally, a helipad and outdoor stage are also located here. Apart from the national grid, the center is also equipped with a backup power system and solar energy to heat the entire building. According to experts, the solar energy system ensures sufficient lighting in emergency situations. Notably, all door systems at the center are automatically controlled.|||The most notable feature at the National Convention Center is the system of meeting rooms with a total area of 60,000m², equipped with modern and highly automated facilities. The main meeting room, located on the 2nd floor of the building, covers an area of 4,256m² and can accommodate 3,800 seats.|||This is a state-of-the-art meeting room with a multi-functional stage that can be automatically raised and lowered.|||The sound equipment system here is designed diversely to meet various conferences, artistic performances, and modern stage lighting needs. This meeting room is equipped with 3 projector screens suitable for different art forms that can be changed as desired. At the seats, mobile digital delegate boxes are arranged, including goose-neck microphones and headphones. Notably, this meeting room can be divided into two separate spaces by an automatic partition system, accommodating large and small conferences, music performances, dance, ballet, and other activities...|||The ceremonial hall is located on the 1st floor of a building with an area of 2,100m², which can be arranged in various styles such as a theater, classroom, standing party, seated party, or round table. The hall has a spacious stage for art performances. This ceremonial hall can be automatically divided into two separate spaces.|||In addition to the main meeting room, the grand hall, high-level meeting room, VIP room, the National Convention Center has nearly 30 small meeting rooms, seminar rooms, banquet rooms, and exhibition areas. The meeting rooms here are equipped with advanced facilities such as multi-channel simultaneous interpretation audio systems, LCD projectors, and synchronized screens.|||There are also auxiliary service systems like banks, post offices, newsstands, travel agencies, restaurants, bars...|||Notably, the press and broadcasting center here has 3 separate rooms for television, radio and print media. This press center is considered very modern, meeting international standards with full equipment for activities such as live broadcasting, ADSL transmission, areas for reporters to write and send news...

title: Tuy Loan Ancient Village
description: Location: Tuy Loan Village is located in the southwest of Da Nang city, in Hoa Phong commune, Hoa Vang district. Characteristics: Tuy Loan Village has been established for over 500 years, bearing a strong mark of history, traditions and cultural identity of Vietnamese rural villages.|||Traveling 15km on National Highway 14B, visitors will reach the ancient village. The river with the same name as the village, "Tuy Loan", winds and embraces the village. The scenery here is very poetic, rustic, charming and holds many interesting secrets.|||The villagers of Tuy Loan built the communal house to worship their ancestors and forefathers.|||The Tuy Loan communal house is a historical and cultural relic that has been nationally ranked, offering an attractive address for research, exploration, and sightseeing.|||The communal house of Tuy Loan village was built in a central location in 1889, covering over 110m² within a spacious 8,000m² area, with a view of the river, facing the mountain, near a major road, and notably featuring an ancient banyan tree with lush branches and leaves, likely over a hundred years old, evoking unforgettable impressions and emotions.|||The stele inside the communal house features an inscription by Tam giap scholar Nguyen Khue from Thanh Tri district (Hanoi), documenting the establishment of the communal house.|||The inscription reads: 'The communal house consists of a main hall and a front room, both made of precious wood and tiled.'|||A stele at the Ngu toc house in the village states that five forefathers, Dang, Lam, Nguyen, Tran, and Le, were ordered by King Le Thanh Ton to expand the borders to the south in 1470.|||These five men stopped and chose this location to settle, cultivate, and named the village Tuy Loan.|||Over a century has passed, yet the communal house remains nearly intact, solemn, and serene under the ancient banyan tree and among the village bamboo groves. The communal house yard features ceremonial pillars, a screen, and painted couplets, exuding a sense of reverence and respect. Every year on the 9th day of the first lunar month, the village holds a ceremony to mark the beginning of the year and organizes a village festival with various cultural and sporting activities such as boat racing, folk singing, and rice cake-making contests. These events attract young men and women, locals, and travelers from afar to participate and visit. On the 11th and 12th days of the 8th lunar month, the village holds a grand ceremony to honor the founders and express gratitude for their contributions to the village, while praying for national prosperity and people's peace.|||The communal house roof, bodhi trees, and water wharf... are characteristic symbols of a traditional Vietnamese village. Located at Tuy Loan, it enjoys a favorable position where water and land routes converge. The scenery here resembles a picturesque painting with a river, wharf, riverbank, countryside, rice fields, a bridge, and a market.|||It is said that Tuy Loan used to be a thriving and prosperous place with a bustling market on land and on the river. The market at Tuy Loan acted as a hub gathering most products from the surrounding areas: fish sauce from Hoi An and Da Nang, forest products from the western region, and fabric, hats, and baskets from Cam Ne.|||The traditional production of rice paper and Quang Noodle in Tuy Loan has been renowned for a long time. Currently, there are over five rice paper production facilities, including Ba Tinh's, which has been family-run for over 40 years. To make delicious rice paper, one must prepare a mixture of five essential ingredients: fish sauce, salt, sugar, garlic, and sesame.|||To create tasty noodles, one must select the right type of rice, specifically the 13/2 rice produced from the sandy soil of Dai Hiep commune (Dai Loc district). The mixing and blending process is a secret and an art unique to the village, giving the rice paper and noodles a distinct flavor that cannot be replicated elsewhere.|||Folk songs have been sung about this:|||Tuy Loan offers a variety of delicious dishes|||Be careful what you say, or your family will be affected!|||Travelers heading to Da Nang, going north to south, should stop by Tuy Loan. Take a stroll around the village and riverside market, savor the flavors of Quang noodles and rice pancakes. Admire the village communal house and the traditional atmosphere. Attending a village festival will be an extremely interesting experience, leaving a lasting impression of a ancient village, a communal house with a rustic natural scenery, friendly and warm-hearted people, and a rich cultural heritage of Vietnamese rural areas.

title: An Hien Garden House
description: Location: An Hien Garden House is situated on an area of 4,608m2 in Xuan Hoa Village, Huong Long Commune, Hue City. Characteristics: An Hien Garden House is architecturally designed in the traditional ruan house style. Besides its architectural value, An Hien is also a rare and elaborate collection of fruit trees and domestic flowers.

title: Tay Dang Communal House
description: Location: in Tay Dang town, Ba Vi district, Hanoi, about 50km west of Hanoi city center. Characteristics: the communal house is known as one of the oldest in Vietnam with sophisticated carving and engraving art.|||The Tay Dang communal house was built around the early 16th century, but it still retains some carvings from the 11th to 13th centuries. This has led to speculation that Tay Dang communal house may have been constructed before the 16th century. The house of worship is dedicated to Tan Vien, one of the four immortal beings in Vietnamese folk beliefs, a key figure in ancient Vietnamese mythology.|||The communal house faces south. According to ancient beliefs, the direction of the communal house aims to honor Tan Vien Saint, considered the spiritual king of the village, contributing to maintaining a peaceful life for the people.||||||The Tay Dang communal house is a unique architectural work. The house has only one compartment in the shape of the letter 'nhat', without a back hall or front altar. The original building materials were entirely made of jackfruit wood, and some Son Lim wood was used during later renovations. In front of the house is a large open space for community activities on festive days.|||This is followed by a semi-circular pond placed right in front of the main gate. This is a common type of gate popular in the 19th and early 20th centuries.|||There are two side buildings on either side of a large yard, dating back to the same period.|||The main hall is built on a rectangular base with high stone steps. The hall has 5 rooms and 4 roofs. Inside, it is structured with 48 large and small pillars stacked in a tiered manner, divided into 3 main rooms and 2 ancillary rooms, surrounded by a veranda. Tay Dang communal house does not have a wooden floor nor walls around it; instead, it features a system of pillars supporting the roof, creating a spacious and well-lit area. The pillars are low and carved in a tapered style (narrower at the top and wider at the bottom), with a square base and a distinctive curved top. The roof structure is designed like a 'giá chiêng' with a larger, curved top part that directs force to the column heads and creates space for a central wooden panel.|||Tay Dang communal house attracts visitors not for its beautiful natural scenery or grandiose scale, but for its intricate wood carvings and decorations still preserved on the pillars, beams, rafters, and wooden boards. Here, visitors can admire the exceptional skill of the craftsmen who have achieved a high level of proficiency. The brilliance of the predecessors lies in the fact that over 1,300 wooden carvings in the house do not repeat any details and are arranged harmoniously, without symmetry like architectural details in many other communal houses. The carvings in Tay Dang communal house bear a strong folk cultural imprint, with themes focusing on the activities of people in Vietnamese villages in the 16th century, such as boating, carrying children, chopping wood, and dancing and singing… They reflect the thinking and intelligence of ancient Vietnamese people about life and labor.|||The Tay Dang communal house has a unique architectural decoration rarely seen in Vietnamese heritage: a decorative strip featuring laughing female fairies riding a dragon boat, connected by intricate floral patterns under the roof; the fairies are playing various musical instruments such as flutes, pipes, and different types of lute.|||The floral motifs include lotus and chrysanthemum flowers along with swirling patterns, carved on the pillars and beams with very delicate lines.|||The ends of the roof are curved and adorned with dragons, ly, quy, and phoenixes made of terracotta; the beams, supports, and brackets all have exquisite carvings.|||The most unique feature of Tay Dang communal house is the dragon carvings in Tran dynasty style.|||Visiting Tay Dang, tourists can be attracted and enchanted by dozens or even hundreds of dragon forms carved into round statues, placed on panels, columns, and serving as head ornaments.|||No other communal house or temple has such diverse and sophisticated dragon carvings.|||With its unique architectural and sculptural values, Tay Dang communal house is likened to a 16th-century folk art museum.

title: Moluong Cave (The Soldier Cave)
description: Located in the Pu Kha mountain range, Mai Chau town, Hoa Binh province, about 2 km from Ban Lac. Moluong Cave is an ideal tourist spot for visitors who love to explore and experience new things in Mai Chau.|||The cave is also known as Bo Luong, meaning 'large water mine', by the White Thai people. According to legend, during the Lunar New Year, the Thai people would go fishing in the deep streams in the area. One woman from Bo village caught a strange egg three times, and on the fourth catch, she decided to take it home to hatch. The egg hatched into a snake, which later turned into a dragon. The dragon brought prosperity to the village, allowing them to cultivate the land into fertile fields.|||To show gratitude, the villagers brought the dragon to Moluong Cave, where it turned into a dragon and stayed. Every year on the 15th day of the 7th lunar month, people see schools of fish swimming out of the cave for the villagers to catch. The villagers believe the fish are a gift from the dragon as a repayment of kindness.|||The cave has four chambers, about 500m deep. The first chamber is the largest, 60m long and 16m wide. After climbing a 10m iron ladder, visitors enter the second chamber, believed to be the home of the gods. The shapes of the stones and stalactites resemble characters in mythological stories, creating a breathtaking wonder inside the mountain.|||The third chamber is large, about 400m2, and cooler than the others. The stalactites hang down like giant teeth, and the atmosphere is peaceful. The final chamber is spacious, 25m high, 15m long, and 12m wide, with many unique stalactites and stone pillars. At the bottom of the cave is an underground stream flowing into Moluong lake.|||During the wars against France and America, the cave served as a base for Vietnamese soldiers to discuss strategies and store weapons and explosives. Therefore, the villagers also call it the Soldier Cave.

title: Son Dong Art Village
description: Location: Son Dong Village, Hoai Duc District, Hanoi, about 20km northwest of the city center. Characteristics: In 2007, Son Dong art village was recognized by the Vietnam Record Book as the largest Buddhist sculpture and worship object village in Vietnam.|||The traditional craft of woodcarving and making worship objects with lacquer and gold or silver leaf has existed for a long time in Son Dong. In 1983, Nguyen Duc Dau, a skilled artisan from Son Dong, established a class to teach wood carving and lacquer painting. Today, 34 students from that class have become skilled workers or teachers, continuing to pass on the craft to the younger generation in the village and commune.|||Son Dong village specializes in creating wooden statues and ceremonial objects with lacquered gold and silver finishes, serving the cultural and spiritual needs of the community. The wooden statues from Son Dong are crafted with precise proportions, resulting in balanced and uniquely distinctive pieces. What's remarkable is that the artisans from Son Dong can create any statue without needing a pre-existing model. From raw mit wood, the skilled hands of Son Dong craftsmen shape statues that seem to come alive, exuding a sense of soul. To achieve this, the artisans must possess experience, knowledge of Buddhist culture, and understanding of spiritual symbolism, as well as familiarity with the characteristics and placement of each statue in the cultural psyche.|||The crafting process involves not only a general method but also unique techniques from each artisan in Son Dong. The material used for making statues is mit wood, known for being soft, having fine fibers, being less prone to cracking, easy to carve, and having high durability. Mit wood is sourced from various provinces such as Phu Tho, Thai Nguyen, Thanh Hoa, Nghe An, etc., then processed to remove the sapwood, leaving only the core for carving. The artisan then uses a string to measure the volume and cuts the wood into the required shape. The initial processing stage focuses on the head and face of the statue. The artisan must carve an outline of the hat (if any), then the forehead, nose, lips, ears, etc. After outlining the overall shape from the face to the base, the artisan proceeds to detailed carving - the most crucial step in completing the statue. The next steps involve smoothing, scraping, and sanding to achieve a smooth surface. During the smoothing process, the artisan uses a flat, thin chisel to separate the details so that the parts do not stick together. This is the final stage for the wood before moving on to the painting process. The technique of applying son and gold leaf to the statue is as intricate as the lacquer art. First, the statue is coated with a mixture of paint and clay soil, then wrapped with raw lacquer and experimental lacquer. After each step, the statue is polished with stone and water. The process of applying and then polishing is repeated until the surface of the statue is flat, smooth, and rounded; then a layer of adhesive lacquer is applied. When the adhesive lacquer is dry to the touch (slightly sticky), the artisan proceeds to apply silver or gold leaf according to the customer's request.|||The sculptures from Son Dong are most famous for their antique replicas, used for the renovation of temples, pagodas, shrines and historical and cultural relics across the country. With their skilled hands, the craftsmen of Son Dong have created many highly sophisticated art pieces such as: The thousand-handed and thousand-eyed Goddess Buddha statue; Arhat statues... During the integration period, many Son Dong craftsmen also make portrait and art statues for export, meeting the demands of foreign partners.|||Today, visitors to Son Dong will witness the process of making statues and immerse themselves in the sounds of the craft village, with the chiseling of statues and the buzzing of saws echoing through the streets. In 2008, the People's Committee of Ha Tay (now Hanoi) approved a project to develop Son Dong traditional craft village combined with tourism by 2010, with an orientation towards 2020. The project aims to create a craft village that harmoniously combines modern production with traditional beauty in each statue, couplet, and horizontal board.

title: Ham Rong Cave
description: Location: Ham Rong Cave is located in Muong Khuong district, Lao Cai province, about 2km from Muong Khuong town. Characteristics: Here, visitors can admire the mysterious beauty of a vast mountainous region.|||From Lao Cai city, following National Highway 4D northeast for about 50km, visitors will reach Muong Khuong district.|||From afar, the villages and hamlets in Muong Khuong district seem to blend in with the lush green of the mountains. As you get closer, the scene unfolds like a vivid painting: Along with the natural scenery are stilt houses and cute bungalows; schools peeking through the trees, vast rice fields of Tung Lau - Na Buu stretching endlessly... and prominently, the Ham Rong cave complex - a famous tourist site ranked as a National Relic.|||To reach the Ham Rong cave complex, visitors must follow the Tung Lau stream with the main entrance being the source of the stream. This stream winds its way through the mountains and creates the "Pao Tung" waterfall - a stunning sight in Muong Khuong.|||The Ham Rong cave complex consists of 4 caves: Lung Pau, Nam Ooc, Muoi Ngua, and Cao Son; of which 2 main caves are connected with a total length of about 750m.|||Lung Pau cave, located in Tung Chung Pho commune, is deep within a towering limestone mountain range. In 1959, the famous Pha Long bronze drum (belonging to Hegir I) with an age of nearly 4,000 years was discovered here.|||Nam Ooc cave, located in Nam Lu commune, has many beautiful stalactites and a Buddha statue, and is often the site of folk festivals of the Nung people and other villages in the region.|||Muoi Ngua cave, also known as Su Ma Tung cave, is located in Ta Ngai Cho commune - a notorious hideout of the infamous Chau Quang Lo bandit.|||Cao Son cave complex is hidden within a towering limestone mountain range. Inside the cave, there are many beautiful stone formations that resemble rice terraces, agricultural tools, tables, chairs... This place is not only a testament to the "exposure of the enemy" by the local military and people who fought against the feudal invaders but also a revolutionary base against the French, and a national defense and security area protecting the country's border in the current period.|||Visiting the Ham Rong cave complex, visitors can admire the mysterious beauty of a vast mountainous region.

title: Van Nien Pagoda
description: Location: 364 Lac Long Quan, Xuan La Ward, Tay Ho District, Hanoi.|||This is a famous ancient temple in Hanoi capital|||Van Nien Pagoda was built in 1011, after King Ly Thai To moved the capital from Hoa Lu (Ninh Binh) to Thang Long (Hanoi today). Over 1,000 years of history, the pagoda now has a typical Nguyen dynasty architecture with a 'Ding' shape, including main sections: Tam Quan gate, front hall, main hall, Mau house, To house... The Mau house worships Lieu Hanh, one of the four immortal gods in Vietnamese folk beliefs.|||The main hall has many Buddha statues, notably a 1.3m high, 600kg Myanmar jade Buddha statue. The pagoda's roof has three raised seals 'Van Nien Tu', meaning eternal existence.|||The pagoda keeps many historical and artistic artifacts, including 11 Le and Tay Son dynasties' documents, two Nguyen dynasty bronze bells, and other worship objects. Notably, the 'Van Nien Tu chung' bronze bell cast under King Gia Long (1802 - 1820) describes Van Nien Pagoda as a large and important ancient temple west of the old Thang Long citadel.|||In 1996, Van Nien Pagoda was ranked as a national architectural and artistic monument by the Ministry of Culture - Information (now the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism).

title: Dam Mon Peninsula
description: Location: Dam Mon is located in Van Phong Bay, in Van Thanh commune, Van Ninh district, Khanh Hoa province, about 80km north of Nha Trang city on National Highway 1A (45km by sea). Features: Dam Mon Peninsula is attractive with long stretches of sand dunes, about 20 large and small islands with primeval forests, and unique features in Dam Mon fishing village...|||The peninsula has a natural area of 128km², and is one of the tourist sites highly evaluated by the World Tourism Organization. It has optimal natural conditions for eco-tourism development: climate, coastline, mountains, landscape, ecological environment, seaport, seafood supply... and all are almost intact.|||In June 2002, a 18.5km road was built from Co Ma pass to Dam Mon, marking the beginning of the development of Van Phong Bay tourist area. Traveling on this new road, crossing the peninsula, visitors can see houses seemingly sinking in sand, vast white sand dunes stretching, with no houses or people around, giving a feeling like driving through a large desert. After the sand dune area, the road runs along the coast from Dam Mon to Dai Lanh. The final destination is a small fishing village in the bay, quiet and green with coconut trees all year round: Dam Mon. Dam Mon has three hamlets: Dam Mon Ha, Dam Mon Thuong and Xuan Dung.|||In this small fishing village, visitors can see people not wearing shoes and sitting or lying on the sand anywhere. Dam Mon Thuong has high sand dunes where visitors can climb up to gaze at the vast blue sea. In Xuan Dung hamlet, visitors can find fresh water by digging a fist-deep hole near the coast. There is a minority ethnic group called Dang Ha, no longer on the Vietnamese resident map, but still existing in Van Phong Bay.|||After visiting Dam Mon village, visitors can take a boat to explore about 20 large and small islands, with primeval forests on the islands. After the mountainous area, visitors can explore underwater. Van Phong is an area with a typical coral ecosystem of Vietnam. Services here include scuba diving to see coral reefs, swimming, boating to Van Phong Bay...|||In the evening, visitors can go fishing for squid or have a campfire on the beach, and it's great to buy fresh seafood like grouper or lobster to enjoy the sweetness of sea creatures just caught from the sea...

title: Cang Ca - Cho Ca Thuan Phuoc
description: Address: 15 Thuan Phuoc, Hai Chau district, Da Nang city.|||Thuan Phuoc fishing port is a bustling trading spot day and night, serving as a key point for fresh seafood supply to local seafood processing units, nearby provinces, and small markets within the city.|||The port is managed by Thuan Phuoc Fishing Port Exploitation Enterprise. In the late 19th century, it was originally a white sandy spit where small boats and fishing vessels would anchor and sell fish to locals. After the country's liberation, the market was built to become a wharf for boats and vessels after their fishing trips. In 2002, a new market was constructed to become the current fishing port.

title: Phu Quoc National Park
description: Location: Phu Quoc National Park is located in the northeast of Phu Quoc island, in the communes of Bai Thom, Cua Duong and Ham Ninh, Phu Quoc island district, Kien Giang province. Characteristics: This is one of the National Parks in Southern Vietnam that still preserves intact ancient primeval forests. Here, there are many natural beauties with forests, sea, streams, waterfalls and hills.|||Mentioning Phu Quoc Island immediately brings to mind a northwestern island in Kien Giang Province with a cluster of scenic spots and historical sites, including Phu Quoc National Park, an attractive destination that visitors must stop by when traveling to the island.|||From Duong Dong town (Phu Quoc), following the Duong Dong - Ham Ninh road, visitors will arrive at Ham Ninh commune. From here, going back up to the north of the island about 10km, visitors will reach Phu Quoc National Park.|||With a total area of over 31,422ha, Phu Quoc National Park is divided into 3 functional sub-areas: strictly protected sub-area (8,786 ha), ecological restoration sub-area (22,603 ha) and administrative - service - scientific research sub-area (33ha).|||The flora in Phu Quoc National Park is quite diverse. The vegetation here is mainly evergreen forest growing on low hills and mountains with a total of several hundred species, including: large trees (such as tram, dau, ven ven, oil song nang, oil cat, cay, de, sang sot, da, bua,…), precious orchid species (Lan Van Hai, Ai Lan La Dep, Am Lan Nui…), precious medicinal herbs (ha thu o, bi ky nam, cam thao, nhan tran, do trong, sa nhan…) and some other parasitic species (orchids, ferns, white cotton vine…)|||Alongside a rich flora, the fauna here is also very diverse, featuring: 30 mammal species, including 5 listed in Vietnam's Red Book such as the forest wolf, white monkey, and pileus langur; 200 bird species with 4 listed on IUCN's Red List and 3 in Vietnam's Red Book; 50 reptile species, with 9 on IUCN's list and 18 in the national Red Book…|||The sea part of Phu Quoc is also very diverse with coral reefs of different shapes and sizes shimmering in the sea water. There are nearly 100 species of hard coral, nearly 20 species of soft coral and 62 species of seaweed. In addition, the fish system in the coral reefs is also very rich with groupers, butterflyfish and some other species, including some very important and rare species such as giant clams, conchs, turtles, dugongs…|||With its rich forest and sea ecosystems, Phu Quoc National Park is one of the country's biodiversity centers.|||Currently, Phu Quoc National Park is being conserved, developed and continues to breed and collect rare and endangered wild animals.|||Coming to Phu Quoc National Park, you have arrived at an attractive eco-tourism destination. You will have the opportunity to join a 4-hour tour to conquer and explore Mount Chua at 565m high - considered the roof of Phu Quoc, on the Ham Ninh mountain range. Standing on the top of Mount Chua, you can feel the joy of victory and admire the vast and spacious landscape; the poetic and lyrical scenery of nature. From here, looking down, the National Park looks like a watercolor painting: mixed with the dark green of the forest leaves, the turquoise blue of the ocean are the pink and purple colors of sim flowers, mua flowers, especially the fresh red color of the sea daisy - a characteristic flower in Phu Quoc.|||In addition, the Garden is also accentuated by the crystal clear and pure white color of the famous streams originating from the Ham Ninh mountain range, such as Tranh Stream, Da Ban Stream and Da Ngon Stream... Among them, perhaps the most impressive and attractive to tourists is the breathtaking natural scenery with Da Ngon Stream and a 7-storey waterfall flowing day and night without stopping.|||Here, visitors can admire the picturesque natural scenery, immerse themselves in the crystal-clear waters of pristine beaches like Duong Beach, Thom Beach, or relax on flat rocks listening to the gentle stream flow, the chirping of birds calling their flocks, and the subtle fragrance of wild orchids by the stream.|||Visitors can also explore, camp, fish, and enjoy local specialties such as Phu Quoc sim forest wine, grilled bien mai fruit, and stream fish.

title: Vo Canh Inscription
description: Location: At Vo Canh village, west of Nha Trang city, Khanh Hoa province.
