description: Location: Located northeast of Quang Ngai province, 15 nautical miles (about 24km) from the mainland.|||Key features: It holds a strategic position in the East Sea of Vietnam, holding great tourism potential and valuable information about the Hoang Sa archipelago.|||Covering around 10km² with a total coastline of over 25km, Ly Son island district consists of 3 islands: the main island (Ly Son) in the territory of An Vinh and An Hai communes, Cu Lao Bo Bai island (also known as Be island) in the territory of An Binh commune, and Mu Cu islet to the east of the main island, which is the smallest and uninhabited.|||Ly Son Island is known for its breathtaking natural scenery, where the sky and sea meet. The island's towering mountains rise up against the vast expanse of sky and earth, and are also immersed in the deep blue of the sea... it's a truly stunning natural picture.|||The main island is the center of Ly Son district, also known as Cu Lao Re. It is home to Thoi Loi mountain, the largest of the five mountains in Ly Son. From the top, visitors are overwhelmed by the natural beauty of the island with black rock formations, a result of lava flows from millions of years ago, and fields of shallots and garlic, creating a multi-colored landscape.|||was removed as there was no second sentence, the translation is done on the given text|||A must-visit destination on Lon Island is the To Vo arch, a natural stone "gate" about 2.5m high with a spectacular shape and no human intervention. Around To Vo are black and shiny rocky beaches with unusual shapes rising above the clear water. Watching sunrise or sunset is a great time here. Because of its beautiful scenery, it's called the Gate of Heaven. This is also a top photography location among young people visiting Ly Son Island.|||Located about 3 nautical miles northwest of Lon Island, Be Island still retains its pristine beauty. Be Island is home to one of the most beautiful coral reefs in the country, with diverse colors and a long history. This coral reef is also home to a rich aquatic flora and fauna, with vibrant colors and diverse shapes.|||Thus, one of the most popular activities among tourists on Be Island is snorkeling or diving to explore the rich and diverse marine life, with schools of fish swimming around or coral reefs in vibrant colors…|||Visitors come to Ly Son not only to admire the majestic natural scenery but also to explore the daily life of residents and experience the unique cultural space of the island district. Ly Son has many cultural and historical relics such as: Chua Hang, Chua Duc, Hang Cau, Mieu Ba Chua Ngoc, An Hai village communal house, Dinh Ba Roi, Giếng Vua, remnants of Hoang Sa - Truong Sa sea team, Am Linh Tu, and cultural sites of Cham and Sa Huynh…|||Ly Son has a rich cultural potential, where many legends, stories, and folk songs are passed down; many traditional cultural activities such as the worship of Ca Ong, the Tứ Linh boat racing festival at the beginning of the year, the Khao Le The Linh Hoang Sa festival in February and March (lunar calendar)... On Ly Son Island, there are many stone artifacts, Chinese, Cham, and Dai Viet ceramics. In the heart of the island, many Cham and Sa Huynh cultural relics are hidden. In particular, many important documents are preserved here, proving that Vietnam has asserted its sovereignty over its seas and islands from a long time ago.|||Ly Son is also considered a culinary paradise with many rustic seafood dishes, retaining their fresh flavor. The island's specialties include king crab, crab, squid, sea urchin, sea spinach, and dozens of types of sea snails with unusual names like jumping snail, dun snail, cur snail, or elephant snail. Ly Son is also known as the "Garlic Kingdom". If you visit Ly Son during the garlic harvest season, you can try the unique garlic salad, made with garlic stems and leaves mixed with peanuts. The garlic here is mild and fragrant, not pungent, and combined with the nutty flavor of peanuts, it creates an irresistible and unforgettable dish.

title: Tay Ninh Cao Dai Holy See
description: Location: Long Thanh Bac commune, Hoa Thanh district, Tay Ninh province, 4km southeast of Tay Ninh town, about 100km northwest of Ho Chi Minh City.|||This is a complex of famous architectural, artistic and religious works of the Cao Dai religion and is the headquarters of the Tay Ninh Cao Dai Church.|||Construction began in 1933 and was officially completed in 1955. The Cao Dai Tay Ninh Holy See is where the Divine Eye is worshiped - a sacred symbol of Cao Dai.|||In addition to the Divine Eye, Cao Dai also worships Sakyamuni Buddha, Goddess Quan Am, Jesus Christ, Confucius, Lao Tzu,... According to Cao Dai scriptures, the Holy See represents the White Jade Palace (where the Supreme Being resides) on earth.|||Located within a 40km² area, the Tay Ninh Cao Dai Holy See complex includes nearly 100 different architectural structures, built with reinforced bamboo concrete. The holy see has 12 gates, all featuring intricate carvings of the Four Supernatural Creatures (Dragon, Unicorn, Turtle, and Phoenix) and lotus flowers. The main gate is the largest, with a unique decoration featuring two dragons fighting for a pearl, lotus flowers, and three religious symbols: the Spring and Autumn Annals, the Bhaisajyaguru mantra, and a duster, representing the harmony of the three teachings (Buddhism, Taoism, and Confucianism). On the main gate is a relief of the phrase "DAI DAO TAM KY PHO DO" in Vietnamese script above and Chinese characters below.|||From the main gate, follow the path leading straight east to the center of the compound of the Toa Thanh. Here are three pagodas - where the three dignitaries are worshiped: Duc Ho Phap, Duc Thuong Pham, and Duc Thuong Sanh. Beyond the pagodas is Dai Dong Xa square, where there is a statue of Prince Siddhartha riding a horse in search of enlightenment, followed by his attendant Channa. Next is Cuu Trung Thien (where the remains of Cao Dai dignitaries who were promoted to the rank of Tien or higher are kept) with a 9-level bat guai shape and painted in three colors: yellow, blue, and red. Nearby is an ancient Bodhi tree brought from India by Thera Narada and given to Toa Thanh in 1953. Not far from the Bodhi tree are two viewing stands - one to the east called Dong Khan Dai and one to the west called Tay Khan Dai - where pilgrims and visitors come to watch the procession of the Mother's carriage during two grand festivals each year.|||Visitors will reach the Thien Hoi (Holy) Hall. Overall, it is designed to resemble the Long Ma (Dragon Horse) bowing to the sage, a mythical creature carrying the Ha Du (Yellow River Map). This symbol inspired Phuc Hy, one of the three legendary rulers of ancient China, to create the Bagua. The hall is 97.5m long and 22m wide, featuring typical characteristics of Cao Dai temples and blending Eastern and Western architectural styles. The Thien Hoi Hall is surrounded by 156 large and small columns supporting the eaves of the corridors, both inside and out.|||The front of the Toa Thanh is the Hiep Thien Dai area, resembling the head of a Long Ma looking straight west.|||On either side of the entrance to the Toa Thanh are a bell tower (left) called Bach Ngoc Chung Dai and a drum tower (right) called Lei Yin Co Dai. Both towers are 27m high, with 6 floors of varying heights. The main entrance to the Toa Thanh is called Tịnh Tâm Đài, resembling the mouth of a Long Ma.|||Above Tịnh Tâm Đài is a semicircular balcony called Lao Dong Dai. On Lao Dong Dai is Phi Tưởng Đài or Thong Thien Dai, resembling the forehead of a Long Ma with 2 doors considered the Long Ma's eyes.|||The outside of Thong Thien Dai is adorned with the symbol of Thien Nhan.|||Through 5 steps of Tịnh Tâm Đài is the Tịnh Tâm Điện area. The upper floor of Tịnh Tâm Điện is the Hiep Thien Dai pavilion, where 15 high-ranking officials are worshipped: Ho Phap, Thuong Pham, Thuong Sanh, and 12 Thoi Quan.|||Connected to the Hiep Thien Dai area is the Cuu Trung Dai, which has a shape like the body of a Long Ma. This area has 18 pillars divided into two parts, decorated with dragon figures, intricately carved. These rows of pillars divide the Cuu Trung Dai area into 9 compartments, each with a height difference of 18cm, called "Cuu Pham Than Tien". This is the area for ceremonies of each level of followers in Cuu Trung Dai.|||The central row of pillars has an escalator and a balcony, where dignitaries stand to preach to the faithful, called Giang Dai. In the last 3 compartments of Cuu Trung Dai, 7 chairs are placed for the 7 highest-ranking dignitaries of Cuu Trung Dai. The highest is the chair of the Giao Tong, carved with dragon figures, followed by 3 chairs of the 3 Chưởng Pháp, carved with phoenix figures, and finally 3 chairs of the 3 Dau Su, carved with unicorn figures. Above the last compartment of Cuu Trung Dai is a 17m-high tower, called Nghinh Phong Dai.|||Located at the end of the holy building is the Bac Quai Dai area facing east, resembling the tail of a dragon horse. This area has 8 pillars arranged in a Bac Quai shape, with a large globe in the center symbolizing the universe, featuring the Thien Nhan in the middle and 3072 stars representing 72 globes and 3000 worlds around it.|||Within the sacred compound, there are many other architectural works such as Hanh Duong, where meetings and training sessions for monks are held, Giao Tong Duong, Ho Phap Duong, Nu Dau Su Duong, the office of Hiep Thien Dai, Van Linh house, Bac Tong, Trung Tong, Tan Nhon, Khach dinh, Thuyen Bat Nha, hospital, school, workshops... Notably, the Phu Mat Temple, where Co Mau - the sacred Mother of humanity is worshipped, and Ba Hue garden is located opposite the temple.|||Additional information: The main ceremony is held at 12 pm. Visitors can visit at any time but should note some common rules: remove shoes upon entry, keep the area clean; and enter through designated doors: men on the right and women on the left.

title: Cai Be Floating Market
description: Location: Cai Be Floating Market is located in Cai Be town, Cai Be district, Tien Giang province, on the Tien River, at the border of three provinces: Tien Giang, Vinh Long, and Ben Tre. Characteristics: Cai Be Market is the largest wholesale market in the Mekong Delta. The market takes place on the river, operating day and night on a large scale. Goods are very diverse and abundant.|||Cai Be is a district with the largest fruit gardens in Tien Giang province, with famous fruits like oranges, honey oranges, cat xoai, xa ly guavas, and sugarcane quýt...|||Tourists are increasingly visiting Cai Be because the town has streets along the riverbank, sometimes hidden, sometimes visible under the water coconut trees and mangrove forests, creating a picturesque scene. Cai Be has a pure, rustic beauty, rich in garden characteristics. Here, gardens are connected, rivers and canals are intertwined. Transportation in Cai Be is entirely by water.|||Cai Be Market takes place on the river, with boats coming and going like a loom. The market operates day and night on a large scale, with boats from distant gardens coming to sell and buy goods. Therefore, the goods at the market are very diverse, from fabric, household items to poultry, seafood, and even food and drinks. The fruit trading area is located at the mouth of the floating market, along Tan Long islet, stretching for a kilometer. Boats from Ho Chi Minh City, Long An, An Giang, Can Tho, and Ca Mau come to buy goods. Tam ban boats are filled with fruits: red rambutans, yellow xoai, soursop, and fresh green watermelons...|||When dawn breaks, the floating market is bustling like a city on the river. Small boats selling snacks like rice, phở, and hủ tiếu run through the boats to sell goods. Sitting on a boat, tourists can enjoy a hot bowl of hủ tiếu or a fragrant cup of coffee in the morning...|||Cai Be Floating Market is a transfer station for fruits and products to be distributed to all regions (even to China). Prices here are surprisingly cheap.|||The area selling various roots and fruits runs from the intersection of Nha Tho to the gate of Vam Long Hai. This area usually has large boats with a capacity of 5-10 tons from other provinces carrying special products to sell and then buying goods to take back to their provinces.|||The area selling rice and bran is located separately on a river bend. The uniqueness of the floating market is that boats selling something hang that item on a pole so that buyers know what they are selling without having to shout.|||When the sun sets behind the trees in the distance, the "floating city" lights up. At night, the floating market is brightly lit, looking like stars falling. Some boats hang small lanterns at the bow, creating a lively atmosphere.|||Visiting Cai Be Floating Market, tourists will experience many interesting things and discover new things about the Mekong Delta.

title: Cu Lao Thoi Son
description: Location: Thoi Son eco-tourism area is located in the lower part of the Tien River, in Chau Thanh district, Tien Giang province. Features: Thoi Son eco-tourism area covers about 1,200 ha and is a concentrated fruit tree growing region. The charm of Thoi Son lies in its ability to escape the hustle and bustle of the city.|||Visitors to Thoi Son can take a boat ride along the winding canals between the lush water coconut trees and the willows along the riverbank. They can take a leisurely stroll along the winding stone paths, passing through lush fruit gardens. Guests can sit in the gardens, drink honey tea, and listen to traditional music. Thoi Son at night is magical with bright moonlight, cool breeze, and vast waters. Visitors can sit on a boat, glide gently on the river, and watch the moon rise, or sit with friends, drink, and listen to the smooth, soulful singing of the village girls.|||The houses in Thoi Son still maintain their ancient, traditional architecture. The home of Mr. Tam Cho is a typical example of an old-style house. The house is built with wooden columns, and each roof has nine rafters arranged according to Feng Shui principles.|||Inside the house, the decor is also traditional, with a cabinet adorned with mother-of-pearl, intricately carved long chairs, and couplets with golden characters. The surrounding garden is filled with bonsai trees, carefully cultivated. Visitors to Thoi Son can visit a coconut candy workshop, where candies are made by hand, and buy handicrafts and household items made from coconut trees. In addition to eco-tourism programs, the locals in Thoi Son also introduce visitors to their culinary culture, with dishes such as grilled fish, fish hotpot, and fried fish.|||The number of visitors to Thoi Son is increasing, especially foreign tourists. Thoi Son attracts visitors with its diverse and unique eco-tourism programs and products, as well as its attentive service. Thoi Son is becoming a popular destination in Tien Giang.|||

title: Dong Tam Snake Farm
description: Location: Dong Tam Snake Farm is about 9km from My Tho City. Features: It is a center for snake breeding, venom extraction for export, combined with medicinal plant cultivation and research on snakebite treatment for people in the Mekong Delta.|||Originally known as Enterprise 408, Dong Tam Snake Farm is also called the Center for Breeding, Research and Processing of Medicinal Materials of Military Region 9. Not only is it a place for treating snakebite patients, but Dong Tam Snake Farm is also a unique tourist destination, part of the My Tho - Cu Lao Thoi Son - Dong Tam Snake Farm tour. Visitors can witness hundreds of different snake species, from harmless snakes (water snakes, gáo snakes, etc.) to venomous snakes (horse tiger snakes, cobra, etc.), as well as rare animals like pythons, crocodiles, soft-shelled turtles, foxes, bears, etc.|||Currently, around 30-40 thousand international and domestic tourists visit each year. To attract more tourists, the Department of Commerce and Tourism of Tien Giang province is collaborating with Dong Tam Snake Farm to upgrade the entire area, plant more greenery, and add more rare animals... Once completed, the snake farm is expected to welcome around 10-15 thousand visitors annually.|||

title: Chua Hang
description: Located in khom 3, Chau Thanh town, Chau Thanh district, Tra Vinh province, 5km south of Tra Vinh town. It's an ancient Khmer temple on a 10-hectare land with many ancient trees and a habitat for various bird species.|||Chua Hang is one of the most beautiful temples in Tra Vinh province.|||From Tra Vinh town, go 5km south, pass the Tam Phuong sluice, and you'll arrive at Chua Hang, also known as Kamponyixprdle (Mong Ray). Locals call it Chua Hang due to its gate resembling a cave. The temple grounds are vast, with half of the area being a natural forest, dense with tall trees, and a haven for many bird species. The main gate faces the riverbank, while the side gate is built with a thick, arched wall. Two Yak statues, about human size, stand on either side of the main gate. Yak, a fierce creature, is tamed by Buddha and serves as a protector.|||The temple plays a vital role in the community, handling moral education and preserving cultural heritage. Young Khmer men typically spend a few years studying here before being considered adults, a prerequisite for getting married. The temple grounds house a large school for children. Inside the temple, there are about 20 small stilt houses, each accommodating one person, where Khmer men stay for a month to pray and purify their souls.|||The temple courtyard once had a vast colony of bats. During the 1968 Tet Offensive, a bomb hit the temple, killing 62 people, injuring 57, and causing significant damage, scaring the bats away. Today, a thousand storks have returned, roosting on trees every evening. On some days, the temple staff collect dozens of young storks, nurse them back to health, and release them. However, the bat colony has vanished.

title: Nodol Temple
description: Location: Nodol Temple is located in Giong Lon hamlet, Dai An commune, Tra Cu district, Tra Vinh province, about 40 km south of Tra Vinh town. Characteristics: Also known as Co Temple or Giong Lon Temple. This is a large and architecturally distinctive Khmer cultural temple in Tra Vinh, featuring a gate, main hall, stupa, monk's quarters, and meeting hall.|||The main hall has curved roofs shaped like dragon tails, with spire-shaped towers resembling Mount Xome and familiar figures like Riehu, four-faced god Mohabrom, bird Kâyno, Mahaknốt. The temple is surrounded by bamboo groves and sao and dau trees. Locals call it Co Temple because for over a century, the temple grounds (about 3 ha) have been home to thousands of birds, including storks, doves, and others, with storks being the most numerous, featuring various types like white storks, black-faced spoonbills, and others.

title: Mu Cang Chai Terraced Fields
description: Location: Mu Cang Chai terraced fields are located in La Pan Tan, Che Cu Nha and De Xu Phinh communes, Mu Cang Chai district, Yen Bai province. Characteristics: The terraced fields are on mountain slopes, tier upon tier.|||Mu Cang Chai is a district in the west of Yen Bai province, about 300km northwest of Hanoi.|||From Hanoi, take Highway 32, passing through the 27km Khau Pha pass. In October, visitors are surprised by the golden rice fields on the mountain slopes.|||The Mong people grow rice on these terraced fields during the spring and summer crops. October is the best time to visit. The fields are narrow due to the steep slope, and the height difference between each tier is about 1-1.5 meters.|||The water for the fields comes from sources above, and the Mong people use a clever system to distribute it.|||In recent years, Mu Cang Chai terraced fields have become a popular tourist destination. On October 18, 2007, it was recognized as a national monument by the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism.

title: Tay Thien Tourist Area
description: Location: Dai Dinh commune, Tam Dao district, Vinh Phuc province Characteristics: It is a tourist area with diverse biology and rich flora. Tay Thien is also a famous spiritual tourist destination in Vinh Phuc province.|||Tay Thien scenic area is about 70km from Ha Noi, a 1-hour drive. This scenic area is well-known and has become a popular tourist destination, attracting a large number of visitors to Vinh Phuc.|||Covering an area of about 148ha, located on the slope of Thach Ban mountain in the Tam Dao range, Tay Thien scenic zone has a diverse ecosystem. According to scientific research, Tay Thien's flora includes 130 families, 344 genera, and 490 species, with some species holding significant scientific and economic value, such as pơ mu, la hán, and sam pông. The forest is home to pine trees that are thousands of years old. The fauna is also quite diverse, comprising 4 classes, 26 orders, 86 families, and 281 species, including rare animals like the golden turtle, white pheasant, white-cheeked black langur, and Tam Dao newt.|||The rich biodiversity, along with the system of temples and pagodas of cultural and archaeological significance, attracts tourists and researchers.|||From the 18th century, Tay Thien was a scenic area and was described by Le Quy Don in "Kien Van Tieu Luc": "...at the bottom, the water is dark blue, deep and bottomless; on the mountain slope, there is Tay Thien Co Tu temple, with green bamboo and pine trees, the scenery is serene and spacious. At the top of the mountain, there is Dong Co temple, it takes two days to climb up and down. From the left side of the Giai Oan stream, climbing up to the lotus pond, the water is bright blue, in the pond, there are rare stones and red lotus, blooming all year round. On both sides of the pond, streams flow from the mountain slope, on the left is Bac stream, originating from the rock crevice at the top of the mountain, flowing down like a silk fabric; on the right is Vang stream".|||Tay Thien Temple worships National Mother Tay Thien Nang Thi Tieu. According to legend, she was born from the spiritual energy of the Tam Dao region. She was beautiful, capable, and had strategic talent, helping King Hung Due Vuong defeat enemies and protect Van Lang. After the war, she declined the king's rewards and returned to Tay Thien forest. Some records say Prince Lang Lieu married her, and the traditional banh chung and banh day cakes were created with her significant contribution.|||After she passed away, she was revered as the National Mother of Tay Thien and many temples were built in her honor. Interestingly, locals avoided saying "tieu tien" (spending money) because it was a taboo due to her name, instead saying "pha tien" (an alternative phrase). Besides the di sites dedicated to National Mother Tay Thien, this scenic area also has many Buddhist temples such as Phu Ngi, Thien An, and Dong Co. Some artifacts like bronze statues and bells over 1,000 years old are still preserved today.|||Visitors to Tay Thien come in large numbers every year, representing a wide range of ages and backgrounds. From young children with their parents to elderly individuals "climbing mountains with a cane" and mostly young travelers, students, and pupils. Each person has their own appearance, wish, and aspiration. Regardless of their purpose, circumstances, or conditions, they all perform rituals and offer incense to pray for their wishes with sincerity before the Buddha. Many elderly visitors hope to reach Bat Nha stream, Giai Oan spring, Bac waterfall, and Vang river, and to burn incense at the Nirvana realm (Dien Thuong Temple). For all visitors, Tay Thien scenic area is like a "fairyland" in the vast forest, dispelling fatigue, worries, and worldly concerns.|||In 1991, Tay Thien scenic area was ranked as a national monument

title: Bong Cave Hut
description: Location: Bong village, Tan Trao commune, Son Duong district, Tuyen Quang province.|||Key feature: This is where Ho Chi Minh stayed the most and for the longest period during the 9-year resistance against the French colonialists (1946 - 1954).|||Hang Bong is near the foot of the west mountain of Tan Trao commune, about 300m from the Pho Day river. The cave is not very spacious but has a high ceiling and is well-ventilated.|||About 50m in front of the cave, there is a natural well formed from rock crevices. The location of the cave is not too secluded but is private enough, convenient for living, working, and observing from afar. That is why Uncle Ho built a hut here and stayed for up to more than a year at a time. The hut is about 20m2, built in the style of a one-room stilt house with a thatched roof and a veranda, leaning against the cave wall. From here, you can clearly see the road leading to the center of Tan Trao commune, the winding Pho Day river, and the long-stretched Bong village rice fields up to Hong Thai communal house.|||Ho Chi Minh first stayed in the Bong hut from October 17, 1949 to September 1, 1950, a period of over 10 months.|||During his stay, he signed many important decrees, including the Decree on General Mobilization, to mobilize all human, material, and financial resources for the resistance against the French colonialists.|||Other decrees included Decree No. 121 (October 20, 1949) on military ranks, insignia, and uniforms, and Decree No. 126 (November 4, 1949) on military service.|||In early January 1950, Ho Chi Minh secretly traveled to the Soviet Union to establish diplomatic relations between the two countries.|||On July 27, 1950, he sent a letter reminding the Central Organizing Committee to care for wounded soldiers, families of martyrs, and families who contributed to the revolution.|||On September 1, 1950, Ho Chi Minh left to lead the Autumn-Winter Border Campaign.|||On October 10, 1950, after the border campaign in autumn and winter ended in victory, Uncle Ho returned to Bong cave for the second time and stayed here until February 4, 1951 (nearly 4 months) to continue directing the resistance.|||This was also the time when Uncle Ho and the Party Central Committee issued many important resolutions on internal affairs and economy.|||In late December 1950, Uncle Ho visited the Laotian resistance government in Da Ban village, My Bang commune (Yen Son district).|||After that, he went to Kim Binh (Chiem Hoa district) to attend the 2nd National Party Congress (from February 11 to 19, 1951).|||The third time Uncle Ho returned to Bong cave was from February 20, 1951, to December 30, 1952.|||From here, on March 3, 1951, he attended and spoke at the opening ceremony of the United Vietnam Minh - Lien Viet Congress and the establishment of the Lien Viet Front. On May 6, 1951, he signed Decree No. 15 establishing the National Bank of Vietnam. In December 1951, he sent a letter to artists on the occasion of an art exhibition, affirming the role of art and artists in the revolutionary cause. In early September 1952, on the 7th anniversary of the August Revolution and National Day on September 2, Ho Chi Minh called on the entire people and soldiers to prepare for a full counterattack, leading to final victory.|||During the days at the Bong cave hut, although extremely busy and facing many difficulties and illnesses, Uncle Ho still wrote poetry, including many poems that have followed the long history of Vietnamese poetry, such as: "Going by boat on the Day River", "New Year's Congratulations", "Sixty Years Old", "Facing the Moon", "Remembering a Soldier", "Climbing the Mountain", "Untitled"...|||The Bong Cave historical site is particularly important for educating young people about the patriotic tradition.|||It serves the research process on the history of resistance, the history of the Communist Party, especially about the revolutionary activities of President Ho Chi Minh.

title: Tan Trao Banyan Tree
description: Location: Tan Lap hamlet, Tan Trao commune, Son Duong district, Tuyen Quang province. Feature: considered a symbol of the revolution of the liberated capital.|||Tan Trao Banyan Tree witnessed many significant events of the country, especially during the pre-uprising period in August 1945. Under this tree, on August 16, 1945, General Vo Nguyen Giap read Order No. 1, and soon after, the Liberation Army held a ceremony to depart, heading to Thai Nguyen to liberate Hanoi, witnessed by the people of Tan Trao commune and 60 national representatives attending the National Congress.|||Initially, there were two banyan trees about 10m apart, locally known as "ong banyan" and "ba banyan". Over time, due to weather conditions, the trees aged, and by 2008, only a small branch of "ong banyan" and one branch of "ba banyan" remained.|||From 2008 to 2010, the Tuyen Quang Provincial People's Committee collaborated with organizations and enterprises to develop a plan to care for and restore the Tan Trao banyan tree. The Vietnam Forestry Science Institute successfully grafted 21 out of 26 branches to preserve the gene source and create roots on the trunk.|||After years of care and restoration, the historical Tan Trao banyan tree has gradually regrown. The scar on the remaining branch of "ba banyan" has developed into two root clusters, each with a diameter of 80-90cm, and a leaf canopy of about 30-40m2. The small branch of "ong banyan" has also regrown into a new cluster of four thriving trunks.|||The revival of the historical Tan Trao banyan tree is of great significance, not only as a symbol of the revolution but also as a source of pride for the Vietnamese people.

title: Ben En National Park
description: Location: Ben En National Park is in Nhu Xuan district, Thanh Hoa province, 36km southwest of Thanh Hoa city. Characteristics: The total natural forest area is 16,634 ha, including 8,544 ha of pristine forest with many mountains, rivers, and lakes with various names and legends.|||Ben En National Park is home to many rare species. There are 462 plant species from 125 families, including precious species like green lim, flowered lat, cho chi, trai ly, and bu huong. Rare animals include red wolves, horse bears, black gibbons, and golden-faced pheasants.|||The scenery of Ben En National Park is poetic. The 3,000 ha Song Murc lake has over 20 large and small islands. Many caves with stalactites are mystical.|||Visitors to Ben En National Park can research rare flora and fauna, live among the trees, listen to birds and gibbons at night, and grill fish by the stream, making for a fascinating experience. In the future, Ben En will become a very attractive tourist destination.

title: Ho Dynasty Citadel
description: Location: Ho Dynasty Citadel is located in Vinh Loc district, Thanh Hoa province, about 150km from Hanoi. Characteristics: The citadel was built by Ho Quy Ly in 1397 using large and solid green stones.|||Ho Dynasty Citadel is situated on the administrative border between Vinh Long and Vinh Tien communes, Vinh Loc district, Thanh Hoa province. It has many names: An Ton Citadel, Tay Do, Tay Kinh, Tay Giai, Thach Thanh. Ho Quy Ly built it in 3 months, from January to March 1397. In 1400, Ho Quy Ly ascended to the throne, named the country Dai Ngu, and the citadel became the capital from 1400 to 1407, known as Tay Do.|||Tay Do Citadel consists of a citadel, an inner citadel, and a moat. Today, only the inner citadel remains with many ancient relics. The inner citadel was built on a nearly square land, with east-west sides 877m long and north-south sides 880m long, covering an area of 771,760m2. The outer wall was built with 7 rows of stones, 2 rows underground, and 5 rows above ground. The size of the 5 stone layers from top to bottom is 0.4m - 0.6m - 0.8m - 1.0m - 1.1m. The stone slabs weigh around 10 to 20 tons. The total volume of the stone wall is approximately 25,000m3, and the earthen wall is around 80,000m3.|||The inner citadel has four gates built in an arch shape: South, North, East, and West, with an average height of 6 to 8m. The South gate is the main gate with three entrances, while the others have only one. Historical records describe the inner citadel having architectural works such as Hoang Nguyen Palace, Nhan Tho Palace, Phu Cuc Palace, Dong Cung, Dong Thai Temple, and Tay Thai Temple. Remaining relics include stone dragons on the stairs, foundation of the inner citadel, Hoa Nhai stone road, stone stele, stone cannonballs, ceramics, and other valuable artifacts characteristic of Tran-Ho culture.|||At Tay Do Citadel, the Ho Dynasty left many historical marks, such as establishing Xa Tac altar in 1397, building Nam Giai altar and performing a ceremony in 1402, and organizing two doctoral exams in 1400 and 1405. Both exams had 190 successful candidates, including Nguyen Trai, a world cultural celebrity and national hero of Vietnam.|||The Ho Dynasty Citadel was ranked as a national architectural and artistic relic in 1962.

title: Lam Kinh Historical Site
description: Location: Lam Kinh citadel is in Xuan Lam commune, Tho Xuan district, Thanh Hoa province, 51km west of Thanh Hoa city.|||Characteristics: Built by King Le Thai To (Le Loi), Lam Kinh citadel is also known as Tay Kinh.|||This area contains Le Thai To's tomb and Vinh Lang stele with a concise description of King Le Thai To's career, compiled by Nguyen Trai.|||Huu Lang - King Le Thai Tong's tomb; Khon Nguyen Tomb - Tomb of Royal Mother Ngo Thi Ngoc Giao (King Le Thanh Tong's mother); Chieu Lang - King Le Thanh Tong's tomb; Du Lang - King Le Hien Tong's tomb; King Le Tuc Tong's tomb; Le Lai Temple.|||From Thanh Hoa city, follow provincial road 15A west for 51km to reach Lam Kinh, the cradle of the Later Le period in Vietnamese history.|||Lam Kinh is located in Tho Xuan district, a region that gave birth to two Le dynasties (Early Le and Later Le) - an area where nearly a thousand years ago, the ancestor of Emperor Le Loi saw birds flying together in a flock, and decided to build a house there.|||The Lam Kinh Imperial Citadel is situated with its north side against Dau Mountain (also known as Du Son) and its south side overlooking a river. Chua Mountain serves as the front, with Phu Lam forest on the left and Huong and Ham Rong mountains on the right, shielding the west. The Imperial City, palaces, and Thai Mieu in Lam Kinh are laid out along the north-south axis on a series of hills in the shape of the character 'king'. The four-sided citadel is 314m long, 254m wide, with the northern wall curved like a bow, having a radius of 164m, and is 1m thick.|||In Lam Kinh, visitors can enjoy the sweet and spicy flavor of Phu Quang lam cake, a type of cake made from glutinous rice powder, molasses, mixed with peanuts and ginger.|||They can also savor the softness and dark color of Tu Tru black cake, the fatty and crispy taste of Dam Set fish fried golden; these are famous products of Lam Kinh.|||In Thanh people don't say "to" Lam Kinh, they say "return to" Lam Kinh. Return home, return to the historical site, return to the origin of great feats. Return to Lam Kinh, where the Lung Nhai Oath took place. One night in the Binh Than year (1416), 18 sons of the land stood before a roaring fire, vowing to drive the Ming invaders out of the country.|||Lam Kinh is the "golden cradle" of legendary stories. A story tells of an old monk who advised Le Loi to bury a sacred object on a land shaped like a national seal. The land spirals like a snail, with Chieu mountain in front serving as an altar, and Long mountain on the left and Ho mountain on the right paying homage. The right side has Ho Thuy and the left has Long Son, connected like a string of pearls, signifying a throne for the Son of Heaven. Another story is about a magical sword given by Le Than, a fisherman, which accompanied Le Loi in battles for 10 years before being returned to the Golden Turtle, forming the legend of Hoan Kiem Lake in the heart of the capital. There's also a tale about a mustard green leaf with the imprint of a national seal, which the wife of Le Loi found, bearing the name Le Loi on the back. Another story tells of a white-clad girl who died by the river and turned into a fox spirit, distracting the Ming army and saving Le Loi. The story of Le Lai, the second leader of the uprising, who saved Le Loi by taking his place and sacrificing himself.|||Every year on the lunar August, the Lam Kinh festival begins. The anniversary of Le Loi's death (22/8/1433) is solemnly celebrated. The sound of gongs and drums resonates through the forest. Folk dances: ceremonial dances, Dong Anh lantern dance, and a majestic dragon dance. Games: throwing, constructing a nêu tree, and enthusiastic Spring Performance singing.

title: Nui Coc Lake Scenic Spot
description: Located in Dai Tu district, Thai Nguyen province, 15km southwest of Thai Nguyen city. Known for its natural beauty and the legend of Nang Cong and Chang Coc.|||The road to Nui Coc is a scenic route through vast forests. The lake is surrounded by a stunning natural landscape.|||Nui Coc is famous for its natural beauty and the legend of Nang Cong and Chang Coc.|||Nui Coc Lake is an artificial lake, built in 1993 and completed in 1994, with a main dam of 480m and 6 auxiliary dams. The lake covers 25km2, with over 89 islands, and has a water capacity of 175 million m3.|||It's a beautiful destination and a great place to relax, with a well-developed tourist infrastructure.||||||

title: Vietnam Museum of Ethnology
description: Located in the center of Thai Nguyen city, Thai Nguyen province. Built in 1960 on a large campus with many ancient trees. The museum displays the cultural heritage of Vietnam's 54 ethnic groups.|||Total area is 28,000m2 with over 3,000m2 used for exhibitions, storage, and other activities.|||The museum preserves over 20,000 original artifacts and documents of Vietnam's 54 ethnic groups.|||The exhibition system consists of 6 rooms, each using nearly 2,000 objects.|||- Introduction room: overview of the cultural characteristics of Vietnam's ethnic groups.|||- Viet-Muong room: includes Viet, Muong, Tho, and Chut ethnic groups.|||- Tay-Thai room: includes Tay, Nung, Thai, Lao, Lu, San Chay, and Bo Y ethnic groups.|||- Hmong-Dao and other South Asian groups room: includes Hmong, Dao, Pa Then, La Chi, La Ha, Co Lao, and Pu Peo ethnic groups.|||- Mon-Khmer room: includes Kha Mu, Mang, Khang, Xinh Mun, O Du, Khmer, Ba Na, Xo Dang, Co Ho, Hre, and other ethnic groups.|||- Han-Hoa, Tibetan-Burman, and other groups room: includes Hoa, Ngai, San Diu, Ha Nhi, La Hu, Phu La, Lo Lo, Cong, Si La, Gia Rai, E De, Cham, and other ethnic groups.|||The museum also has an outdoor exhibition area.|||It attracts many domestic and foreign visitors, as well as overseas Vietnamese.

title: Binh An Tourist Area
description: Location: Binh An Tourist Area is located beside National Highway 1A, at 71, Ward 2, Soc Trang Town, Soc Trang Province. Features: Binh An Tourist Area spans several hectares and is a scaled-down replica of Dam Sen Cultural Park in Ho Chi Minh City.|||This is a destination with many activities and services: entertainment, dining, stage performances, accommodations... The system of greenery, flowers, swimming pools, fish ponds, and amusement rides is arranged logically, harmoniously, and in harmony with nature, being both serene and vibrant. The tourist area can cater to the needs and preferences of various ages and groups.|||Upon entering the gate, behind the stage, you can see an artificial mountain about thirty to forty meters high, topped with a large statue of Lady Buddha Quan Am. At the foot of the mountain is a fish pond; the vegetation is planted naturally; winding paths wind between large and small rocks, simulating mountain trails. Vines cling to the trees, creating a lush atmosphere. Inside the mountain is a mini-hotel. Next to the mountain is a two-story villa with a mixed Russian and Middle Eastern architectural style. This is a venue for weddings, galas, and parties...|||The emergence of Binh An Tourist Area has broken the tranquility of a town deeply marked by Khmer culture in the Mekong Delta.

title: Puong Cave
description: Location: Puong Cave is on the Nang River in Ba Be district, Bac Kan province, 5km from Cho Ra town.|||The Nang River flows under the limestone mountains, between steep cliffs, through Lung Nham mountain, where it is known as Puong Cave. A small boat navigates through the cave, surrounded by dim light, with strangely shaped stalactites appearing in front of the cave entrance. Inside the cave, hundreds of thousands of bats live and reside.

title: Dinh Lang Dinh Bang
description: Location: Dinh Bang communal house is located in Tu Son town, Bac Ninh province. Characteristics: Dinh Bang is one of the most famous ancient communal houses of Kinh Bac land.|||It is the hometown of Ly Cong Uan (also known as Ly Thai To), the founder of the Ly dynasty and the pioneer of Thang Long capital (in 1010).|||Dinh Bang has a cluster of cultural relics, especially those from the Ly period, forming a unique memorial site, echoing history, of national significance, with a full range of: communal house, shrine, pagoda, tomb, tomb complex,... characteristic of a Vietnamese village culture.|||Dinh Bang communal house was built in 1700 and completed in 1736, thanks to the initial efforts of Nguyen Thac Luong, a man from Dinh Bang, and his resourceful wife Nguyen Thi Nguyen from Thanh Hoa, who bought lim wood to build the communal house, ensuring its longevity. The communal house worships three tutelary deities: Cao Son Great King (Earth God), Thuy Ba Great King (Water God), and Bach Le Great King (Agriculture God).|||The拜堂 (Bai Đường) hall of the communal house is rectangular, 20m long, 14m wide, divided into seven compartments, with two wings on a high foundation with stone steps. The grandeur of the communal house is reflected in its wide roof and rare lim columns, with around 60 large and small columns having a diameter of 0.55-0.65m.|||The floral patterns on the architectural elements are diverse, intricately carved, and harmonious. The structural framework of the communal house is sturdy, held together by various mortise and tenon joints. Each carved panel in the communal house is a unique masterpiece. The more one admires, the more one is captivated: the 'Bat ma quan phi' (Eight Horses) panel, with horses frolicking in a peaceful landscape; the 'Luong ngai phuc chau' (Two Nges kneeling) panel, with a male and female Nge, each with a distinct expression; the 'Long van dai hoi' (Dragon and Phoenix) panel, 'Ngu long tranh chau' (Five Dragons Contesting a Pearl) panel, 'Luc long ngu thien' (Six Dragons Riding the Clouds) panel,... each panel evoking numerous stories.

title: But Thap Temple
description: Location: But Thap Temple is located in the west of But Thap village, Dinh To commune, Thuan Thanh district, Bac Ninh province. Characteristics: But Thap Temple has unique ancient architectural and sculptural art, with many Buddha statues and precious antiquities.|||Speaking of Bac Ninh, we cannot help but mention But Thap Temple. This is an ancient temple, although it has undergone restoration and repair, it still retains its original charm.|||The temple was built in the late Le period (17th century). According to history, the temple was designed by Mrs. Trinh Thi Ngoc Truc (wife of King Le Thanh Tong) and two Vietnamese-Chinese monks. The temple's name is "Ninh Phuc Zen Temple" and was built in the style of "Inner Palace and Outer Palace".|||The temple has a stone balustrade surrounding the Upper Palace, carved with animal shapes, clouds, sky, flowers, leaves...|||Notable are the lively and vivid carvings of birds, deer, monkeys, dragons, etc. Inside, there are sets of Tam The, Tam Than, and Quan Am statues with a thousand eyes and hands.|||The Quan Am statue in the temple is large and magnificent, standing 3.7m tall with 11 heads, 42 large hands, and 958 small hands. Each hand has an eye, and the rhythm of each arm is different. The statue is placed on a lotus throne, with a halo behind it, and below it are decorative shapes resembling waves and water creatures.|||Connecting the Upper Palace and Tich Thien is a curved stone bridge, from which one can admire the unique beauty of the temple scenery.|||The temple is also home to many precious antiquities and many beautiful stupas, large and small, where the relics of ancient monks are kept.

title: Cai Rang Floating Market
description: Location: Cai Rang Floating Market is located in Cai Rang District, Can Tho City, 30 minutes by canoe from Ninh Kieu Wharf. It specializes in trading agricultural products and local fruits.|||Not having visited Cai Rang Floating Market means you haven't truly experienced Tay Do land.|||Cai Rang is one of the famous floating markets in the Mekong Delta. The market trades in fruits and agricultural products. Every morning, hundreds of boats gather here. Sellers display their goods by hanging them on a pole at the bow of the boat.|||The market offers various services like noodle soup, coffee, and floating restaurants, catering to visitors' needs. Service boats skillfully maneuver to serve customers. The uniqueness of the floating market leaves a strong impression on foreign tourists, who enthusiastically take photos and sometimes exclaim in delight.|||Cai Rang Floating Market usually starts early, around dawn, and winds down by 8 or 9 am. Large barges buy fruits to transport to other places, including Cambodia and China. Other barges supply goods like fuel, salt, fish sauce, medicine, and daily necessities to people in the delta.|||In the riverine region of the Mekong Delta, canoes are a primary means of transportation, akin to bicycles or motorbikes in cities. Most canoes are equipped with engines, with occasional traditional paddled canoes.|||Cai Rang Floating Market is an attractive destination for tourists.

title: Lake Lak
description: Location: Lake Lak is on the road between Buon Ma Thuot city and Da Lat, in Lien Son town, Lak district, Dak Lak province, about 56km south of Buon Ma Thuot city via highway 27. Characteristics: Lake Lak is a beautiful landscape in the Central Highlands. The lake provides a lot of fish and is a huge freshwater reservoir supplying water to hundreds of hectares of fields, while also making the climate here cooler.|||After passing Lac Thien pass for about 10km, turn right at Lien Son town and you'll see the summer resort villa of former Emperor Bao Dai. This was where he often came to enjoy the scenery, hunt, and rest when he had the chance to come to Buon Ma Thuot city. The villa is on a hill overlooking the lake.|||The lake is over 500ha and is connected to the Krong Ana river. The surface of Lake Lak is always green, reflecting the pine forests on the hills surrounding it. The surrounding area is a large primeval forest with a rich flora and fauna.|||During the rainy season, hundreds of streams and waterfalls flow into the lake, making it wider and causing waves to surge like the sea, flooding the surrounding grasslands. Further out, where the water is deeper, is home to various species of lotus and water lilies. The lotus in Lake Lak is very beautiful, covering a long stretch of the lake's surface, making the scenery even more poetic.|||Near Lake Lak is Jun village, a typical village of the Mnong ethnic people. Visitors can take a ride on the back of an elephant to explore the village and the surrounding mountains. If you stay overnight, you can enjoy the chieng cồng (gong) performances of the Mnong people.

title: Tomb of the Elephant Hunter King
description: Location: The tomb is in Buon Don district, Dak Lak province. Characteristics: The tomb belongs to a powerful village chief who was respected by people throughout the region, the man who founded Buon Don, and had great merit in the early days of establishing and developing the profession of hunting and taming wild elephants here.|||Khunjunob, whose real name was N' Thu K' Nul, was born in 1828. He was a powerful village chief who was respected by people throughout the region. He founded Buon Don and had great merit in the early days of establishing and developing the profession of hunting and taming wild elephants. He hunted hundreds of elephants, including a white elephant (Bach Tuong) that he gifted to the Thai royal family in 1861. The Thai king was very impressed and awarded him the title Khunjunob (Elephant Hunting King). He lived, worked, and led the people of Buon Don, and eventually chose this place as his final resting place, living to be 110 years old.|||After he passed away, news of his death spread quickly throughout the region. His funeral was held with full traditional rituals, lasting many days, with the participation of many ethnic groups from near and far.|||After his death, his nephew (who called him "cau") named R' Leo K' Nul, took charge of the funeral and burial arrangements. At that time, Buon Don was a multi-ethnic community, mainly consisting of M'Nong, Ede, and Lao people, so R' Leo and the villagers decided to build his tomb in a combined M'Nong-Lao architectural style to show their gratitude and respect for the late village chief. The tomb's architecture reflects the M'Nong-Lao culture, with clear motifs and decorations, including lotus buds on the four corners and top of the tomb.|||R' Leo K' Nul (Khunjunob's nephew) was born in 1877 and became the new leader of the village after Khunjunob's death. During this period, R' Leo proved to be an excellent leader, knowing how to promote the local strengths and contributing significantly to maintaining and developing the traditional profession of hunting and taming wild elephants.|||Notably, he helped strengthen the relationship between the village and neighboring ethnic groups, as well as with the feudal dynasty at the time (Bao Dai). He gifted Bao Dai a white elephant and established a "Bao Dai Royal Elephant Hunting Team" for the king. He passed away in 1947 at the age of 70. Three years after his death (1950), the "leaving the grave" ceremony was held, and his tomb was built in the Cambodian temple architectural style. This architectural style was chosen by King Bao Dai, who sent representatives to oversee the construction. The tomb was completed at a total cost equivalent to the value of one elephant with long tusks at the time.

title: Three-Level Waterfall
description: Located in Dak Nong district, Dak Nong province, about 8km from Gia Nghia town along highway 14 towards Buon Ma Thuot. The area around the waterfall has many ancient trees and a large flat area for tourists to camp and relax.|||It's called the Three-Level Waterfall because the stream flows down three levels before reaching the bottom. The three levels are connected over a distance of about 40m. The first level is not very high, with water falling from over 1.5m. About 20m away is the second level, where the green stream water flows between rocks and falls from a height of about 2m, creating white foam. The third level is the largest and main waterfall, with a height of over 20m, flowing between the quiet mountain scenery and spilling over to both sides of the stream.|||The stream is quite wide here, with many trees providing shade for tourists to rest and enjoy the scenery. Standing below and looking up, the mist created by the waterfall surrounds it like a layer of fog, making it a breathtaking sight.

title: Trinh Nu Waterfall
description: Located about 25km southwest of Buon Ma Thuot city center.|||Before merging into the Serepok River, the Krong No River flows over rocky terrain, creating a picturesque scene, and is named Trinh Nu Waterfall.|||Legend has it that the waterfall is named after a young girl who took her own life there due to a tragic love story.|||Visitors can walk along the waterfall's path, resting under leaf-roofed huts, and enjoy the natural scenery.|||For those who want to stay overnight, there are cozy cottages near the waterfall, offering a chance to relax and enjoy the surroundings.|||The majestic natural scenery and warm hospitality make it an ideal destination for relaxation.

title: Pha Din Pass
description: Pha Din Pass, also known as Pha Din Slope, connects Son La and Dien Bien provinces. It was famous during the Dien Bien Phu campaign for withstanding thousands of tons of bombs and remaining intact. Today, it is known as one of the "four great peaks" of the Northwest region, famous for its challenging terrain and breathtaking scenery.|||The name Pha Din originates from the Thai language, where "Pha" means "sky" and "Din" means "earth", implying a connection between heaven and earth.|||The legend of Pha Din Pass. People in Lai Chau (now separated into Lai Chau and Dien Bien) and Son La have long passed down a story about determining the border between the two regions through a horse racing competition across Pha Din Pass.|||After a long and arduous journey, the two brave warriors and their two strong horses had similar strength and willpower, so the distance they traveled to the meeting point on the pass was not significantly different. However, the Lai Chau horse was slightly stronger, so the section of the pass belonging to Lai Chau was longer than the section belonging to Son La.|||Information about Pha Din Pass|||During the intense war, Pha Din Pass was one of the important supply lines for weapons, ammunition, and food for the Dien Bien Phu campaign (1954) of our army.|||It has become a symbol of bravery with over 8,000 young volunteers who were determined to sacrifice for the country.|||In 1954, to cut off our supply line, the enemy relentlessly bombed National Highway 6 for 48 days, with Pha Din Pass and Co Noi Junction receiving the most bombs. At the top of Pha Din Pass, a stele still stands, marking this historical event.|||By 2005, the government decided to upgrade National Highway 6 to the Northwest. The section from Son La to Tuan Giao was implemented from 2006 to 2009, dividing Pha Din Pass into old and new routes from the intersection at the top of the pass:|||Old Pha Din Pass: 32km long (from km 360 to km 392, on the old Highway 6) with the highest point being 1,648m above sea level; and around 125 notorious sharp turns, narrow road, many sections only wide enough for one car to pass.|||was removed, so the description is translated as a single sentence.|||Pha Din New Pass: built along the left side of the old National Route 6, the length is reduced to 26km with about 60 curves, some curves are up to 60 meters wide, the slope is reduced to 8%, and the road surface is nearly twice as wide as before.|||Since the new Pha Din pass route was put into use, it has made travel safer for vehicles.|||The old Pha Din pass route is now only suitable for locals or adventurous tourists seeking to conquer and explore.|||Tourism at Pha Din Pass|||Whether conquering the old or new Pha Din pass, visitors can feast their eyes on the majestic and breathtaking natural scenery. From afar, the pass looks like a rope connecting mountains, floating among the clouds. The winding, twisting, and turning of the road is as beautiful as if it were only in a painting.|||From the foot of the pass, you are captivated by rustic villages, peacefully nestled in the lush green valley.|||Halfway up the pass, the forest is shrouded in mist, occasionally dotted with red and purple flowers.|||At the top, the cool mountain air envelops you, and the vast expanse of clouds and rolling hills stretches out endlessly.|||Life is vibrant on Pha Din pass, not as desolate as it used to be. People from Phoung Lai commune, Thuan Chau district, Son La province and Toa Tinh commune, Tuan Giao district, Dien Bien province gather to trade local goods. Fresh produce, flowers, orchids, and livestock are all locally sourced, making them popular among tourists who stop to buy souvenirs.|||A comfortable life is reaching every Mong household on Pha Din pass, where clouds surround all year round. Especially when the trio of coffee, wild apples, and sand ginger are prioritized for development. Witnessing the changes here, we see the value of the old saying "Xa follows fire, Thai follows water, Mong follows mist" still holds true today.

title: Buu Long Tourist Area - Long An Lake
description: 6km from Bien Hoa city center, Buu Long tourist area is built around an artificial lake formed by stone excavation, known as Long An Lake, spanning tens of hectares.|||Visitors to Buu Long can climb to a 35m-high islet in the lake's center, a haven for dozens of rare bird species, take a boat tour or ride a Swan Pédallo on the lake, and explore the giant stone dragon that spits water, mermaid scenes, and the Kong Long park that was inaugurated in February 1995.|||Near the lake are two low hills; on Buu Long hill stands the ancient Buu Phong pagoda, nestled behind a large bodhi tree. There's also the Long Son Thach Dong cave with an 'eagle's beak' shape and mysterious, dripping stalactites. After exploring the lake, hills, and pagoda, visitors can also visit the famous Tan Trieu pomelo village and witness the traditional stone carving craft, which bears the artistic signature of the late 17th century Lingnan region in China, practiced by a small Chinese community near the lake.|||Buu Long and Long An Lake are attractive destinations for tourists seeking a day of relaxation in nature.

title: Tram Chim National Park
description: Dong Thap is a province in the Mekong Delta, known for its beautiful scenery, with two major rivers, Tien and Hau, bringing fertile alluvial soil from the Mekong River.|||Located in the low-lying area of the former Dong Thap Muoi region, Tram Chim National Park is a miniature version of Dong Thap Muoi, with pristine natural beauty.|||In 1991, Tram Chim became a nature reserve to protect the red-crowned crane and other rare bird species.|||On May 22, 2012, Tram Chim National Park was recognized as a Ramsar site by the Ramsar Convention Secretariat.|||Tram Chim has a unique ecosystem, home to over 100 vertebrate species, 40 fish species, and 147 bird species, including 13 rare bird species.|||Visitors can take a boat tour to explore the park's natural beauty, especially during the flood season.|||The ideal time to visit Tram Chim National Park is from December to early May.|||You can witness the life of various bird species, enjoy the fresh air, and watch the red-crowned crane's dance.

title: Son Tay Ancient Citadel
description: Location: In the center of Son Tay town, Hanoi. Features: This is an ancient citadel with military architecture and a system of walls and gates made entirely of ong stone.|||Son Tay is known for its numerous famous landscapes and historical sites, such as Dong Mo lake, Son Tay ancient citadel, Duong Lam ancient village, Va temple, and Mia temple.|||Son Tay ancient citadel is notable not only as an ancient fortress with a unique military architecture but also for its robust walls and gates made of laterite, a characteristic building material of the Son Tay region.|||From the center of Hanoi, follow Highway 32 about 40km west, and you'll reach Son Tay town. The Son Tay citadel is located in the town center, built in 1822 and was once the capital of the Tam Tuyen region, including 3 provinces: Son Tay, Hung Hoa, Tuyen Quang, under King Minh Mang, the Nguyen dynasty.|||Forming a quadrilateral shape, the perimeter is about 1,304m with 4 arched gates: East, West, Front, and Back. Each gate has an 18m-high watchtower. The wall is built with red laterite bricks, 5m high. Surrounding the wall is a 3m-deep, 20m-wide, and 1,795m-long moat.||||||Inside, there are 4 cannons placed at the 4 corners of the citadel.|||There is Kinh Thien Hall (a 5-bay building), where the king worked and rested when on inspection tours.|||There are also residences and offices of high-ranking officials, such as Tong Doc, An Sat, De Doc, and Doc Hoc.|||In addition, there are a well, a flagpole, and soldiers' barracks.|||The Son Tay ancient citadel was built according to the Vauban-style fortification of France.|||is not needed as there is only one sentence|||According to historical records, Son Tay ancient citadel was designed by French engineer S.P.de Vauban. He revolutionized the art of defense under King Louis XIV and built many important fortresses in France, such as those in Lille (1667) and Namur (1692). The Vauban-style fortress has a clear geometric shape with projecting angles, suitable for the developed military conditions. In Vietnam, this type of citadel was built in several locations, including Gia Dinh (Saigon), Hue city (Thua Thien - Hue), Son Tay (Hanoi), Vinh (Nghe An), Dong Hoi (Quang Binh)…|||After nearly 200 years with many historical ups and downs, this ancient citadel has deteriorated.|||In 1994, the Ministry of Culture and Information (Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism) recognized Son Tay ancient citadel as a national historical and cultural site.|||In 2003, the ancient citadel was restored, partially recreating its original appearance. To allow visitors to admire the unique architecture, relax, and enjoy the scenery, the grounds were landscaped with lush trees and other facilities.|||is not needed as there is only one sentence group, so the translation remains as is: In 2003, the ancient citadel was restored, partially recreating its original appearance. To allow visitors to admire the unique architecture, relax, and enjoy the scenery, the grounds were landscaped with lush trees and other facilities.|||On February 16, 2009, the Hanoi People's Committee decided to continue renovating and tidying up the Son Tay ancient town historical and cultural relics to serve the 1,000th anniversary celebration of Thang Long - Hanoi.

title: Phu Vinh Rattan and Bamboo Weaving Village
description: Location: Located in Phu Vinh village, Phu Nghia commune, Chuong My district, Hanoi, about 30km from the city center. Characteristics: Phu Vinh rattan and bamboo products have reached the highest level of bamboo weaving art in Vietnam.|||According to legend, Phu Vinh was once a place where many storks gathered, and their feathers fell, covering the area. People collected these feathers to make hats, which were durable and beautiful, and soon became popular. Later, when stork feathers became scarce, people turned to using rattan and bamboo to weave various products.|||Traditional Phu Vinh rattan and bamboo products are simple in shape but require skilled craftsmanship. To produce these products, artisans must go through many steps, from selecting and processing materials to crafting the final product. If the material is bamboo, it must be dried, then soaked in a chemical solution to prevent rot, and finally polished and dried again. The next step is to put the bamboo in a furnace, using straw or bamboo leaves to achieve the desired color. After that, the bamboo is taken out, cooled, and then straightened and shaped into thin strips. If the material is rattan, it must be dried and split into thin strips. The color of the products is varied, ranging from the natural color of the rattan and bamboo to colors achieved through the use of PU paint.|||Phu Vinh rattan and bamboo products come in hundreds of designs and types, some requiring high technical skill, such as portraits, landscapes, and ceramic products wrapped in rattan. Some Phu Vinh rattan products are preserved as rare and valuable art pieces, such as a Chinese character calligraphy piece woven from rattan at the Hue Palace Museum. In 2007, the Phu Vinh Artisan Club was established to preserve and promote the traditional craft, and now Phu Vinh rattan and bamboo products are exported to nearly 50 countries worldwide, highly regarded by tourists from Japan, the US, Germany, France, and more.

title: Thanh Chuong Viet Phu
description: Location: Thanh Chuong Viet Phu is located at Day Dieu slope, Keo Ca, Hien Ninh commune, Soc Son district, Hanoi, about 30km north of Hanoi city center.|||Characteristics: This is a miniature northern Vietnamese countryside, preserving traditional cultural values and showcasing the typical beauty of a northern Vietnamese village.|||Viet Phu Thanh Chuong is the name that writer Kim Lan and many of his friends gave to the 10,000m² house of his son, painter Thanh Chuong.|||Visitors can admire the overall beauty of the northern countryside of Vietnam from hundreds of years ago.|||The complex of ancient architecture with a touch of modernity and tens of thousands of historical and cultural artifacts from the Dinh, Ly, Tran, and Le dynasties has made the villa a popular cultural tourist destination near the city.|||From the entrance, visitors are reminded of the ancient beauty of Thoa Ha village gate, Duong Lam. The wooden gate has three doors, one main door and two side doors, with a small attic roofed with red tiles, surrounded by many stone statues and intricate carvings. When entering the gate, visitors will encounter familiar and rustic features of the countryside: a fish pond with a stone bridge for fishing on the right, an ancient well relocated from Thanh Hoa by an artist on the left, and a path leading visitors to explore the entire villa, marked by rows of Bat Trang bricks laid quite evenly.|||One of the beautiful features of the architectural complex here is the ancient house area with different styles and layouts. This ancient house area includes 3 typical houses of the North region of Vietnam, with the most impressive being a 5-room ancient house made of lim wood, about 200m² - typical of the architecture of the Red River Delta region, which was moved from Nam Dinh to here. With the very peaceful name "Thanh Tinh", the house is intricately carved and decorated with couplets painted in red and gold; inside the house, many rare antiques and beautiful lacquer paintings are on display. To create a more rustic and folk feel, in front of the house, there is a lotus pond, a well, jars, and lush greenery; behind the house is a Thatched House with Earthen Walls - a very detailed simulation of the thatched house of farmers in the old days with an entrance made of earth, earth-plastered walls, and trellises, with tre chairs, antique tea sets, and traditional farming tools.||||||Một kiến trúc khác nằm trong khu nhà cổ này cũng ấn tượng không kém đó là ngôi nhà sàn dựa theo kiến trúc nhà sàn của người dân tộc Mường ở Hoà Bình. Đây là một ngôi nhà sàn bằng gỗ với tầng trên để ở và tầng dưới để tiếp khách. Phía trước nhà sàn là một ao sen nhỏ với một chiếc cầu đá cổ, xung quanh cây cối xum xuê, xanh tốt.|||To have a chance to rest and relax at the villa during Tet holidays, and to further explore the ancient cultural heritage, artist Thanh Chuong has also built a 5-bay, 2-wing traditional house made of lim wood with an area of about 120m² within his villa. This house is a typical representation of traditional Vietnamese architecture.|||was removed as there was no second sentence to translate, the original text had only one sentence separated by a period.|||In addition to 3 typical ancient houses, there are many other beautiful architectural works, typically:|||The 5-story Water Tower is a structure next to the stilt house, designed in the style of Dau Pagoda.|||In the ground floor, there are exhibits of antique furniture and a large drum on a wooden pedestal.|||Outdoor Buddha Ancestor Worship Area. The place is solemnly arranged with a Buddha statue in the center, surrounded by stone incense sticks. On both sides of the stone steps leading to the Buddha's feet are many ornamental plants, adding to the beauty of the worship site.|||A 5-story white building with intricate architecture: nestled under curved roofs in the style of ancient temples, the building has a poetic name Tuong Van, meaning auspicious clouds. Next to it is the rustic Thuy Dinh house with worn wooden doors that have faded with time.|||The talent of artist Thanh Chuong is also reflected in the construction of a large hall at his Viet Phu with dozens of antique table and chair sets. In front of the hall is the Lo Mac Huong house, very simple and rustic, surrounded by lush phoenix trees. Every May, the beauty of Lo Mac Huong is even more stunning because it's adorned with the vibrant red color of phoenix flowers. Right next to it is the Dai Khoa house with simple and rustic table and chair sets, adding to the ancient cultural charm...|||Since Viet Phu Thanh Chuong completed its first constructions, many domestic and international tourists have visited every year. Visitors can freely admire and explore the quintessence of Vietnamese culture. The rustic beauty of Viet Phu and the hospitality, clever arrangement, and artistic presentation of the owner have left a deep impression on visitors.

title: Vietnam Fine Arts Museum
description: Located at 66 Nguyen Thai Hoc Street, Ba Dinh District, Hanoi. It is one of the important museums in preserving the cultural heritage of the Vietnamese ethnic community.|||The Vietnam Fine Arts Museum was originally a house built by the French in the 1930s as a dormitory for daughters of French officials from across Indochina. In 1962, the Ministry of Culture renovated the building, adding Vietnamese architectural details, to display Vietnamese art permanently. The museum was officially opened in 1966 with an area of 4200m² and a display area of 1200m². It was expanded in 1997-1999 to a total area of 4737m².|||The display system has been supplemented and adjusted several times to better achieve its purpose of preserving and promoting the unique aesthetic values of the nation in Vietnamese art history. The museum currently stores over 18,000 artifacts representing Vietnamese fine arts from prehistoric times to the present, displayed through various themes.|||It also showcases paintings by famous Vietnamese artists such as Nguyen Gia Tri, To Ngoc Van, Tran Van Can, Nguyen Phan Chanh, and Luong Xuan Nhi.|||To affirm its role as a bridge between the past and the present, and to open up a path for the future of Vietnamese fine arts, the museum was significantly expanded in 1997 and 1999. The museum has also innovated its preservation and display methods, with a more coherent and concise display structure, focusing on the unique aspects of Vietnamese art. The museum aims to achieve international standards.|||To introduce Vietnamese fine arts to the world, the Vietnam Fine Arts Museum is working on digitizing around 50 artworks and will enhance exchange activities with other countries. This activity also poses the challenge of preserving and displaying world art to enrich Vietnam's art collection.

title: Vietnam Women's Museum
description: Located at 36 Ly Thuong Kiet Street, Hoan Kiem District, Hanoi. Features: - Exhibiting and preserving documents and artifacts showcasing the role and achievements of Vietnamese women throughout the nation's development. - A cultural exchange hub between Vietnamese women and women worldwide.|||The Vietnam Women's Museum was inaugurated on October 20, 1995, to commemorate the 65th anniversary of the Vietnamese Women's Union.|||The museum is not only a place for research, preservation, and exhibition of the valuable heritage of Vietnamese women but also a cultural exchange center for Vietnamese women and international women aiming for Equality, Development, and Peace.|||With an exhibition area of approximately 1,200m² in two connected buildings, the museum introduces 5 main topics: - Vietnamese women within the community of Vietnamese ethnic groups.|||- Vietnamese women in the cause of building and protecting the nation.|||- The Vietnamese Women's Union and the struggle for women's liberation.|||- Cultural aspects of Vietnamese women through traditional handmade products.|||- Traditional costumes of Vietnamese ethnic groups.|||The first room features a 3.6m tall gilded "Mother Vietnam" statue, crafted by artist Phu Cuong. The image depicts a strong, vibrant, gentle, and kind-hearted mother. Her right hand is open, symbolizing overcoming challenges, while her left hand cradles a child reaching forward. The ceiling is adorned with white lamps representing the endless source of life - a mother's milk, nourishing generations to come. The statue symbolizes the strength, beauty, and aspirations of Vietnamese women.|||Since its opening, the Vietnam Women's Museum has attracted visitors from both domestically and internationally.

title: Ba Vi National Park and Resort
description: Location: Ba Vi National Park and resort is in Ba Vi district, Hanoi. Characteristics: It is an attractive resort. The scenery is spectacular, with natural beauty blended with human culture.|||From the center of Hanoi, travel about 42km to Son Tay town, then another 16km to Hai stream. Here, visitors can take a boat ride on the lake, visit islands with medicinal plants, bird islands, and stork islands to breathe fresh air amidst beautiful natural scenery.|||Visitors continue to the north slope of Ba Vi mountain to visit Ao Vua waterfall. Water flows from above, creating three tiers of waterfalls. The last tier pours into a small lake with crystal-clear water, known as Ao Vua. Visitors can climb all three tiers via stone steps, surrounded by plants on the mountain slope.|||The journey continues to an altitude of 400m to explore the remains of a resort built by the French in 1940. Visitors can stroll around the park surrounding a swimming pool, take souvenir photos, or relax in stilt houses, enjoying refreshments made from milk produced at the foot of the mountain.|||The journey continues higher. The road becomes steeper, and the mist gets thicker. At 1,200m, visitors reach the peak of Ba Vi mountain. The scenery is breathtaking, with misty fog creating a surreal atmosphere. After enjoying the fresh air, visitors climb 779 stone steps to visit Ho Chi Minh's shrine and another 225 steps to Den Thuong, where the Saint Tan Vien is worshipped. With more energy, visitors can climb further to the Vong Canh peak, surrounded by thick fog. On clear days, visitors can see the scenery of Hanoi, including the Linh Dam modern residential area and many skyscrapers in the city center. It's a truly wonderful experience. Spending a night under the starry sky is a memorable experience.|||The next day, visitors can explore the Ba Vi primeval forest, covering 7,377ha, distributed at altitudes from 200m to 1,300m above sea level. The climate is temperate, with a rich variety of 450 plant species, including many precious ones, and 128 high-grade plant species. There are 250 medicinal plant species. The fauna includes 45 mammal species, 113 bird species from 40 families and 7 orders. There are 15 amphibian species and 86 insect species from 17 families and 9 orders. Rare animals include the northern masked palm civet, Asiatic black bear, Asian golden cat, flying squirrel, silver pheasant, and white pheasant. Aquatic animals include phytoplankton and green algae.

title: Bao Son Paradise Park
description: Location: On Km8 Lang Hoa Lac road in An Khanh commune, Hoai Duc district, 12km from Hanoi city center.|||Features: This is the first international-standard entertainment and cultural tourism complex in North Vietnam.|||Covering 20ha, Bao Son Cultural Tourism and Entertainment Park is part of a new urban area development project in An Khanh (Ha Noi). The project was started in March 2005 and completed by the end of 2008.|||At Van Mieu, visitors can admire a miniature model of Vietnam with unique cultural features. Visitors can also discover products that showcase regional cultural characteristics created by artisans from across the country. Van Mieu was built to preserve ancient architecture, honor traditional cultural values, and highlight the uniqueness of Vietnam's nature and people. Here, visitors can immerse themselves in a vast space with attractive tourist areas such as the old quarter, traditional craft village, food area, eco-tourism zone, and art performances.|||Spanning 5,000m², the old quarter is built with over 20 adjacent houses in the traditional "chong diem" style, tiled with traditional tiles, and some houses feature Western architecture.|||Each house is a shop selling fabrics, handicrafts, electronics, refreshments... arranged to ensure a harmonious combination, vividly recreating the daily life and business of Hanoi people in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.|||This is not only a place to preserve the unique architecture of old Hanoi, but also preserves the spiritual cultural heritage of a thousand-year-old Hanoi, helping visitors to explore the services that once existed in Hanoi's history and still retain their value to this day.|||Strolling through the old town, visitors can take a leisurely walk through the vibrant space of 15 traditional craft villages. Over an area of 10,000m², the craft village area is divided into sub-areas corresponding to each characteristic craft. Visitors will be introduced to the production process, craftsmanship, and context behind the crafts, with a multi-root tree, well, and communal house yard. Visitors can also participate in the production process or buy products from famous crafts such as Van Phuc silk, gemstone paintings, Phu Lang pottery, gold, silver, and gemstones, rattan and bamboo crafts, pottery, wood carving and inlaying, bronze casting, Dao people's wax dyeing, Thai ethnic embroidery, embroidered bags, wood inlaying, embroidery, and antique reproductions... or learn about the community cultural activities of traditional Vietnamese villages such as village meetings, cheo performances, quan ho singing, water puppet shows, and folk music and dance programs… reenacted at the village communal house.|||Next to the old quarter and traditional craft village is the food zone featuring the most special dishes of three regions of the country, introduced at 30 stalls.|||This is also where food festivals will take place continuously. In the 400-seat theater, visitors can watch folk art performances.|||The ecological tourist area occupies an important position in Bao Son Paradise Park. Here, two artificial mountains are built like an ocean world, displaying 2,000 species of fish from around the world, such as sharks, stingrays, dolphins, seals, sea lions... and many types of coral and rare marine life. Visitors can also visit the upper garden with around 500 species of precious orchids from Vietnam and Southeast Asia, the butterfly garden and butterfly museum, a 20m high Maitreya Buddha statue and 12 La Han statues, many lakes with Dragon hatching egg statues, Dragon and Phoenix statues...|||Unlike the serene and peaceful atmosphere of the old town and traditional craft villages, the entertainment zone is a hub for various exciting games, diverse in form and rich in type, catering to the entertainment needs of many, especially young people. The zone features thrilling games like merry-go-round, horse riding, space exploration, electric car racing, intense boat rides, and roller coaster trains; pendulum and swing rides; and a haunted house. The zone also has a pool system, water slides, and hot tubs, making it a complex for hot and cold swimming, and indoor entertainment for tourists all year round.|||The Rooling coaster XD game area is a modern XD cinema imported from Canada with 16 seats.
