description: In summer, if you want to enjoy fresh air, a peaceful space, and rustic dishes of the Mekong Delta, tourists can visit Dong Thap to explore beautiful lotus fields.|||Dong Thap is a fertile land with many lotus fields, but the most outstanding is the Thap Muoi Lotus Tourism Area in My Hoa Commune, Thap Muoi District, about 40 km from Cao Lanh City. The route here is quite easy.|||Dong Thap lotus flowers bloom all year but the lotus fields are most beautiful during the flood season (August to November). Visitors here will be amazed by the endless expanse of lotus fields with the lush green leaves dotted with soft pink flowers and delicate yellow stamens, creating a stunning rural landscape rarely found in urban areas.|||In the lotus fields, there are scattered thatched huts for visitors to admire flowers, rest, and eat. Connecting the huts are wooden paths, simple yet harmonizing with the natural scenery.|||Visitors can venture deep into the lotus fields on a small boat gliding slowly on the water, immersing themselves in cool breezes and the gentle fragrance of lotus flowers, making daily worries and sorrows seem to vanish.|||The lotus here is unique; the flowers start blooming in the early morning with white color, turn pink at noon, deepen to pink by 3 PM, and turn red at sunset. This repeats for three days, after which the flowers turn deep purple and wither.|||Visitors here can also enjoy local specialties that feature lotus, such as grilled snakefish wrapped in young lotus leaves, lotus stem chicken salad, lotus rice, lotus tea, lotus milk, and even lotus tea.|||As evening falls, flocks of birds fly back to their nests, creating dense black dots against the fading blue sky, forming a very peaceful scene.|||Farewelling Thap Muoi Lotus Field leaves a lingering sentiment in the traveler's heart, providing positive energy to continue pursuing dreams, aspirations, and the journey ahead.

title: Ta Pa Rice Field
description: When mentioning the Mekong Delta, one immediately thinks of the beauty of the "flood season", but alongside that, no one can overlook the harvest season of the Delta, a peaceful and colorful beauty.|||Visiting the wonderful golden rice fields, you'll feel your soul calm and leave behind the city's noise. Instead, gentle cool breezes and occasional bird songs echo over the golden rice fields. Located at the foot of Ta Pa and Co To mountains, about 1km from Tri Ton town, Ta Pa Rice Field is a stunning scenic spot in An Giang, considered the only terraced rice field in the Mekong Delta.|||The area's unique and fascinating landscape, due to the local "rotational farming" tradition, will leave a lasting impression on visitors.|||With this tradition, farmers gather to plow and plant together in different areas, moving from one plot to another. Thus, during harvest season, the entire field displays different color patches. Some areas are fresh green, others light yellow, some deep yellow with ripe rice waiting to be harvested, and some dark brown from dry stalks, creating a stunning colorful landscape.|||At Ta Pa Rice Field, visitors can see Arenga pinnata trees – symbols of An Giang's land, standing tall with vitality. Notably, in the middle of the field, there's a path dividing the field, visible from above like a thread crossing the rice field.|||When visiting Ta Pa Rice Field, go at sunrise or sunset. You'll not only admire the endless beauty of the rice fields, feel the fresh, cool air, but also witness the stunning, colorful space of the rice fields and sunlight. The best time is at sunset, when the sun sets on the mountain, the Arenga pinnata shadows stretch long, blending with the image of farmers returning after a day's work, creating a peaceful yet vibrant rural painting.|||When visiting Ta Pa Rice Field, tourists can also climb Ta Pa Mountain to view the serene green lake on the mountain. From there, you can gaze down at the vast, endless fields. It's also the ideal spot to capture stunning, expansive landscape photos.|||Ta Pa Rice Field is most beautiful from September to early November. Especially in November, during harvest season, you'll witness the field filled with vibrant golden and green colors, overwhelming with the area's natural wonders.|||Nature bestows each land and person with unique marks. For Ta Pa, the most concise way to describe it is its harmony, simplicity, and brilliance in its own way. This wonderful beauty isn't just from nature, but also from the labor of the Mekong Delta farmers.

title: Tra Su Mangrove Forest
description: Tra Su Mangrove Forest is one of the most interesting and attractive tourist destinations that tourists cannot miss when visiting An Giang.|||Tra Su is the name of a forest covering 845 hectares with many cypress trees near Tra Su Mountain area Van Giao commune Tinh Bien district.|||Tra Su Cypress Forest is a representative wetland forest of the western area of the Hau River with diverse rare species belonging to Vietnam's special use forest system.|||First check-in spot is the boat dock with a small bridge and beautifully designed pigeon nests above. Starting the journey, the 'tac rang' (a small motorized boat) follows the winding canal, taking tourists deep into the forest. Tourists will be overwhelmed by the fresh green color covering the vast forest area.|||Along the way visitors may encounter local people harvesting honey from melaleuca flowers in hives placed in the forest.|||Upon arriving at Tra Su Melaleuca Forest Conservation Area visitors continue walking along a small path with tall melaleuca trees on both sides providing a cool green shade.|||To further explore Tra Su Forest visitors can take a small boat deeper into the forest.|||Without the noise of engines, the green forest regains its natural space. Gently rowing the boat, the boatman guides tourists through narrow canals into the depths of the mangrove forest. The air is refreshingly cool and fragrant with the scent of trees, tea flowers, and the soft rustling of hanging mangrove branches. Passing under monkey bridges connecting forest patches, visitors admire the dense green carpet of water lilies and lotus leaves covering the water surface, clusters of bright yellow water lilies contrasting against the lush green of the mangroves, and flocks of herons flitting about to build nests in the treetops. All these elements create an enchanting and romantic riverscape unique to Tra Su Mangrove Forest. Tra Su Mangrove Forest is most beautiful during the flood season from September to November, when the entire forest bursts into vibrant new life.|||Visitors should not forget to visit the Observation Tower to admire the vast mangrove forest through a telescope with a 25km view.|||From here you can glimpse the villages where Khmer and Kinh ethnic groups live.|||If you have time you should also visit the unique handicraft villages such as silk weaving Khmer ethnic brocade honey beekeeping turmeric oil processing areas...|||If not taking a boat, visitors can explore Tra Su mangrove forest via the unique and elegant "thousand-step" bamboo bridge. This man-made structure holds a Guinness World Record as Vietnam's longest bamboo bridge in a mangrove forest. Experiencing the full 2km winding length of this bridge is also a challenge for many visitors. The entire bamboo bridge is surrounded by lush green mangrove forests; underwater water lily carpets, birds chirping throughout the forest... creating a poetic, romantic, and incredibly peaceful scenery.|||Being the heart of the Long Xuyen Quadrangle region the local specialties here are very abundant. Tourists have the opportunity to enjoy special dishes such as fish with water lily sour fish stew with water chestnut and water lily grilled snakehead fish and honey tea flower grilled chicken. Tourists can also buy tea tree oil honey to give as gifts to family and friends.

title: Tà Pạ Lake
description: An Giang is a province in the Mekong Delta, one of the largest rice granaries in the South. Tourists passing through coconut groves, vast areca palm fields, crossing the Trieu Khuc ferry heading straight to Thap Son Mountain will enter Tà Pạ Lake in Nui To Commune, Tri Ton District.|||Tà Pạ is a deep lake located on Tà Pạ Hill, within the mystical Thap Son region. Tà Pạ Lake is always a jade-green color, clear down to the bottom. Upon arrival, an expansive, open space stretches before you... relieving all the travel fatigue of visitors. Tà Pạ Lake, like other lakes such as Bao Long Lake and Long Son Lake, was man-made through limestone mountain mining processes.|||Tà Pạ Lake is surrounded by green grass fields covering white limestone rocks, with reed bushes swaying in the wind. Deeper inside is a hidden lake, surrounded by high mountains creating a romantic, poetic space, as if from a legend. Tà Pạ offers a more open, vast space with a grand layout; in the distance, the Thap Son Mountains stand tall under golden afternoon sun, casting a honey-like hue over the Ta Pa fields... Nature has truly blessed this southern land.|||Tourists climb the mountains to gaze down at golden rice fields heavy with grain. The Tà Pạ fields are not as majestic as the terraced fields of Hoang Su Phi or Y Ty, nor as vast as the fields in Long Xuyen or Bac Lieu... But in Tà Pạ, there is a serene, peaceful vastness. It inherits the beauty of areca palm groves, the Khmer ethnic community's villages, and the curved temple spires under the sunset. Oh Tà Pạ...

title: Fingernail Island
description: Fingernail Island is one of the most beautiful islands in Phu Quoc. This place attracts travelers with its charming, pristine, and pure beauty that is unmatched anywhere else.|||Fingernail Island is part of the An Thoi Archipelago, located in the southern part of Phu Quoc Island. The name Fingernail comes from the fact that the fingernail tree also known as seashore pine is widely developed and common here.|||On Fingernail Island tourist activities are not well developed giving the island a wild pure beauty gifted by nature. Visitors are amazed by the heavenly beauty of the clear blue sea long stretches of white sand and rows of coconut trees under golden sunlight creating a relaxing and peaceful space.|||The best time to visit Fingernail Island is from November to April of the following year. This is the dry season on the island with temperatures ranging from 25-28°C making the weather dry pleasant and suitable for exploration and recreational activities.|||Not only does Fingernail Island boast breathtaking natural beauty but it also attracts travelers with many exciting experiences. Snorkeling visitors can witness the unique marine ecosystem and touch colorful coral reefs; participating in fishing activities and having locals cook the catch to enjoy the fruits of their labor.|||In particular the seafood on the island is renowned for its freshness and deliciousness allowing visitors to choose from dishes like lobsters shrimp squid... The most unique dish not to be missed is gỏi cá trích whose fragrant nutty and fresh flavor will leave diners in awe and unforgettable memories.

title: Thom Island
description: Phu Quoc is one of the most attractive destinations for tourists. Visiting Phu Quoc, travelers should not miss Thom Island with its many unique and exciting experiences.|||Thom Island is often compared to a precious gem, with the enchanting beauty of long white sandy beaches, clear cool seawater, and ancient forests creating a harmonious blend of jungle and sea that captivates visitors. When traveling to Thom Island, remember to visit famous beaches like Bai Nam, Bai Chuong, Bai Chao.|||Beyond relaxation, tourists can enjoy water-based adventure sports, conquer fascinating rocky slopes, or explore the simple, rustic lifestyle of local residents.|||Below are some popular activities chosen by visitors to Thom Island:|||Fishing and squid fishing|||Fishing and squid fishing are highly engaging activities attracting many tourists. Squid fishing typically occurs at night. Travelers can also ask local fishermen to guide them in catching sea urchins – a specialty of the island – which are prepared into dishes like grilled sea urchin with garlic, sea urchin sausage, and sea urchin fried rice.|||Swimming and coral reef snorkeling|||The sea at Thom Island is not only clean, clear, and cool but also features colorful coral reefs and diverse marine life. When snorkeling here, visitors must follow lifeguards' instructions to ensure a safe and enjoyable ocean exploration.|||Buying pearls|||Around Thom Island are many aquaculture rafts and pearl farms. Travelers can witness pearl harvesting and choose to buy them as souvenirs for family and friends.|||Don’t forget to try the famous delicious specialties at Thom Island like trich fish salad, red fish salad, clam salad, sea urchin, paper-wrapped grilled sea bass, crispy frogfish, tiger prawns, and abalone.

title: May Rut Islet
description: Is an island that still preserves its pristine and charming beauty, May Rut Islet is becoming a favorite destination for tourists visiting the Emerald Island of Phu Quoc. Here, tourists not only enjoy the rich beauty but also have the opportunity to relax and savor the renowned local cuisine.|||May Rut Islet is located in the west of An Thoi Bay. It is one of the most remote islands of Phu Quoc City (Kien Giang).|||The island impresses tourists with its serene and charming scenery, soft white sand beaches, and crystal-clear turquoise waters. The climate of May Rut Islet is cool and pleasant year-round, making it an ideal place for relaxation.|||In addition to its fresh and clean nature, May Rut Islet also boasts a highly diverse and rich ecosystem of flora and fauna. When visiting, tourists should not miss the opportunity to go fishing at sea and join local fishermen in preparing delicious dishes from sea urchins, clams, jumping snails, croakers, sardines, and grouper...|||With its unique untouched beauty gifted by nature, May Rut Islet offers tourists unique and picturesque spots for photography along the long, soft white sand beaches, rocky shores with varied shapes, swings, piers, and the May Rut hammock... Particularly, due to its geographical location surrounded by many large and small islands, May Rut Islet is an ideal spot for tourists to experience kayaking or stand-up paddleboarding. The shallow water and crystal-clear sea like crystal allow tourists to admire the vibrant coral reefs.

title: Hon Gam Ghi
description: Hon Gam Ghi (Phu Quoc) with its crystal-clear turquoise waters long stretches of white sandy beaches and swaying coconut trees creates a breathtaking paradise that leaves every visitor in awe.|||Hon Gam Ghi also known as Hon Dam Ngang is located to the south of An Thoi Town (Phu Quoc City Kien Giang) and is part of a group of 17 small islands. Currently the only way to reach Hon Gam Ghi is by hiring a boat from An Thoi Port. Along the way visitors can admire the vast sea the clear blue sky and feel the gentle waves lapping against the boat's hull.|||The standout feature of Hon Gam Ghi is its coral reefs that stretch across a vast area sparkling brilliantly under the emerald-green water. This is also the coral conservation area for the southern part of the emerald island of Phu Quoc. The island has many rocky outcrops with unique shapes towering majestically over the sea where waves crash to create white foam forming an impressive and grand landscape.|||Visitors can leave behind the daily hustle and bustle to fully immerse themselves in the serene natural beauty. Additionally the area's abundant and fresh seafood allows visitors to prepare their own seafood BBQ using fish they've caught themselves.

title: Hon Mot
description: Amidst the bustling and vibrant atmosphere of the emerald island Phu Quoc, Hon Mot boasts a pristine, serene beauty reminiscent of a fairy-tale paradise.|||Located in the northeastern part of the island, near the famous Thom Beach, Hon Mot is ideal for travelers who love exploring and connecting with nature. It is only 200 meters from Phu Quoc Island, so locals have built a small wooden bridge to access Hon Mot during the rainy season. In the dry season, when the sea recedes, visitors can experience walking along a floating path across the sea to feel the vastness of the ocean and the fresh, cool air here.|||Being part of the emerald island's ecosystem, Hon Mot features crystal-clear emerald waters and a rich vegetation of ancient trees with beautiful shapes. All of this creates a scenery like a fairy-tale world, captivating any traveler.|||Due to its small size, Hon Mot has only one asphalt road, along which are charming huts for visitors to rest and engage in activities like photography, camping, and BBQ. A unique feature of Hon Mot's ecosystem is the thriving sea purslane with delicate purple flowers, both poetic and eye-catching.|||The tourism activities here are still untouched and novel, so for travelers planning to explore Hon Mot, prepare all necessary equipment, drinks, and help maintain a clean, green, and beautiful travel environment.

title: Ban Buoc Village
description: Located about 25 km west-southwest of the district center Ban Buoc commune of Sam Kho lies entirely on a hill covered with green palm forest. Ban Buoc still preserves its original charm and rich ethnic cultural identity. That is why this area was chosen to develop the Thai Village Tourism Project.|||Ban Buoc dates back to the 13th century with the original name Chua Lot later renamed Ban Buoc. Before 1957 Ban Buoc belonged to Bao La commune. In 1957 it was merged into Sam Kho commune. The village consists entirely of Thai ethnic people with 70 households and over 300 residents who preserve many traditional cultural values. Originally the people of Ban Buoc settled along the stream but in 2007 Ban Buoc was planned to become an ecological tourism area. The entire village moved to the planned site covering 5 hectares including a 2 hectare sports field and a dedicated parking area for tourists. This is a community-based tourism model combining development with preservation of the natural beauty and unique traditional cultural values of the Thai ethnic community. Before becoming a tourism site only one family operated informal tourism services. Now the entire village has 15 households registered for tourism operations. In 2014 Ban Buoc welcomed approximately 500 visitors to experience local culture and daily life.|||The Thai people of Ban Buoc inherit a rich heritage of material and spiritual culture. This includes traditional rice farming and terrace cultivation practices stilt houses made of wooden floors and thatched roofs unique tools like water wheels baskets and pots. The Thai Village Tourism Project is gradually awakening the area's potential. To enhance cultural life for residents and serve tourists the village established a 12-member cultural performance team capable of performing xoe dance Thai folk songs and other programs. The team regularly practices under guidance from elderly villagers. When tourists visit the cultural team performs for them.|||A unique feature of Ban Buoc tourism is that visitors can stay for extended periods up to 2-3 months. During this time they can observe traditional rice farming and terrace cultivation practices and if interested participate in local production activities. Visitors can join young Thai women in climbing hills to collect wildflowers for weaving blankets and mattresses or hiking for scenic views. They can witness the delicate needlework skills of Thai girls in "nhip pha" (blanket embroidery). At night the people of Ban Buoc welcome tourists with traditional xoe dances of the Thai ethnic community.

title: Ban Da Bia
description: Ban Da Bia (Tien Phong Commune, Da Bac District, Hoa Binh Province) features ancient stilt houses for homestays, traditional dishes of the Muong Ao Ta people, sweet and rich rice wine in clay pots, and vibrant local culture with its rustic charm and warm hospitality, all surrounded by majestic and poetic natural beauty that captivates the heart.|||From Hoa Binh City to Ban Da Bia, visitors can travel via water (by boat) or land, both routes being convenient. Whether by water or land, each journey offers unique charm: the water route lets visitors admire the clear, mystical waters of Hoa Binh Reservoir with its large and small islands covered in lush greenery, while the land route offers thrilling experiences through winding roads with steep ascents and descents, shaded by green trees and vibrant wildflowers along the way, ideal for nature lovers and adventurers.|||This area preserves its natural authenticity, attracting travelers who love exploration. Here, visitors can feel the tranquility and peace, far from the noise and chaos of the city, breathe in the fresh, cool mountain air, gaze at white clouds drifting over mountain peaks, and immerse themselves in the songs and dances of the local people, all harmonizing with the calls of birds and animals echoing through the landscape.|||Nights at Ban Da Bia have few lights, allowing visitors to leisurely stargaze or join local performances. This creates a peaceful and relaxing atmosphere, offering a refreshing escape from daily stress and fatigue.

title: Giang Mo Village
description: Giang Mo Village (Binh Thanh Commune, Cao Phong District, Hoa Binh Province) is known as an attractive community cultural tourism destination. The peaceful space in Giang Mo makes this place an ideal stop for those wanting to escape the noisy, bustling city atmosphere.|||From Hanoi, following National Highway 6 for about 86km, visitors will reach Binh Thanh - Cao Phong - Hoa Binh. The Tay Tien Road running through the commune will lead visitors to Giang Mo Village, nestled among vast mountains, forests, and terraced fields.|||Giang Mo Village has over 100 households, all ethnic Muong people, mainly living by farming and animal husbandry. The highlight creating a special attraction for the village is the ancient stilt houses. Stilt houses are closely linked to the customs, traditions, and daily life of the Muong people, built in positions leaning against high terrain like hill slopes or mountain sides to receive the natural air and facilitate their daily activities.|||Along with traditional stilt houses, the Muong people here still preserve their lifestyle and many ancient tools for production made from wood, bamboo, or rattan such as looms, bows, crossbows, and tools for farming... forming their unique customs in daily life and production activities.|||Visiting Giang Mo, tourists can walk along the small road running through the village to admire the pristine, lush green scenery; learn about Muong culture, and enjoy ethnic specialties such as mountain sticky rice, brocade sticky rice, boiled Muong pork served on banana leaves, hill chicken, river fish, and ritual wine at very low prices (Dishes vary according to customer orders). Stay overnight in the stilt houses (30k/person/night), and watch cultural performances by the village's girls and boys as requested by guests.

title: Ban Ngoi
description: Ban Ngoi was formed after the government decided to build a dam to block the Da River for the construction of Hoa Binh Hydropower Plant.|||In the past the village was deep at the foot of the mountain after the water level rose villagers moved to a higher location along the mountain slope.|||Ban Ngoi Hoa lies along the Da River (Hoa Binh Lake) separated from the outside world. The most convenient and common way to reach Ban Ngoi is by boat on Hoa Binh Lake.|||Ban Ngoi Hoa is about 45 minutes by boat from Thung Nai Port Cao Phong and 1 hour 30 minutes from Bich Ha Port (Hoa Binh City). This unique feature has attracted many tourists to visit and explore the village.|||Ban Ngoi is over 30km from Hoa Binh City so tourists can reach it by road then park the vehicle and take a boat to the opposite side to reach the village (Ban Ngoi is on the other side of the river).|||Ban Ngoi has nearly 90 households mostly inhabited by the Muong people giving the area unique ethnic cultural features.|||In front of Ban Ngoi is Nhoi Hoa Bay (Hoa Binh Lake) considered one of the most beautiful spots on the lake. Behind the village are continuous limestone mountain ranges.|||The villagers lives mainly depend on fishing in the river and foraging for food in the forest.|||In 2017 Ban Ngoi was recognized as a Muong ethnic cultural community tourism village. The village has 8 homestays meeting standards for tourists visiting and staying overnight. Each homestay accommodates 20-25 guests per floor each has 2 bathrooms and 2 showers. The homestays are built traditionally according to Muong stilt house style wooden pillars and frames thatched roofs with palm leaves for a cool and comfortable feel. Guests staying overnight pay 100000 VND per guest per mat.|||When visiting Hoa Binh's Ban Ngoi tourists have the chance to explore the unique local culture. Visitors can admire the magnificent natural scenery of rivers and mountains enjoy the fresh cool air.|||Activities like swimming in the lake fishing kayaking exploring the village cave trekking learning to make snail cakes and fishing with locals are exciting experiences for tourists visiting Ban Ngoi. Especially tourists can enjoy fresh delicious local specialties. Additionally joining the village's cultural performances dancing and drinking traditional rice wine are fun activities for visitors.|||It can be said that Hoa Binh's Ban Ngoi is a new destination for groups of students families friends who love exploring and experiencing local culture.

title: Pom Coong Village
description: Pom Coong means the village of hills on a large plain, implying paddy fields – a name rich in imagery and meaning. Pom Coong is known as a cultural village, tourist village, an attractive destination for travelers from all over with nearly 70 households and over 300 residents.|||Traditionally, the people of Pom Coong still build unique stilt houses to live in. The houses are built closely together, separated only by small vegetable plots or narrow fences. Sitting on the doorsteps, people can chat and play together.|||Unlike stilt houses of other ethnic groups, the stilt houses of the Thai people are usually higher, creating a sense of cleanliness and coolness. The floor is about 2 meters above the ground on sturdy wooden pillars. The floor is made of bamboo or split bamboo. The roof is covered with thatch, palm leaves, or improved with bricks. The windows in the house are quite large to catch the cool breeze and also serve as places for the homeowners to hang orchid flower pots, wildflowers, and birdcages.|||Underneath the stilt houses, Thai girls diligently work at the loom to create unique handwoven fabrics that attract tourists. Souvenir products include handwoven fabric panels, bags, and shirts displayed right under the stilt houses in vibrant colors, making the stilt houses of Pom Coong even more prominent.|||Despite being a small village, Pom Coong has up to 4 men's and women's volleyball teams, and two cultural performance teams that regularly practice to socialize and perform for tourists. Tourists who have once visited Pom Coong rarely forget the joyful music from the sap dance, xoe dance, and the dances of Thai boys and girls that captivate the heart. Especially, the locals are hospitable but never hassle or pressure tourists to buy souvenirs. That is also Pom Coong's charm.|||The vitality of Pom Coong's tourism is its clean, purely Thai space. Clean water sources, sanitation facilities, and hygiene infrastructure are well-organized, giving tourists a fresh and safe feeling. Water is mainly from tap water. Waste is sorted, placed in bins, and will be processed. Village roads and alleys are always clean, with no littering by residents.|||Tourists visiting Pom Coong are mainly foreigners, students, and university students passionate about learning about the cultures of ethnic minorities. They come here to better understand the life and people of the Thai ethnic group, immerse themselves in Thai life, and truly enjoy the xoe dances, gong and drum festivals, staying in stilt houses – drinking rice wine, and hiking to admire the hills and people here…

title: Van Village Mai Chau
description: Van Mai Chau, a beautiful tourist village in Hoa Binh, ranks second only to Ban Lac.|||Van Village currently has 94 households with 376 residents, 99% of whom are Thai ethnic people, organized into 5 production teams. The village has 2 homestay families offering accommodation and cultural experiences where visitors can participate in local life. Annually, hundreds of domestic and international tourists visit Van Village.|||Alongside the Thai community in Mai Chau district, the Thai people in Van Village primarily rely on rice farming, animal husbandry, and traditional crafts like weaving and bamboo weaving. Every household maintains clean lanes and hygiene facilities. Modern stilt houses preserve traditional architecture and welcome tourists for stays.|||Visitors to Van Village can explore unique Thai dishes such as steamed sticky rice, grilled fish, and bamboo筒 rice – essential during festivals. Previously, the Thai people used sticky rice daily, with steamed sticky rice being a signature dish. From sticky rice, they create colorful steamed rice with leaves or mix with corn and cassava. Besides, sticky rice is also made into bamboo筒 rice, a popular souvenir for visitors. Though close to the town, Van Village retains the rustic simplicity of the Thai people.|||Here, visitors can admire stilt houses hidden among bamboo groves, winding terraced fields, green corn and cassava terraces creating a poetic landscape. Walking through the village, guests witness the simple lives of locals, encountering friendly smiles and warm greetings. As dusk falls, sharing a humble meal with the community, guests enjoy the spicy aroma of communal wine and join in the graceful Thai dance. The music and dance rhythms help visitors forget stress and find peace.|||Visitors arriving in early year can participate in folk games like 'to mac le', tug-of-war, 'keng loong', spear-throwing, blowguns, and other revived games enriching the Thai community's cultural life.|||With its highland village characteristics, Van Village preserves and promotes ethnic cultural values, promotes community tourism development, and becomes an ideal stop for domestic and international tourists.

title: Bong Lai Temple
description: Located at the foot of Dau Rong Mountain in Ward 3 Cao Phong town Hoa Binh province about 10 km south of Hoa Binh city center Bong Lai Temple (also called Thang Bong Lai Temple) enshrines Dei Nhi Thượng Ngan Tien Nhuong (i.e. Co Doi Thang Ngan) and the various immortal saints of Tu Phu. Legend has it that this is where Co Doi met Thanh Mau Dei Nhi (Mau Thang Ngan) and where she transformed.|||The temple was built in 1890 and renovated in late 2013 on an area of over 5000 m² to meet the religious needs of the local population and visitors from afar.|||Passing through the Tam Quan gate leads to a wide courtyard with two rows of side halls. The left row enshrines the Co (Tu Phu Thanh Co) and the right row enshrines the Cau (Tu Phu Thanh Cau). The main hall consists of three bays decorated with carvings red pillars golden scrolls and elegant couplets in a grand solemn style.|||The outermost bay enshrines Cong Dong Quan Hoang Trieu (Quan Hoang Doi) and Quan Dieu That (Quan Lon Dieu That). The second bay enshrines Jade Emperor Tu Phu Thanh Hoang and Tran Dynasty. The third bay enshrines Tu Phu Chau Ba Son Trang Thuong and Son Trang Thoai. The rear hall houses the altar for Tam Toa Thanh Mau and Co Doi Thang Ngan.

title: Thac Bo Cave
description: From Hoa Binh City, follow National Highway 6 south for over 20km to Cao Phong town, turn right and continue a short distance to reach Thung Nai tourist pier (Thung Nai commune). From here, visitors board a boat and travel upstream along the Da River for about 17km to reach Ngoc landing at the foot of Chua mountain.|||During the dry season, visitors must climb nearly 100 stone steps to reach the cave entrance. In the rainy season, they can simply walk from the boat to a floating house and cross a bamboo bridge to admire the cave's stunning scenery. From the entrance, visitors can look out to the vast Da River and the surrounding layered mountain ranges.|||The cave is named Thac Bo because it is located next to Thac Bo waterfall (also called Thac Van Bo or Gheng Hoa). Thac Bo Cave is over 100m deep, with the widest section exceeding 20m, divided into three zones. From the entrance, visitors enter the reception area with stone benches for resting and sightseeing. This area has a high ceiling, spacious interior, and cool atmosphere. On the cave walls, large clusters of stalactites hang down. Notably, there is a large stalactite shaped like a carp transforming into a dragon or a human figure nearly 2m tall.|||Crossing a small 30m bridge over a small pond leads to the central zone. This area is likened to a "stone forest" due to its layers of stalactites and stalagmites with unusual shapes rising from the cave floor and hanging from the ceiling. Some resemble clusters of bright lights, others like a colorful flower garden, and some look like spiky cacti. Particularly, in the middle of this area stands a 10m-high stone pillar surrounded by smaller pillars.|||From the central zone, climbing stone steps about 50m long leads to the Buddhist worship area, approximately 30m long and 15m wide. The high ceiling creates a cool atmosphere with stalactites shaped like Buddha statues. This area also features altars for Buddha and deities governing the region.|||Thac Bo Cave was recognized as a national heritage site by the Ministry of Culture, Sports, and Tourism in 2007.

title: Afternoon Cave
description: Afternoon Cave is one of the famous tourist attractions in Mai Chau town Hoa Binh. It is considered a precious gem among the mysterious Mai Chau. Every time sunrise rises and sunset falls the cave's every corner which has been designed miraculously by nature becomes even more splendid and attractive. The glistening stalactites attract every visitor's gaze as soon as they enter the cave.|||After walking about 15m visitors will reach the main chamber of Afternoon Cave with a height of over 50m and a length of about 50m. Observing all the stalactites in the cave visitors can truly appreciate nature's ingenuity in creating such diverse formations each offering a different association. They grow everywhere in the cave forming special layered structures on the floor walls and ceiling with natural shapes.|||In the central area directly opposite the entrance are stone formations resembling a sage seated at about 20m height. On the cave floor one side has a dinosaur and the other a kneeling stone goat guarding and protecting the eternal slumber of all living things. Moving deeper to the right visitors encounter a giant resting camel. Behind the camel is a 25m tall time tree with a diameter of 2 to 3m featuring nodes like a natural calendar. The tree was formed by water droplets dripping from the ceiling over millions of years.|||The cave is named Afternoon Cave because when the afternoon sun shines into the cave the stalactites reflect beautiful shimmering light creating magical glows in visitors' eyes. Many visitors are amazed to see the crystal-like reflections making the cave glow as if a gemstone radiates light outward.|||The flowing paths of small water streams winding between the stalactites resemble small rivers in a miniature map. To visit and admire this natural masterpiece visitors must climb 1200 steps a long journey to witness these creations.

title: Ancient Dong Thech Tomb
description: Located in Chieng Dong hamlet, Vinh Dong commune, Kim Bui district, Hoa Binh province, the Ancient Dong Thech Tomb was once considered a sacred and inviolable place for the local people.|||It was precisely because of many legends woven over generations that the Ancient Dong Thech Tomb became a desolate holy site, feared and avoided by people for over 400 years until 1954, when the first footsteps arrived here and the mysteries of this vast land gradually began to be revealed.|||Even the name 'Ancient Dong Thech Tomb' has caused many people to shudder in fear. 'Dong' is an ancient term referring to stone tombs. 'Thech' is the name of an old location in Muong Dong. Thus, Dong Thech refers to clusters of stone tombs placed closely together. This burial site is now located in a valley surrounded by hills, forests, and dense vegetation. It is bordered by Dong Nai Hill, Thech Hill, Thech Stream, and Rang Dong.|||The Ancient Dong Thech Tomb is believed to have existed for over 400 years. It is the burial site of the Dinh clan, led by Dinh Nhu Lenh. Alongside them were the Quach, Bach, and Ha clans, who were once noble local lords sharing governance over the vast Muong Dong land. Some rumors suggest that in addition to burying members of the Dinh clan, this site may also be the final resting place of many servants of officials.|||In the 17th-18th centuries, Dinh Cong Ky of the Dinh clan achieved great merits under King Le Trung Hung. The Dinh clan was later renamed Dinh Cong. When Dinh Cong Ky was alive, it was said he was extremely brutal, cruel, and authoritarian. Upon his death, he was posthumously granted the title of Marquis. King Le Trung Hung even sent people to Thanh Hoa to fetch green stone tablets for his tomb. Descendants of the Dinh family later received similar stone tablets when they died.|||Many rumors claim that a Dinh clan official, after death, wanted to protect buried treasures and forced many young men and women to be buried alive. These young people, out of resentment, transformed into ghosts that harmed people. This superstition is one reason why no one dared to approach this ancient tomb.|||Previously, hundreds of stone tombs lay scattered in the area, creating a strange and eerie landscape of stone pillars of varying heights and sizes in a dense valley. Due to its 'dragon's eye' location—a favorable feng shui site—surrounded by wilderness and tall trees that blocked sunlight, the Ancient Dong Thech Tomb remained inaccessible and untouched for a time, until 1954 when the first archaeological and exploration teams arrived at this 'sacred site'.|||Today, despite being recognized as a historically and archaeologically significant site and a new tourist attraction, many mysteries of the Ancient Dong Thech Tomb remain unsolved. The site has also been reduced in size due to human activity. Many tombs still exist, but ancient Chinese characters on the stone tablets have faded, and some smaller tombs have been nearly flattened.

title: Bell Temple
description: From Hanoi, follow National Highway 5 for about 28km east, travelers will reach Pho Noi town. From here, continue along National Highway 39 for about 34km south to reach Bell Temple.|||Bell Temple has the Chinese name "Kim Chung Tu", meaning Golden Bell Temple. Legend has it that in a year of great flood, a wooden raft was swept by the current into the riverbank of Nhan Duy hamlet, An Tao commune, Kim Dong district, Khoai Chau province, Hung Yen province (now Phuong Hien Nam, Hung Yen City).|||On the raft was a very beautiful golden bell. The local people tried every way to bring the bell to shore, but finally only the people of Nhan Duy hamlet succeeded. Believing it was heaven's blessing, the villagers contributed labor and resources to build the temple and bell tower. From then on, the temple was named Kim Chung Tu (Golden Bell Temple).|||Bell Temple was first built during the Later Le period (15th century). After many restorations, it now features the "Nội công ngoại quốc" architectural style, facing south, aligning with Buddhist beliefs of happiness and goodness. The temple complex is symmetrically arranged along a straight axis from the Tam Quan gate to the House of Ancestors.|||The Tam Quan gate has decorative elements influenced by Chinese art, such as raised dragon carvings and reliefs of the four disciples of Tang Sanzang traveling to fetch scriptures in the West. Beyond the Tam Quan gate is a blue stone bridge built in 1702, crossing the dragon-eyes pond. Continuing through the wide courtyard leads to the main hall with 5 bays and 2 side wings, constructed in the conical roof style. Between the main hall and the upper hall is a small courtyard with a four-faced stone pillar inscribed in Chinese, recording the merits of the people who restored the temple.|||The upper hall also has 5 bays and 2 side wings, similar to the main hall. Inside the upper hall are many beautiful statues such as the Three Realms, Bodhisattvas: Van Thu, Pho Hien, Jade Emperor, Nam Tao, Bac Dou, Buddha Sakyamuni, and Buddha Amitabha. Beyond the upper hall are two symmetrical corridors leading to the Mother's house, Ancestors' house, and bell tower. These corridors house many statues arranged in order. First is the group depicting the Hell of Ten Kings, illustrating the torment people face in the afterlife. Next are the Eight Bodhisattvas, followed by the Eighteen Arhats, the Lord of the Temple, flanked by Gi Lan - Chanh Tai, and finally the Sage of Heaven, beside Diem Nhien - Dai Sy.|||Besides its beautiful architecture, Bell Temple preserves valuable artifacts like horizontal scrolls and couplets, especially the stone stele "Kim Chung Tu Stone Bi Ký" erected in the 7th year of Vinh Thinh (1711). The stele lists names of donors who restored the temple and describes the beauty and streets of Pho Hien.|||In 1992, Bell Temple was recognized as a national architectural art heritage site by the Ministry of Culture and Information (now the Ministry of Culture, Sports, and Tourism).

title: Phuc Lam Temple
description: Phuc Lam Temple Hung Yen is located in La Mat hamlet Phu Uong commune An Thoi district Hung Yen province. This is an attractive spiritual tourism destination about 1 hour drive from Hanoi. With the peaceful serene village scenery and eye catching architecture Phuc Lam Hung Yen Temple has become a temple attracting many visitors to visit.|||Phuc Lam Hung Yen Temple is an ancient temple that has existed for a long time and recently underwent major renovation. With its unique and impressive architecture the temple has been compared to the golden temples of Thailand.|||Anyone visiting Phuc Lam Temple for the first time is amazed by the fairyland like space. The temple not only attracts the elderly but also the youth who frequently visit due to Phuc Lam s captivating beauty.|||The temple grounds cover over 4 hectares with many green trees and beautifully arranged small landscapes. The temple has 4 massive towers and giant Buddha statues exuding a sacred mysterious yet serene and peaceful atmosphere. The temple is a sacred place for people of Hung Yen to pray for wealth luck and peace.

title: Phoenix Temple
description: The temple has a triangular-shaped architecture with an interlocking overlapping structure.|||The two ends have two pillars, the top of the pillars shaped like lotus buds. The eaves are carved with soft floral patterns.|||The center of the front hall is arranged with an altar, with two couplets on either side praising the merits of Cuc Hoa. The left side hangs a large bell cast during the Bao Dai era. The central hall and main hall are placed with a large wooden cabinet.|||Inside the cabinet is the statue of Cuc Hoa. On either side of the cabinet are enshrined Deu Ong and Thanh Hoang. The innermost part is constructed in a layered style, arranged with Buddha statues.

title: Da Huc Village
description: Da Huc Village is located in the center of Binh Son Ward Luc Nam District Bac Giang about 8 km. Along the inter-ward road running through the village looking up is the deep green of the primary forest – the green lim forest. At the forest edge is the ancient communal house overlooking the Cao Lan ethnic community's settlement.|||To Van Thanh the village head stated that the green lim forest of the Cao Lan ethnic people here has been owned for a long time. The forest covers about 6 hectares with nearly 200 lim trees and many other precious wood species. Over the years the lim forest has been cared for and protected by the villagers as a village treasure.|||Elderly village member To Van Quang Danh 82 years old shared From when I was a child the lim forest has been like this. My ancestors also said that when they were born the lim forest was already lush green It can only be said that the lim trees here are hundreds of years old. Among them two lim trees to the left of the communal house are about 50 meters tall with a canopy width of approximately 25 meters and trunks so large that 3-4 people cannot encircle them.|||The locals still share many mysterious stories around the green lim forest and the ancient communal house. The Da Huc communal house beside the green lim forest has become sacred and is a source of pride and reverence for the Cao Lan ethnic people here. No one dares to recklessly cut down branches or trees in the lim forest.|||Every year during the March 15th festival or the Cao Lan ethnic people's ritual days everyone gathers to clean the communal house clear weeds and care for the lim forest to remain evergreen. Whenever there are major family or clan events the villagers usually bring offerings to the communal house to invoke the Forest God for a life of constant good fortune and peace.

title: Au Co National Mother Temple
description: Au Co National Mother Temple is located on the Red River bank in Hung Cuong commune, Hung Yen city.|||This temple has a quiet atmosphere with three sides surrounded by fields and the remaining side bordering the Red River. Not far away is an ancient, solemn temple forming a pristine and ancient historical site.|||According to the temple records, when King Le Dai Hanh drove out the enemy from the borders of Dai Viet, he passed by the Temple of the Lady and stopped for lunch. There, the king was visited by National Mother Au Co in a dream. Later, 24 strong men from Hoang Xa village, with unusual appearances, volunteered to help the king fight the enemy. After the victory, the 24 young men ascended to heaven. Moved by the devotion of National Mother Au Co and the 24 men who helped the country, King Le Dai Hanh bestowed the title "National Mother Anh Linh Thuong Dang – Great King Bach Tôn God".|||Au Co National Mother Temple is the oldest temple in Vietnam. The temple, which enshrines National Mother Au Co and National Ancestor Lac Long Quan, was built in 981. Over 1,000 years have passed, but the temple remains intact and retains its rare ancient charm.|||Annually, the Au Co National Mother Temple festival is held from the 7th to 10th of the third lunar month to return to the roots and honor wise and sacred figures. Particularly in 2014, the temple was honored to receive the record for the oldest architecture in Vietnam and the heaviest bánh chưng in Vietnam, weighing over 5 tons, offered to ancestors and the Hung Kings, and served to people within and outside the province to admire and enjoy...

title: Thien Hau Temple
description: Thien Hau Temple was built in 1640 by 40 Chinese families from Guangdong, Guangxi, and Fujian provinces.|||The temple was constructed in traditional Chinese architectural style with elements like Tam Quan gate, altar house, curved roof eaves, and wooden truss structure. The design and decorative carvings were pre-made in China before being transported to Vietnam for assembly.|||The temple venerates Lady Lin Shimu, the sixth daughter of Lin Nguyet from Putian, Fujian Province, born on the 23rd of March in the first year of Song Jianlong (960). According to legend, she was born with a fragrant aroma and radiant light. During a famine, she discovered a type of seaweed to make rice cakes and a type of oil from a sesame-like plant to help the poor survive.|||In the fourth year of Song Yongxi (987), she passed away on the 9th of September without illness. Legends say she died on a day of "Heavenly Immortals Playing Music." The four characters "Bach Nhat Phi Thanh" carved on the temple's sedan chair symbolize her ascension. She became the Sea Goddess, worshipped in coastal areas for rescuing sailors in distress.|||The temple features a high and wide Tam Quan gate with blue-tiled decorative squares on the walls. The front courtyard has two granite lions and large stone steps. The main hall uses Bat Trang bricks, curved fish-tail roof tiles, and front doors carved with civil and military officials in red and blue. The eaves of the front altar house depict stories from Romance of the Three Kingdoms and Journey to the West.|||Today, the temple preserves 32 imperial decrees and large calligraphy works praising the goddess. Side rooms contain altars for her parents, brother, and Chinese families who contributed to the temple. Annual festivals occur on the 23rd of March (her birthday) and 9th of September (her death anniversary), with traditional foods like Dong Cau cakes, Siu candies, Turtle cakes, and To Chau cakes offered.|||Thien Hau Temple is one of the few preserved Chinese historical sites in Pho Hien. Hung Yen province restored it in 1990 as a national cultural heritage site.

title: Dong Cao Bac Giang
description: In recent years Dong Cao has become a popular weekend camping destination for young travelers who enjoy adventure tourism. With its cool fresh climate and pristine beauty Dong Cao is often compared to Mau Son in Bac Giang. According to evaluations it is one of the most amazing spots for campfires as well as waiting for beautiful moments at sunrise. Together Phuot shares some travel tips for Dong Cao as well as important information to help you plan and invite friends to explore this place.|||Located about 160km northeast of Hanoi Dong Cao is a small plateau in Ban Ga Thach Son commune Son Dong district Bac Giang province. Although called Dong Cao the actual elevation of the plateau is only about 600m above sea level from the highest point. With its relatively flat valley-like terrain and isolation from nearby settlements Dong Cao is a suitable and ideal location for setting up tents campfires and social gatherings.|||Located in the Northeast at 600m elevation Dong Cao has a cool summer climate and relatively cold winters. The road to Dong Cao is mostly unpaved and quite steep making it unsuitable for travel during rain. With this information Together Phuot recommends visiting Dong Cao from September to November when the North has almost no rain showers and hasn't yet entered winter offering dry weather ideal for camping. If visiting in summer June-August monitor the weather to avoid rainy or stormy periods.

title: Thu Sy Weaving Craft Village
description: The Thu Sy weaving craft village in Tien Lu district Hung Yen province has been over 200 years old and still exists today. These are common tools used by farmers in the Red River Delta of Northern Vietnam to catch shrimp crabs and fish.|||In the past the weaving craft was vibrant in Thu Sy with every household weaving. Today due to the use of chemicals and pesticides in rice fields shrimp and fish have decreased. Along with societal development new more efficient fishing tools for deep water areas have emerged so Thu Sy now has only about 500 people who know how to weave traps.|||Annually Thu Sy supplies about 700000 products to provinces such as Ha Nam Nam Dinh Bac Ninh Bac Giang which have lowland plains and many canals and rivers and are also exported to countries like the US Singapore Japan India for interior decoration.|||Although weaving is a secondary craft in Thu Sy during farming breaks it provides 50% of the stable income to support the local people's livelihood.

title: Cam Son Lake
description: Cam Son Lake is located in four communes: Son Hai, Ho Dap, Tan Son, and Cam Son, Luc Yen district, Bac Giang province. This is an area with a picturesque landscape. It also contains the unique cultural identity of the local community.|||From Bac Giang city follow National Highway 1A for about 60 km northeast to National Highway 279 turn right onto the national highway for approximately 5 km with both sides featuring vast fields of lush corn and stilt houses of the Dao and San Chay people faintly visible amidst the green mountains and forests you arrive at Cam Son Lake|||Located at an altitude of about 300m above sea level Cam Son Lake is the fourth largest large hydraulic project in the country (after Dau Tieng Lake in Tay Ninh Phu Ninh Lake in Quang Nam and Ke Go Lake in Ha Tinh) with the task of regulating and supplying irrigation water for agricultural production in Luc Ngan district (Bac Giang) and Huu Luong district (Lang Son province) regulating water sources in the upper reaches of the Thuong River and controlling floods for downstream areas in Lang Giang Yen Dong districts and Bac Giang city (Bac Giang province)|||Cam Son Lake has a water capacity of 248 million cubic meters with an average water surface area of about 2650 hectares. In the dry season when the water recedes the lakebed reveals thick alluvial deposits that local people utilize for growing corn and mixed crops. In the rainy season the lake expands with hundreds of large and small islands scattered across it. Surrounding the lake are high mountains that remain a single green color all year round undulating and overlapping. The beauty of sky clouds mountains and water blending together creates a landscape that is incredibly poetic and enchanting no different from a miniature version of Halong Bay. With its picturesque mountain and water scenery Cam Son is the inspiration for composer Pho Duc Phuong's famous song Lake on the Mountain.|||Studies also show that Cam Son Lake is a suitable habitat for many high-value aquatic species such as shrimp crab lang fish catfish and perch especially sturgeon a cold-water species Currently sturgeon raised in Cam Son weigh between 3 to 4 kg per fish and are consumed in the domestic market and exported overseas|||In addition to abundant natural resources, Cam Son also preserves the unique cultural heritage of the Tay, Nung, Dao, and San Chay ethnic communities. Visitors can admire stilt houses with smoky evening mists hidden among hills and forests; listen to the deep melodies of Sli and Shoong hao; witness unique festivals such as rice planting ceremonies, harvest prayers, New Year celebrations, and housewarming ceremonies; and especially immerse themselves in the romantic atmosphere on boats and shores—a distinctive cultural feature of Cam Son. In the early mornings or evenings, hundreds of boats carrying goods bustle on the lake. Floating markets selling items like sticky rice cakes, seven-color sticky rice, pork, mountain chicken, fruits, and more create a vibrant scene in this mountainous region.|||Currently, Bac Giang province is calling for golf investment projects and developing mountain climbing, fishing, and resort tourism in the Cam Son Lake area. The province is also building a tourist route connecting Cam Son Lake with Khuon Thanh Lake, Ba Hon Mountain, Cam Stream, Moc Stream, Vay Rong Stream, Kin Mountain, Man Village, Lan Loc Island (Bac Giang); Doy Cave, Gio Cave (Chi Lang District, Lang Son Province). It is hoped that in the future, the Cam Son Lake tourist area will become one of the top destinations for resort and ecological tourism in northern Vietnam.

title: Nom Village
description: Nom Village is located in Dai Dong commune Van Lam district Hung Yen province about 20 km from Hanoi. Over the years Nom Village remains a cherished and preserved land by the people of Hung Yen. In the midst of a bustling fast-paced life it's rare to find a place as tranquil as this. The architectural cultural and human beauty remains intact after over 200 years of change.|||Due to this enduring beauty tourism in Nom Village has drawn significant attention. Stepping away from the city visiting a small village you'll feel both familiar and new. The traditional simple beauty of the architecture culture and people remains as the ancient village of Van Lam. Through the moss-covered village gate the inner scene features typical characteristics of an old Vietnamese village. The small houses are all stained with time and daily life of the villagers proceeds calmly and peacefully. The feeling is extremely comfortable and relaxed.|||A visit to Nom Village would be incomplete without experiencing the local culture. Besides enjoying the specialty dishes of Hung Yen visiting Nom Village offers an opportunity to learn about the local culture through its architecture and attractions. Passing through the village gate Nom Market is the most authentic rural market experience in Vietnam. Nom Market was once the most bustling market in Van Lam. The market is simple without concrete structures like city markets.|||The rows of houses in the market are made of bricks and tiles with moss. The goods may not be numerous but are very fresh. Inside the market amidst the cheerful chatter of the villagers you feel unexpectedly joyful.|||An attractive site in Nom Village is Nom Temple. The temple is also known as Linh Thong Ancient Temple. According to Han script documents the temple was built on a large pine hill during the Later Le period. However through analysis of the terracotta statues inside many archaeologists believe the temple has existed for about a thousand years. Nom Temple features distinct East Asian architecture typical of ancient Vietnamese temples. The temple houses over 100 terracotta statues with exquisite carvings. The temple is very sacred and cherished by the people of Nom Village.

title: Van Ha Wine Village
description: Visitors to Bac Giang are captivated by its beauty, the people's warmth, and the culinary delights of the Kinh Bac region, leaving with lingering memories and a reluctance to depart. This sentiment was experienced by Hoang Tuan Anh, Director of the Hai Phong Tourism Promotion Center. We proudly present it to you.|||Van Ha, a famous site in Viet Yen district, Bac Giang province, is renowned for its specialty Van Ham wine, a particularly fragrant and delicious wine that has captivated generations. The royal tribute wine, known as Van Fragrant Beauty Wine, was praised by Emperor Le Hy Tong with poetic accolades. Locals take pride in this centuries-old tradition, as the wine was once a royal court delicacy during feudal dynasties.|||"Van Fragrant Beauty Wine lingers in the North|||The victory of Ru Nguyet shines in the South"|||Van Ham wine's reputation for its rich aroma is well known. Connoisseurs and lovers of traditional wines consider it a regional specialty that can rival any premium whisky worldwide, thanks to its unique flavor of golden glutinous rice, the rich aroma of 35 secret medicinal yeast varieties, and its smooth, carefully aged texture that eliminates harsh alcohol and aldehyde. Even those unfamiliar with wine will never forget a single tasting, as the sweet, fruit-like cocktail sensation overpowers the burn, leaving a gentle, lingering warmth that fades into a pleasant wakefulness.|||In today's world of diverse Western wines, visiting Kinh Bac and enjoying Van Ham wine with its hospitable people truly makes one feel 'intoxicated.' This is not just from the smooth, fragrant wine or the never-ending clay jars, but from the heartfelt greetings and the warm, welcoming spirit of Bac Giang's people, whose hospitality has been celebrated for millennia through folk songs.|||Only by tasting Van Ham wine in Bac Giang can one fully grasp the meaning of 'beautiful wine.' It's not just about the aroma and taste, but also the elegance of wine culture, which is why emperors of old chose Van Ham for royal banquets. This is why not only ancient scholars praised it with the term 'beautiful wine,' but modern artists also composed heartfelt songs:|||Song Cau rises, Song Cau falls, one cup of Van Ham wine intoxicates a lifetime.|||Van Ham wine needs no drinking to intoxicate, remembering the folk songs of distant days.

title: Tho Ha Craft Village
description: Tho Ha Village is surrounded by rivers on three sides like an island, to leave the village you must take a boat or ferry. Visiting Tho Ha you will see vermicelli sheets everywhere in the village roads alleys walls ponds rooftops wherever there is sunlight.|||Walking around the ancient Tho Ha village you will see peaceful and poetic countryside scenes. At the end of Tho Ha village you will see familiar figures by the charcoal stove skillfully roasting vermicelli. The large roasted vermicelli sheets are hot golden crispy and delicious.|||Visiting Tho Ha Craft Village you can learn how to make vermicelli from selecting rice soaking grinding flour steaming drying and cutting which requires meticulousness. Any haste can ruin an entire batch of vermicelli with so much effort.|||Starting from Hanoi to reach Tho Ha Craft Village you can choose buses motorbikes or taxis which are very convenient.|||Motorbike From Hanoi follow National Highway 1 north 31km to Bac Ninh then turn left and go another 3km to Pho Dang go upstream along the Cau River dike 1km to Van Ha ferry after crossing the ferry you will reach Tho Ha Craft Village.|||Bus To take a bus from Hanoi to Tho Ha take bus route 54 Long Bien to Bac Ninh city with a travel time of about 1h20m then take a taxi or motorbike to Van Ha ferry to reach Tho Ha Village.|||Before becoming famous for vermicelli Tho Ha was known as a pottery village. Today visiting Tho Ha Craft Village in Bac Giang you can see ancient houses hundreds of years old made from porcelain shards with unique architecture. The scenic landscape with trees ponds old temples and ancient houses creates a beautiful picture attracting tourists.|||Visiting Tho Ha Craft Village you will see rows of vermicelli sheets under the beautiful sunlight. Vermicelli roasted on charcoal stoves is crispy golden and just looking at it makes you want to eat.|||Enjoy Tho Ha coconut vermicelli with a cup of cool green tea to fully experience the delicious flavor of this Bac Giang specialty. Visiting Tho Ha Craft Village you can also visit other famous attractions like:|||Tho Ha Temple This is a famous temple in Kinh Bac region and a national relic. Tho Ha Temple is the second oldest temple in Bac Giang built in 1576.|||Bo Da Temple This temple is located on Bo Da Mountain north of the Cau River in Tien Son commune Viet Yen district Bac Giang province.|||Ba Chua Kho Temple Located halfway up Kho Mountain Ba Chua Kho Temple is in Co Mi area Vu Ninh ward Bac Ninh very close to the route to Tho Ha Village. Especially during the first days of the new year Ba Chua Kho Temple is a popular destination for people to pray for luck and wealth.

title: Danh Mountain
description: Located 20 km northwest of Bac Giang city Danh Mountain lies on the territory of Lien Chung and Viet Lap communes Tan Yen district. The mountain is large and gracefully winding with the highest peak about 117 m above sea level. Danh Mountain is a place of beautiful natural scenery surrounded by a system of sacred historical sites and mystical landscapes.|||Situated on the summit of Danh Mountain is Dang Temple from which one can overlook the surrounding area and nearby regions of the district. This is a cultural religious site of the local people.|||The Dang Temple complex includes three temples Trinh Temple Thuong Temple and Ha Temple. Dang Temple was built to worship Cao Son Quy Minh deities. In life Cao Son and Quy Minh were skilled generals and after death became sacred spirits who protected the people from disasters and were worshipped by generations. No one knows the exact construction date of Dang Temple but based on historical artifacts like stone pillars ancient incense burners ritual objects and stone altars preserved in the temple it was built during the Le Dynasty in the 18th century.|||Through many historical periods especially during the anti-French resistance the temple was heavily damaged and no longer intact as before. However the local people have repeatedly restored and renovated the temple making it more elegant while retaining many ancient distinctive features.|||With its winding undulating terrain of steep and gentle slopes visiting Danh Mountain offers a spiritual ecological pilgrimage experience. The mountain is surrounded by vast pine and eucalyptus forests many of which are old-growth trees. The fresh cool air creates a peaceful atmosphere. The path up Danh Mountain has 345 brick steps. At the foot of the mountain is a small well named Mu Voi Well. The well is about 2 m deep and has been reinforced with brick and cement around its edges. Locals believe the well never runs dry.|||Visiting Danh Mountain allows tourists to admire the vast majestic landscape and enjoy precious local products like Nam Sâm ginseng which has been cherished for generations|||Nam Sâm famous from Danh Mountain|||Markets overflow with Chung Son ginseng|||Nam Sâm famous from Danh Mountain|||Heals blindness restores eyesight as before.|||Dang Temple is the cultural religious center where the local community has held traditional festivals from ancient times. The festival is held on the 19th 20th and 21st days of the first lunar month annually attracting many visitors to attend the festival visit the scenic area and pay homage to the temple.

title: Van Mieu Hung Yen
description: Van Mieu Hung Yen was first built in the 17th century on the site of Xich Dang village temple, Nhan Duc commune, An Tao district, Kim Dong district in the past, now Lam Son ward, Hung Yen City. The temple was most extensively restored and renovated in the Year of the Pig, 1839 under the Minh Mang era's 20th year.|||Van Mieu has a T-shaped architectural structure, including Front Hall, Central Hall, and Rear Hall. The roof system of the buildings is interconnected in the style of "Trung Thiem Diep Oc". Van Mieu faces south, with the Nghi Mon Gate built grandly and imposingly, resembling the gate of Hanoi's Van Mieu. Inside the gate is a wide courtyard, with a ten-aisle path in the center, and on both sides are the bell tower and drum tower along with two rows of left and right pavilions.|||The inner temple area includes Front Hall, Central Hall, and Rear Hall, with similar architecture built in the truss and hidden pillar style. The entire inner temple area shines with a system of large calligraphy, couplets, hanging doors, and truss columns all gilded and lacquered beautifully.|||The most valuable artifacts of Van Mieu are 9 stone steles listing scholars (from Hung Yen and Thai Binh provinces) belonging to the Tran, Mac, Le, and Nguyen dynasties. Van Mieu is also a historical site that proves the tradition of love for learning of Hung Yen people.|||In the past, Van Mieu had two festival seasons, with the main festivals on February 10th and August 10th annually. On these days, Confucian scholars and provincial officials had to attend Van Mieu for rituals, demonstrating Confucian traditions, respecting teachers and the path, and praying for educational progress.|||Today, during the beginning of spring, cultural activities take place at Xich Dang Van Mieu, including incense offering ceremonies, calligraphy exhibitions, and ca tru singing...|||To preserve the nation's cultural values, Van Mieu Hung Yen is gradually being restored and planned according to its original form.

title: Huong Lang Temple
description: Huong Lang Temple also known as Lang Temple or Giac Vien Temple is located in Huong Lang hamlet Minh Hai commune Van Lam district Hung Yen province. Besides worshipping Buddha Huong Lang Temple also worships Empress Y Lan a woman skilled in state affairs and managing the household during the Ly Dynasty. This is a beautiful architectural masterpiece with historical cultural and scientific value.|||It is said that the temple was built by Empress Yi Lan during the Lý dynasty around 1115. The temple has a large scale covering nearly one hectare consisting of multiple buildings with an inner palace outer court architectural layout. It includes a three arched gate with three entrances a three step staircase leading up to a flat platform. The temple is divided into three levels from the first to the second level there are also three steps and the third level is the main area. This area includes monks quarters a council hall and the main hall. During the anti French resistance the temple was destroyed and was restored in 1955.|||The temple faces Lang River. The front hall is arranged on a high stone staircase with carved crocodile-shaped steps. The structure features a wooden beam and column system with four rows of pillars. All pillars are placed on stone bases decorated with lotus petal motifs in Lý Dynasty style. The wooden beams are made of teakwood carved with floral patterns. The raised parts of the statues are smooth even and meticulously crafted without abrupt breaks. This is the largest existing statue base of the Lý Dynasty preserved at the site. Additionally the temple has ten pairs of stone handrails carved with phoenixes badgers and ivy chrysanthemums; four square stone pillars supporting the stone beams and many stone column bases intricately carved with lotus and chrysanthemum petals. These are invaluable works of the Lý Dynasty still preserved.|||The main hall faces the temple's main direction towards Lang River, near the village road, restored in 2005 with a scale of 7 bays, 20m long and 5m wide. To enter the front hall, one must pass through steps divided into 5 paths by 6 staircases with carved stone crocodiles facing forward. The front hall features an architectural style with overlapping beams and brackets supported by four rows of column bases, all columns resting on stone bases decorated with lotus petal patterns in Ly Dynasty style. The beam structures are made of rosewood with carved stylized floral motifs.|||The rear hall is separated from the front hall by an open space. The rear hall has an overlapping eaves style architecture with two tiers and eight roofs. In the center of the rear hall is the "Linh Vat" lion supporting a lotus throne forming a large stone base. This lotus-shaped stone base has a total length of 4.2m width of 3.5m and height of 1.15m assembled from square stone blocks carved with soft lotus patterns the raised blocks on the surface are almost without sharp edges all are smooth even and meticulously crafted with no sudden breaks in the rhythm. This is a distinctive feature of Ly Dynasty sculpture art.|||The rectangular base is made of rectangular stone slabs, constructed with stone. The base consists of four tiers that gradually narrow inward, each step 0.13m high and 0.5m wide. The stone pedestal features lion carvings assembled from multiple stone slabs. The sides of the statues have been damaged, leaving only the ends. This is considered the largest remaining stone pedestal from the Lý Dynasty preserved at the site. The Buddha statue seated on this pedestal was lost during the anti-French resistance, so in 2005, the Temple Site Management Board and the local community contributed funds to create a new Avalokiteshvara statue with a thousand eyes and thousand hands placed on the pedestal. Additionally, in the main hall, there are statues of virtuous figures and Emperor Tran Trieu.|||Chua Huong Lang currently preserves many unique and distinctive relics from the Ly period. Also at this site, people discovered a site named Chua Lang Site, including a lion statue also known as Mr. Sam. The statue was made from a large stone slab, 2.80 meters long, 1.50 meters wide, and 0.90 meters high, used as a base for a statue that no longer exists. Both ends of the stone slab are carved into the shape of the lion's head and back. The lion's face is depicted as valiant, with a large rounded nose, bulging eyes like two eggs, and a high forehead. The lion's hindquarters are rounded, densely decorated with spiral patterns and lotus vines; four square stone pillars at the four corners support the stone beams of the previous structure, and many column base stones are carved with lotus petals and chrysanthemums.|||The temple has ten stone handrails carved with phoenixes civet cats and ivy chrysanthemums four square stone pillars at the corners supporting stone beams from the previous structure and many stone column bases carved with lotus petals and chrysanthemums. Inside the temple there is a stone stele recording the temple renovation in the 16th century.|||Due to its cultural-historical, artistic, and architectural values, Huong Lang Temple was ranked as a National Architectural and Artistic Heritage Site by the Ministry of Culture and Information (now the Ministry of Culture, Sports, and Tourism) on March 13, 1974.

title: Phu Thi Temple
description: Phu Thi Temple is located on a large site, outside and at the foot of the Red River dike, in Me So commune, Van Giang district, Hung Yen province. The temple was built in the shape of a "Dinh" (丁) character, facing southwest, and has the Chinese name Hung Phuc Tu.|||The temple was built during the Later Le dynasty and follows the Northern School. It has been restored multiple times, with the most recent restoration in 1991. Entering the temple, visitors first pass through the tam quan (main gate). Externally, the tam quan appears as three separate structures with three doors. The central door is two-story with a square base. The upper and lower levels are equal in size, with curved eaves on the second floor. The two side doors are symmetrical, with steps leading to the upper level of the central door.|||Beyond the tam quan is the front hall (Thuong Dien). Externally, the front hall is built in the "chong diem" style with bell and drum towers on the roof. The temple bell (Dai Hong Chung) was cast during King Minh Mang's reign. Inside, the front hall consists of five bays with a spacious and open layout. Four rows of lim wood pillars are evenly distributed in the center. The central beam of the front hall features a carved dragon and moon canopy inlaid with gold.|||Against the inner walls are six statues: Khuyen Thien, Trung Ac, two monks, and two attendants. These statues add solemnity to the front hall. Additionally, the temple houses ancient wooden or clay statues such as Chuan Te, Di Toc (1.08m tall), Thap Dien Minh Vuong (0.90m tall), and Cap Co Doc (1.07m tall).|||Following the front hall are four bays of the main hall. The main hall is the ancestral shrine, solemnly arranged with a plaque inscribed "Phuc De Tai Mau". This structure is unique with crab-claw beams and a vaulted ceiling, creating a deep and solemn atmosphere. Below the curved ceiling, the altar is symmetrically arranged for offerings and Buddha statues. Additionally, the temple has a dedicated room for the veneration of Chu Manh Trinh (1862–1905), a scholar who designed and built the temple when he was the provincial judge of Hung Yen.|||With its distinctive ancient architectural value, Phu Thi Temple was recognized as a Historical and Cultural Site on April 4, 1984, under Decision No. 14 of the Ministry of Culture and Information (now the Ministry of Culture, Sports, and Tourism). It is hoped that in the near future, Phu Thi Temple will become an attractive spiritual destination, drawing many visitors for worship and sightseeing.

title: Thai Lac Temple
description: It is said that the temple was built on a high mound called Van Mieu, where the water flows into the river like two dragons approaching the mother dragon. The temple was built during the Tran dynasty facing southeast, a direction symbolizing growth and development.|||After many renovations, Thai Lac Temple has an architecture style of "Nội Công ngoại quốc" consisting of a Front Hall with 9 bays, beams arranged in the "chong ruong gia chien" style. The Sacrificial Hall has 2 bays with simple beam structures. The Upper Hall has 3 bays with well-preserved "gia chien" beam structures showing strong Tran dynasty architectural features, two corridors each with 7 bays, and a Rear Hall with 7 bays decorated with leaf pattern carvings.|||Thai Lac Temple also preserves 20 wooden reliefs in the Tran style depicting various themes. In the central bay of the Upper Hall are carved wooden beams combining architecture and decoration. On the wooden panels are scenes of fairies playing traditional musical instruments: two fairies riding phoenixes, one playing flute, one playing bamboo flute, fairies playing zither, etc. On the supporting panels are scenes of fairies with human heads and bird bodies offering flowers. On the column bases are carvings of mythical creatures holding lotus flower bases. These are valuable artistic works, a precious resource for ancient musical art. The carvings also reflect the spirit of Dong A (Tran dynasty's spirit) with three victories over Mongol invaders in the 13th century. The carvings show the skill and artistry of ancient craftsmen.|||Additionally, the temple preserves three stone steles, large inscriptions, ancient bricks, and statues. These are rare artifacts needing long-term preservation and research.|||Annually, the traditional festival of Thai Lac Temple is held from the 6th to 8th of March lunar calendar. This is a major local festival linked to the rain prayers of the old Thai Lac community, wishing for favorable weather and abundant harvests. The festival mainly takes place at temples honoring the Four Methods across the village, centered at Thai Lac Temple. The ritual involves processions of the Four Methods deities around the village. The festival includes traditional folk games: mooncake making, tug-of-war, clay pot smashing, reenactments of old theatrical stories, etc., attracting many locals and visitors.|||With its spiritual and sculptural values, Thai Lac Temple is a place for visitors to find peace and serenity. This sacred Buddhist site brings tranquility and hopes for good things in life.

title: Da Hoa Temple - Da Trach Temple - Ham Tu Gate - Sậy Beach Heritage Site Complex
description: Located in Khoai Chau district (Hung Yen province), about 20km east of Hanoi and 35km northwest of Hung Yen city center, the Da Hoa Temple - Da Trach Temple - Ham Tu Gate - Sậy Beach heritage site complex preserves unique cultural and historical values to this day. It attracts many locals and visitors from afar.|||To reach the historical site complex, visitors can take two routes: By water, from Chuong Duang Do pier (42 Chuong Duang Do, Hanoi), by boat along the Hong River eastward for over 2 hours to Binh Minh pier (Binh Minh commune, Khoai Chau district), or by land, from Hanoi, following the river embankment road over 20km to Binh Minh commune. From here, visitors will reach the first site in the complex, Den Da Hoa temple located in Da Hoa hamlet, Binh Minh commune.|||Temple Da Hoa|||The temple was built on a high flat rectangular area of 18720m². The main entrance faces west towards Bai Tu Nien (Nghe Dao village Tu Dan commune) – where Princess Tien Dung daughter of the 18th Hung King met Chu Dong Tu and the two formed a marital bond.|||The temple is divided into three areas. The outer area has an area of 7200m² with no surrounding walls. The only structure is a two-story stone stele house with eight curved roofs and four doors facing all directions. Inside the stele house are stone steles describing the temple restoration and the miraculous encounter of Chử Đồng Tử and Tiên Dung. From here, a 6m wide brick path lined with ancient banyan trees leads to the main gate. Beyond the gate is the middle area with 3400m² enclosed by low walls.
