This area features greenery interspersed with two sections: the right side has a bell tower with a 1.5m bronze bell; the left side has a drum pavilion with a 1.2m stone drum. A brick path separates these sections leading from the main gate to the main gate with three doors. Above the main gate hangs a golden plaque with four red-painted characters “Bồng lai cung khuyết”. Passing through the main gate enters the inner area with 11520m². The architecture combines Nguyễn dynasty palace style with harmonious elements of Buddhism, Confucianism and Taoism. The inner area includes: main courtyard, main altar, secondary courtyard, incense burning platform, secondary shrine 1, secondary shrine 2 and the rear sanctuary. Connecting the shrines are pavilions, stables, and gun houses. The rear sanctuary contains three altars: Central altar for Lord Chử Đồng Tử, Left altar for Queen Tien Dung Princess, Right altar for Concubine Hong Van – Tay Sa.|||The overall architectural complex in this area comprises 18 curved-tiled houses shaped like 18 stylized dragon boats.|||This unique architecture aims to recreate the scene of Princess Tien Dung's fleet sailing with sails unfurled along the riverside of yesteryear.|||In addition to its unique architecture, Dang Hoa Temple preserves many rare artifacts, such as: 3 wooden altar sets dating from the late 17th to 18th centuries. These are considered the oldest altar sets found in the country today; a pair of Bach Tho ceramic vases (100 'tho' characters none of which are the same are carved on the vase bodies) ...|||Da Trach Temple|||Leaving Da Hoa Temple visitors will arrive at Da Trach Temple Yen Vinh hamlet Da Trach commune linked to the legend of Da Trach Lake According to legend at the spot where Chu Dong Tu and his two wives Princess Tien Dung and Hong Van ascended to heaven on the 17th day of the 11th lunar month the ground collapsed into a large lake Da Trach Lake the lake formed overnight Believing it to be a divine response the local people built a temple to worship the three in the Da Trach Lake area and named it Da Trach Temple also known as Hoa Temple|||Den Da Trach Temple has been restored many times however the current architecture is the result of the 1890 restoration in the Gong (工) style facing east with a half moon pond and intricately carved dragon phoenix roof decorations consisting of three bays. The rear hall is the most beautifully designed with a three tiered vaulted roof giving visitors the feeling of standing inside a boat cabin. From the outside on the right side first is the earth god shrine of the temple followed by warrior statues then the shrine of the ancestors of Saint Chu Dong Tu on the left is the Bế Ngư Thuyền Quan (Gold Carp Boat Official) shrine featuring a gilded wooden carp statue followed by the shrine of Trieu Viet Vuong (548 – 571). In the center of the rear hall are three altars Saint Chu Dong Tu (center) Queen Tien Dung Princess (left) and Concubine Hong Van (right). The site also houses two horse statues one red and one white. Legend says these were the horses ridden by Saint Chu Dong Tu and his two consorts to cure people of illness|||Besides the main architecture, the temple area also includes a bell tower housing the Da Trach Bell (Da Trach Temple Bell), cast in 1902, 1.5m long, 0.8m wide; two rows of nine rooms, which were previously used to store nine palanquins; two stone steles placed opposite each other (one is broken), erected in 1817, 1.6m tall, 0.8m wide, 0.17m thick; a semicircular pond; many horizontal scrolls and couplets recording the legend of Chu Dong Tu - Tien Dung - Tay Sa; notably, the image of a hat and a staff - two objects used by Saint Chu Dong Tu to save people and help the world.|||Da Trach Temple was recognized by the State as a national historical and architectural art site in 1989.|||To commemorate the merits of De Thanh Chu Dong Tu and Princess Tien Dung, the local people hold the Chu Dong Tu Festival annually. This is one of the 16 largest festivals nationwide featuring attractive cultural and sports activities. Most unique is the water procession with 10 boats following each other to the Hong River to fetch water for the ceremony at Den Da Hoa and Da Tract temples. This activity follows the old customs and lasts for two hours. During the boats' movement, dragon dances are performed on the boats.|||Ham Tu Mouth – Reed Beach|||From Da Trach Temple traveling more than 2km south leads to Ham Tu Gate (Ham Tu Commune) This is a famous historical site marking the glorious victory against the Mongol army in 1285 by the people of Dai Viet under the Tran Dynasty The final destination of this journey is Bai Sa (Tan Dan Commune) – a famous historical site associated with the Bai Sa Uprising led by Nguyen Thien Thuat from 1885 to 1892 – one of the uprisings of the Can Vuong movement in the late 19th century against French colonial rule

title: Phuong Hoang Temple
description: Phuong Hoang Temple, also known as Cuc Hoa Temple, is located in Minh Tien commune, Phu Cu district, Hung Yen province. The temple is dedicated to Madame Cuc Hoa, the wife of Tong Tran, a national hero.|||The legend says that Madame Cuc Hoa was a talented and beautiful young woman from a wealthy family. She met Tong Tran and his elderly mother while they were on their way, having lost their fortune. Seeing Tong Tran's intelligence and wit, she fell in love with him. Despite the strict social norms of the time, she chose to give up her luxurious life and follow Tong Tran through his hardships.|||She was a virtuous and chaste woman who managed the household and supported her husband's education. When Tong Tran went to the capital to take the imperial exam, he passed with flying colors and was praised by the king as 'a national talent'. After his success, Tong Tran went on a 10-year diplomatic mission, and Madame Cuc Hoa remained loyal and faithful.|||She was pressured to remarry but remained devoted to her husband. When Tong Tran returned, he found out about her situation and disguised himself as a beggar to test her loyalty. Touched by her unwavering commitment, he took her back, and the king honored her as a 'quận phu nhân' for her exceptional virtues. After her death, the locals built a temple in her memory.|||The temple's architecture was rebuilt in the Nguyen style with themes such as the four noble creatures and four precious things. The main hall features a statue of Madame Cuc Hoa with a kind face. The temple follows the tradition of 'tien than hau phat' (worshiping gods in the front and Buddha in the back). The temple is a source of pride for Hung Yen people.|||The temple was recognized as a national historical site in 1991. Madame Cuc Hoa embodies the ideal virtues of a Vietnamese woman, and her story with Tong Tran carries significant human values.

title: Dinh Da Nguu - A Temple of a Hundred Pillars
description: Located in the middle of Da Nguu village in Tan Tien commune, Van Giang district, the Da Nguu communal house, also known as the "Temple of a Hundred Pillars", is an ancient temple in Hung Yen province that still retains its original architecture, landscape, and valuable artifacts.|||According to the elderly, Da Nguu village has the shape of a lying buffalo with 72 spiritual land gods. In the center of the village, there is a beautiful and airy location known as "Hinh Nhan Quai Bang" land, so the villagers built the Temple of a Hundred Pillars. The temple is nearly 7 centuries old, with the architectural style of the Ly - Tran dynasty. The temple has the shape of the Chinese character "Si", consisting of two main buildings: the front hall and the rear palace. The character "Si" means "students and intellectuals". The temple is commonly known as the "Temple of a Hundred Pillars" because it has 100 wooden pillars.|||The temple is dedicated to Saint Chu Dong Tu, one of the "Four Immortals" in Vietnamese cultural beliefs, and his two wives, Tien Dung princess and Tay Sa princess. The temple was built in 1706 and renovated in 1910. The temple is a magnificent and relatively intact example of Vietnamese architecture and art.|||The highlight of the temple is the 100 skillfully carved wooden pillars made of lim wood, which have been preserved to this day. The temple also features a beautiful courtyard with red bricks and two tall pillars leading to a clear well.|||The temple has been recognized as a national historical site by the Ministry of Culture and Information in 1995. Every year, on the 9th, 10th, and 11th days of the second lunar month, the villagers hold a traditional festival, during which they wash the statues in the temple. Visitors come here in the summer to enjoy the serene atmosphere, the fragrance of blooming lotus flowers, and the majesty of the temple.

title: Ho Ban Nguyet
description: If you've ever set foot in Hung Yen, you can't miss Ho Ban Nguyet. This lake has been a scenic spot attracting tourists. Anyone who comes here leaves with a deep impression of the charming landscape, spacious atmosphere, and annual festivals.|||The lake's shape resembles a crescent moon, hence its name. It's a leftover curve of the Red River when it changed course. Ho Ban Nguyet boasts a poetic landscape with clear water, surrounded by lush trees and cool shade, with one side being Nguyen Ho Street and the other being Dai Ha dike. The serene space in the midst of the city makes the lake a source of fascination for intellectuals and travelers.|||The lake is shrouded in mist, its water reflecting the trees like a large mirror. The lake's surface is calm and clear, much like poet Chu Manh Trinh's praise: 'The lake's autumn scenery shines like a mirror.' The beauty of Ho Ban Nguyet is also compared to other scenic spots: 'Let's put aside ancient tales and ask Chau Doanh and Vi Khon if this land is not superior.' Ho Ban Nguyet is a remnant of the Red River and a venue for numerous cultural and historical events. Visiting Ho Ban Nguyet in Hung Yen, you'll have a unique experience and enjoy the rare natural beauty.

title: Long Thuong Bronze Casting Village
description: Long Thuong bronze casting village in Dai Dong commune has over 200 households with more than 800 people. The village currently has 70 casting furnaces, providing regular employment for around 700 workers with an average income of 10 million VND per person per month.|||Over 400 of these workers are locals. Today, Long Thuong bronze casting village has expanded its production and specialized in various products. Separate production facilities have been established for different items such as mâm-making, chậu-making, and casting of worshiping objects.|||Thanks to its organized structure, the village has rapidly developed. The products made here are mainly worshiping objects like đỉnh, hạc, chân nến, đèn, mâm bổng, bát hương, which are consumed nationwide. A bronze product is the crystallization of the artisan's passion and talent. The bronze casting profession requires not only technical skills but also meticulousness, finesse, patience, and dedication to produce a perfect product.|||The young generation of artisans in the village is promoting the expertise of their predecessors by applying new methods to create products that not only retain traditional characteristics but also have a more sophisticated look. With the skillful hands of talented craftsmen in the village, these products have contributed to creating a unique cultural beauty for the rural landscape.

title: Bun Village
description: When mentioning famous tourist spots in Hung Yen, one must not forget Bun Village in Yen Nhan Town, My Hao District, Hung Yen Province. This is also the address for the best bun sauce in the country, which is even exported abroad.|||In the North, bun sauce seems to be an indispensable dipping sauce in family meals, and its flavor evokes nostalgia for those who are far from home.|||The ingredients for making bun sauce are not hard to find, but the processing stage is very elaborate and time-consuming. To create fragrant, golden-yellow bun sauce, it requires great skill and experience from the craftsmen.|||Visiting this craft village, tourists can witness the process of making bun sauce, chat with experienced craftsmen, and feel the beauty of labor in the Northern countryside.

title: Ao Tien
description: Located in the third corner of Ba Be Lake, Ao Tien is a small 3-hectare lake nestled in a valley surrounded by vast primeval forests. It has underground water connections with Ao Tien and Ba Be Lake.|||Despite being about 100m from Ba Be Lake, Ao Tien remains full of water all year round. The lake is circular, over 1000 square meters, with no inflowing or outflowing streams, resulting in crystal-clear water. The area enjoys a cool and fresh climate thanks to the surrounding tropical forest.|||A stroll around Ao Tien or a leisurely boat ride on its calm waters will transport visitors to a serene and idyllic world.|||Besides its breathtaking beauty, Ao Tien is also home to mysterious footprints on rocks, linked to a legend about a hunter and seven fairies. Visitors can see a rocky outcrop, believed to be where the fairies played chess.|||The lake is home to various aquatic species, making it perfect for nature lovers. Visitors can spot rare fish like the giant catfish, and explore ancient trees like may teo and o ro along the way.|||Ba Be National Park is a true wonder, a natural heritage site worth exploring. There are many more exciting experiences waiting for you to discover.

title: Bà Góa Island
description: The small Bà Góa island rises in the middle of Ba Be lake's Pé Lèng section. According to legend, the island was once home to a kind widow and her child who used two wooden boats to save villagers during a great flood.|||From a distance, the island looks like a miniature 'non bộ' surrounded by the turquoise waters of Ba Be lake. Locals call it Pò Giả Mải, formed by stacked rocks and lush greenery, with tree roots embracing the stones. Despite being surrounded by vast waters, the island remains serene and majestic.|||The best time to admire the island is in the late afternoon when it's bathed in a peaceful atmosphere. You might see a Tày girl paddling her wooden boat past the island. As the sun sets, the scenery becomes even more breathtaking, with the girl's black clothes and fair skin standing out against the fading light.|||Legend has it that the widow and her child lived in a small house at the end of the village. When a beggar woman was shunned by the villagers, they took her in and helped her. The beggar then advised them to scatter chaff around their house. During a stormy night, the land sank, forming Ba Be lake, but the house with chaff remained intact, becoming Bà Góa island. The mother and child used their wooden boat to rescue people during the flood, making the island not just a beautiful sight but also a symbol of kindness and compassion.

title: Pac Ngoi Tourist Village
description: Pac Ngoi Village is an ideal stopover for travelers visiting Ba Be Lake. This place preserves the customs, practices, and distinctive cultural lifestyle of the Tay ethnic people in Bac Kan. Visitors on a Ba Be Lake tour to Pac Ngoi Village will experience a simple, friendly rural life and the unique characteristics of the local people.|||The distinctive feature of Pac Ngoi village|||Pac Ngoi is a village in Nam Mau commune, Ba Be district, Bac Kan province, about 50km from Bac Kan town. It is located in a favorable position with flat terrain, in front of a vast green field with the peaceful flavor of the mountainous region. Behind the village is a limestone mountain range resembling a giant wall that hugs and protects the village. Therefore, Pac Ngoi is an ideal stopover for tourists on Ba Be Lake tours when taking a leisurely boat trip on the lake.|||Although it has been over 10 years since tourism activities started here, Bac Kan is one of the few places that has managed to preserve most of the unique customs and traditions of the Tay people. From the way they build stilt houses to their daily lives and clothing, everything is imbued with a distinct identity.|||This is probably the reason why visitors are drawn to Pac Ngoi to explore, experience, and immerse themselves in the simple life of the locals.|||Besides, the scenery of Pac Ngoi village also has a strong attraction to Bac Kan tourists. The romantic landscape is created from the combination of mountains, forests, rice fields, and clear blue lakes. During your visit and relaxation here, you can play and experience the daily life of the locals. Surely, the interesting experiences here will help you gain more understanding of the culture of each region you've visited.|||Experience homestay service in Pac Ngoi|||When visiting Pac Ngoi on a Ba Be Lake tour from Hanoi, guests can experience a traditional stilt house homestay, which is extremely interesting and impressive. The stilt houses here retain a strong ancient character, with a unique architectural style and red tiled roofs built in the yin and yang style. Combined with the picturesque scenery, this is a wonderful spot for travelers to spend a night.|||Homestays in Pac Ngoi have appeared since the early days of developing the tourism industry. Up to now, people have implemented many other services to better serve tourists, such as scenic boat trips on the lake, serving traditional dishes, or becoming guides to take groups to famous tourist sites in the area…|||Choosing to stay in a homestay in Pac Ngoi village, you will have the opportunity to experience a full day with various activities. Many tourists try on ethnic costumes, do all the daily work like local people and participate in fishing on the lake and then grill and eat on the spot.|||Although not as luxurious as resorts, homestays still offer full amenities and a comfortable space to immerse yourself in the natural beauty of the mountains and forests. Each morning, visitors traveling to Ba Be Lake can sit and sip a cup of coffee watching the sunrise over the mountain peak. Especially, the people of Pac Ngoi are very friendly, always giving a warm welcome to every guest from afar. If you need to ask for directions or have other questions, they are always willing to advise and answer very enthusiastically.|||Tay ethnic cuisine - Pac Ngoi|||The most enticing thing for tourists is perhaps the specialty dishes of Bac Kan. You don't need to go to a fancy restaurant or have a professional chef to enjoy many delicious and authentic dishes with the flavor and color of the mountains. At homestays, they serve meals to tourists, so you can rest assured that the prices are very reasonable and not overcharged as many people worry.|||When visiting, you must try the local specialties like grilled Ba Be lake fish, steamed chicken with lemongrass leaves, shoulder pig, sour shrimp... These dishes go well with sticky rice cakes and create a perfect combination. The Tay Pac Ngoi people have a traditional leaf-fermented wine. You can sip on a few cups to experience the intoxicating flavor of the Northwest mountains on a Ba Be Lake, Bac Kan tour.|||Not only that, there are some specialties you can bring back to the lowland as gifts for your family after your trip. These include smoked buffalo meat, Northwest sausage, sour shrimp and plum jam.|||The sour shrimp and plum jam are packed in boxes, while the sausage and meat are packed in vacuum-sealed bags, making them easy to transport.|||Pac Ngoi is one of the ideal destinations that tourists must visit. Nature has blessed this place with a cool climate, picturesque scenery, and fresh air, providing visitors with a wonderful relaxation time.|||In particular, Pac Ngoi has a lot to offer for exploration and enjoyment.|||The local dishes are simple yet extremely appealing, with traditional cooking methods.|||Traveling to Ba Be Lake in Bac Kan, you will receive a warm welcome from the locals, with affection and fondness for this land.

title: Bac Waterfall Ban Vang
description: Located 8km south of Ba Be Lake and 3km northwest of Hua Ma Cave, Bac Waterfall Ban Vang is in Hoang Tri commune, Ba Be district, Bac Kan province. This natural waterfall is divided into multiple tiers, with small lakes at its base, forming beautiful natural bathing areas that attract many tourists.|||Standing from the top of Khau Vang pass, looking down, Bac Waterfall resembles a white silk strip, soft and gentle, flowing down from the sky. From the ground, looking up, the waterfall looks like a magical bridge, connecting the earth to the sky in the vast and spacious mountainous area.|||The waterfall is about 40m high, with a steep, vertical rock face, hidden in the endless green of primeval forests, and features clear and pure water pools along with large, gentle rocks. Here, visitors can admire the scenery, bathe, and capture beautiful memories. The space is cool, fresh, and peaceful, allowing visitors to relax and feel comfortable.|||Bac Waterfall possesses a pristine, raw, yet pure beauty. Gazing at it, one feels like being in a vast and expansive natural landscape. The water is clear, but at each moment, it has a distinct tone. Sometimes, the water flows gently through the rocks to the downstream, and sometimes it rushes violently. On hot summer days, immersing oneself in this cool water is incredibly wonderful. When traveling to Ba Be Lake, tourists should visit Bac Waterfall Ban Vang!

title: An Ma Temple
description: Visiting Ba Be Lake for tourism, apart from swimming and admiring the poetic beauty of caves and surrounding lake spots, visitors can also explore An Ma Temple - a spiritual site located on An Ma Island in the lake, to pray for luck and peace.|||An Ma Island is a limestone island situated in the second lake (Pe Lu), about 30m above the lake water level. The island resembles a horse wading through water, with a turtle-shell shape, covered in lush greenery, offering a perfect spot to observe the lake scenery. On the island lies An Ma Temple, dedicated to Buddha, Mother Goddess, and other deities. This ancient temple was rebuilt in 2007, measuring 9m long and 6m wide, made of wood and tiled with scale-like tiles.|||An Ma Temple holds spiritual significance tied to the legend of Ba Be Lake. The story goes that once this area was a fertile land with lush vegetation. One stormy night, the ground cracked, and the Thung Lung valley sank into a vast sea... Only a kind-hearted old woman's house was spared as she had been warned about the impending flood. Following the goddess's advice, she led the villagers north to find new land. After waiting for them in vain, she turned into stone standing amidst the Ba Be sea and sky. The remaining island was named 'Po Gia Mai,' or 'Widow Island.'|||Grateful for the Widow's kindness and virtue, locals built a temple on the largest island in Ba Be Lake. Annually, on the 10th to 12th day of the first lunar month, villagers organize the Long Tong Festival, visiting the temple to pray for peace and blessings.|||For locals, An Ma Temple is also associated with another event. Legend has it that the temple is where the loyal officials of the Mac dynasty were honored after their failed battle against the Le dynasty. They took refuge in Puong Cave before martyrdom. To commemorate these officials, locals built a temple in their honor but renamed it to avoid retaliation from the Le dynasty.|||The An Ma Temple festival takes place on the 6th day of the second lunar month every year. Visitors come not only for spiritual significance but also to admire the diverse orchids, enjoy the serene lake scenery, and breathe in the fresh air, letting go of life's fatigue.

title: Na Phoong Cave
description: Na Phoong Cave is part of Ba Be National Park in Nam Mau commune, Ba Be district, Bac Kan province.|||This is an interesting destination that visitors to Ba Be Lake shouldn't miss.|||The cave boasts a majestic natural beauty and is part of the Ba Be National Park tourist area.|||It is about 700m long and 180m high, and has an underground stream from Nam Cuong commune that flows through the cave to Bo Lu village where it empties into Ba Be Lake.|||Due to its remote and steep location, during the resistance war against the French (1950-1954), Na Phoong Cave was chosen as the headquarters of Voice of Vietnam Radio.

title: Dong Nang Tien
description: Dong Nang Tien is located in Luong Ha commune (Na Ri). It is one of the natural caves with majestic beauty, associated with a legendary myth.|||In 1999, Dong Nang Tien was ranked as a national historical site by the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism.|||From National Highway 3, turn onto National Highway 3B for over 60km to reach Yen Lac town, Na Ri district. The Bac Giang river flows gently through the valley like a silk strip, making this highland area even more picturesque. From Yen Lac town, go through Pho Co on the 5km asphalt road towards Khuoi Hai, Luong Ha commune to reach the foot of Phja Trang mountain. The Nang Tien cave is hidden behind the lush, pristine forest.|||Standing from afar, Phja Trang mountain resembles a sleeping maiden amidst the clouds; walking up stone steps into the cave, natural stalactites formed over thousands of years glimmer and shine under the light of electric bulbs, creating an ethereal ambiance… This is a natural cave, about 60m deep within the mountain, with an entrance about 6m high and a vaulted ceiling ranging from 30-50m high. Inside the cave, there are many stalactites and stone pillars forming a scene of "dragons flying, phoenix dancing", mesmerizing and captivating.|||The terraced fields near the cave, with a stream of cool water flowing around, are called "fairy fields" and "fairy stream" by locals.|||The cave has small side passages, some stretching from tens to hundreds of meters, with a few connecting to the mountain slope, adding to the mystique and romance of Nang Tien cave.|||Legend has it that 7 fairies descended from heaven to bathe and admire the scenery at a stream at the foot of Phja Trang mountain. As they were busy admiring the landscape, picking flowers, and catching butterflies, they lost track of time and couldn't return to heaven before nightfall. Feeling sorry for them, the heavens created a cave for the fairies to stay overnight. From then on, the stream was named "Khuoi Hai", meaning moon stream, and the cave where the fairies stayed was called Nang Tien cave. These names have been passed down to this day.|||The elderly in the area also tell the story of an ancestor named Ly who, while searching for wood to make a plow, stumbled upon the cave and saw the fairies playing chess. He was so captivated by the game and their beauty that he sat down to watch until nightfall, forgetting to return home. His family searched for him in vain and eventually held a funeral. After watching the entire game, Ly left the cave and found that his bamboo pole had been infested with insects. By the time he returned home, his family had already held a 3-year memorial service for him. These mystical stories have been passed down through folklore to this day.|||Ranked as a national historical site since 1999, nowadays, Nang Tien cave has been gradually invested in road infrastructure, allowing cars to travel easily. Hundreds of sturdy stairs have been built leading to the cave entrance; the area has staff taking care and keeping the keys to open the door for visiting tourists.|||Nang Tien cave is a national site with great potential. To tap into this potential effectively, it needs investment to preserve and develop tourism professionally and sustainably.|||Preserving its pristine beauty and linking it with local legends and stunning features inside the cave, tourists can explore Nang Tien cave combined with visiting ancient stilt houses, enjoying ethnic cuisine, and listening to traditional songs. This makes it an attractive destination in Na Ri, connecting with Ba Be tours and other historical and revolutionary sites across the province, contributing to unlocking local tourism potential.

title: Hua Ma Cave
description: Ba Be is an ideal tourist destination for visitors.|||Located 6000 meters southwest of Ba Be Lake, Hua Ma Cave is part of the Ba Be Lake complex, in Quang Khe commune, Ba Be district (Bac Kan), a natural cave that's truly wonderful and attractive. To reach the cave, visitors must climb 300 meters up the mountain. The cave entrance is 3 meters wide and 5 meters high.|||Once inside, visitors can enjoy the fresh and cool air, with stalactites and stalagmites of various shapes, creating a mesmerizing and magical atmosphere.|||Hua Ma Cave has been known to locals for a long time. According to legend, a king once traveled nearby and his horse couldn't pass a stream. The king asked locals about the area, known as 'Le Pjèn', which means a place of ghostly spirits and poisonous water. People believed that at night, the cave would emit mournful cries, the spirits of innocent people killed by enemies.|||The king ordered soldiers to build a temple in the cave to help the spirits find peace. After the temple was built, the cries stopped. Locals now call it Hua Ma Cave, which means 'horse head'.|||The cave features stunning stalactites and stalagmites in various shapes, such as towers, flowers, and lotus blossoms. The cave is about 1 hectare wide, with a 10-meter high ceiling and 500 meters deep, creating a spacious and cool atmosphere. It's perfect for visitors to escape the heat during summer.|||When visiting Ba Be Lake, tourists can't miss Hua Ma Cave, a fantastic destination for both domestic and international travelers.

title: Na Khoang Waterfall
description: Na Khoang Waterfall is located at the foot of "Gia Cay" mountain in Na Khoang village, Na Phac town, Ngan Son district.|||This is one of the province's key scenic spots and a promising tourism destination.|||Located about 45km north of Bac Kan city, visitors can reach Na Khoang Waterfall by car, motorbike, bicycle... The waterfall has a relatively large slope, creating many different sized waterfalls and cascades, forming a picturesque and unique landscape. It is situated right next to National Route 3, making it very convenient for tourists to visit.|||From the road, visitors can see a white stream, winding through the rocky slope, standing out amidst the green of the trees, which is Na Deng stream where it merges with Ban Mach stream.|||The Na Khoang waterfall area has a tropical monsoon climate, with an average temperature of around 20 degrees Celsius.|||The surrounding area is mainly regrowth forest, with a coverage of about 85%.|||When visiting Na Khoang, tourists can admire a 5m-high waterfall with an average length of about 600m and a width of about 15m. The Na Khoang waterfall has a system of large and small streams.|||The stream water of Na Deng, when reaching the top of the waterfall, meets the stone slopes from both sides, forming a trough-like shape, making the flow winding like a small canal.|||This scenery easily evokes in tourists the harmony of nature, with green trees on both sides of the stream, the white color of the water, and the gray color of the stones, all like an overall painting.|||The winding flow on the stone slope makes this seemingly discordant picture become soft and elegant.|||The ruggedness of the mountain stones and the softness of the clear water soothe the coldness and roughness.|||And then everything bursts forth when the water cascades down from the top of this natural waterfall.|||The clear and deep water of Na Khoang is an ideal destination for tourists to enjoy the fresh feeling of the source, and a place to relax after stressful and tiring working days.|||From Na Khoang, visitors can take two routes to the waterfalls upstream. For adventure-seekers, take the path against the stream to explore the upper waterfalls. For a more leisurely experience, follow the trail created by Bac Hai Ha Co., Ltd. along the Na Deng stream.|||On the way, guests can enjoy the fresh climate and serene ecosystem. The well-preserved and restored forest along the stream features bamboo groves and scattered hardwood trees.|||Each waterfall has a convenient path leading down from the trail, allowing visitors to explore easily.|||Na Khoang has become an attractive eco-tourism destination.|||The provincial People's Committee issued Decision No. 2382/QD-UB on November 8, 2010, recognizing and ranking Na Khoang waterfall as a provincial scenic site.|||Nature has gifted this place with a romantic waterfall, gentle and serene with a picturesque landscape, fresh and cool climate, attracting visitors to come and admire, relax.

title: Deo Gio Pass
description: The moment you hear the name Deo Gio, you feel invigorated by the fresh and cool air. Deo Gio Pass is located in Ngan Son district, Bac Kan province, a popular stop for tourists. Standing on the pass, you feel like you're on a vast and majestic space. Looking down is National Road 3 connecting Bac Kan and Cao Bang provinces.|||Scattered are the houses of local ethnic people at the foot of the mountain, and in the evening, the smoke from cooking fires rises like mist, creating a magical scene. A breathtaking natural landscape that every traveler stopping by can enjoy the fresh air and stunning scenery.|||On the pass, there are many restaurants serving tourists, with specialties like corn wine and rice wine soaked in forest herbs, and wasp larvae pickled in chili sauce - a local delicacy. During the pear season, the pass is filled with baskets of ripe yellow pears, sweet and refreshing for hot summer days. Honey is another rare specialty, with golden and fragrant honey being a treat. In winter, boiled corn is a warm and comforting snack.|||Traveling from Bac Kan to Cao Bang, most tourists stop at Deo Gio Pass. Especially in summer, a refreshing dip in the mountain stream is a must. Enjoying traditional dishes like forest vegetables, bam cakes, wasp larvae sautéed with sour bamboo shoots, and dried buffalo meat sautéed with garlic, and in cold winter, Khau Nhuc - a dish made from sweet potatoes and pork - is a must-try. Khau Nhuc is a traditional dish of Bac Kan people often served during festivals.|||As the highest pass in Ngan Son district, Deo Gio Pass has been known to many tourists. Especially in spring, you can admire the pink peach blossoms and white plum blossoms. Spring is coming, and flowers are blooming, welcoming the new season. The whole village will be filled with laughter, and the smell of sticky rice and grilled pork will fill the air. Local people will welcome a warm and happy spring.

title: Ban Chang Lake
description: Ban Chang Lake is located in Duc Van commune, 6km south of Ngan Son district center, bordering National Highway 3 to Cao Bang. It is a beautiful natural lake with a semi-circular shape, situated in a valley with an area of about 5ha. The lake is surrounded by vast pine forests and has a particularly cool and fresh climate, making it suitable for eco-tourism, community tourism, and collective tourism activities such as boating, swimming, fishing, and camping.|||On weekends, summer days, and holidays, Ban Chang Lake attracts many groups of travelers, young people, and families to come and organize picnics, weekend fun, barbecues, fishing, and relaxation.|||With these special advantages, in the future, Ban Chang Lake will become an attractive tourist destination for visitors to visit, relax, and resort, while also being a highlight associated with traditional local tours and Northeastern regional tours.

title: Kim Hy Nature Reserve
description: Kim Hy Nature Reserve is located in Na Ri district, Bac Kan province, covering over 14,000 hectares, stretching from Vu Muon and Cao Son communes (Bach Thong district) to Luong Thuong, An Tinh and Con Minh communes (Na Ri district). This reserve preserves the pristine state of nature with a rich and diverse ecosystem, featuring limestone mountain forests, representing the unique value of the Northeast region of Vietnam.|||The Kim Hy Nature Reserve, located in Na Ri district, Bac Kan province, covers an area of over 14,000 hectares, extending from Vu Muon and Cao Son communes (Bach Thong district) to Luong Thuong, An Tinh and Con Minh communes (Na Ri district). It is a place that retains the primeval state of nature with a rich and diverse ecosystem, including limestone mountain forests, symbolizing the distinctive value of the Northeast region of Vietnam.|||The Kim Hy Nature Reserve has been highly evaluated by domestic and international scientists for its rich variety of rare and precious species of animals and plants that need to be strictly managed and protected. Notably, there are white-cheeked gibbons, squirrels, and monkeys that are species at risk of extinction globally. Especially, coming to Kim Hy Nature Reserve, you will witness the diversity of bat species here, considered to have the highest component diversity in Vietnam.|||Kim Hy is also home to some rare gene sources of endemic plants at risk of extinction, such as the Fokienia hodginsiana or stone pine, of which there are only a few left in 4 northern mountainous provinces of Vietnam and 2 provinces in Guangxi and Guangdong (China). Moreover, this place is considered a large wood reserve of Bac Kan province with thousands of precious tree species like ironwood and pine.|||In addition to fauna and flora, Kim Hy Nature Reserve is also rich in mineral resources, especially gold. Coming to Kim Hy, you can explore the rich ecosystem, adventurously enter the forest through winding paths deep in the woods, discover and explore the hideouts of animals or find large precious wood trunks. It is even more interesting when you sit under the shade of forest trees, enjoying the symphony of birds and the wind.|||Rich in resources, but the Kim Hy Nature Reserve in Bac Kan province is not only devastated by illegal gold mining but also precious forest products are continuously cut down with an increasingly brutal level.

title: Na Tu Historical Site
description: This is where Uncle Ho met and gave four poems to the Voluntary Youth Force: "No matter how difficult the task is/ As long as you are determined/ Moving mountains and filling seas/ You will surely succeed".|||The site was built from 2016 to 2018 with a total investment of 38.3 billion VND, including a cluster of Uncle Ho's statues with the Voluntary Youth Force, a reception house, Uncle Ho's shrine, gardens, fences and auxiliary areas.|||In 1996, the Ministry of Culture and Information (now the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism) recognized and ranked the Na Tu relic as a national historical site. The site was restored to include a memorial house for Uncle Ho, a stele house, a youth shock force hut and ancillary works. The Na Tu historical site in Cam Giang commune has been honored to welcome many high-ranking Party and State leaders, young union members across the country and tourists to visit.|||This was the military base of the 312 youth volunteer team, responsible for protecting Na Cu Bridge, a crucial bridge on National Highway 3 to ensure smooth traffic and serve the frontline.|||On March 28, 1951, a special event took place here between Uncle Ho and the youth volunteers.|||In June 1950, the Party Central Committee decided to launch the Border Campaign. To meet the requirements of the war, tens of thousands of young and healthy laborers were needed to serve the resistance.|||This force included young volunteers, civil servants who built roads, protected bridges, and transported food and ammunition for the goal of “all for the all-out victory campaign”.|||At that time, President Ho Chi Minh directly instructed the Central Committee of the Vietnam National Youth Union to establish a youth shock force to serve the battlefield.|||On July 15, 1950, a youth volunteer team was established. After the campaign, the Vietnam-China border was opened, and route 3 not only became a campaign road in North Indochina but also a vital traffic route for the whole country.|||This route runs from Hanoi to Thai Nguyen, then through Bac Kan, over Giang Pass and Gio Pass to Cao Bang, connecting with route 4 (Cao Bang - Lang Son - Mong Cai).|||From National Route 3, there are many roads connecting to neighboring provinces, facilitating transportation to the Vietnam-China border.|||At that time, seeing the importance of road number 3, the French colonialists focused their air force to fiercely attack and cut off this strategic transport line. To ensure traffic for the Viet Bac war zone, the youth volunteer teams were assigned to protect and repair National Highway 3, taking on the task of safeguarding and fixing this vital road for the resistance war.|||On March 19, 1951, President Ho Chi Minh directly went to the border region to inspect the road bridge repair from Thai Nguyen to Cao Bang, and visited youth shock troops and some transport units, warehouses along the route.|||On March 28, 1951, in Na Tu forest, the 312 youth shock troops were honored to welcome Uncle Ho. He was accompanied by comrade Tran Dang Ninh, Director General of Food. After shaking hands with the youth and inquiring with care, Uncle Ho unexpectedly asked: "Are you girls and boys finding it hard to dig the mountain?" The youth shouted in unison: "Uncle, no". "Can you fill up the sea?" A shy voice replied: "Uncle, we have never seen the sea". Uncle Ho smiled and said: "Digging a mountain and filling up a sea are two difficult tasks. But if we have determination and willpower, we can do them". Then, on the spot, Uncle Ho composed and recited four poem lines to the 312 youth shock troops.|||The event of Uncle Ho visiting the 312 youth shock troops in Na Tu and giving four poems is a great source of encouragement for young soldiers on the traffic front. The four poems Uncle Ho gave to the youth shock team were passed on by comrade Duong Thiet Son (then Secretary of Bac Kan Provincial Party Committee) who took Uncle Ho to visit the unit to the Central Youth Union and were composed into a song called 'Youth follow Uncle Ho's words' by musician Hoang Ha. Since then, Uncle Ho's teachings have become the guiding principle for the actions of generations of Vietnamese youth, always determined to strive to complete outstanding tasks, contributing greatly to the cause of national liberation and national reunification.

title: Phu Thong Fort Relic
description: The Phu Thong Fort historical relic site is located 300m from the Phu Thong town intersection, at the junction of National Highway 3 and Provincial Road 258 in Phu Thong town, Bach Thong district, 18 km north of Bac Kan city.|||During the resistance war against the French colonial invasion, Bac Kan served as a key resistance base and a focal point in the French plans to attack Viet Bac in the 1947 Viet Bac - Autumn Winter campaign.|||In October 1947, French expeditionary forces led by Lieutenant Colonel So Va Nhac, with 1,200 troops, parachuted into Bac Kan town (now Bac Kan city), marking the beginning of the 1947 Viet Bac - Autumn Winter campaign; on October 15, 1947, they advanced, occupied, and built a fortified fort on a hilltop in the Na Cot area, Phu Thong town, to control and eliminate our forces.|||The fort was rectangular, 100m long and 50m wide, with a south-facing gate made of solid wood, 1m thick and 2m high earth walls with wooden reinforcement, and external wooden stakes with many loopholes; the four corners had four mother bunkers, two-story brick and stone houses.|||Here, our army launched three consecutive attacks on Phu Thong Fort, marking the growth of the Vietnamese People's Army and serving as a rehearsal for the eventual defeat of the French at Dien Bien Phu in 1954.|||In 1996, the Ministry of Culture and Information (now the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism) ranked the Phu Thong Fort historical site as a national historical relic.|||Since then, the site has been well-preserved. Every year, it welcomes many delegations from central and local authorities, serving as an educational site for young people to remember the sacrifices of their predecessors for today's peace, independence, and freedom.

title: ATK Cultural Site, Cho Don, Bac Kan
description: The ATK - Cho Don historical site (Bac Kan) is part of the Viet Bac relic complex, marking the activities of President Ho Chi Minh and central leaders during the resistance war against France (1946 - 1954).|||The ATK - Cho Don historical site (Bac Kan) is part of the Viet Bac relic complex, marking the activities of President Ho Chi Minh and central leaders during the resistance war against France (1946 - 1954).|||During the long resistance war against the French colonialists, along with Dai Tu and Dinh Hoa districts (Thai Nguyen), Son Duong and Chiem Hoa (Tuyen Quang), Cho Don district was assigned a sacred and great task: Chosen by the Central Party and Uncle Ho as a safe zone for the resistance war. This land welcomed and protected the Central agencies and top leaders of the Party and State. On December 8, 1947, Uncle Ho came to Cho Don to lead the resistance war. From 1947 to 1951, Uncle Ho lived and worked in Ban Ca, Na Quan (Binh Trung commune), Na Pau (Luong Bang commune). Cho Don district also witnessed the presence of comrade Truong Chinh, General Secretary of the Central Party at Khuoi Linh (Nghia Ta commune); Prime Minister Pham Van Dong at Khau Ma hill (Luong Bang commune); Na Quan village (Binh Trung commune) was chosen as the venue for the Central Party Congress from 1947 to 1952, where the Border Campaign was summarized. These localities have been ranked as national historical sites by the State. From 1947 to 1952, most of the central agencies were based in Cho Don district, including: Voice of Vietnam, Radio station, Military Technical Department, Military School, Arms Factory, Cuu Quoc newspaper printing factory, Military Medical Surgery Station...|||Since being chosen as a safe zone, the young Party Committee and government of Cho Don had the great responsibility of protecting the safe zone. The urgent work of the Party Committee and government of Cho Don at that time was to purify the area, prevent espionage war, and consolidate communication. The movement to produce and supply food for the resistance war was promoted across the people. Everyone here raised their awareness of keeping secrets, and wholeheartedly took care of the central agencies. Young people in Cho Don enthusiastically joined the main force to fight against the French, and voluntarily participated in youth shock teams to build traffic roads...|||Coming to the ATK - Cho Don relic site, besides visiting traditional historical sites, tourists have many opportunities to learn about the local people's lives, explore the cultural beauty of this place, and witness the changing scenery on this land with a rich revolutionary tradition.

title: Ba Be Spring Festival
description: The Ba Be spring festival takes place on the 9th and 10th days of the first lunar month every year.|||The festival features boat racing, Cong throwing, wrestling, archery, and traditional dances and singing performances by local ethnic groups. The festival also helps visitors understand more about the people and cultural traditions of this place.|||Ba Be Lake is located in the northern part of Bac Kan province, 240km from Hanoi. It is home to 7 ethnic groups, including Tay, Nung, Dao, and Hmong, with Tay people making up 61%. Their traditional customs and culture have attracted many tourists from across the country and internationally.|||Ba Be Lake is the most beautiful scenic spot in Bac Kan province, with a rich cultural heritage of traditional ethnic groups. It has attracted many domestic and international tourists. The Ba Be Lake festival is held on the 9th and 10th days of the first lunar month every year.|||The lake is 145m above sea level and is surrounded by limestone mountains up to 1754m high. It is believed to have formed 200 million years ago. The lake is called Ba Be because it consists of three interconnected lakes, stretching 8km in length and 3km in width. The locals consider Ba Be Lake as their sea.|||The lake has many small islands, particularly Ao Tien, where legend has it that fairies used to come down to bathe and play chess. Ba Be seems more beautiful with its primeval forest, rich flora and fauna, and green streams and rivers like soft silk.|||During this time, people are preparing for the festival while celebrating Tet. They make various types of cakes from glutinous rice flour mixed with forest leaves, such as tro cakes, khao cakes, and sticky rice cakes. The special Khua Quang wine made from corn grown on the mountain tops, distilled with leaf yeast, gives a feeling of euphoria like walking on clouds.|||On the festival day, each commune and town in Ba Be district sets up a stall and sells local specialties. They offer a variety of products such as handmade fabric, ethnic clothing, mushrooms, wood ear, honey, corn wine, dried bamboo shoots, and even wild potatoes, cassava, sweet potatoes, and cat's meow.|||On the morning of the 10th day, the festival officially opens with a ceremony. It begins with 16 communes offering incense. The offerings from each commune are simple, including glutinous rice, chickens, bananas, cakes, and a bottle of corn wine. The 16 offerings are respectfully presented by young women to the mountain, river, and lake gods, praying for a peaceful year with favorable weather, a bountiful harvest, and thriving living things.

title: Tay Yen Tu
description: Tay Yen Tu in Bac Giang belongs to a Buddhist relic complex.|||This place is considered a land of spiritual significance with many beautiful natural landscapes.|||Surrounded by dense forests and much higher than other nearby mountains, it boasts unique natural attractions.|||It is said to be a place where natural energies converge, making it highly suitable for building temples and practicing meditation.|||Yen Tu Mountain is located in the Dong Trieu mountain range in Northeastern Vietnam. To the East it belongs to Quang Ninh province, to the West it belongs to Bac Giang province. This area has a diverse terrain of mountains, plains, and midland regions and is considered the cradle of ancient Vietnamese civilization. This place has a glorious history of fighting against invaders to protect our country.|||This historical site is associated with a temple and a majestic mountainous landscape. The mountains are vast and densely packed, home to a rich variety of wildlife, creating a picturesque scene that can be considered the most beautiful in North Bay. Some notable tourist attractions here include: Suoi Mo, Binh Long, Dong Thong Eco-Tourism Site, Vinh Nghiem Pagoda, Vai Hermitage, Bac Lake…|||Notably, the western slope of Tay Yen Tu is home to a series of historical sites closely related to the formation and prosperity of the Truc Lam Yen Tu Zen sect, including Vinh Nghiem Pagoda, Am Vai, Ho Bac, Binh Long, Suoi Mo, and Dong Thong ecological area…|||Tay Yen Tu is a spiritual tourist site built to recreate the journey of Buddhist propagation by King Tran Nhan Tong.|||This place has a natural landscape of rugged mountains, suitable for eco-tourism development.|||The local government established Tay Yen Tu to promote eco-tourism and spiritual tourism.|||Visiting Tay Yen Tu, the first thing you'll learn about is the story of King Tran Nhan Tong's monastic life. He is the Buddha King associated with many legends about the Truc Lam Yen Tu Zen sect. You'll learn about its origins and the cultural traditions of this Buddhist Zen sect.|||Tay Yen Tu is a large pagoda with a unique architectural structure. It is divided into three distinct areas as follows:|||Chua Ha|||Chua Ha has a flat area with a very favorable location for sightseeing and entertainment. It is also the center for festivals, tourism activities, and religious events.|||Trung Temple|||Trung Temple is located on the slope of Yen Tu Mountain. This place mainly consists of areas such as the scenic viewing platform and walking path to Thuong Temple. In parallel, there is a cable car route and several rest stops and souvenir shops.|||Thuong Chua|||Chua Thuong is considered the final destination on Yen Tu mountain.|||This is the most ideal meditation spot for Buddhists.|||Tay Yen Tu was granted the title of Vietnamese Cultural Heritage by the Ministry of Culture, Tourism and Sports.|||When you visit here, you are exploring a land with many ancient customs and practices. Some cultural events here attract not only Vietnamese people but also foreign tourists.|||Every year, nearly 1 million domestic tourists and nearly 5,000 foreign tourists come to explore.|||Bac Giang is located in the north, 50km east of Hanoi.|||West Yen Tu is a system of historical and cultural relics.|||West Yen Tu is located on the west side of Yen Tu Mountain in Bac Giang.|||This is the birthplace of the Truc Lam Yen Tu sect of the Tran dynasty, and was recognized by Unesco as a world cultural heritage.

title: Xuan Giang Ancient Citadel
description: Bac Giang is an ancient land with a historical tradition closely tied to the country's process of building and defending the nation.|||Xuong Giang ancient citadel is located in Xuong Giang commune, Bac Giang city, Bac Giang province. It was built by the Ming army in the 15th century (1407). The citadel was built of earth and had a rectangular shape, measuring 600m in length from east to west and 450m in width from north to south, covering an area of 27ha. The earth walls were high and thick, with fortresses at the four corners, a wide moat surrounding it, and four gates, with the main gate facing west.|||After conducting a survey and reviewing the monument's dossier, not many remains of the ancient citadel can be seen today. The city wall is about 3-4m high above the paddy field, 25m wide at the base and 16-20m wide at the top. There are 4 bastions at 4 corners, each 4m high and protruding outwards. The citadel is surrounded by a moat.|||During the first excavation in 2008, archaeologists from the Institute of Archaeology initially outlined the system of architectural works of the ancient citadel of Xuong Giang.|||According to historical records, the victory of Xuang Giang of the army and people of Dai Viet led by Le Loi, crushed 100,000 invading Ming troops in nearly a month in Lang Son and Bac Giang today. With four major victories: on 10/10, the vanguard was crushed and Thai Tu Lieu Thang was killed at Chi Lang pass; on 15/10, the enemy was defeated at Can Tram (Huong Son - Lang Giang), forcing the general Bao Dinh Ba Luong Minh to commit suicide; on 18/10 at Ho Cat (in Voi, Xuong Lam, Phi Mo - Lang Giang), the Upper Minister Ly Khanh had to kill himself and on 3/11/1427 at Xuong Giang, after 10 days of siege, the rebels defeated over 70,000 enemy troops led by Cui Tu and Huang Fu, forcing the Ming army in Dong Do (Hanoi) to surrender and withdraw back to their country.|||The victory of Lam Son - Le Loi's army led by General Tran Nguyen Han, captured Xung Giang and defeated Lieu Thang's army, significantly contributing to the historical victory, overthrowing the brutal Minh dynasty's rule that lasted 20 years and decisively securing Vietnam's independence in the 15th century.|||The siege battle of Lam Son insurgents on September 28, 1427 and the glorious annihilation battle on November 3, 1427 which Le Quy Don assessed: Since the Tran dynasty captured Tich Le Co, O Ma Nhi until then, Vietnam had never had a bigger victory against Northern invaders like this (according to Dai Viet Thong Su).|||Thang Xuong Giang is considered the center of the battle and later witnessed many important events of the homeland, especially the uprising led by Nguyen Huu Cau (Quang He) in the second half of the 18th century.|||To commemorate the historic victory of the Lam Son army at Xuong Giang citadel, Bac Giang province organizes an annual festival on the 6th and 7th day of the first lunar month. The festival features various rituals and entertainment activities. On the eve of the festival, on the night of the 5th day of the first lunar month, young people gather to burn bonfires. At temples, communal houses, and cultural centers, lanterns are lit throughout the night until the fifth watch of the next morning, when participants gather and march to the festival site. On the early morning of the 6th day of the first lunar month, processions from different wards and communes, carrying flags, beating drums, and riding decorated vehicles, converge on the festival center.|||With that historical significance, on January 22, 2009, the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism issued Decision No. 293/QD-BVHTT-DL, ranking Xuong Giang as a National historical victory site. There are 14 relics here: Northeast gate, east gate, north gate, southwest gate, south gate, central area, vestiges of the citadel, section of Xuong Giang river flowing through the citadel; archaeological excavation sites No. 2, 3, Phu well, Thanh temple and 2 sites outside the protected area: southeast gate, west gate. The protected relics are scattered in residential areas of Dong Giang, Nam Giang, Trai Bac villages, Xuong Giang commune. There is also an area of the Middle-level Cultural - Sports and Tourism School, Plant Protection Sub-Department of Bac Giang province...|||With its recognized historical values and the consensus of various levels, sectors, and people, the Xuang Giang victory historical site is a source of pride for the people of Bac Giang and Vietnam in general, in the glorious history of fighting against foreign invaders.

title: Hang Chieng - Khe Nuong Dau Waterfall
description: This is an interesting eco-tourism spot familiar to locals but less known to outsiders in Tuan Dao commune (Son Dong). It is a great place to cool off during hot summer days.|||“You haven’t really been to Tuan Dao if you haven’t been to Hang Chieng - Khe Nuong Dau”, according to Mr. Hoang Van Lap, Vice Chairman of Tuan Dao People’s Committee. The challenging introduction encourages us to explore this high-altitude stream in the vast mountains, despite the unpredictable weather. Located in a remote valley, surrounded by protective forest in Lam Tuan village, the place got its name Hang Chieng because local guerrillas hid many gongs used as signals during the fight against French colonialists, with lush strawberry fields nearby. Historically, locations in the commune like Don Tay, Don Chua, Da Bo, Ly Hai, and Cua Dam became a source of fear for invaders. In late 1948, the Tuan Dao guerrilla team used Hang Chieng - Khe Nuong Dau as a base to work with local forces to attack and destroy the French Don Chua fort.|||The natural beauty of this forest includes a stunning waterfall. The stream flows continuously, sometimes rushing into natural pools, and other times flowing gently. It takes 4 to 5 hours to reach the stream, involving hiking through the forest, bathing in the stream, and admiring the pristine nature of the mountainous region. Visitors can also challenge themselves by climbing rocks with unique shapes, creating unforgettable experiences. The journey provides a comfortable and relaxing feeling, with a thrilling experience when navigating the vast mountains. The waterfall, flowing from high above, thunders down, chasing each other through large round rocks to the downstream. Tourists are mesmerized by the numerous waterfalls spraying white water mist. This stream also supplies clean water for hundreds of households in the area.|||This destination remains untouched, attracting visitors with dense forests covering both sides of the stream. During hot summer afternoons, locals often invite each other to the stream for a bath. When guests visit, local families usually take the opportunity to introduce and promote this waterfall.|||Visiting Tuan Dao, tourists can enjoy hiking, admiring natural scenery, and learning about traditional customs of minority ethnic groups including Tay, Nung, Hoa, San Diu, Dao, Cao Lan…

title: Dinh Huong Tomb
description: The Dinh Huong Tomb is located in Dinh Huong village, Duc Thang commune, Hiep Hoa district. It is a unique architectural complex of stone sculptures from the Late Le dynasty, recognized as a national cultural historical site since 1965.|||According to documents preserved in the Cultural and Information Office of Hiep Hoa district, the tomb was built in 1727. The tomb preserves the remains of Quan Cong La Quy Hau. His real name was La Doan Truc (born in 1688 and died in 1749). He was a meritorious person to three generations of the Posterior Le dynasty and had been sent on two diplomatic missions to the North. After his death, he was posthumously titled as Phuc Than.|||The tomb is situated on a round hill, about one hectare wide, surrounded by a stone wall (recently restored). The architectural layout of the tomb complex consists of three main parts: the burial area in the middle, the worship area on the left, and the stele area on the right.|||The stone tomb area is about 100 square meters, built with square stone blocks. In front of the tomb, two mandarins on horseback stand facing each other. These statues are considered masterpieces of stone sculpture art. The mandarin on the right has a big face and a broad chin, while the one on the left has a long beard and a small face. All the statues are finely crafted, exuding an elegant and extraordinary aura.|||The worship area is also built in a square shape like the tomb, with a stone wall surrounding it. In front of it, there are three-level stone steps, on which a stone altar, a worship table, and two servant statues carrying ceremonial items are placed. There are also two stone lions lying down with their heads raised to the sky. The entire lion statue is covered with scales resembling a dragon's, with a long mane intricately carved. In the distance, there are two kneeling elephants.|||To the right of the tomb is a four-gated pavilion with a stone stele recording the merits of the person being worshiped. The inscription remains clear to this day.|||Overall, the main construction materials of the Dinh Huong Tomb are green stone, carefully carved and sculpted. The human and animal statues at the tomb are made of green stone, carved to be very lifelike.|||According to Mr. Dong Quang Khanh, Deputy Head of the Cultural and Information Office of Hiep Hoa district, over the years, the tomb has been invested with over ten billion dong to restore and preserve. This is a favorite destination for locals, tourists, and researchers.

title: Tay Yen Tu Nature Reserve
description: Tay Yen Tu Nature Reserve in Bac Giang province covers a total area of 13,022.6 hectares of forest and forestry land. With an average elevation of 300-1000m above sea level.|||In addition to storing and preserving many rare species of flora and fauna, the reserve also has many beautiful natural landscapes, which are a potential for exploiting and developing tourism with 4 main tourist routes.|||1. Dong Thong route - Dong Pagoda (Yen Tu)|||The complex of historical sites of Chua Dong and other temples on the Yen Tu mountain range is a spiritual realm, closely associated with the Truc Lam Zen sect founded by King Tran Nhan Tong.|||From Ban Mau village (Tu Mau commune), visitors can hike through a rich tropical forest to reach Chua Dong and other temples in the complex.|||The Dong Thong eco-tourism center is located at the foot of the mountain, featuring a large stilt house and a small house by the poetic Nuoc Trong stream, which has crystal-clear water from an underground spring.|||On the way, visitors can see various species of orchids and wild orchids, hear birds and animals singing, and admire the ancient trees.|||Near Chua Dong, visitors can see a giant stone turtle that is thousands of years old.|||After the trip, visitors can feel peaceful and serene, surrounded by nature.|||Accommodation is available at the tourism center in Thanh Son town or at the Dong Thong eco-tourism center.|||Visitors can also explore the local market, try Yen Tu forest honey and men leaf wine, and learn about local customs and traditions.|||2. Ba Tia Waterfall tour|||From Thanh Son town, go about 4km on the asphalt road, you will find the Nuoc Vang stream located in Thanh Luan commune. From here, you can take a picnic and walk along the stone path or the forest trail for about 2km to see the majestic Ba Tia waterfall.|||The main waterfall is divided into three strong streams that flow into a crater-like area, creating a white foamy water before smoothly flowing down.|||The origin of the waterfall's name is unclear, but it has been called Ba Tia for a long time.|||You can freely swim and dive in the clear water, and all your fatigue will disappear without you even realizing it.|||3. Biểng Village – Vung Tron – Khe Ro tourism route|||From the center of An Chau town (Son Dong district), going through 15 km of paved road, you will reach Bieeng village with Kinh, Tay, Dao and Hoa ethnic groups, each with their own unique cultural identity and customs, yet living in harmony with one another for generations. They mainly live by farming, growing rice, raising livestock and poultry, and cultivating colored crops. Some villagers, during their free time, often gather medicinal herbs from the forest to make traditional medicine.|||The scenery of Khe Ro forest is pristine and untouched, hiding many secrets waiting to be discovered, like a magical world of ancient, dense forests. The streams, waterfalls, and rocky rapids are breathtakingly beautiful, such as Ba Tang (Khe Din) and Dong Duong (An Lac) waterfalls, which sparkle like miniatures of Ban Gioc in Trung Khanh (Cao Bang).|||There are also Vung Tron lakes with crystal-clear water, where you can swim freely, and a stilt house nestled under the shade of ancient trees, reflecting its image in the water. Visitors can stay overnight in the stilt house to experience the mystical and serene atmosphere of the forest. You can also join local people in catching fish, crabs, and snails in the streams.|||A night with a delicious meal and a taste of the local rice wine will surely leave you with unforgettable memories. Even if you only visit this place once, you will feel a lingering attachment and not want to leave.|||4. Nuoc Vang Stream – Giót Waterfall (Luc Son - Luc Nam)|||From Than intersection, Luc Nam town (Luc Nam district), follow provincial road 289, through Luc Nam bridge about 30 km, you have arrived at the eco-tourism line of Nuoc Vang Stream - Giot Waterfall. This place has a very strange stream, flowing endlessly for centuries with a golden brown water stream smooth as honey. Nuoc Vang Forest is still pristine, the harmony between geology and climate creates vitality for countless tropical flora and fauna to develop very richly. You will visit 2 ancient brown Tro trees nearly 600 years old and admire the Giot Waterfall over a dozen meters high, flowing all four seasons with a stream of water like misty rain resembling a white scarf draped on the mountain top.|||Behind the waterfall area is the ancient Da Ran rocky beach, stretching out with countless natural stone slabs of diverse shapes to admire endlessly.|||Coming to this tourist line, during the chestnut season, locals display and sell chestnuts at Dong Dinh market stretching for kilometers. Luc Nam chestnuts are famous and well-known in many places on the market, with a delicious taste, both fragrant and rich, blended with a fatty and aromatic flavor that is hard to forget even after one bite.

title: Dong Thong Eco-Tourism Area
description: Dong Thong Eco-Tourism Area is located in Tuan Mau commune, Son Dong district, 87km from Bac Giang city center and 130km from Hanoi city in the Northeast direction. From here, you can reach Suoi Mo Tourism Area in Luc Nam district, 25km away, or follow the beautiful provincial road 279 to Ha Long World Heritage Site in Quang Ninh, 65km away... and join many journeys to beautiful scenic spots in the region.|||Dong Thong Eco-Tourism Area is part of the Tay Yen Tu tourism route - a key tourism route being focused on by Bac Giang province for planning and construction. This area also preserves many rare animal species and serves as a stopping point for tourists before conquering the Phù Vân Yên Tử peak from the West.|||When visiting Dong Thong, tourists can visit Non market to taste Yen Tu forest honey and local specialties like men lá rice wine; or learn about customs, culture, and folk rituals of ethnic people such as rain praying ceremony, new rice offering ceremony, and sắc cấp ceremony of Dao people in Mậu and Đồng Thông villages. At Dong Thong, tourists can also have a picnic trek through the forest to Chùa Đồng and other temples in the Yen Tu mountain range.|||To unlock the great potential given by nature, Bac Giang People's Committee has approved a project to invest over 2,700 billion VND in upgrading and renovating the transportation system from Bac Giang city to connect with provincial road 293 through Yên Dũng, Lục Nam, and Sơn Động districts, which is a favorable condition for Bac Giang to strongly develop cultural, spiritual, and eco-tourism in the Tay Yen Tu route.

title: Sunflower Field
description: Thousands of sunflowers are blooming in a field in Bac Giang, attracting many young people to take pictures. This place is expected to be one of the hottest tourist spots in Bac Giang.|||Located 55 km from Hanoi center on National Highway 1A, this nearly 3-hectare sunflower field is part of the Rose Garden film set in Bac Giang. The flowers have been blooming since the 30/4 holiday and are now attracting many visitors to admire and take photos.|||The field's owner, Le Van Duong, invested in planting and upgrading the garden into a wedding photo studio because he loves sunflowers.|||After the first planting experience, Mr. Duong decided to divide the planting into three batches so that there are always flowers available to serve customers.|||You should go early to get beautiful pictures, ideally from 7 am to 11 am. The sunflower field also attracts many couples to take wedding photos.|||To get here, from Hanoi center, take National Highway 1A to Viet Yen, then turn onto DT284. When you reach My Do street, turn left onto Hoang Hoa Tham street to arrive at the garden.|||The garden is open daily from 6 am to 9 pm. The entrance fee is 50,000 VND per person. Groups of 5 or more people get a 20% discount, and groups of 30 or more get a 30% discount. For wedding photos, you can contact the owner directly.

title: Ba Tia Waterfall
description: Located in the west of the Tay Yen Tu conservation area, Son Dong has been known to many tourists for its poetic natural scenery such as the primeval Khe Ro forest, the gentle golden stream with a unique yellow color, and the windy and peaceful Dong Cao hamlet.|||And it would be incomplete without mentioning Ba Tia Waterfall, a must-visit destination when exploring this pristine but charming land.|||To reach the town of Thanh Son (Son Dong), then go another 3km to the lower source of Ba Tia Waterfall. But according to the experience of travelers, to fully appreciate the beauty of the waterfall, visitors should park their motorbikes at a local house and walk about 1km more.|||Crossing the bumpy path with large stones covered in green moss that can be slippery, the natural scenery unfolds before your eyes, making you forget your fatigue and hardship.|||Ba Tia Waterfall is the source of the gentle and peaceful Nuoc Vang stream. The waterfall's water also has a distinctive yellow color. When you reach the source, you will be amazed and thrilled to see the majestic beauty of the 20m-high waterfall.|||The water flows down through many steps, creating a deafening sound with white foam, and then becomes calm, winding through the stone crevices like a silk ribbon across the forest.|||The waterfall is surrounded by primeval forests with various tree species and wildlife such as deer and wild boars. The scenery is enchanting and idyllic.|||Visiting Ba Tia Waterfall in the summer, you can escape the noise, dust, and worries of the city, and immerse yourself in the cool water, blending with the green nature of the ancient trees, and listening to the chirping of forest birds, which brings a feeling of relaxation and peace.|||Recently discovered, Ba Tia Waterfall still retains its pristine beauty, making it a destination for young travelers who love adventure and want to return to nature.|||Here, groups of friends can set up camp for the night, light a campfire, grill fish, or enjoy local specialties such as grilled chicken and dishes of the ethnic minority people.|||The road to the waterfall is still difficult due to lack of investment, but once you conquer the path, the charming scenery will make it worthwhile. You will be surprised and thrilled by the natural beauty that this land has been endowed with.

title: Nguyet Ho Temple
description: Nguyet Ho Temple is one of the ancient relics associated with thousands of years of history and culture of Bac Giang homeland. The temple is located in an area with many relics in the upper reaches of the Thuong River, in Huong Vi commune, Yen The district, Bac Giang.|||In recent years, Nguyet Ho Temple has become a spiritual and religious highlight, attracting thousands of visitors from across the country who come to pray for luck, wealth, and peace in their lives.|||According to legend, in the Bo region (Yen The), the story of the lord of Nguyet Ho is recorded as follows: At the end of the reign of Hung Due Vuong, the Thuc army invaded the kingdom of the Hung. Hung Due Vuong then ordered a search for talented people to help the king defeat the enemy. At that time, in the Bo region, Mr. Cao and Mr. Quy responded to the call and were chosen by the king to fight against the invaders.|||They returned to this place to practice their military skills, waiting for the right moment to destroy the enemy. When the Thuc army arrived, the two sides clashed fiercely. Due to the enemy's superior strength, the Vietnamese army retreated along the Thuong River and then ambushed the enemy in a strategic location. The Thuc army was defeated, and those who retreated were chased and destroyed by the Vietnamese soldiers.|||The victory was achieved thanks to the bravery of Mr. Cao and Mr. Quy. After their triumph, they rewarded their soldiers and returned to the capital to report their achievements to the king.|||Before returning to the royal court, the two gentlemen rode their horses to the Tu Forest area to take a comprehensive look at Bo region one last time and suddenly turned into gods there. Their wives and daughters heard the news, remembered them with longing, and spontaneously transformed as well, on the 15th day of the second lunar month.|||After defeating the Thuc army, the king conferred the title of Upper Dignity and Happiness on the meritorious generals and ordered the localities, where the generals fought against the enemy, to build temples and worship them forever.|||During the reign of Emperor Le Dai Hanh, an imperial decree was issued to confer on the gods in Bo region the title of "Cao Son Quy Minh great virtue heroic strategy extraordinary Great King Upper Dignity".|||During the Nguyen dynasty, the local people built a temple in Huyết Hồ and requested the court to allow them to worship the female god, Nguyet Nga phu nhân, and her daughter of the Cao family.|||In the third year of Emperor Tu Duc's reign (1850), an imperial decree was issued to Nguyet Nga phu nhân and ordered the people of Bo region to worship her.|||Later, another decree was issued to confer on her the title of Nguyet Nga công chúa.|||In the first year of Emperor Duy Tan's reign (1907), another imperial decree was issued to Nguyet Nga phu nhân.|||The Temple of Lady Nguyet Ho has a long history. Originally, it had a hall dedicated to Princess Nguyet Nga and was decorated with statues according to the Mother Goddess worship. Over time, the temple has been restored and renovated multiple times thanks to the local people and philanthropists.|||The complex of relics currently includes: The temple gate, temple yard, Nguyet lake, the main temple area consisting of Dai Bai hall and Hau Cung, built in traditional ancient style.|||In the inner palace, there are statues of the temple's patron deity, Chua Nguyet Ho (Nguyet Nga princess) and other worshipped figures following the Mother Goddess religion, including the Saintly Mother, Quan, Chau, Ong Hoang, the girls, boys, and Duc Thanh Tran. The outer two halls, Toa Dai Bai, are also arranged with statues worshipped according to the Mother Goddess religion.|||Thus, through its long history, Nguyet Ho Temple has accumulated many layers of beliefs. Besides worshiping "Lady Nguyet Ho - Goddess of Divination", it also honors "The Three Courts of Holy Mother", and worships the Maiden, the Boy, Son Trang, the Lords and King Tran.|||For a long time, the Nguyet Ho Temple has been associated with a "worship of the Mother" cult. According to researchers, the Mother worship cult is an ancient Vietnamese belief that has existed for a long time and continues to develop.|||The festival day of Goddess Nguyen Ho is on the 15th day of the 2nd lunar month. On this day, people in Bo region parade a palanquin from Bo Ha communal house to Ha, Trung and Thuong temples. After the ceremony at Trung temple, the palanquin is paraded back to Nguyen Ho temple.|||Here, the ceremonial worship of Lady Nguyet Ho is conducted with unique rituals such as the ceremony to offer literature to Lady Nguyet Ho. The ceremonial literature offered to Lady Nguyet Ho is performed through the form of chanting. The person chosen to chant must have a good voice, be skilled in playing the lute, and their family must not be in mourning.|||In the ritual of worshiping the Mother Goddess at the temple of Lady Nguyet Ho, there is also the custom of spiritual mediumship which takes place on the first days of the year and during festivals.|||Visitors coming to worship the Mother Goddess and participate in spiritual mediumship are mostly from Hai Phong, Hai Duong, Quang Ninh, Lang Son, Hanoi... gathering here to offer literature and chant to Lady Nguyet Ho.|||The Nguyet Ho Temple is part of the shared spiritual space of Mother Worship along the pilgrimage route from Nguyet Ho Temple to Suoi Mo Temple, Bac Le Temple, Ba Mo Temple, Thuong Dong Dang Temple and finally down to Ba Chua Kho Temple in Bac Ninh.

title: Chua Ve Pagoda
description: In 2018, during repairs, locals discovered 3 stone pedestals with lotus flower carvings from the Tran Dynasty (13th-14th century). The pedestals are square, made of green stone, with intricate lotus flower designs. This finding provides new insight into Chua Ve's history, suggesting it may have been built during the Tran Dynasty, contrary to previous assumptions that it was built during the Le Dynasty (17th-18th century).|||The pagoda is located next to two communal houses, creating an ancient atmosphere in the center of Ve village. According to elderly locals, the pagoda was once beautiful and majestic, especially after the abbot, Sư Tổ Giáp Linh, led renovations and added new statues and a bell. The architecture was in the 'nội công, ngoại quốc' style, featuring a Tam quan gate, a large courtyard, a Tam bảo hall, two corridors, and a drum tower.|||After several renovations, the pagoda has been largely restored to its original architecture. The complex spans over 5,000 square meters, with a five-room, two-eaved Tiền đường hall and a tiled roof.
