The wooden frame is sturdy, with intricate carvings of clouds, leaves, and mythical creatures.|||The pagoda houses many valuable artifacts, including ancient Buddhist statues, intricately carved with fine details. Other notable items include ceramic incense burners, wooden fish-shaped drums, and a stone incense burner from the Le Dynasty (1705-1720).|||The annual festival at Chua Ve Pagoda takes place on the 7th day of the first lunar month, featuring traditional rituals and games. One notable game involves arranging characters in a large formation, while another involves a 'capturing the ball' competition. These activities reflect the agricultural traditions and cultural heritage of the local community. With its unique cultural and architectural values, Chua Ve Pagoda was recognized as a national artistic monument in 1994.

title: Kim Trang Pagoda
description: Dubbed the third-largest ancestral temple in Northern Vietnam, Kim Trang Pagoda still preserves its cultural and spiritual values, along with its impressive architectural scale – once a pride of Bac Giang, a land famous for its numerous temples.|||Kim Trang Pagoda was originally in Kim Trang commune, Tuy Loc Son district, Yen The county; now it is in Viet Lap commune, Tan Yen district, Bac Giang province.|||According to literature, Kim Trang Pagoda was built in 1742 during the reign of King Le Hien Tong.|||Legend has it that at that time, there was a Buddhist monk of the Truc Lam Zen sect who was practicing at Duc La Pagoda. One day, while passing by here, he saw a young buffalo herder building a temple, picking flowers and fruits to offer to Buddha with great joy. The monk was delighted with the location and decided to stay and teach the villagers to build the temple. When Kim Trang Temple was completed, the monk stayed to take care of it and spent decades building more structures. Therefore, the temple has an architecture of 'nội Công - ngoại Quốc' with a large scale, similar to Duc La Pagoda in Yen Dung district.|||That's why people at that time sang a folk song:|||Firstly, it is Duc La Pagoda|||Second only to Quang Phuc, third is Trang Temple|||Thus, Kim Trang Pagoda is the third largest ancestral temple in Bac Giang province, after Duc La Pagoda and Quang Phuc Pagoda (formerly in Da Mai commune, Bac Giang city, but Quang Phuc was destroyed during the resistance war against France); and it is the largest ancestral temple in the old Yen The region. Up to now, Kim Trang Pagoda is still the largest pagoda in Tan Yen - Yen The district.|||Over time, Kim Trang Pagoda has undergone several renovations. In the 8th year of Canh Thinh reign (1800), locals refurbished and cast a large bell, with the names and hometowns of donors inscribed on it. In 1939, the pagoda underwent a major renovation, which removed the boat-shaped pediment and sealed the ends. However, the overall scale of the pagoda remains quite large, comprising front yard, rear yard, main hall, triple gate, Buddha hall, rear sanctum, ancestral hall, subsidiary buildings, guest house, and a garden with stupa tower (where the ashes of the pagoda's monks are interred)... The pagoda is surrounded by lush trees and a serene pond, creating a peaceful and solemn atmosphere.|||Most of the Buddha statues in the temple are carved from jackfruit wood, antique, lacquered and gilded, entirely covered in gold, creating a magnificent beauty.|||The arrangement of statues at Kim Trang Temple is similar to that at To Duc La Temple. Specifically, in the front hall, there are two large guardian deity statues; next to them are the Saintly Worthy and the Virtuous One, also lacquered and gilded, sitting on a noble throne.|||Entering the main hall, it's a 'world' of numerous Buddhas gathered on the altar.|||Notably, the 7 statues of venerable monks in the rear hall are all lifelike portraits, with no identical statues, resembling ordinary people more than following Buddhist rules. This is also a distinctive feature of the statues of venerable monks that can only be found at Kim Trang Pagoda.|||In addition, at the Mau altar, there is a statue of Mau Son sitting with a gentle posture, 3 high neck lines, a beautiful and benevolent face, wearing a phoenix hat, gold lacquer, also made of wood, extremely beautiful.|||Kim Trang Pagoda is not only a spiritual temple but also a valuable source of historical and artistic significance, showcasing unique architectural and religious values.

title: Khe Chao Lake
description: Khe Chao Lake, also known as Khe Chao Lake, is located in Tau village, Long Son commune, Son Dong district, Bac Giang province. The lake is situated at the foot of Ha My pass, about 25 km from An Chau town. The lake covers an area of approximately 27 hectares, featuring numerous small islands and surrounded by primeval forests of the Tay Yen Tu range, which boasts a rich ecosystem and is home to many rare species listed in the Red Book. With its picturesque natural scenery and fresh air, the lake offers favorable conditions for developing various types of tourism.|||Visiting Khe Chao Lake, tourists can immerse themselves in the majestic and pristine natural landscape, explore the rare beauty of this sacred land in Yen Tu. To discover the area's scenery, visitors can take a boat ride around the lake, stop to visit the islands - home to numerous bird species such as storks, herons, pelicans, and mergansers. In particular, tourists can set up camps, swim, or relax by the lake, enjoying the green water. The lake's fish are mainly natural ones released by a project's enterprise annually to help locals improve their livelihoods, enhance forest and environmental protection, and serve tourists. Visitors can catch fish, grill them on the shore, and enjoy traditional local dishes like glutinous rice with ant eggs, five-colored glutinous rice, grilled chicken, and local wine.|||Besides exploring the natural beauty, tourists can visit the model of breeding and releasing sturgeon and salmon for tourists to visit and supply the domestic and international markets. Additionally, visitors can learn about and discover the unique cultural features of various ethnic groups such as Kinh, Tay, Nung, Dao, San Chi, Cao Lan, Muong, and Hoa. They can also visit historical and cultural sites like Luc Lieu communal house, which honors General Dao Khai Tran Ngoc, and the Nguyen clan's ancestral house, which honors Mr. Nguyen Ky Tai. Continuing from Khe Chao, tourists can visit the Tay Yen Tu nature reserve, the Dong temple on Yen Tu mountain via the Dong Thong tourist area, and the Mau village with the legend of the beautiful girl who went to the king of the Dao people in Tuan Mau – Son Dong. If connecting tours, from here, tourists can continue their journey, exploring the eastern part of Yen Tu, to reach the Ha Long Bay - a world natural heritage site in Quang Ninh, about 45 km away.|||With its rich tourism potential in both natural and cultural aspects, Khe Chao Lake has many advantages to attract investment and develop into an attractive tourist destination of Bac Giang province in the future.

title: The Thousand-Year-Old Dahuang Tree
description: Located in the Tien Luc relic complex, which has been recognized by the state as a National Heritage, the thousand-year-old Dahuang tree in Bac Giang is considered a "divine tree" and is also the only Dahuang tree of its kind in the world.|||For tourists who love nature's beauty, the term 'green heritage' has become familiar recently as the trend of restoring and preserving green heritage has become widespread. One of the most famous green heritage sites nationwide is the thousand-year-old Dahuang tree in Bac Giang. Not only is it an impressive tree with a beautiful landscape in the Tien Luc relic complex, but this special Dahuang tree in Bac Giang is also a living witness to history and carries profound spiritual significance.|||The thousand-year-old Dahuong tree is located in Tien Luc commune, Lang Giang district, Bac Giang province.|||It is a heritage tree that attracts many tourists to visit thanks to its impressive beauty and unique features.|||No one knows when the Dã Hương tree in Tien Luc appeared. According to elderly villagers, it has been large and beautiful for generations. The village's ngọc phả records that King Le Canh Hung (1740-1786) recognized it as 'Quoc chu do moc Da Dai Vuong', the largest Dã Hương tree in the country, during one of his visits, impressed by its beauty and size.|||Tính đến nay người ta vẫn chưa thể xác định được tuổi của cây dã hương này, tuy nhiên theo các nhà khoa học thì cây ngày đã tồn tại ít nhất 1000 năm. Người dân ở thôn thì vẫn thường gọi cây với cái tên là "cây dã hương nghìn năm tuổi".|||Visiting the thousand-year-old Dahuang tree in Bac Giang, tourists will be amazed by its beauty. The tree's trunk has a circumference of up to 17.4m, a height of 36m, and a large canopy covering an area of about 2 sao of land. The tree has a thick bark of up to 15cm.|||With its large trunk and wide canopy, this heritage tree has a majestic appearance and a hint of mossy elegance. Especially when combined with the scenery of the Tien Luc relic complex, it creates a nostalgic and quintessential Northern Vietnamese countryside atmosphere, transporting visitors back to the past. The scenery here is like a rustic yet vibrant painting that captures the essence of rural life.|||The thousand-year-old Dahuong tree in Bac Giang not only boasts a beautiful appearance and majestic stature, but also represents a cultural beauty and a sacred symbol in the cultural space of the Vietnamese people. The tree is considered a sacred creature that carries significant cultural and spiritual meaning for the local people. It is said that the fragrance of the tree is the reason why the people in the surrounding area enjoy good health and are less susceptible to epidemics.||||||Notably, elderly residents in Tien Luc have observed a special phenomenon showing the close connection between the thousand-year-old Dahuang tree and human life. This tree species never breaks or falls due to any natural phenomenon. However, if a branch dries out and falls to make way for a new one to grow, it signals a major change in the country's life.|||Specifically in 1945, a northeastern branch of the tree broke, coinciding with the success of the August Revolution. In 1954, the western branch broke, signaling the victory at Dien Bien Phu. The southern branch broke in 1964, a year linked to the Gulf of Tonkin incident. In 1975, the western branch broke again, and that same year, South Vietnam was liberated, and the country was reunified. In 1984, the northwest branch broke, associated with the Contract 10 event. In 2006, the southern branch broke, and Vietnam officially joined the World Trade Organization. People often recorded these events linked to the tree's broken branches under the name 'canh hop nhap.'|||Located about 21km from Bac Giang city center, the thousand-year-old Dahuang tree is an attractive destination for tourists.|||Here, visitors can not only admire the majestic appearance of the ancient tree but also hear stories surrounding this heritage tree and explore the unique cultural and spiritual aspects of Northern Vietnamese people.|||If you have the chance to travel to Bac Giang, don't forget to visit this one-of-a-kind world heritage tree.

title: Yen The Uprising Historical Site
description: When visiting the Yen The Uprising Historical Site, guests can explore and pay respects at the Temple of Oath of the Yen The insurgents. The temple was built in the late 19th century and witnessed the entire uprising 132 years ago. Initially, the temple was thatched with straw, bamboo, and leaves. In 1897, during the second period of reconciliation between the Yen The insurgents and the French colonizers, Hoang Hoa Tham had the temple renovated and personally selected each piece of wood to build the wooden structure using lim wood. Fortunately, the original architecture remains intact today. The temple follows the Đinh character architecture, consisting of a 3-room 2-wing main hall and a 2-room rear sanctum. After the renovation, Hoang Hoa Tham named it Dia – Trung – Tien, indicating the temple's location as a harmonious intersection between heaven and earth, the mortal world and the realm of gods, and also to describe the beautiful scenery surrounding the temple.|||This temple was often used by Hoang Hoa Tham as a venue to gather his troops, recruit talented individuals, and have them drink wine and swear loyalty before each battle. After victorious battles, he would also hold celebrations here to reward his soldiers. Today, this temple is considered the most sacred site in Yen The district, serving as a cultural, religious, and spiritual hub for locals and tourists from within and outside the province.|||After visiting Den The Temple, you will pay respects at the monument of national hero Hoang Hoa Tham to commemorate the legendary hero. Next, you will visit the Yen The Uprising Exhibition House, a two-story building. The first floor showcases an ethnographic corner of Yen The district. On the second floor, you will see images and artifacts related to the uprising, including weapons, ammunition, and daily items of the rebels. This will give you a vivid insight into the clever battles and indomitable spirit of Hoang Hoa Tham and his followers.|||On the other side of the monument yard is Phồn Xương fort, the headquarters of the Yen The insurgents. Phồn Xương fort, also known as Đồn Gồ or Đồn Cụ, is located on the south side of a hill about 20m high, nearly 800m south of Goi Stream. The fort was built by Hoàng Hoa Thám in 1894 to guard the only path into the insurgents' base.|||Phồn Xương fort is a large base with a unique structure, different from Ho Chuoi fort and others. The fort has a rectangular architecture, running along the North-South direction, covering an area of over one northern sample, including two circles of walls. The outer wall starts from the eastern slope, wrapping around the foot of the hill, up to the top of the hill, forming a crescent shape to protect the inner citadel, 140m long, 0.80m thick, and 4m high.|||The inner wall lies on the top of the hill, nearly rectangular. The eastern wall is 71m long, the northern wall is 85m long. The wall is made of rammed earth, 2m thick at the base, 3m high, and 1m wide on top. Inside the wall are 3 different levels for standing or kneeling to shoot. The wall has embrasures all around. The outer wall is sloped like a roof.|||The architecture of Phồn Xương fort is a unique design that not only meets the requirements of a fortified stronghold but also flexibly addresses combat mobility and serves as a command center and rebel transaction hub. Over time, the fort system has been eroded by weather, and the walls no longer remain intact as before. The Eastern wall still retains many of its original architectural features. The wall still bears clear bullet marks and crenellations. This place was the headquarters of the rebellion, the starting point for spreading the movement to local areas. Đề Thám built Phồn Xương fort as not only a place of living for his family and followers but also a meeting place for discussions between Đề Thám and contemporary heroes like Phan Bội Châu, Phan Chu Trinh, Kỳ Đồng... on national salvation. Today, inside the fort, a temple dedicated to bà Ba Cẩn, the third wife of Hoàng Hoa Thám, has been built to commemorate her significant contributions to the Yên Thế peasant uprising.|||The Yen The peasant uprising cultural and historical site has formed a valuable historical complex that is cherished and preserved by the local authorities and people. The Yen The uprising relic was classified as a Special National Historic Site by the Prime Minister's Decision No. 548/QD-TTg on May 10, 2012.|||Every year, on the 15th, 16th and 17th of March in the lunar calendar, the Yen The festival is solemnly organized by local people. This is one of the largest festivals in Bac Giang province.

title: Tho Ha Pottery Village
description: The pottery craft in Tho Ha dates back to the 12th century and is one of the three oldest centers of Vietnamese ceramics, alongside Phu Lang and Bat Trang.|||According to the village's family chronicle and archaeological artifacts, Tho Ha is considered a cradle of the pottery craft. Tho Ha was once a bustling pottery trading port in the Kinh Bac region.|||The prosperity of the pottery craft helped the villagers build a complex of impressive architectural works, including communal houses, temples, and village gates.|||The village legend tells the story of the ancestor of Tho Ha pottery, Tiến sĩ Đào Trí Tiến. At the end of the Ly Dynasty, Đào Trí Tiến, Hua Vinh Cao, and Luu Phong Tu were officials in the imperial court and were sent on a diplomatic mission to the Northern Song Dynasty (960-1127).|||After completing their mission, on their way back to Vietnam, they stopped in Thieu Chau, Guangdong Province, where they encountered a storm and had to stay.|||There, they visited a famous pottery kiln and learned the techniques.|||Upon returning to Vietnam, Đào Trí Tiến introduced the art of making deep red pottery to Tho Ha, Hua Vinh Cao introduced white pottery to Bat Trang, and Luu Phong Tu introduced golden pottery to Phu Lang.|||Previously, the annual ceremony to honor the ancestor of pottery was organized by the potters of Tho Ha in rotation at their homes.|||Due to its long history of development and prosperity, Tho Ha pottery village has many ancient relics with significant cultural values.|||One of the notable sites is the Tho Ha communal house, built in 1692, which is a cultural relic ranked as a national historical site. The dragon and phoenix motifs blend harmoniously with clouds, people, trees, flowers, and animals, showcasing the skillful hands of the craftsmen.|||Walking through the village, the most fascinating are the small alleys. The reddish-brown color of the old bricks, worn smooth, reveals the passage of time, while the narrow alleys, lined with dark brown walls, exude an ancient charm.|||Visitors to Tho Ha often have a special impression of the quaint, nostalgic, yet rustic and profound beauty of the village.

title: Suoi Mo Festival
description: The Suoi Mo Festival has been held for a long time, taking place annually on the 30th of the 3rd lunar month and the 1st of the 4th lunar month, attracting many visitors. The festival mainly takes place at three temples and around the Suoi Mo eco-tourism area.|||The Suoi Mo Festival occurs in late March and early April of the lunar calendar every year, in the Suoi Mo eco-tourism area, Nghia Phuong commune, Luc Nam district, Bac Giang province. This festival originates from the spiritual and religious needs of the local people. According to legend, Suoi Mo temple complex consists of three temples: Ha, Trung, and Thuong, dedicated to Saint Mother Thuong Ngan Que Mi Nuong, the daughter of King Hung. She is credited with helping the locals to open up the Mo area, build dams, and dig canals to bring water for agricultural production. To commemorate her merit, people built three temples along the two sides of the stream and hold a grand festival every year.|||Within the festival, various cultural, sports, and spiritual activities are organized, such as a performance of hat van and hau dong, Quan ho singing, sports competitions, and traditional games like wrestling, niêu pounding, and tug-of-war.|||One of the highlights of the Suoi Mo Festival is the ceremonial procession. Early in the morning, 25 procession groups from all villages in Nghia Phuong commune move to the festival center at Noi Island. From there, the processions go to the temples to make offerings, praying for favorable weather, a bountiful harvest, and thriving crops.|||The Suoi Mo Festival can be considered as a convergence of traditional cultural values of ethnic groups in Nghia Phuong commune. It is an occasion for people to meet, exchange, and share, wishing for good things. By attending the festival, tourists can experience and immerse themselves in a sacred and mystical space with beautiful waterfalls, green forests, and a cool eco-tourism area, making it an ideal spiritual and eco-tourism destination for visitors.

title: Yen The Festival
description: The Yen The uprising broke out in 1884 in Bac Giang and then spread to Bac Ninh, Vinh Phuc, Thai Nguyen, Lang Son and other provinces. Under the leadership of Hoang Hoa Tham, the nearly 30-year-long uprising showed the resilience and indomitable spirit of Vietnamese peasants in the late 19th and early 20th century national liberation movement. In 1984, the people of Yen The and neighboring areas organized the 100th anniversary of the Yen The uprising in Phon Xuong. Since then, it has become a tradition that every year on March 16th, the Yen The Festival is solemnly organized with many diverse activities, attracting the attention of a large number of people and tourists.|||The festival features a variety of cultural and sports activities such as lion dancing; kite flying; blindfolded goat catching; cooking rice; throwing a ball; tug of war; archery; cock fighting; art performances; martial arts; chess; table tennis; soccer; a fair displaying local products; and a youth camp… On the morning of March 16th, the festival officially begins with an incense-offering ceremony to commemorate the hero Hoang Hoa Tham at his statue. After the incense-offering ceremony is a flag-raising ceremony to recreate the ritual of launching the uprising by Hoang Hoa Tham's troops. Then, a parade symbolizing the strength of the Yen The uprising is held in a solemn manner to the sound of beating drums and resonant chimes.|||Also within the festival framework, an exhibition house about the Yen The uprising is open to visitors to explore artifacts and precious images of the activities of Yen The insurgents over a century ago.

title: Tho Ha Festival
description: The Tho Ha Festival (Van Ha commune, Viet Yen district, Bac Giang) takes place from the 19th to the 21st of the first lunar month every year. The festival honors the Village God. Although the festival is held annually, a large ceremony with a procession is only organized every three years. This festival preserves many unique characteristics of Northern Vietnamese culture.|||The Tho Ha village festival consists of two parts: the ceremony and the festival. The ceremony is organized in a solemn and traditional manner. From early morning, the chief officiant, the announcer, and the entire council of elderly men dress up to welcome the procession from the temples to the village communal house. The chief officiant stands at the triple steps to receive the procession. Once everyone is in their places, the ceremony begins with solemn rituals. All participants express their respect and invite the Saint to join the festival with the villagers and pray for the Saint's blessings for a new year filled with health, prosperity, and happiness.|||After the ceremony, the festival continues with traditional games such as cockfighting, boat racing, wrestling, chess, badminton, and boat rowing to catch ducks… Notably, Tho Ha is considered a cradle of the art of Quan Ho singing. The young men and women from neighboring villages gather at the festival to sing for days and nights in the communal house courtyard or on boats. The romantic and smooth songs captivate many visitors. Besides Quan Ho singing, another exciting and dynamic competition that attracts many participants is Chinese chess. The chessboards are set up for contestants to show off their skills. The winners are joyful and happy, while the losers are not discouraged and look forward to the next year's festival to meet their opponents again. The festival concludes with everyone leaving in a joyful atmosphere.|||The Tho Ha Festival is a cultural beauty of Kinh Bac people, enriching Vietnam's cultural heritage, and is worth preserving and promoting.

title: Dinh San Festival
description: The San village used to belong to Phuong Lan commune, Phuong Nho district, Lang Giang prefecture, Kinh Bac province, Dai Viet country. This is a picturesque land with favorable geography, conditions to gather and connect with all four directions.|||Located beside National Highway 31, about 15km northeast of Bac Giang city, the national architectural art complex of Sàn communal house and temple is situated on the head of a phoenix, with the villages stretching out on both sides of the bird's wings. In front of the communal house is a village pond and a well, harmoniously set in a scenic spot with a mountain and water, creating a spiritual convergence that attracts visitors from all over during the festive seasons at the beginning of the new year.|||San communal house worship the village founders Cao Son, Quy Minh and Minh Giang Do Thong. According to legend, they were three generals under the 18th Hung King, who defeated the invaders and helped the people. On April 20, 1995, the state decided to recognize San communal house and temple as a "National cultural and historical artistic relic". In a spring conversation with senior citizens, 85-year-old Do Van Duoc, former Chairman of Phuong Son commune People's Committee, recalled: In 1715, San villagers built the communal house. At that time, the village had two eastern and western hamlets. Each hamlet was responsible for providing materials to build one side of the communal house. The village invited two teams of craftsmen to work together on a unified model but independently on each side.|||Every artisan strives to perfect and showcase their skills and craftsmanship, resulting in truly exquisite and unique architectural art pieces.|||Passing through the large courtyard in front of the entrance leads to the grand hall, comprising three spacious rooms with two wings on each side, exuding grandeur and majesty with four elegantly curved roof finials.|||The ridge is adorned with a pair of dragons welcoming the moon, and at the ends, there are decorative kìm and sấu figures.|||The lively depictions of nghê and phượng dancing on the frieze, along with the chanh flowers running along the ridge, add to the dignified yet elegant beauty.|||The communal house is constructed in the cong-shaped style.|||The grand hall and rear palace are connected with three transverse rooms, making the communal house impressive and superior to others in the region.|||Many intricate details remain on the roof beams, showcasing the artistic style of the Le Trung Hung period with themes of 'Four Symbols: Dragon - Snake - Turtle - Phoenix', 'The Fairy Riding a Dragon', and 'Dragon and Cloud Meeting'.|||This also conveys the message of a sacred land with a rich history, where the Dragon King and the Fairy Queen gave birth to a heroic people, bringing about prosperity, peace, and abundance.|||On the 10th day of the first lunar month, the eastern and western villages prepare two ceremonial trays to worship Saint Cao Son and Quy Minh. Families and clans gather their children to go to the communal house for the ceremony. The family trays are similar to the village trays but smaller. In recent years, there are also trays from teams and villages.|||The procession of high trays and full platters from villages and hamlets, to families and clans, connects seamlessly under the vibrant spring atmosphere, showcasing the prosperity and joy of a land known for its talented people and auspicious spirit. The 10th day marks the main festival, but celebrations have been in full swing since the 8th. Many traditional games are vividly recreated, including: chasing the fairy, climbing the bridge to catch ducks, smashing pots, playing cards at the communal house, human chess, snatching the ball, playing with shuttlecocks, spinning tops, and wrestling...|||The unique charm of our homeland is showcased through the traditional 'du tien' game, a distinctive and joyful activity that takes place during village festivals. The game features a sturdy bamboo pole structure, consisting of four large, old bamboo trees, each about 5-6 meters long, planted about 3-4 meters apart and tied together at the top with a rope. Two players stand facing each other, jumping and pushing the pole to swing higher and higher. When they reach a height of about 4-5 meters, surpassing the tied rope, it's called 'giat noc'. From this height, the peaceful rural landscape unfolds before their eyes, filling their hearts with joy. They then let go, allowing the pole to slowly come to a stop, ending a thrilling round of play. The festive atmosphere of the village celebration seems endless, filling the air until the first days of the Lunar New Year, as the saying goes: 'Chua San on the 27th of the second lunar month, anyone who doesn't attend still hears the joyful sounds'.|||Descendants of San village, no matter where they go to work, return to their village during these days to attend the festival as a way to show gratitude to their ancestors. Amidst the hustle and bustle of daily life, the beautiful and simple cultural heritage of this ancient village is like a final note in a melody that connects the bonds of village and neighborhood.

title: Den Tu Ha Festival
description: The Den Tu Ha festival takes place in Hong Giang commune, Luc Ngan district, where the temple is dedicated to General Than Canh Phuc. This historical site is located in Hong Giang commune, Luc Ngan district, Bac Giang province.|||The temple honors General Than Canh Phuc (also known as Vu Thanh) from the Ly dynasty, who played a significant role in repelling the Song invaders in the 11th century (1075-1077).|||The temple complex is situated in the south of Ha Ho village (now known as Kep Hai village). During the Ly dynasty, this area belonged to Dong Giap, a large region in Lang Chau of Dai Viet.|||The temple features a unique architectural design, following the traditional Tam layout, comprising three main structures: Thuong, Trung, and Ha temples, accompanied by the Ha temple and a pagoda. These structures form a harmonious and connected architectural ensemble stretching over 400 meters along the Luc Nam riverbank.|||The temple is dedicated to General Than Canh Phuc (Vu Thanh) and six other Phò Mã and princesses of the Ly dynasty. The site preserves numerous valuable artifacts, including 21 imperial edicts from various dynasties. In 1991, the temple was recognized as a national historical and cultural site by the Vietnamese government.|||The festival takes place from the 6th to the 8th day of the first lunar month, featuring a procession that reenacts the general's journey to fight against the enemy. This event aims to commemorate the glorious past and promote national unity and spirit. The festival has become a significant event in the region, attracting a large number of visitors.|||Currently, some parts of the complex are in disrepair and require urgent restoration and conservation efforts. The local authorities and people are working to secure funding and support to protect and preserve this cultural heritage site.|||With the approval of the Bac Giang Department of Culture, Sports and Tourism and the Luc Ngan District People's Committee, along with the support of the Vietnamese family and local residents, a new construction project is underway to build a guesthouse, premises, and entrance gate to welcome visitors and enhance the site's appeal.

title: Long Tong Festival
description: The Long Tong Festival (also known as the 'going down to the fields' ceremony) is a top-tier important celebration at the start of the new year, tied to the agricultural planting culture.|||It is organized to convey people's wishes for favorable weather, good crops, and a prosperous life.|||This festival vividly expresses a rich, diverse, and unique cultural heritage.|||The Long Tong Festival in Ba Be has long been famous in Viet Bac.|||After decades of interruption due to war and a narrow view of cultural and folk beliefs, the festival was revived in 1995.|||It has been held annually on the 10th day of the first lunar month at the Ba Be lake, under the foot of Bo Lu mountain, in Nam Mau commune, Ba Be district, Bac Kan province.|||The Long Tong festival features a variety of rituals and lively celebrations. It's a festival for every household, as all families participate in the ceremony. Each family has its own altar, with a boiled rooster, lean pork, a pair of square cakes (mon hua) wrapped in banana leaves, boiled eggs dyed with four colors - red, purple, yellow, and green. There is also red glutinous rice symbolizing the sun, and yellow glutinous rice symbolizing the moon, on each plate of glutinous rice is a red paper swallow, carrying the symbol of spring, expressing the wish for a warm, prosperous, and peaceful life.|||On the morning of the Long Tong festival, families in the village organize the ceremony and carry their altars to the largest field in the village. The altars are arranged in a row, with the top altar being that of the respected old shaman, who is also the master of the festival.|||People stand in a circle around the offering table. When incense is lit, the shaman reads a prayer and performs rituals to pray to the gods, including the God of Agriculture, Phuc Hy, Mountain and Water gods, and the village guardian, for favorable weather, livestock prosperity, and a peaceful and prosperous village. The most beautiful girls in the region bring water for the offering, stored in gourd shells, considered sacred water taken from the source. The shaman then lifts the sacred water containers, praying for water from heaven to nourish the fields. After the prayer, the shaman pours the water in all directions, and everyone gathers to receive the blessing.|||The ceremonial part is followed by the festive part, starting with the tung con game. The con balls are made of fabric, stuffed with rice and cotton seeds, and have colorful tassels. Young men and women take turns throwing the con balls onto a circular target at the top of a pole. The con ball and the target represent the unique symbols of Yang and Yin, the origins of the universe and all things. When the con ball passes through the center of the target, it signifies the harmony of Yin and Yang, and life will flourish, resulting in a bountiful harvest. Therefore, at every Long Tong festival, the game of throwing con balls into the target is a mandatory ritual, as the community believes that if Yin and Yang do not harmonize, the village will not have good luck that year, and the harvest will be poor. The person who throws the con ball into the target is rewarded with a full platter of food.|||Usually, the winner only gets the honor, while the feast is shared with the village! Another interesting thing is that when young men and women catch each other's leftover balls, it's considered a match made in heaven. Therefore, the Long Tong festival is also an opportunity for young people to get to know each other and start a romance. After the festival, there are games like archery, spinning tops, tug-of-war, and blindfolded goat herding... On the night of the Long Tong festival, young men and women sing Sli and Luon songs all night long, exchanging invitations, greetings, and goodbyes...|||The unique feature of Ba Be's Long Tong festival is that people attending the festival not only for fun, but also to sell their own farm products, making Long Tong festival also has the color of a agricultural product fair.|||The Long Tong festival of Ba Be is truly a folk festival, rich in identity, diverse in forms of activities, creating an attraction for tourists from all over the world to this land.

title: Xuanduong Love Market
description: Xuanduong Love Market takes place once a year on the 25th day of the 3rd lunar month in Xuan Duong commune, Na Ri district (30km from Yen Lac town, 45km from Bac Kan town).|||Although not as famous as Khau Vai Love Market in Ha Giang or Sa Pa Love Market in Lao Cai, Xuanduong Love Market possesses unique cultural characteristics of the Tay and Nung ethnic communities in Na Ri district, Cho Moi district (Bac Kan) and neighboring districts of Lang Son and Thai Nguyen provinces.|||The market originated from a touching story of a young Tay ethnic couple who loved each other deeply, living in Pac Sen village, Xuan Duong commune, Na Ri district. They fell in love through traditional songs and dances at local festivals. One day, while working in the field, the wife was taken away by bad people. The husband searched for her but couldn't find her in time.|||The local people were moved by the couple's story and named the field Nà Rỳ (long field) to commemorate their love. The name Nà Rỳ was later used for the district, which was eventually pronounced as Na Ri. Years later, when the couple met again at a market, they were overjoyed but could only cry and reminisce about their past love, as they had already built new lives. The locals, feeling sympathetic for the couple, decided to hold a gathering on the 25th day of the 3rd lunar month for those who had missed their chance at love to meet and revisit their past.

title: Deo Giang Historical Site
description: The Deo Giang historical site, located on National Highway 3, the road to Cao Bang, lies between Ngan Son and Bach Thong districts. During the resistance war against France, our army and people achieved a glorious victory here, a notable ambush on National Highway 3.|||On the morning of December 12, 1947, at Km 187, 188 in Lang Ngam commune, Ngan Son district, Bac Kan province, where mainly Dao ethnic people live, a group of 22 enemy vehicles, including tanks, armored cars and jeeps, carrying soldiers, fell into an ambush set by the 165th Regiment (Capital Regiment). The ambush site was a treacherous stretch of road, with a high mountain on one side and a deep ravine on the other.|||The first shots fired by our soldiers destroyed one enemy car and killed many enemy soldiers. Then, our forces used firepower to attack the enemy formation, and our soldiers rushed down the road to engage in close combat.|||We won a great victory, killing 60 enemy soldiers (including 2 lieutenant), destroying and burning 17 vehicles, capturing 2 million Indochinese dollars, and seizing a large amount of important weapons, military equipment and supplies.|||This can be considered the largest ambush battle compared to others in the Deo Giang area. From this battle, our forces gained valuable experience in battalion-level ambush tactics.|||This battle is closely tied to the attack on Phu Thong fort on July 25, 1948, which created a significant impact, boosting morale and motivation for our armed forces in the early days of the resistance against French colonialism.|||It contributed to the nationwide effort, alongside the people, to thwart the French colonialists' destructive plots in the Vietnam Northern Border Zone.|||From this glorious battle, Deo Giang has become a historical landmark associated with the heroic victories of our military and people during the 1947 North Vietnam Counterattack - Autumn Winter campaign. The historical site of Deo Giang is a source of pride for the military and people of Bac Kan, and the Vietnamese People's Army.|||Giang Pass and Phu Thong, two famous battlefields have become part of revolutionary poetry, mentioned in To Huu's poem 'Viet Bac' composed in 1954, after the victory against French colonialists in Dien Bien Phu, and the return of President Ho Chi Minh, Party Central Committee, and officers to Hanoi. In the emotional atmosphere of separation, To Huu wrote the poem 'Viet Bac' to recreate the history and sentiment between Viet Bac people and revolutionary cadres. The poem mentions these two historical sites:|||Do you remember when I come back|||We come back and remember Phu Thong, Deo Giang|||With its special historical significance, in 2001 the Ministry of Culture and Information (now the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism) recognized and ranked the Deo Giang historical site as a national historical relic.|||The relic on the left features a large bas-relief depicting the battle at Deo Giang pass, while on the right is a commemorative stele recording the history of the battle. Today, Deo Giang relic is an ideal stopover for tourists and trekkers to rest and enjoy the fresh air on the pass, take souvenir photos, and also a place to remind younger generations about the determination and sacrifice of their predecessors for today's peace and independence.

title: Ba Be National Park
description: Ba Be National Park, Bac Kan province was established by the Prime Minister's Decision No. 83/TTg on November 10, 1992.|||The park is located in the northwest of Ba Be district, 68km from Bac Kan town in the northwest direction and 250km from Hanoi capital to the north.|||Ba Be National Park, Bac Kan province was established by Prime Minister's Decision No. 83/TTg on 10 November 1992.|||Ba Be National Park is located in the northwest of Ba Be district, 68km from Bac Kan town in the northwest direction and 250km from Hanoi capital to the north.|||The Ba Be National Park area covers a total of 44,750ha, including: 10,048ha core zone and 34,702ha buffer zone. The core zone consists of: 3,931ha strictly protected area, 6,083ha eco-recovery area, and 34ha administrative service area.|||The hydrological system of Ba Be National Park includes rivers and streams such as Cho Leng, Bo Lu, Ta Han, Nang River and Ba Be Lake.|||Ba Be Lake receives water from Ta Han, Bo Lu and Cho Leng rivers from the south of the National Park with a total basin area of 420km2.|||The three rivers and streams flow into the lake, and after being regulated, part of the water flows into Nang River in the north of the lake, continuing to flow to Gam River.|||The Nang River is the upper source of the Red River, flowing in the east-west direction with a total basin area of 1,420km2.|||During the flood season, in addition to the three rivers and streams in the south, water from Nang River can flow into the lake and the water level in the lake can rise from 2-3m.|||When the floodwaters of Nang River recede, the water in the lake continues to flow into Nang River.|||Ba Be Lake is located at a height of 150m above sea level, with an area of 450ha, and an average depth of 17-23m, with the deepest point reaching 29m.|||The lake plays a crucial role in regulating the water source in the area: during the dry season, water from the lake flows out to Nang River in the north, and when there is a large flood, the water from Nang River flows into the lake, causing the lake water to be retained.|||Ba Be Lake has the ability to regulate over 40 million m3 of water for Nang River and Gam River.|||Ba Be Lake is the only natural lake on a mountain that has a particularly important significance in Vietnam, and is a large natural tectonic lake.|||Due to the special geological and hydrological tectonic mechanism lying in a limestone region, Ba Be Lake does not dry out and this is a unique and interesting feature of Ba Be Lake.|||Ba Be is one of the national parks with high forest coverage and primeval forest ratio in Vietnam's special-use forest system and global limestone mountain areas.|||The park is covered by over 73.68% of closed subtropical moist evergreen forest, of which the primeval forest on limestone mountains is considered a model of the ecosystem on limestone mountains typical for Northeast Vietnam and the world.|||Ba Be has high diversity with 1,268 species of high-order vascular plants, including globally threatened species such as Nghien and Kim Giao. The fauna system is rich with 81 mammal species, 322 bird species, 44 reptile and amphibian species, and 106 fish species, many of which are globally threatened, including White-cheeked Langur, Eurasian Otter, Fire-backed Pheasant, and White-winged Duck.|||The Ba Be Lake area has the highest diversity of freshwater species in Vietnam's protected areas, with 106 fish species, including many rare and economically valuable species such as: Snubnose fish, Pangasius fish, and Threadfin fish. The annual seafood production in Ba Be Lake is a major source of income for a portion of the population living around the lake.|||Ba Be has many beautiful caves.|||In 1986, Ba Be was recognized as a National Historical Cultural Heritage.|||In 2003, it was recognized as an ASIAN Heritage Site.|||On February 2, 2011, Ba Be National Park was recognized by the Ramsar Secretariat as the 1938th Ramsar site in the world and the third Ramsar site in Vietnam.

title: Thach Long Pagoda
description: Thach Long Pagoda, also known as the Stone Dragon, is situated in a stone cave with an entrance resembling a dragon's open mouth. According to legend, in the past, people from Vi Huong - Bach Thong commune transported a gold Buddha statue of Shakyamuni down the Cau River to worship in their village, Hoa Son, at the top of the Phja Bjooc mountain range. The heavy gold statue required the use of a raft for transportation. However, as they reached Cao Ky commune, the raft started spinning and couldn't move forward. As night fell, the procession had to set up camp for the night. The next morning, they were shocked to find the Buddha statue missing. The procession then lit a large incense stick and prayed for the Buddha to show them the way to his new location. The smoke from the incense stick led them to a beautiful and spacious cave. The Buddha Shakyamuni was already seated at the highest point. Realizing the sacredness of the cave, the villagers built a pagoda within it.|||Thach Long Pagoda is divided into two parts: the first part, Thien Pagoda, is located on high ground with stone steps leading up to the cave entrance. The highest floor, Thuong Dien, symbolizes the heavenly realm and worships Buddha Shakyamuni. The middle floor, Trung Dien, represents the world and features an image of Uncle Ho. Inside the cave, the stone walls naturally form like a majestic canopy sheltering the Buddhas. This can be considered a masterpiece of natural architecture. The second part, Ha Dien or Am Pagoda, is accessed by walking around the mountain slope for about 80 meters. The entrance to Ha Dien is slightly narrower than Thien Pagoda, and the interior, though not as spacious, is about 6 meters high and 6 meters wide with a niche extending deep into the side.|||Thach Long Pagoda is not only rich in legends but also a historical site and a source of pride for the people of Cao Ky commune. Due to its unique structure and secluded location, during the Ly Dynasty, the pagoda was used as a fortress to fight against the Tống army. During the resistance war against France, the pagoda served as a production site and secret weapon storage for our military. At that time, the villagers hid all the Buddha statues and discontinued their visits to the pagoda. After peace was restored, the pagoda was returned to the local authorities so that the people could resume their worship.

title: Phya Khao Tourist Site
description: Phya Khao Tourist Site is located in Cho Don district, known for its mild climate and clean environment. With an average elevation of 800m above sea level, the climate here is warm in winter and cool in summer. The French had previously discovered this location with its excellent climate and built a resort here. Phia Khao mountain, located in Ban Thi commune, Cho Don district, has an elevation of over 800m above sea level and is home to the Cho Dien - Ban Thi lead and zinc mine. Even on the coldest winter days, the labor and production atmosphere here remains vibrant.|||Phia Khao mountain, located in Ban Thi commune, Cho Don district, has an elevation of over 800m above sea level and is home to the Cho Dien - Ban Thi lead and zinc mine. On the coldest winter days, the labor and production atmosphere here remains vibrant. Visiting Phya Khao, you will see the stunning natural scenery and experience the unique culture of the mountainous ethnic groups, gaining valuable knowledge.|||Phya Khao is ideal for tourists who want to connect with nature, conquer and explore the beautiful primeval forest. Besides enjoying the fresh and refreshing air, visitors can explore the local environment and people's lives.|||Camping and mountain climbing are two must-try experiences when visiting Phya Khao, offering exciting adventures for professional travelers. Additionally, the site preserves unique architectural works from the French colonial period.

title: Den Tham
description: Den Tham is located in Cho Moi district, Bac Kan province, with many legendary stories that have become part of the local people's consciousness. The temple is situated right next to the paved road leading to Quang Chu commune, about 4km from National Route 3 and 45km south of Bac Kan city.|||The temple is dedicated to the female general named Tham, who played a significant role in fighting against the Black Flag army in the late 19th century.|||Originally, the temple was a place of worship for the Mountain God and Water God to pray for the safe passage of boats.|||In the late 19th century, the temple was renovated to honor the female general Tham, who led the fight against the Black Flag army.|||The story goes that there lived an old fisherman and his son who made a living on the Trang Co river. One year, a severe flood hit, and the raging waters swept away the old man's boat and nets. After the floodwaters receded, he cast his nets again. As the sun began to set, he finally caught a heavy load, but to his dismay, it was only a stone. On subsequent attempts, he still only caught that strange stone. He decided to move to another part of the river, but again, he caught the same stone. Just as he was about to discard it, a voice from within the stone said: 'Old man, take me home.' Finding this peculiar, he brought the talking stone back home. When he threw it to the ground, it collided with another stone, broke open, and surprisingly, a gold shine filled the inside of the stone. There were gold bars inside. Believing that the Jade Emperor (Giang) provided the gold to compensate for the flood's devastation, he distributed it to the people living nearby. Even with the gold, the old man and his son continued to work hard to make a living by the Trang Co river. Grateful, the locals built a temple to worship the two stones, the Mountain God and the Water God, so that boats passing by could have a safe journey.|||The Tham temple complex consists of the main temple, Co Tham shrine and Son than shrine. The main temple is divided into three rooms, worshiping: Five respected gentlemen, Hundred Spirits, Tran Hung Dao saint, Mother of the Heaven, and Quan Yin Buddha.|||The Co Tham shrine is located next to the main temple, on the left, with a concrete vaulted architecture, on the altar is a statue of Co Tham wearing a green shirt, under the pedestal is a pair of phoenixes carved in stone.|||It is known that at the end of the 19th century, the temple was restored to worship Co Tham, a female general who bravely led the army to defeat the Black Flag enemy.|||The elderly still tell the story of Tham, the daughter of an old fisherman, known for her beauty, kindness, and elegance. She was admired by young men from all over the region. At a young age, she was taken by the lord of the region to be his wife. She lived a life of luxury but was filled with a hundred humiliations, especially when the Black Flag invaders came to harass, and the lord not only failed to resist but also collaborated with them. She found ways to escape and gather the poor to rise up against the invaders. The lord, consumed by resentment and a desire for merit, led the invaders to attack. The female general led the army bravely to fight back. A fierce battle took place at Trang Co River, with blood flowing like a river, but her soldiers remained unwavering. Unfortunately, the female general was hit by a poisoned arrow and died. Her soldiers were furious and decided to fight to avenge her. The invaders fled in terror, and the lord was captured and executed to appease their commander. To commemorate the brave female general, the people built a temple in her honor.|||Every year, pilgrims from all over come to Den Tham for worship and prayer, especially during the first days of the Lunar New Year. After many years of restoration and repair, in 2012, the temple was recognized as a provincial historical and cultural relic, serving as a cultural and spiritual hub for the local people.

title: Dau Dang Waterfall
description: About 4km from Puong Cave along the Song Nang river, a small stream on the left will lead visitors from Song Nang river into Ba Be lake. However, continue for about 2.5km to reach Hua Tang Tay village (Nam Mau commune) at the border of Tuyen Quang province. The name Hua Tang translates to Dau Dang in Kinh language. Here, boats cannot proceed further because the river is blocked by large and small rocks stacked over nearly 2km, dividing the water into several small streams, creating the Dau Dang waterfall, which is both majestic and spectacular.|||The 53m-high waterfall pours water from the entire Song Nang river, winding between large limestone rocks stacked on top of each other and divided into three sections: the first section, water flows strongly and turbulently from the top; the second section, water splits into two streams; and the third section, the waterfall flows gently between the rocks, serene and romantic. Visitors will be surprised and fascinated by the contrast between the gentle river and the fierce waterfall with murky sediment. In the midst of wild and majestic nature, humans feel weak and small.|||Visitors are warmly welcomed by Hua Tang locals, and have the opportunity to enjoy Anh Vu fish, vow xao (stir-fried bamboo shoots) with homemade rice wine made from forest leaves, which are specialties of Ba Be lake. If lucky, visitors can also try Chien fish, which is rare in the market and can weigh up to 10kg.

title: Roọm Waterfall
description: Bac Kan – a northern mountainous province with untouched natural spots, caves, and cascading waterfalls. Upon setting foot in Bac Kan, visitors are likely to head to Ba Be Lake, Ba Be National Park, and Puong Cave, which are renowned domestically and internationally. However, none would miss the chance to witness the pristine and majestic beauty of Roọm Waterfall|||The waterfall's flow is sometimes powerful and fierce, hitting rocks and creating high splashes that form silver waves; at other times, it gently flows through stone crevices, producing sounds like melodies from a mountainous region.|||In the fresh, airy, and cool atmosphere, people seem to shed their fatigue, tension, and worries, rediscovering themselves in peace and serenity.|||Notable features: Roọm Waterfall area comprises a cluster of beautiful rocks, mountains, and rivers blending with the natural scenery. The waterfall is where the Cau River is blocked by a 1 km stretch of rocky outcrops, creating a picturesque scene.|||Related services: After swimming and playing, visitors can dine and rest at local spots in the village or town to recharge for another day exploring Bac Kan's appealing destinations.|||Nearby attractions: Historical Nà Tu relic site, Deo Giàng, Phu Thong Fort, Ba Be National Park, Puong Cave, Thắm Temple, etc., are options for visitors to continue their journey.

title: Tam Son Pagoda
description: Tam Son village has a pagoda named Cam Ung Tu, built on the top of Chua mountain, in Tam Son commune, Tu Son town. The pagoda was built during the Ly dynasty and was a major Buddhist center associated with the life of the king who founded the Ly dynasty and the princesses of the Ly family. The pagoda was continuously restored, renovated, and expanded during the Tran, Le, and Nguyen dynasties into a large pagoda with many buildings.|||The uniqueness of Tam Son Pagoda is not only a place of Buddhist worship but also honors the princesses of the Ly dynasty and famous scholars of the village who are revered as 'hau Phat', reflecting the distinct tradition of Tam Son village, known for its love of learning and scholarly achievements.|||The statues in the pagoda are masterpieces of Buddhist sculpture from the Le and Nguyen dynasties. The pagoda also preserves many valuable artifacts, including bronze bells, incense burners, and a stele 'Tam son xa dang khoa bi ky' from the early 20th century, listing 16 eminent scholars from Tam Son village.|||The pagoda and people of Tam Son were honored to welcome President Ho Chi Minh in 1967.|||The pagoda was destroyed by American bombing in 1972 but was rebuilt according to its original architecture to serve the spiritual needs of the people and preserve memories of the Ly dynasty, King Ly Thai To, and President Ho Chi Minh.|||Tam Son Pagoda was recognized as a national historical and cultural relic by the state in 1992.

title: Chua To (Phuc Nghiem Tu)
description: Chua To, also known as Phuc Nghiem Tu, is located in Man Xa village, Xa Ha Man commune, Thuan Thanh district, Bac Ninh province. The temple was built around the 2nd century AD, during 25-187. In 1313, it was renovated with 50 rooms, as recorded on a pair of ceremonial couplets:|||"Ngui thap gian pham vu huy hoang nam thien thang tich|||Thien van co huong hoa cung giang bac dia danh nam".|||The temple worships Buddha Mother Man Nuong, part of the Tu Phap complex, linked to the legend of Khau Da La, the founder of Buddhism. A folk saying goes: "There is a teacher who stays in the West, practicing and meditating under the name Khau Da La". It is said that Khau Da La was a holy monk who came to Luu Lau (now Thuan Thanh) to preach.|||According to legend, in Men village (the ancient name of Man Xa), Man Nuong, the daughter of Tien Ong Tu Dinh, went to the temple to study. One day, after sweeping the temple, she fell asleep at the entrance. Khau Da La, returning from preaching, did not want to wake her and stepped over her. Man Nuong later became pregnant and gave birth to a girl.|||Along with other high-ranking monks, he founded the Tu Phap system, including Van, Vu, Loi, and Dien, corresponding to cloud, rain, thunder, and lightning. This system quickly spread and became part of the folk beliefs, showing the compatibility between Buddhism and daily life, praying for favorable weather, a good harvest, and a better life for the people.|||Khau Da La took the child to a dung tree (mulberry tree), and unexpectedly, the tree's branches spread out, and the child disappeared into the trunk! Later, the tree was knocked down by a storm and floated to Luu Lau. The villagers tried to pull it ashore but failed. Man Nuong, knowing the story, came to the river and, as if by maternal instinct, threw her hairpin and pulled the tree to the shore, to everyone's surprise. According to legend, the child later became Thanh Cao Vuong Phat, residing at Dau temple. The tree was carved into four gods of Tu Phap and worshiped at Dau, Dau, Tuong, and Dan temples.|||The family of Man Nuong's parents was built into a temple, and later generations often referred to Chua To as "Cai gia vi tu".|||Chua To is closely tied to Vietnam's Buddhist history and is where some of the earliest architectural works appear, such as wells, bells, bronze khans, stone steles, and wooden engravings. The temple still has an ancient well, said to have been created by Man Nuong, using the staff of Khau Da La to save the crops from drought.|||Every year, on the 8th day of the 4th lunar month, people from all over the country come to visit and participate in the festival at Chua To.|||The temple was ranked as a national historical and cultural site on April 20, 2001.

title: Dong Ho Painting Village
description: The colors of the paintings remain vibrant and fresh even after they dry, giving the impression of being wet. The shapes and colors are arranged next to each other.|||Oh, girl with a green waistband|||Come back to Mai Village with me|||Mai Village has a calendar and rules|||There is a cool bathing pond and a painting craft.|||Dong Ho - a familiar and charming village name, located on the banks of the Duong River, has long been part of the spiritual life of Vietnamese people with famous folk paintings, rich in national character.|||Dong Ho village paintings are not drawn by artistic inspiration, but made using wooden blocks for printing. To have engravings that reach a high level of sophistication, there must be a draftsperson. The draftsperson and the engraver require a love for art, an artistic soul, and high technical skills. The printing process is perhaps not too difficult, as anyone can apply color to the woodblock and print.|||The paper used for printing is a type of smooth Xuan paper. Before printing, the paper is coated with a layer of crushed eggshell, which creates a distinctive material for Dong Ho folk paintings.|||The colors blend naturally. The painting colors are often taken from natural materials: black is made from burnt bamboo leaves; green is made from the bark and leaves of the tràm tree; yellow is made from the flowers of the hòe tree; red is made from the trunk and roots of the vang tree; and white is made from crushed eggshell...In recent years, some people have used modern chemicals and colors for printing, which has increased production but compromised the traditional color quality and made the colors less vibrant. Moreover, the colors fade quickly.|||Dong Ho folk paintings do not strictly follow anatomical rules, light principles, or the laws of perspective in modern painting. The artists creating folk paintings often use a stylized approach to composition and color description. All of them use a simple line drawing style to express themselves, making the paintings interesting with naive and simple but reasonable and sensible details.|||Not only do Hanoi residents and people from some provinces and cities in the country appreciate and love Dong Ho folk paintings, but also many foreign tourists, artists, and art enthusiasts come to research and admire the famous folk art of Dong Ho village.

title: Den Do Festival
description: The Den Do Festival takes place on the 14th, 15th, and 16th of the third lunar month every year in Dinh Bang village, Dinh Bang commune, Tu Son district, Bac Ninh province. This is a festival rich in national cultural identity, echoing the call of ancestral roots, commemorating the coronation of King Ly Cong Uan, marking the beginning of a prosperous dynasty, and building and developing the country and the brilliant culture of Dai Viet.|||Den Do is a beautiful temple located in Dinh Bang village, Tien Son district, Bac Ninh province, 18 km from Hanoi. The temple is dedicated to 8 kings of the Ly dynasty: Ly Cong Uan or Ly Thai To (1009 - 1028); Ly Thai Tong (1028 - 1054); Ly Thanh Tong (1054 - 1072); Ly Nhan Tong (1072 - 1128); Ly Than Tong (1128 - 1138); Ly Anh Tong (1138 - 1175); Ly Cao Tong (1175 - 1210) and Ly Hue Tong (1210 - 1224).|||Den Do, also known as Co Phap Dien or Ly Bat De temple, was built in the 11th century (1030), on the southeast land of Huong Co Phap, Chau Co Phap (Dinh Bang village). According to Zen master Ly Van Hanh, this land is where the heavenly breath gathers, with 8 dragon heads facing the temple.|||The Den Do Festival lasts for 3 days (from 14th to 16th of the third lunar month), with the main event on the 16th, the day King Ly Thai To ascended the throne, featuring a sacred ceremony and a grand procession. The procession, with tens of thousands of participants, starts from Kim Dai temple to Den Do (about 3 km). The procession begins with a group of martial officers, bare-chested, wearing loincloths, holding shields and followed by hundreds of soldiers. Next is a group of 100 people carrying a red-draped palanquin with black hats.|||The palanquin of Thanh Mau is led by 18 female officers, followed by the Bat De palanquin, each with a horse and 16 male officers wearing red clothes. The procession continues with people wearing festival costumes, elderly villagers, and locals, with flags and parasols covering the field, and the sound of drums filling the sky. Besides the ceremonial part, the festival includes various folk games such as cockfighting, releasing pigeons, wrestling, Quan ho singing, and many other entertainment activities.|||The Den Do Festival is a long-standing traditional festival that has become a custom voluntarily preserved by the people of Dinh Bang, and an indispensable part of the spiritual and cultural life of the locals. With its traditional historical and cultural values, the Den Do Festival serves as a reminder to future generations to cherish and preserve the cultural heritage built by their ancestors.|||Visitors to the festival can pay homage to the 8 kings of the Ly dynasty and visit the scenic Kinh Bac region. The Den Do procession highlights the sacred significance of the festival, remembering historical figures and stirring up pride in the ancestral roots and the revival and prosperity of the country since the Dai Viet era.

title: Lim Festival
description: Lim Festival is a unique cultural and artistic celebration of Quan ho villages, formed long ago. The festival has attracted many people of all ages from everywhere to join in the spring festivities, mostly young men and women. As usual, they come together to sing and for the elderly, it's an opportunity to revisit their youth, while for young men and women, it's a chance to find friends and love. This distinctive cultural event has become a priceless asset in Vietnam's folk culture heritage.|||Similar to other traditional festivals, Lim Festival also features solemn and respectful ritual activities to honor the merits of the gods, such as processions, sacrifices, and folk games for entertainment and competition. Early on the 13th, a procession of scriptures from Trung Temple to Hong An Temple takes place, followed by rituals and then a procession to fetch sacred water from Hong An Temple back to Trung Temple. After the procession, the festival's opening ceremony begins.|||When guests visit, they rarely see such a spectacle; however, at Lim Festival, visitors want to see, hear, and sing Quan ho with the 'liền anh' and 'liền chị'. This is also the most basic characteristic of this festival.|||Quan ho is a unique folk song from Kinh Bac region (now Bac Ninh province). Quan ho folk songs are famous not only for their romantic lyrics, passionate love for life and love, or 200 distinctive musical tunes but also for their rare characteristics compared to folk songs in other regions. From daily conversations to behaviors at festivals, 'Quan ho people' are always gentle and humble. The custom of 'kết chạ' between Quan ho villages or making friends between Quan ho groups has formed a noble moral lifestyle. Quan ho people are 'liền anh', 'liền chị' and always refer to themselves as 'liền em'. For Quan ho people, when guests come, they must:|||Lấy than, quạt nước tiễn trà người xơi.|||Trà này ngon lắm người ơi,|||Người xơi một chén cho tôi bằng lòng.|||And when it's time to leave, the farewell is difficult because the songs always seem to hold guests back:|||Người ơi, người ở đừng về...|||The Quan ho singing festival is often associated with temple festivals. Therefore, temples are where Quan ho people gather and welcome guests. There are 49 villages that sing Quan ho, located in four districts and towns in the south of Bac Ninh province. But when it comes to Quan ho, people immediately think of Lim Festival. Lim is the colloquial name for Lung Giang commune. The festival takes place on a hill where Lim Temple (Hong An Temple) is located. Lim Festival is the most crowded and famous among Quan ho festivals. The festival takes place on the 13th of the first lunar month, which is the first day of Lim Market.|||At Lim Festival, spring tourists can watch and listen to Quan ho singing on hills, behind temples, on boats, and in private houses; they can also listen to pair singing (male and female duets) or groups of males and females. Visitors can also experience other traditional cultural activities of the locality or participate in traditional games like swinging, cockfighting, bird fighting, wrestling, and communal games, which are heritages of ancient village festivals preserved by Lim Festival.

title: Chua Dai Bi
description: Chua Dai Bi, also known as To or Tay Pagoda, is located on a riverbank about 1km from the southern bank of the Duong River and 100m from the outside of the Duong dike, in Van Ty village, Thai Bao commune, Gia Binh district, Bac Ninh province.|||According to ancient records, this pagoda was built by Hyen Quang in 1305 on a beautiful site to the west of the house during a visit to his parents' hometown. It was named Dai Bi Tu, symbolizing the great compassion of Buddha and the Bodhisattva Quan The Am who helped his parents embrace Buddhism.|||Chua Dai Bi has undergone many renovations and restorations, with the earliest architectural features dating back to the Le and Nguyen dynasties.|||The temple grounds also house the 'Temple of Three Patriarchs', dedicated to Tran Nhan Tong, Phap Loa, and Huyen Quang, the three patriarchs of the Truc Lam Zen sect.|||Behind the temple, in 2005, the local people rebuilt a communal house to honor three national heroes who defeated the invading Thuc army during the 18th reign of Hung Vuong.|||Dai Bi Pagoda has a unique architecture. The Tam Bao (main sanctuary) follows a special architectural structure known as 'chuoi vo' (a type of traditional Vietnamese wooden structure), comprising a front hall and an upper hall, facing south towards the Duong River dike.|||This architectural work was renovated during the Nguyen Dynasty and remains well-preserved to this day. The front hall consists of 5 rooms and 2 gables, with 4 curved roof ridges and a pediment decorated with 3 Chinese characters 'Dai Bi Tu'. The front hall has a door and a wooden partition across all 5 rooms.|||The frame of the front hall is made of Lim wood, constructed in the 'con chong gia chieng' style, with 8 rows of horizontal columns and 4 rows of vertical columns. The con chong (decorative wooden posts) are decorated with intricate carvings of stylized flowers and leaves. The middle room of the front hall connects to the upper hall, while the side rooms house statues of Hoi Phap (Protector Deity), Duc Ong (the virtuous lord), and Thanh Hien (Sage).|||The back sanctum connects to the central compartment of the main hall with 3 rooms, where low brick shelves are built, graduating from inside out, to place the worship statues. The system of statues here includes some newly carved by the people, while the rest date back to the Nguyen dynasty. The arrangement of statues is similar to many temples in the Red River Delta, however, some statues are placed incorrectly according to Buddhist principles.|||Located on the right side of the main hall, separated by a spacious courtyard, is the Ancestor Temple. This is where the three patriarchs of the Truc Lam Zen sect are revered. The temple faces west, with an architectural structure of the chuoi vo style, comprising 3 front rooms and 1 rear chamber. The frame is made of lim wood, with columns still bearing inscriptions in Chinese characters recording the names of those who contributed to the temple's renovation. The roof is built in the con chong gia chieng style, with a smooth, plain finish.|||At the temple, in the rear sanctum is a large altar, inside which are placed the statues of the Three Ancestors, meticulously carved and lacquered with gold. In the altar, in the center is the statue of King Buddha Tran Nhan Tong, on the left is the statue of Huyền Quang, on the right is the statue of Pháp Loa. The statues are carved in a meditative posture, wearing Buddhist robes, each with a distinct facial expression but all exuding intelligence and a serene, elegant aura. In front of the altar is an intricately carved ceremonial gate with themes of the four spirits and four precious things, leading to a compartment with a solemn display of ceremonial objects.|||Behind the Ancestor's house is a guest house, a monk's quarters and a communal house; behind the main hall is a stele house, recording the life and career of the third patriarch, Huyền Quang. Behind the stele house is a communal pavilion recently rebuilt in 200, consisting of 5 rooms and 2 gables. This is a place of worship for the three village guardians who defeated the Thuc invaders during the 18th reign of Hung Vuong.|||The Dai Bi Pagoda relic was recognized and ranked as a National historical site by the Ministry of Culture and Information (now the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism) in Decision No. 34/VH-QD on January 9, 1990.

title: Chua Dam
description: Chua Dam, also known as Chua Ram, is located in Nam Son commune, Bac Ninh city, Bac Ninh province. It is a famous Buddhist temple from the Ly dynasty and an important historical site with nearly 1,000 years of history.|||According to historical records such as Viet Su Luoc, Dai Viet Su Ky Toan Thu, Dai Nam Nhat Thong Chi, and Lich Trieu Hien Chuong Loai Chi, in 1085, Queen Ly Y Lan had the intention of building a temple while visiting Dai Lam Son.|||The Ly dynasty ordered the construction of the temple in 1086. The next year, King Ly Nhan Tong visited the temple, had a banquet, and composed a poem called Lam Son Da Yien. After ten years of construction, in 1097, Chua Dam was completed and was named Canh Long Dong Khanh by the king. The king also granted 300 mau of land to the temple and assigned seven families to take care of the temple's gates. In 1105, three stone towers were built at Lam Son temple.|||Over time, the temple received special attention from the royal court and was expanded. King Tran Nhan Tong visited and praised the temple's architecture in a poem.

title: Dinh - Chua Khuc Toai
description: Located in a cradle of history and culture, Khuc Toai has long been famous in folklore as a village specializing in wooden household utensils, known for the saying 'Ma Dong Ho, do lang Choi'. It's also a village of traditional Quan Ho singing with famous and talented young men and women.|||The historical and cultural depth of Khuc Toai is distilled and shines in the complex of ancient communal house and temple. The dinh and chua of Khuc Toai are situated next to each other, forming a sacred ancient complex in the village, facing southeast.|||In front of the complex is a large pond and vast fields with lush green rice all year round. Behind it is 'Choi' bridge and 'Choi' market, which have become an integral part of the folk memory in Kinh Bac region.|||The bridge was built on a large scale during the Le Trung Hung period with the 'thuong gia ha kieu' style, connecting the village's hamlets and enhancing their density and warmth. This bridge holds significant architectural and artistic value and has been photographed by the Institute of Far Eastern Antiquities for preservation and research.|||The Choi market was once famous in folklore with its fair on the 8th day of the first lunar month, featuring various goods and the 'an cuon' custom.|||Khuc Toai Temple is not only known for its beautiful scenery, but also stands out with its historical, cultural and artistic values. The temple's literary name is 'Dien Phuc Tu'. According to the inscription, it was once a famous ancient site in Kinh Bac. According to local legend, it was built on a large scale by a local scholar, Nguyen Thuong Nghiem, during the Le Dynasty; therefore, the locals worship him as Hau Phat at the temple. The Dien Phuc Temple preserves many precious artifacts: A set of Buddha statues from the Le and Nguyen dynasties; a statue of Nguyen Thuong Nghiem; stone steles, stone incense burners; particularly a bronze bell with the temple's name and dated 'Phuc Thai 6' (1648), which is one of the oldest bells in Vietnam. The body of the bell is engraved with Chinese characters telling about Vietnam's ancient historical sites such as Bao Thien Tower, Quynh Lam Pagoda, Pho Minh Stupa, Pha Lai Pagoda and treasures of 'An Nam Tu Khi' from those sites; it also engraves a poem praising Khuc Toai's rich homeland and literature.|||Khuc Toai communal house was also built a long time ago, but it was restored and expanded on a large scale during the Nguyen dynasty. On the front beam of the Tien Te (Front Worship) hall, there is still an original Chinese inscription recording the restoration year 'Duy Tan Quy Suu nien' (1913). This is a unique and representative architectural work of the Nguyen dynasty that has been preserved to this day. The Dai dinh (main hall) has an architectural layout of 'square walls and a curved roof', with layers of curved and elegant roof tiles by the river. The frame of the communal house is made of precious lim wood, decorated with magnificent decorations and intricate carvings concentrated in the Tien Te hall.|||The artisans of Khuc Toai village have demonstrated their creative talent in this communal house using various artistic techniques: relief carvings, sculpted carvings, perforated carvings, and channel carvings. The architectural parts such as the roof, rungs, brackets, and pillars are all carved and decorated. The Tien Te hall has two central roof frames with a 'stacked rung' structure and the heads of the rungs are carved with flowers and leaves in a free-flowing style. The side rooms have roof frames of the 'pan me' type, with dragon and tiger head carvings.|||The dragon and tiger head statue aims to emphasize the majesty and sacredness of the communal house. The pillars are decorated with dragon heads holding beads with intricate carvings. The central room features two large dragons with complete details of head, body, and tail; however, the dragon scales are designed as blooming flowers and leaves. Twenty-seven pillars in the central room are carved with half-body dragons coiled in clouds approaching the communal house. The other seven pillars are carved with leaf-like dragons. The wooden door in the central room is carved with various themes from Confucianism, Taoism, and Buddhism, such as: Two dragons worshiping the moon, dragon descending, phoenix dancing, dragon and horse reading books, and precious objects… The woodcarving art of Khuc Toai communal house not only demonstrates the talent of ancient artisans but also conveys their aspirations for a prosperous and peaceful society. Along with architectural and sculptural values, Khuc Toai communal house preserves many precious artifacts, including 20 royal decrees from various dynasties for the worship of Saint 'Tam Giang', saints 'Quy Minh', 'Trung Hue', 'Dong Vinh' (the earliest decree dates back to 1730, and the latest to 1924), three stone steles from the reign of Bao Dai 3 (1928) documenting the restoration of the communal house during the Nguyen dynasty; and many ancient ceremonial objects such as incense altars, worshipped beds, ceremonial chairs, and precious objects - outstanding artworks from the Le and Nguyen dynasties.|||In addition to its outstanding values in architecture, sculpture and antiques, Khuc Toai temple and pagoda also holds significant traditional festival values. Every year, the pagoda festival on the 14th day of the Lunar New Year and the temple festival on the 6th day of the Lunar New Year are famous Quan Ho festivals of Kinh Bac. The Khuc Toai temple and pagoda complex with its many-sided values in architecture, sculpture, antiques and festivals not only is a unique cultural heritage of a once famous craft village in folklore but also contributes to the typical cultural heritage of Bac Ninh homeland.

title: Phuc Lam Pagoda
