description: Phuc Lam Pagoda is an ancient pagoda located in the west of Tam Tao village (Phu Lam commune, Tien Du district, Bac Ninh province). Until now, the exact time of construction is unclear, but it is known that the first major renovation took place about 500 years ago.|||The pagoda has a shape like a mountain, with eight roofs and eight corner spires. On both sides are two rows of auxiliary buildings, each with five rooms. Behind the pagoda is a 4-room Ancestor's Hall. The main hall consists of 7 rooms and 2 wings. The columns and roof frame are made of solid lim wood. The roof spires are intricately carved with four-linh and four-quy patterns. The pagoda still preserves many precious artifacts such as Tam The statues, stone steles, stone nghia… There is also a stone incense burner with unknown age.|||In addition to the main structures, the pagoda also has a Tam Quan gate with large Chinese characters 'Phuc Lam Tu' in an ancient style, a Quan Am tower, a stupa garden… In front of the main hall and on the left side of the pagoda's courtyard, there is a stone archway with three raised Chinese characters 'Giao Si Duong'. Opposite the stone archway, on the other side of the pagoda's courtyard (also on the right side of the main hall) and one knee into the main hall, is the Giao Duong building.|||In the pagoda's grounds, there is also a stupa garden, ancient trees, a Tam Quan gate. In the temple grounds, there is a beautiful well. In front of the pagoda, there is an ancient temple thousands of years old. The pagoda was restored in 2009 but still retains its ancient charm. Phuc Lam Pagoda is one of the largest pagodas in Phu Lam commune.|||Legend has it that Dao Dat and Dao Minh were two generals who helped King Thuc An Duong Vuong fight against the northern invaders. When the Co Loa citadel fell, the two generals retreated to Tam Tao village and opened a school. The current Giao Duong building was built by the people of Tam Tao village on the old foundation where the school was located, which was also the place where the two generals lived and died. To commemorate their merits, the people built a shrine to worship them.|||After Dao Dat and Dao Minh passed away, the villagers built a small shrine with five rooms next to the pagoda, generation after generation burning incense in their honor. Thus, it is very likely that the shrine to Dao Dat and Dao Minh was built immediately after the fall of Au Lac kingdom (around 208 or 179 BC). If counted until now, it has been nearly two thousand years old. This information also provides a basis to assume the time when Phuc Lam Pagoda was first built.|||In 2016, Phuc Lam Pagoda (Phuc Lam Tu) was recognized and granted a certificate of historical and cultural relic by Bac Ninh province People's Committee.

title: Le Phung Hieu Temple
description: Le Phung Hieu Temple located in Hoa Dinh area, Vo Cuong ward, Bac Ninh city, was originally built a long time ago but restored recently. The temple preserves many valuable ancient artifacts about the deified person, especially two stone steles named 'Pha luc tam vi thanh' dated 1901 and 'Su tich bi ky' dated 1880, which describe Le Phung Hieu and two heroes of the Ly dynasty.||||||Le Phung Hieu was born on the 8th of January in 982 in Bang Son village, Hoang Hoa district, Thanh Hoa province. From a young age, he was very passionate about martial arts such as boxing, sword dancing, and knife throwing. As he grew up, he became a strong and exceptionally skilled martial artist. King Ly Thai To heard about him and had him summoned to the capital Thang Long, where he was promoted to the rank of Vu Ve Tuong Quan.|||In 1028, Ly Thai To passed away, and the royal court followed his instructions to install Prince Tat Ma as king (Ly Thai Tong). However, three princes, namely Dong Chinh Vuong, Duc Thanh Vuong, and Vu Duc Vuong, led their armies to surround Thang Long citadel to start a rebellion (known in old records as the Three Princes' Rebellion).|||Prince Buddha Ma entered Can Nguyen Hall from Truong Phu Gate and knew something was amiss. He ordered all gates closed and said: 'I have not wronged my brothers, but now the three princes are doing something unjust, forgetting the late emperor's teachings to usurp the throne. What do you think?' The people in the palace asked to go out and fight a decisive battle. Le Phung Hieu, on his own horse, charged straight to Quang Phuc Gate, killed Vu Duc Vuong. The armies of Dong Chinh Vuong and Duc Thanh Vuong ran away in fear. After calming the Three Princes' rebellion, the king's throne was secured. King Ly Thai Tong then granted Le Phung Hieu the title of 'Do Thong'.|||In 1044, the Cham army invaded our country, and General Le Phung Hieu accompanied the king to fight against the enemy. Upon their victorious return, the king rewarded him with titles and fiefs. However, he only asked to climb Mount Bang Son and throw a large sword far away, and wherever it fell, he would be granted land to govern. The king agreed, and Le Phung Hieu climbed Mount Bang Son and threw the sword over 10 miles away to the village of Da Mi. The king then granted him that land as "thuc ap" (a fief), and from then on, the custom of "Thac dao dien" began.|||Later, he led many military campaigns against the Cham and returned victorious. He lived a life of loyalty to the king, always discussing matters that benefited the people and the country. He lived to be 77 years old, and after his passing, people in many places built temples in his honor.|||The Hoà Đình Temple has long been famous for its traditional festival. According to old customs, every year on the 6th day of the 2nd lunar month, the temple holds an annual festival. From the 5th day on, the villagers organize a procession to bring the royal seal from Trung Quan tower to the temple and carry the palanquin from the temple to the communal house for worship. The procession is complete with flags, banners, umbrellas, and gongs. In the afternoon of the 5th day, they hold the "entering the books" ceremony.|||During the festival days, after the ceremonial part, there is the festive part with folk games such as wrestling, tree climbing, boat racing, and Quan Ho singing… Notably, on the morning of the 6th day, there is the "wrestling worship" custom: The village selects two elderly men who are still healthy and have harmonious families to participate in the wrestling match. Right after that, young men in the village and wrestlers from other villages come to participate in the competition. The prizes are not very big, but the winners are considered to be lucky for the whole year. This custom is related to the worship of Lê Phụng Hiểu, who was skilled in martial arts.|||General Le Phung Hieu was a highly meritorious figure under the Ly Dynasty. His name and merits are not only recorded in historical books but also passed down through folklore. Kinh Bac - Bac Ninh was where he wandered as a child and led troops to fight enemies, so many communes have worshiped him as the village guardian deity, typically Hoa Dinh Temple.

title: Den Ba Chua Kho
description: In the ancient and culturally rich Kinh Bac region, the Temple of Ba Chua Kho in Co Me village, Vu Ninh ward, Bac Ninh city, is one of the most revered and famous temples dedicated to the goddess.|||Every day, hundreds of people from within and outside the country come to worship, pray for prosperity and wealth, but it is most bustling and vibrant in the 1st and 2nd lunar months of the year.|||People come here with a shared belief that Ba Chua Kho will bless their businesses with smooth operations, prosperity, and good fortune.|||Legend has it that Ba Chua Kho was a woman from Qua Cam village, with extraordinary beauty and great organizational skills. She managed to produce, store food and oversee the national treasury during and after the victory at Nhu Nguyet in 1076 led by Ly Thuong Kiet.|||She also attracted settlers, established villages in Qua Cam, Co Me, Thuong Dong, and helped people clear land for agriculture.|||She later became Queen under the Ly dynasty, assisting the king in governing the country and managing the grain store. She was killed by enemies while distributing grain to save the villagers.|||Moved by her compassion, the king posthumously honored her as Phuc Than. The people of Co Me are grateful for her and built the Temple of Ba Chua Kho at the old grain store location on Nui Kho.|||The temple was established during the Ly Dynasty, initially a small shrine. During the Le Dynasty, it was renovated and expanded into a large temple complex with many architectural works: Tam quan gate, road, yard, forecourt, second hall, rear palace - a solemn worship center with meticulously carved images of the Goddess. Despite being damaged by time and war, in 1989, Ba Chua Kho Temple was recognized by the State as a national historical and cultural relic, and Bac Ninh province has since restored and expanded it on a large scale, including various architectural works such as: Tam mon gate, Forecourt, third hall, second hall, Upper hall (Goddess hall), Son Trang tower, Lau Co, Lau Cau, "Cửu trùng thiên" altar and other auxiliary works. Most of the works have been restored and embellished with a traditional appearance, enhancing the value of the relic.|||Every year on the 12th day of the first lunar month, to commemorate the anniversary of Ba Chua Kho's death, the local people of Co Me and visitors often hold an incense-offering ceremony, prepare offerings to worship Ba Chua Kho, and then offer them to the altars in the temple in the following order: Tien Te, Tu Phu Cong Dong, De Nhi Cung, De Nhat Cung (The Three Sacred Ladies); worship Buddha at the village pagoda and worship Thanh Tam Giang at the communal house. The offerings can include vegetarian and non-vegetarian dishes, live animals, Son Trang cakes, fruits, incense, and ceremonial items.|||Visitors to the Temple come to pray for peace, fortune, but mostly to 'borrow capital' from Ba Chua Kho, wishing for a prosperous year, good business and success. The 'borrowing capital' ritual is very clear: people write in the prayer how much they borrow, for what, and when they will repay. Some even promise to repay triple or tenfold... with the notion that if you borrow, you must repay, so regardless of whether business is good or not, people still keep their promises, which is to make offerings at the end of the year at the Temple of Ba Chua Kho.|||During the beginning of the year, around the Temple there are hundreds of shops selling worship items, bustling with people coming and going. The ceremonial altars are purchased by pilgrims according to their preferences, sometimes simple incense sticks, flowers and a few sets of hell banknotes, other times more elaborate with a dish of glutinous rice, a tray of five fruits, or a whole roasted chicken... The main intention is to pray sincerely.|||To serve visitors attending the festival, the people of Co Me have organized to welcome and serve everyone with increasing attention, aiming to minimize and gradually eliminate negative issues, hoping to satisfy the pilgrims visiting the Temple.|||People come here not only to pray and wish for good fortune but also to meet and admire the scenery of the Temple. They can visit famous historical and cultural sites such as: Co Me Village Communal House, Bac Ninh Ancient Citadel, Bac Ninh Temple of Literature; explore the old quarters and enjoy the local specialties of Bac Ninh.

title: Ngoc Well - Den Cung
description: Even if you visit temples everywhere. It's not as sacred as lighting incense at Den Cung.|||With magical and sacred stories told for generations, Den Cung - Ngoc Well is a spiritual destination attracting pilgrims from afar, especially during the new year.|||Den Cung - Giong Ngoc Temple in Viem Xa, Hoa Long Ward, Bac Ninh City (also known as Diem village), is a sacred place of worship for the Three Palace Mother Goddesses from ancient times.|||The temple's spirituality has been famous in folklore for a long time, dating back to the pre-Ly and pre-Le dynasties.|||During the Ly dynasty, the imperial army fought against invaders along the Cau River and came to this temple to pray for victory, which was then granted.|||Today, this place is a popular tourist destination, attracting many visitors who come to pray for love, career, and good family fortune. As you walk through the Tam Quan gate of Den Cung, you see a harmonious and ancient architectural complex. The space here is very airy with many ancient trees providing shade, making visitors always feel peaceful and refreshing.|||The Jade Well is located in the middle of Den Cung yard. On hot days, after sightseeing and visiting the temple to make offerings, tourists often don't forget to ask for water from the Jade Well to drink. The Jade Well is semi-circular in shape, about 20m2 wide, with 11 brick steps, 4 stone steps and 1 wooden step made of lim wood at the edge of the well. At the bottom of the well is a natural layer of porous stone, about 10m deep, the water in Jade Well is clear blue, you can see down to the bottom.|||To fetch water, visitors have to leave their shoes on the shore and walk barefoot down to the well. The water scooped from the well can be drunk directly without filtering or boiling, and it tastes refreshingly sweet and natural. According to the locals in Diem village, the water flows from the mountain and seeps through layers of sandstone, creating its unique sweetness and coolness. That's why the villagers often take water from Ngoc Well to make tea for guests, and brew wine for important family and clan events. For tourists visiting and worshiping at Den Cung Temple, Ngoc Well water is not just a drink, but also believed to bring health and clarity. Therefore, many people bring containers to ask for well water to take home, hoping to bring good luck and fortune to their families.|||Diem Village is famous as the cradle of Quan ho folk songs. To have the enchanting Quan ho singing with a resonant, deep, smooth, and lively voice, people in Diem Village believe it's thanks to drinking water from Gien Ngoc Well. Although the magical effect of this water is yet to be confirmed, those who have heard the Quan ho melodies here can easily recognize the unique, sweet, and profound resonance in the voices of the singers.|||Although the water from Gien Ngoc well has been used by tourists and locals for a long time, it has never run dry, even during drought seasons. On days when the water level is low, visitors can easily see three 'divine fish' swimming in the well. The locals call them 'divine' because no one in Diem village knows exactly when these three fish appeared. The villagers believe that they are the incarnations of two princesses, Ngoc Dung and Thuy Tien, and one of their ladies-in-waiting. Cung Temple is where the two princesses of the Ly dynasty, who founded the village and taught the locals their crafts, are worshiped. During the Bao Thai reign, a temple was built on stone pillars, and remnants of it still exist today. Subsequent dynasties have conferred titles upon the Goddess worshiped here.|||After the floods in 1957 and 1971, which caused the well to overflow, the three fish still lived here without swimming away. Villagers also released some fish and turtles into the well, but strangely, they soon died or moved away. With many magical and sacred stories told for generations. Today, visitors to Den Cung and Giong Ngoc well not only come to pray for good luck and wish for good things, but also want to go down to get water from the well, take a sip to taste the quintessence of a Quan Ho village.

title: Den Vua Ba
description: Legend has it that "Vua Ba" is the princess and daughter of the sixth Hung King. When she reached marriageable age, her father held a "throwing the ball" ceremony to find a suitable husband for his daughter. Unfortunately, the person the princess disliked was the one who caught the ball.|||She asked her father, the king, to let her leave the palace with her ladies-in-waiting and live a simple life. When she arrived at Viêm Trang, she was charmed by the gentle river, beautiful scenery, and fertile soil. She decided to settle down, reclaim the land, and teach the locals how to grow crops, raise silkworms, and weave fabric.|||Miraculously, she composed songs and taught the people how to sing them. These were the first folk songs of Quan Họ.|||Therefore, 'Queen Bà' is considered the ancestor of Quan Họ culture.|||Is it because of that, that until now, men and women from the same village are not allowed to marry, and have to be as unrelated as "Vua Ba"? Is it because of that, that out of ten folk songs, nine talk about longing, yearning, asking, and melancholic rendezvous?|||Is it not so, that the poignant beauty of both those 'still destined' and 'no longer destined' is layered upon one another through the ages, like salt rubbed into the heart of those who have been wounded and not yet healed, since ancient times. Is it not so, that on that mat, six artisans: Ngo Thi Khu, 90; Nguyen Thi Vu, 85; Ngo Thi Lich, 82; Nguyen Thi Ban, 79; Ngo Van Su, 87, and Nguyen Van Bat, 86; play the roles of host and guest, to present a 'bowl of quan ho' from Diem village.|||One can say that the strictness in quan ho villages was created by the strict regulations that have been in place for a long time, and they have their reasons. Visiting Diem village, you can explore the Temple of the King and Queen, the ancestors of the quan ho village, which was originally built a long time ago but has undergone many restorations. The oldest architectural and sculptural mark that remains is a pair of stone "sau" on the body with clusters of cloud and spear leaves in the artistic style of the Le Trung Hung period. The later architecture belongs to the Nguyen dynasty, with the front of the Tien Te building still bearing the original Chinese characters: "Hoang trieu Khai Dinh cuu nien" (1924). By 2000, the temple was completely restored and rebuilt. The temple has a "Vuong" style architecture consisting of Tien Te, Thieu Huong, and Hau Cung, with a wooden frame decorated with carvings and ornate tile roofs.|||The King Ba Temple preserves many precious ancient artifacts, including a throne, statues, imperial edicts, horizontal boards, couplets, and other ceremonial objects.|||In the Tien Te hall, a large horizontal board hangs in the middle, beautifully decorated with lacquer and gold, featuring the four large Chinese characters 'Vương Mẫu giới phúc' (Queen Mother bestows blessings), with the inscription 'Khai Dinh Giap Tu' (1924) next to it.|||The couplets on either side of the pillars praise the merits of the Queen Ba: 'Vạn cổ cương thường Thần thị phục/Thiên thu hưởng hỏa cựu như tân' (Ten thousand generations of integrity, the gods still serve/For a thousand years, the incense fire remains as good as new).|||The rear palace is a place of solemn worship, with an altar and on it is a throne, a statue of Queen Ba and many other artifacts.|||The throne is made of wood carved with dragons, clouds, flowers and leaves, lacquered and gilded in the style of the Nguyen dynasty.|||The plaque with Chinese characters 'Đương cảnh thành hoàng quốc vương thiên tử nhữ nương Nam Hải đại vương' (The current virtuous queen of the country, the king's mother, the great queen of Nam Hai).|||The statue of Queen Ba sits serenely in the middle: sitting cross-legged, her hands resting gently on her lap, her head wearing a crown adorned with flowers; her face is beautiful and benevolent, with long ears, a neck with three folds, and a necklace; her outer robe is soft and smooth.|||On the altar are other precious ancient artifacts such as incense burners, loc binh, water vessels, lampstands, candlesticks, and a notable trio of red lacquered wooden balls placed beside the throne, which are associated with the 'cướp cầu' (stealing the ball) custom of the Queen Ba festival.|||There is also an imperial edict from the year Thieu Tri 4 (1844), conferring a title on the person being worshiped.|||The people of Viam Xa village are always proud that: "Our ancestral origin of Quan Ho/ The lyrics were born by Our Lady/ Since ancient times, young and old/ Anyone who can sing is honored." Specifically, the villagers of Viam Xa have preserved the most ancient customs about the lifestyle of Quan Ho at the Temple of Our Lady such as: Whenever there is a drought, there is a tradition of singing Quan Ho to pray for rain, and when singing, only Quan Ho groups from the village are allowed to sing and only sing traditional melodies (ancient voices). On the other hand, according to travel experiences in Bac Ninh, only Viam Xa village has preserved the oldest Quan Ho customs such as: singing Quan Ho covered head, communal house tradition, communal sleeping, making friends, making chạ… Viam Xa is a village with many generations of Lien Anh, Lien Chi, and famous folk artists who understand Quan Ho etiquette and can sing the most traditional melodies in the region. All festivals of the temple, communal house, and pagoda of the village all stand out with Quan Ho cultural activities and attract many Lien Anh and Lien Chi Quan Ho from surrounding villages to participate in the festival.

title: Dau Han Communal House
description: Dau Han Communal House lies peacefully on the banks of the Cau River, an ancient village located on the southern bank of the river, surrounded by water and lush green fields. The Cau River not only carries fertile silt to nourish the villages on both banks but also witnesses many significant historical events of the nation during the wars against foreign invaders.|||Bac Ninh is one of the cultural cradles of the Red River Delta. Therefore, it's no surprise that almost every village or commune in Bac Ninh has at least a communal house, a temple, or a village shrine. Dau Han Communal House is situated near a small road on the southern bank of the Cau River, Dau Han village, Hoa Phong commune, about 6km northeast of Bac Ninh city center. According to the village chronicle and royal decrees, this is the place of worship for Saint Tam Giang, who helped King Trieu Viet Vuong defeat the Liang invaders in the 6th century. Tam Giang comes from the title given by Vietnamese feudal dynasties to two saints: Tam Giang upper equal god. However, some people believe that 'Tam Giang' originates from the common name of three rivers: Cau, Thuong, and Duong, where there are many temples dedicated to the two saints.|||The Dau Han Communal House was built on a large scale during the Le Trung Hung period and was restored during the Nguyen dynasty, maintaining its original beauty of 'tetra linh, tetra quy' architecture, exquisite and sophisticated art.

title: Dong Ky Village Festival
description: The village festival takes place on the 4th day of the first lunar month every year. Although it's a small-scale festival, it is famous nationwide for maintaining its unique traditional characteristics. Previously, the festival lasted for weeks, but in recent years, it has mainly focused on the 4th day of the first lunar month.|||The Dong Ky Village Fireworks Procession is the most representative activity that the wealthy craft village in Bac Ninh has preserved to this day. It is a traditional ritual that many people look forward to during the three-day festival (4th, 5th, and 6th days of the first lunar month). The festival of making and burning fireworks used to be a way to commemorate and recreate the sound of the day when General Thien Cuong, who was later revered as the village's tutelary deity, ordered the army to fight against the enemy.|||The festival actually starts from the 3rd day of the first lunar month. Early on the 3rd day of the first lunar month, the ceremony of escorting General Thien Cuong to the Middle Temple is conducted with dignity.|||The Fireworks Procession is the most distinctive feature of the Dong Ky Village festival. All preparations for the procession are made early on the 4th day, but at exactly 9 am, two large fireworks are carried by young men in the village from the head of the village (Ban Khanh tiet) to the communal house, accompanied by a procession of hundreds of people, witnessed and eagerly awaited by thousands of visitors.|||The Dong Ky festival is most vibrant with the fireworks procession custom, but cultural and sports activities around the festival area are also lively. Visiting Dong Ky during the festival, one can listen to Quan ho singing on boats all day on the 4th day and in the mornings of the 5th and 6th days. This is also an opportunity for the village's Tuong theatre troupe to perform for the villagers. The Tuong performances take place right in the communal house's yard; every night, the village stage is lit up, and sometimes in the afternoon, the sound of Tuong drums echoes, urging people to come and watch. Notably, both Quan ho and classical Tuong performances are performed by the villagers themselves. The traditional wrestling tournament attracts dozens of wrestlers from 7 provinces to compete; and various sports like badminton, volleyball, Chinese chess, and cockfighting… demonstrate the healthy cultural aspects of the Dong Ky village festival.

title: Kinh Duong Vuong Tomb
description: There is an ancient relic site including a temple and the Kinh Duong Vuong Tomb, who was revered as the water ancestor of Vietnam, started the era of Hung Kings, and made Vietnam's history glorious, located in Phuc Than hamlet, Than Thuy village, Xich Quy land (now Alu village, Dai Dong Thanh commune, Thuan Thanh district, Bac Ninh province) which is still little known to many people.|||The temple and tomb of Thuy To are simple and humble, located on a plot of land near the riverbank outside the dike, about 500m from the Duong River. The ancient tomb, shaded by large trees, creates a serene and majestic landscape. During the French colonial period, the tomb was severely damaged. It wasn't until 1971 that the people of A Lu village were able to plan and restore it to be spacious, cool, and still bearing the distinctive mark of ancient architecture.|||The tomb is entirely made of green stone, with a simple architecture in the style of an eight-roofed, eight-sloped pyramidal structure. The tomb's foundation is elevated, surrounded by a protective wall.|||The front of the tomb faces the Duong River, with stone steps leading down to the water's edge. There are four tall, green stone gate pillars with a pair of stone dragons curled up, their heads raised high.|||On either side of the gate, there are lantern posts decorated with reliefs of ancient Vietnamese people hunting, gathering, and farming, similar to the scenes often seen on ancient bronze drums.|||Who is Kinh Duong Vuong?|||The temple of Kinh Duong Vuong is located inside the dike. In the front altar, there are two large boards: 'Nam bang Thuy To' (The Ancestor of Southern Vietnam) and 'Than Tien Thien tu' (the son of God, Fairy and Heaven). The back altar has 3 altars. The middle one is for Kinh Duong Vuong with the board: 'Nam bang Thuy To' (The Ancestor of Southern Vietnam). The right altar is for Lac Long Quan with the board: 'Hai khoat son truong' (Wide sea, long mountain); The left altar is for Au Co with the board: 'Bach Viet To' (The ancestor of Bach Viet) and some Han Chinese horizontal scrolls and couplets.|||The book Dai Nam nhat thong chi records that in 1840 during the reign of King Minh Mệnh, the tomb was restored. Kinh Duong Vuong originated from the North. Emperor Minh is the great grandson of King Than Nong, who traveled to the South, married Vu Tien, and had a son with extraordinary intelligence and strength, named Loc Tuc. He was crowned king of the South, ruling the country from around 2879 BC…|||Elders in A Lu village, where for generations families have maintained the incense and tombs of Kinh Duong Vuong's ancestors, share that locals have preserved dozens of royal decrees from various dynasties. These documents confirm that this site is a royal tomb where annual ceremonies are conducted according to national holiday rituals, with officials from the royal court presiding over the ceremonies.|||The village's chronicles also record that Loc Tuc was an exceptionally intelligent and virtuous man. After being crowned king of the southern region by his father, Loc Tuc established the Dâu tribe, built his capital at Lien Lau (Luy Lau, now in Thuan Thanh district, Bac Ninh province), named his kingdom Viet Thuong, and styled himself Kinh Duong Vuong. He took Long Nu, the daughter of Dong Dinh Quan, as his queen, and they had Sùng Lãm as their child.|||In 2789 BCE, the country was renamed Xich Quy, then lost. Sung Lam succeeded his father, styling himself Lac Long Quan. Lac Long Quan married Au Co and had 100 sons, the eldest of whom inherited the throne and was called Hung Vuong, or strong king.|||Growing up, King Hung Vuong saw that Luu Lau land was open, with high ground to attack from, but no retreat if defeated. He then moved to Nghia Linh (Phong Chau, Phu Tho), which had a good defensive position. He built the capital there and changed the country's name to Van Lang, dividing it into 15 regions. The region near his hometown was called Vu Ninh and he ruled for 18 generations…|||King Kinh Duong Vuong passed away on the 18th of January (year unknown) at Phuc Khang, Vu Ninh province (now Alu village, Dai Dong Thanh commune, Thuan Thanh district, Bac Ninh province).|||Every year on the 18th of January (lunar calendar), the people of Alu village hold a festival to commemorate King Kinh Duong Vuong, who founded the Vietnamese nation and to show gratitude to their ancestors, the royal forefathers of the Hung Kings, demonstrating the traditional Vietnamese values of filial piety and respect for their heritage.|||In 2013, Bac Ninh province planned to preserve, restore and promote the value of the national historical and cultural relic complex of the Tomb and Temple of Kinh Duong Vuong, along with supporting services to develop cultural and spiritual tourism, enhancing the festival's reputation, fitting the role and historical position of the worshiped person here: Kinh Duong Vuong - the national founder, the ancestor of the Vietnamese people.

title: Dai Bai Bronze Casting Village
description: The ancient Dai Bai bronze casting village, also known as Van Lang or Bui village, is located in Gia Binh district, Bac Ninh province. Dai Bai village is about 37km from Hanoi's city center. Visiting Dai Bai village, you'll have the opportunity to buy creative bronze products: from worship, decoration, and feng shui to high-end bronze pictures, and statues.|||The village originated from bronze casting, and the ancestor of the craft taught villagers how to cast simple items like basins, pots, and pans. In the 11th century, Nguyen Cong Truyen, revered as 'Tien tien su', contributed to developing the craft and creating new designs.|||Thanks to his efforts, Dai Bai village improved production, creating new products like bronze statues, incense burners, vases, pictures, and couplets.|||Nowadays, besides traditional bronze crafting, Dai Bai village applies modern techniques like engraving, molding, polishing, and coloring. This allows the village to produce diverse, detailed, and high-quality products.|||The products from Dai Bai village have a good price, high durability, and artistic value, as they are crafted entirely by hand using traditional techniques.|||With the goal of preserving and promoting the cultural identity of Dai Bai bronze, we help customers worldwide buy authentic Dai Bai bronze products with 100% quality guarantee and 10-year warranty.

title: Viêm Xá Quan Họ Village
description: Viêm Xá Village, also known as Diềm Xá, is located in Hoà Long commune, Yên Phong district, Bắc Ninh province. The village is blessed with a beautiful landscape featuring the Ngũ Huyện river and Kim Sơn mountain.|||Viêm Xá is considered the original Quan Họ village and the birthplace of the Quan Họ folk song. The village is home to a temple dedicated to the goddess, Đức Vua Bà, who is still revered by the locals. Archaeological findings include precious artifacts such as intricately carved stone tools and jewelry.|||The village is home to the Đền Cùng complex, which includes a temple and Tiên Giếng well, located at the foot of Kim Sơn mountain. The village also features the Đình Làng Viêm Xá, a communal house with an inscription that reads: "Thần linh dựng lên làng Diềm, trải qua các thời đại đều phong tặng ngang trời đất". The village has a serene lake, which is used for boat racing and Quan Họ singing during festivals.|||The Đền Vua Bà, located a few hundred meters from the communal house, is a simple yet sacred site for the locals and Quan Họ enthusiasts. The temple showcases Lê dynasty architecture and features various artifacts, including a statue of Vua Bà and ceremonial objects.|||The people of Viêm Xá take pride in their heritage as the cradle of Quan Họ. Despite the challenges, they strive to preserve their cultural legacy, and the village remains a vibrant hub for Quan Họ singing and cultural activities.

title: But Thap Pagoda Festival
description: The But Thap Pagoda Festival is a traditional festival held annually on the 23rd and 24th days of the third lunar month at But Thap Pagoda, in Thuan Thanh district, Bac Ninh province. With activities that highlight traditional cultural values, the festival contributes significantly to preserving and promoting the nation's cultural identity.|||The festival activities are organized according to traditional rituals, with a focus on both cultural heritage and modern life. The ceremony takes place within the pagoda's grounds and includes various religious activities such as: Buddha worship, incense offering, prayer ceremonies for good fortune, and ancestor worship.|||After participating in the rituals and admiring the unique architecture of the pagoda, including the stone bridge, rice mill, pen tower, and the thousand-eyed and thousand-armed Avalokiteshvara statue - a national treasure, visitors can enjoy a wide range of cultural and artistic activities such as Quan ho singing on dragon boats, chèo performances, and various art shows. There are also folk games and sports competitions like Chinese chess, card games, table tennis, and badminton. These activities attract not only locals but also visitors from neighboring provinces.|||But Thap Pagoda was recognized as a Special National Historical and Cultural Site by the Prime Minister in 2013. The pagoda was originally built during the Tran dynasty. It was rebuilt on a large scale during the 1642-1674 period under the Le dynasty with a layout of 'nội Công ngoại Quốc'. After several restorations, the current architecture of But Thap Pagoda dates back to the 17th century, featuring Tam quan, a bell tower, main hall, and other structures. The pagoda also preserves hundreds of artifacts from the 17th to the 20th centuries, including nearly 100 statues, and notably the National Treasure - the thousand-armed and thousand-eyed Buddha statue, a masterpiece of Buddhist art from the Le Trung Hung period.

title: Bac Ninh Kho Temple Festival
description: The Kho Temple is located on the slope of Kho Mountain, in Co Me village, now part of Vu Ninh ward, Bac Ninh city, Bac Ninh province. Co Me village has a cluster of ancient religious buildings, including Co Me communal house, Co Me pagoda, and Kho Temple, all recognized as national historical sites. The village communal house honors Saint Tam Giang, the pagoda worships Buddha, and the temple honors Lady Kho - legend has it that she stored grain for the Ly dynasty army on the Nhu Nguyet frontline and bravely sacrificed herself on the 10th day of the first lunar month. The villagers are grateful and have built a temple to commemorate her.|||Co Me is an ancient village where people traditionally grew rice. It is also a native Quan ho village.|||The traditional customs of Co Me village include three main events:|||- 12th day of the first lunar month: Temple festival|||- 15th day of the first lunar month: Pagoda festival|||- 10th day of the 8th lunar month: Communal house festival.|||The pagoda festival is the largest village event with rituals such as setting up a ceremonial pole at the pagoda, making offerings to Buddha, and performing sacred plays.|||The festival activities include a sacred tree climbing, tug-of-war, but most notably, the Quan ho singing program welcoming Quan ho friends from Huu Chap village and organizing singing competitions at the 'house Chua' that lasts until late at night.|||The communal house festival takes place in the 8th lunar month, with the tradition of fetching water from the Cau River to the communal house to worship saints throughout the year. The participants are young men and women selected by the village to carry palanquins with ceremonial water to the riverbank. Four young people (2 men, 2 women) then carry the palanquin to a boat, row to the middle of the Cau River, fill water into the palanquin, and return to the communal house in a grand procession.|||The Kho Temple festival, also known as the Co Me Temple festival, takes place on the 12th day of the first lunar month. On this day, Co Me villagers offer food and incense to Lady Kho and the altars in the temple area. They also prepare for the Pagoda festival - the largest festival of the village on the 15th day of the first lunar month.|||Since the Kho Temple was recognized as a national historical and cultural site, the temple festival has become a major event in Co Me village and Bac Ninh province. The Pagoda and Communal house festivals are maintained according to tradition, but the whole village focuses on serving pilgrims at the temple. People offer incense and pray to Lady Kho almost all year round.|||Every year, during the early spring days, thousands of pilgrims come to the Kho Temple, with tens of thousands of visitors on some days. Coming to the temple festival and praying to Lady Kho, everyone wishes for her blessings for a peaceful life, prosperous business, and a rich and thriving future. With that faith, many benevolent people have contributed to the restoration and embellishment of the temple, making it increasingly solemn and beautiful.|||During the Kho Temple festival, especially on the 14th day of the first lunar month (a common tradition of both Co Me communal house and pagoda), visitors not only pray to Lady Kho for a prosperous business but also participate in typical cultural events of Bac Ninh province, such as Lim festival, O festival, Hoa Dinh festival, Hữu Chấp village tug-of-war, and spring Quan ho singing contest organized by the province.

title: Dua Ba Temple Festival
description: The annual festival at Dua Ba Temple, the ancestral temple of Quan ho, is held by Diem village (also known as Viem Xa village, Hoa Long commune, Bac Ninh city) on the 6th day of the first lunar month.|||The Vua Ba Temple Festival is the largest and most important festival of Viem Xa village (Hoa Long - Yen Phong). It is also the only Quan ho festival in the Quan ho region, as it is the ancestral Quan ho festival. All activities in the festival are directly related to Quan ho. From early morning, the female Quan ho singers adorn themselves in traditional attire, wearing quạ hats, their faces radiant, and shyly hiding behind their conical hats, dressed in vibrant áo tứ thân. The male singers, wearing khăn xếp hats and áo the shirts, sing Quan ho melodies to welcome guests from afar.||||||The King and Queen Festival takes place on the 6th and 7th days of the second lunar month. According to legend, on the 6th day, the Queen Mother descended to Viem Trang hamlet (now Viem Xa village). She was a princess, daughter of King Hung Vuong. As she approached marriageable age, many suitors came to ask for her hand. Her father organized a tournament to choose a son-in-law. However, she did not agree to marry the winner and asked her father to let her travel around the country.|||As she and her ladies-in-waiting left the capital, a heavy storm with strong winds swept them up, and then dropped them down in Viem Trang hamlet.|||At that time, Viêm Trang was a wild and overgrown land, full of shrubs and reeds. She led the effort to clear the land, establish fields and villages, and arrange for people to get married. She also taught the locals how to work the land, grow mulberries, raise silkworms, and make sugarcane honey. She composed songs and taught young men and women how to sing them.|||After her passing, the villagers built a temple to honor her as Đức Vương Mẫu, the Queen Mother, the ancestor of Quan họ, and the guardian deity of the village.|||The main festival day is on the 6th, but from the evening of the 5th, the villagers organize a ceremony to open the temple gates and offer incense, praying for rain to wash the temple. The people of Viam Xa village believe this rain-praying ceremony is very effective. Indeed, on the night of the 5th and morning of the 6th, it rarely fails to rain. The next morning, when the procession of Queen Ba starts, the sky usually clears up.|||The ceremony to worship the gods on the 6th day of the first lunar month always includes singing Quan ho, praising the merits of the Female King, and praying for favorable weather for a bountiful harvest. The singing at the festival of the Female King only uses La rang tone (the village of Viem Xa calls it A rang tone). Later, the villagers also staged and performed the legend of the Female King outdoors, not inside the temple. The performance includes solo and humorous verses with content about male and female romantic interactions.||||||The Hoi Diem festival begins with the ceremony of opening the gate of the Vua Ba temple (the mother of quan ho folk songs). Following the tradition, the villagers organize to take water from the Ngoc well in the temple to hold a water procession around the village, through the communal house, Cung temple and then back to Vua Ba temple. Along the procession, locals and tourists alike can immerse themselves in the distinctive atmosphere of quan ho.|||Besides the communal pond, where people gather at the Den Cung or head into the village, the gentle and smooth melodies of ancient Quan ho songs echo from every small alleyway. Every year, Diem village hosts four festivals in January, February, March, and August, and notably, all of them feature Quan ho performances following traditional customs. The village has preserved this traditional practice, maintaining existing relationships and exchanges while expanding interactions with Quan ho groups from neighboring villages, making the festivals vibrant and engaging.|||Quan ho can be considered a "magnet" that attracts visitors to Hoi Diem Festival. Singing Quan ho is an activity that takes place throughout the festival. It's no surprise that Hoi Diem Festival, although it's just a village festival, becomes a cultural rendezvous for thousands of visitors.

title: Bac Ninh Cathedral
description: Construction started in 1889, completed in 1982, and restored in 1990. The Holy See granted a permanent indulgence for pilgrims to receive a plenary indulgence.|||Construction started in 1889, completed in 1982, and restored in 1990. The Holy See granted a permanent indulgence for pilgrims to receive a plenary indulgence. Located in: Bac Ninh Town, Bac Ninh Province. The Bac Ninh Diocese and cathedral are located in Ninh Xa Ward, Bac Ninh City.|||The Bac Ninh Diocese (Latin: Dioecesis Bacninhensis) is a Roman Catholic diocese in Vietnam. The Diocese of Bac Ninh was established on May 29, 1883. The diocese covers 5 provinces: Bac Ninh, Bac Giang, Bac Kan, Thai Nguyen, Vinh Phuc; 3 districts of Hanoi City and some communes and districts of Lang Son, Tuyen Quang, Ha Giang, Phu Tho, Hung Yen, Hai Duong.|||The population in the lowland and midland areas mainly live by farming. The highland areas, apart from farming, also have additional income from forestry products.|||Some major rivers flowing through the diocese are: Duong River, Red River, Thai Binh River, Lo River, Gam River, Ca River, Day River, Cau River, Cong River, Ca Lo River, Thuong River, Luc Nam River.|||Ethnic groups In the diocese, the highland areas have some ethnic minorities such as San Diu, Hmong, Dao, Meo, Cao Lan, Hoa, Tay, and Nung.

title: Bac Ninh Ancient Citadel
description: Bac Ninh Ancient Citadel, a typical military architectural work of Bac Ninh province, was built in 1805 during the reign of King Gia Long of the Nguyen dynasty, on the territory of Do Xa village, Vo Giang district (now in Ninh Xa ward), Hoa Dinh village, Tien Du district (now in Vo Cuong ward) and Yen Xa village, Yen Phong district (now in Ve An ward), all of which are now part of Bac Ninh city.|||This is the first ancient citadel in Vietnam built according to a hexagonal design and one of the four most beautiful citadels in the North region at that time. The citadel covers an area of 545,000 m2, with a 9-foot high wall made of earth and stone, later replaced with stone and brick, surrounded by a deep moat. The citadel has four gates, each with a bridge crossing the moat, and inside the citadel are arranged various sections including the Office of the Town Governor, the Watchtower, the Gunpowder Depot, and the Communal House.|||According to historical records, during the Nguyen dynasty, Bac Ninh Ancient Citadel was the center of the administrative machinery of the two provinces of Bac Ninh and Thai Nguyen. During the French colonial period, recognizing the importance of this citadel, on May 16, 1925, the Governor-General of Indochina signed a decision to rank the Bac Ninh citadel as a typical architectural and artistic work. In August 1945, after the Japanese occupation, the people of Bac Ninh surrounded the Japanese army in the citadel, conducted a revolution to seize power, and forced the Japanese to return the citadel.|||In the history of Vietnam's struggle, Bac Ninh Ancient Citadel was a particularly important military position, located in the northern defense line, protecting the Capital, and blocking invading armies at the gate of Thang Long Citadel. It was also a political and military center, and the seat of the Kinh Bac province (now Bac Ninh province).|||Bac Ninh Ancient Citadel is also a place that marks events associated with the development of the province and the revolutionary movement of Bac Ninh province led by our Party.|||In 1980, the Bac Ninh Ancient Citadel was ranked as a historical and architectural monument by the Ha Bac Provincial People's Committee and handed over to the Bac Ninh Town People's Committee (now Bac Ninh City) for management. In 2005, the Bac Ninh City People's Council passed Resolution No. 23/NQ-HDND on the preservation and promotion of the historical value of the Bac Ninh ancient citadel.|||However, up to now, the citadel has not been restored or renovated; especially the human impact has caused the monument to deteriorate seriously. The remaining vestiges of the Bac Ninh Ancient Citadel are three gates, a part of the wall and a deep moat, two cannons, and notably the front gate with a watchtower and a nearly 20-meter high flagpole.|||These values and the current state of the Bac Ninh ancient citadel in particular and other cultural heritage in general pose an urgent requirement to build a conservation plan and promote cultural values, and mobilize resources to implement the strategic goal of making Bac Ninh a centrally-affiliated city. Preserving and restoring the Bac Ninh ancient citadel is a practical act that contributes to rapid and sustainable socio-economic development, making Bac Ninh a civilized and modern city, and striving for sustainable development...

title: Luy Lau Ancient Citadel
description: Following the ancient river still known as the Dau River (located in Thuan Thanh district, Bac Ninh province), visitors will arrive at Luy Lau citadel, considered the second capital of Vietnam after Co Loa, and a cultural and educational center of the country from the 2nd century.|||Along the path strewn with broken bricks, adjacent to the Dau River. The Kinh Bac countryside scene is peaceful and serene, with ducks paddling in the river, and eucalyptus trees swaying gently in the wind.|||Without knowledge of this land, few would expect such a pristine and simple place to hold significant cultural and historical value.|||Thuan Thanh is famous for its many historical sites, considered the cradle of Vietnamese Buddhism.|||Located by an ancient river, Dau Pagoda is the oldest pagoda and the birthplace of Vietnamese Buddhism.|||This is just one of the remaining historical sites within the ancient citadel of Luu Lau - the second oldest urban center of Vietnam from the 2nd century AD.|||According to the book Dai Viet Su Ky Toan Thu: "Sy Nhiep was a Chinese, during the turmoil was appointed by the Han King to be the Tai Thu of Giao Chi. Because of his contributions to Han studies in our country, he was revered by the Confucian scholars, called Sy Vuong, then the old records recorded a separate chapter, called Sy Nhiep chapter".|||Luy Lau was the center, or possibly the capital, of the country for 40 years (185 - 225). Sy Nhiep established the first Chinese character school, propagated Buddhist scriptures at Luy Lau center, and was honored as Nam Giao Hoc To. He built a dense system of temples, centered around Dau Temple.|||Thanh Luong Citadel is located in Thanh Khuong commune, Thuan Thanh district today. Through multiple archaeological excavations, scientists have discovered many valuable artifacts and made the following assessment: Previously, we considered Luy Lau as the capital of the Northern feudal regime, but in fact, it was also an ancient urban center with diverse activities of the Vietnamese people.|||Not only today, the value of the ancient citadel of Luy Lau has been recognized, but previously, the Complete Historical Records of Dai Viet also highly appreciated the role of the builder of Luy Lau citadel: "The historian Ngo Sy Lien evaluated: "Our country got its scholarship, and cultural practices are a civilized nation starting from the Sỹ Vương, that merit not only at the time but also can be passed down forever…" . With great historical value, the government has early studied and recognized Luy Lau citadel as a national historical relic since 1964.|||Although Luy Lau Citadel dates back to the 2nd century AD, it has endured many ups and downs, as well as natural and human-induced destruction, yet it still retains many ancient vestiges.|||Mr. Nguyen Duy Nhat, Director of Bac Ninh Province Relics Management Board, said that Luu Lau Citadel currently retains half of the old citadel with an area of 132,258m2 in the southwest. The eastern part has become residential land of Lung Khe village. Inside the citadel are Phi Tuong and Binh pagodas. The pagodas worship the statue of Sy Nhiep from the Le Nguyen dynasty.|||The earthen wall is about 1-2m high and 1.5m wide. Within the citadel are temples, tombs, pagodas, and Tu Tran (4 raised mounds). Notably, the ancient relic dating back to the 2nd century is the stone bridge leading to the temple of Sy Nhiep.|||Through several excavations, archaeologists have discovered many precious artifacts buried under the cultivation soil, including ceramics, Han dynasty tiles and bricks, hundreds of ancient bronze melting furnaces, early brick foundations and remains of an ancient structure that had caught fire. In 2006, the provincial Department of Culture and Information developed a plan to restore and preserve the site, with a specific conservation plan to be implemented by 2011.|||Today, the ancient river is gradually narrowing down due to people's daily activities. The city walls are constantly at risk of being encroached and destroyed by humans. Luy Lau Citadel needs to be invested in and restored soon to preserve the remaining historical value over time, so that future generations can understand a period of the country's turbulent history.

title: Van Mieu Bac Ninh
description: Van Mieu Bac Ninh was built during the Le dynasty, a period when Confucianism had a significant impact on the country's politics. It is one of the few provincial Van Mieu temples in Vietnam.|||According to the book Dai Nam Nhat Thong Chi compiled by the National History Office of the Nguyen dynasty and the stele "Trung tu Bac Ninh bi dinh ky" erected in 1912, the temple was restored in 1802 and rebuilt in 1844.|||However, over time, especially during the French colonial period, the temple fell into disrepair due to neglect by the Nguyen dynasty.|||In the year Quy Ty, during the fifth year of Thanh Thai's reign (1893), Do Trong Vy, the Director of Education in Bac Ninh province, from Dai Mao village, Thuan Thanh district, mobilized scholars, mandarins, and local people to contribute money to move Van Mieu to Phuc Son mountain (now in Zone 10, Dai Phuc ward, Bac Ninh city). This location was chosen because, according to ancient feng shui beliefs, Phuc Son mountain, rising in a vast and fertile plain, has good fortune; building Van Mieu here is beneficial for education and facilitates the annual worship of the province.|||Before 1945, Van Mieu Bac Ninh was managed by the Council of Administration, headed by the Governor of Bac Ninh, who took care of worship and rituals.|||Every year, the organization of rituals at Van Mieu during the 'spring and autumn seasons' was scheduled for the 1st day of the 2nd and 8th lunar months.|||This was a very important event in the province and was therefore meticulously prepared.|||The participants in the rituals included provincial officials and local authorities.|||On the eve of the main ceremony, Van Mieu was cleaned and decorated with flags and ceremonial objects.|||The offerings, prepared by the Council of Administration, included: buffalo, goat, pig, fruits, glutinous rice, and wine...|||On the main festival day, the Governor of the province, dressed in formal attire, leads the procession, followed by provincial and district officials, and guards. Inside Van Mieu Temple, scholars and notables sit in order, surrounded by majestic ceremonial parasols and ritual implements. The ritual ceremony lasts for a long time, with strict adherence to each movement and procedure of the incense-offering ceremony. After the provincial chief completes the opening ceremony, officials from districts, village heads, and scholars take turns performing the ritual, highlighting the tradition of respecting teachers and valuing education among the people of Bac Ninh - Kinh Bac.|||Today, the Van Mieu Bac Ninh complex covers over 10,000m2 with various architectural works including: The Tam quan gate is built with two floors of roof, impressive and majestic. The center of the temple is the Tien te hall with 5 rooms and 2 wings connected to the Hau duong by a covered walkway, forming a 'Cong' shape. The entire wooden building is made of lim wood, carved with cloud and leaf patterns, and four-ling and four-valuable themes in the artistic style of the Le - Nguyen dynasty. The Hau duong is a sacred place of worship with an altar for Confucius, Four associates, and sages.|||In addition to the main structures, Van Mieu also features Tả vu, Hữu vu, and a stele house, forming a complete architectural complex in harmony with the surrounding landscape. Van Mieu Bac Ninh preserves a system of stone steles, notably the screen stele 'Bac Ninh province restores Van Mieu stele' and 12 'Kim bang luu phuong' steles.|||The stele 'Bac Ninh province renovated Van Mieu stele inscription' located in front of the Tien Te courtyard, with an area of nearly 10m2, is the largest stele in Bac Ninh province that has been preserved to this day. The stele was erected by Nguyen Dinh Quy, the governor of Bac Ninh, in 1928. It is designed in the style of a columnar screen with intricate carvings of letters and patterns on both sides, featuring harmonious and delicate dragon and cloud motifs, as well as the four precious things on the top and edges of the stele.|||The content of the stele informs us about the restoration and renovation of Van Mieu and the contributions of individuals and localities to the restoration and construction. On either side of the stele house, 12 'Kim Bang luu phuong' steles (Eternal Fame inscribed on Golden Slips) were erected in 1889, recording the full names, hometowns, examination years, and positions of 677 scholars from the Kinh Bac region, from the first examination in 1075 to the 1919 examination.|||These artifacts hold special value in terms of science, history, and art, significantly contributing to research on Van Mieu and the traditional scholarly heritage of our homeland and country.|||Over the years, Bac Ninh province has paid great attention to the Van Mieu relic by investing capital, restoring architectural works, supplementing artifacts and worship objects, and upgrading infrastructure and landscape. The site has become increasingly more splendid. On the occasion of the Thuong Nguyen Tet (full moon of the first lunar month) every year, Bac Ninh province organizes a solemn incense-offering ceremony at Van Mieu, attended by provincial leaders and representatives of departments and branches.|||Today, Van Mieu Bac Ninh is a regular destination for many visitors and scientists who come to explore and research. Many books and articles have been published in specialized journals, helping to spread the image and value of this historical site to people across the country.|||At Van Mieu Bac Ninh, numerous organizations, individuals, families, and schools frequently visit to offer incense, confer awards for academic achievements, encourage learning, and commemorate the great scholars of old. This aims to educate and promote the tradition of love for learning and intellectual pursuits to the younger generation in Bac Ninh - Kinh Bac homeland.

title: Dong Ho Village Painting Festival
description: Visiting temples and enjoying spring festivities is a traditional beauty of our nation. As Tet arrives and spring unfolds, trees and flowers seem to burst with vibrant life, marking the season of leisure and enjoyment. Traveling to Bac Ninh, in the Kinh Bac region, where traditional values are preserved, one can find ancient temples and unique festivals.|||While the Lim Festival is famous for its young couples in traditional attire, with turbans, long dresses, conical hats, and delicate silk scarves singing sweet and charming songs.|||The Dong Ho village festival, on the other hand, attracts many tourists with its folk paintings.|||Mentioning Dong Ho village, Song Ho commune, Thuan Thanh district, Bac Ninh province, people immediately recall the traditional folk painting craft of the village. Dong Ho village is located right on the banks of the Duong river, once only separated from the river by a dike, as expressed in the saying 'Having a river for a refreshing bath and a profession of making paintings'. Nowadays, due to the accretion of the river, the distance from the dike to the water's edge is quite far. The Dong Ho village festival has also been held for a very long time, organized annually. Similar to other villages, the Dong Ho village festival involves worshiping and commemorating the village's tutelary deity. Additionally, the festival resembles the ancestor's death anniversary of the painting craft in the village. At the festival, artisans have the opportunity to exchange and discuss the craft of making paintings.|||The craft of painting is closely associated with the communal house, a ancient communal house where villagers worship their tutelary deity. Notably, this communal house, while still serving as a common shelter for the community, has become unique due to its close connection with the painting craft. Therefore, it is often referred to as the 'Painting Communal House'. It was built by Dong Ho folk artists approximately three hundred years ago.|||The communal house, located on the west side of Dong Ho village, faces north. Initially, it had 7 bái đường sections and 2 hậu cung sections, with two rows of thảo xá on either side (5 sections each). The communal house was destroyed by the French in 1950. Today, it only has 5 bái đường sections and 2 hậu cung sections. The architecture follows the 'Đinh' style.|||The temple gate, built in the 'Tam Mon' style, features three arched entrances with curved roofs. Adjacent to the gate is a semicircular well, surrounded by brick walls and a raised edge with steps for easy access.|||The philosophy of yin-yang symmetry and harmony, as well as the charming scenery of Dong Ho village, is likely embodied in the incorporation of the semicircular well into the overall design of the village temple.|||The communal house still preserves many precious artifacts such as: Worship items, Incense altars, Large signboards, horizontal lacquered boards, A set of eight precious items with lacquered and gilded decorations... On the communal house yard are two stone steles, the inscriptions on which commemorate the village's virtuous scholars and those who made significant contributions to the construction of the communal house...|||Particularly, according to travel experiences in Bac Ninh, this is also where the annual painting markets take place with diverse and colorful folk products that are not only attractive but also unique. Visitors here buy their favorite paintings as souvenirs.|||The village festival is usually held over three days: the 14th, 15th and 16th of the third lunar month. At the communal house yard, women wearing ao dai perform a ritual of the festival.|||Stepping inside, some tourists are impressed by the oversized paper offerings, including a horse and a boat, which are placed in an easily observable position.|||Inside the communal house, there are many paper offerings, ranging from exquisitely crafted items like gold and silver trees to common paper offerings for worship.|||From early March, people in Dong Ho village start making gold and paper products to display at the festival. Preparing for the festival, each family is assigned to make an item. The process of making items is an opportunity for families to gather, share everyday life and work. In the past, Dong Ho village had 17 different families living and working on paintings. But today, since paintings are not sold, most families have switched to making paper products, only a few families still keep the traditional job. During the festival, people display and sell traditional Dong Ho paintings in the communal house yard. A paper bridge is built in the communal house, symbolizing exchange and harmony. The festival also has traditional rituals such as worshiping gods, horse racing, and painting competitions, which are very joyful.||||||The village also has folk songs such as:|||Oh traveler on the main road|||Stop and gaze at the scenery, your melancholy fades away|||Buy a fresh colorful butterfly painting|||Buying chickens and pigs that lay eggs and give birth in large numbers.|||The painting contest at Dong Ho Village communal house can be said to be a unique folk cultural activity. Through the festival, it has expressed both the religious rituals and the profession of a craft village, and at the same time, it is a vivid testimony to the formation and long development of the traditional Dong Ho folk painting craft. The special value of the communal house is therefore multiplied.

title: Dinh Bang Communal House Festival
description: This is an ancient communal house built from the beginning of the 18th century, preserving many unique architectural features from the Le - Trinh era.|||It is also a place where the annual communal house festival is frequently held in the second lunar month.|||The festival takes place continuously from the morning of the 12th day of the second lunar month, with offerings including glutinous rice and boiled pork.|||On the night of the 13th, a pair of live pigs are offered to the gods. After the ceremony, the pigs are slaughtered and their meat is divided equally among the participating families.|||The festival also features a tradition called 'ket cha', where people from Cam Giang, Hai Duong, visit the communal house.|||On the communal house's pond, decorated boats carry young men and women who engage in singing and competing in a poetic exchange.|||The boat rowers and passengers sing along, creating a joyful atmosphere amidst the spring breeze and the fragrance of rice.|||The festival embodies the artistic spirit and strength of the Kinh Bac people.|||As the festival comes to a close, people look forward to the upcoming festival at Den Do in the third lunar month.

title: Dau Pagoda Festival
description: Dau Pagoda is one of the earliest Buddhist temples in Vietnam, bearing witness to the transmission of Buddhism in Vietnam originating from India. Every year on the 8th day of the 4th lunar month, which is considered the birthday of Buddha Shakyamuni, locals enthusiastically celebrate the festival.|||This is a large and renowned festival that has become a folk song:|||“No matter where you go|||When seeing Dau Pagoda's stupa, come back|||No matter what profession you have|||On the 8th day of the 4th lunar month, come to Dau festival”.|||Dau Pagoda, also known as Dien Ung, Phap Van or Co Chau, is located in Thanh Khuong, Thuan Thanh district. This is considered one of the earliest Buddhist temples in Vietnam with many ancient architectural works such as Luu Lau ancient citadel, Si Nhiep tomb, a system of temples, towers and communal houses.|||The festival is held on the 8th and 9th days of the 4th lunar month with large-scale ceremonies in three communes of Dau - Luy Lau region (Thuan Thanh), including Thanh Khuong, Tri Qua and Ha Man, with 5 large temples worshiping Phap Van, Phap Vu, Phap Loi, Phap Dien and To temple worshiping Man Nuong - mother of Tu Phap, centered around Dau Pagoda.|||This festival is considered the oldest one still existing today. Historical records show that kings often came to this festival, worshiped Buddha and prayed for blessings. The festival is organized with solemn and traditional rituals to commemorate the birth of Buddha's mother, Man Nuong.|||The main activity of the festival is the village's organization of a procession of Phap Van (Bà Dâu), Phap Vu (Bà Đậu), Phap Loi (Bà Tướng), Phap Dien (Bà Dàn) from their temples to gather at Dau Pagoda. The procession includes ceremonial horses, flags, umbrellas and palanquins. A notable activity is the reenactment of 'mẹ đuổi con' (mother chases her child). The palanquins of each deity are carried around 3 times then return to their original place. Then comes the 'cướp nước' (water snatching) ceremony. When the order is given, the palanquins of the goddesses compete to fetch water. The winning goddess brings good omen for the year.|||Besides, the villagers also organize processions of 'Phật Thạch Quang' and 'Phật Tứ Pháp' to Man Xa Pagoda (the hometown of Man Nuong to worship ancestors) and 'tuần nhiễu' (a rite to pray for peace).|||The Dau Pagoda festival is an indispensable spiritual need in the lives of people in the Dau region. It not only meets the need to find Buddha and immerse oneself in vibrant folk cultural activities but also expresses the desire to pray for good things and a favorable year.

title: Phat Tich Pagoda Festival
description: Phat Tich Pagoda, also known as Van Phuc Tu, is located in Phat Tich commune, Tien Du district, Bac Ninh province.|||Phat Tich Pagoda holds an important role in Vietnamese Buddhist history, being the site of the first Buddhist influence from India into Vietnam.|||Ancient records tell the story of an Indian monk, Khau Da La, who came in the 2nd century AD to establish a hermitage at Phat Tich mountain, using sacred chants to bring favorable weather to the Vietnamese people.|||This indicates that Phat Tich Pagoda was involved in the early encounter between Indian Buddhism and local beliefs.|||Every year on the 4th day of the Lunar New Year, people in Phat Tich hold a traditional festival to commemorate the contributions of their predecessors who built and renovated the temple. During the festive days, visitors from all over come to worship Buddha and pray for a peaceful and healthy new year, smooth work, and prosperity for their families.|||In addition, tourists can admire the scenic beauty of Kinh Bac or participate in traditional games such as wrestling, chess, swinging, and Quan Ho singing.|||Phat Tich Pagoda in Tien Du district is not only known as an ancient pagoda with rich relics and treasures, but also attracts visitors from everywhere due to its Sam Flower Festival at the beginning of spring.|||Legend has it that in the past, the Phung Tich mountain and the pagoda garden were filled with peonies. Every year, when spring arrives, the peonies bloom vibrantly. People from all over come to visit the festival, admire the flowers, and enjoy the serene atmosphere of the pagoda.|||A fairy named Giang Huong descended to earth to join the festival. However, she accidentally broke a peony branch at the pagoda gate and was stopped by a young monk.|||Thuc then offered to redeem her by giving up his own clothes. Moved by Thuc's noble act, Giang Huong expressed her admiration and invited him to 'Bong Lai' to become a couple.|||The romantic story of 'Thuc meets the fairy' has become a lasting part of the Sam Flower Festival at Phat Tich Pagoda.|||The Khanh hoa sample don ceremony at Phat Tich Pagoda aims to promote traditional cultural values in Tien Du district. Through organizing cultural and artistic activities, Quan ho singing, traditional games like Chinese chess, cock fighting, and traditional wrestling to create a vibrant atmosphere among the people. This helps to awaken the pride of local people about cultural heritage; At the same time, encourage people to promote patriotic movements, actively work and produce, achieve the socio-economic development goals in 2017. In addition, the organization of the festival contributes to creating an attractive highlight for local tourists and promotes spiritual tourism sites to attract investment sources for local socio-economic development.|||The Buddha Tich Pagoda Festival is organized with traditional rituals combined with cultural, artistic activities and folk games that are educational and suitable for local customs. The festival ensures a healthy atmosphere for visitors to come and worship.|||The Organizing Committee strictly prohibits any activities that exploit spirituality, superstitious beliefs, gambling in disguise... that affect the sacred and solemnity of the festival.|||This year, the Buddha Tich Pagoda festival takes place on the 4th and 5th days of the Lunar New Year, with the 4th being the main day of the festival. The ceremony includes incense offerings at places of worship, handled by the pagoda and the Buddhist Association. On the evening of the 5th day of Tet, a Great Compassion ceremony will be held to pray for national prosperity and peace, and for the well-being of the people and Buddhists... Along with the ceremony, the festival will feature traditional cultural and artistic activities, serving the people during their spring outing.

title: Tieu Son Pagoda
description: The pagoda, named Thien Tam Tu, commonly known as Tieu Pagoda, is located in Tuong Giang commune, Tu Son town, Bac Ninh province, 20 km north of Hanoi along National Highway 1A.|||The pagoda was built during the Ly Dynasty. It was a place for meditation and Buddhist teaching by many prominent monks during the Ly Dynasty, such as Master Van Hanh. The Dictionary of Vietnamese Cultural Relics (Hanoi, 1993) mentions that this pagoda was once the residence of Master Van Hanh and also the birthplace of King Ly Thai To. The master had raised and educated Ly Cong Uan from childhood to adulthood, who later became the king who founded the Ly Dynasty. According to historical records, in the Cam Tuyen Institute of Thien Tam Pagoda, a white and black dog gave birth to a litter with the shape of two words 'Thien Tu', which corresponded to King Ly Thai To being born in the year of the dog.|||The pagoda has been restored many times. It consists of a gate, a main hall, a house for the monk's quarters, a stele house, a Quan The Am tower, a garden of stupas, and other structures. The current gate was built in 1986; the Quan The Am tower was built in 2001 in the middle of a large pond in front of the pagoda; the house for the monk's quarters was built in 2002 and the main hall was built in 2003.|||The pagoda has a stone stele (0.68m high, 0.40m wide) with four words: 'Ly Gia Linh Thach', dated to the Canh Thinh Nguyen Nien (1793), which records the history of Ly Cong Uan.|||The Buddha hall is decorated solemnly, worshiping the Three Ages Buddha, Di Da Tam Ton...; the altars of Bodhisattva Quan The Am, the Quan The Am cave, the altar of Hộ Pháp, the altar of Ton gia Anan and the altar of Truong lao Cap Co Doc.|||On Tieu mountain, there is an 8m high statue of Master Van Hanh sitting in meditation, facing Thang Long citadel, built in 1992.|||The pagoda once kept a woodblock printing of the book 'Thienuyen tap anh', a work recording Vietnamese eminent monks with literary, historical and philosophical value.|||Notably, the pagoda still keeps a stupa and the mummified body of Master Nhu Tri, who passed away in Quy Mao (1723), a former abbot of the pagoda who printed the 'Thien Uyển tập anh'. On March 13, 2004, the mummified body was moved to Duệ Khánh pagoda, Noi Due commune (Bac Ninh), 3 km away, for a conservation project. The conservation work was completed on September 26, 2004.|||The Thap Vien Tue stele by the Truc Lam Zen sect, built in 2004 at the bảo tháp of Master Nhu Tri, shows that he might be a dharma successor of Master Chan Nguyen, abbot of Long Dong pagoda in Yen Tu following the transmission lineage:|||Minh Chan Nhu Tinh Hai|||Kim Tuong Pho Chieu Thong|||Chi Dao Thanh Chinh Qua|||Giac Ngo Chung Chan Khong.|||The pagoda has been recognized by the Ministry of Culture and Information as a national historical-cultural monument.

title: Da Quan Pagoda
description: The pagoda was built in the early 17th century, during the reign of King Can Thong (Mac Kinh Cung) to worship Da Quan Cong Mac Ngoc Lien, a renowned general who served the Mac dynasty from its beginning to its end.|||This pagoda is located in Da Quan hamlet, Hung Dao commune, Cao Bang town (previously Hoa An district), and was constructed in the early 17th century to honor Mac Ngoc Lien, a distinguished general of the Mac dynasty.|||Ancient records state that the pagoda is situated in Da Quan village, Xuan Linh commune, Thach Lam district, and is a place of incense and gratitude to the person who made meritorious contributions to the country, while also worshiping protective spirits for national prosperity and a good harvest.|||Opposite Da Quan Pagoda is Vien Minh Pagoda, which honors Pham ma Duong Tu Minh, a Ly dynasty official who brought peace to the Cao Bang border region by eliminating bandits. The pagoda has two bells, each 4.5 meters high and 8.9 meters in circumference, weighing approximately one ton. The bells feature an inscription in Chinese characters, praising the beauty of Thach Lam district in the past. This pagoda was built during the Ly dynasty, restored during the Le and Nguyen dynasties, and reconstructed in 2007.|||Every year on the 9th day of the first lunar month, the pagoda hosts the Xuan Festival, where people from all over come to pray for wealth, good fortune, and longevity, as well as to enjoy traditional music and sports performances.

title: Den De Doong
description: The temple is located in De Doong village (locally known as Giang Dong) next to the Bang River, which flows through the Hoa An depression. This depression was formed by the deep Cao Bang-Tien Yen fault. Den De Doong is the only place among the tourist attractions of Non Nuoc Cao Bang Geopark where visitors can experience life and landscapes similar to those in a Red River Delta village, in a mountainous region.|||Den De Doong was built in 1429, initially dedicated to the river and mountain gods who helped the people of Nhuong Ban commune, Thach Lam district. The temple is associated with the legend of calming the river, preventing floods from destroying crops and causing suffering to the people. Later, King Mac Kinh Cung named it Giang Dong temple. During the Le Dynasty (1427-1789), Den De Doong was renovated and additional Buddha and Mother God statues were added for worship.|||The festival at Den De Doong temple is a folk belief of the community, with the aspiration for favorable weather, abundant crops, and prosperity. It takes place on the 15th day of the first lunar month every year. On June 15, 1945, a ceremony was held here to welcome the establishment of the Cao Bang Provincial Interim People's Committee.|||Den De Doong was recognized as a provincial historical and cultural relic by decision No. 2486/QD-UBND on November 4, 2008.

title: Phuc Sen Forging Village
description: Phuc Sen Forging Village is located in Phuc Sen commune, Quang Uyen district, Cao Bang province. It is a traditional craft village with a history of over 1,000 years.|||Phuc Sen is a mountainous region with rocky terrain. Upon entering the village, you can see forges everywhere. These forges have significantly contributed to the daily lives of locals and people in nearby areas. The village produces high-quality hand tools for daily use.|||The iron and steel tools made here are created using manual forges, relying on experience and skill rather than high-frequency smelting furnaces. The blacksmiths can gauge the readiness of each product in the charcoal furnace and then quench it in a nearby water bath. This process allows the production of durable and versatile tools, such as knives, axes, and scissors, which are highly valued by locals and sold in many markets within and outside Cao Bang province.

title: Ky Sam Temple
description: Ky Sam Temple is located in Vinh Quang commune, 5km from Cao Bang city center on the Pac Bo road. The temple was built to worship the historical figure of Dai Vuong Nung Tri Cao, a Tay ethnic person, during the reign of King Ly Thai Tong (11th century).|||Nung Tri Cao was granted the title of Thai Bao by the king and tasked with defending Quang Nguyen district. After his death, the king posthumously granted him the title of Khau Sam Dai Vuong. The story of Nung Tri Cao has become a legend related to the nation-building efforts during the Ly dynasty. His merits have been remembered by later generations and a temple was built in his honor.|||The annual festival takes place on the 10th day of the first lunar month, which is a large celebration attracting people from all walks of life in the province to participate, enjoy the spring, and engage in various games such as swinging, wrestling, martial arts, ball kicking, lion dancing, dragon dancing, and unicorn dancing...

title: Kim Dong Heroic Martyrs' Relic Site
description: This is a memorial site dedicated to heroic martyr Kim Dong, who protected revolutionary cadres during the anti-French period.|||Kim Dong, whose real name was Nong Van Den, was born in 1929. On May 15, 1941, comrade Duc Thanh, a revolutionary cadre, decided to establish the National Salvation Children's Squad in Na Ma village, with Kim Dong as the team leader, along with three other members: Cao Son, Thanh Thuy, and Thuy Tien.|||In August 1942, Kim Dong had the honor of meeting Uncle Ho in Noc En cave on the mountain behind Na Ma village. Uncle Ho praised Kim Dong for being clever, quick-witted, and brave.
