He advised Kim Dong and his teammates to help protect the revolution, and to study culture and politics to contribute to building the country when Vietnam gained independence. On February 15, 1943, while on guard duty during a meeting of the Viet Minh, Kim Dong discovered the enemy approaching and quickly distracted them to protect the revolutionary cadres. He was shot and sacrificed at the age of 14.|||Kim Dong was posthumously awarded the title of heroic martyr by the Party and State in 1997. The Kim Dong relic site, located in his hometown, features his tomb and a grand monument at the foot of a large stone mountain, surrounded by a green forest that provides shade and a soothing breeze.|||The monument depicts Kim Dong wearing Nung clothing, holding a dove carrying a letter, with 14 stone steps and 14 tall, lush lat trees. This site has a large yard where young people from Cao Bang province and across the country often gather for camping, entertainment, and singing.

title: Hoang Dinh Giong Historical Site
description: The Hoang Dinh Giong historical site is located in Na Toan village. This is the birthplace and nurturing ground of comrade Hoang Dinh Giong. Comrade Giong is a Tay ethnic person, born in 1904, and one of the first communist party members of Cao Bang province. He directly trained and built the Cao Bang Party.|||In 1925-1926, comrade Giong was a typical patriotic youth of Cao Bang people. While studying at the Bach Nghe school in Hanoi, he joined the intellectual youth movement demanding the release of Phan Boi Chau. In 1926-1927, in Cao Bang, there were the Tay-suppressing associations in Hoa An and Ha Quang. Comrade Giong had patriotic activities, learned and spread Marx-Lenin ideology, bringing revolutionary light to Cao Bang ethnic people. Therefore, he was tracked and wanted by French colonizers. He found a way to Quangxi, China. In 1928, he was admitted to an organization in China and then returned to Cao Bang to propagate and establish a revolutionary base.|||Comrade Hoang Dinh Giong, a Cao Bang native, during his activities at home and abroad, including in imperial prisons, always aimed for independence. Even in his last moments, he remained strong and unyielding.

title: Ho Chi Minh Relic Site of the 1950 Border Campaign
description: The relic site was put into use on May 19, 2004, showing the high morality of "drinking water, remembering its source" to the genius leader, the beloved father of the nation.|||The site includes a memorial house designed with modern stilt house architecture, displaying images and artifacts related to Uncle Ho's activities during the campaign and a statue of Uncle Ho sitting on Baodong mountain, observing the battle.|||The statue of Uncle Ho is modeled after a photo by artist Vu Nang An, made of composite material, 2.8m high, weighing 418kg, on a reinforced concrete pedestal, the entire statue placed on a stone base with flower-lined tiles. Walking up 845 stone steps, divided into 79 steps, symbolizing 79 spring seasons of Uncle Ho, visitors reach the statue.|||Here, tourists can see the serene and optimistic posture of President Ho Chi Minh, who directly led the battle at Dong Khe fort on September 16, 1950, on the Cao Bang - Lang Son route No. 4, marking the beginning of the 1950 Border Campaign, creating a premise for the great resistance war of the nation.|||At the observation deck, Uncle Ho wrote a famous poem about the spirit and determination of the nation:|||Chống gậy lên non xem trận địa|||Vạn trùng núi đỡ vạn trùng mây|||Quân ta khí mạnh nuốt ngưu đẩu|||Thề diệt xâm lăng lũ sói cầy|||The site also features a pair of precious stone dragons (3.93m long, 1.15m high, 0.393m in diameter, nearly 9 tons) placed on a 1.20m high stone pedestal, crafted by artisans from Hoa Lu (Ninh Binh). The pair of dragons represents the strength of unity and solidarity, growing stronger, of the descendants of Rong Tien; expressing the respectful sentiment of Phu Tho people towards Uncle Ho.

title: Lồng Tồng Festival
description: The Lồng Tồng festival is the largest traditional festival of the Tay and Nung ethnic groups living in Cao Bang. Let's explore the unique and traditional features of the Lồng Tồng festival with BDATrip.|||The Long Tong festival takes place on a large field to pray to Nong Than for blessings and a bountiful harvest in the new year.|||The festival runs from the 4th to the 10th day of the first lunar month.|||It includes rituals such as incense offering and deity worship to express gratitude.|||The festival is led by the person in charge of worshiping Nong Than.|||After the opening gong, elderly men and young strong men carry Nong Than's palanquin and village gods from the communal house to the field.|||Families can also bring ceremonial offerings.|||In the 'xuong dong' ritual, strong and capable men with good moral character and their healthy buffalo are chosen to plow the first furrows, marking the beginning of a productive new season.|||After the main ceremonial part in the field, the Long Tong festival will move on to the festive part with many activities and folk games. There are various games that showcase the unique cultural characteristics of the local people, such as: toss the ball, tug of war, swinging, lion dancing, martial arts, love singing, etc.|||The toss the ball game is the most popular and fun folk game, with many participants, originating from the belief that when someone successfully tosses a five-colored ball through the red center, it will bring good luck and prosperity to the village in the new year.|||Young men and women of the Tay and Nung ethnic groups play tug-of-war, dividing into two teams to perform high-altitude love duets, expressing rituals that symbolize the desire for a good harvest, rain, and water in traditional ancient beliefs.|||This is also an opportunity for people to exchange culture and art, share experiences in economic development, and build a better life. Since ancient times, the Tong Long festival has carried unique cultural beauty, creating a spirit for the labor and production with a new belief in victory, contributing to preserving and promoting the cultural identity of the homeland and country.|||To this day, despite the improved and elevated living standards of the people, the festival still retains its traditional characteristics and continues to grow, taking place in a more vibrant and diverse way. The folk elements with ancient meanings are also preserved to introduce to tourists visiting Cao Bang. When traveling here during the festival season, visitors can admire the beautiful scenery, learn about the ethnic culture and daily life of the highland people, and experience traditional folk games that carry a distinct national identity.|||When traveling to Cao Bang, exploring famous landscapes such as Ban Gioc waterfall, Ngườm Ngao cave or Pac Bo historical site, don't forget to experience the Long Tong festival of the locals in this sacred land. Check out our attractive Cao Bang tours and contact BDATrip immediately. With professional service and dedicated staff, we will assist you in booking a car, flight tickets conveniently and at the best price, as well as support for obtaining Vietnam visa for foreign customers.

title: The Invitation to Mother Moon Festival
description: The Invitation to Mother Moon Festival, also known as the Nang Hai Festival, is a major festival of the Tay people in Phuc Hoa district, Cao Bang. It takes place from the 30th of the first lunar month to the main festival on the 22nd of the third lunar month. Although held separately in each village, visitors traveling to Ban Gioc waterfall can still immerse themselves in this unique festive atmosphere.|||With the meaning of welcoming Mother Moon to bring blessings to the village for a bountiful harvest in the new season. Therefore, every year, the villagers choose a middle-aged woman with a happy life and loved by everyone to be Mother Moon. At the same time, they select about 20 beautiful girls in the village to embody the fairies. In addition, two young and strong men are chosen to lead Mother Moon and the fairies back to heaven.|||During the ceremony, Mother Trang wears indigo clothes, with a red cloth wrapped diagonally around her head. While walking on the road, she carries a bamboo stick with a small betel nut bag, a handkerchief, and a bowl of water with a grapefruit leaf. The bowl of water and the bamboo stick symbolize purification according to the customs of the Tay ethnic people.|||The Moon Mother Festival originates from the folk beliefs of the Tay people in Cao Bang. Previously, with difficult and backward agricultural production conditions, people only knew to pray to heaven for favorable weather. Nowadays, although techniques have developed, this seasonal festival is still preserved and has become a unique cultural belief in the region.|||Before the festival, the Tay people in Cao Bang prepare meticulously to ensure a smooth celebration. They use flags placed at the four corners of the festival ground to ward off evil spirits. The offerings to the local deity and the Moon Maidens must also be carefully prepared and beautifully decorated. This shows the people's respect for the gods who bring them peace and a prosperous life.|||During the Moi Me Trang festival in the Ban Gioc Waterfall tour, you'll see wooden boats carved by local people. They symbolize the wealth offered to Me Trang and 12 bundles of flowers representing 12 nights of rituals, showing the villagers' respect.|||On the holiday, visitors on the Ban Gioc Waterfall tour from Hanoi can also watch an impressive folk dance performance on the day of the Mother Moon and Fairy farewell ceremony. The singing comes from farmers themselves, but sounds very sweet and passionate, expressing their hope for a bountiful harvest next season to host a bigger celebration. This is definitely a memorable experience during your trip.|||Besides participating in festivals and admiring the scenic beauty of the mountains and forests, visitors shouldn't forget to stop and enjoy the specialties of Cao Bang. This place is also known as the 'cradle of Northwest cuisine'. Let's review the famous dishes of this place.|||Traveling to Ban Gioc Cao Bang waterfall during the traditional Moon Mother Festival will give you a deeper understanding of Vietnam's diverse culture. Especially, you can keep for yourself beautiful memories of the Northwest mountains, the simple, honest, and hospitable people, and the land full of emotions.|||Don't forget to try the special dishes to experience the impressive cuisine of Cao Bang.

title: Thanh Minh Festival
description: Every year during the Thanh Minh season, the Nung An people in Phuc Sen commune, Quang Uyên district, and locals in the region enthusiastically participate in the Thanh Minh festival. To date, the festival has preserved its unique cultural activities that cannot be found elsewhere.|||The Thanh Minh festival is a traditional celebration of the people in Phuc Sen. Although its origins are unknown, legend has it that a young Nung couple was deeply in love but their relationship was forbidden due to old customs. In desperation, they decided to die together to be with each other forever.|||The Thanh Minh festival is an occasion to commemorate the faithful love of the young couple. It is not only a gathering for locals but also an event for those who have moved away to return to their hometown to pray for a good harvest, peaceful village, happy family, and blessings for couples.|||The festival features activities such as folk song performances; culinary exchange; agricultural tool-making competitions; and traditional games like grass-pulling, shuttlecock tossing, and tug-of-war.|||Attending the Thanh Minh festival in Phuc Sen commune, visitors can experience a unique festival atmosphere and pay respects to their ancestors. The Thanh Minh Festival has become a spiritual beauty, rich in traditional cultural identity of Cao Bang people, and is being preserved, conserved and promoted.

title: Quang Uyen Fireworks Festival
description: The Quang Uyen Fireworks Festival is a unique traditional festival with a fireworks display at the beginning of spring between communes in Quang Uyen town, Cao Bang. The festival aims to pray for a lucky new year with prosperity and wealth. Every year on the 2nd day of the 2nd lunar month, locals and tourists eagerly come to Quang Uyen to join the festival.|||The Quang Uyên Fireworks Festival is the biggest festival of the year for the people of Quang Uyên district, associated with historical and spiritual elements of the Bach Linh Temple. The temple was built during the Ly Dynasty at the foot of Coc Bo mountain and was completely rebuilt during the Nguyen Dynasty according to Nguyen architectural style. The temple has a three gate entrance, a front yard, a main hall, a back hall, a back sanctum, horizontal boards, and couplets. The gate is engraved with the three words 'Bach Linh Mieu' and features a curved dragon made of crushed brick (Mạc era brick), a carved dragon holding a pearl, and a phoenix and dragon gathering.|||The most impressive part of the ceremony is the 'khai quan' ritual, where the dragon's eyes are opened. The dragon is 'awakened' from a water source, known locally as Bo Coc Chu, under an ancient tree. The ceremony is led by a respected elderly figure, accompanied by a dragon team of 15 people, including 3 drummers, 1 person carrying a ball, and 11 dragon dancers. At the water source, the dragon lies still, its eyes covered with paper. The leader lights incense, prays to heaven and earth, and asks for blessings for the local people, including good weather, a bountiful harvest, and a happy life. After the prayer, the leader cuts the throat of a rooster, uses its blood to open the dragon's eyes, and removes the paper covering. The dragon 'awakens' with three drumbeats, starts to move, and eventually rises. It circles the water source three times before entering the Bach Linh temple, where offerings have been prepared and incense is lit. The dragon bows three times, walks around the temple, and then exits.|||The offerings to be made include 2 roasted pigs, 1 tray of glutinous rice, 1 tray of red-dyed eggs, and 1 tray of fruits. The ceremony takes place solemnly with 4 processions of palanquins, each with 4 bearers dressed in ceremonial attire. The first palanquin carries a portrait of Ho Chi Minh, the second carries the gods, the third carries fireworks, and the last carries a roasted pig, which is the prize for the winning team in the game of seizing the firecracker. Following the procession of palanquins is the dragon procession. After performing the incense-lighting ritual at the temple, the dragon procession departs to Nung Tri Cao Temple, Tran Hung Dao Temple, then goes through the streets to each house. Wherever the dragon goes, it is warmly and respectfully welcomed by the people.|||The festival's entertainment part is lively with many traditional games and performances, such as dragon dances, lion dances, swinging on swings, singing, and competing for the decorated cannon. The most notable game of the festival is the competition to grab the decorated cannon head, which is made from an iron hoop with colorful streamers. The cannon head is placed on a high platform, and after the cannon is fired, the teams compete to catch the head. The team that successfully brings the cannon head to the Organizing Committee wins. Recently, due to the ban on fireworks, the Organizing Committee has modified the game by throwing the iron hoop from the high platform for the teams to compete and catch. According to local people's beliefs, whoever catches the lucky cannon head will have a year filled with good luck, prosperity, and bring great honor to their commune. The winning commune will receive a roasted pig on a litter during the procession of the gods, and the litter will be left for that commune to worship and pray for luck throughout the year until the next festival.|||Over time, the Quang Uyen fireworks festival has existed in the consciousness of many generations of Quang Uyen people and has become a spiritual beauty that cannot be missed each spring.

title: Den Vua Le
description: The Le King Temple is 11km from Cao Bang city center.|||It worships King Le Thai To (Le Loi Cao Hoang De).|||The King Le Temple is located on Long hill (or Dragon hill), a high mound in the north of Na Lu citadel. The citadel has four mounds corresponding to four names: Long, Ly, Quy, and Phuong. According to legend and historical records, the King Le Temple was originally a palace within Na Lu citadel. The citadel was built by Cao Bien. In the 11th century, Nung Ton Phuc (father of Nung Tri Cao), the leader of Quang Nguyen province, continued to build it. During Ly Thai Tong's reign, in the 6th year of the Thong Thuy era, which was 1039, Nung Ton Phuc proclaimed himself the Chiêu Thánh Hoàng đế, and renamed Quang Nguyen province as Truong Sinh country; then he built the citadel and palace in Na Lu.|||In March 1039, Nung Ton Phuc was defeated by the Ly dynasty.|||In 1414, the Ming army occupied our country and stationed troops in Cao Bang, imposing heavy taxes and oppression on the local people. The life of the people was extremely hard. In response, Be Khac Thieu, a wealthy leader in Cao Bang, rallied an army to rebel and allied with Nong Dac Thai to fight against the enemy, achieving victory after a fierce battle in Na Khuoi in September 1426. Be Khac Thieu proclaimed himself Be Dai Vuong and appointed Nong Dac Thai as Nong Nguyen Soai. They were based in Na Luu and repaired and rebuilt the palace in 1430.|||In 1592, the Mac dynasty fled to Cao Bang, and Mac Kinh Cung took over Na Lu citadel to establish a palace. After three generations living in Cao Bang, Mac Kinh Vu was defeated by the Le - Trinh army. The Mac dynasty then abandoned the palace and Na Lu citadel, fleeing to China.|||In the third year of Chinh Hoa, during the reign of King Le Hy Tong, which is 1682, Cao Bang's governor, Le Van Hai, petitioned King Le to repair the old Na Lu citadel into a temple dedicated to King Le Thai To (the current Den Vua Le); the royal robe and sword are then worshiped at the throne.|||Before the August Revolution and during the resistance wars against France and America, the King Le Temple was a historical site closely associated with the activities of the Party during the period of national democratic revolution. In 1936, comrade Hoang Dinh Giong stood up to establish the "Youth Anti-Imperialist Group".|||The architecture of King Le's temple|||The temple is built in a three-compartment layout with 7 rooms, walls made of rammed earth bricks, tiled roof, and wooden pillars and beams. A 600m-long wall surrounds the temple, with two spacious yards covering about 1,000m2 in front of it.|||The temple is where local festivals are held and cultural activities take place.|||The King Le Temple Festival takes place on the 6th day of the first lunar month every year.|||The festival includes a ceremonial part held early in the morning with the participation of a large crowd of locals, and various cultural and artistic activities, traditional games such as Chinese chess, human chess, stick pushing, tug of war… that attract many people to participate.|||The King Le Temple is a historical site that holds educational value in the traditional struggle against invaders of our people. It is also a cultural heritage with architectural and artistic value of the nation.|||This place affirms the value of cultural quintessence, pride in the traditional revolutionary struggle history of our nation in general and Cao Bang province in particular.|||On April 20, 1995, the King Le Temple was ranked as a National Historical and Cultural Monument by the State.

title: Van An Pagoda
description: The pagoda consists of two tall and beautiful buildings. The gate opens towards the Gam River bank, with a Chinese inscription 'Van An Tu' at the entrance. The pagoda is relatively sturdy, with a tiled roof, and a pair of dragons on the roof. The wooden architectural elements are intricately carved with harmonious natural scenery.|||Inside the first building, the center is the altar of Princess Van An from the Le Dynasty, decorated with ceremonial parasols, canopies, and curtains. On either side are porcelain swans and a gold-plated palanquin. Behind the princess's altar is the Jade Emperor's altar, with the Jade Emperor statue holding a sword. On either side are Nam Tao and Bac Dau statues. On the left of the princess's altar is another altar with multiple statues arranged in rows.|||The second building is made entirely of ironwood, with a high platform and a statue of the Goddess of Mercy. Next to it are bronze statues of the Queen Mother, the Tathagata, and the Bodhisattva sitting on a lotus throne.|||Van An Pagoda is now a tourist attraction with a unique ancient architectural style.

title: Phai Khat Fortress
description: Phai Khat Fortress in Cao Bang is where the first battle of the Vietnam Propaganda and Liberation Army took place after its establishment. The fortress is located in Tam Kim commune, Nguyen Binh district, 7km from Tran Hung Dao forest.|||On December 25, 1944, at 5pm, the Vietnam Propaganda and Liberation Army and local people destroyed and captured the commander and all soldiers, seizing enemy weapons.|||The victory at Phai Khat Fortress, although small in scale, created a sense of certain victory for the liberation fighters and marked the growth of the armed forces, paving the way for future battles.|||Phai Khat Fortress was ranked as a national historical site on January 29, 1993, and is one of the relics in the Tran Hung Dao National Special Historical Site.

title: Phuc Tich Truc Lam Ban GioC Pagoda
description: This is the first pagoda built on the northern border of the country. The pagoda was inaugurated on December 15, 2014, and built on an area of 3 hectares, nestled in Phia Nham mountain, about 500m from Ban GioC waterfall, with a main view of the waterfall. From the pagoda, you can admire the rice fields, the white water of Ban GioC waterfall, majestic amidst mountains and clouds.|||The pagoda is designed in pure Vietnamese style with lim wood structure, traditional brick and tile materials, traditional tiled roof, and a system of Vietnamese couplets. The pagoda has all the necessary sections: Tam quan, Avalokiteshvara statue garden, Tam Bao Hall, Ancestor Hall, Mother Temple worshiping Vietnam's ancestors, Tran Temple, paradise garden, La Han statue garden, and a temple dedicated to Nung Tri Cao - a cultural icon of the 11th century in Cao Bang, a military and diplomatic genius who contributed to protecting the northern border of Vietnam. The highlight of the pagoda is the 1.5-ton bronze Great Chung Thien Bao bell tower.|||This is a spiritual and religious site for Buddhists to pray and worship, a place to find peace and serenity.

title: De Dong Temple Festival
description: On the 5th of March (or 15th of the first lunar month), many people and tourists from afar come to visit and join the festival at De Dong Temple in Hong Viet commune (Hoa An).|||De Dong Temple, also known as Giang Dong Temple, is located in De Dong village, Hong Viet commune (Hoa An). The temple was originally built to worship river spirits and stones, and later also worshiped Buddha and Mother Goddess.|||Legend has it that a poor young man used to make a living by fishing. On the anniversary of his father's death, he went fishing, hoping to catch some fish for the ceremony, but he didn't catch any. When he pulled up his net, he only found a stone shaped like two people. He prayed: 'If you are a god, please grant me a catch to celebrate my father's death.' After his prayer, he caught a full net of fish. Seeing that his prayer had been answered, he brought the stone back to Vo Ban and built a shrine to worship it. One stormy night, the shrine was destroyed, and a piece of bamboo flew to Rien Riet hill. From then on, people built a shrine there. However, the location was far from residential areas, and the narrow space couldn't meet the needs of the people's ceremonies. So, people in the region built De Dong Temple and moved the sacred stone to the temple for worship.|||In the 15th century, tribal leader Be Khac Thieu called on people to donate and build a more magnificent temple. During the Mac dynasty (1593 - 1677), the king ordered the production of bricks and tiles to build walls, palaces, temples, and De Dong Temple was also renovated.|||In 1677, after defeating the Mac dynasty, King Le renovated De Dong Temple to make it a place for Buddhist worship and to pray for national prosperity, people's safety, and good harvests.|||De Dong Temple is also where the establishment of the Cao Bang provincial temporary People's Committee was declared and welcomed (on June 15, 1945).|||With its cultural and historical values, in 2008, De Dong Temple was recognized as a provincial historical and cultural site by the provincial People's Committee.|||The De Dong Temple Festival takes place on the 15th of the first lunar month, attracting many people and tourists from everywhere to join in the festivities, pray for luck and fortune, and participate in cultural and sports activities such as Chinese chess, flying shuttlecock, football, and volleyball…

title: Ky Sam Temple Festival
description: On February 25th (the 10th day of the first lunar month), a large crowd of locals and tourists gather for the Ky Sam Temple festival in Vinh Quang commune, Cao Bang city.|||The Ky Sam Temple is located in Ban Ngan, Vinh Quang commune, about 5 km from Cao Bang city center. It honors Khau Sam Dai Vuong Nung Tri Cao (1025 - 1055), a Tay ethnic figure associated with Vietnam's resistance against the Song dynasty during the Ly dynasty (11th century). Nung Tri Cao was the son of leader Nung Ton Phuc and A Nung. He was intelligent and studied in Thang Long capital, becoming a talented strategist. He had a glorious time defeating the invading Song army and was titled Thai Bao by the king. After his death, the king posthumously titled him Khau Sam Dai Vuong and built a temple in his honor.|||The Ky Sam Temple was recognized as a national historical and cultural site in 1993. Over generations, legends about Khau Sam Dai Vuong Nung Tri Cao have become part of the spiritual life and left a deep mark on the cultural and spiritual life of ethnic people in the province.|||The Ky Sam Temple festival is one of the largest in the province, attracting many domestic and international tourists. The festival includes rituals and entertainment. The ritual part starts on the evening of the 9th day of the first lunar month with traditional ceremonies. The festival on the 10th day of the first lunar month is an opportunity for visitors to pray for luck and prosperity. At the festival, visitors can participate in folk games like Chinese chess, flying still, bamboo pole climbing, and blindfolded ball hitting.|||In recent years, the festival has included traditional Tay music performances, making of Dan Tinh (a traditional Tay instrument), calligraphy, and local products, serving tourists. To ensure a joyful and safe festival, the organizing committee assigns tasks to teams and members, coordinates with local authorities, militia, and police to ensure the event goes smoothly and maintains good customs.

title: Thang Hen Lake
description: Located about 30 km from Cao Bang city via Provincial Road 205, Thang Hen Lake in Quoc Toan (Tra Linh) commune is known as a prominent eco-tourism destination with picturesque scenery and romantic legends.|||The legend of Thang Hen Lake is an interesting discovery for tourists. According to folklore, there was a young man named Sung, who was intelligent and handsome. He passed the imperial exam and was rewarded by the king with seven days to celebrate his success with his family. On his way back home, he got married to a beautiful girl named Booc. He was so caught up in spending time with his new wife that he forgot about his return to the capital. On the seventh night, he suddenly remembered and said goodbye to his wife and parents to rush back to the capital. In the dark of night, while running through the forest, he took 36 steps before hitting his head on a mountain and dying. These 36 steps are now 36 large and small lakes with different names in Tra Linh district. It is said that where he lay down is now Thang Hen Lake.|||The Thang Hen lake complex currently has 36 natural lakes, each a few dozen or hundreds of meters apart. The lakes have separate banks, but are all connected by underground caves. These 36 natural freshwater lakes are located in a large valley on the border between Quoc Toan (Tra Linh) and Ngu Lao (Hoa An) communes. The lakes are named in the local dialect, such as Thang Vat, Na Ma, Thang Loong, Thang Hoi…, which have been used for hundreds of years. Among them, Thang Hen is the largest lake in the complex. Thang Hen lake is nearly 2,000 m long, 500 m wide, surrounded by old forests and rocky outcrops, and has a depth of up to 40 m. The name 'Thang Hen' in the local dialect means 'bee tail', as the lake's shape resembles a bee's tail when viewed from above. These natural lakes have many specialties with over 100 types of fish, including shrimp, prawns, red fin carp, catfish…|||Thang Hen has a picturesque landscape with rows of green trees stretching out on steep cliffs, reflecting on the deep blue water, winding through the valley with rocky outcrops. In the morning, from the mountain peak, you can see clouds floating by like white silk ribbons dancing in the wind.|||At the head of the lake is a wide cave called Thang Hen Cave. The cave mouth is 200m deep, 5-6m wide, and 5m high, leading straight up to the mountain top. Water flows out of the cave all year round.|||The lake has two tides rising and falling every day. Notably, around September and October, during the beginning of autumn, the lake's water level drops significantly in just a few hours.|||The water in Thang Hen lake remains blue-green throughout the year, regardless of the flood or dry season.|||The lake area has steep cliffs ranging from 5-30m high, with ancient trees like giant nghien trees over hundreds of years old, various types of orchids, diverse flora and fauna, and wild animals like golden monkeys, grouse, and forest pigeons…|||It takes only an hour by motorbike or car to reach Thang Hen, where visitors can enjoy the cool atmosphere, admire the majestic and poetic landscape of rivers, lakes, and mountains. They can also row a boat from one lake to another, savor local dishes made from lake products, and taste the delicious and warm rice wine distilled from corn and leaf yeast according to the traditional method of the Tay ethnic group.

title: Le Hoi Den Vua Le Temple Festival
description: It's become a tradition that on the 6th day of the first lunar month every year, locals and tourists from afar gather for the Le Hoi Den Vua Le festival in Lang Den hamlet, Hoang Tung commune, Hoa An district. This festival marks the beginning of the temple and pagoda festival season in Cao Bang province.|||The Den Vua Le temple is dedicated to King Le Loi Cao Hoang De (also known as King Le Thai To), one of Vietnam's most brilliant and illustrious monarchs, to express gratitude and devotion. The temple is part of the Na Lu citadel complex, recognized and ranked as a National Historical and Cultural Site by the State.|||The festival is organized to pray for favorable weather, a bountiful harvest, and people's good health, as well as to strive for another year of achieving socio-economic, national defense, and security goals, and building a new rural area. This is also an occasion for people to show their appreciation for their ancestors, a good tradition of the nation with thousands of years of history of building and defending the country.|||The festival features various activities with historical and cultural significance, such as a procession of the king's palanquin, lion dancing, drum beating to open the festival, incense offering, and a review of historical events at the temple. There are also cultural performances, sports competitions, and folk games; a meeting of propagandists with lullabies and folk songs praising the homeland. Additionally, there are booths displaying local delicacies, traditional handicrafts, and distinctive products, as well as a book and photo exhibition showcasing recent achievements in economics, culture, society, and national defense of the province.|||The previous evening, on the 5th day of the first lunar month, a cultural exchange program was held at the Den Vua Le temple to celebrate the Party and the new year, featuring various performances by artists and artisans from local communes and towns, attracting many visitors.

title: Ma Phuc Pass
description: Ma Phuc Pass is one of the most beautiful passes on National Highway 3 and a must-stop for travelers on their way to conquer the Northeastern mountains.|||Ma Phuc Pass is located in Cao Xuyen hamlet, Quoc Toan commune, Tra Linh district, which marks the border between Hoa An and Tra Linh districts, about 22 km from Cao Bang city. The pass is 3.5 km long, approximately 700 m high, and features seven winding slopes between two limestone mountains that resemble two horses bowing down. Ma Phuc Pass is considered the most beautiful pass in Cao Bang and one of the most treacherous routes in Vietnam. Notably, it is a unique geological heritage site of the Non Nuoc Cao Bang Global Geopark recognized by UNESCO.|||As travelers cross Ma Phuc Pass, they will be amazed by the majestic and poetic landscape with rolling hills and mountains.|||Each season, Ma Phuc Pass offers a distinct beauty. In spring, visitors can see vast green fields of corn and rice. In late autumn and early winter, they can admire the blooming buckwheat flowers.|||A special experience at Ma Phuc Pass is exploring the local market and trying regional specialties. One of the most popular and sought-after delicacies is beef.|||Visiting Ma Phuc Pass offers a chance to admire the fascinating nature, join a highland market, and buy local specialties as souvenirs, making it an unforgettable experience for travelers exploring Cao Bang.

title: Camtu Flower Garden
description: The camtu flower garden is located in the Kolia Farm eco-tourism area (Phia Den, Nguyen Binh, Cao Bang Province). It's about 70km from Cao Bang city center.|||The camtu flower is a woody plant that reproduces asexually. Initially, the flowers are white, then gradually turn blue, pink, or purple. The flower color depends on the soil pH.|||The camtu flowers are in full bloom and most beautiful in the first half of June, then they gradually fade.|||The camtu flower thrives in cool climates, not too hot, which is why it's widely planted in Da Lat. Cao Bang also has a relatively mild climate, so locals have tried planting camtu flowers in Binh Nguyen. Due to the soil pH, the camtu flowers here have a beautiful, bright white-blue color with a hint of purple.|||As you enter the garden, you'll see clusters of camtu flowers growing along the stone wall. Most of the camtu flowers are planted in clusters, but they're more abundant along the two sides of the lake. The flowers bloom and cover the entire length of the lake shore. Visitors can admire the flowers while watching the schools of trout swimming in the lake.|||Not only is the camtu flower garden stunningly beautiful, but visitors can also see a 4km distant French colonial villa. Your trip will be even more perfect if you successfully hunt for clouds. The highland houses and terraced fields hide and appear under the floating clouds, making the long journey worthwhile.|||On weekends, many visitors come here, and it has become a popular photography spot for young people in Cao Bang. The garden is not only stunningly beautiful, but visitors can also see a 4km distant French colonial villa. Your trip will be even more perfect if you successfully hunt for clouds.

title: Dong Lan Pagoda
description: Dong Lan Pagoda is an ancient temple with a long history, built during the Le - Mac dynasty.|||It was recognized as a provincial historical and cultural relic in 1997.|||Dong Lan Pagoda is located on Dong Lan hill (called Doong Lan by the Tay people), in the northwest of Cao Bang city. There are several hypotheses about the origin of the name 'Dong Lan', which are associated with historical legends from various periods, such as the legend of Thuc Phan organizing the 'Nine Lords Contesting the King' tournament (other locations associated with this legend include: Tong Chup field, Cao Binh banyan tree, stone sandals in Ban Thanh, and the upturned boat in Khau Lua). According to one story, the lord went to retrieve a bronze drum and stopped here, exhausted, to sleep. Mice then gnawed through the drum's ropes, causing it to roll down the hill and produce a loud sound that echoed throughout the region. The other lords, believing that the lord who went to retrieve the drum had won, abandoned the contest, and thus no one emerged victorious. 'Dong Lan' is believed to be a corruption of 'Tong Lann', meaning 'drum rolling'. Another hypothesis suggests that the name 'Dong Lan' refers to the pagoda's location on a hill shaped like a Lân.|||During the Ly Dynasty (late 11th century), Dong Lan Pagoda was built to worship Buddha.|||In the year of Tan Hoi, Can Thong 19th era of the Mac Dynasty, the queen ordered the construction of the pagoda in the shape of the letter "ding", with two corridors and a back hall, monk quarters.|||Behind the pagoda is the Ly Cung of the Mac family.|||The pagoda was a place for the queen and princesses to chant sutras and pray to Buddha.|||Before the temple was built, on Dong Lan hill, there was a shrine to Tran Quy and Tran Kien. According to historical records, Tran Quy and Tran Kien were noted for their extraordinary talents. Their father, Tran Trieu, married a celestial being and passed on magical powers to his sons. When they came of age, their mother had to return to heaven, and their father went into the mountains to seek immortality. The brothers Tran Quy and Tran Kien remembered their parents' advice and traveled the region, fighting monsters and eliminating harm for the people.|||The people were grateful for their merits and built a temple to honor them during spring and autumn. Throughout the dynasties, they were worshiped. During the Le dynasty, Tran Kien was titled Cai Cong Dai Vuong, a lower-ranking deity, and Tran Quy was titled Dong Lan Dai Vuong, a middle-ranking deity.|||After going through historical events, Dong Lan Pagoda was repeatedly destroyed and heavily damaged, then restored. During the Thieu Tri era (1841-1847) of the Nguyen dynasty, the pagoda was completely rebuilt. The shrine dedicated to Tran Quy - Tran Kien is located in a small separate temple adjacent to the right corridor of the pagoda, while the main hall is used for Buddhist worship. During the resistance war against France, in 1950, the pagoda was once again destroyed.|||In addition, according to historical records provided by elderly residents in Hung Dao commune, the temple used to have an incense burner dedicated to Thach Sanh.|||Thach Sanh is a legendary figure in the folklore of the Tay ethnic group.|||He killed a malevolent spirit to protect the peaceful life of the people.|||On January 15, 1997, the temple was recognized as a provincial historical and cultural relic by the Provincial People's Committee. In 2004, the state funded the restoration of the main hall, added many Buddha statues, and renovated the temple grounds. However, the original architecture of the temple has not been preserved intact. The original artifacts such as bells, Buddha statues, and couplets have been lost. Only new artifacts have been donated by Buddhists since then.|||Dong Lan Pagoda currently has a quite spacious grounds. The three-gate entrance is built solidly and impressively. From the outside, it reads 'Compassion', while from the inside, it reads 'Forgiveness'.|||The temple consists of a main hall with 5 compartments in the front and 1 main sanctuary. There is also an ancestral hall (3 compartments). The temple's roof is tiled with curved tiles, decorated with a pair of dragons welcoming the moon. From the temple yard, visitors have to climb 9 steps to reach the first architectural layer, which is the front hall (bai duong). All doors are built in the form of arched vaults.|||The front hall is spacious and tall, consisting of 5 compartments. The middle compartment features an altar with a statue of the Thousand-Eyed, Thousand-Armed Goddess of Mercy. The right compartment is the altar of General Tran Quy - Tran Kien and a statue of Duc Ong. The left compartment is the altar of Thach Sanh.|||Between the worship hall and the main sanctuary, there is a transitional space that allows natural light to enter.|||The main sanctuary (the triple-gate hall) has two levels of altars. The highest level, right under the roof, has three Trika Buddha statues representing the Buddhas of the past, present, and future. These three statues are identical in size and shape and are placed on lotus thrones. The second level has three statues in a row called the Amitabha Trinity. In the center is the large statue of Amitabha Buddha. On either side are the Bodhisattva and Arhat statues, arranged in a hierarchical order from low to high, majestic and solemn. On the two main pillars of the main sanctuary are two couplets:|||A thousand years of merit and virtue passing down the Three Jewels|||A single thought enlightens the mind like a celestial being|||Temporary translation:|||A thousand years of merit passing down the Three Jewels|||A profound impression reaching nine layers of clouds|||In the temple yard, there is a 3m-high white marble statue of Quan The Am Bo Tat holding a nectar bottle.|||Behind the main hall is the altar room with three altars: the Sacred Mother altar (main hall), the Son Trang altar, and the Tran Dynasty altar.|||Above the main altar is a pair of Thanh xa - Bach Xa snakes.|||In 2007, with the consent of the Provincial People's Committee, the Vietnam Buddhist Church sent monks to reside and manage the temple, ensuring freedom of religious belief for the people.|||The temple is a place for Buddhist followers from many places in the province to come and worship Buddha on the 1st and 15th days of each lunar month.|||The temple festival takes place on the 8th day of the first lunar month every year with many activities: chanting sutras, shaking quẻ for good luck, praying for wealth, lighting incense to pick lộc, organizing traditional folk games…, attracting visitors from all over to join in the vibrant festival.

title: Dong Lan Pagoda Festival
description: On the 8th day of the first lunar month, people in the region and visitors from afar enthusiastically participate in the Dong Lan Pagoda festival, held in Hung Dao Commune (City).|||Dong Lan Pagoda has a long history, dating back to the Le - Mac dynasty. In 1997, it was recognized as a provincial cultural and historical relic.|||During the Ly dynasty (late 11th century), Dong Lan Pagoda was built to worship Buddha. Before the pagoda was built, there was a temple dedicated to Tran Quy and Tran Kien on Dong Lan hill. The book 'Cao Bang Thuc Luc' contains many details about the origin and special talents of the brothers Tran Quy and Tran Kien. Their father, Tran Trieu, married a fairy and their sons inherited many magical powers. When they grew up, their mother had to return to heaven, and their father went to the mountains to seek immortality. The brothers Tran Quy and Tran Kien remembered their parents' instructions and traveled the region, fighting monsters and eliminating harm to the people. During the Le dynasty, Tran Kien was posthumously titled Cai Cong Dai Vuong, a lower-ranking deity, and Tran Quy was titled Dong Lan Dai Vuong, a middle-ranking deity. Grateful for their merits, people built a temple to worship them during the spring and autumn seasons.|||The pagoda also has an incense burner dedicated to Thach Sanh - a legendary figure in Tày mythology. Thach Sanh defeated a demon and protected the people's peaceful lives. The current pagoda consists of a main hall with five front rooms and one main sanctuary, as well as a separate ancestral hall.|||In 2007, with the approval of the provincial People's Committee, the Vietnam Buddhist Church sent monks to reside and manage the pagoda. It has become a place for Buddhists from across the province to come and pray.|||Every year, on the 8th day of the first lunar month, the pagoda festival takes place. The ritual part begins on the evening of the 7th day. During the festival, many traditional games are organized, attracting visitors from everywhere to join in the fun.

title: Bau Truc Pottery Village
description: Located about 10km south of Phan Rang city, right on National Highway 1A, Bau Truc pottery village is in Phuoc Dan town, Ninh Phuoc district, Ninh Thuan province|||Bau Truc Cham traditional pottery village is an ancient craft village that has existed and developed for over 7 centuries since Po Klong Chang brought the Cham people from the hills to the plains to live. Notably, this is a place that preserves many rare and unique features in the pottery art of the ancient Champa people. That's why Bau Truc has become the oldest craft village in Southeast Asia, famous for its excellent handmade pottery products.|||Visiting Bau Truc traditional pottery village in Phan Rang - Ninh Thuan, you will be amazed by a living museum with hundreds of products of different kinds.|||From simple and rustic products you often see to sophisticated and intricate ones, all will show you a vivid cultural picture that has existed for over 800 years.

title: My Nghiep Cham Handloom Village
description: Located in Phuoc Dan town, Ninh Phuoc district, Ninh Thuan province, 12km southeast of Phan Rang town. The village has a Cham name Ca Klaing, and a Vietnamese name My Nghiep, which means a place that produces beautiful professional crafts.

title: Sakai Eco-Tourism Area
description: Sakai Fruit Garden, a colorful and fragrant destination, features a variety of fruits such as Durian, Avocado, Rambutan, and Mangosteen, among others.|||Here, you can immerse yourself in the natural coolness of the stream, providing a refreshing atmosphere for your family on a hot summer day. What's more perfect than having lunch by the stream, watching the majestic Sakai waterfall cascade down in a poetic mountainous scenery?|||The waterfall boasts a wild beauty with large stones reflecting a rainbow, surrounded by a forest and a stream flowing from above, creating a white foam. You can enjoy fresh and delicious fruits at an affordable price. Additionally, you can visit the giant pipes of the Đa Nhim hydroelectric power plant, admire the vast lake, and explore the sharp turns of the Ngoạn Mục pass.

title: Ninh Thuan Museum
description: Ninh Thuan Museum is located in the 16/4 Square complex, Tan Tai ward, Phan Rang - Thap Cham city. The museum has a prime location in the city center with an area of 3,547.14 m2, 1.5 km from Binh Son beach to the east.|||The museum is close to many planned projects, including an international school, a tourist night market, a provincial hospital, a supermarket system, and entertainment areas like kite surfing, sand racing, and Vinh Hy resort.|||From the museum to the Po Klong Garai Cham tower is 9 km west, to Bau Truc pottery village and My Nghiep weaving village - two oldest craft villages in Southeast Asia - is 10 km south, and to Ba Moi vineyard is 7 km.|||The museum's design has a special meaning, combining with the victory monument to create a unique architectural complex with a vibrant atmosphere.|||The museum resembles an Egyptian pyramid from above.|||From a distance, it looks like a cultural transmission ship. This is a place to preserve cultural values of Ninh Thuan, characterized by sunny and windy land. Every Tet, the museum shines brighter with sparkling orbs. Visitors can enjoy the warm spring atmosphere.|||At night, the museum becomes a colorful crystal, shining and creating a mystical space in Phan Rang - Thap Cham city.|||Inside, over 40,000 artifacts are displayed across various zones with different themes, including geography, natural history, and cultural exhibits of Kinh, Cham, Hoa, Raglai, Chu Ru, and Co Ho people.

title: Mui Dinh Lighthouse
description: The Mui Dinh Lighthouse, a French-built architectural work from 1904, stands 16 meters tall on a mountain slope 300 meters above sea level, surrounded by vast sand dunes.|||Located in Phuoc Dinh commune, Thuan Nam district, it is about 45 km south of Phan Rang - Thap Cham city and 300 km from Ho Chi Minh City. The lighthouse now uses solar-powered energy to illuminate the sea, with a 100W capacity, shining over 26 nautical miles to guide ships. Mui Dinh Lighthouse serves not only as a maritime guide but also as a sovereignty marker of Vietnam's sea and islands.|||On the way to the lighthouse, you'll witness pristine natural beauty with large mountains, vast white sand beaches, and stunning blue seas. The most attractive part is crossing the small desert, hidden in a system of hills and surrounded by hundreds of sand dunes. This desert is where the sea and white sand intersect.|||The over 1km path through the sand dunes leads to the sea, featuring freshwater lakes, cacti, and goats roaming on the mountains. After overcoming the challenging sand dunes and steep path to Mui Dinh, the lighthouse reveals itself at the intersection of sea, sky, and mountains.|||Upon reaching the lighthouse, you'll be amazed by the scenery. From the top, you can see the vast space of clouds, sea, water, and endless sand dunes.|||For an ideal trip, visit Mui Dinh Lighthouse in the morning or late afternoon. Wear light, breathable clothing and protect yourself from the sun. Bring sunscreen, hats, sunglasses, and at least two bottles of water, especially if walking through the desert. You can also visit the Tanyoli tourist area, known as the 'Mongolian steppe' of Ninh Thuan, for more experiences in this sunny and windy land.

title: De Cat Tunnel Historical Site
description: During the Dien Bien Phu tour, visitors can also visit the De Cat Tunnel historical site.|||The command bunker of General De Cat is located in the center of the Dien Bien Phu stronghold in Muong Thanh field, Dien Bien district, Dien Bien province. Although nearly 60 years have passed, the structure and layout of the bunker remain intact.|||The De Cat Tunnel, designed by French colonizers, is 20m long and 8m wide, consisting of four rooms for both living and working. The bunker is surrounded by a defensive fence with a dense barbed wire system and four tanks.|||The De Cat Tunnel is a testament to the glorious history of the nation, with countless blood, sweat, and tears shed by our soldiers and people to raise the red flag with a yellow star on the bunker roof. This contributed to the great victories and ultimately led to the reunification of the country in the spring of 1975.|||In addition, visitors can explore the historical site system of the Dien Bien Phu victory, including: Dien Bien Phu campaign headquarters in Muong Phang; Him Lam, Ban Keo, Doc Lap strongpoints; C1, D1, E1 hills. And many other famous sites in Dien Bien such as: Thanh Ban Phu, Xa Nhe Cave, Pa Thom Cave, Dien Bien Phu Victory Museum, Uva hot spring, Cheing So tower,...|||Book your tour now and discover the tourist attractions in Dien Bien that we just sent you! Wishing you an exciting journey to the heroic land of Dien Bien.

title: Him Lam Historical Site
description: Him Lam was one of the outer positions of the Dien Bien Phu fortified complex, located on road 41 (now Vo Nguyen Giap road), the northeastern gate, controlling the road from Tuan Giao to Dien Bien. It was one of the strong resistance centers of the Dien Bien Phu fortified complex.|||Like other strongpoints in the 49-strongpoint defense system, Him Lam was given the euphemistic name Beatrice by the French, named after a beautiful young woman from France. The French built a defensive system on three hills, forming a solid triangle, supporting each other, with fortified positions, powerful firepower, and a network of auxiliary fortifications with dense barbed wire.|||The French also equipped the site with infrared guns to detect targets at night, tanks, artillery, and air support ready to intervene at any time. The force stationed at this strongpoint was the reinforced Foreign Legion battalion, part of the 13th Foreign Legion demi-brigade, which the French considered one of the most elite units, with a record of never having lost a battle before.|||With its robust defensive system, elite troops, and modern weapons, the French boasted that Him Lam was an extremely strong fortress, a "steel door" of the "impregnable" fortified complex.|||On our side, Him Lam was determined by the Front Command to be the opening battle, to ensure the principle of "the first battle must win". Our army arranged strong forces, including reserves; plans for artillery, air defense, and defense against enemy counterattacks were made, along with anticipation of basic situations and their handling during the battle. The task of destroying the Him Lam Resistance Center was assigned to the 141st and 209th Regiments of the 312th Division to directly attack and destroy the stronghold.|||At 17:00 on March 13, 1954, the attack on the Dien Bien Phu stronghold officially began, with successive artillery bombardments aimed directly at Him Lam and the Central Subsector. From the very first shots, we destroyed the command center of the Him Lam Resistance Center, killing the Battalion Commander Pe go (Pesgaux) and 3 other officers, and completely severed communication between Him Lam and Muong Thanh.|||Phan Dinh Got, a squad leader, was severely injured but still charged forward, using explosives and grenades to destroy bunker No. 2. At that time, the enemy's firepower from bunker No. 3 was fierce, preventing our soldiers from advancing. Got, alone and with only one gun, cautiously moved closer to the enemy's gun emplacement, utilizing the terrain and small mounds of earth. When the opportunity arose, Got aimed directly at the enemy's gun slit and fired. As soon as the enemy gunner changed the magazine, Got quickly moved forward and pressed his body against the enemy's gun, blocking the gun slit.|||The 58th Company immediately launched an assault to destroy firepower point No. 3 and, along with other attack units of the battalion, charged forward, using grenades and bayonets to annihilate the enemy. By 23:30 on March 13, 1954, our army had completely destroyed the Him Lam Resistance Center. After the battle, we destroyed nearly 300 enemy soldiers, captured over 200, and seized all their weapons and ammunition. The victory at Him Lam stronghold was the first victory of the Vietnam People's Army, significantly contributing to the success of the Dien Bien Phu campaign on May 7, 1954.|||The Him Lam Resistance Center is one of the component sites of the Special National Historical Site of the Dien Bien Phu Battlefield.|||It is located about 2km north of other attractions such as A1 Hill, D1 Hill (Dien Bien Phu Victory Monument), and the Dien Bien Phu Historical Victory Museum. Every year, when the Hoa Ban flowers bloom, we remember the Him Lam opening battle with its glorious victories, heroic examples, and sacrifices for national independence and freedom.|||The historic battlefield has been preserved and restored with bunkers, trenches, barbed wire fences, and pillboxes.|||It is a place for people and tourists to visit, pay respects, and recall the glorious pages of the nation's history. The Him Lam Resistance Center offers many emotions and meanings for each visitor to Dien Bien Phu in March, during the Hoa Ban season.

title: Tả Sìn Thàng Highland Market
description: Phuot – Tả Sìn Thàng market takes place on the days of Tý and Ngọ every month according to the lunar calendar. Every six days, a market session is held, serving as a venue for exchanging and trading goods and agricultural products among the people of five communes in the northern part of Tủa Chùa district (Sín Chải, Tả Sìn Thàng, Lao Sa Phình, Trung Thu, and Sính Phình). The market is also a place that vividly showcases the cultural identity of the highland ethnic groups in the area.|||Tả Sìn Thàng market retains many unique features of highland markets, with vibrant attire worn by the locals, and a variety of products on display, mostly local agricultural produce and food such as fruits, vegetables, potatoes, cassava, rice, mushrooms, and forest products, as well as livestock like pigs and chickens. Additionally, there are traditional handicrafts, colored threads, dyes, and products made from durable, beautiful woven fabric. The market also offers multi-colored sticky rice, and the smell of simmering 'thắng cố' (a traditional dish) wafts through the air, enticing visitors.|||Besides 'thắng cố', Mông Pê liquor is also a notable specialty. Made from fermented corn using forest leaves, it has a distinct aroma and flavor.|||Apart from Mông Pê liquor, goat meat and Shan Tuyết tea are also famous specialties in Tả Sìn Thàng. The area has nearly 4,000 ancient Shan Tuyết tea trees, with some having trunks so large they require several people to hug. The cool climate and mountain mist allow the tea to thrive, giving it a sweet flavor.|||During the spring, Tả Sìn Thàng market offers a diverse and rich array of goods. Although the variety might not be extensive, it includes local agricultural products, traditional handicrafts, and commercial goods brought from lower regions. The produce on display is fresh and appealing, including fruits, vegetables, rice, potatoes, cassava, tea, mushrooms, chestnuts, forest honey, and more, all produced by the local people.|||In this highland region, where mountains and cornfields are more common than rice paddies, the local produce has a distinct flavor profile shaped by the mountainous terrain. Goods are displayed along the pathways within the market, offering a wide range of fresh products, from forest-grown vegetables to high tea trees, dried mushrooms, and forest honey. The products reflect the authentic and simple lifestyle of the highland people, who rarely haggle over prices and prefer straightforward transactions.

title: A Pa Chai Tourism
description: A Pa Chai is an ideal tourist destination in Dien Bien Phu. Being the westernmost point of Vietnam, this place attracts many people who want to explore and experience. If you're interested in discovering this extreme west, it's essential to learn about this land first. Let's explore what A Pa Chai tourism has to offer in this article.|||Introduction to A Pa Chai|||This is the westernmost point of Vietnam - where the milestone No. 0 marks the border between Vietnam, Laos, and China, so it's also known as the border tri-point. This milestone was unified by the three countries on June 27, 2005. Since then, this place has officially become the western milestone of Vietnam.|||The milestone is triangular in shape, located at an altitude of 1864m above sea level and engraved in three languages of three countries. The milestone is made of granite, standing in the middle of a hexagon. The milestone is about 2 meters high, with three sides facing three directions of three countries and engraved with the name and national emblem of each country.|||What is the best season to visit A Pa Chai?|||Dien Bien is perhaps most beautiful in late winter and early spring. At this time, the chrysanthemums are blooming with bright yellow flowers on the mountain slopes, turning the mountainous landscape golden.|||This is also when the Ha Nhi people are preparing to celebrate Tet. The best time to visit A Pa Chai is from November to April (in the Gregorian calendar).|||This is the dry season, making travel more convenient.|||Where is A Pa Chai?|||A Pa Chai is located in Sin Thau commune, Muong Nhe district, Dien Bien province. Visitors can choose three main means of transportation: airplane, car or motorbike. Currently, the Hanoi - Dien Bien route has been operated by Vietnam Airlines. If traveling by car, visitors can take a bus at My Dinh or Giap Bat bus stations to get to Dien Bien.|||For backpackers, take National Route 6 from Hanoi to Thuan Chau, then from Tuan Giao, follow National Route 279 to Dien Bien. From there, continue to Muong Ghe and to the A Pa Chai border gate. This journey will take a lot of time and effort; so you need to prepare carefully before starting.|||Conquering the westernmost point A Pa Chai|||The journey to conquer the westernmost point of the Fatherland has been undertaken by many tourists with interesting and wonderful trips. From Dien Bien, tourists can follow the route through Muong Cha - Muong Nhe - Chung Chai - Border Post 405 - Ta Kho Khur - Border Post 317 to reach the westernmost point.|||What should I prepare for a trip to A Pa Chai?|||The journey to conquer the westernmost point is relatively long and challenging, with mostly mountainous terrain, and there are no dining services along the way. Therefore, visitors must prepare sufficient backup food for the journey. At the same time, you should also prepare some medicine and medical supplies in case of emergencies such as snake bites or falls on the mountain.|||In addition, visitors need to prepare a local introduction letter from their place of residence or work to complete the procedures for permission from the Dien Bien Border Command. Also, remember to always carry your ID card with you.|||tourist attractions in the far west of A Pa Chai|||In Muong Nhe, two of the most attractive tourist spots are the Zero Kilometer and A Pa Chai border market. Besides, visitors can also participate in thrilling adventure activities such as paragliding, mountain climbing, sea bathing, cloud hunting... Each location, each land here has its own unique characteristics, worth exploring.|||What delicious dishes does A Pa Chai have?|||Visitors here can enjoy specialties like sticky rice, grilled beef, grilled fish, thick cakes, bitter bamboo shoots... A Pa Chai also has many simple, rustic dishes with delicious restaurants and eateries you can drop by. If you have a chance to visit Dien Bien, don't miss these delicious dishes!|||Notes when traveling to A Pa Chai|||The road to Dien Bien is rocky with many pebbles and stones, steep cliffs, and dense thorny forests. Therefore, you must have a strong will and a spirit that is not afraid of difficulties, dangers, and hardships. At the same time, before starting your journey, you should also learn about the route, accommodations, restaurants... and plan a clear itinerary.|||When preparing your belongings, pack only the essentials in a light and compact backpack.|||Remember the tips and information we've provided to stay proactive in every situation.|||If you're looking for an exciting and thrilling journey, then what are you waiting for? Pick up your backpack and start your conquest of A Pa Chai. Hopefully, you'll have the most wonderful experiences in this land.

title: Muang Thanh Field
description: The vast and expansive Muang Thanh field is located in Dien Bien Phu. This is known as the largest field in the Northwest region.|||It is not only a fertile rice field but also the site of the glorious and epic Dien Bien Phu victory, renowned worldwide.|||Muang Thanh field stretches over 25 km in length and 5 to 6 km in width, creating a vast and endless landscape, green as far as the eye can see.|||This vast field stretching from Nghia Lo to Dien Bien is not only famous for being the site of the 'shocking to the world' Battle of Dien Bien Phu. It is also known for its large area and favorable conditions for intensive cultivation, making it a place that produces fragrant and delicious rice. Therefore, locals refer to it as a huge rice granary.|||Nhat Thanh captivates those who love nature with its majestic scenery and lush beauty. The vast field seems endless, green and lush all year round. The trees stand tall and upright like unyielding soldiers, proudly defying the elements. When heavy with ripe grains, they bow humbly.|||The rustic and simple beauty of Vietnamese countryside can be vaguely seen amidst the Northwestern mountains and forests.|||However, Muong Thanh plain has its own uniqueness.|||Surrounded by vast nature, the plain exudes a majestic and heroic aura with majestic mountains and forests stretching as far as the eye can see.|||The weather in Muong Thanh is quite uncomfortable. The temperature fluctuates greatly throughout the day.|||However, the cool atmosphere and gentle sunshine make it even more charming, enticing tourists to stay longer.|||When is the best time to visit Muong Thanh Field?|||The best time to visit Muong Thanh is during the rice harvest season. Around September every year, the place is painted with a golden color, stretching out as far as the eye can see.|||How to get to Muong Thanh field?|||The route from Hanoi to Dien Bien has been completed. Therefore, tourists can easily take a bus or drive a car to explore this vast and fertile Northwest field.|||Travel experience in Muong Thanh field|||When traveling to Muong Thanh, you can't miss the Nam Rom River. The river stretches out, winding gently to embrace the entire field, looping through the valley to fertilize the soil. The golden color of ripe rice, the emerald green of the river, create a beautiful picture here.|||On both sides of the river are rows of tall trees providing shade. Occasionally, clusters of banana flowers in vibrant red bloom and lean to reflect their images in the clear water.|||The Muong Thanh bridge crossing Nam Rom river is also a beautiful tourist spot in the "Nhast Thanh" valley. The simple and rustic bridge along with the river creates a romantic scenery. However, tourists should note that the bridge is only for pedestrians and 2-wheeled vehicles.|||Every year, hundreds of groups of tourists come here not only to admire the magnificent and majestic natural scenery but also to revisit the glorious historical milestones in the fight against the American imperialists and French colonialists. Not only that, most of these natural tourist attractions are free of charge or entrance fees.|||Besides exploring, you can also enjoy local specialties in Dien Bien such as grilled sticky rice, hot springs, bamboo shoots soup or boiled bamboo shoots... These seemingly familiar dishes offer a unique flavor that can only be found in the Northwest region.|||The Muong Thanh valley is a unique beauty of Dien Bien. Besides the famous "Nhất Thanh", Dien Bien is also known for many other tourist attractions such as A1-C1-A1-E1 bunker, Ban Phu Fortress, command bunker or Dien Bien Victory Museum... These are all places that bear the mark of the glorious history of the nation.

title: U Va Hot Spring
description: Surrounded by majestic green hills, U Va hot spring will captivate anyone who sets foot here. With effective investment and exploitation, U Va hot spring tourist site brings an extremely comfortable and relaxing feeling when soaking in the warm water at this impressive Dien Bien tourist destination.|||U Va hot spring is located in Noong Luong commune, Dien Bien district. This hot spring is about 15km southwest of Dien Bien city. It covers a total area of about 73,000m2 with a natural hot mineral stream and an average temperature of about 75 to 85 degrees Celsius. It was discovered by French colonizers in the 1950s.|||To get to U Va hot spring, you can follow this route: from Dien Bien city center, go along Ton Duc Thang - La Thanh - Tran Duy Hung and Ham Chui to DDCT08 at Me Tri, then continue straight to DDCT08. Then follow DT446/TL446/Provincial road 446 to QL6 at Mong Hoa. Go along QL6 and QL279 to Noong Het. You can ask for directions to Noong Luong-Pa Thom at Noong Luong. From there, it's easy to get to this hot spring.|||At U Va hot spring tourist site, you will be able to admire and immerse yourself in the majestic natural scenery and soak in the hot mineral water gifted by nature. Not only that, the natural scenery around this hot spring is truly magnificent, with rolling hills, trees and green forests covering the surroundings, making anyone who comes here feel like they're on a deserted island.|||This place has been and is being invested and exploited for the tourism industry and services of Dien Bien province, so you will be provided with almost full experiences when coming to this U Va hot spring. In addition, you will also learn about the values and quintessence of the ancient culture of Muong Thanh land, which has existed for thousands of years in Dien Bien.|||Legend of U Va hot spring|||The name U Va originates from the legend of a fairy lying on a beautiful cradle. The name "U Va" is transliterated from the word "Ú Vá", where "Ú" means lady, and "Vá" means cradle. You will also hear the legend of seven fairies, who come down to the mortal world every afternoon to bathe in the lake and then return to the hill to play and teach the Thai people how to grow mulberry, raise silkworms, and weave fabric, etc.|||You will also learn about the story of the Hoa Cat rope, which represents the idea of local people after death, wishing to go to heaven. It expresses the connection between heaven and earth.|||What to do when visiting U Va hot spring?|||In addition to soaking in the hot water and admiring the scenery of clouds, mountains and sky, you can also participate in games such as playing badminton, tennis, boating, enjoying xoe dancing performances, singing folk songs performed by Thai and H'Mong people.|||Coming to U Va hot spring in Dien Bien, you will be immersed in a majestic natural space and hear interesting stories here.

title: Dien Bien Phu Campaign Headquarters
description: Dien Bien TV - The Dien Bien Phu campaign headquarters hid in the old forest at the foot of Pu Don mountain, about 40km from Dien Bien Phu city. This was where General Vo Nguyen Giap often worked and rested during the Dien Bien Phu campaign, which led to the famous victory.|||The campaign headquarters were located in Muong Phang for 105 days, from January 31, 1954, to May 15, 1954. With a system of interconnected tunnels and bunkers hidden in the old forest, the headquarters were absolutely safe.|||From this headquarters, you could observe the entire Dien Bien Phu city, Muong Thanh valley, and former French strongpoints like Him Lam hill, Doc Lap hill, D1 hill, C1 hill, and A1 hill.|||The telephone switchboard helped the campaign headquarters connect with infantry, engineer, artillery, and high-angle shooting units, as well as supply and medical units. This was a direct communication network between the campaign headquarters and the Central Party Committee and Uncle Ho.|||The tunnel through the mountain, from General Vo Nguyen Giap's bunker to Thieu Tuong Hoang Van Thai's bunker, and other points, still bears historical significance.|||Next to General Giap's workspace and resting place was a sheltered tunnel. During intense French bombing, the General worked and rested here.|||A 69m-long tunnel connected General Vo Nguyen Giap's bunker to Tham Muu Truong Hoang Van Thai's bunker and military advisor Vi Quoc Thanh's bunker. The tunnel was 1.7m high and 1-3m wide, with a 18m2 meeting room and five communication positions.|||300m northeast of the campaign headquarters, the army and people celebrated the victory on May 13, 1954. The project to restore the Dien Bien Phu campaign headquarters included a plan to create a venue on the old parade ground and a statue to commemorate the 55th anniversary of the victory.|||The War Victory Monument in Muong Phang Park, along with the Dien Bien Phu campaign headquarters, is a must-visit when coming to this historic site, affectionately known as the "Victory Monument".

title: Po Klong Garai Tower
description: Along the North-South railway route, adjacent to National Highway 27A to Da Lat, 7 km west of Phan Rang - Thap Cham town center is a Cham tower complex situated on a hill called Doi Trau, in Ward Do Vinh. This tower cluster was built in the 13th century to worship King Po Klong Garai (1151 - 1205), who ruled Panduranga (present-day Ninh Thuan); it remains intact in both architecture and the Cham people's worship and offerings.|||Po Klong Garai Tower is a complex of 3 towers: the main tower worships King Po Klong Garai, the gate tower to the East and the Fire God tower to the South with a boat-shaped roof. The tower complex is surrounded by a square wall frame on the East and South sides. This is a worship construction that also has architectural and sculptural artistic value with reliefs such as Shiva, the Sacred Bull Nandin, the king... The complex was ranked as a National Cultural Historical Relic by the Ministry of Culture and Information in 1979.|||The main tower is 20.5m high, multi-tiered, with the upper tiers being a scaled-down replica of the lower tier, culminating in a sharp stone pillar, symbolizing a Linga. At the corners of the tower, there are small square pedestals, with stone animal statues and clay fire motif decorations. The tower has one main entrance to the East, with a vaulted roof supported by two large stone pillars, with ancient Champa inscriptions carved on them. Above the door is a relief of dancing Siva with six arms. The remaining three doors, facing South, North, and West, are false doors with protruding and receding brick pillars, each with a meditating deity statue.|||From the entrance, on the left is a stone statue of the sacred bull Nandin, its head facing inward. Inside the tower, there is a Yoni with a length of 1.47m and a width of 0.94m, on top of which is a round Linga. On the Linga pillar is a carved portrait of King Po Klong Girai. Outside, there is a hall connected to the courtyard for worship on a raised platform.|||To the East is the gate tower, 8.56m high, with two doors connecting in the East - West direction, so it's called the gate tower. The tower is also built according to the principle of gradually rising and narrowing.|||To the south between the two towers is the God of Fire tower, 9.31m high. The tower has 3 doors opening to the East, North and South, with the southern one being a window. The function of the tower is for Brahmin monks and priests to arrange offerings and keep the sacrificial fire, so the Cham people call it the Fire Tower.|||What's special is that the tower structure is built with a roof in the style of a house roof (similar to the prong house in the Central Highlands or the boat-shaped roof like the top of a bronze drum).|||Behind the main tower, there is a shrine dedicated to Queen Kut, also known as To Ly.|||South of the tower complex, outside the wall, stands a 2.20m high stone pillar (Linga).|||Northeast of the tower complex, outside the wall, there is a three-sided stone with ancient Cham inscriptions.|||Every year on the last day of the 6th month and the 1st day of the 7th month in the Cham calendar (around September or October in the Gregorian calendar), thousands of Cham people hold a solemn ceremony at the three towers of Po Klong Garai, Po Rome, and Po Inu Nagar. During this festival, known as the Kate festival, Brahmin priests and a large crowd of people will conduct a procession of King Po Klong Girai's costume, worship King Po Rome and the goddess Po Inu Nagar from a village 6 km away to the tower, and perform a ritual bath and dressing of the king's statue.|||On the morning of the 1st day of the 7th month, a traditional dance and music performance is held by the Cham people in front of the tower to offer to the king.|||At this time, around the tower, there are thousands of offerings of fruits, cakes, chicken, goat, wine, and betel leaves from Cham families, praying for happiness, national prosperity, and people's peace.

title: Trung Son Co Tu
description: Trung Son Co Tu is the first and most well-known temple in Ninh Thuan, becoming an essential part of tours to admire the scenery. With its majestic beauty, it is considered a symbol of modern spiritual beliefs.|||Located on Da Chong mountain peak, 60m above sea level, Trung Son Co Tu attracts more visitors as a high-altitude observatory in Ninh Hai district.|||Trung Son Co Tu follows the Northern Buddhist sect of the Linji school. This sect was widely adopted from the Central region to the North as Buddhism entered Vietnam.|||The temple's architecture combines ancient ethnic elements with modern touches. Before the main hall, you can see images like mighty dragons, curved roof tiles resembling boats, and Long - Lan statues attending the moon and the wheel of rebirth… All are arranged harmoniously, though not following a specific logic.|||Due to its construction on hilly terrain, it's hard to distinguish the main hall, worship hall, or ancestral house. The temple complex creates a lively and unique architectural style, but also complexity in identification.

title: Tuấn Tú White Sand Dunes
description: Located in Tuan Tu village, An Hai commune, Ninh Phuoc district, but possessing a completely different beauty from the Nam Cuong red sand dunes, are the Tuan Tu white sand dunes.|||This dune consists of white fine sand hills connected to each other, forming a wavy sand valley with many strange shapes. Its beauty is enhanced by the blue sea, straight rows of poplar trees or robust cactus bushes... Tuan Tu white sand dunes are increasingly attracting many tourists.

title: Ba Moi Grape Garden
description: Mentioning Ninh Thuan, many people immediately think of lush vineyards with ripe grapes. In this land with plenty of sunshine and wind, it's not too difficult to find a vineyard to visit. However, the most famous one is probably Ba Moi Grape Garden.|||Located about 7km from Phan Rang city center, Ba Moi Grape Garden is one of the popular eco-tourism spots in Ninh Thuan. It's considered one of the first vineyards in the grape-growing village in Phan Rang.|||Ba Moi Grape Garden belongs to farmer Nguyen Van Moi, covering an area of about 15,000 m2, where grapes are mainly grown and supplied to the markets in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City. It's also an open eco-tourism site welcoming visitors and a place for agricultural students to study.|||The garden features 13 grape varieties, including 9 fresh grape varieties for eating (4 red, 3 green, Italia, and Blackqueen) and 4 varieties for wine production (Cabernet Sauvignon, Chenin Blanc, Syrah, and Syrah 1). During harvest season, visitors can see unique colors of grapes like black, red, pink, and green on the vines.

title: Hon Do
description: Hon Do is a fossilized coral reef located in My Hiep village, Thanh Hai commune, Ninh Hai district, Ninh Thuan province.|||It is about 17 km from Phan Rang - Thap Cham city center, on the famous Vietnamese coastal road with popular tourist spots.

title: An Hoa Sheep Farm
description: An Hoa sheep farm is located in An Hoa village, Xuan Hai commune, Ninh Hai district, Ninh Thuan province. It is about 16km from Phan Rang - Thap Cham city center to the Northwest, on the way to National Route 1A to Nha Trang. This is one of the largest free-range sheep farming and breeding areas in Ninh Thuan province.

title: Da Bia Mountain
description: Da Bia Mountain (also known as Thach Bi Son), standing at 706m, majestically dominates the northern part of the Deo Ca range.
