On the peak lies a massive 76m-high rock formation with a unique shape, often shrouded in white clouds at dawn or dusk, mysteriously appearing and disappearing.

title: Phu Yen Museum
description: Phu Yen Museum is located at 151 Tran Phu, Ward 5, Tuy Hoa City. It is one of the typical cultural works of Phu Yen. The museum has a total area of 3 hectares, and inside, it is displaying tens of thousands of artifacts meeting national standards. With that attraction, Phu Yen Museum is gradually becoming a notable tourist destination for many visitors.

title: Hon Chua
description: Hon Chua is located in An Phu commune, Tuy Hoa city, about 8 km north of the city center along the coastal road. Tourists can start from Long Thuy beach and take a 10-minute boat ride to Hon Chua.

title: Hon Lao Mai Nha
description: Hon Lao Mai Nha is located in Phuoc Dong village, An Hai commune, Tuy An district, Phu Yen province. It is a small island situated in the middle of the sea, over 4km from Dam O Loan and 27km north of Tuy Hoa city. It is also known as Cu lao Mai Nha.

title: Quang Duc Xua Exhibition Space
description: Located on National Highway 1, at the entrance to Mang Lang Church, near Da Dia rock formation, Quang Duc Xua cultural tourism space features three ancient houses and a spacious fruit orchard. It displays nearly 100 stone grinding mortars, pounding stones, and agricultural tools.

title: Mang Lang Church
description: Mang Lang Church is located in An Thach commune, Tuy An district, 35 km north of Tuy Hoa city center.

title: General Museum
description: The General Museum of Binh Dinh is located in the heart of Quy Nhon city, at 26 Nguyen Hue. Here, over 1,000 documents and artifacts are displayed, offering visitors a comprehensive and detailed insight into the country and people of Binh Dinh through various historical periods. Notably, with hundreds of artifacts of the unique Champa culture being preserved here, the museum is considered to have one of the largest collections of Champa artifacts in Vietnam, including mysterious stone inscriptions that many researchers have yet to fully decipher.|||The museum was built in 1980, covering an area of 3,960m2, divided into three main sections: the exhibition area of 2,000m2, the administrative block, and the souvenir block. The indoor exhibition area consists of five rooms with five main themes: the 'Land and People' room with 241 artifacts, the 'Resistance against France' room with 122 artifacts, the 'Resistance against America' room with 233 artifacts, the 'Cham Culture' room with 173 artifacts, and the 'Ho Chi Minh with Binh Dinh – Binh Dinh with Ho Chi Minh' room with 185 artifacts.|||In addition to the indoor exhibition rooms, the artifacts displayed outdoors in the courtyard have created an impressive and attractive point for visitors when visiting the General Museum. With an open-space design, not focusing on specific themes or artifacts but rather on suggestive fragments of Binh Dinh's architectural, sculptural, and artistic types, such as large Champa sculptures, statues of Binh Dinh notables, modern art statues, folk games, traditional crafts, and ancient beliefs, visitors will have an overview of Binh Dinh's culture.

title: Quy Nhon Beach
description: Quy Nhon Beach is located in the heart of Quy Nhon city, making it very convenient for visitors to explore and swim, just a short walk from the city center. The beach stretches out in a long, gentle curve, lined with golden sand and clear, turquoise water.|||Located on the southeast coast of Binh Dinh province, Quy Nhon Bay curves like a crescent, with a 5km stretch of sandy beach from Tan Cape to Ghenh Rang.|||At night, Quy Nhon transforms into a more beautiful and peaceful place, with the beach and seaside cafes becoming ideal spots to relax, enjoy the sea views, and watch the sparkling fishing lights offshore.

title: Cohn Chim Ecozone
description: Located about 15km from Quy Nhon City, in Phuoc Son, Phuoc Hoa, Phuoc Thuan commune - Tuy Phuoc district. Cohn Chim Ecozone is like an "oasis" surrounded by vast greenery - green water, green sky and green mangrove forests. On calm and quiet days, when the sea is still, if you take a boat trip on Thi Nai lagoon, you will immerse yourself in the fresh atmosphere with beautiful natural scenery, a "green lung" of Quy Nhon City, a familiar and attractive name for tourists when coming to Binh Dinh.|||Cohn Chim Ecozone covers 480 ha, situated in a vast wetland area surrounded by mangrove forests. Underneath the water surface is a diverse and rich source of seafood, with high-value aquatic species such as shrimp, crab, fish, and various types of mollusks. Along with the ecosystem of seaweed beds that are increasingly being restored and developed. Above the mangrove forest is the habitat of a community of endemic birds, herons and migratory birds... In the late afternoons, flocks of birds fly back to roost, and on full moon nights, Cohn Chim is mystical and enchanting like a fairyland.|||From Cohn Chim Ecozone, visitors can easily move to other nearby tourist destinations, such as Lang Song Seminary, Linh Phong Pagoda, Hon Kho Island... From Quy Nhon City, it's less than an hour by boat, or just about 30 minutes by car and a short ferry ride to Cohn Chim Ecozone. This place will give visitors moments of living with nature or interesting experiences of traditional jobs of fishermen in the wetland area.

title: Thi Nai Lagoon
description: Located 8km northeast of Quy Nhon city, Thi Nai Lagoon is the largest in Binh Dinh province with a rich ecosystem featuring various precious species of flora and fauna, and many beautiful landscapes that attract tourists.|||Thi Nai Lagoon covers over 5,000ha of water surface, stretching over 10km in length and nearly 4km in width. This place has valuable natural resources and diverse biology with a rich mangrove ecosystem, including 25 species of seaweed; 64 species of plankton, 76 species of fish; hundreds of bird species, of which 23 are water and migratory birds, and 10 forest bird species. In the lagoon, near the western shore, there is a small mountain with a tiny temple built by fishermen to worship the water god, shaped like an ancient tower, called Thap Thay Boi, making the lagoon's landscape more dynamic and appealing. Every early morning, on full moon nights, surrounded by lush green mangroves, the lagoon's surface appears misty and mystical like a fairyland.|||Historically, Thi Nai Lagoon was a naval base of the Tay Son dynasty, where intense naval battles took place between the Tay Son rebels and Nguyen Anh's army in the early 19th century (1801).|||Located to the east of Thi Nai Lagoon, like a massive shield protecting Quy Nhon city from the sea, is Phuong Mai peninsula, with a series of rugged mountains and giant sand dunes stretching about 15km into the sea. The northern part of the peninsula and to the northwest have beautiful beaches running for dozens of kilometers. From a distance, Phuong Mai peninsula looks like a dragon's head, with its body extending northwards to the De Gi estuary. The southern tip of the peninsula is a sharp, dagger-like protrusion with many fascinating and treacherous rocky coves, where swallows often come to nest, producing the highly nutritious and rare "bird's nest" delicacy.|||Blending with the natural beauty of Thi Nai Lagoon and Phuong Mai peninsula is the Quy Nhon - Nhon Hoi bridge and road system, with a total length of over 7km, including 5 short bridges and Thi Nai bridge. Notably, Thi Nai bridge, at 2,477.3m long, is the longest sea-crossing bridge in Vietnam with 54 spans connecting Quy Nhon city and Nhon Hoi economic zone. Thi Nai bridge is not only a source of pride for the people of this land but also an attractive highlight for tourists visiting Quy Nhon city.

title: Eo Gio Scenic Spot
description: Eo Gio is located in area 3, Ly Luong village, Nhon Ly island commune, Quy Nhon city, Binh Dinh province. It's a beautiful blue sea in a horseshoe shape, surrounded by high stone mountains. The scenic spot has been popular with photographers and tourists, and is often called the most beautiful sunset spot in Vietnam.|||The name Eo Gio comes from its geographical location. Seen from afar, Eo Gio looks like a saddle, situated between two high mountains by the sea. From above, it resembles a funnel. The location always has strong winds blowing from the sea. In winter, the sea is rough with heavy rain and strong winds. The sea waves crash against the rocks, creating grooves and forming steep cliffs over time. These natural elements have created a pristine and majestic beauty.|||From the top of Eo Gio, visitors can see the entire island commune of Nhon Ly. They can observe fishermen at work, people buying seafood, Phuoc Sa temple with its beautiful architecture, and the Quan Am statue on the mountain, watching over the local fishermen. There is also Ngoc Hoa Tịnh Xá with the largest two-faced Quan Yin statue in Vietnam. All these sights blend together, creating a stunning Eo Gio landscape like a fairyland.|||Visitors can come to Eo Gio from March to September lunar calendar, except during stormy weather. This period offers calm seas, gentle breezes, and clear waters, ideal for outings, snorkeling, and climbing Eo Gio.

title: Quang Ngai Provincial Museum
description: Quang Ngai Museum was established in 1989, separated from Nghia Binh Museum. At that time, the museum only had over 200 artifacts and continued to receive more artifacts from Son My and Ba To museums.|||The museum now has two main exhibition areas: an indoor exhibition and an outdoor exhibition.|||With an indoor exhibition area of 17,000m2, the museum showcases themes on ancient Sa Huynh culture, discovered first in Quang Ngai, and the culture of ethnic groups living in Quang Ngai province, including Kinh, Hrê, Ca Dong, and Kor, as well as the history of Quang Ngai's struggle from before the Party's establishment to the province's complete liberation.|||The outdoor exhibition features representative artifacts of Champa's architectural and sculptural art, appearing in Quang Ngai from the 2nd to 14th centuries, and Nguyen dynasty cannons of various sizes.|||Since its establishment, the museum's collection has grown in quantity and quality, with over 15,000 artifacts and nearly 6,566 documents, films, and images.

title: My Khe Beach
description: My Khe Beach is 15km east-northeast of Quang Ngai provincial center, situated between the beautiful coastal area from Dai river mouth to Ba Lang An.|||It features natural attractions like An Hai sandbank, stone formations, and Sa Ky estuary.|||The beach is 7km long, stretching from Tinh Ky to Co Luy, with Co Luy being a scenic spot with a river, coconut water ponds, and villages shaded by coconut trees.|||The beach has a crescent shape with a wave breaker at An Vinh, golden sand, and is shaded by trees. It's becoming a popular spot for tourists to swim and travel, with many restaurants serving seafood.

title: Mo Cay Victory Site
description: The Mo Cay Victory Site is located in village 1, Duc Chanh commune, Mo Duc district, about 15 km south of Quang Ngai provincial center and 6 km north of Mo Duc district town.|||Visitors can use cars or motorbikes from Quang Ngai city center, following National Route 1A south for about 15km to reach the site.|||The battle took place on a 1km section of National Highway 1A in Mo Cay. To the west of the road are Go Dui, Phuoc Lai and Van Thanh fields. To the east of the road is Tong Giang field in village 1, Duc Chanh commune, Mo Duc district. The rice fields had been harvested, with many raised field borders and canals, which was favorable for ambushing and launching a surprise attack to destroy the enemy.|||Over time, the original relics of the Mo Cay battle have almost disappeared. The terrain, topography and natural scenery of the battle have changed over time, leaving only the location associated with this battle.|||The Moc Cay Victory historical site spans 1000m long and 60m wide along National Highway 1A and nearby fields. The protected area must be defined by representative points related to the battle.|||This site is located in the west of the National Highway, covering a total area of 2885m2.|||In 1994, this 2885m2 area was leveled to build the victory monument and grounds.|||The monument area includes: gate, surrounding wall, yard, walkways, lighting system, flower and tree planting areas. The statue is built in the center of the area. The statue structure is made of reinforced concrete, depicting a character standing with a raised knife, facing the national highway.|||In 2008, a new monument was built from Granite, approximately 12.75m high, with a base height of 2.75m and a statue cluster of around 10m. The statue cluster shows two characters holding guns and one holding a stick, symbolizing the victory of Mo Cay, achieved through the coordinated efforts of Ba To guerrilla team, local guerrillas, and people.|||The pedestal is decorated with reliefs depicting smoke and cloud themes, symbolizing victory and peace.|||The Mo Cay Victory Monument is a cultural work of historical significance, commemorating the outstanding military achievements of the Ba To guerrilla unit.|||It features an impressive architectural sculpture combined with a flower garden, creating a harmonious balance of architectural forms with the surrounding landscape.|||The Ba To ambush victory at Mo Cay left valuable lessons on flexible application of ambush tactics on National Route 1A, achieving high combat efficiency and eliminating many enemy forces. This experience was applied during the Vietnam War. On June 7, 1966, the 48th Battalion, provincial armed forces, bravely ambushed and defeated the 3rd Battalion, 4th Regiment of the South Vietnamese army, killing 408 soldiers, including 2 American soldiers, burning and damaging 18 vehicles, and capturing 267 guns of various types. Mo Cay became a notable location for victories against Japanese and American forces during the national liberation struggle.|||The Mocay War Victory Site is a place that marks the victory and honors the heroic spirit of our revolutionary army and people during the resistance against the Japanese fascists. It is also a place to educate young people about revolutionary ideals, patriotism, and the responsibility to protect the country.

title: Gan Yen
description: Gan Yen scenic spot is about 35 km north of Quang Ngai city center, located by Thanh Thuy fishing village, Binh Hai commune, Binh Son district (Quang Ngai). This scenic spot still retains its pristine and majestic beauty.|||The name Gan Yen is said to originate from the fact that the rocky shores had many small caves, which served as shelters for birds like swallows, swifts, and starlings. The spot features fantastical, rough-hewn stones stacked layer upon layer, forming a towering cliff that stretches out to the sea.|||The combination of sky, clouds, landscape, water, and black stones in various shapes creates a stunning watercolor painting. According to locals, these black stone layers may be the result of volcanic eruptions millions of years ago.|||Especially, visiting Gan Yen during low tide, when the coral reefs are exposed, reveals incredibly beautiful scenes, like thousands of flowers blooming together. The locals believe that the beauty of nature can only be fully appreciated during the low tide season. "At this time, the sea recedes, revealing extremely beautiful coral flowers and starfish of various colors, making visitors feel like they are in a fairyland. This scenery appears 2-3 times a month when the tide is low, on the first and middle days of the month, from April to July of the lunar calendar".

title: Hang Cau
description: Hang Cau is located in An Hai commune, Ly Son island district, at the foot of Tho Loi mountain, next to Hang Church, stretching eastward along the coast. The cave was formed by the sea water eroding the foot of Tho Loi mountain.|||This is a place for tourists to stroll on the sand, fish, dive to see coral, or climb on the rocky shores to admire the vast natural scenery, and behold the unique geological and geomorphological beauty of the cliff and coastline. Hang Cau has abundant seaweed, a type of seaweed with high nutritional value, and is an ingredient for many dishes such as seaweed jam, seaweed soup, fresh seaweed salad or simply a summer heat-clearing dish. And there are countless coral reefs, many species of seafood live here, there are also rocky shores running from the shore out to sea, sit on it and cast a line, just fish, just enjoy the cool breeze and admire the moving scenery around.|||It seems that nature has favored this place, you can stand from afar to look at the majestic sea and sky picture; the waves gently roll, the south wind blows gently; the sunshine shines on the cliff, revealing the time marks over thousands of years of formation with many volcanic eruptions, and the sea advances and retreats.|||Hang Cau has become a unique and impressive destination of Ly Son tourism, leaving a lasting impression on visitors when coming to the island.

title: Thach Ky Dieu Tau
description: Located 16km northeast of Quang Ngai city center, Thach Ky Dieu Tau rock (An Vinh village, Tinh Ky commune) is one of 12 famous scenic spots in Quang Ngai province, with a unique beauty and many interesting things. This place is likened to a work of art arranged by stone, a masterpiece of nature with traces of volcanic activity and the process of sea advance and retreat millions of years ago...|||Thach Ky Dieu Tau rocky reef is located on the southern bank of the Sa Ky estuary. It was formed by volcanic activity that erupted and flowed into the sea millions of years ago, creating this natural rock barrier across the mouth of the sea.|||From above, the reef is not far from the prosperous An Vinh village and is separated from the village by a lush green forest of poplar trees.|||When viewed on a map, this area resembles the foot of a giant stepping out. The position of the foot is exactly where the reef has a shape like 5 toes protruding into the sea.|||The reef consists of stacked rock masses stretching for kilometers, constantly pounded by waves, with foam swirling around it, and hidden beneath the jade-like clear water, creating a rare, pristine, and majestic scene.|||Notably, about 15-20 meters from the shore, a rock formation juts out into the waves, resembling an old man sitting fishing. Nearby, a boulder bears the impression of two gigantic footprints. Adjacent to this is a cave-like structure, open at both ends, at the same level as the tide.|||Every time a wave hits one end of the cave, water shoots out from the other end, leading locals to imagine it as a giant's wine cauldron. For centuries, they have shared tales of a giant who allegedly carried stones to block the sea entrance.|||When almost done, the carrying pole broke, which is now the entrance to Sa Ky port. The piles of stones on either side of the gate today are An Hai and An Vinh capes.|||On them, one can still see the clear footprints of the giant and his wine cauldron.|||The name Thach Ky Dieu Tau is explained by researchers as follows: the word 'ky' in 'Thach Ky Dieu Tau' means a rocky reef or an underwater boulder, also implying water crashing into rocks. According to the book 'Quang Ngai tinh chi' (published in 1933): 'Thach Ky Dieu Tau: At the Sa Ky gate, there is a rocky reef protruding into the sea, which from a distance looks like a human figure, hence the name.' Local people in Son Tinh have long been familiar with a simple name: Lao cau ghanh da. Regardless of the name, Thach Ky Dieu Tau still possesses a pristine and charming beauty.||||||When visiting Thach Ky Dieu Tau, tourists should choose two of the most beautiful times of day to admire the scenery: sunrise or sunset. At these two times, thanks to the special lighting, the scenery of Thach Ky Dieu Tau becomes even more magical. If you're lucky enough to visit during the moss season, you'll get to see a Thach Ky Dieu Tau with a fresh green color, full of vitality, with moss covering the dark, rugged stones that are millions of years old. Unlike the Da Dia rock formation in Phu Yen with its evenly arranged hexagonal stones, Thach Ky Dieu Tau consists of rocks of diverse shapes and sizes, clearly reflecting the erosion process of nature and the activity of the volcanic system in the past. This is also a characteristic of the rocky shores and sea in Quang Ngai.|||Not only can visitors enjoy the fresh air and peaceful scenery, but they can also experience many interesting activities at Thach Ky Dieu Tau such as: Camping; swimming in the "mini swimming pool" which are deep pools on the rocky shore; catching sea urchins, fishing, picking seaweed or learning about the life of An Vinh villagers. Visitors can also taste special seafood like Huynh De crab, sea eel, mullet, and red snapper... cooked to the locals' taste. In addition, visitors can explore nearby tourist attractions like Sa Ky lighthouse, My Khe beach, An Vinh cape, An Hai sandbank or Tinh Ky water coconut forest.

title: Bau Trang
description: In local dialect, 'bau' means 'lake'. The lake is surrounded by many white sand dunes, hence the name Bau Trang.|||Bau Trang is divided into two lakes: Bau Ong and Bau Ba, separated by a sand dam. Bau Ba is also known as Bau Sen because of the lotus flowers that bloom around the lake in summer, covering the entire area.|||From a high hill, Bau Sen looks like a vast lake, approximately 70ha in size. The lake's water is deep blue, stretching 3km long, 500m wide, with an average depth of 5m and a maximum depth of 19m during the rainy season. The lake's ecosystem is rich, with many types of freshwater fish, including a 30kg grass carp. The north side of Bau Sen has a shaded eucalyptus forest, while the other three sides are vast white sand dunes. Bau Ong is smaller, about 23ha, and located near the sea.|||The water in Bau Trang is sweet and cool all year round, soothing the hot and dry air of the vast sand dunes. Here, visitors can rent a local boat to explore the lake, fish, admire the lotus flowers, and experience the romantic beauty of the lake amidst the white sand or rent a dune buggy to feel the thrill of crossing the rolling sand dunes.

title: Dinh Thay Thim
description: Dinh Thay Thim has existed for 138 years, built on December 25, 1879, located in a quiet oil forest on white sand, now in Tam Tan village, Tan Tien commune, La Gi town, about 12km northwest of the town center.|||Every year, Dinh Thay Thim holds two major festivals: the Tomb Sweeping Festival (5/1 lunar calendar) and the Autumn Festival (14-16/9 lunar calendar) to honor the beautiful culture of this land, and to recall the merits of the kind-hearted Taoist who helped people build boats, prescribe medicine, and tame wild animals… and was loved by the people in the region.|||In recent years, La Gi town has organized the Cultural and Tourism Festival of Dinh Thay Thim, combining it with the Autumn Festival, to promote the local tourism potential, with traditional rituals and cultural, sports, tourism, and charity activities bearing the distinctive mark of coastal folk culture.

title: Mui Ne Sand Dunes
description: Mui Ne Sand Dunes are located in ward 5, Mui Ne ward, Phan Thiet city. This is one of the longest sand dunes stretching for kilometers, spreading over an indefinite area with a large overall size.|||The most unique point of Mui Ne Sand Dunes is that after each strong wind or a day and night, the appearance of the sand dunes becomes completely new, different from its previous shape.|||The erosion of sand creates countless strange and wonderful shapes. When viewed up close, they seem to be within walking distance, but from a distance, they appear endless. This is why the golden sand dunes in Mui Ne are also called flying sand dunes.|||The color of the sand is also a point that attracts tourists to the flying sand dunes. The sand here has dozens of colors, mainly gold, ivory white, grayish white, dark red, light red... mixed together, looking very beautiful.

title: Ganh Son
description: Beyond the beautiful and charming city of Phan Thiet, Binh Thuan has many other attractive tourist spots that can captivate visitors. If you want to explore the beauty of this land, visit Ganh Son, a destination about 80 km from Phan Thiet city center.|||Ganh Son is located in Chi Cong commune, Tuy Phong district, Binh Thuan province, approximately 80 km north of Phan Thiet city. It features hills and rocky outcrops with a distinctive red color. The shapes of the mountains and rocks also display a variety of unusual and colorful forms.|||From the top of Ganh Son, you can see the entire scene of the bustling and cozy fishing village. The red of the rocks and the green of the sea blend together, creating a harmonious atmosphere that is both near and far, vague yet real...

title: Phan Thiet Water Tower
description: The Phan Thiet Water Tower was designed by architect Souphanuovong (later President of the Lao Democratic People's Republic).|||The Phan Thiet Water Tower was built from 1928 to 1934 to provide clean water for the French Governor's residence and the people of Phan Thiet. The tower is made of concrete and brick, standing 32m tall, divided into three parts. The lower part is an octagonal tower, 22m high with a base diameter of 10m. The top part, or water tank, is also octagonal, 5m high and 9m in diameter, decorated with ceramic pieces arranged in a circular pattern. The tower's roof has three layers of octagonal tile roofing.|||The tower has a capacity of 400 cubic meters of water. Its unique architecture features a decorative pattern with the words: Hoi, Phuc, Tho, Kiet, Loc, which symbolize happiness, prosperity, longevity, good fortune, and wealth. Over the years, the tower has inspired many writers, poets, photographers, and artists.|||After more than 70 years, the Phan Thiet Water Tower still stands proudly on the banks of the Cai Ty River, adding to the beauty of Phan Thiet city and witnessing the city's many changes.

title: Duc Thanh School Historical Site
description: The Duc Thanh school historical site is located at 39 Trung Nhi, Duc Nghia ward, Phan Thiet city. The school was built in 1907 with the name Duc Thanh meaning "Educating young generations to awaken national consciousness". At that time, it was considered a progressive school renowned everywhere. In 1910, on his way to find a way to save the country, patriot Nguyen Tat Thanh stopped and taught at this school.|||The school where Uncle Ho taught, over time, had deteriorated significantly, so it was restored. Today, visitors to Duc Thanh school will see the restored school with its original features (3 rows of desks and chairs, a blackboard...), Nha Ngu, Ngan Du Sao, Uncle Ho's jackfruit tree, a well and surrounding landscape arranged harmoniously, giving visitors the feeling that Uncle Ho's image is still here.|||The Duc Thanh historical site was ranked as a National Historical Site by the Ministry of Culture and Information in 1986.

title: Phu Vinh Ancient Village
description: Location: Phu Vinh Ancient Village is located in Vinh Thanh commune, Nha Trang city, Khanh Hoa province. Characteristics: With a history of over 200 years, Phu Vinh Ancient Village retains many ancient houses, bearing the distinct characteristics of Central Vietnam.|||Currently, the village has 6 ancient houses selected as tourist attractions, all situated along the curved road of Vinh Thanh commune. Notably, there is the nearly intact ancient house of Mr. Nguyen Xuan Hai (64 years old). This house has gone through six generations but remains largely unchanged. Mr. Hai's house is unique, nestled within a garden spanning over 4,000m². The house is built in three sections, with five annexes connected, featuring 36 wooden pillars. The ancient ambiance is preserved with old couplets, an altar, a worship cabinet, wooden pillars, and family utensils. The yin-yang tiles on the roof are over 200 years old, and the front yard still has a brick platform with ancient tiles laid six generations ago.|||Stepping into this well-preserved ancient house, visitors experience a fascinating journey through the past, untouched by artificial elements. Adjacent to the house is a fruit garden with various trees like rambutan, durian, longan, jackfruit, guava, and custard apple. Mr. Hai's garden also features two 100-year-old mai trees, which bloom with vibrant yellow flowers in the spring.|||Visiting Phu Vinh Ancient Village, tourists can take a horse-drawn carriage ride through the village. Nha Trang is one of the few places where horse-drawn carriages still exist, and Vinh Thanh is the only area where they can be found. The leisurely ride on an old carriage provides an authentic experience. The journey takes visitors to traditional weaving and incense-making sites, across a wooden bridge, offering a glimpse into rural life.|||In Phu Vinh Ancient Village, tourists embark on a serene journey through ancient houses, surrounded by the scent of straw, grass, and the sounds of chickens and buffalo. The village is devoid of vehicles and urban noise, with no high-rise buildings in sight. The sight of hedges made of dandelion flowers often surprises foreign visitors.

title: Ba Ho Stream
description: Ba Ho Stream is located 25km north of Nha Trang, originating from Hon Son peak, over 660m high, flowing between two mountain ranges down to Phu Huu village, Ninh Ich commune, and then pouring into Nha Phu lagoon.|||Ba Ho Stream is a fascinating natural wonder with cool streams and dense forests, making it an excellent spot for exploration. It's called Ba Ho because at the source, the stream widens into three consecutive lakes behind the mountain, creating a unique natural scenery. The stream has formed three large lakes, each with its own beauty and legendary stories passed down through generations. The first lake is about 1km from the second, and the second is 300-400m from the third.|||The first lake is the most accessible, being at the lowest altitude. During the rainy season, it features a beautiful waterfall, making it more attractive than the other lakes. However, in the dry season, the waterfall has less water, making it less interesting. Here, you can swim, play on the rocky outcrops with friends, and have a light meal after a tiring hike. The second lake is similar to the first but with murkier water. The scenery around it is quite charming, with a large tree providing shade, making it a suitable spot to rest, swim, and eat. This area is mainly visited by a small group of young locals, as it requires considerable effort to reach. Families or groups with elderly people and young children may find it difficult to get here.|||The hike from the second lake to the third is relatively short but challenging. Without a companion's support, it might be tough. However, the thrilling feeling when climbing up to the top of the stream is indescribable. At the third lake, you'll find very few visitors, mostly those who enjoy exploration and self-challenge.|||Ba Ho Stream is indeed an interesting trekking point; prepare your spirit and health well to explore the natural beauty amidst the mountains and forests, away from the hustle and bustle of city life.

title: Hoa Lan Stream
description: The Hoa Lan Stream Eco-Tourism Site is a famous tourist destination not to be missed when visiting Nha Trang. Here, tourists can enjoy the romantic beauty that nature has bestowed upon this place.|||Located about 30km from Nha Trang city center to the Northeast, the Hoa Lan Stream Eco-Tourism Site is situated on the Hon Heo Peninsula. Thanks to its geographical advantages, this site attracts many tourists, especially young people and foreign visitors, to come and explore during their Nha Trang trips.|||The first thing visitors can feel when coming here is the feeling of immersing themselves in nature with the fresh air of the mountains and forests, waterfalls. The site is named 'Hoa Lan Stream' because of a stream called Hoa Lan. The water in this stream comes from the mountain waterfalls, flowing through the rocks and then into the Nha Phu lagoon. The stream seems to be the lifeblood of the peninsula. Hoa Lan Stream is not only a place with stunning natural scenery but also a site preserving the remnants of the Cham people from ancient times, marking the event of a Cham king who once made a pilgrimage to Hoa Lan Stream. According to recent research and discoveries by an archaeological team, there are inscriptions on the rocks under the stream, which are believed to be the oldest Sanskrit inscriptions in Vietnam. Since being planned and invested as a tourist site, Hoa Lan Stream has welcomed thousands of domestic and international visitors to visit. Legend has it that this place used to have many colorful wild orchids, including many species such as Tu vu nu, Phuong hoang, Tai trau, Duoi soc, Duoi cho, Duoi ga, Tien nu, Que huong…|||Since being planned and invested as a tourist site, Hoa Lan Stream has welcomed thousands of domestic and international visitors to visit. Currently, Hoa Lan Island has over 100 species of orchids blooming all year round, An Binh beach stretching with white sand and golden sunshine; a garden of ostriches, deer, peacocks,... Along with accommodation services (resorts, collective houses, tents), entertainment services such as paintball, ostrich riding, elephant riding, photo shooting with elephants, snakes, bears, or water motorcycles, parasailing,...

title: Ta Gu Waterfall
description: Ta Gu is a small waterfall located in Son Hiep commune, Khanh Son district, Khanh Hoa province. It's a popular spot for young travelers to have fun, relax and set up camp.|||Ta Gu Waterfall offers visitors an exciting travel experience, exploring and admiring the beautiful nature. The waterfall is about 100km from Nha Trang city center. From Nha Trang, visitors can head towards Lam Dong province. At To Hop town, turn onto Provincial road 9 to Son Hiep commune to reach Ta Gu Waterfall.|||The waterfall is named Ta Gu because it's on the stream of Ta Gu river, originating from Hon Ba peak. It's also known as Nga Waterfall because from a distance, it looks like a pair of white elephant tusks. Ta Gu Waterfall has been chosen by Khanh Hoa province as one of its tourism symbols. Hidden in a vast primeval forest, visitors can hear the roar of the waterfall from afar. To get to the waterfall, visitors have to walk about 200m under the forest canopy, across a small stream and a large and deep lake. At the foot of the waterfall, visitors can still swim in the stream and waterfall during the hot summer. Next to the lake are many flat rocks and some large boulders. To reach the top and see the whole waterfall, visitors have to climb an additional 200m. Ta Gu Waterfall is over 40m high with a huge stream of water pouring down the standing cliff. The stream of water is divided into two parallel branches, looking like a girl's long hair. Standing near the waterfall, visitors can feel the cool and refreshing mist.|||Besides admiring the beauty of the waterfall, visitors can also learn about the Raglai ethnic group. They are one of the 54 ethnic groups in Vietnam, mainly living in Binh Thuan, Ninh Thuan and Khanh Hoa provinces. The Raglai people have many epic songs and mythological stories with historical and artistic values, including the legend of Ta Gu Waterfall's origin.|||On December 18, 2009, Ta Gu waterfall was ranked as a historical and cultural relic by the Khanh Hoa Provincial People's Committee, at decision No. 3286/QD-UBND.

title: Cam Ranh Bay
description: From Nha Trang city, follow National Highway 1 for over 40 km, then turn east, cross the majestic Long Ho bridge over Thuy Trieu lagoon to reach Cam Ranh.|||Cam Ranh covers approximately 100 km2, with a width of 5 to 6 kilometers, a bay depth of 15-20 m, and a length of nearly 15 km. With its advantages of being wide, deep, and sheltered (surrounded by mountains on all sides, with calm waters all year round), Cam Ranh can accommodate large ships of around 100,000 tons at the port and 200,000 tons at the bay entrance.|||The beauty of Cam Ranh Bay is famous for its stunning natural scenery, with mountains and sea combining to create a masterpiece. Cam Ranh was once bustling and lively but now is peaceful and calm. The town is vibrant, but at night, it is unusually quiet. Along the coast, there is a charming plain with emerging towns like Ba Ngoi, Da Bac, Bao Gieng, and the peninsula on the other side of the bay, including My Ca, Binh Ba, Vung Nom, and especially Thuy Trieu lagoon, which is very shallow and a breeding ground for blood clams. Thuy Trieu blood clams are famous and not inferior to those in O Loan lagoon (Phu Yen).|||If you visit Cam Ranh, you can take a 60-minute boat trip from Ba Ngoi port to Binh Ba island. Binh Ba is windy and wavy all year round, with a picturesque landscape, featuring Bai Nom - a bustling fishing village - living a peaceful life. The food here is diverse, with the most famous being Binh Ba lobster, caught and grilled on the spot, then enjoyed with friends and family over drinks. In addition, Cam Ranh Bay has snails, crabs, oysters, seaweed, squid, and various types of fish, plenty to enjoy, both affordable and delicious. Cam Ranh has much potential for economy and tourism. The scenic spots and famous sites around the bay are ready to welcome tourists, such as Kinh Beach (Binh Hung), Binh Lap, and Bai Nom - Binh Ba.

title: Baan Mern Community Tourism
description: Nestled among rolling hills and fields, Baan Mern (Thanh Nua commune, Dien Bien district, Dien Bien province) is known as an attractive community tourism destination, drawing many domestic and international visitors.|||From Dien Bien Phu City, following National Highway 12 about 6km to the north, visitors will arrive at Mern Village. From a distance, Mern Village looks like a beautiful painting with its back against the mountain and its front facing a vast expansive field. Standing out against the green backdrop of trees and sky are traditional stilt houses of the Black Thai people. The village not only captivates tourists with its stunning scenery but also offers a fresh, cool atmosphere and a clean, green, and beautiful environment.||||||The village has over 110 households with more than 500 people, all of whom are Black Thai ethnic people. The Black Thai people here live by growing rice, crops, raising livestock, and making traditional handicrafts such as weaving and embroidery.|||In recent years, local residents have joined hands to develop community tourism associated with building a civilized lifestyle, clean eating, clean living, and clean drinking. By following the correct approach to sustainable community tourism development, Ban Men village has become not only an attractive tourist destination for many domestic and international visitors but also a place where traditional cultural identities are preserved and promoted, including the weaving and embroidery of traditional fabrics. Previously, women in the village would weave and embroidery traditional fabrics only for their families, but now they also serve the needs of tourists. The village's traditional fabric products are typically pieces of fabric, Piêu scarves, or bags with the embroidered phrase "Ban Men traditional fabric - a souvenir" aimed at promoting the unique cultural nuances of the village to visitors.|||Along with weaving and embroidery, the Black Thai people here still preserve traditional stilt house architecture..., forming their own customs in daily life and production.|||Stilt houses are typically built with their back against a hill or mountain, and their front facing a river, stream, or field, following the principle of "mountain embracing and water gathering". The house is made of good wood, bam, bamboo or vau, with four tile roofs, of which the two roofs at the two ends of the house are built in a turtle shell shape. Notably, at the two ends of the roof ridge, there are two crossed wooden beams in the shape of an X called "khau cut" with many decorative patterns of young tree buds, crescent moon shapes... to both block the wind and express the beliefs of worshiping the moon and the buffalo of the Black Thai people. The stilt house has two floors. The upper floor is for the family's activities and receiving guests, while the lower floor is for storing looms, agricultural tools, wood, firewood... To ensure the stilt house meets the standards for serving tourists, the villagers have invested in building new facilities such as toilets, water tanks, and a cultural stilt house with traditional architecture for community activities. Additionally, to create an impression on tourists, Ban Mean village has established a food team of 10 people with experience in culinary preparation and an art team of 15 people with good singing voices, expressive performances, and beautiful dances.|||When visiting Ban Mern, besides admiring the distinctive natural scenery of the Northwest, tourists can experience daily activities with local people such as: making traditional dishes (rice wine, lam rice, grilled trout, bitter bamboo shoots, boiled buffalo meat with chamm cheo dipping sauce); taking care of livestock and poultry; going to the forest to collect firewood; going down to the stream to catch fish; weaving and embroidering ethnic textiles or participating in cultural activities (singing Thai folk songs, xoe dance, fan dance, sap jumping, blowing sao pi pap, pi o flute).|||With continuous efforts, Ban Men has consistently achieved the title of cultural village at the provincial level. It is also an attractive community tourism destination for both domestic and international tourists. This makes it a typical community tourism village in the development of economy and construction of cultural life in Dien Bien province.

title: C1 Hill
description: C1 Hill is one of the Eastern strongpoints in the central subsector, a shield that effectively formed the main defensive line to block enemies from the East and Northeast to attack the Dien Bien Phu fortress and Muong Thanh airfield - the French colonial trump card.|||Like most of the remaining strongpoints, the C1 Hill fortress, which the French named Eliane 1, was one of the strongpoints in the Eliane cluster, named after a beautiful French girl. C1 Fortress was located at an altitude of 493, among A1, D1, D3 strongpoints with a height of 50m and gentle slopes. Here, the French colonialists deployed Company 3, Battalion 1, Infantry Regiment 4 of Morocco to guard. In addition, there was the support of the 6th colonial parachute battalion, the 5th Nguyen battalion, and one company of the 8th shock parachute battalion, under the direct command of Bigeard, Deputy Commander of the Central Subsector.|||For the Vietnam People's Army, Battalion 215, Regiment 98, Division 316, led directly by Regiment Commander Vu Lang, was assigned the task of attacking and destroying strongpoint C1.|||C1 Hill is a strategically important stronghold. Capturing it would provide the Vietnamese People's Army with a foothold to advance to strongholds C2 and A1, posing a serious threat to the French forces on the eastern highlands. Therefore, both the Vietnamese People's Army and the French forces made efforts to consolidate their positions on this hill. The two sides engaged in 12 intense and protracted counterattacks, fiercely contesting every inch of land, every gun emplacement, and every stretch of trench, but neither could gain a decisive advantage.|||On 30 March 1954 at 5pm, the Vietnam People's Army launched the second attack on Dien Bien Phu stronghold.|||The Vietnamese army's artillery fired intensively at the Eastern hills, including hill C1.|||The 215th Battalion, 98th Regiment, 316th Division quickly approached the target, using explosive charges to clear a path through 7 layers of barbed wire.|||During the battle, comrade Vu Lang, commander of the 98th Regiment, called for the artillery to cease fire and seize the opportunity while the French forces were paralyzed.|||The battalion commander, Bui Huu Quan, ordered the infantry to charge.|||To organize an effective attack, company commander Le Van Di had the initiative to dig a 20m-long underground tunnel from the Vietnamese army's position to the French flagpole.|||From this tunnel, they captured bunker No. 3 and used it as a base to throw grenades at the French forces.|||With just one swift charge, after 10 minutes the 38th Company had captured the bunker on the hilltop. Team Leader Nguyen Thien Cai planted the "Decisive Fight, Decisive Victory" flag on the flagpole. The battle lasted 45 minutes, during which the Vietnam People's Army annihilated and captured the entire company of 140 French soldiers from the 1st Battalion, 4th Moroccan Infantry Regiment who were guarding it, temporarily taking control of outpost C1.|||At the Command Post, Colonel Vu Lang called and ordered Captain Le Van Di to pull back 200m down the hill, leaving only one platoon as a reserve for the Vietnamese artillery on Doi D hill to fire at the French battlefield before the 811 company charged. After consideration, Captain Le Van Di decided to pull back one reserve platoon 200m, while the rest of the unit still held their ground, reasoning that their well-built positions could withstand the artillery bombardment. If they retreated too far, they would lose the initiative and surprise, and the French artillery in Hong Cum would have time to fire and cause casualties to the Vietnamese army, while the French in C1 would have time to regroup and counterattack. On the night of May 1, 1954, after 32 days and nights of defensive fighting at outpost C1, the 98th Regiment of the 316th Division completely captured the high ground C1, paving the way for other units to attack and destroy the remaining outposts of the eastern wall. The bold and wise decisions of Captain Le Van Di contributed to the victory at outpost Doi C1, opening the way into the center of the Dien Bien Phu fortified complex.|||The C1 Hill relic is one of the component sites of the Special National Historical Site of the Dien Bien Phu Battlefield.|||It is a glorious testament to the great victory of the Vietnamese military and people during the resistance war against French colonialism. The victory at C1 Hill and other hills in the east during the second attack led to the Dien Bien Phu victory on May 7, 1954.|||Over 66 years later, the C1 Hill relic remains a resounding testament to the heroic Vietnamese military and people.

title: Doc Lap Hill
description: The Battle of Doc Lap Hill was a battle that took place at the hill of the same name during the first phase of the Dien Bien Phu Campaign. This was the second battle of the campaign, which took place from the night of March 14 to the early morning of March 15. After the battle, the Vietnamese People's Army gained full control of the hill, repelled the French counterattack, and nearly destroyed the northern subsector of the Dien Bien Phu stronghold.|||Independence Hill, located in the northeast of Dien Bien district's basin, belongs to Thanh Nua commune. Previously, Independence Hill was an important stronghold (named Gabrielle by French colonizers, after a beautiful French girl) part of the Dien Bien Phu fortified group of the French.|||With the task of defending the northeast, aiming to block the attack route of our forces from Lai Chau and protect Muong Thanh airport; here, the French army deployed many strong firepower and a battalion of elite soldiers who had fought and been undefeated in many places around the world.|||The Independance stronghold was proclaimed by French colonizers as one of the most impregnable fortresses.|||Mr. Quàng Văn Ky, 97 years old, from the Thai ethnic group in Na Ten village, Thanh Nua commune, shared: Before the French colonialists occupied Doc Lap hill, it was a lush forest with many large trees, 40-50cm in diameter. Every year, people from nearby villages such as Mern, Na Nom, and Na Ten would come here to perform rituals to worship their village and district according to their ethnic customs, praying for favorable weather, a good harvest, and the well-being of their community.|||However, during their occupation, the French army destroyed the forest to use the wood for building barracks, fortifications, and bunkers. When they ran out of materials, they would destroy villagers' homes to obtain wood. Furthermore, they forced people from nearby villages around Doc Lap hill to relocate to Mo village (in Thanh Nua commune), several kilometers away, as they suspected the locals of hiding Viet Minh members.|||On March 15, 1954, the 312th and 308th divisions of the Vietnam People's Army defeated and liberated the Doc Lap stronghold. After the historic Battle of Dien Bien Phu, Doc Lap hill was left in ruins, with the ground devastated by bombs and artillery, and a complex network of trenches, barbed wire, shells, and unexploded ordnance.|||In the years that followed, the site was managed by the government as part of the Dien Bien Phu Victory historical complex.|||Near the foot of Doc Lap hill, there are villages such as Men, Na Nom, Tong Khao, Na Ten... of the Thai people. Due to the impact of the old regime, most of the people were left poor, hungry, and illiterate. They only grew rice once a year with low yields, raised livestock and poultry under the house floor, and had superstitious beliefs.|||After peace was restored, the people of the villages around Doc Lap hill, as well as the Dien Bien region, united to heal the wounds of war, and competed to develop production. With the support of the government, schools, health stations, and Nam Rom irrigation works... were built to serve the people's lives. Bad customs and social evils were eliminated, and the new life of the people was revived and gradually improved on the land that was once devastated by bombs and shells.|||At the foot of the historic Independence hill lies a thriving village, now prosperous and affluent.|||Children go to school, and the village is illuminated at night with electric lights.|||The village has built schools, a healthcare center, a post office, a communal house, and residential houses... all modern and well-maintained facilities.|||Poverty and backwardness have been overcome, and the village is now a cultural one, where people enjoy a good life, and many households are striving to get rich.|||The former battle-scarred landscape is now a fertile field with multiple crops per year, yielding abundant harvests.|||The local rice has become a specialty, widely known and enjoyed across the country.|||A new life and a new vitality have come to this historic land.|||Independence Stronghold, a historic site of the great war, reminding future generations to uphold the tradition of heroic Dien Bien Phu, building a beautiful and prosperous homeland. This place has become a tourist destination for domestic and international visitors.

title: Pa Thom Cave
description: Dien Bien is known for its heroic historical pages and white ban flowers blooming in spring. This place also has a pristine beauty of Northwest mountains that is worth visiting once in a lifetime. Surrounded by a dense primeval forest, Pa Thom Cave has a pristine, mystical beauty and is associated with a legend about love during the creation of the world.|||At 1500m above sea level, the journey to Pa Thom Cave is quite challenging but also very interesting. From Dien Bien Phu city, go down to Dien Bien district on National Road 279 for about 10km, then turn right at Ban Phu Market to Noong Luong commune (Dien Bien district). Through the valleys with flowers and grass surrounding the villages, warm and familiar, you will reach the foot of a stone mountain covered with ancient forest, shrouded in mist and fog, full of primeval and mystical atmosphere. Crossing Nam Rom stream by raft, you will start an exciting mountain climbing journey. Up high with mist and fog covering the space, if you look closely, you can see the cave entrance appearing before your eyes. At this point, if you are not afraid of heights, try looking down at the foot of the mountain and you will surely be amazed to find yourself standing in a white cloud field under the sparkling sunlight, with Nam Rom stream winding and crystal clear.|||With its unique and majestic beauty, Pa Thom Cave surprises and delights visitors from the very first step. The cave entrance stands over 10m high and nearly 20m wide, featuring a massive stone elephant that has been here for tens of thousands of years.|||As you venture deeper, you'll be amazed by a 20m-long, shiny snake-like rock formation, as if it just emerged from the depths of the cave.|||To fully explore the cave, you'll need to walk through 9 arches.|||Since it's a natural, untouched cave, don't forget to bring a flashlight or candles for an authentic experience.|||The cave is filled with countless natural stalactites and stalagmites in unique shapes and vibrant colors.|||The sound of dripping water from afar adds a strange and captivating melody to the otherwise quiet cave.|||Coming to Pa Thom Cave, visitors not only admire the natural beauty of the land but also learn about a legendary love story that locals have passed down for over a thousand years. The story goes that one spring day, a prince was wandering along the Nam Nua stream when his hair got tangled with 7 strands of hair. As he continued upstream, he found a bathing area where 7 fairies were sleeping. The prince kissed the 7th fairy and confessed his love. The story reached the King of Heaven, who agreed to their union on the condition that the prince would prepare gifts within 7 days and 7 nights to express gratitude to heaven and earth. Unfortunately, on the final challenge, the prince's arrogance led him to touch the fairy, causing a loud explosion, landslides, and a strong wind that swept the fairy away. The prince chased after her, fighting a giant python guarding the cave entrance. After defeating the python, the prince found the fairy had flown back to heaven through a small passage. Overwhelmed with despair, the prince turned to stone, facing east towards the mountains, at the spot where they first met. The cave where the prince battled the python to meet the fairy is now Pa Thom Cave. Besides this oral tradition, locals and authorities have discovered an ancient bronze drum and many remnants of the past that archaeologists and locals have yet to uncover.|||A land tied to legends for thousands of years, Pa Thom cave, once a primitive and mysterious grotto, is increasingly affirming its position in the country's tourism industry, attracting a large number of visitors each year. If you're curious about this cave, why not pack your bags, gather your family and friends, and explore this natural wonder.

title: Xa Nhe Cave
description: The Xa Nhe cave, a national historical site, is located in Ban Bang De B, Sang Nhe commune, Tua Chua district, Dien Bien province.|||The cave has existed for millions of years at an altitude of over 1,500m above sea level, surrounded by a lush primeval forest with characteristic biodiversity of the Northwest region.|||In early March 2014, Xa Nhe cave was ranked as a national historical site by the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism.|||Xa Nhe Cave is also locally known as Kho Xo, which means 'explosive cave', because it used to be home to many bats, and locals would use their guano to make explosives. Over millions of years, natural geological movements have formed caves within the mountain ranges.|||Here, visitors can explore a 700m deep cave with an arched entrance, 5m wide and 17-18m high. The cave has a maximum width of 20-25m, with many nooks, levels, and a mostly clay floor. The cave is home to many bats and birds.|||As you venture deeper, the cave becomes more magnificent with intricate formations created by stalactites and stalagmites. Each chamber has a unique beauty, sparking curiosity and a passion for exploration.|||The cave is divided into five compartments, featuring various shapes resembling people and animals, such as toad, crocodile, shark mouth, and dragon... The ceiling of the cave is adorned with sparkling stalactites, showcasing soft and flowing lines like waterfalls, and sometimes sharp and pointed shapes like coral. The stalactites inside the cave appear like flowing waterfalls with countless sparkling crystals. The cave floor is covered with a forest of stalagmites and stalactites in diverse shapes and forms. The limestone terrain, fragmented and weathered, has been shaped by rainwater seeping through the rocks, leaving behind calcium deposits that form stalactites, stalagmites, and stone pillars. These formations create a unique landscape within the cave. Additionally, there are numerous stalactites hanging from the ceiling in layers, forming images of small ponds, rice terraces, and a gray-black stone tortoise statue. The cave floor resembles tiered rice fields, and some areas feature a chessboard-like pattern, surrounded by white, cone-shaped stalactites that resemble ancient castles.|||All 5 caverns boast enchanting beauty, making a strong impression and evoking powerful emotions in visitors. Standing inside the cave, guests feel as though they're in an ancient castle with grandiose yet romantic and dreamy architecture.|||Besides its scientific research value (geology, minerals, archaeology...), Xa Nhe cave holds tourism potential. The natural scenery around the cave remains pristine, with a rich ecosystem and primeval forests that attract visitors to explore, research, and experience.

title: Muong Tinh Cave
description: However, few people know about a revolutionary base that greatly contributed to the nation's glorious historical victory, which is Muong Tinh Cave located in Ban Trong village, Xa Dung commune, Dien Bien Dong district.|||From 1945 to 1954, many important revolutionary events took place here, contributing to the victory of Dien Bien Phu.|||After nearly 60 years, despite many changes, Muong Tinh Cave still retains its historical value, marking the heroic years of the past. Visitors can return to history, relive the nation's events, and experience the struggles of those who worked together to support the revolution.

title: Tham Pua Cave
description: Tham Pua Cave holds significant importance for many people in Northern Vietnam, serving as the starting point for the Tran Dinh campaign, another name for the Dien Bien Phu campaign led by General Vo Nguyen Giap. The cave is located at the foot of Pú Hồng Cáy limestone mountain, in Po village, Chien Dong commune, Tuan Giao district, Dien Bien province.|||Today, Tham Pua Cave is a beautiful limestone cave. Outside the cave is a spacious area over 100m2, with a high entrance, many stalactites, and a stream running through it. When sunlight shines through, it creates a shimmering, mystical scene.|||The cave's average width is about 3m, but some areas expand to tens of meters. Its length stretches hundreds of meters, with many side passages and interconnected caverns. In front of the cave, two ancient cay trees and a lush primeval forest thrive. At the foot of Pu Kien mountain range lies a vast field with a clear water source.|||Historically, Chien Sinh commune was home to the Thai and Mong ethnic groups; however, in recent years, Kinh people have also settled there. During the 1954 Dien Bien Phu campaign, Tham Pua Cave, along with Tham Poong Han cave, served as the headquarters for General Vo Nguyen Giap, who led the campaign.|||After national reunification, Tham Pua Cave has become a tourist destination, helping younger generations remember the glorious victories of their predecessors. Upon visiting, you'll be captivated by its pristine beauty. Local authorities and businesses have developed infrastructure to facilitate travel and sightseeing for visitors.

title: Muang Ne Nature Reserve
description: Muang Ne Nature Reserve in Dien Bien is considered one of Vietnam's largest nature reserves, boasting high biodiversity and rich forest ecosystems, making it an attractive destination for nature exploration.|||The reserve covers approximately 45,581 hectares, with 25,679.08 hectares designated as strictly protected, 19,888.42 hectares for ecological restoration, and 32.8 hectares for administrative services. The buffer zone spans 124,381 hectares, home to several highland ethnic groups such as the Ha Nhi, Khmu, and Mong, with distinct cultural identities.|||The reserve features a tropical monsoon climate with characteristics of a highland tropical climate, with two distinct seasons: a rainy season from April to October and a dry season from November to March. The terrain is complex, with a high degree of slope, and two main river systems (Nam Ma and Nam Ne) that are the headwaters of the Da River.|||The reserve is home to many primeval forests, including lowland evergreen forests, low-mountain evergreen forests, high-mountain evergreen forests, and bamboo forests, which are being preserved intact. The forest flora is diverse, with 740 species documented, including 35 rare and precious plant species, 29 of which are listed in Vietnam's Red Book and the World Red Book.|||The reserve is also a habitat for many rare and precious animal species, with 291 species documented, including 55 endemic species and 45 listed in Vietnam's Red Book, such as the Asiatic black bear, sun bear, and silver langur.|||Visiting Muang Ne Nature Reserve offers an opportunity to immerse oneself in pristine nature, challenge oneself with adventures like stream wading, forest trekking, and mountain climbing. From a high vantage point, the scenery unfolds like a vibrant painting, with green forests, golden flowers, and red soil roads, alongside traditional houses and villages scattered throughout.|||Additionally, visitors can conquer the 0 A Pa Chrai milestone, the westernmost point of Vietnam, and participate in the A Pa Chrai border gate market on the 3rd, 13th, and 23rd of each month.

title: Hua Pe Hot Spring
description: Hua Pe hot spring is a beautiful spot not to be missed during the 2.9 National Independence Day holiday. After days of stressful work, what could be more wonderful than finding a place to relax and unwind?|||Located 5km northwest of Dien Bien city center, Hua Pe hot spring is in Thanh Luong commune, Dien Bien district. The road to Hua Pe hot spring is actually not difficult.|||However, Dien Bien has a challenging terrain that can be difficult to navigate. The steep slopes and winding mountain passes pose a significant challenge. If traveling by motorbike, visitors need to have steady hands to avoid potential dangers.|||Nature has gifted Hua Pe hot spring with an abundant source of water. The spring water maintains a consistent temperature of 60°C and is rich in valuable minerals.|||In addition to the hot spring, the Pe Luong artificial hot water lake with year-round breezes has been formed.|||This place has become a very attractive eco-tourism destination for both domestic and international tourists. Moreover, Hua Pe mineral spring has not been exploited like professional tourism services.|||This is an ideal destination for tourists looking to relax. Soaking in hot mineral water is a therapy that helps improve health, especially for musculoskeletal and neurological conditions. Not only that, visitors can also unwind and relieve stress while taking a mineral bath.|||Hua Pe mineral spring water has a high safety level, very good for human health. This has been tested and evaluated by the Institute of Medicine. Therefore, local people also use this mineral spring water in their daily lives.|||In addition, Hua Pe mineral spring contains many special things, such as being drinkable. The hot spring water is rich in nutrients that help detoxify the body and supplement essential minerals.|||Travelers often share that there are many hot springs, but Hua Pe is the only one that's drinkable. So, when traveling here, don't forget to try a sip of the spring water. After soaking in the hot mineral water, visitors can explore and admire the surrounding scenery. The feeling of immersing oneself in peaceful nature is truly wonderful!|||Hua Pe hot mineral spring has been replanned to better serve tourists with a mineral spring bath lake, large swimming pool, double swimming pool…|||Additionally, water recreational activities are also developing. Certainly, in the near future, this place will be an attractive tourist destination in Dien Bien province.|||Especially, tourists can't miss unique Dien Bien specialties. A typical dish to try is Black Chicken from Tua Chua. This is a black-boned chicken breed endemic to the H'mong people. The H'mong call it Ka Du. Ka Du is entirely black in appearance, with black bones. The chicken meat is very fragrant, delicious, and firm.|||Muang Thanh sticky rice with a sweet fragrance, cooked from glutinous rice. The bird meat is rich and tender. Sprinkle some golden fried shallots on top, the flavor of this specialty is unforgettable.|||Wrapped cabbage with green starfruit is also a must-try dish - a very popular one for those who love sour flavors. The starfruit must be green, juicy, and lightly coated with a white powder. The cabbage leaves should be neither too old nor too young. This dish is typically enjoyed with chamm cheo - a legendary condiment from Northwest Vietnam.

title: Thanh Ban Phu
description: The Thanh Ban Phu relic is located in Noong Het commune, Dien Bien district, Dien Bien province, built from 1758 to 1762, covering over 80 mau, leaning against the Nam Rom river; the base is 15m wide, the top is 5m wide, 15m high; the wall is made of earth, planted with thorny bamboo brought from Western Thanh Hoa, with a deep and wide moat of 4-5 thuoc.|||There's a legend that elephants and horses could walk on the city's walls. The city has four gates: front, back, left, and right.|||In the 18th century, after leading a peasant uprising against the Le - Trinh dynasty in what is now Thai Binh, general Hoang Cong Chat brought his troops to the Northwest region.|||He allied with local generals Ngan and Khanh to defeat the invading Phe army, liberating Muong Thanh land.|||To commemorate his great merits, at Ban Phu citadel, the people built a temple dedicated to Hoang Cong Chat, the leader who fought against the Phe invaders and protected Muong village.|||Today, although no longer as grand as it once was, the Thanh Ban Phu relic has been restored with a section of the wall for visitors to imagine the ancient citadel in all its majesty and grandeur, a military architectural work that guards the border region. From the watchtower, visitors can admire the landscape of the entire area with low-rise stilt houses hidden behind green bamboo groves and stretching fields. Inside the citadel is a cultural stilt house that can accommodate hundreds of people, on either side of the wall are stone-paved lotus ponds and a system of brick paths and wide yards for cultural, festive, recreational and sports activities. At the center of the temple is an ancient tree known as the 'solidarity tree' by the locals. It has a single root, but consists of 3 harmonious trees - a ficus, a banyan and a crape myrtle - intertwined, shading the entire temple grounds.|||Legend has it that this ancient tree was planted by leader Hoang Cong Chat and two Thai leaders, General Ngai and General Khanh. Despite going through many historical ups and downs, the ancient tree remains firm, symbolizing the spirit of unity between the Thai, Kinh and other ethnic groups in Muong Thanh land, representing the solidarity between lowland and highland regions.|||Next to the ancient tree is the temple dedicated to Hoang Cong Chat and his generals. This is a place for visitors to offer incense, express their devotion and pray for peace and good fortune…|||Over the years, the Thanh Ban Phu relic - temple of Hoang Cong Chat has been gradually preserved, protected and restored, meeting the demand for historical and cultural exploration of visitors from and outside the province. Notably, the Hoang Cong Chat temple festival was recognized as a national intangible heritage by the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism in 2015. The festival takes place on the 24th and 25th of the 2nd lunar month (the anniversary of Hoang Cong Chat's death) and is considered the most important event of the year at the temple.|||The ceremonial part of the Hoang Cong Chat temple festival takes place with great solemnity and respect, featuring sacred rituals that have been preserved and passed down through generations. The festival begins with a palanquin procession and a reenactment of history, depicting General Hoang Cong Chat and his generals Ngai and Khanh defeating the Phe invaders and liberating Muong Thanh:|||For the souls of the deceased|||Ethnic groups unite|||Love each other like siblings in harmony|||The gourd fruit, ancient drill holes|||Attached forever like glue...|||(Excerpt from the ceremonial oration on festival day)|||Right after the ceremonial part, the atmosphere becomes vibrant and dynamic with various cultural and artistic activities and traditional folk games of the ethnic groups. The atmosphere is truly lively with many performances such as traditional costume shows, singing and dancing, folk games like tug-of-war, sack racing, blindfolded duck catching…. Besides, visitors can enjoy ethnic dishes or buy local products like brocades, wickerwork, souvenirs…

title: Muang Luan Tower
description: Muang Luan Tower is an architectural work of art with valuable sightseeing and research significance, located in Muang Luan village, Muang Luan commune, Dien Bien Dong district, Dien Bien province. From Dien Bien Phu city, following National Route 279 southward, to Pom Lot junction, turn left to Na Sang, pass Keo Lom slope (wind slope), Lu Stream and then straight to Muang Luan village, about 90 km away.|||Muang Luan Tower is located at the beginning of the village, under Hua Ta mountain (source mountain). The tower is constructed in a square shape, large at the bottom and smaller at the top, with a 1m high base, each side being 5.50m, without decorative patterns, plastered with a layer of mortar from bottom to top to create a stylized lotus tower, with 6 layers stacked on top of each other. The entire 15m high Muang Luan Tower is arranged and decorated into two parts. The tower body from the base up has many smooth round shoulders, stacked on top of each other, combined with engraved and relief patterns depicting stylized birds, flowers and leaves in harmony. Notably, a prominent feature is a raised dragon running around the tower body, forming a double eight shape. All four sides of the tower show five pairs of dragons, giving the tower a majestic appearance, both sturdy and durable.|||The second part of the tower has two layers and a spire. The faces of each layer are not decorated with patterns but plastered with mortar, lime sand and honey. Each construction is expanded in the middle, with two tapered ends like a diamond shape. At the junction of each layer, patterns and motifs are decorated, made of burnt clay such as bird heads, lotus petals, leaves and sun shapes. The decorative motifs are connected to each other to create a harmonious graphic, with a tight layout. Inside the lotus petals, swords have small mirrors attached. Especially, the sun shape attached to the four sides of the tower also has mirrors attached to shine in four directions when the sunlight hits. The connection between the second layer and the spire is also decorated like the first and second layers but smaller to create a gentle, soft beauty. The red color of the burnt clay of the decorative motifs, mixed with white, brown and black gray, makes the tower more ancient, standing out against the deep green background of the Northwest mountains.|||Muang Luan Tower like a gentle, elegant girl standing quietly reflecting on the clear Ma River…This is a work of art representing the unity of ethnic groups, and the construction of the tower also shows the long-standing Vietnam-Laos friendship.

title: Muang Phang Cherry Garden
description: Many domestic and international tourists when visiting Dien Bien have known about Muang Phang as the headquarters of the Vietnamese army during the historic Dien Bien Phu battle "Luminous across five continents, shaking the earth". However, few people know that on an island in the middle of Pa Khoang lake, Muang Phang commune, there is a cherry blossom garden currently in bloom, marking the friendship between Vietnam and Japan.|||The appearance of cherry blossoms in Dien Bien is also quite interesting. Mr. Tran Le, 66 years old, Director of Muang Phang Forestry and Technology Joint Stock Company, the owner of this "Flower Island", tells the story: Previously, he was acquainted with a Japanese partner in economic relations on processing and exporting agricultural products. Since he knew Mr. Le was a biology researcher, his Japanese partner gave him 10 cherry blossom seeds to grow in Vietnam. Although his company has many branches in several provinces, he decided to bring the seeds to Muang Phang to test the growth because the soil conditions here are quite suitable, and also because this is a historical land with much significance. With 10 seeds, from 2006 he grew 9 trees, of which his Japanese partner took back 5. The remaining 4 trees were planted on "Flower Island", and after 3 years, they started to bloom and bear fruit.|||However, since they were grown from seeds, the flowers have changed and no longer retain their original color. From these initial trees, Mr. Le grew 500 more trees which are currently planted in the garden, of which 40 trees from the first batch are now blooming. With 5 hectares of land assigned to him, Mr. Tran Le plans to cover the entire "cherry blossom island" in the middle of Pa Khoang lake. In addition, Mr. Le gave the Dien Bien Provincial Department of Agriculture nearly 600 seedlings to propagate to other districts in the province. Not only growing and propagating cherry blossoms, Muang Phang Forestry and Technology Joint Stock Company is currently growing and researching over 40 other flower species, including a fresh red lily that has not been found anywhere else in the world, and is planning to name it "Muang Phang Lily".

title: Rang Beach
description: Rang Beach (Tam Quang commune, Nui Thanh district, Quang Nam province) offers a tranquil beauty, still largely untouched by human development. It's an interesting spot for travelers to visit after leaving the noise of the city behind, and a cool place to stay and escape the heat of summer.|||Located about 2km from Chu Lai airport, Rang Beach stretches along the road from Ky Ha port to Dung Quat oil refinery (Quang Ngai province). The natural scenery here remains pristine, with rocky shores, turquoise sea water, and fresh air, making it ideal for relaxation and tourism.|||Although Rang Beach has been known for a long time and is a popular destination for travelers during the summer, tourism development in the area has been limited, so it doesn't have the same level of noise and activity as other beaches.|||The sunrise over Rang Beach is a breathtaking sight that attracts tourists and photographers alike. During the summer, the sun usually rises between 5am and 6am. In the early morning, locals gather on the beach for exercise, take a refreshing dip, and fishermen head out to sea in their boats. Fresh seafood, including fish, squid, and shrimp, is sold directly on the beach.|||The beach also features large rocks and stones stacked on top of each other, creating a unique landscape. Standing on these rocks, visitors can gaze out at the vast sea and see boats and fishing baskets dotting the water.|||There are family-run restaurants scattered along the beach road, as well as small shacks on the sand, serving fresh seafood dishes. After a swim, visitors can enjoy grilled fish, lobster, steamed squid, and other local specialties under the wind-swept shacks.|||In addition to enjoying the beach, visitors can buy local specialties like fish sauce, seaweed, and abalone wine as gifts, as well as fresh seafood like squid, lobster, and fish.

title: Huynh Thuc Khang Memorial House
description: This is a national historical and cultural relic, located in village 1, Tien Canh commune, Tien Phuoc district, Quang Nam province, about 35 km west of Tam Ky city.|||Mr. Huynh Thuc Khang was born in 1876 in Thanh Binh village, Tien Phuoc district, a smart and studious person, a patriot. He passed the Doctorate exam in 1904 and led the Duy Tan movement in Central Vietnam in 1908, but was arrested by the French and sent to Con Dao prison. In 1927, after his release from prison, he founded the Tieng Dan newspaper to propagate the national struggle. After the August 1945 revolution succeeded, Mr. Huynh was invited by President Ho Chi Minh to be the Minister of Home Affairs and later served as Acting President. He passed away in 1947 in Quang Ngai while on a trip to Central Vietnam.|||The Huynh Thuc Khang Memorial House is an old house in a large garden with an area of nearly 4000m2 built by his family in 1869, following the common architecture of the Nguyen dynasty. The house has 3 rooms, tile roof, wooden frame with intricate carvings. The overall architecture bears the mark of Nguyen dynasty style with curved lines and carved patterns.|||The memorial house has been restored and upgraded several times and is not only a national historical site but also a 'red address' for young people to learn about their traditions and follow their ancestors' aspirations.

title: The Monument Complex of the Heroic Vietnamese Mother
description: Located about 7 km from Tam Ky city, on the top of Cam Mountain, Phu Thanh village, Tam Phu commune, Tam Ky city, Quang Nam province. The Monument to the Heroic Vietnamese Mother is situated next to many other attractions, with a natural setting close to the majestic mountains and forests, attracting many visitors from afar.|||The complex covers an area of 15 hectares on the top of Cam Mountain. As you enter from the outside, you will see on both sides the front square with 8 tall pillars depicting the symbolic images of Northern mothers, gentle and kind; Central mothers, strong-willed and diligent; Western Highland mothers, though not full, still dedicating every corn kernel to the soldiers; and Southern mothers, steadfast and unyielding…|||The main statue is based on the image of the heroic Vietnamese mother Nguyen Thi Thu in Dien Thang commune, Dien Ban district, Quang Nam province. The 18.5m-high monument is made of sandstone, with the statue blocks made of granite, stretching 120m along the arc. The portrait of mother Thu is carved with simple, rustic features, a gentle beauty, welcoming her children into her arms.|||On both sides of the main statue are rock walls formed from natural stone blocks, arranged skillfully and smoothly like the notes of a symphony. The rising and falling notes seem to symbolize the hard and bitter years of the children.|||In front of the monument is a large lake over 1000m2. Inside the granite block in the shape of an arc is a museum within the mother, covering 400m2, including display and preservation rooms. This is where the heroic Vietnamese mothers are honored, along with images, films, and documents about their lives during the fierce years and their selfless dedication to Vietnam.
