Many believe that the sacred power of the Mother Goddess helped the Tran army win against the Mongols in many naval battles in the Northeast. The temple once housed many statues, including a large, lifelike statue of the Mother Goddess in white attire, known as Bach Ngoc Thuy Tinh, whose piercing eyes seemed to follow you wherever you stood. In front of the temple stood two statues with sharp, intimidating eyes that nobody dared approach in the late afternoon. There were also statues of five high-ranking officials, a girl, and a boy outside. Over time, the temple has been rebuilt multiple times, and when Cai Lan Port was constructed, the temple was relocated to a higher area, resulting in the loss of many ancient artifacts. In 1986, a large number of ancient coins and artifacts were discovered in the old temple area, indicating that many pilgrims had visited and made offerings in the past. However, all signs have since been altered, and the grounds have been leveled, making it impossible to pinpoint the exact location of these ancient relics. In 2009, a new pagoda was built beside the temple within the Cai Lan Port area.|||

title: Loi Am Pagoda and Yen Lap Lake Relic Complex
description: Loi Am Pagoda is an ancient pagoda built in the 15th century (during the Le Thanh Tong era), set amidst a picturesque landscape with a harmonious blend of mountains and water, topped by Loi Am Mountain, featuring a natural 'heavenly chessboard' at its peak, standing 503m high, offering a panoramic view of the Northeast region, rivaling that of Tan Vien and Tam Dao.|||Yen Lap Lake was constructed in 1976, combining beautifully with the surrounding landscape to create a scenic spot. The Loi Am Pagoda - Yen Lap Lake historical relic complex has formed a romantic landscape, famous since ancient times, and now even more renowned for attracting tourists interested in cultural, spiritual, and ecological tourism.

title: Tung Sau Pearl Farm
description: Tung Sau boasts stunning scenery and calm seas. It's home to a pearl farming and processing area operated by Ha Long Pearl Joint Stock Company, a product being developed as part of Quang Ninh's tourism product development plan. The company's processing, display, and sales area has been recognized as a standard restaurant.

title: Quang La Flower Paradise
description: The eco-tourism site 'Quang La Flower Paradise' is part of the 'Fruit Tree Garden and Eco-Tourism' project in Quang La commune, approved by the Hoanh Bo District People's Committee in Decision No. 926/QD-UBND on June 1, 2015. The project is implemented in two phases. Currently, phase 1 of the project has been completed, including: planting fruit trees in combination with medicinal plants; a multicolored flower field; building a workshop for preliminary processing of medicinal herbs, a net house for plant breeding; forming a medicinal herb maze, a coconut tree house and a bar, a cafe on the tree serving visitors. Tourists can experience gardening, harvesting medicinal herbs, processing medicinal herbs; fishing; soaking feet in herbal medicine... eating traditional dishes; playing traditional folk games (stick pushing, con throwing, archery, tug of war, sack jumping...)|||'Quang La Flower Paradise' was built on the idea of 'A harmony between nature and life'. Where agricultural production activities, value-added agricultural product processing activities will become a tourism product, a place where visitors can experience and immerse themselves in nature.|||In addition, the 'Quang La Flower Paradise' tourist site is also adjacent to Bang Ca commune, which has the Dao Thanh Y Bang Ca cultural heritage preservation area. The Dao Thanh Y people there still preserve the valuable traditional cultural capital such as: village festivals, Sắc Ceremony; embroidery and traditional costume making; folk medicine; folk songs and dances...); there is a folk club operating regularly, effectively with many folk artists who are knowledgeable about traditional culture.

title: Thanh Y Dao Ethnic Cultural Conservation Village
description: The Thanh Y Dao Ethnic Cultural Conservation Village is a unique cultural preservation project in Quang Ninh Province, invested by the Department of Culture, Sports, and Tourism.|||The village has a population of 138 households, all of whom are Dao Thanh Y ethnic people. The villagers have preserved their traditional cultural heritage, including festivals, rituals, and intangible cultural values such as embroidery, traditional medicine, culinary arts, and folk music and dance. The village also has a folk club with many skilled artisans, including four who have been recognized as Vietnamese Folk Artisans.|||The village is home to many traditional Dao Thanh Y dishes, such as five-color sticky rice, khe snails, khe fish, ginger-cooked chicken, and Bau wine. Many farms in the area grow organic fruit trees and raise wild animals like porcupines, wild boars, and local chickens. The village is also located in the center of the traditional Bau wine production area, a unique drink of the Dao Thanh Y people.|||During the two resistance wars against the French and American colonizers, Bang Ca Commune was an important resistance base, and in 2008, it was recognized as a provincial historical relic.|||The Thanh Y Dao Ethnic Cultural Conservation Village project has been invested with over 15 billion VND, featuring a community house, two model houses of the Dao Thanh Y people, a festival ground, and a 7-room exhibition house showcasing traditional culture, adjacent to the historical site of the resistance base against the French.

title: Man Mountain Scenic Complex
description: Man Mountain, historically known as 'Bân Sơn' meaning harmony and perfection, is a stunning natural wonder. The name 'Bân' signifies a beautiful and complete mountain, both inside and out, with the Mân River flowing through it, earning it the local name 'Mân' or 'Mằn' due to a pronunciation variation.|||The Man Mountain scenic complex is steeped in thousands of years of history and legend, reflecting the deep cultural and spiritual life of the local people through stories like the giant who shouldered rocks to mend the sky, the sacred Bạch Thạch temple, the origins of the quýt lú garden, the story of the mountain with a mouth, and the tales of Ông Cộc, Ông Loang, and Ông Dài. Notably, Man Mountain was a crucial military location in the feudal era, serving as a signal reception and transmission point from Bài Thơ Mountain and Xích Thổ (Nhà Mạc) Citadel for offensive and defensive strategies, especially during the Trịnh-Mạc conflict in the northeastern region.|||Man Mountain is situated between two streams, the Đá Trắng (Bạch Thạch Khe) and the Lưỡng Kỳ (Khe Bân), which flow into the Đá Trắng River, creating a breathtaking landscape with lush vegetation and a unique harmony of mountain and water. This is also the most beautiful limestone mountain, uniquely preserved in the Cửa Lục Gulf area, part of the Ha Long Bay World Heritage site.|||Man Mountain exemplifies the limestone mountain system of Hoành Bồ District, standing over 400m above sea level with steep cliffs, treacherous gorges, and a varied landscape of square, round, smooth, and pointed formations, resembling a kneeling elephant with its trunk bowed towards the Khe Bân stream.|||At the foot of Man Mountain, the Bạch Thạch Temple was built by locals to worship various deities, including Cao Sơn Thượng Đẳng thần, Quý Minh Thượng Đẳng thần, Đại Càn Quốc gia Nam hải, and Đệ nhị Long Vương thượng đẳng thần. In addition to the deities worshiped at Bạch Thạch Temple, Hoành Bồ District is home to a system of temples and shrines related to Man Mountain and Bạch Thạch Temple, scattered across Thống Nhất Commune, Đồng Lâm Commune, and Trới Town, including the shrines of Ông Cộc, Ông Loang, Ông Dài, Thánh Mẫu Shrine, and Xích Thổ Temple. These shrines are closely linked to Bạch Thạch Temple and Man Mountain through captivating legends and divine stories, leaving behind three shrines that worship the three sons of the Man Mountain deity (Ông Cộc, Ông Loang, Ông Dài).|||The shrines of Ông Cộc (Trới Town, Zone 9), Ông Loang (Cài Village, Đồng Lâm Commune), and Ông Dài are located at the confluence of the Bạch Thạch and Bân streams before they flow into the Cửa Lục River.|||Beyond its natural beauty, Man Mountain holds significant cultural and spiritual value. It is connected to the legend of 'The Giant Who Shouldered Rocks to Mend the Sky'.
